column2: Playing their helter-skelter game, which has strangely become an art form, the New York Generals Churned their way to a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Toros yesterday.
Sophisticated racegoers and holiday visitors alike reacted similarly to a masterly showing by Ogden Phipps's Buck passer at Aqueduct yesterday.

THE many-sided emotional experience of the American fighting man in Vietnam--speechless sorrow over the loss of comrades, elation over mail from home, the unremitting hardships of combat in the jungle and the passing ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 The Vesper Boat Club, the Olympic champion in 1964 at Tokyo, won the senior eightoared race in the Independence Day Rowing Regatta in the Schuylkill today and the Philadelphia club carried off the team honors for the Anthony Gallagher Memorial Trophy with a total of 515 points.

A 46-year-old employe of a West Side fish company was fatally stabbed early yesterday. The man, who was apparently attacked while he was on his way to work, was found on the sidewalk at Ninth Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets.
that he expected to remain in home "for some time" for work on church ecumenical matters.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 4--The bodies of seven persons killed in the crashes of two light planes were found today in the Catskills near Kingston and Ellenville.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 Mrs. Billie Jean King, the defending champion, marshaled all her power of serve and volley to overcome Virginia Wade of Britain, 7-5, 6-2, in 50 minutes today as three Americans battled into the women's singles semi-finals of the Wimbledon tennis tournament.

GREAT NECR, L.I., July 4 Miss Tanya Kreizman, daughter of Mrs. Leo Kreizman of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Mr. Kreizman, was married this afternoon to Ronald Arthur Cowers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cowen of Middle Village, Queens.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)--Climax II, owned by August Muckler of St. Louis, won the $56,300 Stars and Stripes Handicap for the second consecutive year at Arlington Park today.
A spokesman for Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that City Hall would give minute study to the Transit Authority's new record operating budget to determine its possible effect on municipal finances.
BUDAPEST Have your face slapped in Budapest. It will make you look better. Especially if Mrs. Erzsebet Szenal Brodi smacks it.
The Boeing Company has announced plans to increase the gross weight of its 747 jumbo jet by 4 per cent, or a maximum of 15 tons by mid1971.
There'll be a new breed of space representatives calling on the agencies this week.
The Staten Island Ferry is changing the style of what its well-dressed passenger in peril will wear.
DENVER, July 4 District Attorney Bert M. Keating, one of the most popular political figures in this city's history, died at Rose Memorial Hospital here today of lung cancer. He was 63 Years old.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 4 The retiring executive secretary of the National Education Association clashed with his successor today over the issue of teacher strikes as the organization's annual convention went into its third day here.

BRASILIA, July 4(Reuters) Brazil Federal Supreme Court has received a request from West Germany for the preventive arrest and extradition of Hitler's former deputy, Martin Bormann, court officials said today.
MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)--Premier Aleksei N. kosygin declared last night that the positions of France and the Soviet Union were close together on the Vietnamese and Middle Eastern questions.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 A United Nations Secretary General Thant was continuing his efforts to free two Guinean diplomats who have been detained in Abidjan by the Ivory Coast.

THE HAGUE, July 4 Foreign Secretary George Brown set forth in a 3,800-word major policy declaration today the terms that Britain will seek in her Common Market application and the political goals she hopes to achieve in a wider Europe.

MOSCOW, July 4 Yuri Grigoravich is the most talented Russian choreographer since Mikhail Fokine and Fedodor Lopukhov, and it is one of the most hopeful aspects of the contemporary soviet ballet scene that he is director of the Bolshoi company.

New Jersey's signature on the Mid Atlantic States Air Pollution Control Compact is by far the most encouraging, recent development in the fluctuating battle against this menace. If Congress speedily approves the agreement, which New York has already signed, it will bring into existence the nation's first interstate agency in the fight for clean air.
Weakness in British Government bonds and industrial issues marked trading on the London stock market yesterday.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 4 (UPI)--Harry S. Truman reviewed a Fourth of July parade that passed his home today.

NASHVILLE, July 4 Negro Leaders ultimately must confront and subdue the black power movement if they are to maintain their influence in the community, Dr. Herman. E. Long, president of Talladega College in Alabama, said here today.
World Airways, Inc., has announced the appointment of Ralph Sacks as regional vice president for sales in the Eastern United States.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 4 (UPI) Roman Catholic bishops in Texas have sided with the Texas Council of Churches in a lawsuit against Texas Rangers and other law enforcement officers.
WHEATON, Ill., July 4 (AP) An open housing ordinance was adopted last night by Wheaton, a city seven miles west of the site chosen for the world's largest atomic accelerator at Weston.
ALGIERS, July 4--Attorney General Alidor Kabeya of the Congo arrived here today to discuss with Algerian officials the extradition of the former Congolese Premier, Moise Tshombe.

Richard Blumhagen and his wife, Barbara, recently moved into a six-bedroom house in Schenectady, N.Y., so they would have more room to accommodate their summer guests. Their guests are five children, who live with then 77-year-old grandmother in a depressed section of Queens.
The patriotic pealing of bells and barrages of outlawed firecrackers greeted Independence Day in the city and the suburbs yesterday.
Donald Reinstein quit his job, canceled plans for a three-week vacation in Munich, spent $670 for a ticket to Israel, and had $50 left in the bank.
BUENOS AIRES, July 4 Bolivia has asked Argentina to send ground troops into Bolivian territory to help fight guerrillas said to be operating near the two nations' frontier.
Warm, seasonal weather offset several days of heavy rainfall during June to give New York's leading department stores a substantial gain in sales over last year.
A substantial improvement in the United States balance of trade this year was forecast yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

BERLIN, July 4 For the second year in succession a Polish director won first prize in Berlin's annual film festival when the Golden Bear was awarded today to Jerzy Skolimowski for his comedy "Le Depart" ("The Start").
Charles G. Moerdler, one of the youngest and post flamboyant members of the Lindsay administration, will resign today as Buildings Commissioner.

ALMOST all the bridgeplaying countries of the world have at least one opportunity annually to take part in international competition. But for India, South Africa, Australia and some others, distance from the scene of action is a major factor.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 Cale Yarborough, a 29-yearold racing driver from Charlotte, N.C." won the annual Firecracker 400 before a crowd of 48,400 here today.
The Police Athletic League will unveil a vehicle called a Palmotive at 11:45 A.M. today at Borough Hall, Brooklyn, as part of a major educational program, "Exploring Negro Heritage."

The city's $15-million appropriation for its own model cities program and nearly $100-million in school improvements are among the programs that have been picked by Mayor Lindsay for top priority in capital spending for fiscal 1967-68.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 Cries of anguish from property owners were echoing in California today, with the loudest coming from San Franciscans.
The Port of London Authority has announced that the new Knock John Channel in the estuarial approaches to the Thames and the Port of London is now open.

MOSCOW'S effort to cover its Middle East defeat and that of the Arabs with a General Assembly Victory has failed. The idea that the United Nations should permit the Arab states to maintain belligerency while calling on Israel to withdraw its troops simply did not appeal to most countries as being either just or likely to win Israeli compliance.
BOSTON, July 4 Power returned early this morning to the many areas of Cape Cod that were blacked out at 5:29 P.M. yesterday by a break in a 115,000-Volt transmission line in West Barastable.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 4 A paneled, carpeted courtroom will soon be a permanent fixture here on the ground of Pilgrim State Mental Hospital. The courtroom, described as the first to be built in a state hospital solely to hear the legal problems of the mentally ill,will be ready for use this ...

WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich., July 4 (AP) A Wealthy, elderly farmer was shot to death and his sister was wounded last night by four intruders who ransacked their home and shot them while they were tied to chairs.
A teacher group opposing they United Federation of Teachers agreed yesterday with its union rival that the Board of Education's new pay proposals were "ridiculous."

New York City's claim to a higher credit rating for its marketable debt has been strongly reinforced by its budgetary performance in the fiscal year that ended last month. For the second successive year the city managed to balance its books without tapping its reserve funds or resorting to dubious borrowing practices.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 Sources close to Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh said tonight that he would not return to South Vietnam unless given Permission by the Government.

Business activity may be turning up but the recession now taking place in corporate profits is likely to continue for some time to come. This conclusion is held by forecast ers who predict a rapid business resurgence as well as by those who foresee a relatively modest rise.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 4 A Congtregational minister charged today that "Mount Vernon is controlled by a vicious group of gangsters" Who he said are acting "through their servants in City Hall, on the police force, on the school board and is both major political parties:"

AMMAN, Jordan, July 4 The chief Jordanian economic planner said today that his Government hoped Palestiaians who had fled across the Jordan River from the Israeli-occupied west bank could return there.

WASHINGTON, July 4 Senator Robert F. Kennedy, following months of study and consultation with leaders in in- dustry and the universities, has completed and will soon present in the Senate two major proposals for an attack on slum problems.
ATLANTA, July 4 (UPI) A scaffold supporting spectators at a "salute to America" parade collapsed today, injuring 25 of 30 persons who fell eight feet to the ground.

Moise Tshombe, former premier of the Congo and previously leader of the rebellious Katanga Province, has fallen into the hands of bitter enemies the Algerians. This is one suspicious aspect of his sensational kidnapping in the sky while on a flight during which his chartered plane was seized and taken to a military airbase near Algiers.

TOKYO, July 4 An Irish tenor from Teaneck, N.J., who specializes in lugubrious Japanese folk ballads sung to the accompaniment of a native flute called the shakuhachi, is the current sensation of Japanese show business.
Columbia, Md., a new town being developed on a 14,000acre tract in Howard County, midway between Baltimore and Washington, has attracted its first industrial facility.

A few big museums in outlying metropolitan areas will serve the growing suburban public better than a spreading scatter of small museums, the Regional Plan Association has concluded after a survey of museum attendance.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 4 The New York Yankees tonight bought Steve Barber from the Baltimore Orioles.
A 70-year-old woman was found dead yesterday after firemen put out a fire in a five-story brownstone house at 9 West 32d Steeet, near Fifth Avenue.
NEW DELHI, July 4 (Reuters) Children danced in the muddy streets of hundreds of North Indian towns and villages today as long-awaited monsoon rains poured down.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 4 Mr. and Mrs. Elmer W. Van Horn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Van Horn, to George Alexander Piroumoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Piroumoff of New York and Craftsbury Common, Vt.
LONDON, July 4 The House of Commons, after sitting through the night to overcome a threatened filibuster, voted today to approve the long-argued bill to reform Brit- ish law on homosexual conduct.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 4 Mickey Mantle hit two home runs today and became the fifth ranking home run hitter in baseball history. But the Minnesota Twins still won their sixth and seventh straight games by defeating the New York Yankees in a day-and night program, 8-3 and 7-6.
City inspectors, posing as tourists have found that some drivers of horse-drawn carriages in Central Park have been billing passengers up to four times the legal rate.
The first financial report of the Franklin National Bank since its merger with the Federation Bank and Trust Company showed yesterday combined total assets of $2,333,281,200 as of June 30.
Death is a magnet that quickly draws gypsies together from their dispersion.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 Stanley Dancer, the renowned harness horseman and squire of Never Egypt, N.J., has had under his charge such outstanding trotters as Noble Victory, Egyptian Candor and Worth Seein', among others. It might be, though, that Nevle Pride...

ROCHESTER, July 4 Erwin R. Davenport, founder with the late Frank E. Gannett of the Gannett group of newspapers and broadcasting stations died today at his home in Miami Beach, according to word received here. He was 91 years old.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., July 4 An appeal on behalf of former Premier Tshombe, sent to President Houari Boumediene of Algeria, was made public here today by Robert Morris, president of the University of Plano in Texas.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 4--A movement to foster international understanding through "sonides" has sprang up here under the leadership of a retired builder.

TEL AVIV, July 4 An Egyptian MIG jet plane was re- [ ported to have been shot down by Israeli antiaircraft fire over the Gulf of Suez today. According to a communique issued here late today, two Egyptian fighter planes, both Soviet-supplied MIG-19's, penetrated the airspace above Israeli-occupied Sinai at 2:55 P.M.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 Following is the text of a resolution on Jerusalem and a resolution on humanitarian considerations, adopted today by the General Assembly:
DIAMOND POINT, N.Y., July 4 The Lake George Park Com mission, which is proud of the area's nearly perfect air and pure water, is worried about another type of pollution Visual Pollution.
The overseas push by American hotel chains, which started in the late nineteen-fifties, is now attracting a growing number of diverse companies.

Always sensitive to the symbolic, the New York Mets used July 4 for a modest declaration of independence of their own yesterday by beating Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants for the first time, 8-7.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 4 (UPI) The Patriotic party, headed by the Minuteman leader, Robert Bolivar DePugh, nominated today former Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace as its Presidential candidate for 1968 contingent upon Mr. Wallace's approval of the party's choice for second man on the ticket.
FIERY RUN, Va., July 4 President Johnson says we should forget about the "good old days" and "count our blessings," and while this is two cliches in one sentence, he has a point.

UNTIL Hank Luisetti arrived on the scene in whirlwind fashion about three decades ago, basketball was dominated by the Celtics not the Boston Celtics, but the Original Celtics. They formed the first of the great professional teams in that ancient era when the play-for-pay phase of the come-on an extra added attraction.
"I almost feel like a pioneer. I would say that I'm unusual then I started, there were very few women C.P.A's here,' said Mary. E. Beniteau in a recent interview.

LONDON, July 4 Britain's foreign-exchange reserves fell by 43-million ($120.4-million) in June, apparently as a resuit of factors connected with the war in the Middle East. The total is now 1,012,000,000 (S2.83-billion).

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Adm. William M. Fechteler, former Chief of Allied forces in Southern Europe and former Chief of Naval Operations, died in Bethesda Naval Hospital this attack. He was 71 years old and had resided in Washington since his retiremen in 1956.
The city shut down its independent Office of Civil Defense yesterday and promoted into a new, permanent job the man who had disassembled the old defense unit.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 3 North Korea has mounted an elaborate infiltration program preparing for possible guerrilla warfare in the South, according to intelligence sources here.

DRAINAGE INCREASED AT TENNESSEE DAM LAWRENCEBURD, Tenn., July 4 (UPI) A lake held by a leaking earthen dam was being drained at a rate of 90,000 gallons a minute today to reduce the threat that the dam would break and inundate three small communities.

ASHVILLE, Ohio, July 4 At 11 o'clock this morning, a cherry bomb exploded, the thousands of people lining the streets held their breath as the distant drums rolled out their steady, staccato rat-a-tat-tat, and the big parade began.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 4 For the last year, the expressions of resentment from Suffolk's East End over court-mandated reapportionment have stopped short of the vow "the East shall rise again."
In his reply to Senator Kennedy of Massachusetts Secretary of Defense McNamara failed to meet the central issue of the Government-subsidized national rifle matches.
Although, for political reasons, the Soviet presidium has started to rearm the shattered Arab states, it is logical to assume that Soviet economists and Soviet Marshals are arguing for caution.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 5 North Vietnamese gunners fired more than 300 rocket and mortar shells during eight attacks on Marine positions at Conthien and Dongha, near the demilitarized zone, last night and early this morning, a United States spokesman said.

CONTHIEN, South Vietnam, July 4 Pledged to recover the bodies of comrades who died in bitter fighting Sunday, two battalions of United States marines pushed forward slowly today against stubborn North Vietnamese resistance less than a mile from the demilitarized zone.
LAKE GENEVA, Wis., July 4 (AP)--An enforced peace prevailed today in this Southern Wisconsin resort community after a weekend of vandalism and disorder by teen-agers.
BONN, July 4 A round-up of at Least 14 South Koreans resident in West Germany by secret policemen sent specially from Seoul led to a protest by the Bonn Government today.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board reluctantly abandoned today its prohibition against management lockouts of employes in non-strike situations.
HINGHAM, Mass., July 4 (UPI) Walter Elliot, a 39-yearold construction worker, today became the third man in a week to set sail alone across the Atlantic.

PARIS, July 4 In dingy offices annd dim halls, a revolution has begun here. It aims at a great leap forward in French musical life that will affect both provincial classooms, where children sing their scales, and they concert halls of Paris, Where this fall Charles Munch will begin welding 110 musicians into what France hopes will become her first symphony orchestra of international renown.

Investors returned from the long Independence Day holiday weekend in a buying mood yesterday.
Wometco Enterprises, Inc., which operates a chain of television stations, achieved record sales and earnings in the 12 and 24 weeks ended June 17, it was announced yesterday in Miami.
The first of more than 600 abandoned Brooklyn tenements began to topple yesterday as Mayor Lindsay helped start a citywide slum demolition program in the Brownsville-East New York section.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)--Navy figures show drug usage among sailors has insreased, with the rate of discharges because of Drugs this year more than double that of last year. The hallucinogenic drug LSD has ben involved in....
WASHINGTON, July 5--The State Department was preparing today to evacuate American dependents from Bukavu, where dissident army units were reported to have seized control from the Congolese army.

CLEVELAND, July 5--Three Democrats filled today to oppose Mayor Ralph S. Locher in the party primary Oct. 3. Two Republicans will run against each other in their primary, to be held the same day, with the winner in each party meet-....

Five "distinguished senior American writers" will get awards of $10,000 apiece from to National Endowment for the Arts. The writers, all poets and critics are Kenneth Patchen, Yvor Winters, John crowe Ransom, Louise Bogan and Mal-... colm Cowley.
George C. Scott has undertaken three assignments for the new season, all for Saint Subber.
AWHOPPING rise in merger switch in the wherewithall to stock in the majority of cases characterize consolidation in the first six months of 1967.

Residents of the United States Virgin Islands have contributed $1,200 in medical supplies and drugs to the rebellious Caribbean island of Anguilla. . . ..

ALBANY, July 5--The first drawing for prizes in the state lottery will be held in three stages, starting here July 20 and ending in New York City July 24 and July 26, State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. MurPhy announced today.

DETROIT, July 5--The Big Three automobile manufacturers have been meeting secretly for more than a year to build a united front against the new contract demands of the United Automobile Workers, it was learned today.
An 18-year-old gunman, attempting to hold up a Brooklyn furniture store, was shot, dead yesterday by a store employe he had just shot in the head.

Richard Tucker, the Metropolitan Opera tenor, doesn't sing in the shower at the Glen Oaks Country Club. He wouldn't dare, lest he usurp the prerogatives of Rubin Levine, another member and a close friend. Recently, when Mr. Tucker boomed out a few phrases from La Gioconda when the cold water hit him, Ruby Levine shouted:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 5 (UPI)--A pilot who mistook Ohio State University's airport for Port Columbus was grounded today by Trans World Airlines.

Cowles Communications, Inc., publisher of The Suffolk Sun, and the International Typographical Union have been ordered to discontinue a collective bargaining agreement opposed by the National Labor Relations Board.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5--It will be John Newcombe against Wilhelm Bungert for the Wimbledon tennis title. The big Australian, charging to the net behind his blazing serve, won from Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia, 9-7, 4-6, 6-4, in 2 hours today.
"Routine trading" was the general rule in the nation's commodity exchanges after the holiday yesterday.

The New York State Athletic Commission announced plans yesterday for its own tournament to select a world heavyweight champion. The local group had withdrawn its recognition of Cassius Clay when the champion refused induction into the military service of the United States on April 28
ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP)-- Chico Ruiz doubled, stole-third and scored on Nelson Briles's wild pitch in the 10th inning to give the Cincinnati Reds a 2-1 victory tonight over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) --A Federal Bureau of Investigation agent shot and critically wounded a parole violator today after the fugitive held him and another agent captive for more than two hours.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 (AP)--The North Vietnamese are using a new Soviet-made weapon, the RPG7 antitank gun, in their effort to wrest northern territory of South Vietnam from the hands of United States Matines.
OTTAWA, July 5--A radiant Queen Elizabeth ended today her visit to Canada to celebrate the country's centennial.
SANTA FE, N.M., July 5 (UPI)--The "most dangerous" of the raiders who shot up a county courthouse in an attempt to claim ancient land grants was in jail today.

There is a serious gap in the procedures governing shipment of radioactive materials--especially radium --within and between states. For the third time in less than a year a national hunt is on to find lost radium that, in the hands of a child or an unsuspecting adult, could cause burns that might result in cancer.
Short-term interest rates continued to rise yesterday as the Treasury sold $4-billion of bills maturing next March and April. long-team interest rates declined slightly.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 5 --a Communist defendant told the special military tribunal here today that "since I disagree with the present Government, I know I will be sentenced to death."

Tatsure Goto, the newly named president of Mitsui Co. (U.S.A.), Inc., predicted here yesterday that the giant trading company's sales volume in this country would reach $1billion a year "within 12 months."

William T. Diamond, the city's Deputy Commissioner of Buildings, was named Acting Commissioner yesterday as Charles G. Moerdler formally resigned.
The domestic commercial airlines spent $5-million last year to replace lost baggage and deliver misdirected baggage to passengers according to the Air Transport Association.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) --A Federal Judge made permanent today an injunction barring Girard College, a private school for male orphans, from denying admission to Negroes solely because of their race.
New York may have its Rheingold Central Park Music Festival but in the San Francisco area it's Music at the Vineyards.

Yellow bulldozers, red cranes, green trucks and pale blue drilling and excavation rigs dot the eight blocks in the western half of the World Trade Center site as work an the $575-million project accelerates.
Mayor Lindsay proposed yesterday that the head of the state's new transportation operating authority enter all talks involving rapid transit in the city.

MIAMI, July 5 (UPI)--A Government lawyer charged today that a witness at a deportation hearing for Felipe Rivero, a Cuban exile leader, had been threatened with death in an effort to keep him from testifying.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)--A union official said today that a Johnson Administration proposal to build United States merchant ships in foreign countries would hurt the nation's economy and jeopardize defense needs.

Mayor Lindsay, replying to a teachers' union bid to help in contract negotiations, declared yesterday that "we don't have a money-making machine." He asserted that his margin for teacher pay rises in the budget had been re-...

The Allstate Insurance Company, in a radical departure from industry practice, has expanded its guarantee to automobile policyholders: All clauses in their policies will be renewed for five years, no matter how many claims are filed.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 5 (AP)--A wildcat strike developed at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company tonight and threatened to become a full-scale walkout tomorrow morning-- the first in the company's history.

The Ogden Corporation and the Susquehanna Corporation, two major diversified companies, are competing in efforts to acquire the Atlantic Research Corporation, a sophisticated engineering research organization for aerospace, electronics and other fields.
TRENTON, July 5--A policeman does not need the traditional type of courtroom evidence to stop and search a suspicious person, the State Supreme Court said today in a unanimous ruling.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 5-- With a plea for more state aid for harness racing, George Morton Levy Sr. was inducted today into the Hall of Fame of the Trotter. There were dignitaries on hand in this bucolic cradle of the standardbred as a likeness of Levy was unveiled.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of William G. Stott as an executive vice president.

PRAGUE, July 3--The state of artistic freedom in Czechoslovakia and the dominant role of the Communist party in cultural life were strongly criticized at a stormy congress of Czechoslovak writers here last week.

WAYNE.Pa., July 5--Mrs. Elsa McDonald Davis, the wife of Bancroft G. Davis, vice pressident of the Madison Fund, Inc., a New York investment trust, died yesterday in the Bryn Mawr Hospital of leukemia. She was 42 years old.
AUGUSTA, Ga., July 5 (UPI)--A former convict has been named the new president of the Georgia Prison Wardens Association.

An 18-year-old runway girl confronted by a with a choice of six month in jail or resumption of life with her parents in Brooklyn, ignored the counsel of her hippie friends in-Criminal Court yesterday and chose home.

The business of managing other people's money may not lack hands, but it often is in need of skill, time and patience. To provide these, many banks offer the relatively little-known service of custody accounts.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4--The wife of Vu Hanh visited the National Police prison once again today, but returned home after an hour without seeing her husband, a well-known writer.

Wayne M. Hoffman, the 44year-old executive vice president of the New York Central Railroad, has decided to spread his wings. He is resigning as the so-called heir apparent at the Central to become chairman of Flying Tiger Line, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 5--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara asserted today that the department's cost reduction progtram realized savings of nearly $1-billion during the fiscal year just ended.

TOKYO, July 5 (Reuters)-- The Japanese Finance Ministry has prohibited further purchases by foreign investors of shares in the Sony Corporation for fear of foreign control of the electronics concern, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 5--The chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee said today that he saw "no compelling reasons for an immediate tax increase".
A Bronx woman lay wounded on a kitchen floor for about eight hours yesterday after she apparently had been shot by a rejected boyfriend who then
The appointment of Don C. Miller as a vice president was announced yesterday in providence R.I., by Textron, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company.
A State Supreme Court referee rejected yesterday charges by General Motors of collusion between Ralph Nader, the auto safety critic, and Vincent Gillen, a former investigator for the company.

Applications for working papers an the city in June were up 41 per cent over the corresponding month last year, Warren. J. Feulner, coordinator of employment certification, said yesterday. More than 55,000 children applied.
ATHENS, July 5--The Greek tourist organization denounced tonight as an "anti-Greek slander campaign" report that the Greek revolutionary regime had imposed censorship on Greek theaters.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 5--President Joseph D. Mobutu closed the Congo's frontiers today and asked African countries for military aid to repel "foreign aggression" in two eastern provinces:
Broadway's financial picture "is not as dark as has been painted," Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 5--A computer in Washington studied human hearts beating in France and relayed the analyses back to the bedsides almost instantly today via communications satellite.
CINCINNATI, July 5--William C. Wichman, the City Manager, ordered the police today to "use all the methods known to you to suppress lawlessness".

A State Supreme Court justice reserved decision yesterday on a move by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith to stop an American-Italian group from using the words "anti-defamation league" in its name.
WAHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) --The Federal Trade Commission moved today to halt deceptive advertisting claims over which aspirin is better or faster. It said they were all about the same.

At Vifla del Mar in Chile--so far away in terms of the current preoccupations of Washington--a twoweek conference of the Inter-American Economic and Social Council (IA-ECOSOC) has recently ended. It was important to Latin America, now beginning the long, long road to a hemispheric common market. It was marginal to the United States, because the Middle East and Vietnam bulk larger today than Chile and Brazil.
Soviet-built surface-to-air missile crashed back to earth south of Haiphong yesterday, setting an entire village afire.

PRINCETON, N.J. July 5-- Two psychologists at Pinceton University reported today that their studies of tenrecs--small furry animals with sharp quills on their backs--have ended with virtually noting positive to report.

Prices closed in a narrow range on the London stock market yesterday. In the absence of selling pressure, like that of the day before, the market was considered to have a steadier trend.

The bombers had caused the landslides earlier with the air of monsoon rains.

Britain's first detailed statement of its negotiating proposals should advance the effort to push past France into the Common Market. The directors of the Federal space science program pleaded yesterday for continued financial support to exploit the use of space for the improvement of life on earth.

Louis Cassels, Washington newspaperman and religion editor of United Press International, received the Supple Memorial Award of the Religious Newswriters Association last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 7--Two Strategic Air Command B-52 bombers collided today and crashed into the South China Sea off the Mekong Delta, a United States military command spokesman announced.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 6--Max H. Schmid, an international industrialist who had business interests in Germany, Austria, Canada and the United States, died Tuesday here at his home on Rippowan Road. He had been in ill health since he suffered a heart attack a year ago. He was 76 years old.

It now appears probable that the Constitutional Convention will propose to lower the voting age to eighteen from 21, where it has been ever since the state's first Constitution was adopted in 1777. If this change were effected, the voting rolls would be enlarged by nearly a million inexperienced and immature voters--which is one reason why some politicians who are particularly popular with youth are in favor of it.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 6 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Bachert of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen E. Bachert, to John L. Sipos, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sipos of Carle Place, L.I.
Twelve of the nation's large chain store organizations achieved sharply higher sales in June, according to reports made yesterday.
ELATH, Israel, July 6 (AP)-- Israel is pouring millions of dollars into this sweltering little Red Sea port to build a trade route to rival the Suez Canal.

The Gorham Corporation, a household name in silverware for some 135 years, will be acquired by Textron, Inc., in a tax-free exchange of stock valued currently at $32million, the two Providence, R.I., companies announced yesterday. Trading in Gorham stock on the American Stock Exchange was delayed pending the acquisition news. On its opening sale, the price zoomed 20 1/8 points to 60.

Although the sessions and personal encounters of the International Threater Institute's congress in New York last month were valuable on many levels to those who took part, there was a residue of unanswered questions.

PITTSBURGH, July 6--The United States Steel Corporation expects steel shipments to pick up considerably in the last three months of 1967, but not before, Edwin H. Gott, president, said here today.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) --Robert E. Lee, a Republican who has been a member of the Federal Communications Commission for the last 14 years, said today he had resigned to enter private industry.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Brown of York, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Jay John Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Murray Jr. of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Michael Mayer performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner).

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 6--The black-and-orange duffelbag with the Baltimore Orioles' monogram looked strange in the New York Yankees locker room--as strange as the man who owned it, Stephen David Barber.

Fourteen shipping lines engaged in the coffee trade from Brazil are again embroiled in a dispute that threatens the breakup of four steamship conferences, executives of various lines stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6--In his foreign policy review in Chicago this week Secretary of State Rusk said President Johnson was "deeply intent on trying to improve our relations with the Soviet Union," but the diplomtic reports out of Moscow and elsewhere are extreme ly discouraging on this question.

READING about Lolita's sexual excursion along America's billboarded, blotchy highways was one thing, but, for Norman Sunshine, taking the weekend round trip from the city to Bucks County, Pa., "was like reading Vladimir Nabokov over and over and over."
PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 6-- Suffolk County's first publicly financed family planning pro gram will soon get underway in 12 centers extending from the eastern farm camps to the western suburbs.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6 (UPI) --The touring professionals patched up temporarily today a quarrel with the Professional Golfers' Association but served notice their compromise, agreement assured peace only for the remainder of the 1967 season.
FREEPORT, the Bahamas, July 6--Sir Stafford Sands, the multimillionaire government official named as a consultant to gambling operators is these islands, has declared himself a nonresident.
A Negro surgeon has charged that a policy of racial discrimination at Harlem Hospital caused his replacement as a section chief last week by a white doctor.
WASHINGTON, July 6--Attorney General Ramsey Clark has issued sweeping new regulations forbidding all wiretapping and virtually all eavesdropping by Federal agents except in national security cases.
TEL AVIV, July 6--The torpedoes were ready for firing when our three Israeli torpedo boats zeroed on the gray ship moving slowly on a southeasterly course off El Arish.

Today's Greek dictatorship shocks Americans, who are keenly wedded to democratic ideals and who regard Greece as democracy's mother. They forget that Greece is also the mother of monarchy (monarchia), demagogy (demagogia), anarchy (anarchia), tyranny (tyrannis) and despotism (despotes).
WASHINGTON, July 6--The Labor Department is doubling its efforts to help the hard core unemployed with a $52million program that will provide job opportunities for 34,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The Administration's $10-billion underestimate last year of the cost of the war in Vietnam caused "havoc" in the economy and "the same dreary cycle of events threatens again in 1967," the Congressional Joint Economic Committee charged today.

The huge shareholder family of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company absorbed a paper loss of more than $800-million yesterday in the wake of a Federal Communications Commission cutback on the company's permissible rate of return on investment.
ALBANY, July 6--A Constitutional Convention committee today sent the question of lowering the voting age to 18 to the convention floor, but without a recommendation for approval.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 6 (Reuters)--Nigerian oil production and exports to Europe were threatened with almost total stoppage today by a government decision to extend its naval blockade of the Eastern Region to include tankers.
The Women's City Club reported yesterday that many apartment buildings in the Bellevue South urban-renewal area hed deteriorated markedly after the city took them over.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 6-- Ethiopian language instructors engaged in a Peace Corps training program at the University of Utah returned to classroom duties today.
Electronic box-offices for the sale of reserved seats to theater and sporting events were opened yesterday at three Gimbels stores in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, July 6--France's withdrawal from the BritishFrench V-G military aircraft project, with its devastating effect on British defense planning, is only the latest in a series of French moves damaging to this country's interests.

MIAMI BEACH, July 7-- Thomas P. Smith, who retired in 1944 as assistant commissioner of borough works of Brooklyn and held many other New York City posts, including that of deputy controller, died here yesterday. He was 84 years old and had made his home here in recent years.

YONKERS, July 6--A blanket could have covered the first four finishers in the Bye Bye Byrd Pace, the one-mile invitation pace that topped tonight's harness racing card at Yonkers Raceway. And first under that mantle, as he was under the wire, would have been the 4year-old Good Time Boy.
JERUSALEM, July 6--Thousands of religious Jews demonstrated here today against what they charged was the Arab desecration of holy places in the sector of the city formerly held by Jordan.
The nation's commodity futures markets continued to lack sparkle yesterday.
An Old-Timers Game of staggering youthfulness is the feature of this weekend at Shea Stadium, where the New York Mets will entertain the Atlanta Braves tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 6--The National Education Association today deplored de facto segregation in large cities and approved a policy calling for "bold experimentation" with student busing, educational parks and metropolitan area school districts.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, continued to outperform its field with increases in both sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter, ended May 27. Its results were announced yesterday. Nearly all the food chains have shown lower figures, generally reflecting higher operating costs.
Park Commissioner August Heckscher was scolded yesterday in a court opinion that held he had displayed "substantial lack of compassion" in imposing a "harshly excessive" penalty on a park employe.
The nation's commercial banking system has just come through a confusing and difficult week in which it had to contend with the Fourth of July holiday and a $4-billion Treasury financing.

BUFFALO, July 6--About 200 Negroes and a few whites from Build, an amalgamation of 143 Negro groups here, demonstrated at City Hall today and later at the Chamber of Commerce and demanded that 3,500 permanent jobs be made available for Negroes in the city.

Herman Shumlin, director or producer of such hits as "Grand Hotel," "The Corn Is Green" and "The Little Foxes," has turned to playwriting for the first time. He has dramatized part of Peter De Vries's "Reuben, Reuben." The novel was published in 1964 by Little, Brown.

The fragility of the British economic and military position has once again been underscored by France's abandonment of a joint Anglo-French project--an advanced swing-wing aircraft for the mid-190 period.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, July 6--The most impressive display of Israeli air power since June 5 was put on today over the Negev. Fighters, trainers and transports streaked across the cloudless desert sky in celebration of Israel's military victory and in honor of her dead.
WASHINGTON, July 6--A proposal by the National Education Association that states be given free rein in spending Federal school aid funds was criticized in several quarters here today.

Late yesterday afternoon a band of unhappy teen-age boys walked down a teeming play street--113th Street between Eighth and Manhattan Avenues--and confronted a Police Athletic League official with their problem.
WASHINGTON, July 6--A Congressional subcommittee has charged that $1.3-billion worth of housing projects insured by the Federal Government is in financial difficulty.
British Government bonds dropped to new lows for the year on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

The New York Hanseatic Corporation, underwriter and distributor of investment securities, announced yesterday the election as senior vice presidents of Timothy P. Donovan, Herbert B. Jones and William S. Mason Jr.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 6--The annual outdoor Clothesline Art Sale will take place at the Guild Hall on Saturday from l0 A.M. to 6 P.M.
The Information Center in Times Square will open a display next week designed to promote the idea that New York is a synonym for Film City.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 6--The Rev. Martin Duffy, who charged Tuesday that "Mount Vernon is run by a vicious group of gangsters," said today that someone in a car tried to run down his wife and daughter last night.

Louis Sherry at Philharmonic Hall, 64th Street and Broadway. PL 3-0200. The captain of Louis Sherry at Philharmonic Hall knew a thing or two when he extended the dessert order and announced: "Now you come to the best part of the meal."

To find the world's best player, few authorities would look beyond the Italian Blue Team, which has now won ten world titles. Some years ago Pietro Forquet of Naples would have been the general choice, but nowadays there would be many votes for his partner, Benito Garozzo of Rome, or for Giorgio Belladonna, also of Rome.

HOUSTON, July 6 (UPI)--Eddie Mathews's two-run single capped a three-run first inning off Ferguson Jenkins tonight that sent the second-place Chicago Cubs reeling to their fourth straight defeat as the Houston Astros chalked up a 4-3 victory.

Although the City Council killed Mayor Lindsay's plan for Little City Halls in all the boroughs, the underlying concept is sound: to enable New Yorkers to bring local problems to the corner "storefront" instead of trying to Go-Fight-City-Hall itself. The concept has extra meaning in the summer, when people and problems move into the streets.
A dispute over architectural fees has slowed construction of the new Bellevue Hospital and threatened a shutdown that could cost the city millions of dollars.
With the Metropolitian Opera House in back, Philharmonic Hall at the side, the quartet on the little wagon on Lincoln Center Plaza struck a new note at cocktail time yesterday.
The stock market closed on the fence yesterday, with price advances and declines on the New York Stock Exchange in almost even balance.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6--The representative of the Congo charged in the Security Council today that foreign mercenaries recruited in Western Europe were being used in an attempt to keep the Congolese President, Joseph D. Mobutu, from carrying out a progressive reform program.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 6--A pair of 22-year-old amateurs, John Baldwin and Jeffrey Alpert, scored a best ball of 67 today and led 103 other teams in the annual John G. Anderson memorial golf tournament.

LAKEIVILLE, Conn., July 6 --Frank R. Kelly, a shotgun champion and captain of the All-American Skeet Team in the nineteen-thirties, died yesterday in the Sharon Hospital of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and had been ill for some time. He made his home here and also in Casey Key, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) --The antipoverty agency says there is no evidence to support the charge by Gov. Lurleen Wallace that there is a link between a Negro farmers' cooperative in Alabama and "violent 'black power'" activities in the state.

A massive search by the police and Federal agents for a 4-yearold boy who vanished at Coney Island on the Fourth of July was ended last night when the child was found alive and unharmed in the home of a 54year-old Brooklyn widow.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)-- the 16th Medal of Honor to be awarded during the Vietnam War went today to an Army sergeant who died while charging an enemy machinegun position.

UNTIED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6--The Pakistani delega tion denied today a report that it had been prepared to accept a United States compromise resolution on Jerusalem but that Jordan had rejected the compromise, which, consequently, had not been submitted to the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, July 6--Intercity, truck tonnage in the week ended July 1 was 5.5 per cent below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
The Cartwrights will be getting a new cowhand and some fresh scenery for the Ponderosa next season, their ninth on the National Broadcasting Company's popular Western series,
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 6 (UPI)--A report summarizing the problems of the Apollo moonship listed new areas of trouble today.

CHICAGO, July (AP)-- Paul Blair blasted a solo homer in the first and singled across another run in the third in pacing the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-1 victory over the firstplace Chicago White Sox today.
ALGIERS, July 6--The Algerian Goverciment today again made no formal announcement on the fate of former Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo, who has been held a virtual prisoner here since Friday.

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 6 --The Government of President Joseph D. Mobutu said today that loyal troops were fighting rebellious Congolese soldiers and foreign mercenaries in the streets of two eastern cities of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, July 6--A recent survey has indicated that the Administration's experimental program to underwrite public transportation in low-income areas has apparently succeeded in its primary mission: helping the poor find jobs outside the ghetto.

AKRON, Ohio, July 6--The B.F. Goodrich Company has threatened to reconsider plans for expansion here because of an 11-week strike by the United Rubber Workers. The tire manufacturing company also said that it would have fewer jobs available for Akron workers after the strike.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday it had established the presence of a number of phantom workers on the payroll of Chet Maintenance Corporation, a ship maintenance concern that it is investigating.

BT New York Corporation, a bank holding company, expects earnings for the second quarter to be "flat or down slightly" from a year earlier, but to show an increase of 6 per cent for the year as a whole, Lewis Lapham, vice chairman, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6-- Intrepid and Columbia, the newest and the oldest of the four 12-meter yachts seeking to become the defender of the America's Cup against the challenge from Australia, beat the models of three years ago today, each coming from behind on the same leg.

BERLIN, July 6--A doubledecker commuter train loaded with children collided with a gasoline truck at a grade crossing in East Germany tonight, touching off an explosion that took a heavy toll of life in Europe's worst rail disaster in 15 years.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) --The Johnson Administration, concerned about criticism that ithad abandoned the civil rights fight, reported record activities today in the filing of rights suits.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 6 (AP) --A 17-year-old boy died at Jones Beach today when a sand tunnel he was digging between two four-foot-deep holes collapsed.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP)-- The First Federal Savings and Loan Association began operation today of a vending system that enables its employes to buy food and drink on credit in the lounge.
NASHVILLE, July 6--Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the Urban League, accused Northern liberals tonight of having deserted the civil rights movement when it spread outside the South.

For what may be the best of motives, the Department of the Interior has involved itself in the worst of arrangements. In an effort to gain the cooperation of the State of California in the creation of a national redwood park, the Interior Department is offering several tracts of Federal land in exchange for two state redwood parks.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 6--The defending champion, Mrs. Billie Jean King, will meet her old rival, Mrs. Ann Jones, for the Wimbledon singles crown on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) --The Treasury Department said today preliminary sales of new Freedom Share savings bonds totaled $1.5-million during May and June but many sales to payroll savers are yet to be recorded.
WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 6 (AP)--A small plane, laboringto gain altitude on takeoff, struck a tree and crashed, killing two of its occupants and seriously injuring the other two.

Only two incinerators have been certified to operate by the Department of Air Pollution Control since the May 20 deadline for upgrading apartment building incinerators. The move was made to comply with the city's air pollution control law.
The widow of a slain gambler asked the State Supreme Court yesterday in a civil suit to rule that Mark Fein, now serving a life sentence for slaying her husband, be declared the murderer.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $1.1-million program to aid 52 Southern Negro colleges in breaking out of their academic isolation.

WASHINGTON, July 7--A New York painter and illustrator has invented a plastic bicycle without hubs or spokes.

Assemblyman Fank G. Rossett was elected New York County Democratic leader yesterday. A member of the so-called old-line group of Manhattan district leaders, he won easily in a contest with a Reform Democrat.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 7 (UPI)--A whooping crane that was born yesterday at the San Antonio Zoo died tonight.

PITTSBURGH, July 7--Mrs. William Steinberg, wife of the musical director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, died at Allegheny General Hospital here tonight. She was 64 years old and lived here and in East Hampton, L.I.
The student body of the North Carolina School of the Arts' summer session will assemble for the first time tomorrow evening at Kennedy International Airport in Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission ordered the General Electric Company today to stop promotional payments to builders and contractors that are based on restrictive buying agreements.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)-- The Defense Department withdrew a request tonight for a waiver on use of foreign-flag ships in the coastal oil trade-- after the waiver had brought a threat of a general maritime strike next Tuesday.
A portly, perspiring man wedged his frame into the crowd inching into the United States Passport Agency at Rockefeller Center yesterday and groaned, "Holy mackerel."
The Appellate Division yesterday affirmed a State Supreme Court ruling that prohibited tenants of the Lincoln Towers development from hanging bedsheets and aluminum foil from their windows.
Mayor Lindsay walked smiling last night through a crowd of 500 hecklers who spoiled his plans to take what he had hoped would be a "quiet little walking tour" in Harlem.
Before last night's game went into extra innings at Shea Stadium the New York Mets had won seven of eight overtime contests.
TEL AVIV, July 7--Israel intends to reopen the Arab schools in her newly occupied territories, but only after ridding them of all traces of anti Israeli propaganda.

WASHINGTON, July 7--In the final days of the Kennedy round of trade negotiations, the United States withdrew 80 per cent of its offers to reduce tariffs on steel and two-thirds of its offers on synthetic textiles, it was disclosed today.
Protective gates on stores and iron bars on house doors have become standard equipment in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 7 (AP)--Union officials today called for a general strike vote as increasingly heavy worker absenteeism cut into production at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans will make a half-hour appearance on the National Broadcasting Company television network next Saturday to reply to its criticism of his conduct of an investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 7 --Basking in the glow of recessed ceiling lights and hanging Tiffany lamps, the Heck scher Museum reopens here on Sunday after a $150,000 eightmonth renovation.

A blueprint far improving education by developing closer cooperation between the city schools and the communities they serve is being drafted by a special panel appointed by Mayor Lindsey last spring,
Federal agents raided yesterday a one-family home in Huntington, L.I., described as the principal and most professional factory for the manufacture of hallucinogenic drugs in the metropolitan area.
The Longines of Wittnauer Watch Company reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended March 31.
DANBURY, Conn., July 7-- Dr. William H. Cable, secretary of the Connecticut Osteopathic Examining Board, died of a heart attack in a physician's 54 years old.
BALTIMORE, July 7 (AP)-- Workers at two Baltimore breweries voted today to accept a new contract and end a six-day strike. Workers at a third brewery rejected the contract and remained on strike.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 9.4 per cent in production for the week ended July 1 compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

Dresser Industries, Inc., a diversified industrial producer based in Dallas, is making a tender offer to stockholders of Symington Wayne Corporation in an attempt to block the merger proposal of Universal American Corporation and Symington Wayne.
Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday for a "living room" day-care program for children of mothers on welfare to free the women for employment.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 7--Almost 25,000 Hong Kong residents have applied for entry visas for Taiwan since the proPeking rioting in Hong Kong broke out in mid-May, according to Chinese Nationalist sources.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7--Intrepid and Columbia were clearly faster than Constellation and American Eagle in their respective races of the America's Cup defense trials in moderate smoky so'westerly breezes today.

The "shop" concept by which department stores are hoping to look like specialty stores and specialty stores hope to look like boutiques is in danger of being overdone, according to the country's largest retail interiordesign company.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7--A meeting of Arab heads of state to work out a new Pan-Arab policy gained support today. This development came in the wake of the failure of the United Nations to resolve the Middle East crisis.
A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that an Israeli-born woman could not remove her two American-born children to Israel because this would deprive them of their "treasured birthright."

Potential mergers remained the major topic of interest in the railroad industry yesterday. Representatives of the Illinois Central and the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroads met in New Orleans to discuss a possible merger. This was a reopening of previously reported negotiations but, as in the past, no definite decisions appeared to have been reached.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 7--The head of the gambling monopoly on Grand Bahama Island has said that the Federal Bureau of Investigation must clear all prospective American managers of the island's casinos.

BRUSSELS, July 7--Michel Andre, a 28-year-old Belgian teacher, who was the last European to leave Bukavu after the outbreak' of the rebellion there, said today it had been started by discontented Katangese soldiers.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 7 (AP)--Iowa has found what may be a solution to the conflict between the Amish religious sect and state school laws.

WASHINGTON, July 7--President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo, in a letter to President Johnson, has requested United States logistic assistance in put ting down a military rebellion in the eastern provinces, State Department Officials said today.
A rally led by recently depressed British Government bonds carried prices moderately higher on the London stock market yesterday. Trading was light and selective.

OMAHA, Neb., July 7 (UPI) --Maj. Gen. william J. Crumm, commander of the Strategic Air Command's Third Air Division, was listed among six men missing today after a midair collision of two B-52 Stratofortresses on a Guam-to-Vietnam bombing run.

ALBANY, July 7--New York's highest court ruled unanimously today that the liquor industry cannot use the state's Fair Trade Law to thwart a 1984 law that was designed to reduce the retail price of liquor.

FRANK GIOVANI ROS, SETI, who once fought gangs of Irish boys for the right to swin in the East River, celebrated his election yesterday as leader of the New York County Democratic Organization by inviting an Irishman to lunch.
A former Roman Catholic priest and feather from' Chicago who went to live in the Soviet Union in protest against American policy in Vietnam came back to the United States with a bride this week.

Four gallons of ladybugs have been released along a 20block area of Riverside Park at the edge of the Hudson River in a biological warfare experiment against insects that damage trees and shrubs.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7--Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the United States commander in Vietnam, renewed today his appeal to Washington to send him more troops.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States Railroads in the latest week ended July 1 was an estimated 13.1-billion ton-miles, 4.9 per cent below the corresponding 1966 week.

Robert Crawford Brinker, assistant to the publisher of Sports Illustrated, died on Thursday at the age of 51. He lived on Cedarwood Drive in North Stamford, Conn.

DETROIT, July 7 (UPI)--Independence Day and model hangeovers held car production this week to 157,395 units, compared with 207,853 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

WASHISIGTON, July 7 (UPI)--The Public Health Service said today that it would begin testing television tubes soon to determine whether there was a potential X-ray hazard to viewers.
LONDON, July 7 (AP)--The Earl of Harewood, 44-year-old cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, applied today to have a divorce decree against him made final.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) --Assistant Secretary, of the Interior J. Cordell Moore said today that more than 200 million barrels of oil "have been interrupted or delayed in transit" as a result of the Mideast conflict.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) --Capt. Howard B. Levy lost his second bid in as many days today for his release on bail pending appeal of his conviction for making disloyal statements about the United States' conduct of the Vietnam war.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 7 (AP)--Superior Court Judge James L. Vallely today fined The Worcester Telegram and Gazette, Inc., $1,000 and one of its reporters, E. Thomas McCabe Jr., $100 for contempt of court.
MILLBRAE, Calif., July 7--Dr. Hilda Taba, professor of educational, admintstration at San Francisco State College, died yesterday in Peninsula Hospital, Burlingame, after a short illness. She was 63.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7-- Winter is very cruel to Buenos Aires. By the middle of June, the frigid Antarctic winds shake most of the foliage from the trees. The rain streaks the gray buildings and turns the narrow streets into quick little streams bobbing with black umbrellas in the morning.
RUSSIAN icons now on the market can be checked against the selection on view at the Gallery of Modern Art, 2 Columbus Circle.

WASHINGTON, July 7-- Officials of the Justice Department have been quietly meeting with news media representatives in racially tense cities to urge restraint in reporting racial outbursts, a department spokesman said today.

DETROIT, July 7--The Chrysler Corporation disclosed today that it had recalled 14,066 automobiles for inspection for possible safety defects. There were no accidents because of the troubles, Chrysler said.

BERKELEY, Calif. July 7 (AP)--A girl and boy from wealthy Chicago families were kidnapped while touring the hippie section of Berkeley last night but escaped in nearby Richmond, the police said today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 7--Nine suspected gambling places have closed in the last few days as a result of a police harassment campaign, Police Commissioner George Kummerle reported today.

Anyone who looks for the causes of the 1848 Revolution, which toppled the throne of the "Bourgeois King" Louis-Philippe, must come upon the Praslin murder, a crime of passion: it glows amid the duller debris of history such as the dynamics of industrialization and the class struggle.

THIS quixotic, quicksilver, slightly flawed novel is ul timately in the Fitzgerald phrase the triumph of an attitude. The attitude is that of the European aristocrat one part gallantry, one part understatement and one part a bypassing of the everyday-ness of bourgeois life. In her first book, German-born Ursula Zilinsky maintains this attitude throughout, bolstering her point of view with quotations from William James.

MOGADISHU, Somalia. AT the sign of the banana leaf there is an African chew-in, a gathering for an all-night session of cat-napping and deep perception, of Somali poetry and glowing evocations of the things that really matter: love, war, death, famine, horses, women. This is not a juvenile subculture of hippies or druggies, or dropouts smoking the baked scrapings of banana peels just to tie one on cheaply.

"WHAT Australians have not so far looked for in themselves is their own personality and where it has really come from. . . Thus James Aldridge's narrator, at the end of "My brother Tom," which may be intended as part of a new literature leading Australians toward the painful business of self-discovery.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The District of Columbia's Board of Education today appointed a Negro, Benjamin J. Henley Jr., as acting superintendent of schools. Mr. Henley, 55 years old, is the first Negro to serve as the top public school administrator here.

DALLAS, July 8 (AP) Los Angeles scored two goals in a five-minute span to tie the Dallas Tornado, 2-2, and clinch the Western Division championship of the United Soccer Association.
