Cuomo Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Cuomo of Brooklyn. The Rev. Eugene F. O'Neil performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John J. King.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. When Mrs. Ray Anselmo, wife of a Washington car dealer, covered the floors of her new summer home in marble, she had the foresight to do it in beige. "It's just the color of sand," she said happily, one recent Sunday, as she watched her six daughters troop past on their way from the beach.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8 Circumstantial evidence is piling up that Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara, the guerrilla warfare theorist, is alive, probably somewhere on the South American continent.

WASHINGTON, July 9--The United States Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to extend for two years the unused tariff-cutting authority in the 1962 Trade Expansion Act, with the understanding that "no major round of tariff negotations would be undertaken during this period."
FRESH CREEK, Andros Island, the Bahamas, July 9-- The Navy is exploring the ocean here with the same zeal the Air Force has expended on space.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Scientists have discovered that one of the valves of the human heart, long thought to be just a passive flap of tissue, actually has muscle fibers, nerves, blood vessels and the ability to contract and relax on its own.

LUSAKA, Zambia, July 9-- Rhodesia Railways, one of the three remaining common services operated between Zambia and Rhodesia since the former Central African Federation broke up, has now been officially split up.

A family drive through Central Park in a horse-drawn carriage seemed like the perfect end of a vacation for the Saverio Sasso family from Stockton, Calif., yesterday--until they were getting out of the carriage near the Plaza Hotel.
ROUEN, France, July 9(AP) --Jochen Rindt of Austria drove a Brabham-Cosworth at record speed today to an easy victory in the Grand Prix de France for Formula Two sports cars.
Tenants must be educated in "basic standards of decency" if housing code enforcement is to succeed. Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday.
Frank G. Rossetti, newly elected New York County Democratic leader, will try today to work out a division of other major party offices that will produce unity in the county committee.

Nine men and five women were named yesterday to represent the United States in kayak and canoe competition at the Pan-American Games at Winnipeg, Man., from July 22 to Aug. 3. The selections were made on the basis of performance in trials that ended yesterday at Orchard Beach Lagoon, the Bronx.

TORONTO, July 9--India's first private enterprise investment in the Western Hemisphere--a $10-million hardboards plant--has recently been opened near Halifax, Nova Scotia, by the president of India, Dr. Kakir Husain.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 9-- Officials reported today that federal forces had surrounded the crossroads town of Nsukka, about 30 miles north of Enugu, capital of the secessionist Eastern Region.
It's "gung ho" in Gotham these days, according to Mayor Lindsay.
HONG KONG, Monday, July 10 (UPI)--Communist China said today that a Communistled armed revolution similar to that in Vietnam had broken out in Burma.
JERUSALEM, July 9--An Israeli soldier was killed today and two were injured when their jeep ran over a mine six miles north of Qantara on the Suez Canal.
Special to The New York Times

INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) --Frank Beard rallied from two strokes behind with a threeunder-par 33, 36-69 today and won the $100,000 Speedway open golf tournament by three strokes over Rod Funseth and Rives McBee.
BRUSSELS, July 9--The Congo has become less dangerous for white settlers than was feared on Friday, according to Belgian Foreign Ministry sources.

Despite predictable expressions of disappointment from the company and of dismay from Wall Street, the Federal Communications Commission's decision last week to set a rate of return of from 7 to 7.5 per cent for the interstate services of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is neither startling nor severe.
LIKE all commercial enterprises, publishers hunt for products that will sell, and sniffing out the "big" novel is an important part of any fiction editors's job-- crucial if he's ambitious.
MOSCOW, July 9--The Soviet Union unveiled seven su personic fighters and fighterbombers today in the country's first major air show since 1961.
At about 5 P.M. yesterday an Overseas National Airways jetliner, soaring up from Kennedy Airport, broke through the cloud cover at 5,000 feet over Long Island, and 15-year-old Andrew Gaines yelled:
Many small businesses view the services of a certified public acountant as a burdensome expense once a year. And that is why many small ventures will remain small, if in business at all.

WASHINGTON, July 9--The United States has dispatched three large military transport aircraft to the Congo in response to a request by President Joseph D. Mobutu, whose Government is putting down a rebellion led by white mercenaries.

The president of the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that his union would urge members to go to banks to borrow the equivalent of several months' salaries to face a possible stoppage in the city's school system next fall.
GENEVA, July 9 (UPI)--World economic growth slowed in 1966, the United Nations reported today.

In a tactical coup that succeeded so brilliantly that even Casey Stengel, watching from a box seat, must have been dazzled, Manager Wes Westrum maneuvered his New York Mets to a ninth-inning 5-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium yesterday.
The superliner United States has been scheduled for its longest winter cruise and one that will take the 52,000-ton vessel across the Equator for the first time.

BUFFALO, July 9--Ch. Reggen's Madas-L of Marydane, the top-winning Great Dane in the country, took the top prize today to make a clean sweep for the weekend, having won the best in show at the Genesee Valley Kennel Club in Rochester yesterday.

The successful completion of sea trials of the 600-passenger ferry Bluenose with its new flume stabilization system has been announced by John. J. McMullen Associates, Inc., naval architects and marine engineers. The concern is a consultant to Canada's Department of Transport.
In Pittsburgh not long ago, an art collector who had bought a painting for $80 donated it eight months later to a university museum and claimed a $7,500 Fedaral tax deduction.
LOS ANGELES, July 9--Kipchoge Keino of Kenya upset Ron Clarke of Australia, the world record-holder, in the 5,000 meter-run today in the United States-British Commonwealth track and field meet.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)--Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd has told Congress that only three states and the District of Columbia had auto- mobile inspection requirements in 1966 "that amounted to anything."

RYE, N. Y., July 9--Miss Catherine Farrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Farrell, was married this afternoon to Robert J. Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson of New Windsor. Msgr. John D. McGowan performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.
Six of the state's leading private universities have appealed to the Constitutional Convention to refrain from weakening the authority of the state's Board of Regents.
TOKYO, July 9 (Reuters)-- The first typhoon of the season roared in from the Pacific today and by tonight had left 347 persons dead or missing in the southern areas of Japan.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 9-- Miss Fatima Jinnah, the spinster sister of Pakistan's founder who challenged Mohammed Ayub Khan for the presidency in 1965, died of a heart attack in her sleep here last night. She was 74 years old.
MOBERLY, Mo., July 9 (UPI) --Nine-inch rains fell in the Missouri Valley today, forcing residents from homes in several Missouri counties.
Bronx Republican insurgents plan to boycott a county committee meeting tonight, at which Representative Paul R. Fino will seek re-election as leader.

BALTIMORE, July 9--Either foiled or frustrated for half a season, Fritz Peterson, who had 12 triumphs last year to share with Mel Stottlemyre the honor of being the leading winner on the Yankee staff, at last was credited with his initial 1967 victory today. But he needed help.

Aqua-Chem, Inc., makers of water conversion equipment and heaters, reported yesterday net earnings of $1,829,255 for the fiscal year ended May 31, an increase of 38 per cent from the $1,354,601 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
Endowed with a dowsing-rod sensitivity to the new and interesting, Ted Shawn, artistic director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, always has a few surprises for patrons.

The Bank of America, the nation's largest commercial bank, announced over the weekend that its earnings rose 10.1 per cent in the first half. Consolidated net operating earnings came to $59,437,000, or $2.09 on each of the 28,480,000 shares outstanding on June 30.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 9 --President Johnson, rested and buoyant after 10 days at his ranch near here, headed back tonight toward Washington and a bundle of problems with Con gress and the war in Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9-- Prospective delegates either specifically or tacitly pledged to Senator Robert F. Kennedy will enter at least half a dozen Democratic Presidential primaries next year, a Kennedy backer said here today.

Two Army paratroopers, one of whom was reported to have been decorated by President Johnson for bravery in Vietnam, were accused of beating and robbing a civilian on a midtown Manhattan street early yesterday.
FORT LEE, N.J., July 9-- Mrs. Elizabeth Smith, 27 years old, of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died after an accident on a ride at Palisades Amusement Park here this afternoon.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP)--Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo le, said today that there would be more racial riots unless the white community did more to help Negroes gain jobs, housing and economic security.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9-- An offer by the United States to provide nuclear materials at cast to Latin-American nations that renounce the manufacture of atomic weapons has excited a wave of opposition in Brazil.
The State Health Department has completed plans for a program to clean up interstate and coastal waters in time to qualify for extra Federal aid.

HONG KONG, July 9--Communist demonstrators clashed with policemen in this British colony again tonight as slogans appeared on walls in the crowded Wanchai area saying: "Liberate Hong Kong." Four persons, including a policeman, were killed.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 9-- Hilda's Kitten, an aged chestnut mare who has competed in only one other event this year, won the open jumper championship today at the Tri-state Horse Show.
MAMARONECK, N.Y. July 9 --Gene Francis and Billy Edwards, Long Island golfers, added the John G. Anderson final today to the medalist honors they won in a playoff yesterday.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 9(AP)--Union employes of the world's largest shipyard voted today to call a general strike despite a court order directing the workers to stay on the job.

Miss Carol Ruth Levine was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey M. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Weiss of Wyncote, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Emanuel Rackman at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Far Rockaway, Queens. The parents of the bride are Mr. and Mrs. Leo Levine of Far Rockaway.
When a successful Broadway producer forms an association with a promotion and marketing agency to enter the field of industrial show production there ought to be a good reason.
PITTSBURGH, July 9--Steel officials were keeping a close watch on inventory trends last week.

The Constitutional Convention, whose sessions resume today, is at a critical point in its work. There is some ground for cautious optimism that it may bring forth a better Constitution than the antiquated charter now in force.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9--Critics of Robert W. Komer, the controversial formet Presidential assistant, con cede that he has accomplished more than they had expected during his first two months in South Vietnam.

Morris Fox, a retired glass manufacturer, who was active in researching and publicizing Nazi crimes against the Jews, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 1155 Park Avenue.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $95,966,002,022, consist of Treasury securities as follows:

Following is a step-by-step account of the political and diplomatic moves in Israel that led to her third war with neighboring Arab states in 20 years. It is based on facts now available through reports from corresponds of The New Yrok...

The marriage of Miss Ute Amelle Adolph, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Adolph of Bad Hamburg, Germany, to Capt Frank D. Finn, U.S.A., took place here yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Francis M. Finn of Bayside, Queens, and the late Mr. Finn.

In a long-term leasing transaction involving total rent of more than $2-million, the 30th floor of the General Motors Building, being built on the site of the old Savoy Plaza Hotel, has been leased by Moore McCormack Company, Inc., and its principal subsidiary, MooreMcCormack Lines.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 9 --A report accusing Florida's biggest land developer, the Gulf American Corporation, of "unethical sales practises" may lead to a complete investigation of installment land sales in Florida.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 (Reuters)--The Vietcong struck at the biggest American troop billet in Saigon tonight, setting off a shrapnel-spraying mine and following it with sniper fire from across the street.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 9--Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara flew close to the demilitarized zone today and witnessed a heavy barrage of naval gunfire, artillery and air strikes against North Vietnamese emplacements.
WASHINGTON, July 9--A growing volume of complaints against automobile insurance companies by indignant policy holders has raised the possibility of one or more Federal investigations of the industry.

The marriage of Miss Ellen Lois Kase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kase of Flushing, Queens, to Charles Risbarg took place yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Stanley Howard Forster of Englewood, N.J., and Leo Risbarg of Newburgh, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- When the 90th Congress convened last January, a number of Democrats expressed fear that it would be a "do-nothing" body.

JAFFREY CENTER, N. H., July 9--Mr. and Mrs. B. Leonard Krause have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Holden Krause, to Pfc. G. Clay Hollister, of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dickerman Hollister of Greenwich, Conn.

BOSTON, July 9--Joseph Barboza, a convict once described in a Massachusetts court as "one of the real killers" in the state, has written to a reporter that he intends to expose the leaders of organized crime in New England.

MASTER Bernard Zuckerman, a Manhattan Chess Club stalwart, a former club champion and a veteran of international play, produced a worthy candidate for a brilliancy prize in the Metropolitan League matches.

MOSCOW, July 9 (AP)--Bill Crothers, a lanky Toronto pharmacist, stormed to an easy, 10yard victory in the 800-meter run today in the second day of the Znamensky Brothers Memorial track and field meet.
WASHINGTON, July 9(AP) --George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, affirmed today labor's support for civil rights legislation.
CINCINNATI, July 7--Until recently the Rev. Fred Shuttles worth felt like a hero from the wars when he walked along the streets in Cincinnati's Negro districts.

The police in most of the nation lack scientific and technical crime-solving aids that authorities believe are essential to effective law enforcement according to a study financed by the Department of Justice and made public yesterday.

WALDEN, N. Y., July 9-- Two years ago, Mrs. James Cole of New York was watching the judging at the Seigerschau in Mannheim, Germany, and a 14-month-old puppy attracted her attention. The pup finished ninth of 145 shepherds at the championship show. When Mrs. Cole returned to New York, she had bought Fels von der Rottunbrucke for her Dornwald Kennels.

The black situation in Aden and the surrounding South Arabian Federation of sultanates and sheikhdoms has lightened a little in the last two weeks. Aden itself, where British and police authority had collapsed, is now again under control. However, the British had to bring in reinforcements from the United Kingdom to reconquer the district known as the Crater, where 22 British soldiers were recently killed in an army mutiny.

WASHINGTON, July 9--More than 37,000 Americans have completed final applications to VISTA--the domestic Peace Corps whose initials stand for Volunteers In Service To America--over the last two and onehalf years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9--Au Truong Thanh, a former member of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's Cabinet who is a candidate for the presidency, today accused the Premier of taking "stumbling steps toward dictatorship" and of organizing a "smear operation" against him.
A 20-FOOT-HIGH window wall flanked by Italian marble forms the new store front of Charles Co. at 340 Madison Avenue (43d Street).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Monday, July 10--The Security Council agreed early today to authorize Secretary General Thant to "proceed as he has suggested" with his plan to station United Nations observers on both sides of the Egyptian-Israeli cease-fire line along the Suez Canal.
Mayor Lindsay, trailed by a squad of aides, will go to Albany today for a speech to Constitutional Convention delegates tomorrow about what New York City wants in a new state Constitution.
JERUSALEM, July 9--With Leonard Bernstein conducting and Isaac Stern and Jenny Tourel as soloists, the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra returned today to Mount Scopus for the first time in 24 years.

TRENTON, Juky 9--Richard Petty overcame the heat (98 degrees inside his Plymouth), Darel Dieringer of Charlotte, N.C. (a tenacious rival in a Ford Fairlane), and a slipping tire safety tube to win the first Northern 300-mile late model stock car race here today.

When the 90th Congress convened last January, most observers doubted that it would have a constructive session. During its first half-year, Congress-- which returns to work today after the Fourth of July recess--has fully justified that pessimism.

Mexico's one-party democracy has just proved its unassailable strength for the umpteenth time. That paradoxical land of oligarchy and revolution has given the Institutional Revolutionary party (P.R.I.) a victory in the congressional and state elections that would satisfy a Communist Politburo.
KANSAS CITY, MO., July 9 (AP)--Policemen used tear gas today to disperse an unruly crowd of young Negroes involved in a disturbance in Swope Park, on Kansas City's east side.

Dr. Russell Galbraith MacRobert, a neurologist and psychiatrist, died yesterday of cancer in the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 37 Maplewood Street, Larchmont, N. Y. His office was at 101 East 80th Street.

As the earth turns, even nightclubs have their seasons. In spring, the fresh, bright faces of prom-trotters fill the clubs. Then, when sumer is icumen in, the prom-trotters disappear and the fresh, bright faces are found out on the floor, entertaining.
WASHINGTON, July 9--Air travelers are increasing at the rate of 10,000 a day, forcing the Government into a further expansion of its air traffic control network.

Reactivation of the handsome outdoor clock at the old New York Sun Building at Broadway and Chambers Street is good news to those who cherish the memory of that newspaper, which ceased publication in 1950. It is also good news to those people who find it necessary to depend upon the horological information conveyed by public timepieces--in other words, those who have forgotten their wristwatches.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 9-- King Hussein declared tonight that Jordan would not make a separate peace with Israel "so long as there is a ray of hope in our efforts for a summit conference."

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) --More than a million American cars and 89,000 foreign cars have been recalled by manufacturers to correct defects since the auto safety law became effective last September, tha Federal Highway Administration has told a House Appropriations subcommittee.

GENEVA, July 9--Speaking on behalf of 1,600 leading lawyers who will gather hers tomorrow, a Washington lawyer promised today: "We will put all the law in the world on one computer right here in Geneva."
Two Pennsylvania Railroad trains about 70 miles apart derailed within a 21-minute period early yesterday, ripping up track and disrupting schedules for 150 trains between Washington and New York.
HOUSTON, July 9 (AP)--An American Legion parade turned into a fight today between 150 Marine reservists and 30 peace demonstrators.

The Willie Bobo Sextet can be a hard act to follow, even when you are Dave Brubeck playing to a house well salted with Brubeck fans. If Mr. Brubeck looked on this as a problem, it was solved for him very neatly by Mr. Bobo Saturday evening at the Rheingold Music Festival in Central Park's Wollman Rink.

The city's Health Commissioner disclosed yesterday that he had proposed an increase in the salaries of key professionals to hold those already in his hard-pressed department and to overcome present shortages.
PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP)-- Willie Stargell's leadoff homer in the ninth inning gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory today over the Cincinnati Reds.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9-- Wandelaar, a new fiber-glass sloop of tho Cal 48 Class, won the Riverside Yacht Club' Stratford Shoal overnight race today, an event that almost proved to be no race at all for lack of wind.

WASHINGTON--During his lunch hour one day recently, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy walked into what had been Walter Lippmann's home for 22 years, deposited some books he didn't want entrusted to the movers and dashed back to the Capitol.
HONG KONG, July 9--A British official here was asked recently whether there had been any uneasiness in official quarters about Peking's belligerent attacks on the Hong Kong authorities.

The head of the Social Service Employes Union yesterday accused Mayor Lindsay of fomenting violence in the threeweek-old Welfare Department work stoppage.
The establishment of a new regional institute at Columbia University for the study of Southern Asian countries was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia.
ST. LOUIS, July 9 (AP)--Late goals by Rudi Kolbl and Allie McNab enabled the St. Louis Stars to tie the Baltimore Bays, 2-2, in a National Professional Soccer League game tonight.
The bond market this week will find out whether the Fourth of July week rise in prices and decline in interest rates were anything more than a brief display of monetary fireworks.

Five of the nation's maritime unions have offered to give up a traditional feature of collective bargaining, retroactively of settlement terms, in an effort to bring about a continuity of operations in the merchant marine.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 9 --Mrs. Cornelia Van Wyck Kellogg, widow of Frederic R. Kellogg, a lawyer, died yesterday in her home at 25 Colles Avenue. Her age was 87.
STORMVILLE, N.Y., July 9 --A 21-year old skydiver was killed here this afternoon on his first jump when his parachute failed to open.

ONE bidding concept that has been abandoned by the experts, although it is still to be found in some textbooks, is the free raise. A player who planned to raise the opening bid should not be diverted because his righthand opponent makes an overcall.
Robert Moses has formulated plans to bar the use of any Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority funds to meet losses on the city's transit system until after 1985.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 9 (UPI)--Rosie, the whooping crane, hatched a second youngster this morning, her second in four days, but zoo officials quickly took this one from her.
The Rev. Robert L. Ryan, assistant professor of theology at the Fordham University School of Education, died Saturday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 72.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 9 (AP) --Don Mincher's two-run homer sparked the California Angels to a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics today that extended the Angels' winning streak to six games.

WHILE other hairdressers are busy putting curls into straight hair, Louis Gignac, who is the first half of the Louis-Guy D Salon, has become the Pied Piper of women who have naturally wavy hair and loathe it.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9--"I am not a career diplomat," says Endalkachew Makonnen, Ethiopia's chief delegate to the United Nations.

Hal I. Leyshon, a public-relations consultant who helped develop the images of Florida as a resort, President Harry S. Truman as a choice for election in 1948 and James Caesar Petrillo as "Friendly Jimmy" rather than as the "Czar of Music," died of a heart attack yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 45 East 85th Street.

Alarmed by the dwindling number of Broadway theaters as their sites are sold for other buildings, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday urged that New York consider the need to replace the lost houses.

WASHINGTON, July 9--A new study by the staff of the House Banking Committee showed today that, in a recent 27-month period, 424 commercial banks were taken over by new owners who used money borrowed from other banks to make the purchases.
A 24-year-old Bronx man's "police uniform" was convincing in almost every respect except for a pearlhandled revolver, it was charged yesterday.

New York City desperately needs more small neighborhood parks, particularly in congested, low-income areas. We welcome, therefore, the gift to the city of six playgrounds along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, and its promise of twenty more small parks and playgrounds on left-over bits of land.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- Cuba has given the United States permission to fly weather planes over the island for the first time since the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Ned A. Eddy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Dawn Kathryne Eddy, to Kenneth R. Rashid. His parents are Mrs. James G. Rashid of Rockford, Ill., and the late Mr. Rashid, who was in the motel business. The marriage is planned for Sept. 23.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Political candidates spent almost as much for radio and television advertising in 1966, a year without a Presidential campaign, as they did in 1964, a Presidential election year.

Ben Kubasik, associate director of the Public Broadcast Laboratory of National Educational Television, was appointed yesterday as executive director of the National Citizens Committee for Public Television. Mr. Kubasik, 38 years old, will assume his new duties on July 31 at an annual salary of approximately $40,000.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- The Committee for Economic Development added its voice today to the continuing demands for the renovation of state governments.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) --The Peace Corps said today that it planned no disciplinary action against five volunteers in Ecuador who protested United States Vietnamese policy in a letter to The New York Times.
CLEVELAND, July 10 (UPI) --Jim Bede, an aviator, went aloft today in his experimental "gas tank with wings" in an attempt to fly around the world without refueling.

HANOVER, N.H., July 10 --Frank Martin, the dis tinguished Swiss composer, ended a visit to Dartmouth College's Congregation of the Arts last night with an appearance as guest conductor in a concert of his works given in Spaulding Auditorium.
Stocks advanced in the heaviest trading in two months; volume 12.13 million shares.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- Yields on the new issue of three-month Treasury bills rose only slightly at today's auction, despite the fact that the Treasury added $100-million to the amount sold.
PARIS, July 10--The International Chamber of Commerce called today for the internationalization of the Suez Canal.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 10 (UPI)--Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, who reached the semi-finals of the Wimbledon tennis championships last week, won her first-round match today in the Swedish outdoor championships, beating Anna Marie Almgren, 6-2, 6-0.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)--The White House confirmed today that President Johnson rides a bicycle around his Texas ranch, but George Christian, the press secretary, said there was nothing new about that.
Nearly complete returns from the first month of the New York State lottery indicate that sales were only about one-quarter of what the state had predicted.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 10-- Captains of 26 boats spent a long weekend on the prowl searching the Atlantic for broadbills. When the four-day Deep Sea Club's tournament had been concluded, however, only one swordfish flag was flying at the club's dock.
Eli Lilly Co. reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its 90-year history for the six months ended June 30.

VIENNA, July 9--"Death rules in the Valley of the Puster," said a man who knows. He was talking about the South Tyrol, where violence practiced in the name of the 230,000 Austrians under Italian rule is increasing.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 10 --A "radically different" kind of urban education was called for today by the United States Commissioner of Education to prevent the coming generation of racially isolated minorities from being trapped in the ghetto.
Two separate indictments were returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury charging a finance company and five individuals with defrauding consumers in New York and New Jersey.

MOSCOW, July, 10--An article in the Young Communist League newspaper denouncing censorship in the Soviet theater was reported today to have led to the dismissal of an editor of the paper and reprisal against two writers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 10 --Mark Hirsch of Pine Hollow, and Dan Kelly of Massapequa High School, shared the lead with 73's in the qualifying round of the junior division of the Long Island Golf Association junior and boys championship. The tournament is being held on the par 70, 6,379-yard Garden City Country Club course.
