Young actors, singers, dancers and instrumentalists are being sought by the Theater Workshop for Students to appear in productions at the East River Park Amphitheatre next month.
PARIS, July 10--An additional indication that Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara had been serving with the guerrillas in Bolivia was published here today.
New York State yesterday afternoon postponed a $49.98million sale of housing bonds that had been scheduled for this morning.
LIPNO, Czechoslovakia, July 10 (Reuters)--Barbara Wright of the United States finished ninth yesterday in the women's kayak singles event of the world canoe slalom championships.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 10-- Both sides in the Nigerian fighting issued confident statements today contradicting each other.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- The nation's labor federation asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its decision upholding the contempt conviction of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- Retail sales remained almost unchanged in June at a level of about $26-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --More than $13-million in repairs are needed at the Eisenhower Lock in the United States section of the St. Lawrence Seaway at Massena, N.Y. The estimate was made by the administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
GENEVA, July 10--The construction of an "unexpectedly large" number of nuclear power plants was planned last year, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency.

The International Bach Society, an organization formed last fall by Rosalyn Tureck, the pianist, held its first advanced study group session last night at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --House Speaker John W. McCormack and the House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, put themselves on opposite sides today regarding President Johnson's request for a tax increase.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --The Washington Whips scored three goals in the second half tonight, two by Jim Storrie, and defeated the Los Angeles Wolves, 3-0, to win the Eastern Division championship in the United Soccer Association.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. July 10 (UPI)--Eleven Negroes were fined here today for disorderly conduct and breaking the peace by use of lewd and offensive language in a disturbance yesterday at Swope Park.

Lawyers for Mark Fein, charging constitutional violations during his 1964 trial, asked Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri yesterday to issue a writ of habeas corpus to free the former business executive from a 30-year-to-life sentence for the slaying of his bookmaker.
Mayor Lindsay is making it more difficult for New Yorkers to check on him at Gracie Mansion.
With Cassius Clay in exile, boxing's new heavyweight era involved yesterday the return of a familiar name, Floyd Patterson, and the request for an interesting innovation, an "overtime" round.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) --The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would investigate the tax-exempt status of the American Farm Bureau Federation at the urging of Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of upstate New York.

IF happiness is a warm puppy, as Peanuts's creator, Charles Schulz, tells us, stockholders of American Telephone and Telegraph would appear, in the late Fred Allen's words, to be holding a bag of wet mice.

BRUSSELS, July 10--France warned today, in a blistering attack against the idea of British membership in the European Common Market, that the character of the community would change for the worse and that the Iron Curtain might drop again.

The stationing of United Nations observers along the Egyptian-Israeli cease-fire line, as proposed by Secretary General Thant and approved by the Security Council, is a vital prerequisite for further progress toward a Middle East settlement. Egypt's agreement to the proposal is an encouraging sign, as are the reports that Israeli acquiescence will shortly be forthcoming.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- Dr. James M. Nabrit Jr., president of Howard University the country's largest predominantly Negro academic community, announced his retirement today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9-- Mrs. Kate Shaffer Muldaur, who formerly worked for The New York Times in various departments, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital after a brief illness. Mrs. Muldaur, widow of Barton Muldaur, an engineer, lived at 1380 North Avenue. She was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --The Pentagon announced plans today to detonate 2,000 tons of conventional explosives in the Pacific next month as part of its program to improve nuclear detection capabilities.

ALBANY, July 10--Mayor Lindsay, seeking greater fiscal home-rule powers for New York City, came here tonight to confer with leaders of the State Constitutional Convention and to meet with rank-and-file delegates tomorrow.

ROME, July 10--A month short of 40 years after their deaths in the electric chair in the state of Massachusetts, the case of Italian anarchists Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti is to be reopened tomorrow in a courtroom in Milan.
The Chicago North Western Railway and the Essex Wire Corporation announced yesterday a revision of the terms under which the railway would acquire the wire maker in a tax-free exchange of securities.

HONG KONG, July 10--A trolley driver was stabbed to death and a bus driver was assaulted here today in new violence as Communists stepped up their intimidation against the strikebreaking transport workers.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark, by administrative action, has forbidden all wiretapping and virtually all bugging by Federal agents, except in national security cases. Clark does not believe these are effective tools of law enforcement, but some who do are scheduled to make their case in hearings before Senator McClellan's subcommittee this week.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 10 (UPI)--A strike halted work today at the huge Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, which was in the midst of $470-million worth of contract projects, including the outfitting of the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 10 --A Suffolk Democratic leader was appointed today to the county's Republican-controlled Sewer Agency in an apparent move to restore public confidence in a sewer system.

ANAHEIM, Calif July 10-- Baseball's reigning celebrities converged on suburban Los Angeles today for the 38th AllStar Game, which will be played here tomorrow in the year-old home of the California Angels.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 10 (AP)--Douglas MacLean, a film producer, died here yesterday at the age of 77. He had suffered a stroke five years ago.
LOS ANGELES, July 10 (AP) --The Los Angeles Rams acquired Bernie Casey today in a Trade that sent Tom Moore to the Atlanta Falcons.
President Johnson was urged yesterday by a group of 59 educators, scientists, clergymen and others to seek negotiations with Communist China for the control of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman told a freshman Congressman today that he "ought to be ashamed" of himself for suggesting the Administration was using the Vietnam war to solve its farm problems.
WHITE PLAINS, July 10--A proposal to set up a centralized court system to replace local courts in 46 Westchester communities was rejected by the Board of Supervisors today by a vote of 34 to 2.
An investigation made for the New York Stock Exchange has disclosed faulty reporting and record-keeping practices on the trading floor of the nation's biggest exchange.
The First National City Bank reported yesterday that net operating earnings for the first six months of 1967 increased 10 per cent.
The "possible showers" that drenched the city last evening spoiled the al fresco debut of the Municipal Concerts Orchestra's ninth summer season.
ROME, July 1--Vatican City is experiencing what, for the world's tiniest sovereign state, can be described only as a building boom.
The spot rate on the British pound eased in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
PARIS, July 10 (Reuters)-- A security watch was mounted on the ornamental duck pond on the third floor of Orly Airport terminal today after the fourth attack on a duck there since May.

CINCINNATI, July 10 (UPI)-- Sally Buegeleisen of Larchmont, N.Y., and co-pilot Ray Janks of Johannesburg, South Africa, took off today from Lunken Airport in a Piper Twin Comanche, the first plane to start the third leg of the 21st annual Powder Puff Derby.

DETROIT, July 10--Walter P. Reuther indicated today that the United Automobile Workers union would seek wage and benefit increases of 6 per cent or more a year in its bargaining with the automo- bile industry.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The Senate exploded in angry criticism today over President Johnson's dispatch of three military transport planes and supporting personnel to the Congo to help quell a rebellion led by mercenaries.
SKIN is creeping back into fashion. On view for evenings this fall will be one shoulder, both shoulders and an increasing amount of decolletage.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 10 (AP)--A malignant tumor was removed today from the abdomen of Gov. Lurleen Wallace of Alabama. One physician said, "We see no cause" why she should not make a complete recovery.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Allan Boas Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Chase Boas of Ardmore, Pa., to Barry Grabill Balmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Henry Balmer of Paoli, Pa. The couple plan to marry here next spring.

Last night, in another of its current Philharmonic Hall concerts, the Bath Festival Orchestra wandered around the 18th century, picking up a concerto here, a symphony there, and adding a 20th-century work that uses the 18th century as a springboard.
MOSCOW, July 10 (AP)--A private screening of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" was canceled today as American films continued to encounter problems at Moscow's International film festival.

Mr. and Mrs. David E. Lakritz of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rhoda Elizabeth Lakritz, to Roger Berkowitz, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Sidney Berkowitz of Youngstown, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --Following is the roll-cal vote by which the Senate approved today a $23,400 increase in office staff allowance for each of its members:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10--The United Arab Republic informed Secretary General Thant today that it accepted his proposal to station United Nations observers on both sides of the Israeli-Egyptian cease-fire line along the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --The Spanish Navy will soon get its first aircraft carrier, a quarter-century-old American veteran of nine major Pacific battles in World War II.
Almost $700,000 in matching grants for two theater companies and for one ballet troupe was announced yesterday by Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the National Council on the Arts.

Mrs. Marjorie Dodd Sullivan, the widow of Leonard Sullivan, businessman, Army colonel in France in World War I and president of the New York Genealogical and Biographical Society, died yesterday of cancer in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Her age was 75. She lived at 610 Park Avenue.
Cotton futures advanced markedly yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange as a result of a 6 per cent drop in acreage planted this year.
"I've got my mother for a teacher," 7-year-old Kenneth Jackson bragged to a friend. His friend replied, "Who cares? The teachers aren't allowed to hit us, but you've got your mother."
WASHINGTON, July 10-- President Johnson appears to be trying to signal to the leaders of Communist China his revived interest in reducing tension between Washington and Peking.

The Welfare Department, hard-pressed to meet the needs of its 650,000 welfare reciptents because of a work slowdown by caseworkers, said yesterday it was resuming its normal practice of hiring caseworkers as needed.

A resident of Great Neck, L.I., described by the police as a leading figure in the city's numbers racket, was jailed yesterday for refusing to answer questions of a New York County grand jury that is investigating possible ties between the police and gamblers.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 10 --Dean Dixon, the American conductor, left here by air for Frankfurt, Germany, today after announcing his resignation as musical director of the sydney Symphony Orchestra in protest against orchestral conditions.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- "Long Hot Summer Special," said the full-page gun advertisement that Under Secretary of the Treasury Joseph W. Barr held before a Senate subcommittee today.
Plans for the Marquardt Corporation to acquire Automation Industries, Inc., through an exchange of stock were terminated yesterday.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., July 10 --New Zealand switched to decimal currency today with remarkably little confusion.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 --Thailand has stepped up her program to assimilate the Chinese minority, swinging back and forth between "a carrot and a stick" in her approach, but avoiding the violence that has erupted in Burma, Indonesia and Malaysia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10-- President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq retired today as his own Premier to concentrate on pan-Arab strategy against Israel. He named a seasoned politician, Lieut. Gen. Taher Yahya, to head a new Government.
BOWLING GREEN, Ky., July 10 (UPI)--A thunderstorm packing winds up to 75 miles an hour knocked over a tent at the Southern Kentucky Fair tonight, but the 100 persons inside escaped serious injury.
The Manhattan Democratic County Committee voted last night to restrict the use of the terms "Reform" and "regular" in club names.

GENEVA, July 10--Chief Justice Earl Warren urged the lawyers of the world today to sponsor the negotiation of "hundreds and perhaps thousands" of treaties to regulate all phases of international relationships.

The new French Line cargo ship Suffren, the first of two sisterships built with limited container capacity, was displayed here last night at a shipboard reception at her berth, at Wolcott Street, Brooklyn.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 10--South Korea's new National Assembly, chosen in controversial elections last month, was formally opened today. Opposition members boycotted the session and staged protest demonstrations demanding new elections.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --The Southern Christian Leadership Conference has been given a $109,300 Federal grant for a Negro adult education project in Chicago, an Office of Education spokesman said today.

ADEN, July 10 (Agence France-Presse)--A relative lull in violence over the last few days came to an end here today when gunmen killed an Arab and a Somali and wounded at least two Arabs and two British soldiers.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Bartow have announced the engagement of Mrs. Bartow's daughter, Miss Jeannie Hobart Woolston, to Wendell Fenton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fenton of Greenville, Del. A fall wedding is planned.

Lincoln Center: Archduke Trio, Library-Museum, 1 P.M.; International Bach Society, with Martin Bernstein, lecturer, and Ruth Waterman, violinist, Library-Museum, 6; Ravi Shankar, sitar player, and other Indian musicians, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

LANSING, Mich., July 10 (UPI)--Gov. George Romney said today that he believed he could beat Richard M. Nixon if they faced each other next spring in New Hampshire's Republican Presidential primary, the nation's first.
BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP)-- Striking workers shut off the flow of beer from two breweries today and truckers refused to move the products of a third brewing company.

Victor Karl Hammer, a portrait painter and writer on religious architecture, died on Saturday at Lexington, Ky. His age was 84. He had retired in 1953 as a professor of art at Transylvania College in Lexington.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10-- After one day spoiled by fog and today set aside for rest, recreation or whatever work needed to be done, the America's Cup defense trials were scheduled to resume tomorrow with a new start of the roundrobin pairings that had occupied the yachts during the first three racing days.

NOORDWYKERHOUT, the Netherlands, July 10--Seven Cardinals and sixty-eight Roman Catholic bishops from 15 European countries assembled at a preparatory seminar here today, before a four-day conference on the autonomy of bishops and local church organizations inside the Roman Catholic Church.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lea Kennedy Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Tryon Kennedy, to Paul de Blank. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Mauritz de Blank of The Hague. The wedding is planned for Sept. 2 here.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 10-- The Nassau County Ombuds man would not be allowed to investigate citizen complaints about the police, the District
BONN, July 10--The backdrop consists of 100 bas-relief representations of Heinrich Lubke, the second President of the Federal Republic of Germany.

Special to The New York Times SAN FRANCISCO, July 10-- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit refused today to interfere with a blanket stay of execution for all 58 men now on San Quentin's death row.

FAIR HAVEN, N.J., July 10 --Stanley A. Gilbert, a metal- lurgical engineer, died yester- day in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank. He had been ill about six months. He was 55 years old and lived here at 137 Lake Avenue.
The stocK market's advance continued in high gear yesterday.

The American Stock Exchange's efforts to quell speculation in a number of selected issues appear to be serving their purpose, but they also appear to be having little overall effect on the speculative tone of the market.

TRUMP contracts generally fall into one of two classes. Either the declarer leaves the trump suit strictly alone, or he draws as many rounds as possible, perhaps leaving the defenders with a winning trump.

Tennessee Williams, winner of two Pulitzer Prizes and four awards from the Drama Critics Circle, will have a new full-length work, "Kingdom of Earth," produced in New York during the winter. David Merrick probably will be the producer; contracts have not been signed.

Thomas A. Patterson Jr. has been promoted to vice president-marketing manager and James W. Torrant to vice president-industrial sales of the Norse Chain Company, a subsidiary of the Borg-Warner Corporation.

Robert S. Wilson, a radio and television publicity man, and former newspaperman, died on Saturday at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens. He was 62 years old and lived at 32-85 34th Street, Astoria, Queens.
The 20th contract bargaining session between the Publishers Association of New York and Photoengravers Union 1 was held yesterday without progress toward settlement.

The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers challenged each other yesterday to present "realistic" contract proposals and to intensify efforts to avert a threatened mass resignation of teachers.
The election of John A. Munro and James G. Peel as corporate vice presidents and members of the board of directors has been disclosed by Horace S. Ely Co., real estate brokers.

'Twas the night before Christmas at Capitol Records' New York studios yesterday as Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen applied his hot-buttered-rum baritone to "Visit From St. Nicholas," "Silent Night" and other holiday favorites.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has upheld a National Labor Relations Board order for J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., to stop "unfair labor practices" and reinstate 71 employer in its textile plants in North and South Carolina.

As he gazed out yesterday over the melon rind and driftwood-stippled waters of Lower New York Bay at South Beach, Staten Island, Phillip Della Monica said, "I'll swim here on one condition--if Mayor Lindsay brings his family and goes with me."

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Gov. Ronald Reagan of California has told the Administration and Congress that a national Redwood park is not possible unless national forests and other Federal lands are transferred outright to the state.

A pathologist from Kansas has concluded that President Kennedy had Addison's disease, although vigorous attempts were made by his physicians, family and friends--apparently for political reasons--not to describe his illness by that name.

The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday increases in operating revenues for the first five months and for 12 months ended May 31. Net income for the five-month period trailed the year-ago level and ran only slightly higher in the 12-month period.

The Phillips Petroleum Company increased yesterday its posted price for most of the crude oil it buys in Kansas and Oklahoma by 7 cents a barrel. The increase raised the top price in both states to $3.15 a barrel from $3.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --Air Force Col. John P. Stapp, 57 years old, was appointed chief medical scientist of the National Highway Safety Bureau today.
MONTREAL, July 10 (AP)-- The Soviet Union rallied to defeat Hungary, 9-6, and capture the men's saber team title at the world fencing championships here tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 11--A qualified informant said yesterday that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara was doubtful about United States intelligence reports that the North Vietnamese were sharply building up their manpower in South Vietnam and that he felt the enemy was only replacing men lost in battle.
Representative Paul A. Fino was re-elected unanimously last night to a fourth term as Bronx County Republican leader.

ZURICH, July 10 (Reuters)-- Switzerland's gold reserves rose and its foreign currency reserves fell last week following a three-way transaction between the Swiss National Bank, the Bank of International Settlements and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the weekly Swiss National Bank return showed. Gold holdings rose $125-million to $2.80-billion while foreign exchange reserves fell $13.7-million to $382-million.

WASHINGTON, July 10--A Government proposal requiring that the fees charged mutual fund investors for management of their money be "reasonable" could be administered by the courts with no difficulty, a Federal judge told Congress today.
MERRICK, L.I., July 10-- Miss Drue Ellen Devlin and James Michael Kerls have made plans to be married Nov. 11 in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Cathedral in Rockville Centre.
TRENTON, July 10 (AP)-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes named Stanley Van Ness, a 33-year-old Negro, as his chief legal counsel today.
The discovery of Addison's disease in 1855 by an eminent British physician has been described as "one of the most brilliant achievements of medicine in the 19th century."

MANY owners of shops that specialize in l9th-and early 20th-century furnishings come to their calling from such disparate fields as fashion, anthropology and the theater. In the case of Lemeau Arrott-Watt, a willowy Australian woman, who was a fashion buyer and...

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lois Madeleine Tuerk to Robert Eric Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville Hall of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., and Philadelphia, by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tuerk of Forest Hills, Queens.
JERICHO, Jordan, July 10 (AP)--Israeli guards on the cease-fire line today turned back Arab refugees trying to return to the west back of the River Jordan over the Allenby Bridge.

Mrs. Anna Marie Zemke Turner, widow of Dr. John Pickett Turner, former professor of philosophy and psychology at Brooklyn College, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospi- tal. She was 83 years old and lived at 430 West 116th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- Eight liberal Republican members of the House offered a plan today for a mutual deescalation of the Vietnam War by the United States and North Vietnam.
A change in senior management was announced yesterday in Bartlesville, Okla., by the Phillips Petroleum Company, the large oil producer.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 10 --The Rev. Henry D. Cook, pas- tor of the Old Paramus Reformed Church here from 1907 nuntil his retirement in 1952, died yesterday in the Ramapo Manor Nursing Home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

BRIANCON, France, July 10 (AP)--Felice Gimondi of Italy won the 10th leg of the Tour de France bicycle race today on the difficult 151mile mountain run from Divonne-Les-Bains to Briancon. He picked up 2 minutes 55 seconds on the over-all leader, Roger Pingeon of France.
Directors of the Campbell Soup Company elected yesterday Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill as a director of the food processing company, which is based in Camden, N.J.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that "too many of us give way to pessimism" on international affairs.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 10 (UPI)--Loopstitch, an invader from Aqueduct, drew off in the closing yards of the $6,500 feature allowance race at Monmouth Park today and won the 1 1-16 mile turf race by 1 lengths.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the largest and most influential of the 12 districts in the Federal Reserve System, promoted two women staff members yesterday.

NYACK, N.Y., July 10-- Philip S.B. Allen, an assistant controller of the First National City Bank of New York, died today in Nyack Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived on Piermont Avenue in Piermont.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 10 --Violence erupted in Karachi today as Miss Fatima Jinnah, 74-year-old sister of Pakistan's founder, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, was about to be buried near her brother's grave. She died Saturday.

The Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday declines in sales and earnings for the second quarter. Firsthalf sales remained higher, but net income was lower than for the period a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) --Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz moved today to prohibit struck farms in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas from hiring Mexican nationals and other alien workers to break the strikes.

HARTFORD, July 10--Robert H. Witt, vice president and director of marketing for the Heublein, Inc., here, died today in Hartford Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 14 Cedar Ledge Road, West Hartford.
GLADSTONE, N.J., July 10 --Three riders were selected today to represent the United States in the equestrian dressage competition of the PanAmerican Games.

Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell announced yesterday that a study was under way to determine whether existing law enforcement is adequate to cope with "the criminal subsociety using John F. Kennedy International Airport."

BOSTON, July 10--The Boston Herald Traveler, a consolidation of the morning Herald and afternoon Traveler, appeared today as a morning daily newspaper. Sunday editions used the new combined masthead for the first time-- Sunday Herald Traveler.
Site--Anaheim Stadium, Anaheim, Calif. Time--4:15 P.M., Pacific Daylight Time.
A heavy thundershower struck Bergen County in New Jersey yesterday at about 5 P.M. and, with diminishing force, moved across metropolitan New York.

The 18-story office building at 26 Beaver Street, between Broad and New Streets, has been sold for $975,000 by Surrey Investors, Inc., to Milton Barkin, Stephen Barkin and Stephen Sloan, who plan a $200,000 modernization program.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Government's top labor mediator moved back into the rubber industry, labor negotiations today, amid reports of progress in settling the industry's 81-day-old strike.
The American Automobile Association awarded a plaque yesterday to New York State for its pedestrian safety programs. It was the third consecutive year the state was honored by the A.A.A.

The city government moved yesterday to expedite the civil service coffee break by bringing midmorning refreshments to offices rather than have employes slip out to get them or spend time on the phone calling for orders.

The New York State Conservation Department reported yesterday that gypsy moths had appeared in "epidemic proportions in pockets of the Catskills" this summer, but that generally infestation in the state was "light."

Richard B. Evans, who retired on April 1 as board chairman of the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America, of East Orange, N.J., died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 61 Twin Brooks Road, Saddle River, N.J.
The Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod convention saw one of its ministers installed yesterday as general secretary of the Lutheran Council in the U.S.A.

Only five years ago the admission of one Negro student to the University of Mississippi set off rioting and bloodshed, and a similar token integration attempt at the University of Alabama required the protective services of 3,000 National Guardsmen.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 10 (AP)--Don S. Elias, retired newspaper publisher, died today in a hospital of a heart attack. He was 78 years old.

The Congress of Racial Equality's national convention has eliminated the word "multiracial" from its constitution. An unsuccessful effort was made to bar white membership altogether. CORE came close enough. At the least, white co-strugglers have been given a clear message that they will be relegated to second-class citizenship within the organization. To put it bluntly, CORE membership now stands for racial inequality.
BOSTON, July 10--Roy Wilkins said here tonight that Congressmen opposing current civil rights legislation were "creating the atmosphere" for racial violence.

HOYLAKE, England, July 10 (AP)--Deane Beman, a former British and United States Amateur champion, joined Jack Nicklaus, the defending champion, in a practice round today for the British Open golf championship--and came out of the exercise with his confidence zooming.

The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it had lowered its earnings projections for the second quarter and now expected its net income to be "about even" with the level in the corresponding period last year.

Edith Sabra Dudley, editor and publisher of The Gramercy Graphic, a monthly magazine of the Gramercy Park and Stuyvesant Square neighborhoods, died on Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 75 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 (AP)--Secretary General Thant today ordered a high-level troubleshooter to go to Guinea and the Ivory Coast Monday in an effort to negotiate the release of hostages held by both African countries.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 10 (UPI)--The Oklahoma Supreme Court held today that the state 60-year-old ban on white-Negro marriages was unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON July 10 (AP) --The Commerce Department placed special restrictions on the export licensing of nickel today but refrained from imposing any full or partial embargo. The department said it would resume immediately issuing export licenses for nickel, a process it suspended June 9 pending today's action.

LOCUST VALEY, L.I., July 10--Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Stockman Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Park Stockman, to Peter Buckner Stovell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Stovell of Greens Farms, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

YONKERS, July 10--Pay Dirt, the chestnut colt rated by most observers as the 3-year-old most likely to succeed in the triple crown of trotting series, is unlikely to get to the post for any of those prestigious events. In fact, the son of Florican and Impish may be sidelined for the remainder of the year.
The majority of Americans support the main arguments by Israel for permanent peace in the Middle East, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday in The New York Post.

Any compromise on the Congressional redistricting bill reached by the House-Senate conference committee should retain the provision against gerrymandering contained in the original measure passed by the upper house. Senator Ervin's reported desire to knock it out and leave this aspect of the problem to the
WASHINGTON, July 10-- The Senate voted 48 to 31 today to allow each of its 100 members $23,400 more for staff help.

WHENEVER the chief economist of the United Auto Workers, Nat Weinberg, speaks up during negotiating sessions with the Detroit car makers, management officials take notes--and often wince. Their chance to wince again came yesterday, when this year's round of bargaining
ROME, July 10 (Reuters)-- Jacqueline Kennedy arrived here today for a private visit.
United States Lines announced yesterday the appointment of James P. Rafter as general manager for freight sales.
HONG KONG, July 10--Communist China has emerged openly during the last week as the sponsor of two of Southeast Asia's most important Communist parties, the Indonesian and the Burmese.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) --The Public Health Service announced today a new research drive on acute heart attacks, with the award of five contracts totaling some $5-million.

Five gunmen held up a Bronx supermarket yesterday morning, the police said, but then turned their getaway car the wrong way and found themselves waiting for a traffic light in front of the 40th Precinct station house.
Tickets at all prices are still available for tomorrow night's Mayor's Trophy Game between the Mets and Yankees at Yankee Stadium.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 10--A minister who has been crusading against an alleged underworld influence here challenged Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella today to explain reports of a connection between organized crime and the city administration.
Steel production last week-- a period shortened by the Independence Day holiday--fell 1.4 per cent from the preceding week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The latest incidents in Hong Kong are more disturbing than the strikes and riots that have kept the colony in a ferment since early May Herbert Bowden, Britain's Commonwealth Relations Secretary, told the House of Commons yesterday that the latest violence was for the first time caused by the Red Guard militia, which used Communist Chinese Army weapons, and that the trouble may have been supported by Peking.

ALTHOUGH lemons are available all year round, their cool color and refreshing flavor make them particularly appealing during the summer months. Here are two recipes using lemons that would make a warmweather menu out of the ordinary.

The Museum of Modern Art has taken the first step in a long-awaited reorganization of its department of painting and sculpture. It has named William Rubin, formerly a professor of art history at Sarah Lawrence College, as curator.

ASHLAND, Ky., July 10 (AP) --Barbara Boddie of Shreveport, La., a two-time winner of the Western Women's Golf Association tournament, was among the five top qualifiers for this year's event with scores of 74 today at the rain-soaked Bellefonte Country Club's par73, 6,076-yard course.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 10 (AP) --Two seeded Junior Davis Cup Standouts were beaten in the opening round of the Western tennis championships here today.
The Syntex Corporation and Marion Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle, under which Marion would market various Syntex products in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Reports and analyses of Soviet arms shipments to the United Arab Republic in the last month suggest that Egypt has made up some of the sizable losses of the six-day war against Israel but that the pace of the shipments has not yet disclosed the extent of Moscow's commitment.
TOKYO, July 10 (Reuters) --Rescue workers toiled through mud and rubble today in a search for survivors of the havoc wrought by a weekend typhoon.

Encanta, leading almost all the way, won the feature race, at 1 1-16 miles on the turf, at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5year-old mare, flaunting the colors of Jule Fink, scored by a half-length over Jacques Wimpfheimer's Bubbles O'Tudor, with Mrs. Gerard Smith's Fatal Step next in the field of seven.
Prices surged and volume soared on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 10-- Jerome U. Bruner's 40-foot yawl Bianca, a Class D entry, was the apparent leader on corrected time in the biennial race from Marblehead, Mass., to Halifax as the fleet of 73 starters' approached the halfway mark on the 365-mile course.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court in its bid to obtain the shareholder list of Austin, Nichols Co.

ROME, July 10--Something new and someplace new have been added to the Wonderful World of Wilt Chamberlain. The thing is a 1965 Maserati Ghibli sports car. The place is Italy, where Chamberlain has been touring for a month with the Harlem Globetrotters.
CHICAGO, July 10 (UPI)--A Federal judge today ordered James R. Hoffa brought from a penitentiary to attend a hearing July 19 on his appeal for a new trial on fraud charges.
A new publisher for the financially ailing Saturday Evening Post was appointed yesterday by the Curtis Publishing Company.
Channel 13 will be on the air seven days a week next season and plans to televise most of its own productions in color.
Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Lindsay and Senator Jacob K. Javits have been meeting privately to exchange views on support for a Republican Presidential candidate in 1968.
ALBANY, July 10--The Constitutional Convention decisively rejected late today a proposed merger of the Surrogates' Courts with the State Supreme Court. The vote was 137 to 33.

IN a moment of rare generosity last November, this column did nip-ups and cartwheels and wrote huzzas in praise of a woman named Mrs. Pearl Wong. She was then hostess of what was considered a fairly remarkable Chinese restaurant, the Canton Village near Times Square.
All sections of the London stock market moved ahead yesterday.

ATHENS, July 10--Alexis S. Liatis, Greece's representative at the United Nations, was one of five senior Greek diplomats put on the retirement list by the military regime in a major diplomatic shake-up announced today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 11--Twenty-six Americans were killed in a two-hour battle yesterday in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam, a United States spokesman announced today.
Two discount store chains-- Vornado, Inc., operating in the East, and Food Giant Markets, Inc., on the West Coast-- plan to merge through an exchange of Vornado stock valued at $52,510,040.

Announcement has been, made by Mrs. Henry McCormick Gross Jr. of New York and Wainscott, L.I., and Count Carl Adam Moltke of New York and Klampenborg, Denmark, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Moltke, to Philip Henry Isles. He is the son of Mrs. Stephane Groueff of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Philip Isles.
The election of B. William Curry Jr. as vice president for finance and administration was announced yesterday by the Long Island Rail Road.

The 108-year-old Brooklyn Academy of Music has appointed Lloyd Hezekiah, a native of Trinidad and a former anti-poverty worker in the borough's Bedford-Stuyvesant area, as its assistant director, a new post.
Frederick R. Kappel, chairman of the executive committee of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the International Paper Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 --Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, stars of Britain's Royal Ballet, were arrested early today with 16 other persons in a raid on a noisy hippie party. The authorities decided later, however, there were no grounds...
Two policemen who are accused of asking once too often for protection money from an East Harlem policy operator were arrested early yesterday on extortion charges.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11-- Mrs. Edith F. Scott Breyer, wid ow of Henry W. Breyer, founder and former president of the Breyer Ice Cream Company, died today in her home in Jenkintown. Her age was 90.

AMAGANSETT, L.I., July 11--A 242-year-old Amagansett landmark, a weathered saltbox cottage that was turned into a museum of Colonial furnishings three years ago, will be the beneficiary of the third Amagansett Historical Association house tour scheduled tomorrow.
A separate status for Surrogates' Courts was not guaranteed by the Constitutional Convention vote against their merger into the State Supreme Court, a proponent of the merger said yesterday.
Raymond B. LaBonne, since 1966 a vice president of Compton Advertising, Inc., 625 Madison Avenue, died Monday in New York Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived at 281 Congers Road, New City, N.Y.
Stock prices continued to move upward yesterday although an afternoon round of profit taking took a good deal of steam out of the advance.
MINEOLA, L.L., July 11--The acting ombudsman of Nassau County said today that he doubts whether he would want to serve under the restrictions of a proposed law that would make his office permanent.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 11 (Canadian Press)--Light winds off southern Nova Scotia appeared today to have slowed the 72 yachts in the biennial Marblehead-Halifax race.

RABAT, Morocco, July 11 --A magistrate's court here sentenced Mahjoub ben Seddick, considered the most powerful leftist leader in Morocco, to 18 months in prison today for criticism of the Government's policy on Zionism.

LONDON, July 11--London Bridge is going up--for sale On Thursday, the City Corporation, the governing body of London's square-mile financial district known as the City, is virtually certain to approve a committee recommendation that the 136-year-old bridge be put on the market.

Congressional supporters of an independent Maritime Administration will appear before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee today in a renewed attempt to establish a separate agency, free of the Department of Commerce, of which it is now a part.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., July 11--Mrs. Harold Fink and her son Fred Wolinsky of Hampshire, Conn., won the 27th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's mother-son championship today at the Morris County Golf Club.

NORFOLK, Va., July 11--Virginia's long-lived Byrd organization, the political machine that controlled the Commonwealth for 50 years, suffered a humiliating and apparently decisive defeat here today in a Democratic primary election that disclosed the strength of new suburban and Negro voters.
The Welfare Department opened a new center yesterday in Jamaica, Queens, despite the three-week-old work stoppage by many of its caseworkers.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 11-- An appeal by Premier Saad Jumaa to all Jordanian business enterprises not to lay off employes was published in the Amman press today.
A plan to spend $190-million over the next two years to expand capacity for producing paper was announced yesterday by Edward B. Hinman, president of International Paper Company.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- The negotiators for six railroad unions said today that they would withdraw their no-strike pledge if Congressional conferees did not make progress by Saturday toward legislation designed to handle the labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)--The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended today a farm bill containing $2-billion more than was voted by the House.

BALTIMORE, July 11--A wingless rocket plane that will seek ways for men to land at airfields after flights in space made its first public appearance today. The sleek, buglike X-24A was towed from a hangar by a small...
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 1l--The Hol land Festival is now 20 years old, yet it remains the enormous cultural supermarket it always was.
LONDON, July 11--The Suez Canal is blocked in three places.
ALBANY, July 11--Constitutional Convention leaders have told Mayor Lindsay privately that the convention will not give new taxing power to large cities.
New York City's water supply stood at 463.7 billion gallons--or 97.3 per cent of capacity--yesterday, according to the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
Mayor Lindsay's rebuff on his quest for true fiscal home rule for New York City at the Constitutional Convention will strengthen the growing pessimism over the course the convention is taking.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 11-- Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Bronner have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Kathleen Gerry Bronner, to Dr. Juan Bernardo Fiks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Fiks of Buenos Aires.
WHITE PLAINS, July 11--A lot of golf balls were hit by the 139 starters in the Westchester Open championship today as Roy Pace gained the lead with a four-under-par 67.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, July 12 (AP)--Terrorist attacks and threats stopped two-thirds of Hong Kong's public transport today as the police battled more Communist violence with shotguns, tear gas and mobile patrols directed from helicopters.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 11 --Prince Karim the Aga Khan IV, spiritual leader of the world's millions of Ismaili Moslems, has agreed to a Pakistani suggestion to help finance the purchase of arms by Moslem countries in the Middle East, diplomatic sources said here today.

Almost every policeman on foot patrol will have a walkietalkie linking him to his precinct, if a City Planning Commission recommendation is approved at a public hearing on the city's capital budget next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- The unemployment rate rose to 4 per cent in June, its highest level in a year and a half, the Labor Department reported today.
The Grand Union Company announced yesterday the appointment of Bertram S. Kaiser as vice president and general operations manager of its 31-unit Grand Way Department Store division.

SOME day, Ruth and Carlos Sansegundo plan to live in a house made of Lucite bricks and filled with plastic furniture. "Why not?" asked Mr. Sansegundo the other day. "Plastic is strong, cheap and beautiful." "And elegant and easy to keep clean," added his wife.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- George Meany asserted today that "physical abuse and unconstitutional arrest" of striking farm workers by Texas law officers had given new evidence of an urgent need to bring such employes under the National Labor Relations Act.
A member of a 70-man extortion ring that preyed on homosexuals received a maximum five-year sentence yesterday from Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper on conspiracy charges.

BOSTON, July 11--Senator Edward W. Brooke told the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People tonight that the civil rights movement would be betrayed by any effort to exclude white Americans.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (UPI)--Three United States players advanced to the second round of the Swedish international tennis championship today.
Open market sales of Manhattan real estate reached the lowest dollar volume in five years during the first quarter this year, the Real Estate Board of New York has reported.
JERUSALEM, July 11--Premier Levi Eahkol discussed the question of the holy places today with Msgr. Angelo Felici, the Vatican's Under Secretary of State for Extraordinary Affairs.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) --Members of the House Commerce Committee expressed concern today over cost and possible Government control of a proposed nonprofit public broadcasting corporation.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 11--Straddling a blue metal chair, Joe Frazier held out the hands that might be the first to flatten George Chuvalo. His trainer, Yancey Durham, was bandaging them with gauze and tape before the 23-year-old heavyweight workout today at the Concord Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- The Administration's new program to advance the economic welfare of American Indians was subjected to broad questioning today as a Senate panel opened hearings on the proposed Indian Resources Devel opment Act of 1967.

Earnings of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation were halved in the three and six months ended June 30, reflecting the unfavorable factors which adversely affected firstquarter results, the report disclosed yesterday.

IT is hardly news anymore that the great civil rights coalition has broken down and splintered apart, that white resistance to further integration--whether communityprogramed or sought by political means-- has discernably stiffened, or that Negro and -- white leaders seem to have "lost contact" with each other and with the increasingly frustrated and violence-prone youth of the northern urban ghettos.
JERUSALEM, July 11--An Israeli Army spokesman in Tel Aviv reported today another in the series of Suez Canal incidents that has led to a call for United Nations intervention.

TOKYO, July 11 (AP)--The Japanese Government plans to double or treple the number of industrial categories totally open to foreign investment around June of next year, informed sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The United States, increasingly uneasy about how far the Soviet Union intends to go in rearming the defeated Arab armies, today registered concern over "continuing" Soviet military shipments to the United Arab Republic.
A barber placating a child with a free lollipop is not very different from a supermarket rewarding a housewife with free trading stamps, a new advertising campaign suggests.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- Total construction activity continued essentially flat in May at levels well below a year ago, the Commerce Department reported today.
Helmsley-Spear, Inc., real estate brokerage and management company, has named Milton H. Sherman a vice president.

ROME, July 11--A "cultura revolution," similar to that being carried out in China and reported to be led by groups of Chinese youths, has closed down the last Roman Catholic church in Albania and is said to have caused the death of four priests, L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, said today.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 97.3 on Monday from 97.8 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, July 11--A study sponsored by the House Armed Services Committee has concluded that the Soviet Union will achieve a marked nuclear superiority over the United States by 1971 unless steps are taken this year to improve American strategic nuclear capabilities.
WHETHER one's daily bread is Arab hibbis, Jewish rye, Danish pumpernickel or American white, chances are that it is being baked somewhere in Brooklyn.
One of America's biggest companies is involved in an unusual move that offers a case history of what can be done by a business when events go awry.

NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (AP)--District Attorney Jim Garrison's office filed three charges Tuesday against Richchard Townley, a newsman for WDSU-TV here, accusing him of public bribery and intimidation in connection with a Kennedy assassination inquiry.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, July 11--Mr. and Mrs. Herman Raymond Marshall have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Susan Marshall of New York, to Douglas John Merton Graham, son of Mrs. Ellen de Eckhardt of New York and the late Col. Hugh Merton Graham, British Army, retired, ef Duivelshloof, South Africa.
Scientists appear on the road to controlling three serious insect pests--the black carpet beetle, the pine bark beetle and the town ant--by means of the insects' own attractants.

Dick Tracy, Chester Gould's popular cartoon hero, will be brought to the musical stage next spring. The show, capitalized at $500,000 and titled "Dick Tracy," is being prepared by Kay Lewis and Michael Colicchio, a new Broadway producing team. Assisting them will be Joseph Cusanelli, a member of the cast of "Fiddler on the Roof."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11--Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has told officials here that he is determined to hold to a minimum the number of additional United States troops sent to Vietnam, informed sources said today.

PITTSBURGH, July 11--A Northwestern University law professor said today that a new national organization was being formed to counteract the American Civil Liberties Union. It will be called Americans for Effective Law Enforcement.

HOYLAKE, England, July 11 --Jack Nicklaus is the man to beat as 130 golfers, including half a dozen of America's best, tee off tomorrow on the treacherous Hoylake links for the British Open, a classic now more than 100 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11--Two companies of South Vietnamese troops, outnumbered 4 to 1, beat back night-long attacks by North Vietnamese regulars yesterday 60 miles north of Saigon, a Vietnamese military spokesman announced today.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Wed- nesday, July 11--Striking ship- builders at the gates of New- port News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company became a rioting mob early today. Violence raged through the business district of this Tidewater city for two hours.

Paul G. Moeller, a founder and former board chairman of the Moeller Instrument Company, Inc., 132-02 89th Avenue, Richmond Hills, Queens, died of hepatitis Monday in Jamaica (Queens) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 217-15 Grand Central Parkway, Queens Village.
Phil Linz of Philadelphia and Chuck Hiller of the New York Mets exchanged baseball uniforms yesterday. The National League clubs completed the deal for the infielders through waivers.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 11 --Noroton Yacht Club skippers won in four of the seven main divisions, including both Lightning Class races, in the New York Yacht Club's 22d annual junior regatta today on Long Island Sound, conducted from the Riverside Y.C.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11--Following is the text of a letter to Secretary General Thant from Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel about a General Assembly resolution calling on Israel to rescind her actions altering the status of Jerusalem:

GLENS FALLS, N.Y.--Army Specialist 4 Gene F. Col- vin, whose wife in nearby Hudson Falls is expecting a second child any day now, stepped on a land mine 10,000 miles away and was killed June 29. He became, according to The Glens Falls Times grim report, the 15th Vietnam fatal-...

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) --The Johnson Administration is seeking a two-year, rather than a permanent, extension of its power to fix maximum interest rates that banks and savings and loan associations can pay to attract savings.
MONTREAL, July 11 (Canadian Press)--Guy Favreau, former president of the Privy Council, died in a hospital today. He was 49 years old.
ASHLAND, Ky., July 11 (AP) --Peggy Conley of Spokane, Wash., the defender, won her first match in the Women's Western Golf Association tournament today but it was a rough round for the co-medalists.
Large new corporate bond issues marketed yesterday underscored the slight decline in interest rates of the last two weeks. They also showed the drop might not be pushed too far.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11 (UPI)--Major league baseball players rejected today a proposal by the owners that would have raised their minimum salary to $8,500 immediately and to $9,500 in 1968.

The widow and daughter of William Faulkner, the author, and Random House, Inc., publishers, filed a copyright infringement suit yesterday in United States District Court against Cliff's Notes, Inc., a Nebraska corporation.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, July 12--A curfew was imposed over most of Hong Kong island last night as rioters took to the streets in the most widely scattered violence here since the Communists launched their campaign against the Government.

OSLO, Norway, July 11 (Reuters)--Ron Clarke of Australia set a track record for Bislet Stadium tonight in winning the 5,000-meter run in 13 minutes 39.8 seconds. His time was well outside of his own world record of 13:16.6.
Negotiators for the Board of Education and the teachers' union reported yesterday that they had reached agreement on a number of "personnel" items.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- President Johnson disclosed today his intention to nominate David S. Black, a lawyer and public power official, as Under Secretary of the Interior.
The marriage of Miss Brook Seawell to Dr. John Joseph Speidel took place yesterday afternoon at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The Rev. Alanson Houghton performed the ceremony.
Helicopters, boats and shore patrols will be used to keep people from digging clams and other shellfish from the pulluted waters surrounding the city, the Health Department announced yesterday.

The Latrobe Steel Company expects to report a sales increase of 10 to 12 per cent and a slight rise in earnings, for the first six months of 1967, compared with those for the first half of last year, Marcus W. Saxman 3d, president, said here yesterday.
DETROIT, July 11--The Ford Motor Company said today that some contract demands of the United Automobile Workers presented problems that appeared insurmountable at this time.
A 14-year-old Bronx boy was shot to death last night, apparently by a sniper, according to the police.

NEW HAVEN, July 11--Al Sherman, the coach of the New York Giants, announced today three impending position changes for his football team with the opening of training camp scheduled tomorrow at Fairfield, Conn.

Anyone who went down to the East River Park Amphitheater last night to hear the Orchestra of America play the opening concert in the 13th annual Evenings-by-the-River series of free summer concerts ...

By voting down by wide margins a series of meritorious proposals for court mergers, the Constitutional Convention has made a very bad beginning. Supporters of the status quo are clearly in the majority at the convention, at least on matters relating to the judiciary.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The opposition to the Administration's policy of intervening in foreign conflicts is obviously rising. The supporters as well as the opponents of the Vietnam strategy on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee ...
MOSCOW, July 11--Aleksandr N. Shelepin, regarded for several years as a potential candidate to head the Soviet Communist party, was named today chief of the Soviet trade unions, a second-level post.
AKRON, Ohio, July 11 (UPI) --The United Rubber Workers will strike the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company Thursday midnight if no contract agreement is reached, a union spokesman said today.

LONDON, July 11 (UPI)-- Harry F. Oppenheimer, chairman of two of the world's largest mining finance groups, said today that the maintenance of a fixed price for gold will ultimately mean the end of the gold mining industry and the replacement of the international gold standard.

The National Broadcasting Company was told yesterday that it would have to postpone for at least a year the production of a news documentary on Soviet prisons because of its telecast last night of the reminiscences of former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. [A review of the program on Mr. Khrushchev appears on Page 87.]
CHICAGO, July 11--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. announced today nationwide application of Operation Breadbasket.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11--Bill Freehan, the burly Detroit catcher, didn't look nervous when today's All-Star game began, but he sure seemed more worried than usual. He was handling the deliveries of Dean Chance for the first time and he had been warned about the unpredictable right-hander by a couple of experts, Bob Rodgers of the California Angels and Russ Nixon of the Minnesota Twins.
Senatorial criticism of the Administration's dispatch of three military transport planes to the Congo is exaggerated.
As the field in the third race at Aqueduct yesterday began to telescope on the far turn, Saul Nadler leaped to his feet and yelled, "There goes Yuck!"

The Action Committee on American-Arab Relations, a group with offices here, issued yesterday its analysis of the war with Israel. It called on Arabs to recognize their defeat and to become a 20th-century society capable of "a longrange, hard struggle to liberate their land."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 11 Mark Hirsch of Pine Hollow defeated Michael Rattner of Woodmere, 6 and 4, today in the quarter-final round of the Long Island Golf Association's junior championship at the Garden City Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 11--Secretary of State Dean Rusk, replying to Congressional criticism of American involvement in the Congo, asserted today that American military planes had been sent there as a political gesture to help head off a dangerous and mounting wave of antiwhite feeling.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) --Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, urged today legislation to outlaw the private arsenals now in the hands of such secret groups as the Ku Klux Klan and the Minutemen.

LAGOS, NIGERIA, July 11-- A federal military spokesman said today that Nigerian troops fighting to end the rebellion of the country's Eastern Region had met no surprises in their advance into the area.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11-- In the White Plains Community Church this evening, Miss. Susan Cartoun, daughter of Alan R. Cartoun of Rye and Mrs. Anne Vessey of Armonk, was married to Francis W. Juhasz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Juhasz of Pleasantville. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Peter H. Samsom.
The Police and the Hospitals Departments are trying to determine if the use of ambulance sirens is effective in saving patients, or whether it increases the number of patients needing help.

The McNamara visit to Vietnam, the Podgorny tour in the Middle East and the Kosygin trip to the United States reflect reappraisals by Washington and Moscow of unsuccesful military interventions abroad.

A plan for deploying "special judicial task forces" around the state to tackle court congestion is being developed by Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld. It is expected to go before the administrative board of the Judicial Conference with a hope for adoption this fall.
Cass Canfield, the chairman of the executive committee of Harper Row, will step down next month as chief executive of the publishing house, a position he has held for 36 years.
A drop in United States sales of 1968 models of imported cars was forecast yesterday by Heinz C. Hoppe, chief resident officer of Mercedes-Benz of North America.

Directors of U.S. Industries, Inc., voted yesterday to call a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 29 to authorize additional shares of common stock and special-preference stock for use in the company's acquisition program and for other corporate purposes. No equity offering is planned.

The Institute for the Study of Science in Human Affairs at Columbia University has received four grants totaling $460,000. The funds, including one corporate gift and three foundation grants, are in addition to the founding grant of $1-million received last November from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 11--The United Nations Command said today that 15 North Korean soldiers had been killed in nine "particularly serious" clashes with South Korean troops in the southern part of the demilitarized zone during the seven-day period ended July 5.
If the people won't come to the clubhouse, the Brooklyn Democratic organization has decided, then the clubhouse will go to the people --on wheels.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- Governor Romney has apparently executed a major shift in his position on the war in Vietnam.

Dr. Luis Francisco Thomen, medical liaison officer of the World Health Organization and former Dominican Ambassador to the United States, died Monday of a heart attack in Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 54 years old and lived at 251 East 51st Street.

The Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads late yesterday withdrew an offer they had made on June 29 to the Reading Company to talk merger with that 1,250mile carrier if it is not to be included in the Chesapeake Ohio Railway-Baltimore Ohio Railroad system.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 11 (AP)--Pierre Biger, 36-yearold steeplechase jockey, died of congestive heart failure, according to a report today from the Long Branch Medical Center, where an autopsy had been performed because of the circumstances of his death.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 11--Israel today rejected a General Assembly resolution asking annulment of the unification of Jerusalem and asserted that the city's administrative and municipal integration provided the legal basis for protection of the holy places.

Information on how to obtain certificates of birth or death can now be obtained by telephone 24 hours a day from the City Health Department, it was announced yesterday. Persons calling 247-0130 will hear a recorded telephone message giving instructions.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- The House Rules Committee brushed aside constitutional doubts raised by Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today and cleared for floor action Thursday an antiriot bill aimed at Negro leaders suspected of inciting violence.
RANGOON, Burma, July 11 (AP)--Burma has categorically denied Communist China's allegations that the Burmese Government instigated the three-day anti-Chinese rioting last week.
Frank F. Stark, one of the foremost bridge players in New York for the last 30 years, died yesterday at his home at 1130 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

Cotton futures soared for the second consecutive day on the New York Cotton Exchange. The advances came in the wake of the Government acreage report, released Monday, that placed cotton plantings at 6 per cent below the 1966 level.
The City Council last night approved Mayor Lindsay's proposal to merge almost all of the city's housing agencies into a single Housing and Redevelopment Administration.

YONKERS, July 11--While it has been apparent that the response throughout New York State to the lottery has been merery lukewarm, the opportunity to "win a lot for a little" has met with more than casual support at Yonkers Raceway.

Compton Russell of Jamaica upset David Palmer of Mountain Lakes, N.J., who was seeded third, 6-4, 6-2, in the quarter-final round of the 14year-olds division of the Eastern boys tennis championships yesterday.
The engagement of Mrs. Joanne Tree Thompson of 245 East 63d Street to Frederick M. Winship has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Nan B. Tree of Beverly Hills, Calif.

Two forthcoming graduate programs of New York University's School of the Arts will also involve two curatorial departments of the Museum of Modern Art, it was announced yesterday. The programs are in the school's Division of Drama and Cinema and its Institute of Film and Television. Both sections open this fall.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, the Senate's leading critic of wiretapping, was accused today by a Michigan judge of "wrong and un-American" distortion of facts.
LONDON, July 11--According to first-hand accounts reaching London, the Nigerian Army's initial attack on the secessionist Eastern Region has faded out with no major results.

BERLIN, July 11--Berlin's largest newspaper company, the publishing house of Axel Springer, was placed under police protection today following threats by left-wing students to stage sit-ins or otherwise disrupt business.

Maritime labor leaders and many shipping operators are beginning to worry about the outcome of a new "merrygo-round" of employment costs that they are impos ing on the country's merchant marine with, as they concede, "no end in sight." The words "me too" have become a catch phrase in the shipping industry.
DETROIT, July 11 (UPI)-- Abram vander Zee, former director and vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, died yesterday at the age of 73.
MOSCOW, July 11 (Reuters) --A Soviet audience today gave a warm reception to Robert Mulligan's "Up the Down Staircase," the United States entry for the fifth Moscow International Film Festival.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 11--Mr. and Mrs. Anson Burlingame have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Susan Harlow Burlingame, to William Fairchild Weidlich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton F. Weidlich of New York and Washington, Conn.
MIAMI, July 11 (UPI)--An immigration examiner ruled today that Felipe Rivero, a symbol of violent resistance by Cuban exiles to Fidel Castro, should be ousted from this country.

BOSTON, July 11--The children's bureau of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today grants totaling $90,042 for the establishment of a pilot project in child development as an adjunct of industry.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 11 --An estimated $60-million to $100-million tax cut for businesses will go into effect in Florida tomorrow. The savings will come from a cut in "stock in trade" assessments under which counties and cities have taxed year-end business inventories at full value.

LANSING, Mich., July 11-- Gov. George Romney called today for de-escalation of the bombing of North Vietnam and concentration on targets "directly related to the infiltration of men and supplies in South Vietnam."
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11-- The man who pitched for the National League at the start of last year's All-Star Game was pitching for television today and conceded: "Yes, I miss it."
The Dictaphone Corporation, producer of sound recording equipment, announced here yesterday the election of William L. Butcher as a director.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., July 11 (UPI)--Frank Beard vaulted into third place in the Professional Golfer's Association official money earnings by winning the $20,000 first prize in the Speedway open at Indianapolis.

Bernard B. Zients, executive head of Gimbels New York, announced yesterday that Ralph E. Waite, formerly vice president and assistant controller of Macy's New York, had been appointed controller of Gimbels New York and a member of its operating board.

THE New York Shakespeare Festival's Mobile Theater has picked a good title for its new children's show. "Lallapalooza," which will tour the parks through Aug. 19, is a cheerful, boisterous vaudeville show with something for everybody.
National Educational Television has received a $150,000 grant from the Sears, Roebuck Foundatton for production and national distribution of a Pittsburgh-produced program for Pre-schoolers.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) --Vice Adm. Leland P. Lovette, former public-relations director of the Navy and of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, died last night of a blood clot at Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 69 years old.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 11 (AP)--The general commanding United States forces in Vietnam, and a young soldier fighting under him, arrived home in South Carolina aboard the general's jet plane today to attend the funerals of their mothers.
VIENNA, July 11--Austria moved two army battalions to her Alpine border today to stop the movement of terrorists into Italy from the Austrian Tyrol.
The Symington Wayne Corporation filed suit here yesterday to enjoin Dresser Industries, Inc., from making a tender offer for shares of Symington Wayne.

GENEVA, July 11--Prof. John Horty of the University of Pittsburgh Law School said today that by the end of 1967 the school's computer will have the entire statutory law of the 50 American states on tape and available to answer queries by lawyers.

Virtually the entire taxicab industry here has formally protested an order that cabs be equipped with bullet-resistant glass partitions between the driver and the rear seat, and with timing devices on "offduty" signs.

Soviet foreign policy tends to be more ingenious than successful. A legend stressing such ingenuity is still told in Geneva about League of Nations days. As the tale goes, Sir John Simon, Aristide Briand and Maxim Litvinov met in a lakeside restaurant to discuss a GrecoBulgarian crisis.

"My dear man," said the sidewalk orator, appraising his heckler, "you just don't understand the basic simplicity of the war in the Middle East. The Russians are the manufacturers of arms, the Egyptians are the distributors, and the Israelis are the customers."
The City Council voted yesterday to fence in all automobile junkyards in the city and bar them from sight.

ANGUILLA, July 11 (Reuters)--Volunteers armed with rifles, pistols, hoes and rakes stood on beaches ready to fight off an invasion today as Anguillans voted in an independence referendum.
WASHINGTON, July 11--A large-scale Government contract for a prospective study of the effects of birth control pills was announced today by a unit of the National Institutes of Health.
BONN, July 11--President de Gaulle arrives here tomorrow for a semi-annual meeting with Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger as prescribed by the FrenchGerman friendship treaty of 1963.

NEWPORT, R.L., July 11-- At 12:30 P.M. today the New York Yacht Club race committee headed by Harry Anderson notified the personnel of the four candidates for the defense of the America's Cup that the trial racing was off for the afternoon. The committee had waited as long as it reasonably could for a heavy fog to lift, but it did not.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11-- Harry J. Karafin, former investigative reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer, was held over fox grand jury action today on two charges of blackmail, conspiracy and commercial bribery.

WESTON, Conn., July 11-- The engagement of Miss Lydia Faxon Green to Thomas Adams Rothschild has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Green, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Rothschild is the son of Mr. and Mrs. V. Henry Rothschild of Piermont, N.Y., and New York.
WASHINGTON, July 11--Breaking a seven-year stalemate, the Senate unanimously passed today a so-called truth-in-lending bill to help American consumers shop for the best bargains in credit.

Michael G. Tress, president of Agudath Israel of America, which promotes Orthodox Judaism through educational programs, died Sunday night of a stroke in Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn. He was 56 years old and lived at 586 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.
If past performance has any credibility, the New York Mets will win the annual Mayor's Trophy game against the New York Yankees tonight.
The Metropolitan Opera Company completed its first openair series in the city parks last week, and has already decided it would like to do it again next year.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 11 --A proposal of potentially farreaching implications to the maritime industry--that longshoremen take part in all phases of container handling operations, either at waterside terminals or at inland points-- was made here today.
THE DOLOROUS assessments of the Federal Com munications Commission's rate decision regarding American Telephone continue.

SALEM, Ohio, July 11-- Mrs. Elizabeth Deming Huxley, widow of Robert D. Huxley, was married this afternoon to Edward O. Wittmer of Quogue, L.I., a former insurance executive and retired Air Force colonel.
Sir Arnold A. Hall, one of Britain's leading aviation authorities, has been elected chairman of the Hawker Siddeley Group, Ltd., the company announced yesterday in London.

FRANK STARK, who died yesterday, was a leading figure in New York bridge from the early days of the game. In recent years he was most prominent as an administrator, serving as chairman of the Greater New York Bridge Association's board of directors and playing a major part in organizing the 1960 fall national championships here.
Two gunmen held up a West Side jewelry concern yesterday and escaped with $90,000 worth of assorted jewels.
Ravi Shankar, the sitar player, and two fellow musicians from India gave a concert at Philharmonic Hall last night and it was the most in event of the whole Lincoln Center Festival '67.

TAMPA, Fla., July 11 (AP)-- Tampa's merchants opened their doors to Negro job applicants today while the City Council approved an emergency shipment of riot-control weapons and gave the Mayor unlimited curfew powers.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which ranks first in New York and second in the nation in total assets and deposits, reported yesterday that net income from operations increased by 7.8 per cent during the first half of 1967.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) --Record United States crops of corn and wheat dominated production forecasts today in the Agriculture Department's first general crop report of the year.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 11--For the last three days at least, radio listeners here have been able to eavesdrop on personal telephone calls, for reasons nobody has been able to figure out so far.
The spot rate on the British pound eased again in moderate trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here. The closing spot quotation of $2.7886 was three points below Monday's final rate.
BONN, July 11--West Germany's Bundeswehr, the federal army, is facing a sweeping reorganization as a result of progressive budget cuts.
DETROIT, July 11 (UPI)-- Production of 1967 cars will top 7.6 million, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This would be down from the more than 8 million 1966 and 1965 models produced.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 11--The Bahamian Government has deported more than 2,400 Haitian immigrants in the last month, Government sources said today.
MOSCOW, July 8--The Soviet leadership is believed by experienced diplomats to be confronting a serious conflict between hawk and dove factions.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The Johnson Administration went to bat for the farmer today when the Interstate Commerce Commission opened nearly eight hours of arguments on the petition of the nation's railroads for a general freight rate increase, their first since 1960.
The London stock market closed firm yesterday with most shares ending the session at the day's highs.
C.W. Jordan, president since 1964 of the Ryder System, Inc., has resigned. E.M. Prussing, a vice president, also has resigned, it was announced yesterday.
The Soviet Government has "postponed indefinitely" a 10week tour of the United States by more than 200 performers, including stars of the Bolshoi Ballet.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 11 (UPI)--Some of the nation's top golf professionals will compete in the three-day Concord Hotel invitation tournament that opens Thursday.
SEATTLE, July 11 (AP)-- West Coast Airlines resumed service to 38 Western cities today, ending an eight-day shutdown caused by an Airline Employes Association strike.
An odd and drowsy little election took place yesterday in the northeast Bronx.
Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, issued a warning yesterday about what he termed the "serious level of speculative activity" on the exchange.

LONDON, July 11--King Hussein of Jordan is reliably reported to be willing to make a far-reaching deal with Israel that would enable the two states to exist side by side. It would take the form of an elaborate armistice but would not be a peace settlement.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) --A conscientious objector was fined $1,000 and sentenced to three years in jail today for refusing to obey his draft board's order to work at the state hospital in Norristown.

Traffic signal lights in lower and mid-Manhattan failed briefly yesterday at irregular intervals as light connections were shifted from old corner shaft poles to the new overthe-intersection mast arms.

WASHINGTON, July 11--In the most bitter speech he has yet made on Vietnam policy, Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, warned today that a third World War may be "already incubating in the ever-deepening struggle in Southeast Asia."
ALBANY, July 11--The Constitutional Convention completed today its rejection of proposals for major court mergers in the state.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- Senator John Stennis of Mississippi denounced as "a gross libel and slander" today the charges of a physician that the white establishment was trying to drive out or starve out Mississippi's Negroes.

Dr. Kenneth M. Lewis Jr., an associate in surgery of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died Monday in Metropolitan Hospital, after having suffered injuries in an automobile accident last December. He was 43 years old and lived at 8 East 96th Street. His office was at 1160 Park Avenue.
