HAVERFORD, Pa., July 11 --Mr. and Mrs. Walter William Beachboard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Louise Beachboard, to Pierrepont Geoffrey Noyes of New Haven, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierrepont Trowbridge Noyes of Oneida, N.Y.
JERUSALEM, July 11--Israel agreed today to discuss arrangements for the stationing of United Nations observers along the Suez Canal to supervise the cease-fire with the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) --All other members of a House Agriculure subcommittee disavowed today the chairman's attack on the American Farm Bureau Federation. They asked the full Agriculture Committee to do likewise.
NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (AP) --Lieut, Mario Biaggi of New York City, described as America's most decorated policeman, has been elected president of the National Police Officers' Associtaion of America.

TEL AVIV, June 11--A vibrant postwar battle of words between Premier Levi Eshkol and Defense Minister Moshe Dayan is considered by observers here to be symptomatic of a far more fundamental dispute in Israeli politics.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11-- The National League won baseball's 38th and longest All-Star Game today by defeating the American League, 2-1, on a 15th-inning home run by Tony Perez of the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- The Administration probably will send Congress soon a three-part trade bill, including an extension for two or three years of the unused tariff-cutting authority in the Trade Expansion Act.
Ralph Ginzburg, who has been convicted of sending obscene matter through the mails, received an invitation yesterday to a ceremony at the Post Office.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 11 (AP)--Dennis Ralston defeated Butch Buchholz and Louis Ayala turned back Sammy Giammalva tonight in opening matches of the $25,000 United States pro tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) --The Army is rationing one type of ammunition in Reserve and National Guard training in order to conserve supplies for the Vietnam war, officials said today.
Richard A.M.C. Johnson was elected yesterday as vice president of the Dreyfus Corporation, manager and underwriter of the Dreyfus Fund, Inc.

MEXICO CITY, July 11--The ruling Institutional Revolutionary party has announced that it won 87 per cent of the vote and 178 of the contested seats for Federal deputies in midadministration elections held last week.
GUATEMALA CITY, July 11--Enrique Engel, 86 years old, who is reputed to be one of Guatemala's wealthiest men, was seized near his home this morning by kidnappers who drove off with him in a sedan.
AN electronic epitaph to the life and times of Nikita S. Khrushchev was put together from a variety of pictorial sources last night for a vivid portrait of the deposed Soviet Premier.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (UPI)--Jorge Velasquez rode four straight winners at Monmouth Park today, starting his streak in the fourth race. The victories gave him 59 for the meeting and 217 for the year.
Odd-lot investors have swung to the buy side in July after months of sustained selling.

Don Kirshner, the former president of the music and record divisions of Columbia Pictures and Screen Gems, announced here yesterday the formation of Kirshner Entertainment Corporation to deal in music publishing, records and film and TV production.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) --Employers who refuse to hire a person because of his religious beliefs must prove that they would have faced undue hardship if they had done so, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled today.

A program of education and action on open housing, including the raising of funds for that purpose, was adopted almost unanimously yesterday by the biennial convention of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod.
Nearly a third of the victims of fatal fires in New York City last year were children under 12, the Fire Department said in its annual report, issued yesterday.
In West Germany, where advertising by oil companies can be somewhat more competitive than in this country, there's a brouhaha brewing over the Shell campaign promoting Platformate.

ONE of the big race meetings of the year for amateur drivers will be conducted by the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America on the Bridgehampton, L.I., course on Saturday and Sunday. More than 200 cars have entered the eight-race program.
TORONTO, July 11 (Canadian Press)--Dr. Charles Best, codiscoverer of insulin, has formally ended a career of 46 years in medical research.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 11 --Six armed men seized control of a Guatemala-bound freighter two miles off Miami Beach early today, wrecked the radio room and then went ashore in a lifeboat.

A former mental patient, who barricaded himself in his Brooklyn home yesterday afternoon, was shot in the stomach and critically wounded by a patrolman after he allegedly had tried to attack him with a meat cleaver.
The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would enter the jewelry business next month with a large line of high-fashion pieces to be called the Quintessa Collection.

The New York Stock exchange is finding it hard to get used to prosperity. Its latest income and expense survey on the commission business done by member firms in 1966, a year of soaring trading volume, implies that the exchange may have to press for higher commissions on putchases and sales of stock in order to protect profits.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11-- District Attorney Leonard Rubenfeld said today after a twoand-a-half-hour conference with the Rev. Martin Duffy of Mount Vernon that the clergyman could provide no information on crime in that city worthy of presenting to a grand jury.

The Corinthian Broadcasting Corporation went public yesterday as John Hay Whitney, the principal owner and a director, sold 750,000 shares that were priced by the underwriters at $24 each. The $18-million offering quickly sold out and the shares were quoted late in the day at 26 -27 .
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP)-- Mrs. Bertha Duppler Baur, millionaire, suffragette, lawyer and politician, died today in a Chicago hospital. She was 95 years old.
The United Fruit Company reported yesterday a rise in earnings for both the quarter and six months ended June 30.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 12-- There was reason for celebration in the Intrepid syndicate camp today when the America's Cup defense trials were resumed in midafternoon following a fog-bound morning. Both of its 12-Meter yachts came through to smashing victories.
William Henry Dennis 3d, a former director of the State Department's Far Eastern student program, died on Tuesday of a coronary occlusion near his home at 301 East 53d Street. His age was 54.

HOYLAKE, England, July 12 --A former British Ryder Cup golfer, Lionel Platts, chipped in from 60 feet for a first-hole birdie and went on to card a 68 for the opening-round lead in the British Open this hot, humid afternoon. The defending champion, Jack Nicklaus, shot a 71.

Trapped when fire struck a Manhattan mental health clinic, a psychologist soaked his shirt in spray from fire hoses so that he and his actress patient could breathe while they waited 45 minutes to be rescued.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Management and labor clashed sharply today over whether the National Labor Relations Board should impose a stiffer penalty on companies that illegally re fuse to bargain with trade unions.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 12-- United States diplomats are watching the preparations of far-leftist groups throughout the hemisphere in advance of the first meeting of the LatinAmerican Solidarity Organization, scheduled for July 28 in Havana.

Special to The New York Times ELIZABETH, N.J., July 12-- Paul A. Durning Jr. of 542 Magie Avenue, a former underwriter with Chubb Sons, Inc., insurance underwriters in Short Hills, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York after a long illness. A victim of hemophilia, he was 24 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy offered in the Senate today a plan to create jobs for the unemployed and unskilled in the slums through the use of private capital.
The Bolshoi Opera is still scheduled to appear here next year despite Tuesday's cancellation of a visit by another Soviet performing group.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --Mrs. Samuel C. Waugh, wife of a former Deputy Secretary of State, died in Doctors Hospital yesterday. She had suffered a stroke Monday.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) --George Kirby of Walsall, England, scored two goals as the New York Generals routed the Pittsburgh Phantoms, 4-1 tonight in a National Professional Soccer League game before 3,191 at Forbes Field. New York led, 2-0, at half-time.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Government announced new rules today defining the bank and savings-and-loan accounts that it will insure, up to a maximum of $15,000 per depositor.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 97 on Tuesday from 97.3 on Monday.

Special to The New York Times LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 12--A revised zoning ordinance designed to permit E.R. Squibb and Sons, the pharmaceutical company, to build an office and research. complex in a residential section of this community will be introduced at a special meeting of the township committee tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Senator Albert Gore, just back from talks with Arab and Israeli leaders, said today that proper Israeli handling of the problem of Arab refugees offered the key to durable peace in the Middle East, but so far Israel's action had Been "unfortunately inadaquate."
The bond market continued to work its way yesterday toward higher prices and lower interest rates.
Everyone was there except the object of all the attention.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The special committee that is trying to democratize the Democratic National Convention rejected unanimously today proposals for a quota system to insure Negro representation.
The Police Department and the Park Department will conduct joint traffic safety education programs twice daily for children in 22 recreation centers in the five boroughs, beginning today.

TROY, N.Y., July 12 (AP)-- Dr. Robert E. Plunkett, retired assistant state commissioner for tuberculosis control and an authority on TB, died today in Leonard Hospital after a long illness. His age was 77.
The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company's directors voted yesterday to organize and sponsor an equity investment fund.
VOLUME is booming in the over-the-counter market, but the list of gainers continues to be somewhat selective.
DETROIT, July 12--The United Automobile Workers unveiled today a plan to guarantee workers a yearly income.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after an afternoon recovery had trimmed losses posted earlier in the day.
MADRID, July 12--The Government reacted with restrained satisfaction today to the Common Market's decision to open negotiations with Spain next autumn for a preferential customs accord.
The appointment of Dr. Arthur Wayne Brown as dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of Fordham University was announced yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday a joint research and development program to deal with air pollution from motor exhausts through improved emission controls on automobiles.
ALGIERS, July 12--Rene Floriot, a French lawyer, visited Algiers for flue hours today to discuss the legal situation concerning Moise Tshombe's extradition case.

NORTH HAVEN, July 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Stewart Jackson of North Haven and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Suzanne Jackson Salisbury of New York, to John Gallup Cartier of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cartier of Chester; N.J.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 12--Thomas D. Luckenbill has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Mary Louise Luckenbill, to Hans Newlin Neuhauser, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward B.D. Neuhauser of Boston.

ATHENS, July 12--The Public Prosecutor of Athens today asked for the indictment of Andreas Papandreou, son of former Premier George Papandreou, on treason charges. The issuance of an indictment is a step before bringing the case to trial.
Amsted Industries, Inc., a diversified manufacturing concern in Chicago is making a tender for the stock of MacWhyte Company, Kenosha, Wis., maker of wire rope, slings, aircraft cable and tie rods.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 12--Mrs. William Tracey of Essex Fells, the defender, and Mrs. Edwin M. Burke of Somerset Hills, shared the lead today in the first round of the 44th annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association stroke-play championship at Rock Spring.

NEWPORT, Wales, July 12 (UPI)--John Newcombe, the Wimbledon champion, led an Australian sweep into the quarter-finals of the Welsh tennis championship today by beating Geoffrey Paish of England, 6-3, 6-1.

The president of the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that the union regarded the expansion of the city's More Effective Schools program "a top priority" matter in the current contract negotiations with the Board of Education.

Dr. and Mrs. Ahmed Farhad of Teheran, Iran, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Mina Farhad, to Van Vechten Burger Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burger of Cedarhurst, L.I., and 575 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that "some more" American troops would be needed in South Vietnam but not so many as to require a call-up of reserves.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 12 --Across the hall, George Chuvalo had disappeared amid the hissing of a shower. While the 29-year-old Canadian heavyweight cooled off after sparring five rounds today, his new trainer, Freddie Brown, spoke of what he hoped to accomplish for Chuvalo in next Wednesday's 12-round bout with Joe Frazier.

WHITE PLAINS, July 12-- The Rev. Martin Duffy of Mount Vernon will have a chance to tell a grand jury of his charges of organized crime and political corruption in that city. But the Westchester district attorney still believes he lacks direct evidence.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 12--A. Y. Allee, controversial Texas Ranger captain, was directed by his superior today to decline an invitation to testify before the Senate Subcommittee on Migratory Labor in Washington Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Walter J. Sheridan, an investigator for the National Broadcasting Company, said today that he would surrender to New Orleans authorities "in the next few days" in order to contest bribery charges brought by Mr. Garrison.
PEKING, July 12--Communist China charged that four United States Air Force planes fired two guided missiles at Chinese frontier guards today, injuring four soldiers and damaging a house.

SAIGON, Thursday, July 13 (UPI)--The United States com mand announced today that 13,000 American, South Vietnamese, Australian and New Zealand troops had launched a new offensive against the Vietcong 50 miles east of Saigon in some of the worst terrain in Southeast Asia. The area is laced with swamps and dense jungle.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 12 --Kenneth Rosewall lost a set to his fellow Australian, Malcolm Anderson, tonight in winning his opening match in the United States professional tennis championship on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)--The army surrendered today to powerful Congressional opponents of the Pentagon's Reserve reorganization plan and added three Reserve combat brigades, including 20,000 more Army reservists.

The sun never sets over the danger spots on which the Johnson Administration has to keep a wary eye. The Korean truce is being violated more often than the Israeli-Egyptian cease fire. North Korea is geographically dominated by her immense Chinese neighbor while she has been improving relations with the Soviet Union. Both these giants are linked to the Vietnamese war, where South Korea has an expeditionary force.
The Bath Festival Ensemble devoted its Lincoln Center Festival '67 concert at Philharmonic Hall to the chamber music of Brahms last night, and the choice of composer was just right.
EVANSTON, Ill., July 12--A panel of experts pushed a controversial subject a bit deeper into controversy today.
WASHINGTON, July 12--A New York member of the House of Representatives was sharply rebuked today by the House Agriculture Committee for his attacks on the American Farm Bureau Federation.
MADISON, Wis., July 12--The Wisconsin Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill opening the state's Presidential primary to all major candidates.

To New Yorkers accustomed to thinking of the suburbs in terms of tranquil, green-carpeted homes occupied by executives and their well-groomed wives and advantaged children, recent disclosures of deep underworld penetration in Westchester County come as an image-wrenching surprise.

Unless Federal police officials and the Office of Attorney General itself adhere strictly to the new regulations that forbid all wiretapping and control eavesdropping, the real intent of these commendable limitations may be honored in the breach. For the proscriptions must be respected in both legal and moral terms if safeguards against invasion of privacy are not to be overpowered by authorized trespass in the name of fighting organized crime.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 12-- Federal and rebel forces were reported to be continuing their battle today along the frontier between Nigeria and her former Eastern Region. Neither side claimed that seven days of fighting had produced any significant victories or changes in what remains a confused military situation.

GENEVA, July 12--The Interparliamentary Union has canceled the annual conference it was to have held this year in Moscow because the Soviet Union was not prepared to issue visas to a South Korean delegation, a spokesman for the organization said today.

ATHENS, July 12--Melina Mercouri, who is now appearing on Broadway in the musical "Illya Darling," was deprived of her Greek citizenshiptoday by the Athens military regime. In addition, the regime said that the actress's property in Greece was being confiscated.

Presiding Judge Lincoln G. Schmidt of the Suffolk County District Court was sued yesterday for $2.3-million by his brother-in-law, who contended that he had been "unlawfully, maliciously and wilfully" arrested twice at the judge's order.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) --A Honolulu-bound Pan American jetliner with 56 passengers and 11 crew members aboard returned to Los Angeles and landed safely today after an engine caught fire over the Pacific, airport officials said.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12-- In Reality, the only 3-year-old in the field, won the 22d running of the $23,650 Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park by 3 lengths today.

MINEOLA, July 12--The Nassau County ombudsman said today that he had found no basis for charges that the county's antipoverty program was a source of political patronage with big payrolls and no accomplishments.
WHITE PLAINS, July 12-- Roy Pace, a native of Texas, won the Westchester open golf championship today with a 54 hole total of 213.
ANGUILLA, July 12 (UPI)-- Church bells, cheers and street dancing accompanied an official announcement today of this tiny island's formal declaration of independence.
A patrolman routed the occupants of a building filling with smoke in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, then collapsed as he reached the sidewalk.

WASHINGTON, July 12--Military officials here are privately dismayed at news reports from Saigon that only about 70,000 of the 464,000 American servicemen in South Vietnam are combat troops and the rest rear-echelon support elements.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12 (AP)--New Jersey Turnpike officials are considering the installation of experimental scanning devices that register vehicles at toll booths, permitting drivers to enter or leave the highway without stopping for a toll ticket or to pay a toll.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan declared yesterday that Supreme Court restrictions on obtaining and using confessions had "significantly increased the chances that a criminal will escape judgment."

CAIRO, July 12--President Houari Boumediene of Algeria was reported to have pressed in his talks here and in Damascus for an "Arab military fund" to finance military preparations for the expulsion of Israeli troops from Arab territories they occupied in the brief Middle East war.

Mr. and Mrs. George Alexander Taylor of Lloyd Neck, L.I., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Pamela Wilmerding Taylor, to Airman 2d Cl. Peter Converse McDonald, U.S.A.F., son of Mrs. Converse McDonald of Marion, Mass., and W. James McDonald of Boston.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12--Miss Jo-Ann Schonfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Schonfeld, was married this evening to Michael I. Harrison, son of Milton S. Harrison of New York and the late Mrs. Harrison.
MOSCOW, July 12 (AP)--Stanley Kramer, the director, told a group of skeptical Communist correspondents today he only tries to satisfy himself when he makes movies.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12-- A legislator who has said he was offered a $50,000 bribe to drop a bill for dismembering the industrial community of Teterboro accused an Assembly committee today of conducting an inquiry that was "worse than a Star Chamber proceeding."

The contempt of court conviction of a witness who refused under the Fifth Amendment to answer questions by the judge in the trial of three asserted draft-card burners, was dismissed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 12 --Ron Weber and Gibby Gilbert, assistant golf professionals who came north less than two years ago, shared the lead after the first round of the 47th annual New Jersey open tournament.
THIS is one of the most interesting books on the earth's wildlife and its hazard ous conservation that I've read in years.

The City Council has approved, with some modifications, Mayor Lindsay's plan for merging the city's housing agencies into a single administration. This is not only an important forward step in itself, but also improves the prospects of the Mayor's other proposals aimed at improving the city's administrative efficiency.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 12 --Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Bruch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Graybill Bruch, to Capt. Richard Shaw Jones, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lippiatt Jones of Little Falls.
CAPE KENNEDY, July 12 (UPI)--Engineers,troubled by a short circuit tonight called off tomorrow's attempt to launch the Surveyor 4 moon robot.

TWENTY years ago, Debutante of Fredelsa won her championship, the first dachshund Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Onthank owned to accomplish the feat. Since then titles have come so often to the Rose Farm Kennels at Greenwich, Conn., that the Onthanks have long ceased...

In the wake of a United States Department of Agricultural report that wheat and corn production would hit record highs this year, futures prices of those commodities dropped markedly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Should Brooklyn Heights, recently recognized by the Federal Government as a National Historic Landmark, remain chaste and classical in its outward aspect?
State mental hospitals and training schools will increase the salaries of psychiatrists, starting July 27, to overcome an increasing shortage and to improve the therapy.

A theatrical business manager and an accountant were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of giving an Internal Revenue Service agent a $2,500 bribe to approve the 1964-65 income tax returns of Alan King, the comedian.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 12--There were many storybook aspects in yesterday's suspenseful All-Star game, including a somewhat fictional prologue that involved the hero, Tony Perez of the Cincinnati Reds. Arriving late at National League headquarters on the eve of the midsummer spectacular, he made the disturbing discovery that his hotel reservation had been misplaced and that no regular room was available. The chances were that the hotel manager had never heard of him.

PARIS, July 12--The fear of a major world recession triggered by slumps in the United States, West Germany, Britain and France was dismissed today by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

BUDAPEST, July 12--Soviet and Eastern European leaders ended a secret two-day meeting here today with a renewed pledge to cooperate in giving political support and economic and military aid to the Arab countries.

To the delight of the audience at Jacob's Pillow in Lee, Mass., on Tuesday night, Maria Alba's Spanish Dance Company presented a dance program that ranged from traditional flamenco to a form that looked like modern nightclub.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12-- Dr. MacEdward Leach, emeritus professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania, an authority on folklore, died yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 71 years old.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 12 (AP)--Israel will begin pumping from the oil fields in occupied Sinai this weekend, the daily newspaper Maariv said today.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 12 (AP) --George Barr, who flew in the last plane on the Doolittle Tokyo raid 25 years ago, and was the last of the raiders to return home, died today at the post hospital at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.
DETROIT, July 12--Sales of new cars in early July continued on the upswing, the automobile manufacturers reported today.
A 14-year-old Bronx boy was shot to death Tuesday night, apparently accidentally, by two other 14-year-olds who were playing with a .22-caliber rifle, according to the police.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon has maintained a lead in the last three months over other possible candidates for the 1968 Republican Presidential nomination, George Gallup wrote in The Washington Post yesterday in an article on his polls.
Lincoln Center: Bath Festival Orchestra, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.; lecture-recital, International Bach Society, Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 6.
Columbia University has been given a controlling interest in a new cigarette filter that its inventor says will make smoking "materially safer."

NEWARK, Thursday, July 13--Bands of Negroes went through a heavily Negro neighborhood in South Newark last night and early today smashing windows and looting stores. Several policemen were struck by stones.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 12--The engagement of Miss Jane Ruth Reynolds to Eric Mouney Swain has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Revere Reynolds, parents of the prospective bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. John Franklin Swain of San Francisco and the late Mr. Swain.
NORTHBROOK, Ill., July 12 (UPI)--Californians qualified for four of five spots on the United States road race cycling team for the Pan-American games in trials completed today.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 12--The Florida Legislature sent to Gov Claude R. Kirk Jr. today's crime fighting bill he has threatened to veto.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12--Of all the statistics and facts presented to him during his four days in Vietnam, Defense Secretary Robert S. MacNamara pointed to one--the condition, of the country's roads--as evidence of what he called "substantial" military progress.
The Long Island Rail Road had and operating loss of $4,150,795 last year, the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority announced yesterday.
Van Cliburn will appear during the Israel Philharmonic's four-week tour of the United States, starting at Philharmonic Hall July 29. All the artists are donating their services.
The BT New York Corpora- tion, a bank holding company formed by the Bankers Trust Company and three upstate banks, reported yesterday a 3.6 per cent gain in earnings for the first half.
NSUKKA, Nigeria, July 10-- The federal military government in Lagos has been maintaining that this key road junction and university town is "surrounded and under a state of siege."

CAIRO, July 12--Ahmed Hassan el Fikky, Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs, accused Israel tonight of "atrocities perpetrated against mankind during the recent war, and said: "Should Hitler emerge from his grave he would be terribly impressed."

MIAMI BEACH, July 12-- Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was re-elected today to his secondary post as president of the executive board of the union's Atlantic Coast District.

Though the script is all too familiar--a region's most dramatic natural feature threatened by the overdevelopers--it seems particularly shocking when the locale is the lovely island of Oahu in the fiftieth state.
A technician in a long white laboratory coat adds a light fluid to a pinch of brown crushed leaves and watches as the combination changes to a deep purple.

MRS. MOSHE DAYAN, wife of Israel's Minister of Defense, is returning home today after a hectic six-day visit to New York during which she drummed up business for her country's arts and crafts industry, worried about the renewed EgyptianIsraeli skirmishes along the Suez Canal, and was grateful that she had made most of the arrangements for her son's wedding before she left Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Senators of both parties accused the Administration today of being so bogged down in bureaucracy that it could not get food quickly to the hungry people in Mississippi and elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee began hearings today into the causes of deaths of newspapers.

Shareholders of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., approved yesterday at a meeting in Houston the acquisition of the North Judd Manufacturing Company and the South Puerto Rico Sugar Company. Shareholders also voted to reincorporate the company into a Delaware corporation, changing from a Michigan corporation.
EAST LANSING, Mich., July 12--Dr. Henry Siggins Leonard, university professor at Michigan State University, died yesterday in Frankfurt, Germany, where he was vacationing. He was 61 years old.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP)-- Mike Shannon smashed a two run homer off Pete Mikkelsen, a relief pitcher, in the eighth inning tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
THE creeping dry rot at the heart of fun city was in- terestingly diagnosed last night on Channel 9's halfhour documentary on the rise and fall of Times Square, entitled "The Great Blight Way."

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 12 (UPI)--The Government of President Joseph Mobutu today lifted a state of emergency in all but two provinces as the International Committee of the Red Cross attempted to arrange a temporary cease-fire in the rebellious eastern region.
Plans were disclosed yesterday for a national conference on black power that promises to bring together for the first time the many diverse elements of the Negro community.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP)-- Three major food concerns were named by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today as targets of Operation Breadbasket, a boycott campaign designed to gain more jobs for Negroes.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 12-- Another 131,000-barrel-a-day emergency increase in Texas oil production was authorized today by the Texas Railroad Commission to meet the needs of Western Eurpoe and the Eastern Seaboard of the United States, created by the lessened flow of petroleum from the Middle East.

Albert TenEyck Gardner, who had been associate curator of American Paintings and Sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the last 10 years, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment at 15 West 81st Street. He was 58 years old.

Queen of the Stage contributed a performance worthy of the divine Sarah as she scampered to a six-length victory over Gay Matelda in the $27,750 Astoria Stakes for 2-yearold fillies at Aqueduct yesterday.
The mail-order catalogue business, despite its sales lag now, is due for a round of intense competition.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, recommended today that cigarette manufacturers be forced to give the consumer stronger, more specific warnings about the health hazards of their products.

A SUCCESSFUL and unusual bridge event held Tuesday night at the Rochdale Community Center in Jamaica, Queens, was marked by a happy collaboration between the Metropolitan Unit of the American Bridge Association, the organization of Negro bridge players, and the Greater New York Bridge Association.

It was an active but indecisive day yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Prices opened firmly but moved downward until a low point was reached around 1 P.M. A rally developed in late trading and many stocks recouped earlier losses. Some even tacked on a gain.
Flowers may have bloomed in the month of May, but new residential construction activity wilted badly throughout New York State.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 12--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Glassmeyer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Warren Glassmeyer, to Colin Dee Mathews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Mathews of Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) The United Parcel Service announced today that it was discontinuing operations in the Philadelphia area.

The sixth customer yesterday at 10-year-old Erin Lynah's cool-drink stand, at Lenox Avenue near 129th Street, was a tall, blue-eyed man with disheveled hair, a loosened necktie and a sweat-soaked blue shirt that clung to his chest.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has delayed the premiere date of one of next season's new shows rather than run it opposite one of television's highest-rated programs.

Detailed plans for the construction of a pulp, paper mill and timberland complex to cost more than $100-million were announced yesterday by Roy J. Sund, senior vice president of U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., and executive vice president of Champion Papers.

Esso Petroleum Company, Ltd., the British subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), has reached an agreement with the National Union of Seamen to institute a plan putting seamen on annual salaries and permanent assignment to the company.
LONDON, July 12--A weary, strife-torn House of Commons approved the Labor Government's wage-price bill at breakfast time today after its second all-night debate on the measure.
WHETHER the subject is politics, love, life, hus band-stealing, the stage or a director she doesn't like, Melina Mercouri is one Greek who has a word for it--or, rather, many words, some corrdsive.
Richard M. Nixon denied yesterday that he had sought the release of Francis Gary Powers, the U-2 pilot shot down and imprisoned by the Russians, to help him win the 1960 Presidential election.

MONTREAL, July 12 (Canadian Press)--Alexandra Zabelina of the Soviet Union won the individual women's foil title tonight by defeating Antoinella Ragno of Italy, 4-2 in a fenceoff at the 32d world fencing championships.
It was a bus ride that Mayor Lindsay would not have enjoyed.
ASHDOD, Israel, July 12--Two Egyptian torpedo boats were intercepted and blown up by an Israeli naval patrol off the Sinai coast last night, according to a communique issued here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 12--Pakistan submitted to the General Assembly today a draft resolution demanding that Israel immediately rescind her actions for unification of Jerusalem and not take any new actions. The draft asks the Security Council to insure that the resolution is carried out.
If Tuesday was the day of baseball's All-Star Game, can the football season be far behind?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 --Mr. and Mrs. Ira Markwett have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lenore Markwett, to Alford Warriner Cooley, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Cooley of Washington and West Cornwall, Conn.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by the Amerada Petroleum Corporation, a large producer of crude oil and natural gas.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 12--Miss Margaret Jean Brewer and Ross Granville Harrison 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Edes Harrison of New York, plan to be married on Aug. 19 at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less.
HUNTINGTON, L.I, July 12 --A 19-year-old college student pursued a bank robbery suspect here today and subdued him as $6,000 was scattered about a shopping center parking lot.

CAIRO, July 12--The Egyptian high command announced today that its forces destroyed two Israeli vehicles and two tanks in two artillery duels across the Suez Canal cease-fire line this morning and early afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (AP)--A Pennsylvania industrialist was charged today with interfering with a commercial airline flight crew.

SYRACUSE, July 12--Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Bernstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Faith Bernstein, to Jeffrey Stewart Zients, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard B. Zients of Hillside, N.J.
Ray Stark, the movie producer whose first Broadway effort "Funny Girl," recently closed after a run of 1,348 performances, reported yesterday that he was preparing his next Broadway musical.
ALBANY, July 12--The Constitutional Convention began looking for possible compromises today in its dispute over whether New York's voting age should be lowered from 21 to 18.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Business inventories recorded their smallest increase in more than two years in May --a total of only $50-million.
WHEN Lueretha McGriff was graduated in 1950 from William J. Maxwell Vocational High School in Brooklyn, she had high hopes of becoming a dress designer.

QANTARA, United Arab Republic, July 12 (AP)--Egyptian snipers opened fire twice from positions on the west bank of the Suez Canal as an Israeli patrol drove south toward Ismalia today. Two Associated Press newsmen accompanied the patrol.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12--Thirty-five soldiers of the United States Fourth Infantry Division were killed and 31 wounded today in a new battle with North Vietnamese regulars in the Central Highlands, a spokesman for the division said.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino will sail next Monday on the Michelangelo for a sevenweek visit in Italy that virtually will be a state visit.
ROCKLAND, Me., July 12 (AP)--Edward C. Moran, Jr., former United States Representive from Maine and twice unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Governor, died today at his home. He was 72 years old.

Nearly six days of detective work and 2,400 interviews resulted last night in the arrest of a Brooklyn gasoline station owner in the fatal shooting of a teen-age girl on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn last Friday.
The National Board of the Coat and Suit Industry hopes to make its products better known in the Negro market by placing a series of ads in Ebony magazine.
LOS ANGELES, July 12--The California Motor Vehicle Pollution Control Board approved smog control systems today for the 1968 models of five American and eight foreign automobile manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Department of Justice urged the Federal Maritime Commission today to revoke its approval of a steamship conference agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The United States and the other industrial countries may decide to permit the full Kennedy round tariff cuts all at once on goods from less-devel- oped countries instead of staging the cuts over five years.
An organization of professional engineers filed suit here yesterday to compel Mayor Lindsay to appoint a licensed engineer as Commissioner of Buildings "as required by law."
BONN, July 12--President de Gaulle received a hearty welcome from Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger when he arrived today at Wahn Airport for the semiannual FrenchGerman meeting.
The atomic power industry moved ahead yesterday on several fronts. The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago announced plans for building a 2.2 million-kilowatt nuclear power station at Zion, Ill.
John F. Hamilton, stage and screen actor, died Tuesday at Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus, N.J. He had lived since 1962 at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 73 years old.
The Gallery of Modern Art, which remained open until 11 P.M. daily in May and June, is now closing at 8 P.M.

NEW ORLEANS, July 12-- John Cancler, a convicted burglar, refused today to confirm or deny his nationally publicized statement that investigators for District Attorney Jim Garrison had once asked him to plant evidence in the home of a suspect in Mr. Garrison's inquiry into the assassination of President Kennedy.

World opinion is against the unilateral measures Israel has taken regarding the Old City of Jerusalem. These measures approximate annexation. Israel's refusal to rescind them, as demanded by the General Assembly, is now headed for criticism in another formal resolution.

JERSEY CITY, July 12-- James S. Wear has been named publisher of The Jersey Journal, it was announced today. He succeeds Fred A. Stickel, who has been appointed assistants publisher of The Oregonian, in Portland. Both newspapers are owned by S.I. Newhouse.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --After the Republican Senators had issued their statement, Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said it was painful to him to see a committee member "raise a partisan banner of politics at the expense of human welfare." Mr. Stennis is not a member of the subcommittee but has been attending the hearings.

CHICAGO, July 12 (UPI)-- The sole survivor of last summer's massacre of eight nurses and the families of the victims today sued Richard F. Speck, the killer, two taverns and the nurses' hospital for $4,275,000 damages.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- A bill sent to the Senate today would enable the Federal Government to take court action or any other step necessary to halt air pollution anywhere in the country if it presented an imminent danger to human health.
OSLO, Norway, July 12 (AP) --Martin Tranmael, a leading Norwegian Socialist and tradeunion leader, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 88 years old.
Stock prices continued to climb over a fairly broad front on the London stock market yesterday.
BONN, July 12 (Reuters)-- The French-German talks are to continue tomorrow, and the problem of British entry to the Common Market is expected to be discussed.
Seven months of public inquiry by the State Public Servlice Commission into the electric rates of the Consolidated Edison Company came to a close yesterday.
HANOVER, N.H., July 12 (AP)--Halsey C. Edgerton, retired treasurer and business director of Dartmouth College, died last night at his home here after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

DENIS STRENZWILK, a graduate student at Clark son College, Potsdam, N.Y., won the recent New York State Amateur Chess Championship at Auburn. In this five-round Swiss system, Strenzwilk, who scored 4 - , was tied in game points with Matthew Katrein of Albany, but was awarded top honors after a tie-break count.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Most Rev. William J. McDonald, one target of criticism by striking teachers and students last April, announced today that he was stepping aside as rector of the Catholic University of America.

"I never saw so many twins in my whole life," said 9-yearold Raymond C. of East Harlem who is attending Camp Hidden Valley, one of the seven Fresh Air Fund camps on a 3,000-acre natural wilderness tract near East Fishkill, N.Y.

The Senate's passage of the so-called truth-in-lending bill last Tuesday will undoubtedly be signaled as a major leap forward in protecting American consumers, who bought $92.5-billion of goods on credit last year.
CLEVELAND, July 12 (UPI) --Sam McDowell scattered six hits and Max Alvis hit his 11th home run as the Cleveland Indians defeated the league-leading Chicago White Sox tonight, 5-3.
The Court of Appeals has vacated the bribery conviction of Hyman E. Mintz, the Republican Assemblyman who died March 25, 1966, about 40 hours after he had been sentenced to a year in jail.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Something unknown, but seemingly related to a cancer that is common in Africa, has left an identifying mark in many Americans, scientists found.

ABOARD U.S.S. CONSTITUTION, off North Vietnam, July 22--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, South Vietnam's chief of state and the military regime's candidate for President, said today that South Vietnam's armed forces should be increased, but he warned that full mobilization would do more harm than good by disrupting the nation's economy.
BERLIN, July 12--Premier Kosygin was believed to have reported at the Budapest meet ing on his talks with President Johnson at Glassboro, N.J.,on June 23 and 25.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) --The Navy said tonight that it had declassified several files concerning the ill-fated aroundthe-world flight of Amelia Earhart, the American aviatrix.
HONTDORF-LES-BAINS, Luxembourg, July 12 (AP)--Tennis officials from 35 countries, led by the Eastern European bloc, slammed the door today on Britain's plan for open tournaments.

A new Federal agency began hearings here yesterday to determine how to prevent accidents like the New York Central freight collision on May 22 at West 147th Street in which six crewmen were killed and six were injured.
JERUSALEM, July 12--Israel was reported tonight to have assured the Vatican that she would agree to a juridical formula establishing the "universal status" of the holy places in Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --Three South Koreans, including a research chemist at the University of Notre Dame, have returned home voluntarily to tell what they know about a North Korean spy network in Berlin that was aimed at Korean students in the United States and Europe.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12--George Forrest, who represents a Northern Ireland constituency in the British House of Commons, was (knocked unconscious today at a parade sponsored by the Orange Order, a 50,000-member Protestant movement that supports Northern Ireland's connection with Britain.

STANTON, Del., July 12 (AP) --In an upset comparable to the defeat of Damascus in the recent William du Pont Jr. Handicap, Furl Sail had to settle for third money in the $18,390 Rosenna Stakes at Delaware Park today. I Be Dandy was awarded first position through the disqualification of Lewiston.
The New York Philharmonic will give four different programs during its 12-concert, free outdoor series in city parks that starts Tuesday.
Riding high lately, the New York Mets brushed aside the sinking New York Yankees, 4-0, at Yankee Stadium last night as several patterns concerning the annual Mayor's Trophy game retained their shape.
The tall, dark-eyed girl, dressed in a minidress, white fishnet stockings and with her hair done in an ultra-contemporary Vidal Sassoon cut, was asked what was her favorite stage role.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- In a move that could cost the United States millions of dollars of badly needed exports, the European Common Market has quietly set in motion a change in its farm program to increase the production of corn and other feed grains.
The latest entries into the international race to build 300 modern, general-purpose trampships to replace the aging fleet of 800 Liberty ships were displayed here yesterday.

HONG KONG, Thursday, July, 13--The widest curfew in two months of anti-government agitation was imposed last night as rioting erupted for the fourth night in several areas of the colony and a new border threat was reported. Two persons were reported dead and two wounded.
"What an unreal world," Piri Thomas moaned at the silent faces staring up at him from the audience. "Man, what an unreal world."
LONDON, July 12--The uninhabited Inner Hebrides island of Staffa, famed for its caves, one of which inspired Mendelssohn's "Fingal's Cave" Overture, is for sale.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Internal Revenue Service acknowledged today that during the eight years from July, 1958, to July 1966, its agents had made "improper" or "questionable" use of electronic eavesdropping devices on 287 occasions.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP)-- Negotiators renewed efforts today to head off a strike threatened for midnight Friday at eight major copper companies.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to submit the 24day old labor dispute in the Welfare Department to factfinding and criticized the city's failure to do so as "rigid and arbitrary."
INDIANAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) --Cliff Richey, seeking his third straight title, was the only American left in the Western men's singles tennis championship after the third round today.

ALBANY, July 12--Antonio A. Sorieri, First Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services, died yesterday in Albany Medical Center Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Hampton Manor, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The other day in Cincinnati the Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth--once a lieutenant of Martin Luther King in the nonviolent upheavals in the South--told Gene Roberts of this newspaper that the basic reason Negroes rioted was that "they say, 'we've already tried nonviolence and we're still where we are.'"

HALIFAX, N.S., July 12-- Nifia, the 58-foot scratch boat out of Kings Point, L.I., was named the Class A and over-all winner of the Marblehead-toHalifax ocean race today. She crossed the finish line off the Royal Nova Scotia Yacht Squadron club at 11:45.26 last night.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Thursday, July 13--Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr. of Virginia obtained an agreement early today for a continued suspension of union picketing at the nation's largest private shipyard here. The picketing triggered a predawn riot yesterday.

MANTOLOKING, N.J.-- "Cooking aboard should be simple and quick," Mrs. William G. Mennen Jr. said recently as she sat on the porch of her home here. A few feet away, the water of the lagoon lapped at the hull of the Dolly M., the Mennens' 55-foot Chris-Craft yacht.
BOSTON, July 12--Opponents of Roy Wilkins are working the lobbies of the 58th annual N.A.A.C.P. convention in the hope of forcing a floor debate on black power and the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The Senate overrode surprisingly vigorous opposition today and approved the selection of Weston, Ill., as the site for the Atomic Energy Commission's new multimillion-dollar atom smasher.
PARIS, July 12--The Government announced today that it would issue a decree giving French workers a share in the profits and ownership of industry.
The speculative fever that has been infecting the Amer ican stock Exchange has spread to the over-the-counter market.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 12--The Dutch are said to be a very modest people. Perhaps this is why they seem to find it necessary to possess not only one of Europe's best ballet companies but also one of Eu- rope's worst. The Holland Festival offered both of them in juxtaposition, the enormous Netherlands National Ballet and the tiny Netherlands Dance Theater. The two companies certainly provide a striking contrast, like that between David and Goliath.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The chairman of the House Banking Committee accused Governor Rockefeller of New York today of operating "a lottery racket" to avoid taxing his family's multimillion-dollar foundation.

WASHINGTON, July 13--Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 8 which include the Independence Day holiday week were both below the corresponding 1966 holiday week.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Evan Mecham, an Arizona publisher, testified today that "monopolistic" newspapers in his state exercise a "dictatorship" over statewide elections.

Lieut. Col. Saturnino P. Rigor of the Philippine Army and Mrs. Rigor of Manila have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Rigor, to Lewin B. Barringer. He is the son of Mrs. A Morris Shober of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Maj. Lewin B. Barringer, Army Air Forces, of Philadelphia.

"Lohengrin" fizzled. Andrei Voznesensky and 200 fellow Russians couldn't make their date. Almost everybody wanted to see the Metropolitan Opera. The Czechoslovak film program sold out. The Indian sitar player drew an overflow crowd, people sitting on stage.

KIAMESHIA LAKE, N.Y., July 13 Wayne Yates, the lean 25-year-old precision shooter from Atlanta, emerged with a par-shattering 68 today in the Concord Hotel Invitation Golf Tournament and said he had played the greatest round of his brief career.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The House Commerce Committee voted today, 14 to 13, for a $58-million program to help hospitals add enough new beds to serve 150,000 additional patients.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 13 The Peace Corps has quietly gone out of business in Pakistan, where it had one of its most ambitious programs.
ON either side of the footlights, Shakespeare's King John" can be a difficult play.

DEEP COVE, N.S., July 13 (AP) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union feels that China can be bypassed in an agreement to settle the war in Vietnam, Cyrus S. Eaton, the industrialist, said today.

The Associated Councils of the Arts, a nonprofit organization serving state and community arts councils and national arts institutions, has begun publication of Cultural Affairs, a magazine containing views, reports and information on the arts.

ALBANY, July 13 Joseph H. Murphy, State Tax Commissioner and administrator of the New York lottery, said that the Patman bill passed by the House today was "an undesirable intrusion by the Federal Government in an area which has traditionally been the province of the states."
THE Soviet Union is about to see some of the best that America has to offer in fashion.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 Dr. Walter A. Jacobs, an organic chemist who aided the development of cortisone, the antiarthritic hormone, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old. He retired in 1949 as a member of the Rockefeller Institute of New York, now Rockefeller University.

BRISTOL, England, July 13--As ballet companies go, 10 years is no venerable age, but Western Theatre Ballet, which is celebrating its 10th birthday here and in London, is only the fourth British dance company ever to enter a second decade, so congratulations are in order.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Prokoski have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francine Gerri Prokoski, to Lieut. John Augustus Ricci of the Army Signal Corps. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Olindo Ricci of the Bronx.

BONN, July 13 The West German Government has demanded the recall of three South Korean diplomats involved in the disappearance of 17 South Koreans from West Germany, the Foreign Ministry announced today. The names of the diplomats were not given.
Officials upstate denied and ridiculed yesterday an assertion by Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman that hunger existed in seven counties beyond the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The House presented New York's lagging lottery with a new threat today by voting, 271 to 111, to ban the sale of the sweepstake tickets by Federally insured banks.

JERUSALEM, July 13--The sweeping response of Jews throughout the world in support of Israel during the Middle Eastern crisis has motivated an assembly of Jewish leaders to seek ways of strengthening international channels of Jewish community life.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 13 (AP) Federal mediators entered the turbulent Newport News shipyard strike today as helmeted state policemen guarded against a new outbreak of the violence that has injured more than two dozen persons.

As if to prove that a no-star game can last as long as an All-Star game, the New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians battled through 15 innings at Yankee Stadium last night before the Indians won, 4-3.

MOSCOW, July 13 Officials of the State Committee for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries indicated uncertainty today over planned visits to the United States of two major Soviet artistic ensembles.
LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) Queen Elizabeth II will allow her divorced cousin, the Earl of Harewood, to marry his Australian-born mistress, it was announced tonight.

Mrs. Pauline B. Charney, a teacher of emotionally disturbed children and the wife of Herman Charney, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital after a long illness. She was 57 years old and lived at 255 Lake Shore Drive, Pleasantville, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that his plan to rehabilitate or replace up to 400,000 substandard dwelling units in the nation's slums would cost the Treasury no more than $50million annually.

United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau yesterday urged persons to report, cases in which default judgments had been entered or garnishments, filed without any notice to the victim that he had been used.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 13 Now add music to the sun, sand and sea that are year-round attractions of this resort city. The second annual Florida International Music Festival began last night with a concert by the London Symphony Orchestra. And from now through Aug. 6, the Peabody Auditorium will be filled with the sights and sounds of concerts and operas.
The Ford Foundation, in an unusual move, made a grant of $175,000 yesterday to the Congress of Racial Equality to help improve racial relations and opportunities for Negroes in Cleveland.
PARIS, July 13 (UPI) Frenchmen prepared to celebrate tomorrow the 178th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille. Banks and businesses were closed at noon today.
New York City's borrowing costs rose again yesterday with the sale of a $102-million bond issue at an average interest rate of 4.52 per cent.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 13 (AP) The 900 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation here will be laid off gradually before the end of the year as the company is liquidated, company and union spokesmen said today.
Only 15 per cent of Medicare and Medicaid funds are being spent to improve patient care State Senator Seymour R. Thaler charged yesterday.
If you have $50,000 and don't live in Asbury Park, Buffalo or any "small city," you can open your own Arthur.
Five leading architects will design six new public housing projects in the city, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Mike Epstein pounded Detroit pitching for a double, triple and ' two home runs and batted in six runs tonight as the Washington Senators swept a double-header from the Tigers, 8-3 and 6-1.
HAVANA, July 13 (AP)--Premier Fidel Castro, whose previous exploits have included pitching in a baseball game and appearing in a soccer match, now has tried another field--basketball.
Mayor Lindsay has agreed to allow Mitchell I. Ginsberg, Commissioner of Social Services, to go to Jerusalem for two weeks to help it reorganize its Social Welfare Department.

Columbia University's tests on the new, Strickman cigarette filter were performed at the Fitelson Laboratories, Inc., which has been described as "an excellent laboratory" 'by the American Cancer Society.

QANTARA, United Arab Republic, July 13 (AP) The Middle East war is still going on for the tense Israeli veterans in this battle-scarred town on the east bank of the Suez Canal. They are facing Egyptian soldiers only 150 yards away, across the deserted canal.
News stories about the development of a new cigarette filter by an independent research company lit up the tobacco stocks yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and kept them aglow all day long.
WATERLOO, Iowa, July 13 For two successive summers, Negro rioting has erupted in Waterloo and for two successive summers whites have asked the same question: "Why Waterloo?"

THE Vickers "Favorite 50," an analysis of investment company portfolios, showed that the steel group accounted for an impressive 12.5 per cent of all holdings at the end of 1959. That was the year when steel stocks topped out and began their long decline.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (UPI)--John Biggs Jr., retired judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, today became the second Federal judge here in a month to resign as a Quaker over the shipment of medical supplies to the Vietcong.
A group of internationally known artists, including Edward Albee and Leonard Bernstein, are campaigning to get other artists to boycott the Athens music festival this summer.
Bittersweet strains of George Gershwin drifted across City Hall Park during the noon hour yesterday and mingled with the growling of trucks and buses on Broadway.
The General Assembly debate on Jerusalem demonstrates again the damage Israel has done to its own interests by moving to unite the former Jordanian sector with the Israeli new city.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The space agency took the biggest step toward production of quieter jet aircraft engines today since President Johnson opened a drive on jet noise 16 months ago.

PARIS, July 13 (UPI) A virus believed by some scientists to be related to the cause of leukemia and lymphoma "has been caught in the act of infecting, reproducing in, and killing certain human cells," a prominent cancer researcher said today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Senate confirmation of Thurgood Marshall's nomination to the Supreme Court was delayed today as Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, questioned Mr. Marshall at length about his views on defendants' rights.
Interest rates held steady yesterday as some large new corporate and tax-exempt issues reached the market with varying degrees of success and other sales were announced.
HONG KONG, Friday, July 14 The police early this morning raided the premises of a Com munist-led dockworkers union with the support of British troops.

CAIRO, July 13 The United Arab Republic has opened an attack on its most dangerous internal enemies the cotton worm and related pests that threaten to eat up the country's only major remaining source of, foreign exchange.

The International Business Machines Corporation, which accounts for about 75 per cent of the nation's computer business, continued to add to its earnings growth rate in the quarter and half-year ended June 30.
Robert Kusberg, a 65-yearold house painter, jumped to his death from the top of the 27-story One Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, despite the efforts of a policeman to persuade him not to do it.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 12 Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling indicated displeasure with the British-appointed Governor and Commissioner of Police in an interview in his office today.

SANTIAGO, July 13 The leaders of Chile's ruling Christion Democratic party have declared that guerrilla warfare against governments that "ignore the people's rights and offer no electoral solutions" is a legitimate course of action in Latin America.

"The King Dies," by Eugene Ionesco, has been added to the repertory schedule of the Association of Producing ArtistsPhoenix for this season. The troupe will perform it first in Los Angeles, starting Sept. 1, and later at home here at the Lyceum.

Theodore De Lisi, accused of the ftal shooting of a teen-age girl on the Belt Parkway last week, was described in court yesterday as a harmless man who once lived near, and knew, the girl and her family.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., which sells stocks, held a forum yesterday on the stocks of advertising agencies, which sell such things as products and images.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13 Howard Black, who played a major role building advertising linage for Time and Life magazines in their early days, died today at the Greenwich Hospital. Mr. Black, who retired as executive vice president of Time Inc. on Dec. 1, 1962, was 70 years old. He lived on Riversville Road here.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ordered deep cuts today in President Johnson's $2.5billion request for economic foreign aid funds.

GENEVA, July, 13 More than 2,000 lawyers from all over the world urged the United Nations General Assembly today to assume "jurisdiction and control" over the vast mineral resources of the high seas and the ocean bed underneath.

CAMPOBELLO, N.B., July 13 Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain crossed the fogshrouded Bay of Fundy today to become the first official tourist to enter the reception center of the Roosevelt Campobello Park.

Repeal by the Constitutional Convention of the present ban on state aid to denominational schools seems increasingly probable. This retrograde step would weaken the fundamental policy of separation of church and state and seriously endanger the publicschool system.
Five women musicians who call themselves the Ladybirds and who appear on stage barebreasted, were ordered into court last night after their first apperance in New York.

DALLAS, July 13 The engagement of Miss Lillian Marlene Mirkes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl R. Mirkes, to Pvt. Niels M. Johnsen has been announced by the future bride's parents. The prospective bridegroom, who is serving with the Army at Fort Dix, N.J., is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Niels W. Johnsen of Rumson, N.J.

LONDON, July 13 Brig. Gen. Chaim Herzog, who called himself "the first Jewish governor of the west bank of the Jordan in 2,000 years," said tonight that Israel was seeking "some form of associations or understanding" with Jordan.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 (UPI) Bill Mazeroski hit a homer in the sixth inning tonight and singled to drive in another run during a four-run seventh-inning rally as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-5. Bob Veale gained his 10th victory of the season.

Columbia University yesterday released tables to demonstrate the effectiveness of Robert L. Strickman's smoking filter. Tests on the material were performed at Columbia's, request at Fitelson Laboratories, Inc., of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 13 President Johnson declared today there is an "urgent need" for Israel to permit Arab refugees in Jordan to return to their homes in territory seized by Israel last month.
BRUSSELS, July 13 Jean Rey said today that he saw a political as well as an economic role for the newly merged independent executive of the European Common Market.

MOSCOW, July 8 Literary Moscow is convinced Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has won the battle for publication of at least one of his suppressed novels and most writers predict that Soviet literary censorship will vanish next year.

BOSTON, July 13 Cecil B. Moore, president of the North Philadelphia branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, threw up a picket line this afternoon in front of the Sheraton-Boston Hotel to harass Roy Wilkins, the leading advocate of constitutional methods in the civil rights movement.
The midyear report of the F.W. Dodge Company, leading compiler of construction statistics, forecast an 8 per cent rise in housing starts for the year.
PARIS, July 12 France has introduced a new wild card in the diplomatic poker game she is playing to keep Britain out of the European Common Market.
The two municipal contract negotiations that will most affect New York City's fiscal health for 1968 are those involving teachers and transit employes.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 13--Informed sources said today that King Hussein had begun a sweeping reorganization of the Jordanian Army.
LONDON, July 13 Britain's trade deficit widened in June, almost reaching the broad level of April.
The free reserves in the banking system a key indicator of credit policy have jumped to the highest daily average in five and a half years.

YONKERS, July 13 Canadian-owned colts finished one two, three in the $25,000 Su Mac Lad Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway, with Halifax Hanover in a mild surprise taking the $13,750 winner's share of the purse. Joe O'Brien steered the bay son of Hickory Smoke to a three-quarters-of-alength margin over Murray Mir, who finished a neck in front of Marcel Hanover.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Mrs. Thomas Maurice Fitzgerald has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Michelle Fitzgerald, to William Francis Mohan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mohan of Buenos Aires, formerly of Forest Hills, Queens.
DALLAS, Tex., July 13 (AP) Two teams of veterinary researchers said today they had identified a virus that causes the death of chickens.

WASHINGTON, July 13 If you introduce a city looking for a symphony orchestra to an orchestra looking for a city, the result has to be a happy marriage. The city is Columbia, Md., and the orchestra is Washington's National Symphony.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 13 A September wedding is planned by Miss Marina Mary Craven and Jacques Charlton Guequierre. Mr. and Mrs. David Craven have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Jacques Pierre Guequierre of St. Davids, Pa.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Surgeon General William H. Stewart said today that no cigarette filter could give complete protection even if it removed all of the tars and nicotine from the smoke.

Yehudi Menuhin and his Bath Festival Orchestra brought their six-concert engagement at Philharmonic Hall to a close last night. The capacity audience for the final program was indicative of the unusual success enjoyed by the series, part of the Lincoln Center Festival '67.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 13 Miss Ann W. Thayer, daughter of Walter N. Thayer of Rye and Mrs. John E. Sockwell of Greensboro, N.C., was married here this morning to William F. O'Shaughnessy of Mount Kisco. He is a son of William M. O'Shaugnessy of Buffalo and Mrs. Catherine T. O'Shaugnessy of Mount Kisco.
E.F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of Alec R. Jack to the new post of executive vice president.
Mayor Lindsay said at a news conference yesterday that more firemen might soon be shifted to areas of high fire hazards.
WASHINGTON, July 13 A Senate Labor subcommittee chairman criticized the Texas Rangers today for preventing an officer accused of abusing farm workers from a appearing to testify in his own defense.

ATHENS, July 13 Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza, who was Greece's Foreign Minister from 1956 to 1963, was arrested last night on charges of breaking a law forbidding unauthorized indoor gatherings of more than five persons.
HARTFORD, Friday, July 14 Scores of helmeted policemen sealed off Hartford's predominantly Negro North End late last night to contain a second wave of racial violence in the one-square-mile area.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee recommended today full financing for the continued development of two prototype supersonic transport planes, each capable of carrying 250 passengers across the Atlantic Ocean in three hours.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The National Association of Manufacturers laid the groundwork today for endorsement of a tax increase when it issued a report by its taxation committee.

HOYLAKE, England, July 13 Jack Nicklaus shares the lead with Australia's thinman, Bruce Devlin, at the halfway stage of the British Open. The defending champion dissected this flat course, vulnerable under blazing sunshine today, with a surgically efficient 69 for a 36-hole total of 140. Devlin had 70, 70 for his 140.
At 8:48 A.M. today the 1967 season of the International Ice Patrol, conducted annually by men and equipment of the United States Coast Guard, came to an end.
The grain market continued to feel the effects of an Agriculture Department report, issued on Tuesday, which estimated that wheat and corn production this year would reach record levels.
SALISBURY, Md., July 13 (AP) George Handy Wailes, who was made a ward of Princeton University on his 100th birthday last year, died last night at his home here. He would have been 101 Aug. 22.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 13 The left arm of a 4-year-old girl that was nearly severed from her shoulder in an automobile accident has been reattached by surgeons in East Orange General Hospital.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP) Paul Blair, Brooks Robinson and Curt Motton, a rookie, hit homers and Dave McNally pitched a six-hitter tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 10-0 victory over Boston after the Red Sox had won their day game, 4-2, on three unearned runs in the first inning and a homer by Joe Foy.
Sales of the nation's two largest electrical manufacturers G.E. and Westinghouse gained during the first half but net income lagged behind 1966 levels.
A plan to reorganize refugee program in the Middle East was submitted in Washington yesterday to the State Department by Ira A. Hirschmann, a businessman and specialist in refugee problems.
Francis Beattie Thurber 3d, a private engineer and builder, was killed in an automobile accident on Route 100 in Somers, N.Y., on Wednesday. He was alone in the car. Mr. Thurber was 59 years old.
Thomas Gaetano Luchese, a dapper little Mafia lord known to the police as Three-Finger Brown, died yesterday at his luxurious home in Lido Beach, L.I.
Stock prices closed slightly higher on balance yesterday although an afternoon retreat trimmed gains posted earlier in the session.

Two union officials, seven milk company officials and the head of a milk dealers' trade association were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to raise milk prices and intimidate stores and other companies to maintain fixed prices in the city.

In its attack on the "categorical" nature of existing Federal school aid measures, the Educational Policies Commission of the National Education Association echoes the sentiments of the conservative public school Establishment, which is now urging a return to the principle of general aid without Federal strings.

Several hundred solemn pairs of eyes stared at a large movie screen in a playground at the Baruch housing project on the Lower East Side last night, while several hundred jaws chewed rhythmically. They belonged to several hundred children who obviously were having a good time.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 13 Matthew F. Kelly, the first chairman of the Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority and former head of a New York City building corporation that bore his name, died yesterday at the Westport Manor Convalescent Hospital. He was 87 years old and had lived here since 1953.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13 Making his first appearance in defense of his title, Rodney Laver of Australia defeated Alex Olmedo of Peru tonight in the United States professional tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers cautioned the oil industry today against a price rise as an aftermath of the Middle East crisis.
NEWARK, Friday, July 14 The National Guard was called into this riot-torn city early today as Negro mobs spilled from their Central Ward ghetto into the heart of the downtown business district.
MARZABOTTO, Italy, July 13 (Reuters) Families of 1,830 people slaughtered by Nazi SS troops here in 1944 will decide by secret ballot on Sunday whether to pardon the man who gave the order to kill.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has ordered patrolmen not to issue summonses to Orthodox Jews who keep family businesses open on Sunday.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 A jury tonight found the Rev. James E. Groppi, a Roman Catholic priest who is a leading civil rights figure here, guilty of obstructing an officer but not guilty of resisting arrest.

The B.M.I. Musical Theater Workshop, designed to bring young professional lyricists and composers to the ears of producers, directors, agents and recording and broadcasting executives, will present three Tuesday showcases starting on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 13 A needling letter has gone out from the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to the presidents of all the nation's stock exchanges demanding action on the S.E.C.'s long-standing requests for reduced commissions on large stock transactions and for restrictions on the widespread practice of commissionsplitting among securities firms.

ASHLAND, Ky., July 13 (UPI) Mrs. Mark Porter of Riverton, N.J., continued her climb toward her third Women's Western Golf Association championship today as she downed Kaye Beard of Campbellsville, Ky., 4 and 2, in a quarter-final match.
DETROIT, July 13 The United Automobile Workers today outlined its new contract demands to American Motors Corporation, ending the first round of this summer's bargaining with the auto industry.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP)--Hoyt Wilhelm rescued Gary Peters from an eighth-inning jam tonight and saved the Chicago White Sox's 1-0 victory over the California Angels.
BONN, July 13--West Germany and France agreed today to establish a joint commission to discuss the "political and security" needs of the two countries in the next decade.

ERIE, Pa., July 13 (UPI)--Mayor Louis J. Tullio promised Negroes here today that the police would not use dogs again in their East Side neighborhood, where disturbances have broken out on two successive nights.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 Ray C. Bliss, Republican National Chairman, said here today that he hoped former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania would reconsider his decision never to run again for public office.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) The Senate passed a $6.78-billion appropriations bill today to run Federal farm programs through next June 30.

A chemical company president was arrested yesterday on charges of attempting to block a Federal grand jury investigation of alleged bribery involving the income tax returns of Alan King, the comedian.
Two 19-year-old drifters failed last Saturday in an attempt to escape from the Federal House of Detention, 427 West Street.
British trade figures for June sharply reversed the recent price advances on the London stock market yesterday.
BRUSSELS, July 13 (Reuters) Eighty-two refugees arrived here today by air from the Congo.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 13 The rebellion of the French and Belgian mercenaries in the eastern Congo appeared today to have collapsed.
BRUSSELS, July 13 Seven years and four crises after independence of the Congo, dramatic changes are taking place in the mood of the former mother country.

MOSCOW Vyacheslav Zaitsev, the 28-year-old Soviet fashion designer the Russians are forever likening to France's Yves Saint Laurent, likes diamonds, and as far as he's concerned, there's no limit to the amount a fashionable woman may wear.
A Navy pilot whose behavior as a prisoner in North Vietnam has suggested to many that he may have been brainwashed has been allowed to have two American visitors in his prison camp in Hanoi.

Federal District Judge Dudley B. Bonsal denied yesterday the Symington Wayne Corporation's request for a preliminary injunction to prohibit Dresser Industries, Inc., from making a tender offer for its shares.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, the president of Columbia University, announced yesterday that Columbia would make available "immediately" to all cigarette manufacturers a new filter that he said "showed a dramatic reduction in inhaled tars and nicotine."

National Educational Television will present an interview with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower as its final broadcast in the "Conversations 1967-68" series. The half-hour program will be on the N.E.T. network the week of Aug. 6.
Prices advanced on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the trading pace slowed from a sprint to just a run.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 13 The head of Nigeria's federal military government said today that his troops were on the point of taking the town of Nsukka, a major target in their eight-day-old advance into the secessionist Eastern Region.
CAIRO, July 13 A meeting of four Arab Presidents began today on ways to pursue their struggle with Israel.

The purchase of 48 air-conditioned rapid-transit cars now in use at Montreal's Expo 67 for operation on Staten Island is under serious consideration by the city, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday. The cars would cost a total of $3,840,000.
GENEVA, July 13 (Reuters) The International Committee of the Red Cross said tonight that a group of white hostages thought to have been held by fleeing mercenaries in the Congo had been found safe.
