GETTYSBURG, Pa. Before agreeing to run for President in 1952, General Eisenhower used to argue that after finishing his job as NATO commander he should retire and become a nonpolitical elder statesman available to serve his country when called upon for special tasks.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 13 (Reuters) The Roman Catholic church in Colombia announced today that it was handing over all its vacant rural estates to the country's land reform agency for distribution among peasants.

THERE is no reason why a man shouldn't pursue several talents. Real achieve ment in more than one, however, is very rare; for talent is only the beginning, and quality requires talent and then much more. James Stevenson is one of the funniest and sharpest cartoonists on The New Yorker roster. His novels, however four of them to date
Dr. Alvin C. Eurich has been named senior consultant for professional affairs of the Academy of Religion and Mental Health, 16 East 34th Street. He will beein his duties on Aug. 1.

PANAMA, July 11 Despite substantial United States concessions to Panamanian national interests and feelings, approval of the new treaties governing the operation and protection of the Panama Canal and a possible new one is expected to be difficult.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 13 The proposed fourth metropolitan jetport at Calverton, L.I., is now a "dead issue," according to its major proponent, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.
City authorities have asked the Port of New York Authority to move into the second stage in developing a consolidated passenger terminal system for Manhattan's West Side waterfront.

EASTON, Pa., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. William Hugh Kennedy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Hugh Kennedy, to John Gordon Turnbull, son of Mrs. J. Gordon Turnbull of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Turnbull.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey urged delegates to the State Constitutional Convention yesterday to amend the Constitution to provide for the appointment rather than the election of judges.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The Defense Department announced today that all but one landlord around the Bainbridge Naval Training Center and the Patuxent Naval Air Station in nearby Maryland had agreed to end segregation and to observe an open housing policy.
IT was an hour and ten minutes after Robert Louis Strickman walked into an auditorium filled with newsmen and television lights yesterday before he finally lighted a cigar.
TUNIS, July 13 The Defense Ministry issued a new military regulation today designed to close loopholes in a system that permitted almost any male who wished to escape the draft.
PARIS, July 13 President Nasser has been told that Pres ident de Gaulle would like a "dialogue" to start between -Israel and the Arab countries.

Two or three times a week for the last 11 years, Arthur T. Roth and Harold V. Gleason have lunched together at Sid's, a luncheonette a few doors down from the headquarters of the Franklin National Bank in Franklin Square, L.I.
The United Federation of Teachers reduced its salary demands yesterday, but the Board of Education promptly asserted that the union "still insists on much more money for much less work."
DONGHA, South Vietnam, July 13 The marines have a new saying in their outposts near the demilitarized zone. It is "Go north and die."

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 13 Pat Schwab, who makes a habit of setting golf course records, equaled thd Forest Hill, Field Club low of 63 eight under par as he took a six-stroke lead today after the second round of the New Jersey open.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A House Post Office subcommittee voted today to raise postal rates for letters by 1 cent and airmail by 2 cents and to put postcards on the same rate schedule as letters.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) President Johnson saluted Adm. David L. McDonald, retiring Chief of Naval Operations, and the Navy today for "other than combat" service including peace-keeping and humanitarian efforts in rescuing Vietnam refugees.
WASHINGTON, Friday, July 14 The nation faces the threat of a weekend copper strike, but the first break came yesterday in the long strike in the rubber industry.

BONN, July 13 The West German Government's sudden decision to cut its military budget by nearly $2.5-billion in the next four years has forced Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara to cancel a trip here scheduled for this month.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 13 (UPI) The Surveyor 4 lunar robot, its rocket assembly in good shape, was set for takeoff tomorrow toward a section of the moon so rough that the robot has only a 50-50 chance for a safe landing.
They know that their friends are watching the tall breakers curling in at ocean beaches or gliding in canoes over glassy lakes at woodland campsites.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 13 Lord Alport, a Conservative who was sent by Prime Minister Wilson to Rhodesia three weeks ago to assess the political climate and advise where "meaningful" negotiations could he reopened, ended his mission today.

COLEBROOK, Conn., July 13 Hamilton J. Bickford, former technical director of Cheney Brothers Inc., silk manufacturers, died today in a Torrington nursing home following a long illness. He was 67 years old.
JOENKOEPING, Sweden, July 13 (UPI) The competitors in the world modern pentathlon championships here Sept. 7 to 14 will undergo tests for alcohol and drugs.
WASHINGTON, July 13- President Johnson won the public endorsement of his top military commanders today for a relatively modest further build-up of American forces in Vietnam.
*Chateaubriand, 131 West 54th Street, 755-5260. A handsome enough restaurant that is spacious and airy and, compared to many other restaurants in the city, quiet.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13 It blew high and then low today in the America's Cup defense trials, but for Intrepid it made no difference either way. She acquired her fifth victory in five races of the observation portion of the selection process, the latest over Constellation.
Silk, queen of the textile fibers, is pricing itself out of the American market.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13--Communist, Arab and Moslem speakers urged the General Assembly today to find a way to overcome Israel's "defiance" of its resolution calling for annulment of the unification of Jerusalem.

The Greenwich Savings Bank has purchased the property formerly occupied by the Goldfarb Flower Shop at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and 57th Street from the realty investment partnership of Sol Goldman and Alex DiLorenzo. Title passed to the bank yesterday. The bank will erect a building on the site.
NEWARK, July 13 This citys' two outbreaks of racial violence followed, within a few weeks, two disputes between Negro leaders and City Hall that had caused new tensions.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 13 Forty candidates, most of them rookies, passed their physical examinations today and had a short workout their first at the New York Jets' training camp.

The Schavone-Chase Corporation, a new company, has been formed here to deal in domestic and foreign scrap and other materials for the steel and nonferrous metals industries, the principals announced recently.
ITALY, Tex., July 13 (AP) Art Shires, a hard-hitting athlete on and off the baseball field, died of lung cancer today at the age of 60.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., July 13 Miss Gail Ina Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Greenberg of Syosset, was married this evening to Peter Alan Shapiro, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alec Shapiro of New London, Conn. Rabbis Bernard Rubinstein and Leonard Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Huntington Town House.
American Airlines has announced the appointment of Cyrus S. Collins to the newly created post of vice president for public affairs.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 13 Hank Washington denied his label as. a fresh know-it-all. Jack Patera ran new calisthenics that brought forth groans and gasps. A thin Tucker Frederickson, his weight down to 212 pounds, said he felt fine. Darrell Dess ran lap after lap to strengthen his surgical knee. Sid Moret swore because 12 jerseys were stolen. A rookie, Dick Stebbins, impressed Al Sherman but for the wrong reason. Everyone perspired.

CINCINNATI, July 13 Home runs, two by Tommy Davis and a three-run clout by Larry Stahl, powered the New York Mets to a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight in the first game of a double-header. The Reds, behind the combined pitching of Jim Maloney and Ted Abernathy, bounced back to win the second game, 6-3, before 15,133 fans at Crosley Field.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 13 (UPI) Fiddler's Green scored his third straight triumph today when the 3-year-old bay colt sprinted to a three-quarter length victory in the $6,000 Metuchen-Elks Purse at Monmouth Park.
ALBANY, July 13 Democratic leaders of the Constitutional Conventional are pushing to get the controversial churchstate issue before the delegates, possibly as early as next week.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The public and private comments on the Vietnam war have seldom been further apart in Washington than they are today. The official comments remain moderately optimistic; the private comments are much more solemn and even gloomy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 American B-52's struck three times today at the North Vietnamese sector of the demilitarized zone.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Johnson Administration sent three top officials to Capitol Hill today in an attempt to dissuade the House from pushing ahead with a bill to set up a separate maritime administration.
WASHINGTON, July, 13 (UPI) James M. Nabrit said today he was retiring as president of Howard University, the nation's oldest predominantly Negro college, because of a threatened black power takeover.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 13 Students, elderly persons and commuters will be able to catch minibuses in the Town of Hempstead to take them on short trips to school, shopping areas and the Hempstead railroad station.

BERLIN, July 13 Walter Ulbricht, the East German Head of State, and Premier Willi Stoph were reappointed today to their top government positions when the East Berlin Parliament met for its first session following the elections earlier this month.
PARIS, July 13--Tom Simpson, a former world champion bicycle rider, collapsed during the Tour de France today and died as he was being flown by helicopter to a hospital at Avignon.
Esquire magazine has named 20 companies as winners of the first "Business in the Arts Awards" competition.

WHITE PLAINS, July 13 The Rev. Martin Duffy presented to a Westchester grand jury this afternoon what he termed "new" information that he said, bears on his charges of a powerful underworld influence in Mount Vernon.
ITALY, Tex., July 13 (AP) Art Shires, a hard-hitting athlete on and off the baseball field, died of lung cancer today at the age of 60.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., July 13 Miss Gail Ina Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Greenberg of Syosset, was married this evening to Peter Alan Shapiro, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alec Shapiro of New London, Conn. Rabbis Bernard Rubinstein and Leonard Goldstein performed the ceremony at the Huntington Town House.
The Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Baltimore has put its newly acquired 32,000-ton floating drydock to work for the first time.

People who really know their trivia who can remember, say, the sponsor of "Let's Pretend" (Cream of Wheat) or the name of the Lone Ranger's nephew (Dan Reed) will have no trouble identifying the pitchman for Texaco gasoline on the old Milton Berle show.
Bond prices ended the week on a firm note yesterday. All sections of the market showed a modest advance, nudging interest rates down.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 14 The Connecticut Women's Golf Association defeated the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, 27 to 17 , in their annual team match at the Country Club of New Canaan today.
Five hits per team per game was the quota at Yankee Stadium last night as the New York Yankees swept a doubleheader from the Cleveland Indians, 2-1 and 2-0.
NEWARK, July 14 "And then there was this judge," the old vaudevillian would say, "who sentenced a man to 10 years in Newark." Today, the old joke took on a new, grim air.
Tarzan may be facing his biggest challenge. A company has been farmed in New York to help Nigerians produce movies that could wipe out the African image created by Jane's monosyllabic boy friend.

Mayor Lindsay is combing the city's ghettos for talented young musicians to compete for a recording contract and a nightclub booking. The Mayor announced yesterday the start of Operation Sound Search, a nineweek talent hunt in Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and other areas.
Harvey A. Robbins has been appointed president of the Wamsutta-Pacific domestics division of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., the company announced yesterday.

At the United Nations yesterday, the General Assembly, without a dissenting vote, adopted a resolution repeating its earlier request to Israel to "desist forthwith" from any action changing the status of Jerusalem. The Israeli delegation did not participate in the voting on the resolution, introduced by Pakistan and sponsored by Afghanistan, Mali, Guinea, Iran, Somalia and Turkey. The United States and 17 other countries abstained. [Page 1, Column 1.]
SALEM, N.H., July 14--Dr. Fager (the brain surgeon) is expected to visit Rockingham Park tomorrow to see Dr. Fager (the horse) run in the $85,400 Rockingham Special.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 14 A United States Air Force C-130 landed at Kisangani today to evacuate civilians at the urgent request of the Red Cross.
Seventeen residents of Glassboro, N.J., left from Kennedy International Airport on a goodwill trip to the Soviet Union last night, saying they were taking with them "the spirit of Holly Bush."

ASPEN, Colo., July 14 Miss Kate Payne Aldrich, daughter of Larry Aldrich, the fashion designer, and Mrs. Aldrich of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., was married here this noon to Lawrence Stuart Saylor Jr. His parents arg Mr. and Mrs. Saylor of Rye, N.Y. His father is a vice president of the Canada Dry Corporation.
LONDON, July 14--A controversial bill to reform Britain's abortion laws was approved this morning after an exhausting all-night session in the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Administration eliminated the Soviet Union today from bidding on three giant new electric generating units at Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP) Pretense, the solid favorite, and four other candidates were entered today in the $147,100 Hollywood Gold Cup Handicap tomorrow, but the Argentine champion, Forli, was not among the entries.
Fenestra, Inc., one of the biggest movers on the New York Stock Exchange this week, failed to open yesterday because of an influx of orders.

By issuing a commemorative stamp for the 150th anniversary of the birth of Henry David Thoreau (July 12, 1817), the Government has performed a magnanimous deed. No one has ever spoken more contemptuously of government than Thoreau. It is impossible, he said, to be associated with "this American Government" without being disgraced.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 17.6 per cent in production for the week ended July 8, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.
Seven persons were injured in a collision involving a loaded school bus and two cars yesterday in Little Neck, Queens.
ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) Rico Carty hit a three-run homer in the first inning tonight and started Atlanta toward a 4-3 victory over Philadelphia.

GUATEMALA, July 14 The Communist-led guerrilla movement has been put on the defensive in Guatemala and its effectiveness drastically reduced in the last six months. But in the process, a new threat has arisen to the constitutional regime of President Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro right wing terrorism.
PARIS, July 14 France opened her Bastille Day celebration today with a display of military power and ended it with fireworks and dancing in the streets.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 14-Whither Andre previn? This question was raised last night by his conducting of the London Symphony Orchestra in the second concert of the 1967 Florida International Music Festival.

Peter Adams, who describes himself as President of Anguilla, arrived at Kennedy Airport last night and said he would like to meet with President Johnson to obtain sympathy for the independence of his island.
John J. Burns, the Democratic state chairman, and City Council President Frank D. O'Connor discussed with the five Democratic county leaders yesterday ways of unifying the party here.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 14 Students at the University of California will be subject to "disciplinary action, including dismissal," for the use of unlawful drugs such as LSD, the Board of Regents said today.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI) The Rev. Dr. Herbert Booth Smith, former moderator of the Presbyterian Church, U.S.A., and for many years pastor of Immanuel Presbyterian Church here, died Tuesday at Westminister Gardens Rest Home in Duarte, Calif. He was 83 years old.
MOSCOW, July 14 (AP)--Gerry Mulligan, the American jazz musician, played to a cheering crowd of Soviet jazz players tonight in an impromptu, six-hour jam session.
Despite increased sales, earnings of the Scott Paper Company in the quarter and six months ended June 30 declined from last year.
WHITE PLAINS, July 14 Five New York City men and two Westchester residents were arrested yesterday and charged with distributing heroin, cocaine and marijuana in Westchester.

BONN, July 14 Forty-nine taxi drivers on what West Germans call "Snob Island" are rebelling today by refusing to observe a 19th-century ordinance requiring them to wear neckties.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) President Johnson talked by telephone today to Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey and said he would consider sending Federal help if it should be needed in quelling riots in the city of Newark.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 14 The federal military Government issued a decree today enabling it to control all petroleum storage, transport and distribution facilities in Nigeria and to take over such facilities from companies that fail to comply with its directives.
ROME, July 14 The centerleft Government of Premier Aldo Moro won today a vote of confidence on its foreign policy, particularly with respect to the Middle East crisis.
BONN, July 14 The South Korean Ambassador, Lieut. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, offered his resignation today to the Seoul Government, the South Korean Embassy announced.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 14 Thousands of Arab refugees have returned secretly in recent days to the west bank of the Jordan River, authoritative sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Thomas J. Craven, a financial counselor, died here today in the Georgetown University Medical Center. He was 65 years old.
STERN BROTHERS is playing it cool in five model rooms that go on display Monday on the store's seventh floor. The colors are cool and the decor is, as model rooms go, relatively understated.
NEWARK, July 14-LeRoi Jones, the 32-year-old playwright, poet and jazz critic, suffered a head wound and was arrested today on charges of carrying weapons in a riottorn section of Newark.

An inspector's funeral, the first for a civilian employe of the Police Department, will be given Vincent E. Finn, retired chief clerk, who died, yesterday at Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 85 years old.

BRUSSELS, July 14 Informed British sources said today that negotiations for British membership in the European Economic Community or Common Market should start by early 1968 and that by 1969 the British Government should know whether it would be successful.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) The Chicago White Sox went on a rare hitting spree behind Joel Horlen's six-hit pitching tonight and breezed to an 8-0 victory over the California Angels for a split of their double-header.

India's cultural invasion of New York was strengthened last night with the debut of Bismillah Khan, who plays a wind instrument known as the shehnai. He appeared with his "party," as his assistant musicians were designated in the program, in Philharmonic Hall, and brought Lincoln Center's Festival '67 to a close on an international note.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (UPI) A United States artillery shell shot down an American F-4C Phantom jet fighterbomber, Air Force officials said tonight. It was the first accident of its kind in the Vietnam war.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 14 (UPI) America's Surveyor 4 spacecraft sped toward the moon today equipped with a television camera, a magnet and a shovel to ferret out lunar secrets from terrain so rugged that the craft is given only a 50-50 chance of landing safely.

Three Canadian researchers announced yesterday that they had developed a "percolator" filter that removes up to 90 per cent of the tars from cigarette smoke without a loss of flavor to the smoker. They made no disclosure on reduction of nicotine content.
ONE OF the most dramaladen records at the New York Stock Exchange may topple this summer if Big Board volume continues to boom.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a large toy manufacturer had been persuaded, with the help of a $739,500 loan, to stay in New York City and expand rather than move out.
BUDAPEST, July 14 Hungary declared today that the Arab nations could legitimately resume fighting at any moment along the present cease-fire lines with Israel.

SHORTLY after Mr. and Mrs. Lee Haring adopted their son, Bartholomew, last summer, their social worker gave them the same bit of advice that adoptive parents have been hearing for years: "Of course you'll tell him he's adopted."

The International Longshoremen's Association is expecting a ruling momentarily from the United States Department of Labor on one facet of the union's massive drive to banish forklift trucks powered by internal combustion engines from piers in the port and to have them replaced with electrically powered hoisting devices.
AIN GALLUT, United Arab Republic, July 14 (AP) Bedraggled, angry Arab refugees surrounded foreign newsmen visiting their camp today and accused Israeli soldiers of murder, rape, arson and looting.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Investigators from the Senate Antitrust subcommittee are looking into allegations that major banks in New York City and elsewhere are charging their customers illegally high rates for life insurance taken out to cover loans to consumers made by the banks.

HONG KONG, Saturday, July 15--Hong Kong security forces continued their get-tough policy toward Communist insurrectionists early this morning by staging another attack on a center of terrorism and agitation.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Treasury announced today a new system of "validation" of American ownership of foreign securities that must be carried out before the securi

A new batch of counterfeit $20 bills was reported yesterday to be in circulation here. Secret Service agents arrested three men in Wyandanch, L.I., after they had allegedly passed $32,000 in the bogus currency.
BOSTON, July 14 (AP) About half the delegates to the N.A.A.C.P. convention staged a rebellion today, staying in a darkened ballroom after adjournment to call for an overhaul of its governing body.

ATLANTA, July 14 (AP)--Bubonic plague, a now rare but once dreaded disease, was contracted by a Navajo Indian boy last month in Arizona, the National Communicable Disease Center in Atlanta has disclosed.
SALT LAKE CITY, Saturday, July 15 (UPI) A strike began early today at the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

BUFFALO, July 14 (AP) Mrs. Maxon (Cookie) Berger of Buffalo and Mary Dwyer, a freckle-faced teen-ager from Geneva, N.Y., gained the final today for the 37th New York State Women's Amateur golf championship.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 14 (UPI) A three-judge Federal court ordered the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to stop cutting off Federal funds for Alabama school systems.

THE Brooklyn Championships continue today at the New York Hilton, where the Open Pairs and the Limited Pairs (restricted to players with less than 100 master points) will be played at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today that foreign aid must go on indefinitely because the United States cannot afford to abandon the field and let the question of war and peace be determined by others.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) Barry Lee Walley, 20 years old, described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a participant in most of the major civil rights marches in the South, was sentenced to six months in prison and placed on three years' probation today on bad check charges and misuse of credit cards.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 14 Mrs. Henry William Steinhaus has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Steinhaus, to William James Zisson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max R. Zisson of New York and Narragansett, R.I.

The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the state's recently enacted narcotics, addiction control law, which permits the compulsory civil commitment of addicts for as long as three years.
LONDON, July 14 Authorities on sculpture and posture are laughing, or angry, according to their taste, about a statue of Sir Thomas More.

GENEVA, July 14 After holding 170 meetings, and studying 15,000 pages of documents, a three-man arbitration tribunal today completed hearings on the rival claims of India and Pakistan to the 7,000 square miles of uninhabited salt marsh known as the Rann of Cutch.
WASHINGTON, July 14--A special committee of the Federal Communications Commission recommended today a system of pay television that nearly 80 per cent of the nation's set-owners could receive.

VIOLENCE is no stranger to Hugh Joseph Addonizio. As an infantry officer in World War II, he fought across the rim of Africa, landed on Omaha Beach in Normandy, survived the Battle of the Bulge and won eight battle stars and the Bronze Star.
HOYLAKE, England, July 14 A pair of superb 67's fashioned by Roberto de Vicenzo and Gary Player pushed Jack Nicklaus into third place at the end of the third round in the British Open today.

In a challenge to the House Committee on Un-American Activities, the American Council on Education urged the nation's colleges and universities yesterday to resist all future demands to open students records to investigatory agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Four women's organizations that help recruit girls for the Job Corps were advised today by Representative Edith Green, Democrat of Oregon, to learn more about what they are sending the girls into.
CLEVELAND, July 14--For weeks, the financial chart along one wall of Congress of Racial Equality headquarters here told a gloomy story.

Mrs. June Wheeler Bainbridge, widow of Dr. William Seaman Bainbridge, a surgeon and cancer specialist here, died Thursday in Edinburgh, Scotland, were she had lived for the last 14 years with a daughter, Mrs. Angus McIntosh. Her age was 88.
Having already banished Beatle haircuts, miniskirts and bawdy comedies, the Greek military junta has now added Melina Mercouri to the growing list of glories that were Greece.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Heads of the three major television networks urged Congress today to approve creation of a public broadcasting corporation despite the competition it would provide for them.

NEWARK, Saturday, July 15 Gunfire crackled through the streets of this riot-torn city in renewed fury last night, bringing the toll of dead to 11, in- cluding a policeman shot by a sniper while chasing looters.
NEWARK, July 14 National Guardsmen and state police, using armed personnel carriers, fought pitched battles in the streets of Newark tonight against rampaging Negroes.

NEWARK, July 14 Gov. Richard J. Hughes and Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio drove through the core of the riot area here early today, and watched helplessly as men, women and children almost gaily raided wrecked stores.

The city's Commissioners of Health and Hospitals have complained that Mayor Lindsay's reorganization of health services has cut them off from the Mayor, Budget Director and other key officials, and has deprived them of positions of leadership.
An agreement in principle was reached yesterday for a merger of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation srito the Kerr-McGee Corporation in an exchange of stock
BONN, July 14 (AP) Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger said tonight that his Cabinet had "by no means" decided to cut the strength of the West German Army by 60,000 men.

ATHENS, July 14 Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza, the former Foreign Minister who was arrested by the police this week for entertaining more than five guests at home, was released today. He had been arrested for breaking a law forbidding unauthorized indoor gatherings of more than five persons.
The number of young Americans who still are virgins at the time they marry is rapidly declining, a group of doctors writing for the Medical Society of the State of New York has concluded.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 14 (UPI) Three Californians were beaten today, in the quarterfinals of the singles at the Swedish international outdoor tennis championships.

CINCINNATI, July 14 Tony Perez, whose home run in the 15th inning won the recent AllStar game for the National League, singled with the bases loaded in the 10th inning tonight to give the Cincinnati Reds a 1-0 victory over the New York Mets in Crosley Field.
If the Republican-dominated Board of Supervisors has its way, Nassau County's ombudsman the first and so far only one in the United States will be stripped of his investigative powers.
NEWARK, July 14 Ringed by National Guardsmen, state policemen and helmeted city policemen, Newark City Hospital continued to deal today with the casualties of two nights of racial violence.
The Newark riots this week are the worst of more than 40 incidents of racial violence that have erupted in American cities since Negro mobs ravaged the Watts district of Los Angeles in August, 1965.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 14 Miss Marion B. Clausen and Donald H. Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Darien, Conn., plan to marry here Aug. 12.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) Ed Mathews hit the 500th home run of his major league career tonight as he helped power the Houston Astros to an 8-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 14 An official of the Panama Canal said today that, although there was a temporary "bulge" in the traffic of ocean-going ships through the waterway, there was no real congestion as a result of the closing of the Suez Canal.

BERLIN, July 14 Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany advocated today a widening of trade between the Communist regime and West Berlin as well as negotiations on problems of trade, traffic and postal communications with West Germany.

LAUREL, Miss., July 14 (AP) About 250 Jones County residents, concerned about a strike but heartened by a promise of support from the Governor, called today for an end to violence and the prosecution of those responsible for it.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Federal Bureau of In vestigation reported today that its investigations into organized crime led to a record number of convictions during the year ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities said today that it "had never subpoenaed personal student folders."
HANKOE, Norway, July 14 (UPI) William Withnall of Marblehead, Mass., won the world championship in the International One-Design Class today with 13 points.
ROANOKE, Va., July 14 (AP) An engineering-medical research team has undertaken a fight against a disease of infancy that claimed the life of President Kennedy's infant son Patrick in 1963.

Miss Therese Overloop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Overloop of Brussels, was married in that city yesterday to Charles Minor Barringer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Minor Barringer of Chadds Ford, Pa. The civil ceremony at the city hall was followed by a religious one at the Holy Trinity Anglican Church, performed by the Rev. Harold Isherwood.
AUCTION prices for the best of l8th-century, French furniture and decorative objects continue to reach new heights.
NEWARK, July 14 Although charges of police brutality were common in this riot-torn city today, city officials said no formal complaints had been received from the Negro community.

Secretary of State Rusk pledged once again last week that the United States would stay in Vietnam "until the right of the South Vietnamese people to work out their own future, under a government of their own free choice, has been secured."
John R. Strachan became postmaster of New York yesterday, the 32d man and the first Negro to hold the post.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Foster Furcolo, former Governor of Massachusetts, has asked the United States Tax Court to overthrow a ruling by the Internal Revenue Service that he owes more than $36,000 in income taxes.

Paperback Originals. The Wrong People, by David Griffin (Paperback Library, 75 cents); A Fear in Borzano, by Willa Jay (Lanecer, 60 cents); All the Hungry Young Bodies, by Martin Austen (Paperback Library, 60 cents); A Study in Terror, by Ellery Queen; Gorgonzola, Won't You Please Come Home? by Clyde Ames: The Dragon's Lair, by Isabel d'este Wenzell (Lancer, 60 cents each).
WASHINGTON, July 14 Industrial production slipped slightly further in June despite a rise in automobile output, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 15-Enemy gunners blasted the huge American air base at Danang with 50 rounds of rocket fire early this morning, killing 12 United States servicemen and wound- ing 40, the military command announced.
WASHINGTON, July 14 If an orbiting spacecraft is disabled so that normal reentry is impossible, is the crew doomed to keep on circling the earth forever?

STONY BROOK, L.I., July 14 Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Gaiter have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Millichamp Gaiter, to Lieut. (jg.) Michael F. Schuler of the Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred G. Schuler of Nissequogue. A December wedding is planned.
Two Illinois psychiatrists have found that the Theater of the Absurd often portrays a mental disorder they discover in many patients.
CHICAGO, July 14 Kenneth E. Olson, dean emeritus of Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism, died of a heart attack last night at his home in Glencoe. He was 71 years old.

Received farewell call from Ambassador Alexander Matsas of Greece; held special National Security Council meeting on the Middle East; saw George McGhee, Ambassador to West Germany; saw NASA director Webb.
The Federal Office of Economic Opportunity announced yesterday a $750,000 grant to the city to create 842 additional summer jobs in antipoverty programs in the five boroughs.
JERUSALEM, July 14 Israel agreed tonight to the immediate return of hardship cases among Arab refugees who had fled across the Jordan River from the occupied west bank territory.

The Norfolk Western Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to deny petitions of two railroads the Delaware Hudson and the Bostom Maine that it take those lines into its system on the basis of terms fixed by the commission last month.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 14 Dennis Ralston lost to Fred Stolle, his nemesis in amateur competition, in the United States professional tennis championship tonight on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.
Winds, northwest at 10 to 15 knots Saturday, west to southwest at 10 to 15 knots Sunday.

LONDON, July 14 Ed Burke of Newport Beach, Calif., the American champion, won the hammer throw today in the British Amateur Athletic Association championships. But he was so disappointed with his performance and his concentration was so shattered that he dropped the elaborate silver trophy during the victory ceremony. (The trophy was undamaged).
Chandris Line yesterday announced the acquisition of the 17,042-ton British passenger liner Kenya Castle for $950,000 and plans for her conversion into a 20,000-ton trans-Atlantic liner.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 14 Pat Schwab played record golf for the second straight day at the Forest Hill Field Club today and won the 47th annual New Jersey open tournament with a 72-hole total of 271. With his cards of 68 and 72 for the day's rounds, Schwab broke the tourney record set in 1955 by Stan Mosel by two strokes. He was 13 under for the four rounds.
CARPENTRAS, France, July 14 (AP) Government, medical and sports authorities pressed their investigation today into the death of Britain's foremost cyclist, Tom Simpson.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Saturday, July 15 (AP) A group of about 40 Negro youths marched from a housing project here last night and tossed rocks at police cars and through several store windows.

SACRAMENTO, July 14 The Reagan administration has its Man in the Iron Mask a personage of acknowledged stature and consequence, who, because of tactical factors, has in effect been sealed off from the world.
MURPHY, N.C., July 14 (AP) Harry Nelson Atwood, who set several flying records in the early nineteen-hundreds, died today. He was 83 years old.

SILVERSTONE, England, July 14 (UPI) A former world champion driver, Graham Hill, received a severe setback today to his hopes for tomorrow's British Grand Prix when he crashed his Lotus-Ford in practice.
BONN, July 14 Queen Elizabeth II flew to West Germany today to take part in a ceremony celebrating the 50th anniversary of Britain's Royal Tank Corps.
PEKING, July 14 (Reuters) Huge crowds took to the streets of Peking today in a new wave of condemnation of Liu Shaochi, the chief of state.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 14 (AP) Three masked gunmen robbed the Land of Lincoln Bank of $113,000 this morning, and some 85 miles to the southwest a single robber took $11,000 from the First National Bank of Madison, Ill., shortly before noon.
ACCRA, Ghana, July 14 (AP) A federal Nigerian military communique said tonight than Government troops believed they had captured Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, head of the secessionist Eastern Region.
Prices on the London stock exchange continued to ease slightly yesterday, but selling spurred by the widening of the British trade gap appeared to have ended.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey urged delegates to the State Constitutional Convention Thursday to amend the Constitution to provide for the appointment rather than the election of judges.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 14 Mayor Thomas G. Dunn today issued an executive order closing all taverns, liquor stores and restaurants with liquor licenses to reduce the flow of liquor into Newark.
Stock prices rose again yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange rounded out the busiest trading week in its history.
BALTIMORE, July 14 A new $4-million container cargo terminal was inaugurated here today with the arrival of the first vessel to be berthed at the facility.
INTENDED or not, the point of this tale by a veteran French novelist is that the sensitive are punished through suffering, the callous profit through success.

COLUMBIA, Md., July 14 The summer festival of the National Symphony rnay or may not develop into the most important in the United States. But this evening's first concert turned out to be the wettest one in history.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States planned to continue selling arms to some Arab states to prevent an East-West polarization in the Middle East, with the Soviet Union arming all the Arabs and the United States arming Israel.

SEATTLE, July 14 (AP) Mike Zimmerman, a 20-year-old Dayton University junior, slipped to a four-over-par 74 today in the third round of the national amateur public links golf tournament, but held onto the lead by a single stroke.

Who is the real Michael Alden? Television viewers who have been following the adventures of the handsome amnesia victim on the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Coronet Blue" this summer may never find out. The series is scheduled to go off the air Sept. 4 with the hero's identity still a mystery to himself, to the network and to his growing host of fans.

ARLINGTON, Va., July 14 Representative Joe Pool, Democrat of Texas, spent nearly six hours in the Arlington County jail here this morning. He had been arrested and charged with reckless driving and failing to have a Virginia motor vehicle registration card, county officials said today.
Dr. Ethel Percy Andrus, founder and president of the National Retired Teachers Association and the American Association of Retired Persons, died Thursday in Long Beach, Calif. Her age was 82.

Stocks closed higher with special situations strongest in brisk trading. Most tobacco issues were lower; volume, 10.88 million. Corporate bonds rate bonds were firm in lessactive trading; transactions, $17.19 million.

CAIRO, July 14 Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the editor of Cairo's influential daily, Al Ahram, made a plea today for an Arab summit meeting. He conceded, however, that the chances that Arab leaders would reach a unified stand toward Israel and the West were "very slim:"

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 14 (AP) John Donaldson drove in two runs with a pair of singles and Tony Pierce put down a bases-loaded threat in the sixth inning tonight as they led the Kansas City Athletics to a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
Mayor Lindsay signed a measure yesterday setting up a permanent City Office of Collective Bargaining.
DETROIT, July 14--The General Motors Corporation called the new contract demands of the United Automobile Workers Union "wholly unrealistic" today.

ROME, July 14 Immigration and customs inspectors no longer bother stamping the passports of the millions of wheeled tourists crisscrossing the borders of western Europe in what is becoming a record summer of wanderlust.
The Post Office Department, increasingly concerned about airline ticket frauds, is enlisting the aid of computers to detect members of the flynow-pay-never crowd, the Air Travel magazine reports.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 14 Tommy Bolt caught Art Wall on the last hole of regulation play, then beat him with a birdie 3 on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to win the Concord invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Paul Casanova looped a twoout single to right field in the eighth inning tonight, driving in two runs to lead the Washington Senators to a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

NORWALK, Conn., July 14 Robert E. Derektor's Wild Goose, Thomas Harrison's Jada, John R. Geyer's Red Pepper and Dr. Edwin H. Kent's Nicor were the corrected-time winners in their respective divisions today on the first leg of Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual threeday invitation cruise on Long Island Sound.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 Gideon Rafael, Israel's representative, submitted a note tonight to the president of the Security Council calling for prompt stationing of United Nations observers in the Suez Canal area.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14--Secretary General Thant charged Israeli forces today with "looting and the removal of property" from United Nations Emergency Force headquarters in Gaza and storage depots at Camp Rafah.
WASHINGTON, July 14 A Presidential commission recommended today that agricultural policies for the future be built around free markets rather than Government programs.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14 The United States has proposed normalization of relations with Lebanon, including the resumption of ambassadorial representation here and in Washington.
ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) Judge Jack P. Etheridge of Superior Court, in a Georgia test case, ruled today that chronic alcoholism constitutes a legal defense to drunkenness charges.
MIAMI, July 14 (AP) Flight dispatchers say they will strike against National Airlines on July 21 in a year-old dispute over higher pay.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Singer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Arlene Singer, to Dr. Lenard Eduard Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Jacobson of Woodbridge, N.J., and New York.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 14 It is not unusual for music festivals to wind up with a deficit, but lack of funds very nearly shut down the fifth Long Island Festival before it started.

PANACEA, Fla. Five years ago, Jack J. Rudloe, a transplanted New Yorker, was a 19year-old drifter, living in a brokendown automobile in the swamp along the Sopchoppy River in north Florida, catching frogs and tadpoles to make money.

BARCELONA, Spain,, July 14 (UPI) Manuel Santana, a former Wimbledon champion, and Juan Gisbert scored singles victories today to give Spain a 2-0 lead over the Soviet Union in the finals of the European Zone Group A Davis Cup tennis competition.

It had all the earmarks of a James Bond movie: the late hours, the eerie lights, the long shadows, the stealth, the guarded door, the muted voices, the handing over of the papers, the complicated machinery, the sudden roar of a mechanical monster, the hurried loading of a truck, the last-minute instructions for the driver and the speeding into the blackness of night.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall, the first nominee to the Supreme Court to come up for confirmation since the controversial Miranda decision on concessions, continued today to bear the brunt of Congressional displeasure at the ruling.

NEWARK, July 14 Most of the group of young Negro women who were looting the supermarket at Springfield Avenue and Morris Street in leisurely fashion today left their shopping bags and carts and ran outside when someone yelled that the National Guardsmen were coming.
Cotton futures turned irregular yesterday after early strength, which carried the No. 2 contract into seasonal high ground. It closed at $1.70 a bale lower to $5 higher on the basis of final bids.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (AP) About 1,100 office workers of the Union Electric Company in the St. Louis area and parts of Illinois and Iowa went on strike today in a dispute over working conditions. About 3,000 members of two other union locals and 400 construction workers building a new plant refused to cross picket lines.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 14 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. declared today that he would veto a legislative act creating a Commission of Investigation and Bureau of Law Enforcement.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The recently expelled Bishop of the biggest Anglican diocese in South Africa warned today that because of the Government's repressive racist policies, South Africa "will be the next to blow" after Vietnam.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 Fog was the only winner today when it destroyed plans for the sixth set of races in the America's Cup defense trials.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 Following is the text of the resolution on Jerusalem adopted today by the General Assembly:
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Treasury announced tonight that it was halting sales of silver at $1.29 an ounce.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John James Leonard of Kew Gardens, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Mary Leonard, to M. William Benedetto. He is the son of Mrs. Francis M. Benedetto of New York and the late Dr. Benedetto.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Friday, July 15 (UPI) A Vietcong force dynamited a provincial jail 20 miles south of Danang last night and freed 1,200 prisoners, most of them suspected guerrillas.
Almost half a century of jazz styles are being summed up in definitive fashion at two Greenwich Village nightclubs this week.
A new Housing Maintenance Code and changes in the city's Rent Control Statute were signed into law yesterday by Mayor. Lindsay in a City Hall ceremony.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 14--About 100 military prisoners rioted for nearly an hour last night in the stockade here, hurling bunks and foot lockers through the windows, breaking lights and shouting obscenities at military policemen summoned to restore order.
BOSTON, July 14 Three groups of opponents of the "old guard" today attacked the 60-man board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Another increase during June in the average interest rate on conventional mortgages for new homes was reported Thursday by the Federal Housing Administration.
GENEVA, July 14 The United States said today that it would consider contributing as much as $500,000 to a special United Nations Birth Control Fund.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Louis M. Loeb, general counsel for The New York Times, testified today that a special antitrust exemption for newspapers would be unnecessary and unwise.

The sorry rollcall of American cities ripped by summer riots grows. In Newark, National Guardmen patrol the streets; in Hartford, a state of emergency has been declared; even in the heart of the nation's Corn Belt young Negroes riot in a small Iowa town.

ONE of fashion's bestknown labels will soon be appearing in moderately priced hats. The first group of millinery designs by Yves Saint Laurent, priced between $15 and $25, will be available at a number of stores later this month. The hats are being manufactured here by the ...
ROME, July 14 Members of the chorus of the Rome Opera stopped traffic in the middle of the city today with a musical demonstration for more Government aid.

Hundreds of Negroes and whites from all over the city and from Connecticut, New Jersey and Long Island are converging in the East Village these nights to dance at the old Polish National Hall building at 23 St. Mark's Place.

TEL AVIV, July 14 Israeli jet fighters attacked Egyptian artillery positions on the west bank of the Suez Canal today after hours of shelling from the Egyptians that killed five Israeli soldiers and wounded 20, the Government said.

COMPTON, Calif., July 14 (AP) The police said today that Mrs. Pearl Choate Birch, 60-year-old widow of the multimillionaire oilman and farmer A. Otis Birch, had been jailed on a charge of assault with intent to commit murder.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 14 (AP) Jorge Velasquez, the leading jockey in the nation, rode five winners today in eight races at Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)--Fred B. Black Jr. asked the United States District Court today to throw out an income tax evasion indictment against him because of electronic eavesdropping by the Government.
LONDON, July 14 The Royal Mint admitted an error today the first serious one, a spokesman maintained, in the 97 years since the mint became a Government depart ment.

Mrs. Esta Murrie Clevenger of 939 Cedar Brook Road, Plainfield, N.J., a columnist for The Plainfield Courier-News, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center, First Avenue and 34th Street. She was 63 years old on Thursday.
HARTFORD, July 14 Calm returned to Hartford's predominantly Negro North End tonight, after two nights of racial violence.

One of the nation's major Protestant denominations, the theologically conservative Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, made a number of breakthroughs in social action and ecumenism in a convention here this week.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.8 on Thursday from 97 on Wednesday.
Trading remained lively and prices moved up again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14--The General Assembly adopted today without a dissenting vote a resolution repeating its request to Israel to "desist forthwith" from any action altering the status of Jerusalem.
An experimental technique for mapping celestial bodies by bouncing radar signals off them from an orbiting spacecraft was reported yesterday by a team of Stanford University scientists.

CAIRO, July 14 The United Arab Republic said today that its artillery and antiaircraft guns, in returning Israeli fire, had destroyed 5 planes, including a Mirage fighter, 8 tanks, 15 half-tracks, 9 trucks and 2 boats with which the enemy tried to cross the Suez Canal. In addition, Egypt said she had captured two boats and two prisoners of war.

LONDON, July 14 The writer of a letter to The Times of London said today that on June 5 and 6, when Egypt was being subjected to Israeli air attack, "Egyptian Ilyushin bombers were dropping poison gas bombs on the villages of Immed and Boa" in Yemen.

NORTH MASSAPEQUA, L.I., July 14 Law enforcement officials kept a close watch today on the funeral home where visitors have been paying their respects to Thomas Gaetano Luchese, a Mafia leader also known as Three Finger Brown, who died yesterday.

CAIRO, July 14 Thousands of Egyptians greeted President Gamal Abdel Nasser and the Presidents of Algeria, Syria and Iraq with rousing cheers today as they arrived in an open car at the Al Azhar Mosque for Friday noon prayers.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, the chief domestic subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), raised the prices yesterday that it pays for crude oil in a number of West Texas Panhandle fields.
WASHINGTON, July 14 President Johnson conferred today with his Ambassador to West Germany, George C. McGhee, but avoided any public comment on the latest tensions in relations with Bonn.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The threat was raised today of selective railroad strikes on Sunday that could trigger a countrywide railroad shutdown.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 14 (UPI) A settlement was reached today in the violent four-day-old strike that crippled the world's largest privately owned shipyard and snarled work on five nuclear submarines.

HICKSTEAD, England, July 14 (UPI) Frank Chapot of Wallpack., N.J., aboard Good Twist, scored his second victory in the four-day international meeting today, capturing the United States Equestrian Team Stakes, named in honor of the visitors.
The great trek to woods and lakes and seashore has begun. Before Labor Day some six million children will have spent all or part of the summer at camp.
A 6-year-old Bronx boy was killed yesterday when water gushing from an open fire hydrant knocked him under the wheels of a passing coal truck on East 134th Street near Brook Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) A decision on the site for the 1968 Republican National Convention was postponed today, for two weeks.

In Israel's unification of Jerusalem the General Assembly of the United Nations finally has found an issue on which majority agreement is possible. It was approved by 99 votes to 0, with 18 abstentions.

WARRENSBURG, N.Y. The appeal of a river is that, under a single identity, it lives many lives. In Manhattan, the Hudson is a mature woman full blown, worldly wise and soiled. Here in the Adirondacks, she is a laughing, red-cheeked, bright-eyed country girl. She chatters, she sings, she skips and dances. For brief inter- ludes, she glides gracefully and quietly with a solemnness that might strike one as a bit pre- cocious.
