The first significant bout to determine an eventual successor to Cassius Clay as the world heavyweight boxing champion will take place on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden when Joe Frazier of Philadelphia opposes George Chuvalo of Canada.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 15 Miss Anne Sherrill Davidson and Enos Thompson Throop Jr., are planning a midwinter wedding.

AKRON, Ohio, July 15, (AP) Holman Williams, one-time instructor and later a protege of former heavyweight champion Joe Louis, was found dead early today in the wreckage of a private club that had been destroyed by fire.

HARTFORD, July 15 Miss Courtney Ann Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Courtney Graham of West Hartford and Fortunes Rocks, Me., was married this afternoon to William Sebek Donnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sebek Donnell of Winnetka, Ill.

SPEAKING at Chicago, just 30 years ago, Franklin Roosevelt called for "quarantine" against aggressor nations. Public opinion and Congress would have none of it, for the mood of the country was isolationist.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 15 A $260,000 job-hunting program in Suffolk County has begun smoothing the path between the tree-shrouded industrial park and the ghetto.

The chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Miss Mary Russell Marsh and Alexander Hamilton Stephens. The Rev. Irving S. Pollard performed the ceremony, and a wedding breakfast was given at the River Club.

AN apparently authentic car of the WoodlawnJerome Avenue IRT line jolted to a stop last week inside the cavernous sound stage of the old Biograph Studios in the Bronx. The car was actually a $15,000 replica, which was being used for "The Inci- dent," a film version of the 1963 TV drama, "Ride With Terror."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 15 Native Diver raced to his third straight victory today in the $162,100 Hollywood Gold Cup, but the richest race of the summer was marred by a spill at the start with the riderless 0'Hara impeding the favored Pretense throughout most of the race.

The country is in such grave danger of suffocation under a flood of paper originals, single copies and tenth copies that a high Washington official is reported to have ordered destruction of a set of files, with the proviso, of course, that copies be made of everything before the files go to the fire.
TREMONT, Ky., July 15, (UPI) Tons of dirt and rock broke loose from a mountain today, burying several homes and damming the Cumberland River.

Damascus carried out the assignment of toting 128 pounds over the distance of a mile and a quarter yesterday to the satisfaction of most of the observers of the $83,350 Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct. Conceding from 3 to 19 pounds to his eight rivals in the 50th running of the fixture, Damascus flashed a late rally to win by threequarters of a length.

RYE, N.Y., July 15 Miss Robin Adair Rees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mason Rees, was married at noon today to Bruce Kenneth Bernann of New York, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bernann of Charlemont, Mass., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

MIAMI, July 15 The LatinAmerican Solidarity Organization, a Havana-based pro-Communist group that is promoting guerrilla and insurrectional activities, has recently begun seeking cooperation in the United States for advancing its goals.

THIS is a worthwhile, though frustrating book. Peter Schrag, associate education editor of the Saturday Review, begins his report on the dilemma of the urban school with a simple syllogism: the city is the center of American society today; the public school is the core of the ...

FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique, F.W.I. You are met at the airport with a bottle of Je Reviens. The roads are excellent, a change from even a year ago, and a very different story from certain other overseas French Departments, such as Corsica.

The marriage of Nisa Mona Venetia Belden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Orson Belden of Paris, to Pfc. Thomas Francis Bayard 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard 3d of Wilmington, Del., took place yesterday at the American Cathedral (Episcopal) in Paris. Canon James McNamee performed the ceremony.

SKAGWAY, Alaska For the first time in more than 50 years, a new building has been erected in this pictur- esque and historic city, which came to fame as the gateway to the Klondike gold fields in the late 1890's.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 15 (UPI) Dr. Athelstan F. Spilhaus, University of Minnesota scientist and the author of a comic strip, said today that he was resigning to become president of the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.
SAN JUAN Puerto Ricans go to the polls a week from today in a plebiscite to settle the schizophrenic debate over political status that has been waged on this Caribbean island for the past century.

A hydrographic chart of an eight-acre man-made lake in France has become a "must" study material for the oceangoing masters and pilots of the world's largest tanker fleet owner, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The airline ticket sales industry has been hit, and hit hard, for the first time by what it believes to be organized crime.

KYOTO, Japan, July 15 New horizons in the use of hypnosis for treating a wide range of mental and physical disorders were explored here this week by some 500 psychiatrists and other specialists from 27 countries.

The emergency session of the General Assembly, now nearing its end, has twice expressed world disapproval of Israeli absorption of the Old City of Jerusalem. It has voted for humane treatment of the new Arab refugees and their return home.

AN anomaly in the American scene is the arrival of an urban economy at the same time that our great core cities are declining in growth and prestige. No other country in the world is facing a similar contradiction. Our cities are the vortices of urban growth and the centers around which the nation's new suburban communities are polarized.

ST. LOUIS Construction of the Jefferson National Expansion Me- morial, commemorating America's westward growth, seems to be taking nearly as long as the actual winning of the West. Anyone born the year that President Franklin D. Roosevelt first designated this part of downtown St. Louis as a historic site is now 32 years old, and the memorial on the west bank of the Mississippi River is still un- finished.
A small home made of several types of plywood used for the walls, floors, ceilings and roof has been put up in Yachiyodai, Japan, an expanding residential community 20 miles east of Tokyo.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 15 Henry Rox, a former professor at Mount Holyoke College and a sculptor who was perhaps best known for his whimsical figures made out of fruits and vegetables, died yesterday at his home. He was 69 years old.
A crowd of 150 persons attacked a man accused of fatally wounding an 18-year-old youth about midnight Friday in the Corona section of Queens.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 Miss Georgia Mary Forman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Carter Forman, was married this afternoon to Harry H.S. Phillips 3d, son of Mr. Phillips Jr., of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Phillips.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 Senator Charles H. Percy, of Illinois, while discounting his own prospects for the Republican Presidential nomination, indirectly supported today the eligibility of Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 15 The marriage of Miss Christine Jane Dalton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Michael Dalton of Old Brookville, to John Arthur McCann, son of Mrs. Lillian McCann of Lowell, Mass., took place this morning.
WASHINGTON For growing numbers of respectable automobile owners, obtaining liability insurance at reasonable rates and keeping it has become a vexing problem, and Congress is hearing from them.
What Walter Reuther says he wants for the 650,000 members of his United Auto Workers is enjoyed by relatively few blue collar workers in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 15, (AP) Secretary of Commerce Alex ander B. Trowbridge has announced the appointment of new chairmen of 10 regional Export Expansion Councils. They will also serve as members of the National Export Expansion Council.
Men who drive high-speed racing boats often smoke big cigars, drink hard liquor and talk of death with a kind of mystical fatalism.
NEWARK, July 15 "The fires weren't the problem it was the jeering and the snipers' shots," the tillerman of Hook and Ladder Company 7 said here tonight.

A spokesman for the Communist party of the U.S.A. demanded yesterday that Gov. Richard J. Hughes and Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, the New Jersey officials leading the effort to halt rioting in Newark, resign immediately and called for the withdrawal of all troops and policemen from the city.
If I were to compare the two American Presidents whom I met [Eisenhower and Kennedy], the comparison would obviously not be in favor of Eisenhower. ...
The heating and cooling of industrial and commercial buildings with light bulbs is possible under a patent assigned to Lithonia Lighting, Inc. of Conyers, Ga.
HICKSTEAD, England, July 15 (UPI) David Broome of Britain, riding Mr. Softee, won the Derby Trial, the major event on the third day's program of the four-day international equestrian show.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., July 15 Miss Madeline Barbara Salner, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan P. Salver of Bala-Cynwyd, was married tonight to Fredric Harris Weisberg. He is the son of Benjamin R. Weisberg, retired senior judge of the Stamford (Conn.) City Court, and Mrs. Weisberg of Stamford. Rabbi Theodore H. Gordon performed the ceremony at the Main Line Reform Temple.
PARIS, July 16 (AP)--Morris Dancer, owned by Paul Mellon of England, won the $38,000 Prix Messidor today by a neck from the favored Agy after a stretch battle at the Saint Cloud race course.
WASHINGTON, July 16--A top secret report will be sent to the Pentagon soon that could go a long way toward determining the United States' continued ability to deter nuclear war.

LONDON, July 16--Lord Alport returned here today after three weeks in Rhodesia as the British Government's special envoy and declared that "the majority of white Rhodesians would like to see a negotiated settlement," with Britain.

ST. LOUIS, July 16--Jack Lamabe, a 30-year-old righthanded pitcher, was traded to the league-leading Cardinals today by the Mets. The deal was announced just prior to the start of the double-header between the clubs.

New York City has lost the distinction of producing more than half of the personal income in the state. It went below the 50 per cent mark in 1960, sagged to 47.9 per cent in 1965 and is still losing ground.

Larry Connolly of the Mer. cury Track Club and Byron Dyce of the United Athletic Association won yesterday in 5,000-meter road runs that made up a Robert Zaleski Memorial program at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

ROME, July 16--The long, long coat which ends at mid-calf or dips down to the ankles is getting all the attention--and applause--in the Rome haute couture collections for fallwinter which started this weekend.
The reassignment of four top field managers was announced here yesterday by A. Theodore DeSmedt, president of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 16--Ted Fontelieu of the Cedar Point Y.C. of Westport, Conn., won the Thistle Class Long Island Sound District championship today.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 16 --Edgar Perry's Princess took the Luders 16 Class honors as 88 boats sailed today in the Tri-Club Yacht Racing Association regatta conducted by the Huntington Yacht Club.

Miss Caryl M. Curtis, a social studies teacher and guidance counselor for more than 30 years at John Adams High School in Ozone Park, Queens, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 229 West 78th Street.
CLEVELAND, July 16--A massive summer campaign is under way here against the tensions that contribute to Negro rioting.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 16 (UPI)--Seventeen Negroes were arrested and two persons injured during an early morning disturbance here today.

Miss Eleanor Rose Reingold, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Reingold of Marblehead, Mass., was married last evening to Albert M. Fried, son of Mrs. Jacob Fried of the Bronx and the late Mr. Fried. Rabbi Eugene Cohen and Cantor Alfred Oppenheimer officiated at the Park East Synagogue.
The National Broadcasting Company will repeat "Khrushchev in Exile--His Opinions and Revelations" on Monday, July 31, at 8 P.M.

OCEAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 16--"He said, 'I'm dying.' He died right there, I guess." That is the way Sgt. Elwood N. (Buddy) Allston recalled at his home here today the killing of Fire Capt. Michael Moran in a sniper attack in Newark's bloody Central Ward on Saturday night.
The National Transportation Safety Board has announced the publication of a study of the influence of airplane design on accidents in cases where the pilot was found responsible.

ALBANY, July 16--A study made for State Controller Arthur Levitt has concluded that New York State should proceed quickly with its plan to lease a major part of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Monday, July 17--A white policeman was beaten, kicked and shot to death by a rampaging Negro mob last night after he had chased a looter in the heavily Negro West End section of this suburban city.
LOS ANGELES, July 16--It's one thing for the movies to manufacture a hip nun; quite another to come across one in real life.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 16 (AP)--Sixteen elephants, hundreds of other animals and birds and some 400 persons will miss their Monday morning connection between Phoenix and Los Angeles because of the rail strike.

Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's estimate, made during a recent television appearance, that his department is spending close to $3-billion annually in the nation's shipyards was challenged yesterday by an industry spokesman.

Arthur T. Roth, chairman of Franklin National Hank, announced over the weekend that Franklin International Corp., its newly formed subsidiary, had purchased the entire capital stock of American Swiss Credit Co. Ltd.

Miss Jacqueline Elizabeth Marx, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Marx of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Donowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Donowitz of Freehold, N.J. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Pierre.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP)-- Paul Lindblad, a left-hander pitched a three-hitter as the Kansas City Athletics beat the Chicago White Sox, 7-0, in the second game for a split of their double-header today.
PHUVINH, South Vietnam, July 16--Huynh Van Mui rents 2,000 square meters of rice land, about half an acre, on the outskirts of this delta town.

ATLANTA, July 16 (UPI)-- Phil Niekro pitched a five-hitter and Mack Jones singled across the tie-breaking run in the sixth inning today to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The triumph was Atlanta's third straight.

At the Museum of Modern Art these days, a Friendly Grey Computer in a rocking chair calmly blinks answers to questions that might nonplus a counterpart at I.B.M.: "Are we losing the cold war?" and "Will Israel give up captured territory?" "Will my father talk to the lifeguard?" and "Mike is too possessive. Should I break up with him?"
JERUSALEM, July 16--Kalandria Airport north of Jerusalem was incorporated into Israel's domestic airline network today. Regular flights will begin next week.

The entire future of the Soviet-American cultural exchange program has been called into question by Moscow's sudden cancellation of the long-planned tour here of the artists who were to present the Russian Festival of Music and Dance. It has thrown uncertainty over the prospects for two other major events, the scheduled visits of the Moscow Circus in October and of the Bolshoi Ballet and Opera companies next spring.
Miss Diane June Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Schwartz of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Hanon Climo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Climo of New Haven.
NEWARK, July 16 (AP)-- Whether four days of racial disorder would end today was of Little concern to the families of two Negro victims of the riot.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) --Two of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's ten most wanted men surrendered here early today after agents had filled an apartment building with tear gas.
TEL AVIV, July 16--United Nations supervision of the Egyptian-Israeli cease-fire along the Suez Canal was postponed today.

HONOLULU, July 16 (UPI)-- Stormvogel, the big South African ketch flying the colors of the Royal Dutch Yacht Club, crossed the finish line at Diamond Head at 11:15 o'clock last night, far ahead of the fleet in the 24th Trans-Pacific yacht race.
JERUSALEM, July 16-- The head of the 300,000member B'nai B'rith led 1,000 people gathered at the Wailing Wall this afternoon in the ancient Hebrew prayer of thanksgiving.
The Rev. Morton A. Hill marked the eighth annual observance of Captive Nations Week in a sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ACCORDING to "A Short History of Chess," by H. J.R. Murray, "the evidence establishes the Indian origin of chess, and leads to the conclusion that the game was the conscious and deliberate invention of an inhabitant of Northwest India [now Pakistan], who... flourished between A.D. 455 and 543."

MILLBURN, N.J., July 16-- Miss Linda Jann D'Andre was married here today to Capt. Alan E. Davis, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Davis of New Brunswick. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Michael Provenzano of Vineland and James B. D'Andre of Metuchen. Rabbi Irwin Fishbein performed the ceremony at the Chanticler.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) --The Coast Guard said tonight that it had confiscated a Japanese fishing trawler for violating American territorial waters off the Alaskan coast.
The United States Treasury has dropped the other shoe and the result seems likely to be a certain amount of temporary chaos in the silver market.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 15--Pakistan's new capital is steadily emerging at the northern edge of the Punjabi plain.
MILWAUKEE, July 16 (AP) --Winds on Lake Michigan shifted to the southwest today, allowing the record fleet of 168 sailing yachts in the annual Chicago-Mackinac Island race to blossom with spinnakers.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 16--The Bahamian residence permits of three American gamblers will not be renewed when they expire next Jan. 15, Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling announced today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 16-- The most ambitious agrarian reform law in Latin America was signed today by President Eduardo Frei Montalva before a jubilant crowd of 12,000. Many Chilean peasants like those in the crowd will someday get deeds to part of the land that will be soon expropriated under the measure.
MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)-- The top Communist in the Soviet Union, Leonid I. Brezhnev, put in a personal appearance today at that old capitalist sport of kings, the horse races.
PARAMUS, N.J., July 16-- With a mixture of sorrow and delight, foreign tongues and familiar trappings, 3,000 teenagers from 59 countries converged on the Bergen Mall Shopping Center today.

DENVER, July 16 (UPI)--The Denver Broncos acquired three players--Dick Jackson, Ray Schmautz and Richard Tyson --from the Oakland Raiders for Lionel Taylor and Jerry Sturm, it was announced today by Lou Saban, the Broncos' general manager and head coach.

ANHOA, South Vietnam, July 16 (UPI)--The South Vietnamese Government has ordered a halt in construction work at a $50-million industrial complex 28 miles southwest of the United States base at Danang. The project was designed as a showcase of Vietnamese ability to "build while fighting."
MOSCOW, July 16--The Soviet Union made public today a confident account of economic development in the 50th year since the revolution.
More than 160,000 rail commuters will have to scramble for other ways to get into Manhattan today as a result of the strike that has shut down many of the nation's largest railroads.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 16-- More than 10,000 Puerto Ricans, chanting "Long live free Puerto Rico," congregated today at Sixto Escobar Stadium to protest the plebiscite on the island's political status to be held next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 16--The bipartisan Congressional leadership promised President Johnson today to push for legislation tomorrow to end the biggest railroad strike since 1946.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 16-- Leo M. Rogers, a lawyer in Paterson specializing in tax, estate and business law, died Friday of a heart attack in his summer home at 641 Ocean Avenue. He was 72 years old and lived at 136 Sunset Avenue. Ridgewood.
The appointment of H.V. (Pat) Reilly Jr. as manager of passenger relations for United States Lines has been announced by Kenneth F. Gautier, vice president for passenger traffic.

LONDON, July 16--Several thousand smiling, mild-mannered "flower people" sang, chanted, tinkled bells, handed out flowers, blew bubbles and danced today in Hyde Park to campaign gently for the legalization of marijuana.

Nicholas Glaviano, a 19-yearold sailor returning to his ship in Newport, R.I., was startled to learn at Grand Central Terminal early today that the 12:40 A.M. train to Providence had been canceled because of the railroad strike.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP) --Rudy Kolbl's unassisted fiveyard goal in the 38th minute of the first half carried St. Louis to a 1-0 victory over Pittsburgh today in a National Professional Soccer League Game.

WOODMERE, L.I., July 16 --Miss Elaine Carol Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Shapiro of Hewlett, was married here this afternoon to Bruce Josef Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Berman of New York. Rabbi Irving Miller, assisted by Cantor Lazar Wax, performed the ceremony at Congregation Sons of Israel.

ROCKY POINT, L.I., July 16 --Brenda Felicetti rode Fairy Dighton to the green working hunter championship today at the Fox Hill Stables' horse show. The 7-year-old brown gelding won two classes to compile 10 points.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 16-- Fog, mist and rain shrouded the Newport Folk Festival's first five days, from Monday through Friday, but last night the moon and the stars came out for Joan Baez. And she shone.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 16 (AP)--Rich Rollins's leadoff homer in the ninth inning gave the Minnesota Twins a 7-6 victory over the California Angels today for a sweep of their double-header.
A 100-year-old loft building in Brooklyn Heights will be converted into studio apartments for 42 artists.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 16-- More than 300 fellows of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, who are graduate students at 46 colleges and universities, urged President Johnson today "to end all military action against North Vietnam and to initiate negotiations with the National Liberation Front, with a view toward withdrawing our troops from South Vietnam."

The American Civil Liberties Union urged Congress yesterday to defeat the pending antiriot bill that would impose criminal penalties for "inciting" or "encouraging' a riot. The union said the bill would violate the rights of free speech and due process.
By 1970, the city budget will balloon to almost $8-billion, twice the money spent in Mayor Wagner's last year, City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16--The United States has tentatively agreed to support Rumania's Foreign Minister, Corneliu Manescu, for the presidency of the next regular session of the United Nations General Assembly in September.
VIENNA, July 16 (AP)-- Jochen Rindt of Austria, driving a Brabham Crosworth, edged Jack Brabham of Australia by less than a second today and won a Formula Two European Trophy automobile race.
PITTSBURGH, July 16--Automobile companies will soon order large tonnages of steel for September delivery.
JAY, Fla., July 16--Fire, apparently started during a convict brawl, flashed through a wooden barracks at the State Prison road camp late tonight, killing 37 inmates and injuring six others.

PASADENA, Calif., July 16-- Surveyor 4, an unmanned spacecraft, lost contact with its controllers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory here at 7:06 P.M. today, Pacific daylight time, 10:06 Eastern daylight time, three minutes before it was due to land on the moon.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 16 (AP)--A week-long strike marked by sporadic violence ended at the huge Newport News shipyard today as union workers approved overwhelmingly a settlement that had been recommended by their leaders.
ROME, July 16--Residents of Marzabotto voted 282 to 4 today to reject an appeal for clemency by the Nazi officer who ordered the killing of 1,830 townspeople during World War II.
HONG KONG, July 16--The day a year ago on which Mao Tse-tung, at the age of 72, is reported to have swum nine miles in the Yangtze River was elevated to a major anniversary in Communist China today.

Despite the huge success of the Monkees, there has been a decided reluctance to put the rock 'n" roll quartet on public display live. For this Hollywood-created immitation of the Beatles was a pure synthetic.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 16-- Delegates to Maryland's first constitutional convention in a century elected officers last week and adopted procedural rules for the working session of the convention which will open Sept. 12.

Twelve hours after the strike by the International Association of Machinists started, 27 railroads were completely shut down and more stoppages were expected, United Press International reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP)--A mass of chilling air forced temperatures to record lows early today in 13 states, many of them deep in the South.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority said yesterday it had voted to construct what it described as the city's first outdoor year-round swimming pool near the Brooklyn Expressway leading to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP)-- Tony Conigliaro's three-run homer sparked a five-run thirdinning rally that carried the Boston Red Sox to a 9-5 victory over Detroit today. The loss was the Tigers' sixth in a row.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) --Jim Wynn, the major leagues' runs-batted-in leader, drove in three runs with a double and his 22d homer today to lead the Houston Astros to an 8-2 victory over Los Angeles that completed a double-header sweep over the punchless Dodgers.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 16-- Earl McCullouch of the University of Southern California and the 49er Track Club of Los An. geles equaled the world record of 13.2 seconds for the 110meter high hurdles today in the second and final day of the United States track and field trials for the Pan-American Games.

Miss Heather Ann Holiber, daughter of Mrs. Irving Koeppel and Theodore Holiber, both of Forest Hills, Queens, was married here yesterday afternoon to Martin L. Gerson. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gerson of Brookline, Mass.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (UPI)--Ron Santo drove in Glen Beckert with a sacrifice fly in the ninth inning today to give Chicago a 3-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants after a grand slam by Adolfo Phillips and a three-run homer by Ernie Banks had powered the Cubs to a 9-0 victory in the opener.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 16 --The silver bus was decked inside and out with green leaves and orange gladioluses. It shuttled back and forth last night between the Herbert Hoover Elementary School, where 400 guests left their cars, and the ranch house of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Morrison, where a blacktie garden party for the 20-year-old Princess Maria Christina of the Netherlands took place.

"ALL the Gold, Jewels, and Diamonds in the World," wrote John Rowland in a dedicatory preface to Edward Top- sell's zoological encyclopedia of 1658, "are not comparable to any one of the meanest Creatures that hath within it the breath of life."

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 16--Marines on a sweep south of the demilitarized zone came under heavy fire yesterday and killed 25 enemy troops during an all-day battle, a Marine spokesman announced here today.
MIAMI BEACH, July 16 (AP) --Miss California, Susan Bradley, refused today to accept the vacant Miss U.S.A. title and the crown was given to Miss Florida.
KINNELON, N. J., July 16-- Silver Reserve, who broke down on the race track sevens years ago, captured the working hunter championship today at the Smoke Rise horse show.

MOSCOW, July 16 (Reuters) --A new Soviet airliner, the IL-62, which carries 186 passengers and is to go into service shortly, has completed a 9,000kilometer (5,400-mile) nonstop trial flight, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
MILLBURN, N.J., July 16-- Miss Karen Elise Blumenthal and Richard S. Stanzler were married here this evening at the Chanticler by Rabbi Jonathan Prinz. Cantor Nathaniel Sprinzen assisted.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16-- The tiresome game of waiting for fog to lift so that the four 12-Meter yachts trying for the honor of becoming the America's Cup defender against Australia was lost today by everybody involved for the fourth time since last Sunday.
Seven new plays will be presented this week, four next week and six the week after at the third playwrights' conference sponsored by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation at Waterford, Conn.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 16-- Robert F. Chamberlain, emeritus Professor of electrical engineering at Cornell University, died yesterday in the Cedar Manor Nursing Home. He was 83 years old and lived at 125 Merlin Avenue, North Tarrytown.

Having demonstrated all season long that they can't hit well, the New York Yankees showed yesterday that they can't bunt either as they lost a 14-inning game to the Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, before 21,695 at Yankee Stadium.
LISBON, July 16--The Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar has elaborated an ambitious new six-year development plan aimed at bringing the Portuguese economy up to a European level.

The four-week-old welfare work stoppage has hit hardest at services in the home, Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg said yesterday. But he declared that the city had no intention of changing its position in the dispute with the Social Service Employes Union.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 16-- Rear Adm. Robert Webster Cary, U.S.N., retired, a holder of the Medal of Honor, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 76.

ZACAPA, Guatemala, July 15 --In San Jorge, a small town close to this provincial capital, Guatemalan soldiers are digging a well so the townspeople do not have to go hundreds of yards with their jugs to get drinking water from a polluted stream.
Serge Semenenko, the mystery man of banking, will announce his retirement this week as vice chairman and director of Boston's First National Bank to become an independent corporate consultant.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 16 (UPI)--Federal mediators said today that they foresaw no early settlement of a strike that has halted about 90 per cent of the nation's copper production.
NSUKKA, Nigeria, July 13-- Despite charges on the Lagos radio, there apparently are no foreign mercenaries leading rebel Biafran troops into combat.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 16-The noonday sun never appeared here today. And the closest thing to a mad dog was a cinnamon-colored poodle that shivered in the shelter of a parked limousine.
HONOLULU, July, 16 (AP)-- A two-month strike at the Hawaii Tribune-Herald in Hilo ended today after members of three unions voted unanimously to accept terms of a three-year contract.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16 --There were over 500 boats staffed by 1,500 crewman ready to go sailing today at Larchmont Race Week. Because of the lack of a leading ingredient --wind--only 20 boats were able to start a race and of that number merely 12 finished. All the others went home after waiting up to two hours for the glassy appearance of Western Long Island Sound to change.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 16 (AP) --The British High Commissioner in Lagos, Sir David Hunt, ordered the evacuation of all Britons from the secessionist Eastern Region.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) --Ken McMullen hit two home runs today and Bob Humphreys and Bob Priddy combined to pitch a four-hitter as they led the Washington Senators to a 4-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The triumph was Washington's seventh in a row.
The 15-story apartment building at 25 East 86th Street, occupying the west blockfront of Madison Avenue from 86th to 87th Street, has been sold to its tenants by Franshur Associates for $4,833,750.

LONDON, July 16--Thousands cheered Alec Rose, a 59-yearold grocer, today as he set off from the Royal Albert Yacht Club at Southsea to sail alone around the world in the wake of Sir Francis Chichester and his Gipsy Moth IV.
A prominent Negro psychologist suggested last night that the lootings and burning of property in Negro districts is the rioters' way of saying they want such areas destroyed.
EUGENE, Ore., July 16-- This city is using a shackle to hobble cars that have been given parking tickets.
Holiday Inns of America, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Clyde H. Dixon and Frank W. Adams to the new rank of senior vice president.
MANILA, July 16--President Ferdinand E. Marcos made a quick flying trip to South Vietnam today and said on his return that the allied efforts there must not lead to appeasement.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 16 (AP)--Manuel Santana swept through Alex Metreveli, 6.0, 6-3, 6-3, today and clinched the European Zone Group A Davis Cup tennis final for Spain.
LONDON, July 16 (Reuters)--Lynda Bird Johnson presented Britain's top polo award to a winning team today and joined the players in drinking champagne from it.

MADRID, July 16--The clandestine workers' commissions in Spain are threatening a campaign of strikes and demonstrations to attain independent labor unions.
By next summer, some New Yorkers may be enjoying airconditioned subway trains that will roll more quietly into more attractive and better-lighted stations, a transit official said yesterday.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 16--The Congolese Army was reported today to be preparing to move against the mercenary force that occupied the northeastern city of Kisangani until last Wednesday night.

HICKSTEAD, England, July 16 (UPI)--Marion Coakes of Britain, the world's show jumping champion, rode Stroller to victory today in the British Jumping Derby, the premier event at the International Horse Show.
LEEDS, England, July 16 (AP) --Lord Milner, a former deputy speaker of the House of Commons and a leading figure in the Inter-Parliamentary Union, died at his home here today. He Was 77 years old.
Two American oil companies --Phillips Petroleum and Marathon Oil--have placed an order with a Swedish shipyard for the construction of the world's largest vessels to carry liquefied gas.
The Penn A.C. of Philadelphia won the eight-oared race and the New York A.C. took team honors yesterday in the first national junior rowing championships on the Orchard Beach Lagoon, the Bronx.

TOULOUSE, France, July 16 (AP)--Rolf Wolfshohl of Germany won the 15th leg of the Tour de France bicycle race today. He finished a 143-mile stretch from Sete in 6 hours 28 minutes 23 seconds.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP)-- George Halas, the owner and coach of the Chicago Bears of the National Football League announced the signing today of John Paluck, a defensive end,
Hale L. Montgomery, a New York investment banker, died yesterday of a heart attack in his summer cottage in Lindenhurst, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived at 152 East 84th Street.

TEAMS captained by B. Jay Becker and John Lowen- thal met in one semifinal of the Knockout Team Championship at the Brooklyn Sectional Tournament yesterday afternoon, and Philip Feldesman's team played Mrs. Betty Pearly in the other.

SEATTLE, July 16--The Boeing Company has notified the world's major airlines that it will begin accepting orders at 9 A.M. tomorrow for "second-round" delivery positions for its supersonic transport plane.
SAYVILLE, L.I., July 16-- Hartwell (Bucky) Moore sailed Mavourneen to victory today in the final race of the series and captured the Corry Cup, emblematic of Great South Bay Star Class supremacy.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 16 --The Florida Legislature, which convened on April 4 with high hopes that its reapportioned membership would pass enlightened legislation, ended its session Friday with a mostly negative record.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 16 (AP) --Mike Belkin, a Canadian Davis Cup player, won the 80th Western tennis tournament today by defeating Ecuador's Francisco Guzman, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, 6-2.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., July 16--Jerry Crawford of Bow, N.H., and Bob Grossman of Nyack, N.Y., were the victors today in the featured races of the Sports Car Club of America national amateur meeting.
Soviet analysts of the United States economy have told the Kremlin not to expect any serious recession in this country, at least through 1970.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 16--In Temple Sinai this afternoon, Miss Roberta Marcia Zeitler of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Zeitler, was married to Donald Alan Robinson, son of Mrs. Adrian Haas of Scarsdale and Raymond S. Robinson of Mount Vernon. Rabbi Henry Enoch Kagan performed the ceremony.

About 1,000 fans from Memphis honored one of their native sons, Tim McCarver, before the game. McCarver, talking about Bob Gibson's loss as he was taking batting practice, said: "Sure, it's a tough break, but were men, aren't we? We're supposed to be able to accept it and keep right on winning."

BALTIMORE, July. 16 (AP)-- A Baltimore player allowed a shot by New York's George Kirby to roll off his hands and into the goal today for the winning tally as the Generals defeated the Bays, 2-1, before 6, 159 National Professional Soccer League fans.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (AP)--The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists wound up a three-day convention here by electing a New York announcer, Mel Brandt, as its new national president.

KYOTO, Japan, July 16-- This cultural center and former imperial capital is having its annual festival month, and it is one of the times when the exotic East peeps through the thick patina of Westernization acquired in Japan's headlong rush to industrialize.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 15 --The rural Bishop blinked uncertainly into the television lights as he read the announcement he had come to the capital to make.

The significance of the Freedom of Information Law which symbolically took effect July 4 cannot be measured in statutory words alone. Government bureaucrats can take comfort in both the rules and the exceptions. What is more important is that such a law is on the books at all. How it will work will depend primarily on the tone and style set by the Administration and Congress.

Special to The New York Times ORANGE, N.J., July 16-- David Lieberman, president of J. Liberman Co., paper wholesalers, of Jersey City, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in East Orange.

The North Jersey Wind Symphony's concert on the Mall in Central Park on Saturday night had a surrealist quality at times. The listener would see Keith Brion conducting a quiet section of, say, Alan Hovhaness's "Return and Rebuild the Desolate Places" but the sound heard would be that of Herbie Mann and His Group, which was playing a few blocks south at the Wollman Skating Rink.
More than 1,000 Quakers from 38 countries will gather late this month in Greensboro, N.C., for their first world conference in 15 years.
Thanks largely to automation, New York women by the tens of thousands are giving up their evenings at home to become night people.
Four players, led by eighthseeded George Ball of Roslyn, L.I., reached the third round of the Eastern 35 years-and-over tennis championship yesterday at the West Park Racquet Club here.

The sealing of incinerators that do not meet new air-pollution control requirements will be halted today because of a conflict with the new housing code, an aide at the Department of Air Pollution Control said yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 16 (UPI)--Saboteurs destroyed or damaged 10 American-built T-28 bombers of the Royal Laotian Air Force in a raid on the Luang Prabang airfield early today, military officials reported.

The U.S.S., Haven, formerly a hospital ship, has been allocated to the Union Carbide Corporation (New York) for conversion to a specialized chemical carrier. This has been done under authority of the Ship Exchange Act, according to an announcement by J. W. Gulick, acting maritime administrator, United States Department of Commerce.

Senator Jacob K. Javits has been seeking the views of people in various parts of the world on a proposal that private citizens seek to end the Arab refugee problem immediately, by resettling refugees on the west bank of the Jordan River, an area now occupied by Israel.
BOSTON, July 16--Elliot L. Richardson, the attorney general of Massachusetts, said today that he had issued a publication explaining the rights of arrested persons.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 16 --Oliver C. Billings Jr. of Fox Hollow Road, Convent Station, western territory manager of the city mortgages division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in Morristown Memorial Hospital. His age was 63.
When you think of Jack Benny, you probably think of comedy, radio, Jell-O and Lucky Strike.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., July 16 (AP)--A hundred airmen searched a crowded beach here today for 6,000 explosive "mini-mines" that apparently were lost while being tested for use in Vietnam.

Miss Barbara Ellen Cartin, daughter of Mrs. Jerry Korman of New York and Dr. Samuel Cartin of Tucson, Ariz., was married yesterday afternoon at the Carlton House to Sanford Jerome Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldberg of St. Louis. Rabbi Gerold Goldman officiated.

RAILROADS: The New York Central, Pennsylvania, ErieLackawanna, Jersey Central and New Haven lines will run no trains today. Long Island trains will run, except to Manhattan, but the precise schedule is in doubt.

SUTTON, Mass., July 16 (AP)--Kathy Whitworth holed a 50-foot uphill putt on the 18th green today and won the 13th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association championship reaching a goal that had escaped her in eight previous professional seasons.
NEWARK, Monday, July 17-- National Guard troops and the police hunted house to house for snipers today after gunfire claimed three more lives in this riot-torn city.

ST. LOUIS, July 16--The New York Mets accomplished a little miracle today in Busch Memorial Stadium. They beat the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals in a double-header, 2-1 and 8-5. It was only the second time this season Manager Wes Westrum's club had taken both ends of a twin bill. They won their first on June 6 in Pittsburgh.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 16--An Episcopal priest told his parishioners today that he had found the city administration "reluctant" to face a narcotics problem.
ATHENS, July 16--The Government offered easy credit terms and collateral security today for orders to Greek shipyards.

ROME, July 16--Pope Paul VI, speaking from the loggia over the main portals of St. Peter's Basilica, called today for prayers for his trip to Turkey, where he will meet Archbishop Athenagoras, the Orthodox Patriarch, in a "visit of hope" for church reconciliation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16 --Andres Gimeno of Spain gained the most significant victory of his career today in defeating Kenneth Rosewall of Australia in the semi-finals of the United States professional tennis championship at the Lonswood Cricket Club.
NEWARK, July 16--Thousands of residents of Newark's heavily Negro Central Ward lined up today to receive food supplies that had been virtually cut off since the rioting began here Wednesday night.

BRUSSELS--The American in the Westbury Hotel Polo Bar in Brussels is no tourist. He has ordered Old Granddad on the rocks for himself and his guest and, with his little black notebook open, is quoting prices and specifications for miniatur- ized circuitry.
CINCINNATI, July 16 (UPI) --The Philadelphia Phillies pounded out 14 hits today to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 8-0, behind the four-hit pitching of Jim Bunning.
HONG KONG, July 16--The Police intensified their campaign against Communist insurrectionists in Hong Kong today, as Peking launched a new attack on the British administration here.

The appliance industry--both electric and gas versions--have just about thrown in the towel on 1967. There are exceptions in the case of individual appliances, but most are hoping now to limp through this year and look for improvement in 1968.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 15-- Most of the great Euro- pean festivals you go to and watch. The Festival of TwoWorlds here seems to be somewhere to live. The festival simply takes over the town, and the medieval streets, rambling lazily over the Umbrian hillside, the palaces and churches, the cafes and the squares become as much a part of the festival as the theaters are.

BABYLON, L.I., July 16-- Jim Hahn of Bay Head, N.J., captured the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Finn Class championship today, closing out the series with a first-place finish and a third. He was no worse than third in the six races of the series.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16 --Edward H. Chamberlin, professor emeritus of political economy at Harvard University, died today at the Holy Ghost Hospital. He was 68 Years old.

NEWARK, July 16--Rioting has left its mark everywhere in the Negro section--in burned-out stores, in bulletstrafed walls, in heaps of broken glass that crunch under the boots of members of the National Guard as they walk the streets, rifles at the ready.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 16-- Spokesmen for Nigeria's secessionist Eastern Region have acknowledged a retreat, "as a temporary measure," from the area of Nsukka, which federal forces said they captured Friday.
Two leading legal authorities at the Constitutional Convention said yesterday they would vote, if they got the opportunity, to gear the number of judges in the state to the growth in population.
The First Asian Eye Institute in Manila will benefit from a charity ball of the Philippine-New York Junior Chamber of Commerce in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf at 9 P.M. on Saturday.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 17 (UPI)--George Brunet of the California Angels pitched a four-hit, 2-0 victory over Minnesota today and checked the Twins' bid to gain a tie for first place with the idle Chicago White Sox.
GLADSTONE, N.J., July 17 --Four riders and eight horses were named today to the United States Prix des Nations (jumping) team that will defend its gold medal in the PanAmerican Games at Winnipeg.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17 --"Foreigners who come to Bangkok looking for the Venice of the East are disappointed," according to Chamnara Yuvaboon, the wealthy Lord Mayor of Bangkok. "The slightest trace of similarity to Venice is being obliterated."

SEATTLE, July 17 (AP)--Six airlines reserved delivery positions today at a cost of $750,000 each for 16 United States supersonic transports as the Boeing Company began accepting "second round" SST reservations.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (UPI)--A new 70-member committee including Joan Baez, the folk singer; four clergymen, a lawyer, university professors and Quakers was formed today to encourage young men to refuse military induction.

MOSCOW, July 17 (UPI)-- Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, said today that the Newark riots were part of a war between the oppressors and the oppressed in the United States that would continue "as long as capitalism exists."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17 (AP)--Bernard (Peck) Hickman has stepped down as basketball coach at the University of Louisville to spend full time as the school's athletic director.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- The gross national product resumed its growth in the second quarter of this year, despite a slowdown in the rate of increase in military spending, the Commerce Department reported today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 17 (Reuters)--The Indonesian Army today announced the arrest of dozens of supporters of President Sukarno. The Government also moved to head off student demonstrations calling for formal steps to check any comeback by the President, who holds his post in name only.
WASHINGTON, July 17-- Roger Dow, a retired Foreign Service officer, died here yesterday while attending a service at Saint Paul's Episcopal Church. He was 61 years old.

MADRID, July 17--Generalissimo Francisco Franco, still the undisputed leader of his nation, will celebrate tomorrow the 31st anniversary of the beginning of his successful "crusade" against the Second Republic, established in 1931 after Kind Alfonso XIII abdicated and led in 1936 by middle-ofthe-roaders and leftists.
The Hotel Corporation of America has announced the appointment of Arthur D. Dooley as vice president and general manager of the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- An Administration spokesman told Congress today that riots in Newark and other American cities had resulted from "decades of neglect and discrimination" and could be prevented from spreading only by "basic, gigantic, well-directed positive action."
ELIZABETH, N.J., Tuesday, July 18--Racial violence erupted last night in this city of 113,000 bordering on Newark.
LONDON, July 17--An American-owned and operated ship valued at $17-million has been seized in Singapore in the aftermath of the wreck of the supertanker Torrey Canyon.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP)--Joe Foy sparked three scoring bursts with two doubles and a single and Lee Stange scattered seven hits as the Boston Red Sox handed the Detroit Tigers their seventh straight loss, 7-1, tonight.

FRESNO, Calif., July 17 (AP) --Ruins of a lumber yard still smoldered today as relative calm returned to West Fresno after a day and night of vandalism during which an antipoverty official was wounded.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 18--The six shopcraft unions this morning ordered their striking members back to work on the nation's railroads after President Johnson signed a bill calling for an end of the walkout.
Insurance claims adjusters have been gathering on the edge of the riot-torn sections of Newark for the last four days to try to find out how much their companies are going to have to pay in claims.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP)--Charges of air piracy against a Pennsylvania manufacturer were reduced in Federal Court today to two counts of assault aboard an airplane--a misdemeanor.

The Middle East crisis has produced a new television idol, Denmark's Hans R. Tabor. Mr. Tabor, his nation's permanent representative at the United Nations, who served as president of the Security Council during June, has received 8,500 letters from television viewers.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) --House Republican sponsors of a plan to de-escalate the war in Vietnam said today the failure of previous peace feelers was no reason to give up the effort. They said United States diplomacy might have been at fault. The plan was proposed July 10.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 17--Two hundred passengers, many carrying children, were rescued tonight from the coastal steamer Jamhuri, which ran aground last night on a coral reef off Dar es Salaam.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17-- The most unlikely song hit since "Yes, We Have No Bananas" or "Flat Foot Floogee" swept triumphantly through the Newport Folk Festival yesterday, the festival's last day. The song, "Alice's Restaurant " was composed and sung by Arlo Guthrie, the 20-yearold son of Woody Guthrie, who is known for his Dust Bowh ballads and "This Land Is Your Land."

Miss Indrea Kintisch and Thomas C. White plan to marry Aug. 20. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Kintisch's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kintisch of Brooklyn. Mr. White is the son of the Rev. Edgar E. White, a retired Baptist minister, and Mrs. White of Baltimore.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 17-- Gone are the days when shipwrecks occurred often enough to provide havens for frisky fish. Such navigational niceties as sonar and radar have all but eliminated the possibility of new artificial hangouts for the finn-propelled set.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., July 17--Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. McMahon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Lee McMahon, to David L. Myers of Boston, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Myers of Martinsburg, W. Va.

The choir-loft performing area of Judson Memorial Church has a new floor (polished to a gloss by some misguided zealot), but in no other way has the Judson Dance Theater broken from its bizarre patchwork tradition.
WASHINGTON, July 17--Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, disclosed today that he was preparing a detailed reply to a charge of misconduct.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 17--Miss Nancy Maryl Cohen's engagement to Leonard William Kram has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cohen. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Kram of Roslyn Heights.

ROME, July 17--Pope Paul VI was reported today to have ordered the abrogation of the oath against modernism that Roman Catholic priests and ecclesiastical officials have been obliged to take for the last 57 years.
The American Express Company, Inc., had the highest half-year profits in its 116-year history in the six months ended June 30.

HONG KONG, July 17 (Reuters)--Firemen put out a blaze in a hold of the 27,632-ton British luxury liner Oronsay tonight after a 14-hour battle.
NEWARK, July 17--Teenaged Negro youths sat on folded newspapers on a rotting wooden stoop in the Clinton Hill section here today and played cards.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- Radiation exposure can be and important problem in space flights of long duration, although it has produced no significant hazard so far, said a report issued today by the Space Science Board of the National Research Council.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 17 --Forrest L. Daniels, who retired recently as executive vice president and treasurer of Peter Schladermundt Associates, industrial designers of 205 East 42d Street, New York, died here yesterday in his home at 486 North Street. His age was 48.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- The White House called on the National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong, and on North Vietnam today to permit the impartial inspection of American prisoners and to return the seriously sick and wounded among them.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. July 17--The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Ann Pulaski to Mark Stewart Mertens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mertens of Manhasset, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Pulaski.
MIAMI, July 17--The Castro Government is adopting a series of economic and social measures apparently designed to show that Cuba is leading the Soviet bloc countries on the road to pure Communism.
WINNIPEG, Man., July 17-- James E. Coyne was removed from his post as president of the Bank of Western Canada by a unanimous vote of the bank's board of directors tonight.

Silver futures rose sharply yesterday in heavy trading on the Commodity Exchange here. Distant months rose the daily limit of 5 cents an ounce, with the nearby month of July --on which there is no limit --advancing 9.65 cents an ounce. The July contract closed at $1.79 cents an ounce compared with $1.69.85 cents at the prior close.

MONTREAL, July 17--Delegates from 26 member countries convened here yesterday for the one-week 21st congress of the International Federation of Jeunesses Musicales. They arrived just in time for music day at Expo 67.

John B. McCloskey, an official of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, which administers relief programs all over the world, died yesterday after a long illness in his home, 141 East 33d Street. His age was 66.

BRUSSELS, July 17--A proposal by Foreign Minister Brandt for an economic committee of cooperation between the Common Market and Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union, has stirred interest in Common Market headquarters.

Under the pressure of President Johnson's warning of a national crisis, Congress finally passed yesterday the legislation necessary to end the railroad strike. Responsibility for this completely unnecessary crisis must be shared by the strikers and the House of Representatives.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 17-- The major part of the dance activities at this year's Festival of the Two Worlds at Spoleto was provided by the old world in the persons of the Stuttgart State Ballet. However, there is nothing particularly old world about either the company or its director-choreographer, the Englishman John Cranko.
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino sailed for Italy on the Michelangelo yesterday, and invited 300 friends, relatives and political colleagues to see him off.
UTICA, N.Y., July 17 (AP) --Employes of The ObserverDispatch and The Daily Press both of which are on strike, were urged to return to their jobs by the publisher of the newspapers.

Barry Boys, the director of a scheduled series of Shakespearean plays and rehearsal programs on Channel 13, has been discharged by the station for exceeding his $168,000 budget for the first two productions by $35,000.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17--Official statistics indicate that the burden of fighting the Vietcong and North Vietnamese has passed decisively to American troops.

ROME, July 17--The Italian haute-couture designers, who used to be the friskiest, most fun-loving people in fashion, have calmed down in their new fall-winter collections. Most of them feel that too much contemporary fashion has been looking slightly lunatic and too many clothes look right only on 15-year-olds.

NEWARK, July 17--Leaders of Negro groups here agreed today that no single person could speak for all of this city's more than 200,000 Negroes.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 17 --The state's Hudson River Valley Commission announced today its rules for reviewing the plans for industrial, residential and municipal projects that might infringe on a balanced development of the valley.
