Prices edged up in fairly active trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
THE HAGUE, July 17 (UPI) --Premier Ion Georghe Maurer of Rumania urged today that the United States and the Soviet Union dissolve their systems of military alliances.
ABINGDON, Md., July 17-- The Rev. Dr. William Foster Peirce, president of Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, from 1896 to 1937, died today in his home here after a short illness. His age was 99.
Western Carloading Company, one of the nation's major freight forwarders, has named James F. Kelly as executive vice president, the company's top operating officer.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today modification of the oil import program to encourage the use of low sulphur fuel oil to combat air pollution of the East and West Coasts.
YONKERS, July 17--With a record 14 trotters named today to start in the Yonkers Futurity, Thursday night's one-mile test for 3-year-olds may look more like a cavalry charge than a race.
Mrs. Elsie Barber Delafield, widow of Frederick P. Delafield, a lawyer and authority on municipal bonds, died of a heart attack yesterday in her home at 136 East 79th Street. She was 93 years old.
The Soviet Union's newest long-range jet passenger aircraft, the IL-62, is scheduled to make its debut in North America tomorrow.

American confidence in the United Nations has been shaken but far from destroyed by the organization's treatment of the Middle East crisis, according to a survey by Louis Harris, published in yesterday's New York Post.

THE controversy over payas-you-see television finds the Federal Communication Commission a little restless trying to keep up with electronic progress. Last week the agency made public a massive document on pay TV that adroitly sidestepped the issue that has stirred broadcasters, impresarios and Wall Street circles: Pay television that would not go out over the air but would be delivered by wire.

MOSCOW, July 17 (AP)--The Soviet Union contended today that a recent decision by Peking to break a minor Soviet-Chinese-North Korean agreement showed that Communist China was further curtailing relations with Soviet-bloc countries.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday refused to vacate the conviction of J. Vincent Keogh, former Brooklyn Supreme Court justice, for conspiracy to obstruct justice in an attempt to fix a bankruptcy fraud case.

Gus Washington, a 15-yearold athlete from Brooklyn, was selected yesterday for the second straight year to the New York City basketball team that will represent this city in the United States Youth Games next month.

The New York Stock Exchange delayed the opening of trading yesterday in the stocks of 18 foreign companies in an unusual move to draw attention to proposed changes in the interest-equalization tax on foreign securities.

MANASQUAN PARK, N.J., July 17--Lieut. Warren R. Brundage Jr. of the Marine Corps, died last Thursday of injuries received in the crash of a jet plane while on a training flight over Folkston, Ga. His age was 22 and he lived here on Cypress Street.

HONG KONG, July 17--Jenmin Jih Pao, the official newspaper of the Mao Tse-tung regime in Peking, called today on Maoist partisans of Communist China's Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution not to weaken or relent in their drive against those who have been branded as revisionists.
MOSCOW, July 17--President Houari Boumediene of Algeria and President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq arrived today for talks on the Middle Eastern situation with Soviet officials.

The National Council of Chile's Christian Democratic party has come out with a surprising declaration in favor of allowing the Havana-based LatinAmerican "Solidarity Organization" to operate freely in Chile. It even had some kind words for guerrilla warfare, provided such violence is directed against "governments that ignore the people's rights and offer no electoral solutions."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 18 (AP)--The election committee of the Provisional Assembly refused today to give the green light to the military presidential slate headed by South Vietnam's chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, and Premier Nguyen Cao Ky. The military junta called an emergency meeting.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 17--The blacklisting of the public-school system here by the New York State Teachers Association ended today after a tentative agreement on more pay for teachers was reached by the school board and leaders of the local unit of the association.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) --Three war protesters were carried out of the Pentagon in wheel chairs today as defense officials laid down a policy of prohibiting announced demonstrators from expressing their dissent inside the building. ing.

AMATEUR cooks have won money in contests and have paid money to learn from the experts but seldom, if ever, have they paid to demonstrate their skills for the palates of a paying audience. As a fund-raising idea, it can take its place with benefit balls, theater parties, fairs and raffles.

WASHINGTON, July 17--A Controversy within the House Banking and Currency Committee over the financing of Defense Department arms sales by the Export-Import Bank has delayed action on a bill to renew the bank's charter for another five years.

AKRON, Ohio, July 17 (AP)-- An injunction limiting the number of United Rubber Workers members picketing at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company here was granted today after... pickets kept many of the 6,000 salaried workers from their jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- Yields on new issues of Treasury bills moved in diverse directions at today's auction, with those on the 91-day bills falling to their lowest level in three weeks and those on the 182-day bills rising to their highest level since January.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17--Foreign Minister Abba Eban set forth today, as a condition for peace talks with the Arabs, the recognition of Israel's "statehood, sovereignty and international rights."

PASADENA, Calif., July 17 --Flight engineers of Surveyor 4's ground crew met with officials of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory here today to try to find out why the unmanned spacecraft went silent last night just as it was about to land on the moon.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 17 (AP)--Leaders of the nation's five million Presbyterians called today for greater concern about the needs of the people of the world. The statements came after two days of meetings among the moderators of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., the Presbyterian Church, U.S., and the Cumberland Presbyterian Church.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Tuesday, July 18--Negro and white leaders early today announced they had reached agreement on a plan to bring an end to the racial violence that began here last Friday.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission believes that the National Association of Securities Dealers may not have been doing all it should have to protect investors from fraud and other improper activities in the over-the-counter securities markets.

After announcing that they were calling up Roy White from Spokane, where he was leading the Pacific Coast League in hitting with .343, the New York Yankees proceeded to show again how badly they need any kind of hitting by losing to the Baltimore Orioles, 6-1, last night.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 17 --About 75 of the city's 300 municipal employes went on strike today for higher wages.
Two city commissioners expressed sharply different opinions yesterday on the effectiveness of the program to control air pollution from apartment house incinerators.
A group of clergymen seeking to help resolve a contract dispute between the city and its Welfare Department caseworkers failed yesterday to get the sides together.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP)--The Chrysler Corporation will get the jump on the rest of the automobile industry next Monday when it builds the first of the 1968 models.
ATHENS, July 17 (AP)--The Government said today that it had smashed a subversive organization backed by Communists on the island of Crete and arrested eight persons.
A Westchester milkman accused of picking up policy bets as well as empty bottles was indicted with three other persons yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating Federal gambling laws.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 17 --Rodney Laver overcame the menacing challenge of Andres Gimeno of Spain tonight and won the United States professional tennis championship for the third time in the four years it has been held here on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club. The scores of the twohour match were 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, 7-5.
NORFOLK, Va., July 17 (AP) --For the first time since the War of 1812, international naval forces are sailing the Great Lakes.
At the coffee bar on the 8:44 A.M. train from Mineola, L.I., Larry Lippman of South Merrick, L.I., shouted, "Where is everybody?"
BONN, July 17--The West German Foreign Ministry will send a large delegation to Prague Wednesday to negotiate an exchange of trade missions with Czechoslovakia, it was announced today.
AROUND the offices of Peck Peck, the wom en's specialty shop with 67 branches, including 10 college stores, there is a saying that the Peck Peck girls major in classics.
WASHINGTON (UPI)--Following is the text of President Johnson's statement on signing legislation to halt the nationwide rail strike:
HONG KONG, July 17 (AP) --Terrorists struck in Hong Kong again tonight. A 17-yearold youth was found stabbed to death and three bomb blasts injured two men.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 17 (Reuters)--Controversy is raging here because a foot powder called Pulvapies was elected Mayor of a town of 4,000 people.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 (UPI)--Alfred Stern Jr.'s sloop Diavolo sailed across the finish line in rainy, windy weather today with the best corrected time among the first nine finieshers in the 333-mile yacht race from Chicago. She was the seventh boat to finish.

MILWAUKEE, July 17 (AP)-- Lenny Schloss of the University of Tennessee upset Clark Graebner, the nation's thirdranked player, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4, in the first round of the national clay-court tennis championships.

Railroad strikers began returning to work in the metropolitan area just before 1 A.M. today, and the lines rushed plans to resume service for the 160,000 commuters who, in general, calmly met the challenge of yesterday's strike.
Troop level statistics associated with Defense Secretary McNamara's visits to South Vietnam read like altitude markers on a steep mountain road.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (UPI) --The presidents of two major railroad unions today accused the railroads of creating a national crisis and locking out nonstriking employes.
The Chicago North Western Railway announced plans yesterday for construction of a $12.3-million ironore transfer and storage terminal at Escanaba, Mich., the only ore transfer point on Lake Michigan.

WASHINGTON, July 17 --The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved Da vid S. Black to be Under Secretary of the Interior today, after another skirmish in the "water war" between the Pacific Northwest and the Southwest.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) --The Federal Mediation Service today summoned both management and labor to Washington Wednesday in an effort to end the strike at Colt Industries, Inc., the sole producer of the M-16 rifle used in Vietnam.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17-- The Voluntary Defender Association contended in Quarter Sessions Court today that there is no such crime as habitual drunkenness.
WASHINGTON, July 17--Following is the text of the White House statement on prisoners of war in Vietnam:

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 17 (UPI)--President Joseph D. Mobutu said tonight that Congolese troops had cut off a band of foreign mercenaries and rebellious Katangese gendarmes trying to escape through the African bush.
LONDON, July 17 (AP)-- The International Weight Lifting Federation announced tonight there would be no world championships this year.
Central Park: New York Philharmonic, Lorin Maazel conducting, with Michael Rabin, violinist, Sheep Meadow, 8:30 P.M.
The New York Philharmonic warmed up yesterday for tonight's third summer opening in Central Park with a rehearsal audience.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 17 (UPI)--The nation's copper production was almost at a standstill today.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- G. Lincoln Sandelin, controller of operations of the Inter-American Development Bank here, died Saturday of a heart attack while on a mission for the bank in Quito, Ecuador. He was 60 years old.
Chevron Oil Europe, Inc., a new subsidiary of Standard Oil of California, has leased 35,000 square feet of office space in the new 47-story American Tobacco Building at 245 Park Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (UPI)--Chuck Hartenstein came out of the bull pen with two out and the tying run on third base in the ninth inning today to get the final out and give the Chicago Cubs their third straight victory over the San Francisco Giants, 4-3.

The nationwide railroad strike is the most extensive since a two-day walkout by trainmen and engineers in May, 1946. At that time, the unions accepted a wage offer they had rejected earlier because President Truman was pressing Congress for legislation to order a return to work.
CHICAGO, July 17--The American Osteopathic Association denounced today efforts by the American Medical Association to absorb the osteopathic profession.
WASHINGTON, July 17-- The Roman Catholic Mayor of predominantly Roman Catholic Trenton, N.J., sent word to a House committee today that his city wanted a family planning project for the poor.
A literary critic's four-year suit against G.P. Putnam's Sons, the publishing house, on charges of misrepresenting his evaluation of "Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure," ended in a handshake yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17--A securities-industry spokesman warned today that the Treasury's new rules to prevent largescale evasion of the interestequalization tax would not work.
OMAHA, July 17 (UPI)--One man was killed and four others were injured today when a KC135 jet tanker crashed at Offutt Air Force Base, headquarters for the Strategic Air Command.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (UPI)-- Dr. I.C. Middleman, physician for the St. Louis Cardinals, said today that Bob Gibson was able to pitch to three batters Saturday, despite a broken leg, because he "has a high threshold for pain."
John Coltrane, the tenor saxophonist, who was considered one of the most gifted modern jazz musicians of this decade, died yesterday at Huntington Hospital, Huntington, L.I. He was 40 years old.

MILTON, Fla., July 17 (AP)-- Prisoners who survived a prison fire yesterday that killed 37 convicts said at an inquest today that it had been set deliberately by three inmates. They said the three had plotted to "tear the place apart."

SYRACUSE, July 17--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Arthur O'Hara Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Margaret Marie O'Hara, to Thomas Descamp Morse, son of Mrs. Dorothy Hagenow of Springfield, Vt., and the late Romain S. Morse. A September wedding is planned.
LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) --A report in the British newspaper The Guardian today said there was reason to believe that the United States had decided to suspend the bombing of North Vietnam.
A number of airline accounts have been up in the air recently, and a much larger number of agencies on the ground have been waiting for them to land.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 17 --The Louisiana Legislature is seeking to enact legislation to establish a 'labor-management commission of inquiry" to investigate alleged racketeering in labor disputes. A 12-day special session opened today.
The bond market marked time yesterday. The session provided few clues to the course of interest rates.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 17 (Reuters)--The Nigerian Government gave permission tonight for the evacuation of hundreds of foreigners in the secessionist Eastern region.
ALBANY, July 17--The Constitutional Convention voted 102 to 76 tonight to keep New York's voting age at 21.

PIKEVILLE, Ky., July 17-- An angry confrontation between rural Kentuckians and the bulldozers of a Pike County strip mining company seemed assured today by a court ruling that upheld an 80year-old subsurface mineral deed.
CHICAGO, July 17--The Board of Governors of State Colleges and Universities re fused today to approve the appointment of Staughton C. Lynd to the history department at Chicago State College.

BIALOWIEZA FOREST, Poland, July 14--More than 120 bison, majestic reminders of this country's prehistoric past, roam in freedom today in an immense forest that once was the royal hunting preserve of Polish Kings.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 17 (AP)--A former White House aide said today that a high-level Government consensus to shift the United States attitude toward United Nations membership for Communist China was stalled by timing and Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
Mrs. Olga Bortin Stark, widow of Abraham I. Stark, a lawyer, died Sunday in the Hayden Manor Nursing Home, at 34 West 74th Street. She was 83 years old and lived at 330 West End Avenue.

Price increases of as much as 25 per cent were announced yesterday for silverbearing products--such as photographic film and tableware--after basic quotations for the metal took one of the most spectacular one-day jumps in history.

MUZAFFARABAD, Kashmir, July 16--A whitewashed marker at the edge of this town says: "Srinagar 111 miles." For most of the people who live here it would be more accurate if it said, "Srinagar, 20 years."

WASHINGTON, July 17-- The man in the center of the storm surrounding the first nationwide railroad strike since 1946 is one who twice has come to public attention late in his career and both times with a bang.
NEWARK, Tuesday, July 18 --National Guard units and state troopers began moving out of Newark yesterday after Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced at midday that "the rioting and looting are over."

The city plans to provide hospital privileges by Jan. 1 for up to half of the 6,500 practicing physicians here who are not now associated with any hospital, the city's Health Services Administrator said yesterday.

BUKAVU, the Congo, July 17 (AP)--Some residents of this eastern Congo city remained barricaded in their homes today, nearly two weeks, after the Congolese Army went on a rampage of killing, raping and looting.
A men's apparel company, whose silk ties have been emblazoned with stainedglass window designs and Persian rug patterns, will introduce ties decorated with famous medals in a colorful fall campaign.
CHICAGO, July 17--About 120,000 commuters found new ways to get to and from work today when the railroad strike shut down all six commuter lines here.

KYOTO, Japan, July 17--ProCommunist students at Kyoto University, a center of leftism and one of the most respected institutions of higher learning in Japan, area leading a nationwide campus movement to bar members of the Japanese defense forces from taking courses in civilian classrooms.
Steel production last week edged 1.3 per cent above the preceding week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) --This city's first sonic boom today shook houses, rattled windows and drew the gaze of millions skywards.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP)--The First National Bank of Boston confirmed today the retirement of Serge Semenenko, its vice chairman and a director, to permit him to become an independent corporate financial consultant.
Union Camp Corporation, which makes packaging and printing paper, announced yesterday that it will move its headquarters to Wayne, N.J., toward the end of 1969. Its offices are now at 233 Broadway.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Ashley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Jane Ashley, to Jonathan Angell Stableford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Stableford of Easton, Pa.
NEWARK, July 17--Bright yellow sanitation vehicles moved into the rubble-strewn Central Ward today, replacing olive-drab National Guard vehicles.

Two top-ranking state Republicans differed sharply yesterday on whether there should be cross-nominations that would assure keeping Judge Charles D. Breitel, a Republican, on the State Court of Appeals bench.

EL QUNEITRA, Syria, July 17 --Israel returned 591 prisoners of war to Syria today in exchange for an Israeli pilot who had been shot down and an Israeli Arab who had spent seven years in Syrian prisons. The exchange, arranged by the International Committee of the Red Cross, took place near this Syrian town held by Israeli forces.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 17--Society in residence for the racing season from July 31 through Aug. 28, will take in the Philadelphia Orchestra's opening concert in the amphitheater Aug. 3 and go on to a stroganoff supper in the nearby Hall of Springs. The supper will honor Eugene Ormandy, who will conduct the concert, and the pianist Van Cliburn, who will be the guest soloist.

The Continental Can Company achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 63-year history in the three and six months ended June 30, the semiannual report of Thomas C. Fogarty, chairman, showed yesterday.
The stock market ended in a stalemate yesterday.

Henry Cabot Lodge, former Ambassador in Saigon, said yesterday that the United States was making marked progress in the war in Vietnam but that success hinged on "superpolice techniques" to stamp out Communist guerrilla warfare, sabotage and terrorist tactics.
MOSCOW, July 17 (AP)--If someone can tone down the subtitles for "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?", the American film may yet be shown at Moscow's film festival.
FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., July 17 (AP)--An Air Force demolition expert was blinded today when a box of "mini-mines" exploded in his face.
JANSSEN'S, Lexington Avenue and 44th Street. Opera scenes from "La Traviata," with Maida Testa and Anthony Scotti.
The nationwide rail strike disrupted the country's economy yesterday, crippling the movement of people, mail and food supplies.
JERSEY CITY, Tuesday, July 18--A 24-year-old man injured in a firebomb attack on a taxicab here Saturday night died last night in the Jersey City Medical Center.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17--In their continuing fight against inflation in South Vietnam, American economists are making increased use of a new arsenal of weapons--artichokes, lettuce, cucumbers, beans and tomatoes.

GENEVA, July 17--The Soviet Union urged today that the United Nations give "urgent consideration" to steps to assist the Arab states to repair the economic damage resulting from their recent war with Israel.
DETROIT, July 17 (UPI)-- The police disclosed today that a swindler had bilked a Detroit bank of $92,519.
The Symington Wayne Corporation and the Universal American Corporation announced yesterday a revision of the terms of their proposed merger.
TEL AVIV, July 17--United Nations observers began supervising the Egyptian-Israeli cease-fire today after an unexplained delay.
Federal narcotics agents raided an apartment on the Upper West Side early yesterday, seized more than six pounds of pure cocaine and arrested three suspects.
A Molotov cocktail "factory" was discovered in a vacant building in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn yesterday by two fire marshals cruising the area in search of arsonists.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Tuesday, July 18--Sporadic rock throwing, false fire alarms and isolated instances of looting hit here last night as bands of Negro youths congregated in downtown streets.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- Dr. Carl F. Hansen formally asked the United States Court of Appeals here today for a special ruling that would permit him to appeal as a private citizen a sweeping Federal court desegreation decree in Washington.
Mayor Lindsay welcomed 130 Army reservists yesterday who will spend the next two weeks observing how commissioners and deputy commissioners conduct the daily problems of city government.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 18 (UPI)--American marines killed 16 Vietcong yesterday in 10 hours of fighting along the coastal lowlands near Danang, the United States command reported today. The marines were supported by artillery and air strikes and emerged without a single casualty.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 17 --An extraordinary three-day session of the Florida Legislature, to be "devoted exclusively to providing additional funds for the junior college program," was called today by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 17 (UPI)--Joe Namath, the New York Jets' star quarterback, headed the 51 holdovers who reported to training camps today at Peekskill Military Academy.

Tony Vincent of New York, seeded first, and Bill Tully of Pelham, second, won secondround matches and Irving Suntag of Brooklyn was beaten in the Eastern 35-years-and-over clay-court tennis championship at the West Park Racquet Club here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17--Israel has informed Secretary General Thant that all cases of pilferage of United Nations property are brought before courts-martial when they "come to notice."
Sharp declines in earnings for the second quarter and the first half of 1967 were reported yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
NEWARK, July 17--A highranking state official will leave for Washington tomorrow in search of Federal emergency funds to help rebuild this shattered city.

The New York Customs district has collected more than $1-billlon in a 12-month period, for the first time in its history, it was reported here yesterday, by Michael Stramiello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 17--Denny Lyons, the son of a professional, led Jerry Courville, a previous three-time champion, by a stroke today, after the first round of the 15th annual two-day Ike golf tournament at Wykagyl Coun try Club.
Joe Frazier and George Chuvalo finished their training grind yesterday at their upstate resort camps for their 12-round heavyweight bout in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, explained today why a large section of maritime labor has abandoned its fight for an independent maritime agency and now believes the fate of the nation's merchant marine should be placed in the hands of the Department of Transportation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 --Larchmont Race Week came up with a record-breaking fleet today but the wind once again proved less than adequate for a memorable regatta. A total of 409 One-Design sloops in 16 classes went out to race in weak southeasterly breezes but just over half, 234, managed to struggle around the course before the time limits expired.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 17 (Reuters)--The Government said today that supporters of the Patino family, which once owned much of Bolivia's nationalized

NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 17--Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Clear have announced the engagement of Mrs. Clear's daughter, Miss Suzanne Elaine Emery, to David Lee Grogins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Grogins of Danbury. The prospective bride's father is Lester Emery of Camden, Me.

Tommy Trotter, the racing secretary and handicapper for the New York Racing Association, assigned 136 pounds to Buckpasser, Ogden Phipps's magnificent 4-year-old, yesterday for the $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap on Saturday
LOS ANGELES, July 17 (UPI) --Arthur Koehler, a wood scientist who won fame for his detective role in the Lindbergh baby kidnapping in the nineteen-thirties, died here yesterday. His age was 82.
The West German national amateur boxing team will meet the United States leading amateur boxers on Aug. 28 at Singer Bowl, Flushing Meadow, Queens, the Amateur Athletic Union said yesterday.
A new "wilderness road," financed mainly by the United States, is being cut 50 miles through the jungle of Guyana.

WASHINGTON, July 17--A "peace" candidate for President is "virtually certain" if neither Democrats nor Republicans nominate a man with a "sincere desire" to end the war in Vietnam, Dr. Benjamin Spock said today.
AFTER several confusing weeks, the Professional Golfers' Association championship is scheduled to begin on Thursday in the clear atmosphere of Colorado.
Michael Uris, a former screenwriter and story editor, died yesterday of a heart attack in Truro, Mass., where he was on vacation. He was 65 years old and lived at 201 East 77th Street.
The city is preparing a bid of about $2-million in an effort to purchase the liner Queen Mary for use as a floating high school anchored at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 17--Ingrid Poschmann of Syosset, L.I., became the first player to reach the quarterfinals of the New Jersey state women's singles tennis championship today at the East Orange Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) --Whether he wants it or not, Robert E. Lee is going to be nominated for a third seven-year term as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.7 Friday from 96.8 on Thursday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17-- The fog cleared away beautifully this morning only to be replaced by another foe of the yatchtsman and the Observation Trial races in the Ameri ca's Cup defense selection process were canceled again. This time the four 12-Meter yachts seeking to meet Australia for the world's leading sailing prize in September were defeated by lack of wind.
The New York Shakespeare Festival declaimed in Yiddish accents last night, something that would make a delightful habit--at least part time.
SALEM, N.H., July 17 (AP)--Lou Smith, the president of Rockingham race track, announced today that the Rockingham Special, which had its inception last year, would be discontinued.
Eliot Hyman was elected yesterday as chairman of Warner Bros.- Seven Arts, Ltd., a producer and distributor of motion pictures and television films.
ST. LOUIS, July 17--Tim McCarver and Mike Shannon combined their batting prowess to ruin the New York Mets tonight before 25,540 fans (17,857 paid) in Busch Memorial Stadium.

THE knockout team championship at the Brook- lyn Section Tournament that ended at the New York Hilton Sunday night was won by B. Jay Becker, Peter Leventritt, Mrs. Jacqui Mitchell, Dick Kahn and Ronald Crown, all of New York, and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson.
The appointment of Richard L. Eubanks as president of Gibson Greeting Cards, Inc., was announced yesterday in Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, July 17--Here is a self-portrait of Newark taken from that city's application for funds under the model neighborhood program of the Department of Housing and Urban Development:

RYE, N.Y., July 17--The engagement of Miss Jane Dee Dystel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Dystel, to Stanley Stuart Litow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Litow of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
HONOLULU, July 17 (AP)-- The 72-foot ketch Whistle Wing became the fifth Class A yacht to cross the Diamond Head finish line in the Trans-Pacific race early today.
Testing crews of the Federal Water Pollution Control Administration will check the ocean today at Coney Island for bacteria, but not the way the agency had wanted.
The railroad strike depressed department-store sales slightly in New York yesterday, but hotels enjoyed booming reservations from commuters worried about getting home.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., July 17--Mr. and Mrs. Dimitry G. Zachary have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Elizabeth Zachary, to Peter Henry Van Ness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Van Ness of Ridgewood.
OCEANPORT, N.J.,. July 17 --Henry Forrest, for many years one of the most successful trainers in the Middle West, was suspended for 60 days by the board of stewards at Monmouth Park race track today.

The State of New York predicted yesterday that the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads will be challenged as not being in the public interest if the bankrupt New Haven Railroad goes into liquidation before the Pennsy and Central merge.

PITTSBURGH, July 17--Two civil rights groups called today for a citywide rent strike. They urged tenants living in slum housing to pay rent and deposit it in an escrow fund. They asked that tenants living in good housing do the same in sympathy with slum tenants.
TEL AVIV, July 17 (Reuters) --The daughter of Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, the Israeli Defense Minister, will be married Saturday, the day chosen by her brother and his fiancee for their wedding.
Trans World Airlines' computerized flight planning, started two years ago on its international flights, became worldwide yesterday when it was extended to some domestic flights.
James L. Marcus, the city's 36-year-old Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, will be named administrator of the new Environmental Protection Administration.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 18 --Athenagoras I, Ecumenical Patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church, is expected to return Pope Paul's forthcoming visit to Turkey with a visit to Rome, according to an official of the Patriarchate.

If the anti-riot bill that the House is scheduled to consider--and will probably overwhelmingly approve-- today would put a stop to riots, it would be a miraculous piece of legislation. Unfortunately, it will have no effect one way or the other on the root causes of the riots themselves.
LONDON, July 18 (Reuters) --Clive, 33-year-old Brit- ish designer, opened London Fashion Week today with his first fur collection.
The price of silver continued to climb yesterday.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has decided not to retain Louis Harris to conduct its Vote Profile Analysis polls during the 1968 elections.

SALISBURY, N.C., July 18-- Twelve white men, some reported to be members of the Ku Klux Klan, were arrested by Federal agents at dawn today and charged with a 21month terror campaign to prevent school integration in two North Carolina counties.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP)-- Earl Wilson, a right-hander, held Washington to five hits and drove in two runs tonight to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 5-2 victory that ended the Senators' winning streak at eight games.
The margin debt of customers of New York Stock Exchange member firms climbed $190-million during June to a new high of $5.33billion.
"Life With Father" and "The 10th Man" have been scheduled for fall at the City Center by Jean Dalrymple, the director of the house's drama and musical comedy divisions.

Mrs. Judith Mage, the perky 32-year-old president of the Social Service Employes Union, is learning a grim fact now that her union is in the fifth week of a contract dispute with the city: It is easier to start a strike than it is to end it on satisfactory terms. Many older, battle-scarred union leaders...
A huge volume of new municipal and corporate bonds, probably a record for a day in July, was marketed yesterday. Interest rates, however, were little changed and sales results varied considerably.

MONTREAL, July 18--In order to enjoy the re- vival of Lehar's "The Land of Smiles," which opened a six-day run at Expo Theater last night, a case of split nostalgia is a necessity. The production demands quick shifts of loyalty from one genre of old favorites to another.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 18 (UPI)--Diavolo, piloted by Alfred E. Stern Jr. of Chicago, was declared winner today of the Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 18 (UPI)--The Government imposed today strict restrictions on imports and moved to tighten controls on foreignexchange transactions.
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., July 18--The caretaker of a private estate was held today on a charge of first-degree murder in the slaying of a girl and the slashing of her male companion's throat.
MONTREAL, July 18--Despite an attendance of more than 22 million to date, nothing happened at Expo 67 until the arrival today of Their Serene Highnesses Prince Rainier and Princess Grace of Monaco.
BONN, July 18--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger disclosed today that he would fly to Washington Aug. 14, a month earlier than planned, for two days of talks with President Johnson.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., July 18 --Billy Pagles of the Wet Pants Association of Sayville captured the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association junior sailing championship today in the closest series in the 32 years of the competition for the Golden Trophy.
The nation's railroads decided last night to sell the Railway Express Agency. The decision to do so was a unanimous one taken by the full 19man board of the agency.
Silver futures prices advanced the daily permissible limit in active trading here yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.
The bulls and bears are at it again. Their perennial tugof-war has been increasing in intensity since the onset of the summer rally in stocks. For the moment the bulls seem to have more muscle.
ALBANY, July 18--The state released its lottery sales figures for June today and confirmed all the previous gloomy reports.

WASHINGTON, July 18--In an unusual action, the House Agriculture Committee has approved a bill to prohibit permanently the importation of extra-long staple cot- ton from the United Arab Republic and to permit American producers to supply the market.
DENVER, July 18--Although professional golf purses have been soaring the prize money for the Professional Golfers' Association tournament, which starts here Thursday, will remain the same as in 1966.

DORSET, Vt., July 18--Mrs. Melinda Miller Pattison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elam Miller of Dorset and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married today to David Addison Bliss of Otter, Mont. He is the son of Mrs. John M. Gates of New York and Westbury, L.I., and Cornelius N. Bliss of Darlington, Md.
MIAMI BEACH, July 18-- Leaders of the New York waterfront agreed today on the urgency of avoiding another longshore strike when bargain-ing for a new contract opens next year.
The spot rate on the British pound eased to its lowest level in more than a year in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
Ellery Husted, a retired New York architect, died yesterday in a Lisbon hospital. Mr. Husted, who was 66 years old, lived in Portugal.

THE biggest Pro-Am tournament of the season was held last Wednesday at the Middle Bay County Club in Oceanside, L.I. Morrle Elis, a winner of many national championships, collected 25 other leading New York bridge personalities for a 13table game.

Five prominent Jewish busiiness and community leaders repudiated yesterday the current position on Israel taken by the American Council for Judaism. All five men have had associations with the council.
Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that the city was "doing all it can" through summer antipoverty programs to help keep down tensions.

PITTSBURGH, July 18-- Dr. and Mrs. Frank W. Wadsworth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Browning Wadsworth, to Gardner Emmons Jr., son of Mrs. Emmons of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Jamestown, R.I., and Mr. Emmons of Monument Beach, Mass.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Senate investigators are checking the sources and ownership of firearms in the riot-torn Newark area, Senator Thomas J. Dodd said today. The findings are expected to reinforce the argument for Federal firearms regulations.

WASHINGTON, July 18--A former State Department official told Congress today that "official graft and corruption" in many Latin-American countries was one of the impediments to their economic development.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- President Johnson said today that he still favored a 6 per cent surcharge on income taxes and hoped Congress would begin considering it next month.
The president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association charged yesterday that disaster threatened the city unless 1,500 more men were added to the force and antiquated apparatus was replaced.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 18 (Reuters)--Nigerian Air Force planes have begun strafing targets in Enugu, capital of the Eastern Region, which has declared itself the Republic of Biafra, a Government spokesman said tonight.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 --An Eastern Airlines jet with 98 persons aboard landed safely at Kelly Air Force Base this afternoon after losing its left inside wheel on take-off from International Airport here.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) --Manager Harry (The Hat) Walker was discharged today by the sixth-place, Pittsburgh, Pirates and the former manager, Danny Murtaugh, was called in to try to get the team back in the pennant race.

Strikes at various plants sharply reduced profits of the B.F. Goodrich Company in the three and six months ended June 30 with less drastic effect on sales, according to yesterday's report by Ward Keener, president.
NEWARK, July 18--At 1 P.M. today, as two policemen stood guard, the doors of Newark City Hospital were opened to visitors for the first time since Thursday.
LONDON, July 18--The prospects for the creation of a new type of international "money" have been enhanced by a 10-nation meeting in London that ended today.
ALBANY, July 18--The Constitutional Convention, splitting largely along party lines, voted tonight to empower the Legislature to lower the state's voting age below 21 in the future.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --The Defense Department today listed 23 soldiers and 12 marines killed in Vietnam. Three other marines died of wounds and 17 Army men previously listed as missing in action were listed as dead of hostile causes.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)-- The Consolidated Foods Corporation said today the Federal Trade Commission had disapproved the proposed purchase by Lucky Stores, Inc., San Leandro, Calif., of Consolidated's Eagle Supermarket business.

Davis, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the company, announced yesterday. Paramount is a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- The Secretary of Labor, W. Willard Wirtz, and Senator Robert F. Kennedy disagreed in open hearing today on methods of providing jobs for ghetto dwellers.
PASADENA, Calif., July 18 (AP)--Scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory gave up trying to make contact with Surveyor 4 today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Thirteen Republican members of the House Banking and Currency Committee demanded today a Congressional review of Government-financed sales of weapons abroad.
VERONA, N.J., July 18-- Tommy Harmon, who had served for 35 years as the professional at the Montclair Golf Club, died today at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge. He was 70 years old.

With a powerful assist from the Yankees, the Mets evacuated the National League cellar last night by defeating the Houston Astros, 4-2.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- The five belligerents in the Middle Eastern war--Israel, the United Arab Republic, Syria, Jordan and Iraq--altogether had about 3,300 tanks, more than Hitler employed in the invasion of France in 1940.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 18--Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Rowland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Ann Rowland, to Jerry Price Goodwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Goodwin of North Plainfield, N.J.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., July 18--Miss Betsy Lynn Fishman's engagement to Joel Jon Ziegler has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George N. Fishman. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Ziegler of Hicksville.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) --American officials said today that the United States and the United Arab Republic had agreed to raise the level and number of diplomats they left in each other's capitals after they broke relations during the war in the Middle East.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 18 --A career Government employe, Christopher C. Kraft Jr., received the Spirit of St. Louis gold medal tonight from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, which is holding a conference here.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Rosel H. Hyde, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, called today for legislation that would permit the broadcasting industry to grant free time to major political candidates without also granting equal time to minor candidates.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 18-- Dr. Edward J. Carlin of 985 Bryant Street, a practicing physician here for 42 years, a former Mayor of this city and a former member of the Union County Board of Freeholders, died today at the Rahway Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.
ROME, July 18--The newest hat in the Rome haute-couture collections for fall and winter is Forquet's fox toque with a long, bushy tail that curls around the neck and almost conceals one cheek.

VIENNA, July 18--The "whistle stop tour" in this country by Archduke Otto of Habsburg, the former Austrian pretender, has revived the bitter political feud about the archduke's alleged intention to try to restore the monarchy.

The Bronx concern that holds the contract for installation of the steel members in the twin 110-story towers of the World Trade Center has purchased a 13-acre industrial site in Carteret, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Housing starts in June held essentially steady at the annual rate of 1.3 million reached in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- There is more and more talk here about a Rockefeller-Reagan Presidential ticket next year. A month ago the pros were saying it was impossible; now they are saying it is improbable but just might happen.

YONKERS, July 18--In keeping with the apparent theme of this final week of harness racing action of the second of the season's three meetings at Yonkers Raceway, the long shots were decidedly in the limelight tonight. WASHINGTON, July 19-- Critics of the appointment of Thurgood Marshall to the Supreme Court shifted their attack today from his supposed liberal philosophy to an examination of his legal knowledge. Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina questioned Mr. Marshall for an hour on fine points of constitutional law and history.

The Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., long noted for the work of its scholars in mathematics, theoretical physics and astrophysics, is setting up a trial program in the social sciences.

The city plans extensive emergency renovations in all 21 municipal hospitals, Joseph V. Terenzio, the Hospitals Commissioner, said yesterday during a tour of two newly renovated wards at Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Up in Manhattan's "Silk-Stocking District," where very few Puerto Ricans live, the natives of the area have responded to a poll by Representative Ted Kupferman as follows: 30 per cent favor independence for Puerto Rico, 29 per cent favor statehood, and 23 per cent believe the island ought to keep its commonwealth status (7 per cent of the 12,500 respondents couldn't have cared less).

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Jack Valenti, president of the Motion picture Association of America, predicted today that the United States entry, "Up the Down Staircase," would not win a prize at the Moscow Film Festival. The festival ends tomorrow night.

A leading labor arbitrator yesterday blamed what he called management ineptitude for the rapidly rising spiral in maritime labor costs despite two-year-old labor agreements that were designed to limit such increases to 3.2 per cent annually.
John J. Koster, credit manager of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, 1 Park Avenue, died Monday at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 57 years old.
