ATLANTA, July 19--Charles L. Weltner announced today that he would try to regain the House seat he gave up last year rather than support Lester G. Maddox for Governor.
The sky was blue, the waves were friendly and Allan Brown was thumping along yesterday at 57.5 miles an hour, leading the field in the 265-mile Hennessy Long Island Marathon boat race.

Four more American soldiers seen earlier this month on the French-produced documentary on Vietnam, "The Anderson Platoon," have been killed in action since the filming was completed last November, Pierre Schoendoerffer, the producer, said yesterday.
If a man buys his wife a $50,000 diamond ring for Christmas and she dies in February, and he lists the appraisal value of the ring for estate tax purposes as $35,000, what have you got?
The Long Island Rail Road reached agreement yesterday on a new contract with Brotherhood of Railroad Carmen, thus avoiding a strike that the union had set for 5 A.M. today.
Arthur Cohn, for many years a leading figure in transportation advertising, died Tuesday in Miami Beach, after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.
Frederick M. Ellis, chairman of the physical education department at Tufts University, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Burlington, Mass. He was 61 years old.
Strong and persistent demand for industrial shares marked trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Although a few shares failed to hold to their best levels, most closed at the day's highs.

The 12th-century stone columns of the Cloisters cast shadows in flickering candlelight last night as men and women in evening clothes dined under the arcade of the medieval annex of the Metropolitan Museum of Art where Benedictine monks in the south of France once said their prayers.

Miss Ina Gwyn Seward and Charles E. Little McCary were married yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas Episcopal Church here. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Seward of Scarsdale, N.Y. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe T. McCary of Nashville.
Kinney National Service, Inc., is planning to enter the communications publishing field through a $60-million merger with National Periodical Publications, Inc.

ALBANY, July 20 At 10:22 A.M. today State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy, blinking as camera lights flashed, put his right hand inside a seven-foot-high Plexiglas drum and drew out the first winning ticket in the New York State lottery.
NEWARK, July 20 Greyhound Lines, Inc., was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on two safety counts growing out of the crash May 15 near Hackettstown, N.J., of a New York-Scranton bus.

CHICAGO, July 20 The Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today that it had joined a three-year privateenterprise research program aimed at finding ways to re duce air pollution caused by gasoline-powered engines.

ROCKVILLE, Md., July 20 The governing body of Montgomery County, the most nearly all-white suburb of the nation's capital, voted tonight to open the county's door to Negro homeownership up to a point to be determined by a quota.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko eager, in the words of an Eastern European diplomat, "to go home to Moscow with something" has brought about a 24-hour delay in the end of the General Assembly's emergency session on the Middle East.

ALBANY, July 20 The state's controversial Medicaid program has "already proved itself" and has authorized benefits for 2.3 million New Yorkers, George K. Wyman, the State Commissioner of Social Welfare, said today.

SAN CARLOS, Calif., July 20 (UPI) The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced today an agreement with United Press International to provide a nationwide data communications system that would let the news service transmit up to 22 news stories at once on a single telephone line.

Until World War II British foreign policy was founded on the twin assumptions that God was an Englishman and the road to India must be kept open. Downing Street no longer relies on divine approval and, since India's independence, the seaway eastward has lost importance. The logical consequence was London's decision to abandon Singapore.
Insurance written in New York State last year reached a new high, Richard E. Stewart, Superintendent of the Insurance Department, said yesterday.
WOMEN who like French names in their shoes are in for a field day. The labels of Christian Dior, Pierre Cardin and Hermes will be in fall shoe collections in two Fifth Avenue stores.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The State Department said today that Mrs. Cheddi B. Jagan, wife of the former Prime Minister and the leader of a pro-Communist party in Guyana, had been informed that her United States citizenship was being restored under a recent Supreme Court decision.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (UPI) Willie McCovey supported Gaylord Perry's seven-hit pitching with a 475-foot two-run homer tonight in pacing the San Francisco Giants to a 6-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
A 12-mile extension of a cleared barrier strip is being started just south of the demilitarized zone in South Vietnam, Washington sources said yesterday.
THE "many moods of modern" is what Macy's has dubbed its new group of model rooms, which go on view Monday in the contemporary wing on the ninth floor.
WASHINGTON, July 20 A proposed bill of rights for the nation's college and university students has been drawn up by representatives of five major education organizations.

UTRECHT, The Netherlands, July 20 The Roman Catholic Church of the Netherlands and the Dutch Reformed Church, oldest of the Dutch Protestant churches, with roots in the Reformation of the 16th century, announced today that they had agreed to recognize each other's baptism.

DURHAM, N.C., July 20 (UPI) National Guard men stood ready to prevent violence tonight and Negroes demonstrated for open public housing after a warning from leaders to only clap and sing or "somebody's going to be killed."
Mr. and Mrs. Chester C. Moss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ronnie Helen Moss, to Donald F. Rudolph, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Rudolph. Both families are of Brooklyn.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 20 Mr. and Mrs. L. Breton Ely have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Luise Ely, to G. Harrison Houston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Houston of Cos Cob.
The Gillette Company announced yesterday the appointment of William G. Salatich as group vice president and Thomas W. Casey as a vice president.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) Canon Guy Rogers, who served as royal chaplain to four British monarchs, died yesterday at the age of 91.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers reached a tentative agreement today to end a 91-day strike.
WASHINGTON, July 20 European leaders have realized in recent months that only they can close the "technological gap" between their countries and the United States.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., July 20 A bus that can travel on railroad tracks as well as on highways, and that may be used to reduce the traveling time between mid-Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport, was demonstrated today by two transportation agencies.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--The equal time requirement of the Federal Communications Act is wrong and unworkable, Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 At the age of 5, Samuel Cummings learned to dismantle and reassemble a souvenir World War I German machine gun. He believes that was the start of his career. In any case, this boyhood fascination and a robust entrepreneurial spirit ...
WASHINGTON, July 20 "While Mr. Nasser's tanks were still burning," said Samuel Cummings, the world's leading private arms merchant, "we were already negotiating with Israelis for the light weapons."
Percy C. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, urged the city administration yesterday to submit to fact-finding all issues in its contract dispute with the Social Service Employes Union.

LITTLETON, Colo., July 20 Dave Hill, acclimated by residence to the rarefied Colorado air, scored a six-under-par 66 in the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship today. His score set a course record.
MEXICO CITY, July 20 Mexican officials said today that further arrests were expected in connection with what they describe as a plot to overthrow the Government.
The stock market continued to present a kaleidoscopic pattern yesterday, the blue chips were up, the glamours were down and the rest of the list showed a mixture of gains and losses.
PARIS, July 20 (UPI) Bernard Hunt of Britain scored his first tournament victory of the year today when he won the French open golf title with a 17-under-par 271 for the 72 holes.

ST. SIMONS, Ga., July 20 Miss Linda Gibson and Ens. Edwin Parson Young 3d, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Young of Providence, R.I., will be married Aug. 5 at the St. Simons Presbyterian Church.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that street lights three times as bright as the existing ones would be installed in the next two weeks on portions of three Greenwich Village streets.

BONN, July 20 The Civil Court of Munich today ordered the confiscation of this week's edition of the rightwing newspaper Deutsche National and Soldaten Zeitung because it compared Israel's Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, to Hitler.

JERUSALEM, July 20--Premier Levi Eshkol warned tonight that the Arab states and their allies, having lost the military campaign, were now using all political means at their disposal to revive the dangerous situation that drew the Middle East into war.

SAPPORO, Japan, July 20 Among the well-wishers at Tokyo's International Airport when Foreign Minister Takeo Miki flew to Moscow today was a delegation of officials and leaders in fishing and related indus try from Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan's main islands, to remind Mr. Miki of their determination to reclaim several islands north of Hokkaido from Soviet occupation.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 20 Mr, and Mrs. John H. Converse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn McCaig Converse, to Jeffrey E. Baena, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Baena of Greenwich, Conn.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 20 Luis Munoz Marin predicted today that Puerto Ricans would vote by a "comfortable" margin next Sunday to retain the island's commonwealth status.

Britain's military cutbacks East of Suez reflect a long-delayed but unavoidable choice between uniting with Europe and persisting in the old role of a world power. It had become evident that London could not attempt to do both and at the same time successfully weather the financial and economic pressures to which it is being subjected.
HONG KONG, July 20 (Reuters) The Hong Kong government announced new emergency regulations today as raids against suspected leftist headquarters continued.

PITTSBURGH, July 20--John H. Devlin, minority leader of the State Senate, died today in St. Francis General Hospital. He was 49 years old and had served in the General Assembly at Harrisburg for 11 years. He had undergone lung surgery in June.

A conviction in a New York City court is usually the result of a bargain reached between the prosecuting and defense lawyers, and this bargaining should be regulated by law, the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime was told yesterday.

Mrs. Ann Gray of New York and Stewart Sill Gray of Kansas City, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Gray, to David Lefferts Rawle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Rawle of Darien, Conn.

YONKERS, July 20--The 13th edition of the $150,000 Yonkers Futurity Trot had 13 starters tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Even the non-superstitious fans among the 22,271 who saw Pomp ($33.20) emerge the winner of the one-mile test by three lengths had to go along with the general belief that 13 is an unlucky number.
BOTH adversaries in the Great Telephone Rate Decision are making overtures to the stockholders of American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--A group of House Republicans introduced legislation today to increase Social Security benefits 8 per cent, retroactive to last Jan. 1, with no increase in payroll taxes.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Defense Department today picked a design submitted by Litton Systems Inc., for a fast deployment logistics ship whose funding had been denied by Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee approved today a $4.6-billion public works bill but killed "Mike's Ditch," a proposed barge canal that had been favored by Representative Michael J. Kirwan, Democrat of Ohio, for three decades.

NEWARK, July 20--A four-day conference on Black Power, said to have brought together the largest and most diverse group of Negro civil-rights activists ever to assemble in the United States, opened here today in a city that was torn by racial violence ony a few days ago.

A PECULIAR but well-known disease called Inflammation of the Expectations carried off Harry Walker on Tuesday. This selective malady, for which medicine will never find a cure, attacks only a certain segment of the population: baseball managers, football and other athletic coaches, politicians, generals and admirals, ad agency executives and others who expose themselves to responsibility for making good on someone else's promises.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--Food shoppers should begin to get a better idea of what they are paying for in containers and cans by the end of the year, with the enforcement of regulations detailed today.
Bond prices declined yesterday for the fourth day this week, driving interest rates up some more.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled yesterday that mutual fund management companies can not buy or sell securities for their mutual fund portfolios through interposing third-party brokers who do not make a market in the securities.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 20 The Texas Railroad Commission, the state agency that regulates oil output, today raised crude oil production limits to 54 per cent of potential output a new high amid reports that earlier increases had failed to produce anticipated supplies.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 The Arab nations that were left out of the "little summit" meeting in Cairo last week have begun to show signs of resentment.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The Congress is troubled these days about the vast traffic in military weapons. It charges the Administration with deploring the arms race while leading the arms race. And this raises two questions: Is the charge true? And if so, is it wrong?
Three supected narcotics pushers, allegedly trafficking in $300-million a year in illicit drugs, were held yesterday in a total of $850,000 bail by Bronx Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Brust.
TRENTON, July 20 (UPI) The State Supreme Court ruled today that authorities do not have to disclose the identities of informers who witness crimes.
Banking system statistics, past their Independence Day distortions, have returned to normal.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The nation's manufacturing industries operated on the average at only 84.7 per cent of capacity in the second quarter of this year, a new Federal Reserve Board statistical series disclosed today.

A flurry of whooshes and wows filled the theater at Rikers Island yesterday as a curtain of bedsheets lifted and slowly revealed ankles, calves, knees and thighs. In a men's penitentiary, at least, a glimpse of stocking is looked on as something shocking.

John D. Gray, president of Hart, Schaffner Marx, retailer and manufacturer of apparel, declined comment yesterday in Chicago on a proposed affiliation with Austin Reed, Ltd., British retail men's wear chain.

BUCHAREST, July 20 Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, has announced a major shake-up of the secret police organization after criticizing it severely and accusing it of having abused the rights of citizens and trying to exercise political functions of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, July 20 A former Under Secretary of State suggested today that the United States might reluctantly have to assume a special responsibility for trade and aid relations with Latin America as a counterpart to Europe's relationship with Africa.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.9 on Wednesday from 97 on Tuesday.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 20 Iowa's Democratic Governor, Harold E. Hughes, signed into law today a bill to increase state taxes by $102-million, to a total of $373-million.

Thousands of sterile male gypsy moths are being set free in Brooklyn's Prospect Park this summer as part of an experiment aimed at breaking the reproductive chain of the moth, which has been a major killer of trees in the Northeast.
The American Stock Exchange backed down yesterday on reduced trading volume. Prices edged a bit higher in the first hours but the gains evaporated on profit taking as the day went on.

ST. TROPEZ, France, July 20 "Desire Caught by the Tail," a play by Pablo Picasso, had its premiere tonight in a circus tent just beyond the city limits of St. Tropez, where its performance was banned.

Officials of Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union, were ordered yesterday to appear in State Supreme Court today to show cause why they should not be enjoined from striking the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.

The monotonous drone of a real estate auction is a far cry from the yelping excitement of a hard-played baseball game, but one event can be as rewarding as the other, a youthful group of sandlot ball players learned yesterday.

Nature abhors a vacuum and marketing people abhor a missed opportunity. So this month a new company was formed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the avalanche of petroleum industry give-away contests.

The retiring Buildings Commissioner had a point, or at least a third of a point, in his remarks the other day that tenants must be educated in the basic habits of decency if housing-code enforcement is ever to succeed in New York.
WASHINGTON, July 20 A labor leader in the New York area who is charged with having misused union funds filed suit today to prevent the union leadership from removing him from office.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The Justice Department announced today that it would seek to overturn the decision of the Federal Communications Commission approving the merger of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

TOKYO, July 20 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that United States bombs killed or wounded many inhabitants, "mostly old people, women and children," and damaged Roman Catholic churches in three villages of Phutho Province July 13.
Some bird-watchers might turn into bird-haters if they liveon tree-lined 211th Street, between 50th and 53rd Avenues, in Bayside Hills, Queens.

Don Wilson, the lanky Astro rookie who already has a nohitter to his credit, was the master of the Mets last night, pitching a strong two-hit shutout to prevent the Mets from sweeping the four-game series.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 Paratroops of the United States' 101st Airborne Division found a Vietcong prison compound and hospital today near Ducpho, 10 miles southeast of Danang, a military spokesman reported. Nineteen men and three women were found and released.
The tragedy over North Carolina this week was the third time since March that death has resulted from the collision of a commercial airliner and a small private plane.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The Department of Transportation agreed today to conduct a comprehensive study of automobile insurance if Congress authorized it to do so and provided the necessary funds.
SINGAPORE, July 20 (Reuters) A launch carrying French Government agents chased the sister ship of the Torrey Canyon for two hours today to serve a writ, but was outdistanced.
LONDON, July 20--The pound drifted lower again today, closing at $2.7857. The Bank of England was supporting it at that level after an opening of about $2.7861. Volume was light.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 President Rene Barrientos Ortuno has apparently weathered the first political crisis of his year in office in this chronically unstable Andean nation.
DETROIT, July 20 (UPI) Dick McAuliffe hit a homer and double, drove in two runs and scored two tonight in sparking the Detroit Tigers to an 8-4 victory over the Washington Senators.

Diners' Club, the credit card and service organization, confirmed yesterday that it was holding acquisition talks with the Fugazy Travel Bureau, Inc. A spokesman for Diners' Club, was not availplan was in a preliminary stage.
WHITE PLAINS, July 20 Rick Spears of Port Jervis captured the medal in the 48th annual Westchester County Golf Association amateur championship today by scoring 34, 37 71 at Metropolis Country Club.

The following table shows the new and old automobile liability insurance rates for $10,000 and $20,000 bodily injury and $5,000 property damage coverage for private passenger car owners in the metropolitan area.
Dr. Clare M. Howard, retired associate professor of English at Barnard College, died Tuesday at her home in Brookline, Mass. She was 86 years old.
Rear Adm. Chester I. Steele, commander of the Second United States Coast Guard District, with headquarters in St. Louis, died of a heart attack there on Monday. His age was 53.

Dick Genth, who had a $70,000 Italian-built powerboat sink under him in the Gateway Marathon last month in Florida, christened his new Thunderbird IV yesterday with a first-place finish in the 253mile Hennessy Long Island Marathon.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 20 (AP)--The city bus line, crippled by a Negro economic boycott in Hattiesburg, stopped operations at noon today.
Silver futures declined yesterday in active trading.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The State Department made public a policy statement today saying that arms sales to countries in Africa, Latin America, the Middle East and Asia were necessary to prevent extension of Soviet or Chinese Communist domination.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) In a split decision, the Federal Trade Commission ordered the National Dairy Products Corporation today to stop regional price discrimination in the sale of all products by its Kraft Foods Division.
CLEVELAND, July 20 Sam McDowell, the Cleveland lefthander who has been having one of his poorer seasons, got healthy in a hurry tonight in Municipal Stadium against the New York Yankees.
STEVENSVILLE, Mich., July 20 The American Electric Power Company, the nation's largest nongovernmental coal consumer, has decided to enter the nuclear power field.
The Pittsburgh Playhouse reported yesterday a donation of $50,000 from the Richard King Mellon Foundation for its 196768 season.
Philip Salisbury, chairman of the board of Bill Publications, Inc., a business-magazine publishing firm here, died here yesterday, He was 75 years old and lived at 875 Fifth Avenue.

Reflecting a decline in demand for pulp, paper and paper products, sales and earnings of the International Paper Company declined in the second quarter and first half of this year. Edward B. Hinman, president, in the report yesterday, said that "some continued curtailment of production is indicated for the next several months."
ATLANTIC CITY, July 20--The Statler Hilton hotel chain announced today it would construct a $5-million hotel on the Boardwalk at the foot of the Atlantic City Expressway here.
What started a week ago as a move by Fenestra, Inc., to expand led yesterday to the first step toward its delisting by the New York Stock Exchange.
CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI) Dr. Jeremiah Stamler and his assistant were placed on "inactive status" today by the Chicago Board of Health.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Congressmen expressed alarm today over the collision of an airliner and a private plane that killed 82 persons over North Carolina yesterday. The House scheduled air safety hearings for next week.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 20 Miss Sharon Lee Follette, daughter, of Dr. and Mrs. William James Follette of Cresskill, was married this evening to William Lee Tift, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Herding Tift 3d of Macon, Ga. The fathers of the bride and bridegroom are physicians.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 20 The editors of Rhodesia's two daily newspapers were each awarded 300 ($840) damages for defamation with costs in the High Court here today against the Minister of Information, John H. Howman. The publisher of the newspapers, the Rhodesian Printing and Publishing Co., Inc., was awarded 150 ($420), with costs.
MONTREAL, July 20 Princess Grace of Monaco suffered a miscarriage yesterday. She was resting in "satisfactory condition" at the Royal Victoria Hospital today.
A PROMISING new approach to the treatment of narcotics addiction was the subject of a compelling and eloquent one-hour documentary on the American Broadcasting Company last night.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 Clear skies and an honest breeze from the east at 8 to 14 knots made for most pleasant sailing today at Larchmont Race Week, certainly the best day this regatta has had since its start last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission and the Justice Department asked a three-judge federal court in New York today to forbid opponents of the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads to take further legal action in any other court until the New York court hands down its decision.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 20 The racially tense West End of Plainfield was so quiet today that Col. David B. Kelly, the Superintendent of State Police, hinted of a pullout of National Guard units and state policemen tomorrow, barring overnight incidents.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 20 The Blind Brook Polo Club, which is more than 40 years old, will hold its first Polo Ball on Saturday.

CAIRO, July 20 (Agence France-Presse) Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull, who was to have left tonight for Jerusalem after a 24hour visit to Cairo as chief United Nations cease-fire observer, has postponed his departure.

JERSEY CITY, July 20 Local representatives of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People met with Mayor Thomas Whalen today to protest the use of policemen armed with rifles and shotguns to patrol two racially tense sections of the city.
ENUGU, Nigeria, July 20 The slaying of civilians appears to be mounting in areas overrun by federal Nigerian troops in this secessionist Eastern Region.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The House said "no" today to President Johnson's effort to banish rats from the nation's urban slums.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 (AP) Mike Belkin of Canada broke through the blistering service of Cliff Richey, the defending champion, and advanced today to the semi-finals of the national clay court tennis tournament with a 7-9, 6-2, 6-3, 6-1 victory.
A legislative smog may be lifted early in August when Councilman Robert A. Low introduces an amendment designed to clarify the city's controversial air-pollution law.
MONTREAL, July 20 The United States formally presented its showpiece geodesic pavilion at Expo 67 to the city of Montreal today.

NEW ORLEANS, July 20 (AP) The wingflaps of a DC-8 jetliner that crashed into a motel near New Orleans International Airport last March were lowered too sharply and the big plane was sideslipping, an inquiry board learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 Seven New York residents asked the Supreme Court today for a ruling that would permit them to challenge in Federal court the constitutionality of Federal aid to parochial schools.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI) The American high command, under a new program, is planning to triple the amount paid to Vietcong defectors.
MOSCOW, July 20 (AP)--The grand prize at Moscow's fifth film festival was shared today by Soviet and Hungarian entries.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) Julian Javier, Orlando Cepeda and Bob Tolan drove in six runs with homers tonight, powering the National League leading St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

CAMIRI, Bolivia, July 20 (AP) Regis Debray, a leftist French writer awaiting trial in southeast Bolivia on charges of collaborating with Communist guerrillase, says Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara organized the Bolivian guerrilla movement but is no longer in the country. Major Guevara's whereabouts have been a mystery since the spring of 1965.
LONDON, July 20 Unemployment in Britain in July set a 27-year high for the month.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 20 (UPI) John Sellers, a jockey, will be sidelined for two to three weeks because of a fractured left clavicle sustained in a spill at Hollywood Park race track, it was announced today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 20 (AP)--Jim Rheim, a Chula Vista, Calif., medical student who hardly touched a club for nine months, upset Marty Fleckman, the low amateur in the United States Open, 2 up, today in the second round of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

WASHINGTON July 20 (AP) The Treasury Department has recommended to the Justice Department prosecution of the crew members of the Quakermanned vessel that earlier this year carried medical supplies to North Vietnam.

Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation and Dow Chemical Company reported higher second-quarter profits yesterday. Chas. Pfizer Co., the drug producer, showed a slight decline in earnings on increased sales.

NEWARK, July 20 Sargent Shriver, director of the, Federal Office of Economic Opportunity, will come here Monday to discuss the needs, the administrative crisis and mounting criticism of Newark's antipoverty program.

HOLLYWOOD, July 20 Gomer Pyle, of all people, is going to have a steady girl friend and even Batman will have a Batgirl. The baby witch in "Bewitched," who will be three years old, a year younger than the series, has acquired a permanent nanny, who will be played by no less an actress than Hermione Baddeley.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Representatives of Columbia University have met with the Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, to discuss studies of a recently publicized cigarette filter, the Public Health Service said today.
The Board of Education asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday for a meeting to explore the possibility of obtaining additional city funds for teacher salary increases.
Gabe Pressman will move from WNBC-TV's 11 P.M. news program to the early evening news show at 6 P.M. on Monday, July 31.
Doubleday Co. has offered an advance payment ob about $100,000 for a book by Senator Robert F. Kennedy setting forth his views on major national and international issues.

While many states continue to strive to achieve and some to avert the Supreme Court's "one-man, one-vote" dictum, Congress has resumed consideration of the plight of 800,000 Americans who, except in Presidential elections, have no vote: the citizens of the District of Columbia.

A funny thing happened to the House Appropriations Committee's economy ax on the way to the pork barrel this week. Penny-pinching Congressmen who had seemed hell-bent on chopping funds out of the civilian budget to meet rising defense costs suddenly lost their fancy for frugality.
BERLIN, July 20 The site of the execution 23 years ago of members of the bomb plot after their failure to assassinate Hitler was opened as a memorial today.
BOSTON, July 20 (AP)--A 36-year-old woman who has been in a coma since last January, gave birth today to a healthy six-pound girl at Massachusetts General Hospital.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 20 Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Kehrli have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda L. Kehrli, to William R. Lynett. He is the son of Mrs. Edward J. Lynett of Scranton, Pa., and the late Mr. Lynett, who was editor and publisher of The Scranton Times.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had revised its listing requirements to obtain more information on the floating supply of securities proposed for listing on the exchange.
The Community Development Agency, which administers the city's antipoverty program, announced the reassignment of three key staff members yesterday.
DETROIT, July 20 The performance of electric auto mobiles that may be developed in the next decade will fall far short even of today's cars, Ford Motor Company officials said today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 20 Arthur Sheinberg of 17 Nassau Drive, a corporate lawyer and senior partner in the firm of Weisman, Celler, Allan, Spett Sheinberg in New York, died of a heart attack this afternoon at his home. He was 59 years old.

A material witness who said his life had been threatened by the murder suspect he is scheduled to testify against escaped from the Civil Jail early Saturday morning, the sheriff's office reported yesterday.

ROME, July 20 The Vatican today strongly emphasized the significance of Pope Paul's forthcoming conferences with Turkish authorities on peace in the Middle East. At the same time, it issued the detailed schedule of his 42-hour visit to Turkey next Tuesday.
The severely depressed patient was told with "kind firmness" to count hundreds of tiny sea shells into a cigar box.
Judy Garland, recalling when her mother pushed her on stage at the age of 5, once noted ruefully: "Either it was go on and perform or get wrapped around a bedpost."
Moore and McCormack Company, Inc., announced yesterday the establishment of a new subsidiary that will extend its activities into the rapidly growing field of oceanography.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, a pioneer in military aviation who fought with distinction in both World Wars, died today of a heart attack in Wal- ter Reed Army Hospital, where he had undergone abdominal surgery nine days ago. He was 77 years old.

SOME of the most arresting writing of the last decade has been concerned with evoking spiritual apocalypse. It has taken several forms and gone under many names black comedy, fiction of the absurd, high camp, low camp, pop literature, etc. Its staples have been a certain ruthlessness toward its audience, a lacerating indictment ...

HOUSTON, July 20 A graduating class of 39 students who have earned licenses as deck officers will permit 20 United States flag vessels, delayed at West Coast ports because of an officer shortage, to sail to Vietnam in the next few days.

The Civil Aeronautics Board violated its powers last year in permitting international allexpense tour flights by nonscheduled air carriers, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20 The right of foreign students and their families to Medicaid funds was affirmed yesterday by C. Walter Driscoll, Syracuse area director for the State Social Welfare Department. Mr. Driscoll denied the Tompkins County Welfare Department in Ithaca permission to close all its foreign student Medicaid cases.

ABOARD BON HOMME RICHARD, Gulf of Tonkin, Friday, July 21 United States Navy, fliers reported today that they had shot down three MIG-17 jets in furious air action 20 miles north of Haiphong, North Vietnam's main port.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

Trailing the entire field on the far turn, then surviving a claim of foul, Mrs. Gerard Smith's Fatal Step won the seven-furlong feature yesterday at Aqueduct. Opposing seven in the sprint for fillies and mares, Fatal Step beat Lady Dulcinea, the favorite, by a length, with the 32-1 shot, Boiseana, finishing third a neck farther back.

Henry A. Loeb, a member of the board of directors of the American Council for Judaism, said yesterday that he disagreed with the criticism of Israel expressed by other executive officers of the anti-Zionist organization.

If the grilling that Thurgood Marshall is getting had been truly designed to examine his qualifications for the Supreme Court, the Senate Judiciary Committee would simply be carrying out its proper function. While the Solicitor General has been an outstanding and honorable advocate in the field of human rights, his experience as a jurist has been limited. And it is the duty of the Judiciary Committee to inquire into it.

BOGOTA, Columbia, July 20 President Carlos Lieras Restrepo, in a state of the nation report issued today, contrasted what he called the "studied vagueness' of the United States attitude toward the projected Latin-American common market with the United States role in the establishment of the European Common Market.

City officials and the chief officers of the New York Stock Exchange have tentatively agreed to a plan that would soften the impact of the controversial tax on stock transfers and would keep the Big Board in New York.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., July 20 Lawrence Township residents opposing the construction of a $9-million E.R. Squibb Sons plant here are continuing their protest with the final vote on the controversial issue scheduled for next Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today that Republican designation of Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan for President and Vice President in 1968 would make "a whale of a ticket."

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission proposed today a new trade rule to force sellers of transistor radios to list in their advertising and labeling a true count of the number of transistors.
CAIRO, Ill., July 20 Negroes demanded today that the city act on their grievances within 72 hours. Otherwise, they warned, Cairo might "go up in flames."

MOOR PARK, England, July 20 (AP) Roberto de Vincenzo of Argentina, newly crowned British Open golf champion, lost two more matches today in the pro round-robin tournament on this 6,625-yard, par 72 Hertfordshire County course and was still pointless after four rounds.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The White House announced today, with regret, the resignation of Francis Bator, the President's Deputy Special Assistant for National Security Affairs.
WASHINGTON, July 20 An obscure announcement by Yugoslavia has renewed speculation here that she might become the first Communist country to join the 58-nation communications satellite consortium.
OLD TAPPAN, N.J., July 20 At 10:30 P.M. last night, 7-year-old Emily Grossman threw up.

LONDON, Ont., July 20 (UPI) Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth; Carol Mann of Baltimore; Murle Lindstrom of St. Petersburg, Fla.; Susie Maxwell of Oklahoma City and the pre-tourney favorite, Mickey Wright, carded two-under-par 70's today to tie for the first-round lead in the $18,000 Supertest Women's open.
Wall Street is getting clobbered by prosperity. Soaring stock-market volume is creating record commission profits and mammoth headaches.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 20 Vice President Humphrey opened tonight the nation's largest desalinization plant, making this the first American city to get its fresh water from the sea.
ROSELLE PARK, N.J., July 20 Lorenzo S. Spates, who was postmaster in Linden from 1921 to 1933, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 108 Filbert Street.
ST. PIERRE, July 20 President de Gaulle told a cheering crowd here today that St. Pierre and Miquelon "those islands that are as French as can be" represented France on the threshold of America.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The antiriot bill that passed the House by an overwhelming margin last night faced unexpected skepticism and procedural problems in the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) A 4-year-old Virginia boy got to chat with President Johnson and sit in the President's chair today because he knows the names of all the nation's 36 Presidents.
Construction has begun on a $25-million research reactor at the Atomic Energy Commission's Argonne National Laboratory near Lemont, Ill.

FREEPORT, Ill., July 20 Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Doelker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Hope Doelker, to John J. Campagna Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campagna of New York and Quogue, L.I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 26.
Car owners will pay up to $36 more for liability and comprehensive-collision insurance under a substantial revision of rates approved yesterday by the State Insurance...

ADEN, July 20 (AP)--Usually reliable sources charged today that 150 people were killed and more than 350 injured in a poison gas attack last Saturday by Egyptian pilots on Hajjah, a Yemeni royalist religious center 40 miles northwest of Sana. The sources said phosgene was used.

A GOOD pas de deux easily commands attention by virtue of the essential rightness of its male-female dynamics. Tuesday night's program at Jacob's Pillow in Lee, Mass., featured three of those choreographic short stories, each with its dominant tonality.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The 29-year-old husband of one of President Johnson's former secretaries has been confirmed by the Senate for a $26,000-a-year post on the Subversive Activities Control Board.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Johnson is sending two personal representatives on a tour of the allied nations participating in the Vietnam war to solicit more troops and to discuss the possibility of another meeting with their heads of government.

MIDDLESEX, N.J., July 20 Local and state police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were still searching today for the persons who stole 46 semiautomatic carbines here Sunday night from a small gun factory.
BOSTON, July 20 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy arrived back in the United States today after a month-long Irish holiday with her two children.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 20 There are two traffic lights, at Plainview and at Grant Avenues, along West Fourth Street in the cordoned-off riot area here, and cars were stopping on the reds and going on the greens all day today.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 A program supported by Gov. Ronald Reagan to deal with pollution of Lake Tahoe through local action has produced an apparent conflict with a previously initiated Federal clean-up program.
MOSCOW, July 20 The Soviet Union warned today that Israel and the countries supporting her were playing "a risky game with fire."
Second-quarter net earnings of W.R: Grace Co. slipped to $18,109,000, or 99 cents a share, from $20,619,000, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier, the report disclosed yesterday.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 21--Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Harbor Hills and Mrs. Armand Cantor of Fresh Meadow won the Board of Governors Trophy today for the 36-hole best-ball tournament held by the Women's Cross County Golf Association. They scored 71, 76-- 147. The play was over the par75, 6,017-yard Cedar Brook Country Club.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 21-- Kenneth Rosewall of Australia, Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Andres Gimeno of Spain survived the long opening day and night of play without defeat today in the professional round-robin tennis tournament at the Casino while Rodney Laver of Australia, the world champion, was suffering a stunning setback.
HANOI, North Vietnam, July 21 (Agence France-Presse)-- Foreign journalists were taken today to see a damaged Red River dike that, they were told, was hit on Wednesday by an American bomb.

Attorneys representing welfare relief clients testified yesterday before the State Board of Social Welfare that "on six or seven occasions within the past two years, relief recipients who threatened trouble for city Department of Welfare caseworkers were sent to Bellevue Hospital psychiatric ward."
HONOLULU, July 21 (UPI)-- The 39-foot sloop Holiday Too has been named winner of the 2,225 mile-biennial trans-Pacific yacht race from Los Angeles to Honolulu.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21--There was no racing at Larchmont Race Week today because of a lack of wind on western Long Island Sound. Cancellations wiped out both the morning and afternoon regattas scheduled for 16 different classes.
New YorK schoolchildren may be able to walk over a gangway to class not only on the Queen Mary but also on the Oueen Elizabeth.
LONDON, July 21--British banking sources estimated today that the United Arab Republic faced a deficit this year in the neighborhood of $500million with no discernible means of covering it.
Adam Clayton Powell, the deposed Harlem Representative, remained in Bimini yesterday despite reports that he was quitting his self-imposed exile to speak at the black power conference in Newark.
Mayor Lindsay and Robert Moses staged a tempest in a vest-pocket park yesterday.

NEWARK, July 21--Chief Magistrate James Del Mauro today refused to accept a complaint by John Smith a Negro cabdriver, against the two policemen who arrested him, touching off five days of racial violence here.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- The deficit in the Government's ordinary administrative budget in the fiscal year 1967, ended June 30, was $9.9-billion, the Treasury and Budget Bureau disclosed today.

The words "black power" suggest chauvinism and militancy for some dark purpose. They need not. The National Conference on Black Power now meeting in Newark could do much to bring a constructive meaning to the phrase.

LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 21--A city planner assailed tonight a proposed zoning change that would permit E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., to build an office and research complex in a rural residential area of this Mercer County Township.
Sales of the nation's leading chain store organizations rose 10.5 per cent in June, pushing volume for the first half 6.7 per cent ahead of the same period a year earlier.
CONCORD, Mass., July 21-- Political storm clouds have gathered once more over Walden Pond, the retreat made famous by Henry David Thoreau's voluntary exile from such things as politics a century ago.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 21--A ship carrying 580 evacuees, 151 of them Americans from the secessionist Eastern Region of Nigeria, docked here this evening, ending the last planned exodus of a large number of foreigners from the area.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today defended recent statements he has made about the course of the war in Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (UPI)--Gary Sutherland singled in two runs off Ted Abernathy after Tommy Helms booted a potential double-play grounder in the eighth inning tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 5-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
A bill to spur bilingual education in the United States for Spanish-speaking children was endorsed by witnesses yesterday at a special Senate subcommittee hearing in East Harlem.

TRENTON, July 21--New Jersey's much-contested legislative reapportionment plan faced a new obstacle today when the State Supreme Court ordered a hearing on Republican suits complaining of inconsistency and "political gerrymandering."

About 250 residents of the Lower East Side picketed the offices of the New York City Council Against Poverty at 100 Church Street yesterday to protest the imminent closing of neighborhood service centers of Mobilization for Youth because of the lack of funds.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Nationwide efforts to test people for defective hearing may be failing because of equipment inaccuracy, a three-year study by the United States Public Health Service suggests.

DETROIT, July 21--The New York Yankees broke a runless drought that had reached 22 innings tonight, but the eighthinning output proved to be too little, and the Yanks ended up with their fifth straight loss.

MUNICH, Germany, July 21 (AP)--A rightist weekly newspaper issued a revised edition today without the front-page picture of Adolf Hitler that prompted police confiscation yesterday and the night before.
KANSAS CITY, July 22(AP) --Wayne Causey drove in two runs with a triple and single and scored a third tonight in leading the Chicago White Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
WATERFORD, Conn., July 21--"I found this a student play. I'm alarmed at somebody so young writing so old-fashioned a play," said a professional critic.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, July 10--The outstanding fact of Bahamian public life today is the demoralization of the United Bahamian party in the six months since it lost control of government to the Negro-based Progressive Liberal party.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 21--Mr. and Mrs. John F. McIver of Lloyd Harbor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grail Anne McIver, to George Bernard Harte 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harte of New Iberia, La.
The Glen Alden Corporation acquired yesterday about 18 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Stanley Warner Corporation.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 21 --Police Capt. Frank Royce squeezed the trigger of his Remington .30-caliber rifle. The bullet tore a clean hole in a titanium plate 150 yards away --but was then stopped dead by a backing made or specially woven nylon.
DURBAN, South Africa, July 21--Albert Luthuli, the former Zulu chief who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1960, was struck by a train near his home today and died soon afterward in a hospital.
NEWARK, July 21--White citizens of this city's 405,000 residents speak with a confused mixture of hatred, fear and compassion about Negroes who rioted here for five days.

HENDERSONVILLE, N.C., July 21 (AP)--An investigator said today "some very workable information" about Wednesday's two-plane air collision that took 82 lives had been yielded by the recorded radio voices of the two pilots.

WHITE PLAINS, July 21-- An original stretch of the scenic Bronx River Parkway, one of the first automobile parkways in the world, will be straightened and widened for safety reasons over the objections of conservationists.
JUST as fashions change in women's clothing, so they do in antique collecting.

The house-to-house search for stolen weapons in a Negro section of Plainfield, N.J., conducted by state troopers and National Guardsmen Wednesday under Gubernatorial proclamation but without warrants lasted less than two hours.
Buckpasser, Ogden Phipps's grand 4-year-old horse with a record of 21 stakes victories in a career of 29 races, is the 2-5 early-line favorite to win the $108,700 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today.
Silver futures moved lower for the second successive day in active trading on the Commodity Exchange here.

New York State's first modern experience with a lottery has been a bitter disappointment. In the first month of its existence only a little more than one-fifth of the predicted thirty million tickets have been sold. Unless there is a sharp upturn, neither the state nor New York City will realize anything like the revenue they had unwisely counted on.

EAST HAVEN, Conn., July 21 (UPI)--Leaders of a birth control group asked President Johnson today to discourage the Indian Government from adopting a bill proposing the sterilization of all men with three or more children.

NEWARK, July 21--Leaders of the National Conference on Black Power rejected today the concept that Negroes were solely responsible for preventing racial violence in Negro ghettos. They said the basic responsibility rested with white people.
Bond prices underwent their fifth consecutive setback yesterday in light trading.

DETROIT, July 21 (UPI)-- Roy Duby of Tampa, Fla., who holds the world hydroplane speed record, was severely injured today when an explosion ripped a racing boat during a test run of a new computercontrolled engine.

The leader of a hospital workers' union here said yesterday that he would defy a Federal Court order and go ahead with plans to strike Yeshiva University's Einstein College of Medicine and three affiliated Bronx hospitals on Monday morning.
The H-62, the Soviet Union's newest long-range jet passenger aircraft, made its North American debut yesterday with a landing at Montreal International Airport.

Basil Rathbone, the suave Shakespearean actor who won motion-picture fame in the early nineteen-forties as the detective Sherlock Holmes--and regretted the identification the rest of his life--died of a heart attack yesterday.
ALBANY, July 21--Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Stein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan E. Stein, to Ronald Harlan Backer, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Backer of Schenectady.
Mayor Lindsay was asked at his news conference yesterday what he thought of the fact that his Human Rights Commissioner, William H. Booth, was attending the Black Power conference in Newark.
TRENTON, July 21 (AP)-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes made two more appointments today to his blue-ribbon panel investigating the causes and consequences of recent racial disorders in New Jersey.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 21 (AP)--John L. Pitchell, former Rahway councilman convicted of misconduct in office, was fined $2,000 today and given a suspended prison sentence.
BETHESDA, Md., July 21-- President Johnson visited the National Institute of Health here today to renew his commitment, as he put it, to the war on sickness and disease.
Avant garde jazz music crashed, whimpered and walled yesterday at the funeral of John W. Coltrane.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)--The National Cancer Institute suggested today that oral contraceptives be "further evaluated" to determine whether they can cause cancer.

YONKERS, July 21--Twin features on the season's first card of 10 betting races attracted 23,814 harness racing fans to Yonkers Raceway tonight and, to the delight of the chalk-players among them, the favorite prevailed in each event.
"I maintain that every one of us should seek out the best teacher he can find, first for ourselves, and then for the youth, regardless of expense or anything."
Jazz, which has seldom attracted patrons of the arts, has a new patron--the brewer.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --A Filipino waiter in Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's mess has been found to have leprosy, the Pentagon's health chief said today.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- About 9,000 General Electric color television sets that may be leaking radiation are still unaccounted for and may be in use, the United States Public Health Service reported today.
BOSTON, July 21--Dr. L. Cabot Briggs has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Eleanor Livingston Briggs, to Arne Lewis. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lewis of New York.
An almost 40-year-old study suggests that those "ga-ga" sounds that baby girls make may be useful in predicting their adult intelligence levels.
It was an eerie, moody kind of day as New York found itself caught in a battle beween the sun and the fog yesterday.

Glenn A. Cramer, president of Trans International Airlines of Oakland, Calif., said yesterday that his airline planned to seek immediate "judicial review" of a court decision Thursday barring international packaged or inclusive tours on supplemental airlines.

The chapel of Christ Church Methodist was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jane Miller Van Schoick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Van Schoick of Cobleskill, N.Y., to Peter Alfred Warren. His parents are the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Warren of London.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 22 (AP)--Charles M. Hughes, a retired State Supreme Court Justice, died today after a long illness. He was 71 years old. He had been the justice for Schenectady County from January, 1954, until he reached retirement age last December.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 22--A unit of the United States' 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment, outnumbered 3 to 1, reported having killed 90 Vietcong in a two-hour battle yesterday 30 miles northeast of Bienhoa.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 21 (AP) --National Guardsmen moved into the racially troubled North Side of Minneapolis tonight as fire broke out in the area for the third night in a row.

Representative Theodore R. Kupferman chose two locked cars at random on West 44th Street yesterday and then opened and started them without their owners' permission. One of the cars, a pale green 1965 Dodge, was marked, "U.S. Army, Official Use Only."
David C. Bevan, chairman of the finance committee of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation.

HONG KONG, July 21-- Communist China's 800,000 college and university students, who have been away from classes acting as a shock force for the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, are beginning to so back to school.
NLWARK, July 21--Two high-ranking officers of the New York City Police Department have been enrolled as delegates at the National Conference on Black Power here.

LONDON, July 21--In what may have been a burn-thespeculators squeeze play by the Hank of England, sterling rallied today in foreign-exchange trading. Some dealers thought it equally likely that the recovery was a spontaneous reaction by a market that decided the pound had been oversold.

PLAINFIELD, N.J,, July 21 --All National Guard forces, who had been sent here to halt racial violence, were removed from Plalnfield at 8 A.M, today after the superintendent of the state police announced the "return of law and order."

Dr. Ira B. Zasloff, associate professor and subchairman of the department of physical and health education at the Baruch school of Business and Public Administration of City College, died Thursday in Unity Hospital, Brooklyn, after suffering a stroke July 9. He was 62 years old and lived at 79 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.
DETROIT, July 21--The Ford Motor Company reported today 63,805 new car sales in the middle third of July, up 3 per cent from 62,037 sales in the July 11-20 period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- The National Education Association demonstrated its new responsiveness to teacher demands today by taking a stand on school desegregation that diffred sharply from that advocated by powerful superintendents within the organization.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., July 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Filippone have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Filippone, to Julian O. Standen of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Harold Hazelton of New York and Anthony Standen of New York and South Kent., Cnnn.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --President Johnson's recent appointment of Simon F. McHugh, husband of a former White House secretary, to a $500-a-week job on the Subversive Activities Control Board led today to a demand that Coneress abolish the agency.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --The Great Lakes Conference of Senators is proposing a series of amendments to appropriations bills designed to increase the volume of American shipping on the Great Lakes, Senators William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, said today.
ACTIVITY on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange often provides an indication of price fluctuations that may occur the following day on the New York Stock Exchange in dually listed issues.

PEKING, July 21 (Agence France-Presse)--Serious political differences between North Vietnam and Communist China, which became apparent in 1966, have entered a new and perhaps decisive phase, observers here said today.

WASHINGTON, July 21--The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, acting on an urgent request of the Justice Department, temporarily blocked today the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Ameri- can Broadcasting Companies, Inc.

The New York Mets, who climbed past the Houston Astros into ninth place earlier this wreek, tried to climb past the Las Angeles Dodgers into eighth place last night. But they tripped over two pitchers named Bill Singer and Phil Regan.
PATCHOGUE, L.I, July 21-- The National Park Service today announced proposed regulations for controlling beach buggy traffic on the Fire Island National Seashore.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21-- Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Clark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roberts Clark, to John R. Oppenheimer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Armand M. Oppenheimer of New York. The wedding is planned for September.

Miss Jane MacComb Breckenridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James MacComb Breckenridge of Jamestown, N.Y., was married here this afternoon th Michael Dammann Eisner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Eisner Jr. of 1095 Park Avenue and Saxton's River, Vt.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 21 (Reuters)--The Indonesian Badminton Association decided today to drop out of the world championship rather than obey an order that the final match be continued in New Zealand.

At both ends of the 11,700mile sea route that links Kuwait and Ireland two large installations for handling tankers are being built to help move up to 11,250,000 tons of crude oil expected to start moving on the route by August of next year.
ROME, July 21--Deputy Gaetano Martino, president of the Liberal party, a former Foreign Minister and a leading exponent of European unity, died at his home here today. He was 66 years old.

TORONTO, July 21 (UPI)-- George Chuvalo, the Canadian heavyweight who was stopped for the first time in his career by Joe Frazier in New York last Wednesday, will undergo surgery tomorrow on a fractured bone in his eyeball socket. The injury may end Chuvalo's boxing career.
PARIS, July 21--The novel is still in, and so are women writers, but foreign authors are out, according to statistics about the most successful books printed here since last fall.

S. Edwards Carll, chief editor of Prentice-Hall, Inc., book publishers, in the nineteentwenties who retired as special assistant to the president of the corporation in 1960, died Thursday in Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 560 Summit Avenue, Oradell, N.J.
JERUSALEM, July 21--Cities change, some over centuries, others from one generation to another, a few seemingly between visits. But Jerusalem changed overnight a few weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The Administration is considering a plan under which the United States would report to the United Nations its arms shipments to the Middle East.
The four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 14.8 per cent in production for the week ended July 15, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.
MILWAUKEE, July 21(UPI) --Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Wimbledon champion, was upset today by 18-year-old Rosemary Casals, in the national clay courts women's tennis chamnionship.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)--The Food and Drug Administration cautioned today that three spray-type oven cleaning products pressurized with propane gas may cause explosions when used on hot surfaces or near a pilot light.

BUFFALO, July 21 (UPI)-- Booker Edgerson, a defensive back, became the sole holdout yesterday of what originally was an eight-man strike for higher pay as Art Powell and Tom Flores agreed to return to the Buffalo Bills' training camp.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 21 (AP)--Harborvale Stables' Make It rallied in the stretch run today to win the Monmouth Beach Club Purse by a neck at Monmouth Park.
SCRANTON, Pa., July 21--Dr. Tohn T. Black, who served as Connecticut's first health commissioner, died yesterday. He was 90 years old and had been making his home here.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 21-- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won the Garden State Women's Golf Association's match-play championship today for the eighth time in the 14year history of the tournament.
A four per cent decrease in daily job calls for longshoremen last month over May, 1967, was reported yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

NEW DELHI--Many years of observation in the developing nations of Asia, Africa and Latin America have convinced me that in these vital areas the most important economic and political question is: Who owns the land?

CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI)-- Warren Giles, the National League president, disallowed today a protest by Leo Durocher, the Chicago Cubs' manager, of the Atlanta Braves' 2-1 victory over the Cubs yesterday.

THE West Side apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Levenson would be indistinguishable from other small, awkwardly shaped, aging, three-anda-half-room apartments, except that Mr. Levenson dot his hands on it.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) --The United States was accused today of publicizing a dispatch falsely attributed to Novosti, a Soviet press agency. The agency called the dispatch "a dirty forgery."

MANHASSET, L.I, July 21-- Joel Ross of Westbury, L.I., and Kevin McCarthy of Teaneck, N.J., won the singles finals today in the Long Island junior and boys-16 years tennis championships at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --J. Wayne Fredericks, deputy assistant secretary of state for African affairs, said today that he would leave his post in August to rejoin the Ford Foundation and to work on the foundation's international programs.

It is a history seen from the inside of the city, by those who...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21--The Soviet Union's campaign to win a General Assembly demand for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the territory of three Arab states ended in failure tonight. The Assembly voted to send the Middle East issue back to the Security Council.

State Chairman John J. Burns urged Democratic leaders throughout the state yesterday to give serious thought now to the task of selecting the best possible candidate to oppose Senator Jacob K. Javits next year.

BONN, July 21--Dr. Thomas Dehler, one of the most prominent postwar liberal politicians of West Germany, collapsed and died of a heart attack today after stepping out of a swimming pool in Streitberg, a commuity in Franconia. He was 69 years old.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, has urged Harper Row to postpone publication of Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs until after Nov. 7, the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, as a gesture towards American-Soviet friendship.
CAIRO, July 21 (Reuters)--A United Nations spokesman said here tonight that cease-fire observers of the United Nations had not reported seeing any Egyptian patrol boats in the Suez Canal.
HOLLYWOOD, July 21 (UPI) --David Weisbart, who was producing the film of "Valley of the Dolls," died today, apparently of heart failure. He was 52 years old.
The American Stock Exchange is moving ahead with its $1.1-million floor modernization program announced on May 1.
ALBANY, July 21--An outof-state couple--a Jersey City dental technician and his wife --became double winners in the New York state lottery today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)--Patrick Lyndon Nugent will spend two weeks in the White House with his grandparents next month while his parents vacation in the Bahamas.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21--A screening committee reduced the number of candidates in South Vietnam's senatorial election from 640 to 480 today, eliminating, among others, two tickets allied with Thich Tri Quang, a radical Buddhist monk.
LITTLETON, Colo., July 21-- Tommy Aaron set a course record of 65 today and established a four-stroke lead in the Professional Golfers Association championship.

CAPE KENNEDY, July 21 (UPI)--America's Lunar Explorer dashed today toward its rendezvous with the moon tomorrow morning, its instruments already humming back a steady report on the radiation levels that Apollo astronauts might encounter.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower believes that it is time for Congress to decide whether to declare war in Vietnam.
Two major maritime groups have assailed an arbitration award by Herman A. Gray as a clear-cut demonstration of the arbitrator's "obvious hostility" to the shipowner groups.
A show that unabashedly carries a message played a onenight stand Off Broadway this week and proved that even a word like scab sounds lyrical when put to music in Spanish.

BIDGE players tend to be particularly secretive about their ages, as the editors of the Official Encyclopedia of Bridge discovered when compiling biographical data. It was not surprising to find that many women experts would not give their year of--birth, but it was a slight shock to find masculine coyness and to detect a woman player who had deducted 30 veass from her age.

The American Stock Exchange closed out a busy week yesterday on a subdued note. Prices edged down and volume declined.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 21--Peggy Kass of Jumping Brook, won the metropolitan junior girls' golf championship today with a nine-over-par 38, 43-81 over the 5,558-yard Leewood Golf Club course.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 21-- The tiny office in the Ministry of Indian Affairs here, cluttered with parrot-feather totems and Amazon basketwork, hardly seemed the headquarters of an American missionary enterprise.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended July 15 were an estimated 13.5-billion ton-miles, 2.8 per cent below the corresponding week of last year.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 21--The engagement of Miss Judith Lynn Herbert to Peter Gardner Dilfon has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur M. Herbert. Mr. Dillon is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Dillon.
SAN FRANCISCO (UPI)-- The Right Rev. James A. Pike and his wife agreed today to end their 23-year marriage. It will be his second divorce.

BALTIMORE, July 21 (UPI) --Cap Peterson's, two-out, bases-loaded double in the eighth inning tonight gave the resurgent Washington Senators a 3-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and a doubleheader sweep. The Senators won the opener, 4-3, behind the clutch hitting of Fred Valentine.

BONN, July 21--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger told President de Gaulle last week that he disagreed with the French leader's estimate of the role of the United States in Europe, a high West German authority said today.

WHITE PLAINS, July 21-- Six teen-aged boys were rounded up today by the police here and in adjacent Greenburgh on charges that they bad broken into a local sporting goods shop and stolen a small arsenal.

MIAMI, July 21 (AP)--Jimmy Foxx, the Hall of Fame baseball played who ranked third on the list of career home runs, died today at the age of 59. He became ill while visiting his brother, Sam, and died on the way to Baptist Hospital.
