BONN, July 23--Tudor Arghezi, the poet laureate of Rumania and considered one of the masters of the Rumanian language in this century, died July 14 in Bucharest, it was learned here today. He was 88 years old.

LENOX, Mass., July 23--In the baseball world, a prospect who goes directly to the major leagues from high school is a rarity. In the music world, Erich Leinsdorf, music director of the Boston Symphony said tonight at Tanglewood, it is a commonplace that threatens the quality of American music.

Del Insko just about had the summer driving championship at Yonkers Raceway wrapped up as the Westchester oval went into the final night of its second of three meetings this year. The getaway program tonight will mark the end of a 52-night meeting, but the trotters and pacers will return to Yonkers Oct. 19 for its final 50-night stand, which will run through Dec. 15.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., July 23--Miss Ellen Iris Perline, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Perline, was married today to Walter Alan Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Stein. Both families are of Brooklyn. Rabbi Simon Cohen performed the ceremony in the Huntington Town House.
Four and 5-year-old children will get their own school buildings at four sites in the Bronx and Brooklyn under a Board of Education plan.

A State Constitutional Convention committee will propose this week that the Legislature be required to reapportion seats in Congress and the Legislature within a year after each Federal decennial census or to turn the job over to a commission.
The money and capital markets, which so far this summer have been performing with a remarkable degree of grace under the pressure of a record volume of new securities, face a crucial week.
PARIS, July 23--John Bull will have to keep his belt tight for several years to come, it was warned today by the authoritative Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
During the weekend when racial riots were under way in Newark, N.J., the Gallup Poll asked residents of big cities if they expected "serious racial trouble" in their community in the next six months.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 23-- Strolling around the lobby of the Tyrone Guthrie Theater between the acts of its new version of the "Oresteia," which opened Friday night, you come across a wall full of photographs from older productions that illustrate what might be called the toga-and-white-columns approach to Greek tragedy.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) --House investigators reprimanded the Army today for the manner in which it had awarded a $20-million helicopter contract to the Hughes Tool Company and urged that the Air Force and Navy take over the procurement of aircraft for the Army.

METTUPATTI, India, July 23 (AP)--James J. Fahey, a garbage truck driver of Waltham, Mass., was man of the day in Mettupatti today as he celebrated his 49th birthday by witnessing a two-hour solemn ceremony dedicating Our Lady of Dolors Roman Catholic church.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., July 23--The marriage of Miss Carol Sue Riner to Ralph Perlberger took place in Temple B'nai Jacob here this afternoon. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, assisted by Rabbi Samuel Dresner, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Riner of Springfield. Mr. Perlberger is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Perlberger of New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 24--A North Vietnamese battalion, caught by air strikes and artillery in open country and under clear skies, was reported to have suffered a major defeat in a six-hour battle in the Central Highlands yesterday.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23 (UPI)--Three new plaques will be formally unveiled tomorrow when Red Ruffing, Lloyd (Little Poison) Waner and Branch Rickey are inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y.--Bum BUM da da dum, bum BUM da da dum, bum BUM da da dum, bum BAH dum ... It was 8 A.M. and after the scratchy sounds of a recorded Reveille had died away, a man's voice came over the loudspeaker at Camp Tahoe near this heart-of-the-Catskills community, 90 miles out of New York.
AKRON, Ohio, July 23 (AP)-- Rubber workers here voted overwhelmingly today to accept a three-year contract with the B.F. Goodrich Company.

NEW DELHI, July 23--India's Health Minister said today that he was planning to wage a national campaign to win support for the compulsory sterilization of all men who have fathered three or more children.

The purchase of an Argentine whale oil factory, Cruz del Sur (Southern Cross), and plans for her conversion into an offshore oil and gas drilling vessel have been announced by Fluor Corporation, Ltd., of Los Angeles, Calif.

Two "suspicious" fires heavily damaged a vacant tenement and an abandoned factory on opposite sides of a BedfordStuyvesant street last night less than an hour after three teenage prowlers were arrested in the factory.

WASHINGTON, July 23--Despite the doubt and jitters reflected last week in the bond market over the delay of the Administration's tax bill, the tactics of the President and his advisers are designed to increase chances of the bill's passage.
The 40-story I.T. T. Americas Building, which is nearing completion at 437 Madison Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, has received another major tenant.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 23 (UPI)--A whaling ship that has reputedly sailed more miles and caught more whales than any other sailing vessel has been declared a national historic landmark at the restored seaport here.

Levitt Sons, Inc., the world's largest homebuilder, will be acquired by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in an exchange of stock worth some $90-million, under an agreement announced yesterday.
An agreement was reached last night that averted a strike set for today against Yeshiva University's Einstein College of Medicine and three of its affiliated municipal hospitals in the Bronx.

Last New Year's Eve, Luis Munoz Marin sat in a rocking chair at his home in the foothills of the mountains east of San Juan and chatted with friends about the forthcoming plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political status.

SANDS POINT, L.I., July 23 --John Baldwin of Plandome, L.I., staged a spectacular comeback today to win the Long Island amateur golf championship for the second time in three years. He defeated John Humm of the Rockville Links, 3 and 2, in the scheduled 36-hole final at the Sands Point Golf Club.
Puerto Ricans call it El Barrio--the neighborhood. Others call it East Harlem. The city calls it a poverty area.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 23--A plan to free former Premier Moise Tshombe if he is handed back to the Congo authorities by the Algerian Government is being discussed openly by some former mercenaries here.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 --Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian chief of state, is reported to have ended his opposition to an international project for a $33-million hydroelectric dam and irrigation works on the Mekong River.
Time after time in recent years, police action has produced explosive crowd reaction on the streets of New York's ghetto communities.
HINGHAM, Mass., July 23 (AP)--The atomic submarine Greenling hit a buoy off Princess Point today but continued her sea trials after a half-hour delay, the Coast Guard reported.
HICKSVILLE, L.I.--"You used to get one of the best cups of coffee there," M. Fred Noeth said as he slowly drove down Broadway, the main street of Hicksville.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., July 23 (AP)--Trouble broke out again tonight at Hartford Avenue and North Street, where an outbreak occurred early this morning.
New violence broke out last night in the Puerto Rican section of East Harlem and was contained early today.

CAIRO, Ill., July 23 (AP)--A Negro leader announced today that city officials had agreed to offer more jobs to Negroes and to help them find more job opportunities in business and industry. The agreement ended, at least for a time, the threat of renewed violence by militant young Negroes.
Berta, Grant Winkler, Inc., has taken a sweet smelling product with a genteel past and slipped it into a Honda saddle bag, a vinyl boot and a new series of ads for Crepe de Chine.

PEKING, July 23 (Agence France-Presse)--About 500 army trucks with 60 soldiers in each rolled through the center of Peking tonight, preceded by a dozen jeeps presumably carrying the commanders of the convoy.

Air passenger travel will undergo restricted growth in Africa until the nations there provide the prerequisites for tourism, such as accommodations, services and trained personnel, according to a report issued by the International Civil Aviation Organization.

IS home plate too close to the pitcher's mound? Are boys growing so tall, so strong and so powerful that the 60 foot distance is as outdated as the 10-foothigh basket, the 4-minute mile, the 7-foot high jump and the 30-yard field goal? Is that why pitchers dominate baseball, why only two batters in the American League reached 300 last year?

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 23 --Martha (Muffie) Mauger, a 16-year-old Huntington High School junior, rode Chris' Choice to the junior jumper championship today at the Horse Owners Association of the Town of Oyster Bay horse show.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 23 (AP) --George Vizard, a leader of Austin's anti-Vietnam war movement, was shot to death early today in the cold storage locker of a drive-in grocery store where he worked.

CAIRO, July 23--President Gamal Abdel Nasser called tonight for the total mobilization of the Egyptian people and announced that he was reorganizing the armed forces to continue the struggle against Israel.
MANHASSET, N.Y., Bruce Ho of the famous Four Seas restaurant in New York today opened a new restaurant, called Bruce Ho's, in Manhasset.
Dr. Robert H. Aldrich, a Boston surgeon and a specialist in the treatment of burns, died yesterday of cancer in his home in Arlington, Mass. His age was 64.

While New Yorkers and their East Coast neighbors have been moaning over a monotonous procession of wet and dreary days, and particularly weekends, these past few weeks, the citizens of India have rejoiced in a spell of similar--but even wetter--weather. Monsoon rains have come to the great Gangetic Plain, on time and in full flood, soaking parched fields and filling dry wells and streambeds to overflowing.

WASHINGTON, July 23-- In his latest newsletter to con stituents, Senator Wayne Morse included a picture of the President sitting on a rail fence in a cowboy suit and 10-gallon hat. In the background, fat cattle grazed on the banks of the Pedernales.
The eating of clay and laundry starch, which sometimes results in serious iron-deficiency anemia, has been found to be a "not uncommon" practice among some Negroes in New York City.
PEKING, July 23--Chinese Communist authorities refused to authorize the transmission of at least two news reports during the weekend.

Drugstore owners decided at a stormy meeting yesterday not to comply with the city's orders that generic drugs be substituted for more expensive brand-name drugs in prescriptions for Medicaid patients.

Insured women are getting slimmer, while the uninsured women and American women in general are getting fatter, according to an article in today's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Murphy Pacific Marine Salvage Company has acquired the assets of the salvage division of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation and the salvage assets of Merritt-Chapman Scott, West Indies, Inc.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif., has announced the appointment of Robert R. Stark to the newly created corporate position of commercial-carrier operations adviser to the company.

CLEVELAND--July 23 (AP) --Joe Foy's grand-slam homer in the opener and Gary Bell's five-hit pitching in the second game led the Boston Red Sox to 8-5 and 5-1 victories today over the Indians. The Red Sox extended their winning streak to 10 games.
RICHLAND, Wash., July 23 (AP)--Billy Schumacher overtook Chrysler Crew in the third lap of the final heat and piloted Miss Bardahl to victory in the Atomic Cup Race for unlimited hydroplanes today.

The Rev. Aloysius McDonough, president of the Roman Catholic Theological Society of America from 1961 to 1963, died on Saturday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 65 years old and for the last 20 years had lived at the Immaculate Conception Monastery of the Passionist order in Jamaica.
ROCHESTER, July 23--Bishop Fulton J. Sheen of Rochester has given his priests permission to celebrate mass in private homes during evening hours on weekdays.
WASHINGTON, July 23-- Desmond FitzGerald, a deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died today at the age of 57.

WHITE PLAINS, July 23-- Miss Martha Ruskin Grossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alec R. Grossman, was married this afternoon to Kenneth Akiba Stampfer, son of Rabbi Theodore Stampfer and Mrs. Stampfer of Clark, N.J.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 23--Dr. Timothy Leary's attorney said today he would bring action against Sheriff Lawrence M. Quinlan of Dutchess County in connection with the arrests yesterday of 39 motorists outside an estate used by Leary and his followers in nearby Millbrook.
WINNIPEG, Man., July 23 (AP)--The Pan-American Games opened today in solemn splendor with 2,400 athletes from 28 nations parading before Prince Philip of England in gaily hued uniforms.
After a seven-month flirtation with light music, WQXRAM is returning next Sunday to what it has determined is its listeners' first love--classical music.

LONDON, July 23--Everyone interested in ballet knows that Britain's Royal Ballet is not one company, but two, and that while one company is making hippy headlines in California, the other, more sedately, is appearing at the Royal Opera House among the fruit and vegetables of Covent Garden.

The New York Mets kept eighth place within reach yesterday by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-1, in a brisk game that brought special satisfaction to Bob Hendley, Tommy Davis and Manager Wes Westrum.
The Federal Government should give some financial help to the New Haven Railroad, Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP)--Ron Santo and Ernie Banks poled two-run homers today to pace the Cubs to a 6-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants and give Chicago a split of a double-header.
NEWARK, July 23--Sargent Shriver, the director of the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity, has put off his plan for a trip tomorrow to this riot-ravaged city.

Three Chinese teen-aged boys in tight pants leaning against the door of the Chinese Public School of New York turned off a transistor radio that had been blaring rock 'n roll, listened attentively and smiled, shaking their long-maned heads in disbelief.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that sudden changes in Federal and state standards on major highway directional signs might double the cost of the multimillion-dollar program the city was about to initiate.

An 11-point plan to eliminate the disparities in outbound and inbound ocean freight rates in the trade between the United States and the United Kingdom has been submitted to the Federal Maritime Commission by the regulatory agency's Hearing Counsel.

FLAT ROCK, N.C., July 23-- This quiet bucolic community of 1,300 people in the Blue Ridge Mountains of western North Carolina, spent today mourning Carl Sandburg, biographer of Abraham Lincoln and poet, who was its most illustrious citizen.
CHICAGO, July 21--Despite a substantial rise in the number of homicides here, confessions by arrested suspects have dropped about 50 per cent, a study by the Chicago state's attorney's office shows.

QUEBEC, July 23--President de Gaulle praised French Canadians tonight for being "determined to create and direct" their own future. However, he stopped short of endorsing political independence for Quebec.

Price Waterhouse Co. has just published the results of a study which suggests that corporate earnings figures are even less indicative of actual results than critics of accounting methods have contended.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 23 (AP)--Jose Cardenal stole home to cap a two-run rally in the third inning today as the California Angels beat the Minnesota Twins, 2-1, for their sixth straight victory. Jack Hamilton and the Angels' relief ace, Minnie Rojas, combined to pitch a three-hitter.

World Airways, a large supplemental charter airline, said yesterday that it had scheduled 199 inclusive tour flights for 1968 and that the bulk of them were domestic in nature and would not be affected by a high court ruling last week bearing on inclusive or package tours by supplemental airlines.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, July 24 (AP)--Thomas Cardinal Tien, the only Chinese Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church, died today at Chiayi in central Taiwan. He was 76 years old.

William Evans Blood, former president and chairman of the board of the Asheville-Schoonmaker Mica Company of New York and Newport News, Va., died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and formerly lived at 720 Park Avenue.

Some members of Congress are beginning to ask searching questions about America's Governmentsponsored, booming international arms business. It's about time. A series of events in recent years has cast serious doubt on some of the basic assumptions that underlie the arms aid and sales programs. In a number of situations, it is clear that the decision to sell or give American arms has done more harm than good to the interests of the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 23-- Prof. John Cobb Cooper, former president of the International Institute of Space Law, who predicted that "chaos and conflict" would be inevitable in outer space unless "nationality" was established, died in his home here yesterday. His age was 79.

DETROIT, July 23--The New York Yankees broke a six-game losing streak in Tiger Stadium today before 34,623 fans, beating Detroit, 4-2, on an 11-hit attack that seat Mickey Lolich to his 10th straight defeat this season.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 23-- W.T. Coleman Carpenter, senior partner of Colgate, Hoyt Co. of New York, who celebrated his 78th year as a Wall Street broker last January, died here yesterday at the Suburban Hotel. His age was 95.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., July 23--Miss Ann Carol Baseman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Baseman of Cheltenham, was married this afternoon to Michael Frank Rosenblum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob J. Rosenblum of New York and Milton, Conn. Rabbi Jaakov Rosenberg and Rabbi Haskell Lookstein performed the ceremony at Congregation Adath Jeshurun.
JACKSON, Miss., July 23 (AP)--James H. Meredith says he put the race issue aside in deciding to endorse former Gov. Ross Barnett's bid for another term in the statehouse.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP)--Dal Maxvill drove in the tie-breaking run with a seventh-inning single and the St. Louis Cardinals went on to trim the Atlanta Braves, 8-3, today, completing a double-header sweep that sent them back into sole possession of first place in the National League. The Cardinals won the first game, 3-1, on Julian Javier's two-run homer.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 23--Officials said today there were 57 known dead and 147 injured in the violent earthquake last night that was centered on Adapazari, in Western Anatolia, about 100 miles east of Istanbul.
Dr. Luis M. Garfienkel of 173 West 78th Street, a chemist, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 73.

NICHOLAS ROSSOLIMO, the New York grand master, played with dynamic drive throughout the recent First Puerto Rican Open in San Juan, where he scored 5 -1 . Not only did he win the brilliancy prize for his historic victory over Paul Reissman, a former champion of Puerto Rico, but he also produced two worthy candidates for the best-played games in the following victories over J. Gotay and Luis Suarez, both of Puerto Rico.

CHERRY GROVE, L.I., July 23--A beachfront campaign to educate homosexuals on Fire Island about their rights in the courtroom is being prepared by the Mattachine Society, an educational research group that seeks tolerance of homosexuals.
WASHINGTON, July 23-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

CHICAGO, July 23--Ch. Salilyn's Aristocrat, the No. 1 sporting dog last year and the second top-winning dog of all breeds for the first three months in '67, keeps right on the victory trial. Tonight he was singled out by Mrs. Augustus Riggs 4th of Woodbine, Md., as the best among 2,696 dogs at the International Kennel Club show at the amphitheatre in the Union Stock Yards.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23-- Sweeping matches with Kenneth Rosewall of Australia, Andres Gimeno of Spain and Earl Buchholz of St. Louis in the final round-robin, Rodney Laver won the Newport professional tennis tournament today at the Casino. He collected $2,100 in prize money and the Cartier Cup.

Yesterday morning's disturbances in Spanishspeaking East Harlem followed the melancholy and familiar ritual. Once again a police incident set off a flood of rumors that galvanized teen-agers into violence. Fortunately the trouble was contained, but it lasted long enough to buttress the warnings that there is plenty of inflammable material here, and not only among Negroes.

CARLISLE, Pa., July 23 (AP) --Bobby Mitchell, a flanker and running back, signed a threeyear contract with the Washington Redskins of the National Football League today for a salary estimated at $40,000 a year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 23--Ron Mahood of Westchester Hills won the 48th annual Westchester County Golf Association championship today by defeating Greg Powers of the Country Club of Darien, Conn., 6 and 5, in a scheduled 36-hole final at Metropolis Country Club.

BRISTOL, Tenn., July 23 (AP) --Richard Petty mastered the Bristol International Speedway for the first time today as he won the Volunteer 500-mile stock-car race, shattering the track record. It was his 16th victory of the season.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 23-- Eight skippers accomplished sweeps today in the weekend invitation regatta sponsored jointly by the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club and the Narrasketuck Y.C. with close competition marking the 18 other classes.

The American Council on Education, which speaks authoritatively for much of the leadership of higher education, is an essentially conservative organization, not given to hasty or hysterical pronouncements.

CLEVELAND, July 23 (UPI)--Art objects valued at $500,000 were stolen this weekend from the private warehouse of a Cleveland industrialist, the police reported today. It was said to be the largest art theft in Cleveland history.
HONG KONG, July 23 (UPI) --Chinese leftists used fire and explosives today as they continued their campaign of violence and terror in this British crown colony.

The Holland-America Line recently announced the additional cancellation of two transAtlantic round trips of the liner Nieuw Amsterdam, scheduled to have sailed from Rotterdam on Aug. 8 and 29 and from here on Aug. 18 and Sept. 8.

WASHINGTON, July 23--Administration officials say President Johnson has decided that this is not the time to alter the scope of the bombing pressure against North Viet nam. Instead, they report, it has been decided to continue the air strikes at the present rate of about 250 to 300 flights a day against targets throughout North Vietnam and 150 against infiltration routes in Laos.

WHITE PLAINS, July 23-- At the Temple Israel Center here today, Miss Emily Barbara Littman and Dr. Steven Leslie Eisen were married by Rabbi James S. Diamond. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Bertram Littman of Mount Vernon, and Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eisen of East Hills, L.I.

MILWAUKEE, July 23 (UPI) --Arthur Ashe, the top-seeded player, defeated a tired Marty Riessen today in the men's singles final of the national clay courts tennis tourney after Nancy Richey had stopped Rosemary Casals and won her fifth consecutive women's title.
Would that fate always reared its head as prettily as it did Saturday evening in Fernand Nault's "Carmina Burana," performed by "Les Grands Ballets Canadiens" at C.W. Post College in Brookville, L.I.
RYE, N.Y., July 23--A 100mile distance race to Block Island opened the American Yacht Club's 36th annual cruise today with the fleet starting shortly before noon from Scotch Caps, off Rye.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP)-- Home runs by Roberto Clemente, Bill Mazeroski and Donn Clendenon led an 18-hit attack that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 15-2 victory over the Houston Astros today and a split of a double-header.
MOSCOW, July 23 (AP)-- Pravda, the newspaper of the Soviet Communist party, issued what appeared to be an appeal to Rumania today to resume her full role in the Warsaw Pact military alliance.
ANYONE who is all thumbs and has gift-giving in the future might consider a new service offered by Azuma, an emporium filled with goodies at 666 Lexington Avenue (56th Street).

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Monday, July 24-- grocery store owned by a white merchant was set afire by a Molotov cocktail last night on William Street in the heart of the predominantly Negro area where racial disturbances occurred the last two nights.

A WORLD champion who goes down in a slam that could have been made is not likely to be allowed to forget it. On the diagramed deal South went down in six clubs after winning the opening spade lead in dummy and successfully running the club ten.
DETROIT, July 23--The General Motors Corporation reported record new-car sales in the middle third of July.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 23 --Arthur Luland, a retired assistant manager for the Prudential Insurance Company, Newark, died today in a fire in his eighth-floor apartment at 156 South Harrison Street here.
MADRID, July 23 (Reuters) --Jim Clark of Scotland, driving a Lotus 48, won the 117.2-mile Madrid Grand Prix in the European championship series for Formula II cars today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UPI) --Chico Ruiz singled home the tie-breaking run with two out in the seventh inning today as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-1, behind the two-hit pitching of Milt Pappas and Ted Abernathy.
Novelists have them, jockeys have them, prizefighters have them and actors have them. And in the world of advertising, photographers have them too.

The Eastman Kodak Company achieved the highest sales in its history in the three and six months ended June 30, but profits declined under the pressure of the cost-price squeeze, according to the semiannual report issued over the weekend.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 23 (AP)--Roy Emerson of Australia defeated an erratic Manuel Santana of Spain in straight sets, 6-2, 8-6, 6-4, today and won the Swiss international tennis championships.
An industry that provides more than 4,000 skilled jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans in New York is fearful that impending Federal legislation may force some of its plants tp close.
WASHINGTON, July 23-- Senator Stuart Symington charged today that United States controls over the resale of American weapons in the hands of European countries were breaking down.

An unheralded change in New York State's student loan program, effected July 1, makes it now possible for needy, poorly, educated and unskilled persons to reach out for the many better paying jobs that are currently going begging.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes said yesterday that New Jersey National Guardsmen and the State Police would be given special training in sniper control.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23--Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the American commander in Vietnam, denied tonight that he had used his troops inefficiently and that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had said that he did so.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 23 (UPI)--A South African racing driver crashed his vehicle into a mass of spectators crowding a track here today. At least seven persons were killed and 10 were injured.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 23--Miss Diana Aron, daughter of the late Rabbi G. David Aron and Mrs. Aron of Dorchester, Mass., was married here today to Marvin Bradley Hochman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Louis Hochman of Jackson Heights, Queens. Rabbi Avraham Soltes performed the ceremony in Temple Emanuel.

DETROIT, July 23--Walter P. Reuther's plan to win a guaranteed income for auto workers is complicated, but its aims are simple--to give production workers the security and privileges of white-collar workers.
THOMPSON, Conn., July 23-- Jerry Crawford of Bow, N.H., set another record today with his Lola T70 auto racer.

DETROIT, Monday, July 24 --Thousands of rampaging Negroes firebombed and looted huge sections of Detroit last night and early today. Gov. George Romney ordered 1,500 National Guardsmen, backed by tanks, to quell the riot.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, July 23--"Getting shot at is a morale problem for these river patrol boat men," said the Navy commander. "If they don't get shot up every once in a while, their morale goes way down."
LINCOLN, Neb., July 23--Nebraska lawmakers returned to their constituencies today after having made fundamental changes in the conservative direction of state policy.

PARIS, July 23 (AP)--Roger Pingeon, a 27-year-old Frenchman, won the 54th Tour of France bicycle race today and received a tumultuous welcome by a crowd of 30,000 as he pedaled across the finish line.
FREEPORT, The Bahamas, July 23 (AP)--A gambler facing expulsion from the Bahamas says he has no intention of seeking asylum elsewhere from the gambling indictments facing him in New York.
STEWART AIR FORCE BASE, Newburgh, N.Y., July 23-- Two weeks ago 13 men left such jobs as telephone company splicer, engineer, school custodian and tree surgeon to don Air Force flying suits.
PITTSBURGH, July 23--Steel mills were getting some badly needed business last week.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 23 (AP)--Mario Andretti, the defending champion of the United States Auto Club, won his second major race of the season today, the 150-mile event for Indianapolis Speedway-type cars over the 1.7-mile Raceway Park course's seven turns.

THE 90-minute news special on the Israeli-Arab war presented by the National Broadcasting Company last night was a first-rate example of television reporting. The documentary, "Israel: Victory or Else," wove into a single, tightly organized strand the tangle of political, military and emotional threads that drove the Middle East into war, resulted in one of history's swiftest and most overwhelming victories and has already set the stage for the next act in the drama.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 23 (Reuters)-- A grand prix racing car skidded into the crowd and killed seven persons--including two children--today during a race here.
WASHINGTON, July 24 A Congressional committee again found itself frustrated today by the complexity of the problems of air safety.

LONDON, July 24 (AP) The British shipbuilding industry got a shot in the arm yesterday with the announcement of a $22.4-million order for Cammell Laird and Company, Ltd., and the disclosure that this Birkenhead yard had joined a consortium with two large Continental yards to form "one of the most powerful tendering bidding groups in Europe."

DALLAS, July 24 (AP) The world's welterweight championship fight between Curtis Cokes of Dallas, the titleholder, and Gypsy Joe Harris of Philadelphia was called off today when the challenger failed to appear for the weigh in.

Air pollution is worrying the American people and they want action taken to clean the air they breathe, Louis Harris reported yesterday, in a survey in The New York Post.
WASHINGTON, July 24 Concerned over the rioting in a number of cities, members of a Senate subcommittee placed a share of the blame today on the "educational starvation" of the ghetto poor.

NEW YORK models are a determined lot. They work hard, eat little, and invest considerable time and energy getting to the top. But the atmosphere at the summit is rarefied and the days of survival limited. Some elect to marry and retire. Others seek new careers to project their considerable experience.

CHATTANOOGA, July 24 (UPI) Jeff Miller of Plainfield, N.J., and Earl Hassler of Jackson, Miss., advanced today with convincing victories in the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national tennis tournament for boys and girls age 14 and under and 12 years and younger.
