Prices turned slightly upward on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. However, trading was subdued as brokers waited for parliamentary decisions on the management of the country's economy.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Tuesday, July 25 The police exchanged fire with snipers in the predominantly Negro Fourth Ward here last night in the fourth successive night of racial disorders.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 24 A conference of music educators, convened to seek ways of making music more relevant to American life, was told today that its quest might start with a study of the Beatles.

When an English actor is imported to New York for an important role, as Anthony Quayle was summoned hastily some months ago to do Galileo in Brecht's play at Lincoln Center, there is a bitter reaction from American performers. They issue indignant statements and even picket the theater.

DENVER, July 24 Don January played the back nine of the Columbine Country Course in 33 strokes today, just as he did yesterday. But his threeunder-par spurt this afternoon won the Professional Golfers' Association title for him in an all-Texas playoff. With a 69 for the 18-hole extra session, January turned back Don Massengale, his friend from the Lone Star State, by two strokes.
DETROIT, July 24 The Detroit race riots of 1967 bear little resemblance to the riot of 1943.

CECIL BUNDREN is wondering these days wheth er he should cement the outside wall of his narrow, four-story house with its eight rooms and eight fireplaces; the cement would keep the damp from the 1820 building. He is also wondering whether it is worthwhile to turn his backyard into a garden.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 24 Rex Cole, whose promotion of electric refrigerators in the nineteen-twenties and thirties made his name a household word, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at the Gramatan Hotel here.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 24 (AP) Peter Grimm's Escapade became the first yacht today in the history of the Port Huron-to-Mackinac race to win over-all honors five times.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Friday the level it reached on Thursday, which was 113.7.
ROME, July 24 The latest effort by the Vatican to work out an agreement on church and religious matters with Czechoslovakia ended in failure last month, authoritative quarters here said today.
An estimated 5,000 of the nation's businesswomen convened here yesterday to discuss their place in the business world.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 24 Will this be the year when the New York Jets put together all their assets and win the Eastern championship of the American Football League?

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 24 The freshly laid Macadam on Olcek Sokak the Street of Scales, or of Measures was still soft and sticky today and Turkish stonemasons were completing the last 20 yards of a new inlaid, concrete-block sidewalk.

ROCK CREEK, Ohio, July 24 (UPI) A tornado ripped through the Roaming Rock Shores area in Ashtabula County today, injuring two men, destroying a garage they were building and flipping over three trailers.

ADAPAZARI, Turkey, July 24 (AP) Turkish officials say 86 bodies have been recovered so far from the earthquake that rocked western and central Turkey Saturday. At least 110 were injured, half critically. Officials still voiced the fear that the death toll would run into the hundreds.
"Hello, Dolly!," now in its third year on Broadway, will have an all-Negro road company headed by Pearl Bailey. That company's tour will begin Oct. 10 in Washington.

President Johnson's policies in Vietnam have divided the Democratic party more deeply than any issue since the Southern revolt against the Truman Administration's civil rights proposals nearly twenty years ago. Unless the President can narrow that division, the Democrats may well lose the next election.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri announced today that he would not disclose the details of his legal association with counsel for James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, that netted him $48,000 in two years.
There is some doubt that the projected acquisition of Schenley Industries, Inc., by the P. Lorillard Company will occur.
Theodore S. Sweedy, a freelance writer and a former member of The New York Times news staff, died Sunday of a heart attack in Castries, Saint Lucia, in the Windward Islands, on his 62d birthday.
IN 1930, Stern Brothers opened what seems to have been the first special college shop with a "college board."
A Criminal Court Justice yesterday adjourned the hearing involving five girl musicians who have been performing as a topless band in a New York night club.
WASHINGTON, July 24 Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the drug industry today to take a critical look at its policies to see if wide variations in prices charged for a single compound were justified.

By arranging an emergency meeting with Mayor Lindsay to determine how much additional money the city might be able to find for teachers' salary increases, the Board of Education has dramatized the essential weakness of the biennial contract negotiations. Collective bargaining procedures designed to assure labor its fair share of the returns from productivity and profits are ill-suited to negotiations with an employer without any income.

Mrs. Dorothy Wagner Neiman, who as Dorothy Wagner was a piano teacher and accompanist and formerly a concert pianist, died of cancer yesterday at Hillcrest (Queens) General Hospital. She was 55 years old and the wife of Morris Neiman of 99-55 63d Road, Forest Hills, Queens, a lecturer on modern Hebrew language at Brooklyn College and the Ramaz School.
Edna Vance Hamilton, who retired in 1952 as a teacher at Public School 101, 2 Russell Place, Forest Hills, Queens, died yesterday in her home at 69-39 Exeter Street, Forest Hills. Her age was 85.
The men's apparel industry has long been, in many ways, a close fraternity in which the leading manufacturers, retailers, suppliers and publications in the field generally get along pretty well.
Steel production rose last week for the second successive week, climbing 2.3 per cent beyond the level of the preceding seven days, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, Tuesday, July 25 A Negro motorist was shot to death by the police here last night as he tried to run through a police line set up in the troubled Negro Third Ward during a second night of racial disorder.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Following is the text of President Johnson's proclamation issued tonight at 11:30 P.M. on law and order and violence in Michigan:
Mayor Lindsay reached into a pile of 1,547 winning state lottery tickets yesterday and picked the name of a Brooklyn woman as the first of 90 grand prize winners.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)--Thurgood Marshall said today that he thought it was possible to draft legislation to permit wiretapping by law enforcement officers that would be constitutional.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 24--Nassau took the first step today to help the increasing number of elderly persons in the county find low-cost public housing.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. July 24 (AP)--The late Branch Rickey, Lloyd Waner and Red Ruffing were inducted formally into Baseball's Hall of Fame today in brief, colorful ceremonies that were marred a bit by drizzling rain.
MIAMI, July 24 With the opening of the Havana conference of the Latin-American Solidarity Organization still a week away, differences have already begun to emerge in the extreme left.

CASTLETON, Vt., July 24 A few weeks ago the Vermont Fish and Game Department received a number of phone calls pertaining to dead fish on Lake Bomoseen. The bass, northern pike, trout and perch population, callers feared, was being decimated.

Bob Shaw, the 34-year-old right-handed pitcher who once helped the Chicago White Sox win a pennant, unexpectedly was given a chance yesterday to help the Chicago Cubs pursue the same goal. He was sold to the Cubs by the New York Mets for the waiver price of $20,000.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 Philip H. Cooney, former financial vice president of the Insurance Company of North America, died Saturday. He was 70 years old.

The New York Stock Exchange confirmed yesterday that it was "exploring" the possibility of reshaping its brokerage fees basically to the dollar size of a customer's order rather than to the price of the stock.

Shakespeare moved over for Bach last night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. No popularity comparisons can be made; the house was just as full for four concertos as it has been on other nights for "King John." All 2,300 seats were taken and people were turned away.
The first large-scale rioting by Puerto Ricans in New York City has built up shock and questioning among leaders of the Puerto Rican community itself as well as the rest of the city's population.
AKRON, Ohio, July 24 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers reached agreement today on a new threeyear contract.
FRANKLINTON, La., July 24 A group of footsore, weary Negroes ended an all-night civil rights march from Bogalusa here today, and some of them were saying it would be their last.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Legislation to tax the interest on industrial development bonds issued by state and local government agencies was introduced in the House today by Representative John W. Byrnes, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., agreed today to accept a postponement of their planned merger until the case is decided by the Court of Appeals here.
ATHENS, July 24 Christophoros II, the Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria and All Africa, died here yesterday at the age of 91.
BERLIN, July 24 The Western Allies lifted visa requirements today for East Bloc nationals on nonpolitical visits to West Berlin for periods of up to a month.
Don January, a lanky Texan with an easy, openmouthed smile that cuts across a hawk-like profile, once displayed his philosophy of golf by remarking:
LONDON, July 24 (Reuters) Sir Malcolm Sargent, the British conductor, will enter the hospital for a stomach operation, it was announced tonight.
Prices of silver futures fell slightly in active trading yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange despite news of a strike against one of the most productive silver mines in the world.

Directors of a pharmaceutical cooperative in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn voted yesterday to institute legal action for libel, slander and assault and battery against the Emergency Committee for Pharmacy and Public Health.
Senator Jacob K. Javits reported yesterday that he was hard at work setting up his campaign for a third term.
NEWARK, July 24 Fifty major American corporations helped finance last week's National Conference on Black Power, the conference's chairman said today.
HOLBROOK, L.I., July 24 Firemen extinguished a house fire here early this morning and apparently overlooked the body of the 33-year-old homeowner.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Following are excerpts from a discussion April 23 at a hearing of the Senate Subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs between Senator J.W. Fulbright and a witness, Samuel Cummings, president of the International Armament Corporation, a private company selling arms. The text of the closed hearing was released yes- terday.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Lunar Orbiter 4 has lost radio contact with the earth, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
Sydney W. Waxman, a builder and real-estate developer and operator, died on Sunday in his home at 711 Hampton Avenue, Brooklyn. He would have been 60 years old on Aug. 3.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 Australia's John Cooper, a Wimbledon quarter finalist, failed to survive the first round of the 68th Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships, the opening of the major grass circuit, at the Merion Cricket Club today.
Oscar, a slightly foolishlooking, broad-chested, amiable type, has been a bit puzzled by the curious antics of shoppers who come into the Lexington Pet Center.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 24 The actors file across the stage in silhouette. "Baum, baum, baum!" they chant. "Chim, chim, chim, Meow!" Music: a Bach Kyrie. A small movie screen blossoms with a close-up of disemboweled hogs.
MONTREAL, July 24--President de Gaulle shouted a call for a "free Quebec" tonight before a cheering, chanting crowd dominated by French-Canadian extremists.

IN the entire realm of sports there is hardly a better draw than the Wimbledon amateur tennis championships. For years the Standing Room Only sign has daily greeted the ticket-seeker who neglected to make his seat application six months in advance. Unless he queues up all night, he may not be able even to get into the center-court standing area.
The New York Bank for Savings began yesterday to offer to sell mutual fund shares to its depositors, the first such move by any mutual savings bank in New York State.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 24 (Agence France-Presse) The Soviet Union, in a message made public here today, pledged to continue giving effective political and military aid to the Vietnamese people "in their fight against the American imperialist aggressor."
Johnson Johnson, the surgical dressings producer, announced yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J., the election of Thomas E. Batey and Arthur S. Lane as directors.

HOUSTON, July 24 (AP) The Houston Astros gained a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight as Mike Cuellar pitched a two-hitter, fanning 12 men, and scored the winning run on Jim Wynn's two-out single in the 11th inning.
The owner of a Rockland County radio station charged yesterday that his station had been burned down because he had invited a Negro militant to present "ultra black power" views on the air.

The Phillips Petroleum Company attained the highest gross income and net earnings in its 60-year history in the three and six months ended June 30, W.W. Keeler, president and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.
A former ship officer and admiralty lawyer, Edward J. Heine Jr., has been elected as vice president of the United States Lines Company and United States Lines, Inc., a subsidiary.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the first of the industry's Big Three to issue midyear financial figures, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings dropped sharply from the year-earlier level despite a modest improvement over the depressed first quarter.
MADRID, July 24 Fernando Arrabel Dernan, the controversial Spanish playwright, was arrested last weekend while on holiday in Murcia, southeastern Spain.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange backed down rather sharply yesterday on reduced trading volume.

WILTON, Conn., July 24 The engagement of Miss Karen Perry Swan to Francis Edward Murphy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy of Somerville, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Judson Swan 2d of Wilton. The wedding is planned for Aug. 26, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church here.
WASHINGTON, July 24 Following is the text of a statement on riots unanimously approved today by the Republican Coordinating Committee:
HONG KONG, July 24 If he chose, Mao Tse-tung could probably put Liu Shao-chi to death, but he seems more interested in killing Mr. Liu's political influence in China.

ALBANY, July 24 Considerable support has developed at the Constitutional Convention for a proposal to expand the present elective system of choosing judges to include all the judges in the state. The enactment of such a measure would cost Mayor Lindsay and future mayors of New York City a large measure of power and patronage.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) Walter Blum lost his bid to have a 35-day suspension lifted immediately so he could ride today, the closing day, at Hollywood Park.
IF a casualty insurance company collected $1-bil lion in premiums over a 12year period and kept on reserve all but $20-million paid out in claims, it would be considered "suspect to say the least."
DETROIT, July 24 The boast here was that Detroit was less likely to have a riot than were other cities. "We've got a lot going for us," was a common statement by Negro and white leaders.

The commanding officer of the Police Department elite Tactical Patrol Force strongly defended his men yesterday against criticism from East Harlem residents who said they were hostile and guilty of brutality.
JERUSALEM, July 24 Israeli authorities may transfer several hundred Egyptians from the Gaza Strip, where they had been serving as administrators, to El Arish on the coast in northern Sinai.
LONDON, July 24 New York City was said tonight to have submitted the highest bid for the liner Queen Mary. The New York bid was understood to be $2.4-million.

BONN, July 24--Gerhard Schroder, the West German Defense Minister, offered to resign last Thursday in a dispute over military spending cuts, but was asked to stay on by Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger, it was disclosed today.

A television engineering consultant predicted yesterday that between 200,000 and 400,000 television set owners would have to adjust their television antennas at a cost of $69.90 each when the city's nine TV stations moved their antennas from the Empire State Building to the proposed World Trade Center.
Paperback Originals. Assassins from Tomorrow, by Peter Heath; Brandy on the Rocks, by Maryl James; House of Hate, by Dorothy Fletcher; Opal Street, by June Wetherell (Lancer Books, 60 cents each).

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) Ray Culp hurled the streaking Chicago Cubs back into a first-place tie with St. Louis in the National League tonight, scattering five hits for a 3-1 victory over the Cardinals.
Jack L. Warner, whose career has spanned the history of Hollywood, resigned yesterday as the production chief of Warner Brothers-Seven Arts, Ltd.
TORONTO, July 24 (AP) The operation to remove bone fragments from the right cheek of George Chuvalo, the Canadian heavyweight champion, last Saturday was successful, a spokesman said today.

IF Detroit were hit by an earthquake and the Mayor and a reporter were the only persons left alive in the city and the reporter turned to the Mayor and said: 'What do you think of the situation, sir?' the Mayor would probably say: 'Well, this is certainly a matter for concern.'"
A delegation of about 125 Queens homeowners protested yesterday as the Site Selection Board voted to demolish 64 homes in Corona for a high school athletic field.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) Jim Lefebvre's run-scoring single with two out in the ninth inning lifted the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The Republican Coordinating Committee said today that the United States was "rapidly approaching a state of anarchy" because of racial rioting and that President Johnson must share in the blame.

Opening nights are old hat at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., where tonight trotters will resume trotting, pacers pacing and bettors betting. Many of the fans who attended the final program at Yonkers Raceway last night, will be among the 20,000 or more expected to turn out for the start of the season's second of two meetings in Nassau County.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The Justice Department today charged a railroad and two labor unions with employment discrimination against Negroes.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 24 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey issued a strong appeal today to the American Trial Lawyers Association to join the Federal Government in an attack on lawlessness and poverty in the United States.
BONN, July 24 The Israeli military authorities are offering to sell or barter examples of up-to-date Soviet weapons captured in the Sinai Desert to Western countries in return for tanks and planes.
Frank Roberts, manager of the New York Ship-News Reporter's Association, died of cancer Sunday in his home, at 241 East 32d Street, Brooklyn. He was 72 years old.

Governor Rockefeller helped lay the cornerstone yesterday of the Newtown Creek Sewage Treatment Plant, a 32-acre complex of buildings and machinery in Brookyn that he called "the largest antipollution project ever undertaken by the City of New York."

Dr. Leo J. Brueckner, a retired educator, who directed the study of elementary education for the Regents' Inquiry into the Character and Cost of Public Education in New York from 1936 to 1938, died Sunday in Los Angeles, where he lived. His age was 77.

President de Gaulle on his French-Canadian trip has descended from statesmanship to mischief-making. No other characterization is possible after his inflammatory cry to the crowds in Montreal of the extremists' slogan, "Long Live Free Quebec." The general is too intelligent not to realize that he is intervening in Canadian internal affairs with his encouragement of separatism and his overemphasis on the region's Gallic origins, language and culture.
The battle to take over the Dodge Manufacturing Corporation heated up yesterday as the Reliance Electric and Engineering Company sweetened its offer to Dodge shareholders.

WASHINGTON, July 24 A Senate subcommittee approved Senator John Stennis's emergency food and medical care bill in near record time today after having raised the authorization from $10-million to $25-million.

DETROIT, Tuesday, July 25--President Johnson rushed 4,700 Army paratroopers into Detroit at midnight last night as Negro snipers besieged two police stations in rioting that brought near-paralysis to the nation's fifth largest city.
NEWARK, July 24 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and the head of the city's autonomous antipoverty agency jointly called today for a Federal investigation of the agency.
Interest rates, which climbed all last week, continued to move upward yesterday.
The first non-Catholic to teach theology at St. John's University has been hired by the institution for the academic year beginning in September.

Gov. Edward T. Breathitt of Kentucky has scored another point in his uphill battle to stop the rape of his state's forested eastern mountains and rolling western farmlands by ruthless strip mine operators.

CAIRO, July 24 (Reuters) Arab foreign ministers will meet in Khartoum, The Sudan, on Aug. 1 to prepare for a meeting of Arab heads of state and forge a united front against Israel and her supporters, it was announced here today.
LE HAVRE, France, July 24 (Reuters) American yachts placed third and ninth in the 305-mile ocean race-part of the international one-ton cup series which ended last night.
PRAGUE, July 24 (AP) Stokely Carmichael, militant civil rights leader, arrived today from London, where a British newspaper had asked that he be deported.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 24 (UPI) A quartet of sharpshooting servicemen sent the United States off to a fast start in the Pan-American Games today by capturing both gold medals in free-pistol shooting, one of them with a record score for the Games.

TOKYO, July 24 (Reuters) Red Guards led by uniformed security officers invaded a Peking hotel used by Japanese businessmen today, manhandled Japanese trade representatives and put them on mock trial, the Japanese Broadcasting Corporation reported.

Braulio Baeza, the stoical Panamanian who led the nation's jockeys last year with personal earnings of more than $300,000, was injured by a fractious horse at Aqueduct yesterday and taken to a private physician for X-rays.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz leaped into Cacapon River in West Virginia yesterday and helped rescue a girl who had been swept by the current into deep water.

Sentiment for statehood is growing in Puerto Rico, but most of the islanders still want to retain the present Commonwealth status. The statehooders, campaigning under difficulties, raised their percentage of votes from about 35 in the 1964 governorship elections to 39 per cent in this referendum. The Independence party, as expected, got nowhere.
LONDON, July 24--The Labor Government made an effort today to check mounting unrest within its own party.
PATERSON, N.J., July 24 (AP) Eddie Einhorne, an independent television producer who had the rights to the Curtis Cokes-Gypsy Harris fight, said today he is "contemplating legal action."

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 24 (Reuters) "Dona Barbara," an opera by Caroline Lloyd, received unanimous praise by newspaper critics today after its premiere here. It was presented as part of celebrations marking the 400th anniversary of the founding of Caracas.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) The Detroit Tigers announced tonight that because of riot conditions in Detroit, two scheduled games with the Baltimore Orioles had been transferred to Baltimore tomorrow and Thursday night.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP) Hill Clown, benefiting from a 20-pound handicap and given a fine ride by Bill Shoemaker, upset the favorite, Pretense, today to win the $108,500 Sunset Handicap at Hollywood Park.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 24 Mrs. David Larr of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club won today the Long Island area elimination for the Syce Cup, emblematic of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound women's sailing championship.

ORANGE, N.J., July 24 James D. Cummings, a retired engineer of the Bell Telephone Laboratories at Murray Hill, died Saturday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 56 Maplewood Avenue in Maplewood.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 24 The marriage rate in this capital city has more than doubled as a result of social disruption wrought by the Arab-Israeli war, Jordanian officials said today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 24 Luis Munoz Marin appealed today for an end to debate over Puerto Rico's political status. He said the issue had been settled once and for all by the substantial majority that voters gave to the present status of commonwealth in yesterday's referendum.

OTISVILLE, N.Y. The horseshoe-shaped entrance sign on Route 211 says, "Otisville School for Boys." A gravel road winds uphill between well-tended lawns, past a swimming pool, modern redbrick cottages and an athletic field where youths have their choice of activity "even to choose to do nothing."

The chairman of the Connecticut Transportation Authority warned yesterday that the New Haven Railroad would have to shut down in the next 30 to 60 days unless it received more financial aid from the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The minority leader of the House Banking and Currency Committee sought today to force a Congressional review of United States arms sales by attempting to delay an Administration bill to increase economic aid to Latin America.

BUCHAREST, July 24 Rumania, whose independence in international affairs has been voiced increasingly in recent months, stressed today that close cooperation with the Soviet Union and other Communist nations was still the keystone of her foreign policy.
LONDON, July 24 Lord Twining, who was Governor of Tanganyika, a United Nations trust territory in Africa from 1949 to 1958, died in London on Friday. He was 68 years old.

Dr. and Mrs. William M. Hambrecht of New York and Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Barlow Hambrecht, to Diarmaid Hugh DouglasHamilton, son of Mrs. Brian St. Quentin Power of Buckham Hill House in Uckfield, Sussex, England, and the late Lord David Douglas-Hamilton.

LAKE TAHOE, Calif., July 24 The socially prominent of San Francisco who speed on superhighways to their summer homes around this mile-high lake paused over the weekend for two events inspired by an older and wilder West.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, lost today another fight to require that any unused portion of a Senator's $3,000-ayear stationery expense allowance revert automatically to the Treasury.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) The Beatles and two Members of Parliament were among 65 leading Britons who petitioned the Government today to make marijuana legal.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 25 (UPI) The Peking radio reported today that a "serious situation" had developed in Wuhan, a major economic and transportation center in central China.
A call for an end to the "whipsawing" of maritime management by seafaring labor unions has been made by Ed Turner, secretary-treasurer of the Maritime Cooks and Stewards Union.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 25 President Johnson, in the wake of new racial outbreaks, called upon the entire nation early today to condemn and combat lawlessness in all its forms.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 24 Miss Marjorie Ann Levy and John M. Burt Jr., son of Mr, and Mrs. Burt of Islip, L.I., plan to marry in January.

EAST HAMPTON L.I., July 24 In a tradition more than 75 years old, the members of the Ladies Village Improvement Society will stage their annual fair Friday on the grounds of the 17th-century Mulford Farm, on the Village Green and Main Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 25 (UPI) South Vietnamese troops, sweeping through the demilitarized zone on a regular patrol, killed 25 North Vietnamese in a fourhour battle, a military spokesman reported yesterday.
WINNIPEG, Man., July 24 (AP) Behind the sterling pitching of Manuel Alarcon, who fanned 14 men, Cuba scored a 4-3 baseball victory over the United States at the Pan-American Games tonight.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 Yemeni royalists charged here today that the Egyptians had again used poison gas against royalist forces in the civil war in Yemen.
Residents of a rural New Jersey township asked a Federal court yesterday to prevent the construction of a $75-million complex of tall neighboring office buildings in a New York town.

SYRACUSE, July 24 Miss Lynne Judith Woronov, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Woronov, was married to Stephen Charles Glassman, son of Dr. and Mrs. J.R. Glassman, at the Lafayette Country Club here this evening.

The Union Carbide Corporation and the Allied Chemical Corporation joined other members of the chemical industry's big league yesterday by reporting lower earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1967.
BRIDGE-PLAYING in the metropolitan area suffers a seasonal ebb during July and August, but vacations from work do not mean vacations from bridge and social games burgeon in all the resort areas.

JERUSALEM, July 24 (Agence France-Presse) Twenty-five of Jerusalem's leading Moslems, religious and lay, served notice today that they would not cooperate with the Israeli Ministry for Religious Affairs or recognize the incorporation of the former Jordanian parts of the city into the Israeli municipality.
NEW DELHI, July 24 (Reuters)--Finance Minister Morarji R. Desai announced today Government measures to fight a serious recession. They include special help for the engineering and textile industries.

NOROTON, Conn., July 24 Patrick W. O'Neal of the Larchmont Yacht club took a 2-point lead toward the men's championship of Long Island Sound today in the first four races in the 16th annual Hipkins Trophy series.

Mel Torme must be the most nearly complete popular singer. He is a onetime drummer who plays his own piano accompaniments, composes, writes the arrangements for the big bands that accompany him, conducts the bands and, besides singing, make noises like a full brass section and even a choral group.

FLAT ROCK, N.C., July 24 In a woodland church once attended by the first Secretary of the Treasury of the Confederacy, "John Brown's Body," the Union Army marching song, was heard this afternoon, probably for the first time.
JERUSALEM, July 24 Israeli officials tended today to interpret President Gamal Abdel Nasser's speech yesterday as an indication that the Egyptian leader was still searchng for a postwar policy.

ROSTOV, U.S.S.R., July 24 (AP) American tourists, loaded with cameras and tape recorders, are prowling the cobblestone streets of this old Cossack fortress town by the Don River, and one of them was hauled in briefly by the police today.
Falls from windows, fireescapes and roofs have killed 22 children up to 15 years old from June 1 to July 11, Dr. Edward O'Rourke, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

ALBANY, July 24 (AP) The state's share of pari-mutuel revenues from last spring's meeting of Belmont at Aqueduct is $8,802,300, compared with $8,212,877 the previous spring, the Tax Department said today.
KEARNY, N.J., July 24 The defending champion, Cal MacCracken of Tenafly, reached the quarter-finals today in the New Jersey State men's seniors' tennis tournament at the Arlington Players Club.

Members of the Social Service Employes Union early this morning voted down a settlement of a dispute that has resulted in a work stoppage by welfare caseworkers. The rejection came after city officials and union leaders had agreed earlier on a settlement formula.
CLEVELAND, July 24 (UPI) A Black Nationalist leader filed a $500,000 slander suit against Cleveland's chief of police today in connection with Negro riots here last year.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the proposal of the American Electric Power Company, Inc., to acquire the Michigan Gas and Electric Company and thereafter to dispose of the company's gas properties.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 24 Mr. and Mrs. Saul Howard have announced the engagement of Mrs. Howard's daughter, Miss Joan Ellen Deutsch, to Kenneth Cohn, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Archie Cohn of Scarsdale.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills rose to their highest levels since last winter at today's auction. Today's issue of 91-day bills sold at discounts averaging 4.423 per cent, compared to 4.245 per cent on the issue sold last Monday. This was the highest discount since late February.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The Senate directed its Appropriations Committee today to investigate the functions of the Subversive Activities Control Board to determine whether it was still needed.
Thousands of Puerto Rican youths swept through East Harlem Streets last night and early today in renewed antipolice demonstrations that left two dead and at least 12 injured.
BERLIN, July 24 Czechoslovak border guards seized a Swiss newspaperman and his wife last Thursday and held them for 29 hours at Nachod on the Polish border, a West German newspaper reported today.
The First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, announced here yesterday the election of Robert V. McCarthy as vice president for municipal securities.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 24 (Canadian Press) Thirty-two crew members and three passengers from the sunken Italian freighter Giacinto Motta arrived at St. Anthony, Nfld., today.

ALBANY, July 24--The Constitutional Convention gave initial approval today to a proposed voting rights section, the first complete article of a new constitution the delegates hope to submit to the voters in November.
The stock market closed with a moderate loss yesterday after a late-afternoon recovery move trimmed sharper declines posted earlier in the day.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday that its net income for the three months ended June 30 totaled $3,581,600 against $13,000,400 for the period last year. Income for the first half fell to $6,436,300 from $18,134,600 a year earlier.
ATHENS, July 24 The Greek Government pledged today the early restoration of press freedom, suspended after the army coup d'etat April 21.
CAIRO, July 24 A Cairo lawyer said, "Now we know there won't be another war, or at least not for the time being."
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., is reportedly close to signing a contract to open a large, new department store in Bridgeport, Conn., in an urban renewal project known as Lafayette Plaza.

MUCH the same sort of apprehension that the young Briton, Peter Watkins, expressed in his controversial, quasi-documentary, antinuclear bomb film, "The War Game," is pictured by him with brilliance and startling satiric bite in his new quasi-documentary, "Privilege," which came to the Sutton yesterday.
Bruce Barton, the advertising executive, left an estate of about $2.8-million, according to papers filed in the probate of his will in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

HAVANA, July 24 Havana has lost its old prerevolution opulence, but it has also lost its old revolting slums. The city is cleaner but shabbier than it was seven years ago, and somehow it seems younger.
WASHINGTON, July 24 The Johnson Administration released today a working paper outlining proposals for sweeping reforms in housing for the poor.
A stock-brokerage firm, Reynolds Co., has signed a $1million lease for space in the 50-story General Motors Building that will be completed next spring opposite the plaza at Central Park.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed Vincent D. McDonnell to mediate the contract dispute between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers. Mr. McDonnell is chairman of the State Mediation Board.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 24 Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace is scheduled to return to Alabama tomorrow from Houston, where she underwent surgery two weeks ago for the removal of a malignant intestinal tumor.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Tuesday, July 25 H. Rap Brown, national chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was slightly wounded by shotgun fire here last night after urging a crowd of about 400 Negroes in this frequently troubled Eastern Shore Maryland city to "burn this town down if this town don't turn around" and grant militant Negro demands.

The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority and the United States' Saint Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation have announced a three-inch increase in the maximum permissible draft for vessels using the seaway. Ships are now permitted to load to a draft of 25 feet, nine inches.

CHICAGO, July 24 The medical problems of two other defendants caused a postponement today until tomorrow of an effort by James R. Hoffa, former Teamster Union president, to prove that the Government had resorted to wiretapping to obtain evidence on which he was convicted of fraud.

Mayor Lindsay, a Republican who doesn't always follow the party line, had a terse comment yesterday about Republican charges that President Johnson must share in the blame for racial violence in the cities.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported new highs yesterday in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and consolidated net income for the second quarter and first half.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The Voice of America is broadcasting the story of the Detroit riot in 37 languages to countries all over the world, including Communist ones.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., July 25 --Mrs. Mary Mclntire Phair, a retired New York City public school kindergarten teacher, died yesterday in the Hartwick Rest Nursing Home. She was 78 years old and lived at 1893 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn.

A 400,000-share offering of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation common stock valued at $26-million was quickly over-. subscribed yesterday. It reached the market through underwriters managed by Goldman, Sachs Co., Lazard Freres Co. and White, Weld Co.
A Negro neurosurgeon began operating his own bus company without a franchise yesterday in the ghetto of South Jamaica, Queens, an area that he said was without convenient public transportation.
William Zeckendorf Sr. will step down as chairman of the board of trustees of Long Island University in October. He has held the post for 25 years.

Mr. and Mrs. George Werdinger of 30 East Ninth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felicia Renee Werdinger, to Norman Wyloge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Wyloge of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

HAVANA, July 24--The Cuban Government is now engaged in an interesting experiment. Economically, it is still relying on aid and trade with the Soviet Union, but ideologically it seems to be following not the Soviet coexistence line in Latin America but the more revolutionary doctrines of Communist China.

Eastern Air Lines profits fell to $8,586,000, or 77 cents a share, in the June quarter of 1967, although June earnings rose to $2.9-million from $2.4-million a year earlier. In the June quarter last year, earnings were $9.38-million,' or $1.01 a share. Operating revenues for the three months ended June 30 were $166.4million, against $144.1-million a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP --Gulf Western Industries, Inc., a Houston industrial concern, agreed today in a Federal antitrust case to sell most of the facilities it is acquiring from Desilu Productions, Inc., the Justice Department reported.
SAGINAW, Mich., July 25 (AP)--At least eight persons were shot and wounded tonight as sniping and arson broke out here, 100 miles northwest of Detroit.

TOKYO, July 25 (Reuters)-- A test here has showed that an oil tanker accident in the Bay of Tokyo, such as the March grounding of the Torrey Canyon off southwest England, would be disastrous, the Maritime Safety Agency said today.
LONE STAR GAS, a natural gas distributor based in Dallas, continues to trade heavily while rumors circulate concerning a possibletake-over.

New experiments with persons whose brains have been divided surgically Support the findings of earlier studies of monkeys--that the brain is actually two brains, each able to act independently and to perform advanced mental functions.

Mrs. Moise Tshombe, wife of the former Congolese leader now being held in Algeria, arrived at Kennedy International Airport from Brussels last night on a visit here to seek United Nations action to free her husband, who has been sentenced to death in the Congo.
A group of officials from Tanzania, an East African land where big game roam in vast wildlife preserves, has arrived in the United States for a 14day tour--beginning at the Bronx Zoo.
ROCHESTER, Wednesday, July 26--Police cars rolled through deserted streets here this morning as the racial disorder that had resulted in two deaths dwindled into isolated vandalism.

Sporadic violence recurred last night and early today in East Harlem and the South Bronx as crowds of Puerto Rican youths continued the antipolice demonstrations that have caused three deaths and more than 30 injuries since early Sunday.
FERNANDINA BEACH, Fla., July 25--T. Howard Kelly, author and editor, died at his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old and also had a residence in Chicago.

The American Tobacco Company, the nation's second largest cigarette maker, turned in record sales for the three and six months ended June 30. Earnings, however, were slightly lower than last year, according to the report yesterday of Robert B. Walker, the president and chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP)--J.R. Ludlow Wray, who was a star football player at the University of Pennsylvania, and a co-founder of the Philadelphia Eagles, died yesterday at the age of 73. He lived in Oreland.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., July 25--Miss Carol Wall and John Harrison Bivins 3d, teachers in the Syracuse schools, plan to be married next month. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David Wall, parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Bivins is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bivins of Riverside, Conn.

Silver futures eased again in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange although the strike at the Cerro de Pasco mine in Peru contin- ued with no sign of a break. The mine normally produces about 2 million ounces of silver a month.

MAPLEWOOD. N.J., July 25 --Daniel H. Reheis, president of Reheis Co. of Berkeley Heights, died yesterday at Berkeley Hall Nursing Home after a song illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 54 Sagamore Road here.
New York City is weighing the possibility of operating its own cable television transmission system, it was learned yesterday.

HONG KONG, July 25--A labor strike is in progress in Canton, according to reliable reports reaching here today. No details are available, but the reports are supported by the fact that no freight cars have reached the Hong Kong border from the Chinese side for the past two days.
GUANTANAMO, Cuba, July 25--Leaders of North Vietnam and the National Liberation Front told an enthusiastic Cuban audience today that they would certainly win the war in Vietnam.
Industrial stocks turned lower in fairly active trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. The Government's rejection Monday of devaluation seemed to have had little influence either way.

LOS ANGELES, July 25--The first permanent Federally subsidized professional theater in the United States, financed by nearly $1-million, was established here today in the center of the Negro and Mexican-American communities.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)--The legal basis for President Johnson's order last night sending troops to the aid of state and local officials in the Detroit riot has been on the books since 1795.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) --Bernard Hillenbrand, executive director of the National Association of Counties, said today that the organization's 32d annual convention will be held in Detroit, beginning Saturday, despite the rioting there.
The New York Stock Exchange plans to establish a new computer center in Paramus, N.J., to handle the demands of its growing volume and expanding electronic services.

The nation has cause for deep concern if the leaders of both political parties are unable to forget political considerations when murder, arson and looting are sweeping some of its major cities. This grave domestic crisis demands a level and a quality of mature leadership that have been shocking in their absence.

The arrival of Pope Paul VI in Istanbul yesterday had the effect of re-establishing the Vatican's contact with the city that was once the seat of the Roman Empire and, later, of the Eastern, or Byzantine, Empire, which controlled a great part of the Middle East and the Balkans.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 25-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation began today a search for H. Rap Brown, the youthful black power leader whose speech to Negroes here late yesterday was blamed by Gov. Spiro T. Agnew for a night of gunfire and arson in this Eastern Shore Maryland city.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 25-- Neil Donovan of Shore View scored a 73 to lead 14 qualifiers in the sectional round of the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship. Play was over the 6,533-yard par-72 Middle Bay Country Club course.

Although coal traffic of the Norfolk Western Railway rose sharply in the first half this year and contributed $123.3million to the system's gross income, a drop in merchandise traffic and a rise of $8-million in operating expenses resulted in the company's reporting a net income of $34.9-million, down from $46.2-million in the 1966 period.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 25 --Pope Paul's pilgrimage today to the cathedral of Eastern Orthodoxy's Ecumenical Patriarch, Athenagoras I, is a major advance in the movement toward reconciliation that began when the same leaders met three years ago on the Mount of Olives, in Jerusalem.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 25--Premier Ion Gheorghe Maurer made a strong attack today on interference and pressure in the relations between Communist countries.
Lane Bryant, Inc., announced yesterday its election of Arthur Malsin as corporate vice president and Joseph B. Siegel as vice president in charge of merchandising for the Lane Bryant retail stores.
The Hupp Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had been discussing a merger wit White Consolidated Industries, Inc., both of Cleveland.
Billy Rose's avoidance of taxes on the bulk of his estate was upheld in court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)--A state Senator who helped start a daily newspaper in Oklahoma said today that both major wire services had displayed "great reluctance" to serve it.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 25 --The Federal Government killed plans for two urban-renewal projects in this suburban community early this year after the city administration had refused to provide integrated housing, Federal housing officials said today.

TORONTO, July 25--Steps are being taken to wind up the operations of the Bank of Western Canada, Marc Bienvenu said today in a letter to shareholders of the York Lambton Corporation, Ltd., and British International Finance Canada, Ltd., of Toronto.
LONDON, July 25--Britain, France and West Germany have joined forces to produce a short-to-medium-distance airliner designed to reduce the cost of air travel by the early nineteen-seventies.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 25 --John Walter Madigan, a former probate judge here, died last night at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 66 West Road, New Canaan.

CLEVELAND, July 25-- The engagement of Miss Dinah Gail Esral and Michael Alan Nemeroff, seniors at the University of Chicago, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Albert A. Gilman. Mr. Nemeroff's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Nemeroff of New City, N.Y.

Ticket Reservation Systems, Inc., which is testing a network of electronic box offices for the sale of reserved seats to theater and sporting events, has added Alexander's at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street to its pilot project. Gimbel's stores in Manhattan, Garden City, L.I., and Yonkers already have outlets.
About 350 people attended a funeral service for Basil Rathbone, the actor, yesterday morning at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP) --Willie Stargell, Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder, filed a suit today against Pittsburgh Weekly Sports, accusing it of publishing a false story saying Star- gell started a fight with a team- mate, Roberto Clemente. The suit, filed in United States District Court, called the story slanderous and libelous and asked 750,000 damages.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's leading petroleum enterprise, captured new records in revenues and earnings in the second quarter and first six months this year, according to the mid-year results issued yesterday by M.L. Haider, its chairman.
DETROIT, July 25--Many of Detroit's Negroes have turned angrily on the city's police-- not for possible brutality but for not having cracked down hard on looters when the trouble began.

NOROTON, Conn., July 25-- Patrick W. O'Neal of Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club, who took a 2-point lead when the first four races were sailed in the men's championship of Long Island Sound yesterday, placed second in the final race off Noroton Yacht Club today and won the 16th annual Hipkins trophy regatta by 1 points.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 25--Gene Borek of Pine Hollow and Richard Maresca of Half Hollow Hills High School, put together a 34, 33-67 to win the Metropolitan Golf Associa- tion first annual pro-junior tournament. Play was at the par 72 6,396-yard course of the Rockville Links Club.
H.I. Romnes, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Cities Service Company.

When "Gone With the Wind," the 1939 film classic, opens at the Rivoli Theater here Oct. 11, audiences will see a new, large-screen, 70-mm. version that has involved almost as much technical wizardry as it took to make the film almost 30 years ago.
PONTIAC, Mich., July 25 (AP)--Calm apparently returned to this city of 82,000 tonight after a night of violence in which two Negroes were shot to death, one by a state legislator.

WASHINGTON, July 25--In a token bow to economy, the House today stripped $1.6-million in planning funds for a controversially New England public power project from the vast $4.5-billion public works money bill. The vote was 233 to 169.

Mr. Havenner, whose political mentors were Senator Hiram W. Johnson of California and Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin, helped establish the Progressive party in California in the nineteen-twenties. He had been secretary to Senator Johnson and an organizer of his re-election campaign in 1922. In 1924 he managed Senator La Follette's California primary campaign for the Presidential nomination.
The Dormitory Authority of the State of New York has named Roger G. Spross, an architect, as an associate director. He will work in the authority's New York office.

HOUSTON, July 25 (UPI)-- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the resignation of Dr. William A. Lee, manager of the Apollo lunar module spacecraft program at the manned spacecraft center.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 25 (UPI)--Twenty guerrillas stormed a 15-man Bolivian Army outpost in the interior and seized arms, uniforms and food supplies before turning their captives loose, it was reported today.
Nikolai A. Talensky, Soviet military historian and theorist, died in Moscow last week, according to Soviet press reports. He was in his seventies.

There were 124 more welfare caseworkers back at their jobs... here yesterday, but about 3,000 continued their stoppage as picketing resumed at 34 Welfare Department centers. The stoppage began June 19.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York raised nearly $120-million yesterday in one of the most costly financing in the big power company's 83-year history.
LONDON, July 25--Racial tension stirred by both whites and blacks in Britain was reflected today in Parliament and in proceedings in a country magistrate's court.

Attended funeral services at Washington National Cathedral for Navy Secretary-- Designate John T. McNaughton, his wife and son, victims of an airplane accident last week; met with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and special advisers Rostow and Christian; nominated Edward M. Korry to be Ambassador to Chile and Martin J. Hillenbrand to be Ambassador to Hungary.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 25 (Reuters)--Following, in unofficial translation from the official French version, is the text of the address delivered by Pope Paul VI today:
MADISON, Wis., July 25-- Gov. Warren P. Knowles signed today a new Presidential primary law making Wisconsin the first full-scale testing ground for 1968 candidates.
Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel of Congregation B'Nai Abraham in Brooklyn died Monday in Monsey, N.Y., where he was on vacation. He was 79 years old and lived at 1415 55th Street, Brooklyn.

OVER a cup of coffee in the soothing, air-conditioned comfort of the softly lit and well-upholstered press room at Shea Stadium, three former baseball players were having a relaxed conversation the other day.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Wednesday, July 26--Negro youths broke windows in this city's downtown Negro district for the second night in a row last night. The "small disturbance" was quickly brought under control, the police said.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) --The Commissioner of Labor Statistics proposed today that the Government issue expanded price information in dollars and cents from that would mean more to the average consumer.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 25--King Hussein announced a sweeping program today to provide military training to Jordanians who are not now in the country's 50,000-man army.

NORTH SCITUATE, Mass., July 25--The engagement of Miss Susan Clark Parsons, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Whitman Parsons, to Ira Michael Wolfe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Wolfe of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 25 (Reuters)--Eastern Nigeria said today that its forces had bombed four federal supply bases in the Northern Region and had launched a ground attack across the border.
Support for a cultural ven ture will be shared for the first time by the State Department and an industrial organ ization.
Second-quarter earnings of the United States Steel Corporation dropped 44 per cent from the year-earlier level, the company reported yesterday.
RYE, N.Y., July 25--The engagement of Miss Marian D. Wagner to Robert L. Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ryan, has been announced by the mother of the prospective bride, Mrs. Carl Wagner.
New-car sales of the Chrysler Corporation rose in mid-July by just 12 units from the 1966 level, despite dramatic increases for some of its models, the company reported yesterday.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 25-- The Union County Board of Freeholders today approved the emergency purchase of $65,000 worth of riot-control equipment, including firearms, walkies-talkies and patrol cars.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Keepers of the budget estimate that Federal funds will be channeled to urban areas at a rate of $10-billion this year if Congress adopts President Johnson's proposals. But what part of that figure might help to prevent riots defies consensus.

The Constitutional Convention probably owes its existence more to the protracted battle over reapportionment that began with the "one-man, one-vote" doctrine of the Supreme Court in 1964 than to any other single factor. That makes it all the more regrettable that the convention seems headed for a reactionary decision in this vital area, also.

CAIRO, July 25--The United Arab Republic announced today its austerity budget, which called for tax and price increases to offset the $395-million loss of foreign revenues caused by the closure of the Suez Canal and other economic reverses resulting from the brief war in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Representative Emanuel Celler said today that a staff study by the House Judiciary Committee would focus on "the adequacy of state regulation of the auto insurance business."
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- The wife of the Right Rev. James A. Pike, retired Episcopal bishop of California, was granted an interlocutory decree of divorce today in a five minute court appearance.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)-- Looting broke out in a Negro area on Chicago's West Side late tonight. The police said some firebombs were thrown, but that the situation was under control.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The State Department confirmed today that Donald C. Bergus, director of the department's United Arab Republic desk, would leave for Cairo shortly to head the token mission of United States diplomats in Egypt.

GLEN COVE, L.I. July 25-- Nick Raasch of the Onondaga Golf and Country Club, the defending champion, led the way through the first round of the New York men's amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club today. Par for the 6,222-yard course is 35, 35--70.

Plans for Spring Mills, Inc., to acquire the Collins Aikman Corporation were terminated yesterday. The decision was ratified by directors of both companies. Officials said operational problems made a merger inadvisable.

Mosze Nudelman, editor of the humor page of The DayJewish Journal, Yiddish-language daily newspaper, died on Monday at Coney Island Hospital, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived at 1650 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25 --Dr. and Mrs. DeWitt Hendee Smith have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Hendee Smith, to Richard Smythe Reed of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. George X, Reed of Winthrop, Iowa.
The Sperry Rand Corporation has decided to pay its first cash dividend in almost seven years.
RUMSON, N.J., July 25-- Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook and Charlotte DeCozen of Montclair shared the first-round lead today in the 34th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Shore tournament.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., formally elected its new chief executive officer yesterday morning and presented him with a record of higher revenues and earnings for the first half and the 12 months ended June 30.

Paperboard production rose nine-tenths of 1 per cent with 428,700 tons in the week ended July 22, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
BRISTOL., England, July 25 (Reuters)--A doctor said at a conference in Bristol today that he could scientifically pick the winners of horse races by using a heart-beat machine.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 25-- Neither rain, fog, wind nor slop could keep the harness racing fans from Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 25--Gov. Ronald Reagan branded racial strife in Detroit and elsewhere today as "riots of the lawbreakers and the mad dogs against the people."

Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor yesterday announced plans to form their own company, Taybur Productions, for international film production. It's first film will be "Boom!", an adaptation of Tennessee Williams's stage play "The Milk Train Doesn't Stor Here Anymore." Production will begin Aug. 14 in Sardinia. The Burtons will co-star.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., July 25 (UPI)--A 16-year-old boy from San Antonio, Tex., won election as president of Boy's Nation today, the first Negro to win the top post in the event sponsored by the American Legion.
"The Reivers," which won William Faulkner his second Pulitzer Prize, will be filmed for Columbia Pictures.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP)-- Orlando Cepeda drove in two runs tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals gained a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs and took a game lead in the National League race.

The password to immunity from the blind fury of the new Negro racists these days is "soul brother." Scrawled on shop windows in ghettos in Boston, Cincinnati, Newark and Detroit, it has said, in effect, to Negroes bent on "getting Whitey": "We are black like you."
LONDON, July 25--Prime Minister Wilson reopened the door to negotiations with the white minority regime of Ian D. Smith in Rhodesia today-- but only a chink.
TEL AVIV, July 25--The ruling Mapai party adjourned late tonight without voting on an issue that will effect the future leadership of Israel--the conditions for a merger with the Rafi party.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 25 (AP) --Reinforced police units converged on several areas of the city tonight as at least seven firebombings were reported in the second night of racial disturbances here.

"She was a very nice person, very sweet," John LeBoy, chairman of the 23d Precinct Youth Council, said yesterday. He was speaking of Mrs. Emma Haddock, a 44-year-old mother of six, who was shot to death Monday night as she stood at a window of her apartment watching the East Harlem rioting.

Hart Schaffner Marx, Inc., manufacturer and retailer of apparel, has arranged to buy an 11.6 per cent interest in Austin Reed, Ltd., a British men's wear chain, for about $1 million. The plan was revealed in a joint announcement by the concerns yesterday.
NEWARK, July 25--The Newark Teachers Union denounced the city's "second-rate, deteriorating" school system today as a major cause of the recent riots.

HAMDEN, Conn., July 25 (AP)--Charles B. Lenahan, publisher of The Hamden Chronicle, died yesterday at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, where he had been confined since suffering a heart attack at Cape Cod June 11. He was 40 years old.

DALLAS, July 25--Mr. and Mrs. Wayne F. Comer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Louise Comer, to James Ansil Ramsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ansil S. Ramsay of Jacksonville, Fla.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25 --Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Wentworth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Joy Wentworth, to Bruce Shepard Kapp, son of Mrs. Carl Kapp of Elizabeth and the late Dr. Kapp.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 25 --A publication that is exceeded in worldwide distribution only by the Bible is celebrating its 45th anniversary.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 25 --Ken Burnette, a pro, and Lou Lamanna, an amateur of Cedar Hill won the 47th annual New Jersey State Golf Association's pro-amateur championship today at the Forest Hill Field Club.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass:, July 25--The conductor of the Seattle Symphony said tonight that there was a "strong possibility" that the smaller community orchestras in America would decline sharply or disappear, leaving as few as 12 major orchestras to serve the nation on a regional basis.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Both Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress called today for the creation of a special committee to investigate riots and other civil disorders.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, July 26--The Peking radio reported this morning that a million people had attended a rally in the Chinese capital to pledge support for followers of Mao Tse-tung in the central Chinese economic and transportation center of Wuhan.

The abortive attack on the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de. Cuba exactly fourteen years ago today has the same relationship to the Cuban revolution that the fall of the Bastille has to its revolutionary proto type in France. Latin-American history is studded with failures that are given glory in their respective nations for what they tried to do and what they started.
EL ARISH, United Arab Republic, July 23--A glance at the scene here would be enough to bring a Soviet quartermaster to tears.

Many persons prominent in public life were among the more than 800 who attended yesterday a funeral service for former General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein. Rabbi Philip Hiat conducted the traditional rites at the Mount Neboh Congregation, 130 West 79th Street.

DETROIT, Wednesday, July 26--National Guard tank crews blasted away at entrenched snipers with .50-caliber machine guns early today after sniper fire routed policemen from a square-mile area of the city.
LONDON (AP), July 25-- Sixteen cash bids for the liner Queen Mary will be considered tomorrow at a board meeting of the Cunard steamship line in London.
A white-hulled, 102-foot yacht, flying the British ensign at its stern and artfully crammed with the most modern navigational aids, began a weeklong prowl of the waters of New York Harbor yesterday.
LONDON, July 25--A court ruled today that manufacturers may not tell retailers how much to charge for candy bars and chocolates.
Between torrential rainstorms, the New York Yankees played a 1-1 tie with the Minnesota Twins last night and fell to last place in the American League.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 25-- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors would be increased from six members to 18 under a charter revision proposal made jointly today by the Republican-controlled board and the Democratic County Executive.
LONDON, July 25--The Minister of Social Security, Miss Margaret Herbison, resigned today in protest against restrictions on the expansion of her department and on certain social welfare payments.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The Polish Communist party appears to Western diplomats to be caught up in an intense struggle brought on by policy differences over the Middle East and a speech by the party leader, Wladyslaw Comulka, viewed by some as anti-Jewish.
BINHTRIEU, South Vietnam, July 25--Between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning, there were knocks on the doors of five huts in this hamlet on the outskirts of Saigon.
ATLANTA, July 25 (UPI)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today he supported President Johnson's use of Federal troops to deal with rioting in Detroit.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Products may be on the marked within two years to give an important new type of protection for the teeth, a scientist and educator predicted today. Dr. Irving Glickman of the Tufts University School of Dental Medicine told a meeting on preventive dentistry that many companies were "racing" to develop products to reduce the frequency and severity of periodontal disease.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 25--Fifty black mine workers were killed and 49 injured today at Western Deep, South Africa's biggest, deepest and most modern gold mine at Carletonville, about 50 miles from here.

MONTREAL, July 25--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson rebuked President de Gaulle tonight for his statements supporting a "free Quebec." Mr. Pearson called them "unacceptable to the Canadian people and its Government."
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 25 (AP)--A car skidded across the rain-slicked New York State Thruway during a heavy storm here today, causing a four-car pileup that killed three persons and injured five.

The hard rain in Central Park last night, about 45 minutes before the New York Philharmonic's concert at the Sheep Meadow, did not discourage the thousands of people who had already arrived for the music. They endured, the orchestra announced that the concert would go on as scheduled, and it did --for an audience estimated at intermission time at about 40,000.
The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has signed a 21year lease to open a branch office in the 10-story office building at 711 Third Avenue, on the east blockfront between 44th and 45th Streets.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 25 --Mr. and Mrs. James Stacy Hendrix have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jane Hendrix, to David Blakemore Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Adams of Carmel, N.Y., and Montclair, N.J.
HAVANA, July 25 (AP)-- Stokely Carmichael was quoted by the Cuban news agency Prensa Latina today as saying that American Negroes were organizing urban guerrillas for "a fight to the death."

JERUSALEM, July 25--Israel's hopes for cooperation from Arab leaders in Jerusalem and the occupied west bank of Jordan are being undermined by Arab charges of collaboration against those who cooperate with the Israelis.
WASHINGTON, July 25 UPI)--President Johnson was reported today to have gone almost sleepless last night after he ordered Federal troops to Detroit.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25--Arthur J. Goldberg was appointed United States representative at the United Nations two years ago tomorrow. It is unlikely that his assignment has given him a more satisfying moment that that at 4 P.M. on July 17, when the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, arrived at the United States mission looking for help.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 25-- Dick Goldstein, a New York lawyer, upset Bill Tully of Pelham, the third-seeded player, 6-4, 6-4, and gained the quarter-finals of the national claycourt tennis championship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Club today.
BRUSSELS, July 25--Petrofina, S.A., the big Belgian oil company, denied today that it would be taken over by an American oil company, as stock market rumors have suggested.
MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, July 25--Alexander Matanovic of Yugoslavia took first place with 8 points after the 12th round of the International Chess Tournament here last night.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.8 on Monday from 96.9 on Friday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 113.5 on July 22, 1966.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 25 --The police arrested 17 men and four juveniles at a supermarket parking lot here last night and confiscated 13 guns, 2,000 rounds of ammunition, axhandles, knives, nightsticks and a Ku Klux Klan robe.

THERE is a fairly interesting new Greek restaurant at 117 West 57th Street that bears the name Piraeus, My Love. The name is borrowed from the title of a song in the Broadway musical "Illya Darling." Piraeus is, of course, the port of Athens, and the restaurant's decor is appropriate.

BILL VUKOVICH Jr., whose father was killed in 1955 while trying for his third straight victory in the 500mile race at Indianapolis, will make his debut in big car competition in the 150-mile race at Langhorne, Pa., on Sunday.

United Air Lines has placed orders totaling $690-million for 79 jetliners. It was the largest airline equipment purchase announced at one time.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- The New York Mets put on one of their rip-roaring finishes against the San Francisco Giants tonight. They scored three runs in the top of the ninth inning to tie the game, then gave up a run in the bottom of the inning to lose, 5-4. They were trailing, 4-1, going into the final inning of their first game on a 10-day trip west when the fireworks went off.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 25 (UPI)--Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace flew home from Texas today to cheers and roses to convalesce from a cancer operation.

ROCHESTER, Minn., July 25 (AP)--Martha Wilkinson of Yorbalinda, Calif., backed up her opening-day play with another fine round today to move into the second round of the 37th annual Trans-Mississippi women's golf tournament.
ALBANY, July 25--The leaders of the Constitutional Convention today rejected a delegate's proposal that the convention scrap its Sept. 26 deadline for final action.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Sir George Edwards, head of the British-French Concorde supersonic airliner project, called today for international cooperation on limiting aircraft noise.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25 (AP)--Calumet Farm's Home Lass led a field of six to score a seven-length victory today in the New York Athletic Club purse at Monmouth Park.

THEATER IN THE STREET is offering a traveling show this summer that is topflight children's entertainment, although it is not billed as such. The curtainraiser is "Shulo, or How the Animals Dug Their Well," an African fable adapted by Mary Kennedy and performed with simplicity and charm by the company (in some neighborhoods, they do it In Spanish). CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)-- J.C. Martin hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 3-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the first game of a double-header.
NEWARK, JULY 25--The Negro taxi driver whose arrest July 12 set off six days of bloody racial rioting here was indicted today on charges of assaulting two white policemen.

Jascha Heifetz is the latest artist to volunteer as solsist with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra during its fund-raising tour of the United States. The violinist will appear with the ensemble in the Hollywood Bowl on Aug. 13, under the direction of Eliahu Inbal, Israeli conductor.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- More than 150 representatives of book publishers, authors, educators, and computer information developers today endorsed a proposal to set up a special national commission or copyright laws.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 25--The New York Giants dropped Hank Washington, the Negro quarterback candidate from West Texas State, off their player roster today, but the tall, lean 22-year-old from Los Angeles will remain on the training camp scene.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 25 (AP)--Arthur Ashe, the Davis Cup tennis ace from Richmond, and a half-dozen superb Yankee swimmers and divers set a record-smashing pace for the United States today in the Pan American Games, but the only gold medal in the widespread competition went to Chile.
TOKYO,--Young men entering business in Japan often find that the path to the executive suite often begins on an army drill field or in the mediation hall of a Zen temple.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Yields on nine-month and oneyear bills rose well above 5 per cent at today's auction for the first time since last November, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Stock prices marked time yesterday as the market digested a flood of second-quarter earnings reports and continued to consolidate the sharp gains of recent weeks.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 25--Pope Paul VI flew to this overwhelmingly Moslem city from Rome today to bring the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox com-... munion a step closer after nearly a millenium of separation.

The playwrights' conference, sponsored by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation at Waterford, Conn., will begin the second week tonight of a three-week program of staged readings of new plays. Each reading will be followed by an appraisal from a panel of professional drama critics.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 (AP) --United States District Judge Edward J. Devitt has signed a dismissal order acquitting the 13 remaining defendants in the American Allied Insurance Company case.

BOSTON, July 25 (UPI)--Jim Hall sparked California to an early four-run lead with three hits and two runs batted in, sparking the Angels to a 6-4 victory over the Red Sox tonight and breaking Boston's winning streak at 10 games.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP)-- A number of firebombs were thrown on the city's East Side early today and one seriously injured a 71-year-old woman when it landed in her bed.

Emanuel Ress, who was known as the "button king" for his energetic promotion of buttons with political slogans, died of cancer Monday night in the New York Infirmary. He was 59 years old and lived at 62-10 84th Street, Rego Park, Queens.

Some of the 14 cottages now at the State Training School for Girls at Hudson, N.Y., are firetraps and vermin-infested, Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell said yesterday.

The Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation has announced the appointment of Robert A. Neale as vice president and special assistant to the general manager.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The Senate's chief exponent of the Food-for-Peace program said today that the Administration "doesn't make sense" when it curtails food aid shipments and orders a cut in a new year's wheat acreage while people go hungry at home and abroad.

PARIS, July 26 Citroen and Berliet, two of France's major car manufacturers, have agreed to merge, it was reported here today. Citroen is the biggest privately owned auto maker in the country, while Berliet is first in trucks.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 (AP) Manny Mota singled home the tie-breaking run in the sixth inning tonight leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

The stock market's summer rally showed signs of reviving yesterday as glamour stocks and an assortment of lower-priced issues led the market upward in its broadest advance in a week.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI) Roving gangs began breaking windows and throwing bottles in South Philadelphia tonight. Two hundred policemen were rushed to the scene.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Thursday, July 27 H. Rapp Brown, chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was arrested yesterday at the Washington National Airport as a fugitive from Cambridge, Md., where he is wanted on charges of inciting riots and arson.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration selected the Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday as the primary contractor to coordinate the engineering and scientific buildup for major space missions beyond the Apollo lunar landing program.

More than 16,500 military ballot applications for the November election have been received this year by New York Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo. This exceeds any total for a similar period since World War II, primarily because of the troop buildup in Vietnam.
EPHESUS, Turkey, July 26 Pope Paul VI ended his visit to Turkey today after praying in the small stone building where, according to one tradition, Mary, the mother of Jesus, spent her last years.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 26 Nearly $2-million in gifts have been received by Cornell University in what has been called the most successful alumni campaign in the school's 102year history.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 26 This city has halted a tree nursery project of the Neighborhood Youth Corps following complaints of rowdyism.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Defense Department made public today the names of 24 men killed in Vietnam. Among them were Specialist 4 Stephen Lebitz Jr., of Jamaica, Queens and Pfc. William S. White of Brooklyn, both of the Army.
A real estate broker who practiced on Staten Island has had his New York State license revoked after being found guilty of seeking to cheat potential home buyers.
ANKHE, South Vietnam, July 26 A 25-year-old American sergeant was sentenced today to 10 years at hard labor for his role in the killing of a suspected Vietcong prisoner.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has won a significant round in enforcing the antifraud provisions of the securities laws in connection with stock offerings.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) The police said several gasoline bombs were tossed into a supermarket in the heart of the city's Negro district tonight and a complete alert was established to prevent the spread of trouble.
TOKYO, July 26 (UPI) The Hanoi radio said today that American planes and artillery pounded a dam just north of the demilitarized zone for four consecutive days recently.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 26 Jiggs Bigelow, one of the most successful stream anglers in this northern Adirondack country, had a rude awakening yesterday. He failed to take a trout under conditions he said were made to order for his "magic morsels" dead minnows.
