Directors of Textron, Inc., authorized here yesterday a two-for-one stock split of the common shares and raised the quarterly dividend rate on shares outstanding when the stock split becomes effective.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Jordan's Ambassador to the United States said today that his Government and Israel could easily negotiate a peace settlement through a third party if the Israelis withdrew from all Arab territories.

Prices on the London stock exchange declined slightly yesterday in limited trading.

Earnings of the Inland Steel Company fell in the second quarter and first six months this year, the company reported yesterday. Profits totaled $11,206,000, or 61 cents a share, compared with $18,364,000, or $1.01 a share, in 1966. Sales and other revenues totaled $242,283,000, against $279,244,000 a year earlier.

Criminal contempt indictments against three men linked to the Mafia have been dismissed on the ground that the grand jury had not been told that the defendants had offered to testify under a grant of immunity.

After several years of desuetude, the Metropolitan Regional Council is showing encouraging signs of revival. It fell victim several years ago to parochial fears and jealousy in the suburbs of New York City, which led to the defection of several of its suburban members. James J. Flannelly, a retired examiner of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, died on Monday in Tralee, Ireland, where he was vacationing. He was 65 years old and lived at 2005 East 22d Street, Brooklyn.

An 18-inning loss to the Minnesota Twins, 3-2, completed a split twilight-night double-header in which the Yankees won the first game, 6-1.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 26 The engagement of Miss Barbara Joyce Kopple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Kopple, to Richard Kevin Keating, son of Mrs. Edward M. Hallam of Mamaroneck, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP) The three major automobile makers reported that workers' attendance at their riotthreatened Michigan plants was below normal today but considerably higher than it had been Monday and yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP)--Fernando Azevedo scored from 10 yards out with 40 seconds remaining tonight to give the Baltimore Bays a 3-2 National Professional Soccer League victory over the Los Angeles Toros.

United Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday a net income for the quarter to June 30 of $25,320,000, the highest for any quarter in the company's history. In the same quarter last year, the line had earnings of $18,412,000.

ALBION, Mich., July 26 (IPI) Firebombers damaged two vacant homes, blasted a water softener plant and just missed an elementary school in here tonight before a combined force of state and local police restored order.

Ralph L. Gates, an account executive with Young Rubicam, Inc., the advertising agency, died yesterday of a heart attack in a physician's office on East 38th Street. He was 50 years old and lived at 2 Peter Cooper Road.

Mrs. Catherine Jacqueline McGuire Lawler, wife of Andrew M. Lawler, a lawyer at l70 Broadway, died on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital. She lived at 101 Cooper Street, Inwood, upper Manhattan.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 27 --Byron Clark, senior partner in the law firm of Clark, Fox, La Guardia Ferri at 271 Madison Avenue in New York, died yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 1161 Hillside Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. George F. Ferris of 1125 Park Avenue and Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Denham Ferris to Hal A. Kroeger Jr. of St. Louis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kroeger of Tarrytown, N.Y.

ATLANTA, July 27--James D. Robinson Jr., board chairman of the First National Bank of Atlanta, who was prominent in national banking circles, died last night at a private hospital after a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

ADEN, July 27 (Reuters)-- South Arabia's Federal Supreme Council (Cabinet) today relieved Premier-Designate Hussein Ali Bayoomi of the task of forming an interim administration to guide this nation to independence next January.

A disease-causing agent has been found that is so resistant to sterilization by heat, chemicals or radiation that some biologists regard it as nonliving. Yet it proliferates in its host in the same way as do bacteria or viruses.

HAMILTON, Mass., July 27 --Mrs. Stephen B. Vernon of Hamilton and Walter Reed of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jenny Leeds Reed, to Michael Anthony Slote, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Slote of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 27--William Harmon of Winged Foot carded an eagle 3 at the 11th hole today and scored a 4-and-2 quarter-final victory over Bob Donaldson of Bethpage State Park in the 50th junior championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Rockville Links Club.

WATCHUNG, N.J., July 27-- Martha Wade, 16 years old, of Raritan Valley won the 13th annual New Jersey junior girls golf championship today with a 44, 43--87 at the Twin Brooks Country Club. Miss Wade won by three shots despite seven three-putt greens on her tour around the 6,132-yard par-37, 36--73 course.
DETROIT, July 27--Detroit's four-day riot appeared to be ending today. Only an occasional sniper shot broke the silence this evening in the city's riot areas. A 9 P.M. to- ...
Two civil rights leaders denied yesterday a report that they had drafted an appeal for an end to Negro violence in response to an indirect appeal from President Johnson.
Although insurance companies will pay millions of dollars in claims resulting from the rash of riots, the settlements will probably be no more that a fraction of the actual losses.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 27 (Reuters)--An earthquake struck Turkey today for the second time in six days, killing at least 100 persons, according to first reports.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)--Three big-city newspaper executives said today that daily journalism was thriving in the suburbs but beset by financial problems in metropolitan centers.
LOS ANGELES, July 27-- The New York Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers resumed their celebrated struggle for eighth place tonight in a hectic game that seesawed into extra innings in Dodger Stadium.

LONDON, July 27--In an atmosphere of cost-cutting corporate consolidation rather than banner-waving socialism, the Labor Government will take ownership tomorrow of 90 per cent of Britain's steelmaking capacity.
Eight persons were injured, six seriously, when a gas explosion shattered a row of seven stores in the upper Bronx last night.

Only a national effort on a scale comparable to the New Deal's Works Progress Administration can hope to cope with "the poverty and social chaos in the cities," a writer on urban problems said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 27-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to place restrictions on United States arms sales to underdeveloped countries.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) --Herman Toll, a Representative from Philadelphia from 1958 to 1966, when he retired because of illness, died yesterday in Albert Einstein Medical Center here. He was 60 years old.
The Armco Steel Corporation reported yesterday a 34 per cent decline in second-quarter earnings from the level a year earlier.
PARIS, July 27--The storm over President de Gaulle's Canadian adventure reached a peak in Paris today, but he sailed into it as if serenely confident that it would soon blow over.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that his party had been "irresponsible" in blaming President Johnson for the nation's race riots.

The inflammatory situation in the poverty pockets of the city today makes all the more essential an end to the needless strike of welfare workers. Although welfare checks have been going out regularly, the centers have had to curtail services. Home visits in the ghetto neighborhoods have been drastically reduced.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) --The Senate Finance Committee approved today a Housepassed bill designed to give a better tax break to divorced fathers on expenses of children.

DETROIT, July 27--Police Commissioner Ray Girardin said today he had found no evidence that Detroit's Negro riot had been caused by outside agitators or by any conspiracy to wreak chaos upon the nation's cities.
JERUSALEM, July 27--The seventh annual Festival of Music and Drama will open here Sunday, its program damaged to some extent by the six-day Arab-Israel war.
LONDON, July 27--Winston Spencer Churchill wants to become a member of Parliament.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 (UPI)--William Dale Archered, a 55-year-old hospital attendant, was arrested today on a Federal indictment accusing him of killing his 15-year-old nephew and two of his seven wives, including Mary Brinker Post Arden, an author, by giving them overdose injections of insulin.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 27-- Walter I. Waite, a retired executive of Standard Brands, Inc., died today at the Manhasset Medical Center after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 95 North Woods Road.
The Chrysler Corporation achieved record sales in the second quarter and first half, but profits fell sharply in both periods from 1966 levels, it was reported yesterday.

The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra arrived here last night for 20 benefit concerts in the United States and Canada to help Israel's economic reconstruction in the wake of the recent war with her Arab neighbors.

LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 27--The Township Committee approved early this morning a far-reaching zoning change that would permit E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., to build a $9-million research and administration complex in a prime residential neighborhood.

Ismael Laguna, the Panamanian challenger, who will fight Carlos Ortiz of New York and Puerto Rico for the lightweight title in Shea Stadium on Aug. 16, opened training yesterday on the main floor of Madison Square Garden.

The continuing effect of higher wage rates and fringe benefit costs accompanied by a drop in carloadings took their toll on earnings of the big, wealthy Western railroads in the second quarter and first half this year.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 27--The sale of alcoholic beverages was banned here today as Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella declared a state of emergency and imposed a curfew on the predominantly Negro South Side following three nights of violence.

CHICAGO, July 27--A verse about flowers and birds that kindergarten pupils recited in public school in nearby De Kalb was banned today by the United States Court of Appeals here, which ruled it is a prayer.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 25-- Eight days ago the Hootenannys appeared with their banjos, guitars and ukuleles on Santiago's television to sing American folk songs.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 27--A music educator's symposium here asked Paul Williams, 19-year-old editor of the folk-rock magazine Crawdaddy!, what they could do to reach their students.

PARIS, July 27--The little black dress with the underprivileged look is the big news in the French hautecouture fall and winter collections for it is upstaged only by the black suit or the black coat.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 27 --Mrs. Lucile Russell Becker, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Russell of Babson Park, Fla., was married at her home today to Donald C. Stuart. He is the son of the late Donald C. Stuart, for many years a professor in the department of modern languages at Princeton University, and the late Mrs. Stuart.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 26--The Rumanian National Assembly, normally one of the dourest and most regimented in Eastern Europe, was the scene of a 20-minute struggle today between Government and party leaders and an assemblyman named Dragoiescu.
FREDDIE GOODWIN was hardly an innocent abroad when he arrived in the United States last February to coach a team he had never seen. But he was impressed by the apparent abundance here.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP)--Home runs by Billy Cowan and Bobby Wine accounted for all the scoring in a five-run third-inning outburst today that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to an 8-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday a rise in earnings for the quarter ended June 30 and a new high in first-half profits.

TEL AVIV, July 27--The sense of imminent disaster has gone out of the Egyptian-Israeli confrontation over small-craft navigation in the Suez Canal. In fact, the situation has settled into a stalemate that may be convenient for both sides for some time.
Juan Valdez wants you.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27-- Long-shot players in the crowd of 19,067 at Monmouth Park today came up with the largest single payoff and the highest daily-double return of the New Jersey season when Royal Pop won the opening race and paid $123.40 and Tiny Fib ($25.40) took the second for a $2,366.40 double.
Just Kidding just nipped Who Called at the wire in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday and enabled Johnny Rotz to "feel a little better."
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) --A bill designed to strengthen local police departments was cleared today for House debate.

DURHAM, N.C., July 27 (UPI)--Duke University disclosed today that it had decided to take an active role in trying to solve the city's racial problems and proposed a plan that would move hundreds of negro families into traditionally white sections near the school.

A Navy helicopter carrying an injured 13-year-old boy from Annapolis, Md., landed yesterday in Central Park, where hospital aides waited to rush him to Mt. Sinai Hospital's hyperbaric chamber for treatment of spreading gangrene.

WASHINGTON, July 27--H. Rap Brown, the militant black power leader and chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, advised Negroes in Washington tonight to "get you some guns" and to "burn this town down" if it does not satisfy militant Negro demands.
GLEN COVE, L.I, July 27 --A State Supreme Court justice and two collegians were among those gaining the quarter-finals today in the New York State amateur golf championship.

HAVANA, July 27--In his remarkable speech to half a million Cubans this week, Fidel Castro treated the racial riots in the United States as one front in a worldwide struggle for the liberation of oppressed people. He did not say or imply that Negro revolution in America was led or evern influenced by Communists, but he linked the fighting in Detroit, the war in Vietnam and the ...

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON N.Y., July 27--Mrs. Athleen Dickey Crouse, an associate of the Streb real-estate agency in Dobbs ferry, died here today in her home. She was 63 years old and was the widow of Kenneth C. Crouse.

DENVER--Small guerrilla movements are now fighting established governments in Guatemala, Colombia, Venezuela and Bolivia. These are coordinated, if loosely, by a single command under Ernesto Che Guevara, one of Castro's principal collaborators. They are avowedly Communist-inspired, but their doctrine is more elaborate and ...

In the broadening Congressional inquiry into America's new role as the world's leading arms merchant, a particularly hard look needs to be taken at United States arms sales to underdeveloped countries.
DALLAS, July 27 (AP)-- Stockholders of Central Airlines of Fort Worth voted today in favor of a proposed merger with Frontier Airlines of Denver.

On the basis of well-authenticated evidence, Egypt has been using and is continuing to use poison gas against Yemeni royalists. The United States has at last made public its belief that gas may have in fact been employed. An investigation by the United Nations Human Rights Commission is clearly called for.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 27-- Henry J. Mason, who retired in 1958 as president of Johnson Higgins, international insurance brokers at 63 Wall Street, New York, died here today in his home. His age was 63.

The spot rate on the British pound rose 8 points to $2.7864 in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday. The gain largely reflected weekend considerations. Currency for delivery Monday was quoted at $2.7856/58.
The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company has acquired 49 per cent of the stock in a Bronx community antenna television system owned by Theodore Granik, the producer.
MESHULAM RIKLIS, who sold 200,000 shares of Schenley Industries for a $2-million overnight profit in March, may try to buy the whole shooting match.
GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz., July 27 (AP)-- A sightseeing plane crashed here last night, killing the pilot and six passengers.

Things were humming last night in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art. Jeremy Steig and the Satyrs, last night's electronically oriented entry in the museum's Jazz in the Garden series, cluttered the sculpture court with an impressive array of amplifiers to which were attached an electric flute, an electric clavinette, an electric guitar and a tape machine loaded with what might have been remnants of soundtracks from war movies.
Directors of Delta Air Lines, Inc., proposed yesterday a three-for-one stock split and an increase in the authorized common to 25 million shares from 8 million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that 65,000 men would be added to the South Vietnamese armed forces --not 55,000, as he said last week. He also indicated that the United States had agreed to equip them.
Spartans Industries, Inc., and Pueblo Supermarkets Inc., have terminated their negotiations for the acquisition of the HillKorvette supermarkets by Pueblo, the two concerns announced yesterday.
The election of John B. Henrich as executive vice president and general counsel of the National Lead Company was announced here yesterday.

Pan American World Airways said yesterday preliminary, unaudited results indicated net income in June of $10,255,000, or 31 cents a share, compared with $10,848,000, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company reported yesterday a decline in second-quarter share earnings despite increased revenues for the period. The quarterly report placed operating revenues at $133,398,885 for the three months ended June 30, compared with $124,987,909 a year earlier.
DETROIT, July 27 (AP)-- Auto production continued to fall this week as model changeover and the Detroit riots cut into assemblies.

AREA A--Excellent white marlin fishing has prevailed of the New Jersey coast. Sportsmen have been taking the billfish north of Barnegat Ridge, with some being landed farther south in the Five Fathom Bank area. Tuna fishing is reported as good off shore.
The Board of Estimate approved plans yesterday for a Williamsburg urban renewal project as Puerto Rican leaders contended thay had been discriminated against in the historic Brooklyn community.

Directors of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation and Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc., agreed in principle yesterday on a plan to merge the wholly owned Olin subsidiary, E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., with Beech-Nut.

MADRID, July 27--An accord to publish two manuscripts of Leonardo da Vinci belonging to the Spanish National Library was signed here today by the Spanish Government and two publishing companies, one American and one Spanish.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) --Representative Durward G. Hall, Republican of Missouri, called today for more responsibility on the part of news media in reporting racial disturbances.

WATERBURY, Conn., Friday July 28--Waterbury policemen used gas and warning shots last night to disperse Negro mobs that swarmed through the North Square section hurling bottles and rocks, smashing store windows and looting.

EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands, July 26--An unusual experiment in monastic life is being watched all over the Netherlands. With the approval Of the Dutch hierarchy, three former contemplative Trappists have cast away the life of the cloister to seek what they call "the reality of human existence in our fellow men, and in this reality to find God."
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 27--A 36-foot lapstrake sport fisherman named Sea Urchin, owned by Herbert Merrick, became the first winner of the plush New York Yacht Club cruise today.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- President Johnson announced tonight that he had named a special advisory commission to investigate the epidemic of racial disorders and to recommend remedial measures to him, Congress, governors and mayors.

Police patrols were increased in the midtown shopping area last night, particularly along Fifth Avenue, following the looting of two men's clothing stores on the avenue by a band of Negro youths Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)--The International Association of Fire Fighters, American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organization, asked today for legislation to make it a Federal Crime to interfere with firemen performing their duties.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 27-- Police Chief Brice G. Kinnamon announced that an unidentified Negro was arrested here this afternoon and charged with the attempted murder of a white city policeman during last Monday's wave of rioting and arson.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.8 on Wednesday from 96.9 on Tuesday.
Prices of wheat futures fell slightly in quiet trading at Chicago yesterday, just about erasing their gains of Wednesday's session, traders reported.
From its earliest day, our nation has been dedicated to justice, to equality--and to order.

HAVANA, July 26 (Reuters) --Cuba's 1967 sugar harvest has officially ended with a total yield of 6,128,287 tons--the third largest in Cuba's history. The harvest was the longest on record, lasting almost eight months.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned firmer in all sections yesterday despite a slight downturn near the close of trading.

Directed top Government officials to consider the request of Governor Romney of Michigan and Mayor Cavanagh of Detroit to declare Detroit a disaster area and make it eligible for Federal assistance; received credentials from the new Ambassadors of Togo and Rumania; participated in Defense Department cost reduction awards.

BALTIMORE, July 27 (UPI)-- Denny McLain, backed by Dick McAuliffe's homer and runscoring single, pitched a sevenhitter for his 12th victory tonight, as the Detroit Tigers downed the Baltimore Orioles, 4-0.

The New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday to suspend trading in the common stock of the First Western Financial Corporation, a deficitridden savings and loan holding company, and to delist its shares from the exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)--The Department of Commerce said today the economic data it had collected through June pointed clearly to the upturn predicted by President Johnson's advisers last January.
A new field in underwriting ocean marine insurance was opened yesterday when the Marine Insurance Office of America issued an "all risks" policy for a submarine.
Corporate income in the second quarter continued the downward trend of the first three months as more companies felt the effect of pressures on profit margins.
Too many audiences throughout the country are being shortchanged. Frederick O'Neal, president of Actors Equity Association, said yesterday.
The site of the last four brownstones on Central Park South was purchased yesterday by two investment builders who plan to erect a 24-story apartment house on it.
HOUSTON, July 27 (AP)-- Grady Hatton, the manager of the last-place Houston Astros of the National League, received a new one-year contract today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) --Fahran Ahubeilat, Jordan's ambassador to the United States, said today that he had been misrepresented in remarks concerning the circumstances under which Jordan and Israel could reach a peace settlement.
SANTA FE, N.M., July 27 (UPI)--The outdoor amphitheater home of the Santa Fe Opera, site of the American premiere of Paul Hindemith's "Cardillac" last night, burned to the ground early today.

MADRID, July 27--A defense involving the letter "i" may determine whether Fernando Arrabal, the Spanish playwright accused of "blasphemy" and "grave insults" against the state, will be acquitted or be condemned to years of imprisonment.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 27--Dr. and Mrs. Franz J. Ingelfinger of Cambridge and Ipswich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Ingelfinger, to Seth Tudor of Marlboro, Vt. He is the son of Mrs. Tasha Tudor of Webster, N.H.

For the 50th-anniversary season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, the Goldman Band and its conductor, Richard Franko Goldman, have been inviting American composers to appear as guest conductors of their own works.
The U.S. Smelting, Refining and Mining Company has purchased an option to acquire a controlling interest in the Cudahy Company.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27--There are "many major battles to come" in the Central Highlands, the departing commander of the American First Field Force said today.
The Chemway Corporation said yesterday its board had accepted the resignation of Louis E.S. Santamaria as president and a director effective Aug. 31. No reason was given for the resignation.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 (UPI)--Julius Boros, Ray Floyd and Dick Lotz carded two-under-par 70's over the rugged 7,200-yard Hazeltine National Golf Course today to share the first-round lead in the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic.

Stock prices continued to advance yesterday although some profit taking in the final minutes of the session trimmed earlier gains. Glamour issues, lower-priced issues and a sprinkling of blue chips were among the stocks that posted some of the strongest gains.
FORT ERIE, Canada, July 27 (AP)--A man who thought he had bet $100 on the favorite in the seventh race at Fort Erie race track yesterday collected $5,055 when a 49-1 shot won.

Miss Lorraine Filippone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Filippone of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Julian O. Standen, son of Mrs. Harold Hazelton of New York and Anthony Standen of New York and South Kent, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Robert Moher.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a new set of rules today governing the conduct of securities sellers who are not members of the National Association of Securities Dealers. The group outside the N.A.S.D. mainly includes mutual fund organizations that have their own sales forces.

The regional director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics declared yesterday that ghetto residents of New York and other major cities were the victims of social change on a scale as big as that of the Depression of the nineteen-thirties.
The Federal Reserve is pressing its policy of easy money, banking statistics issued yesterday indicated.

Mr. and Mrs. Philemon E. Truesdale 2d, of New York and Acoaxet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Truesdale, to Gordon G. Wisbach Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Gale Wisbach of Winchester, Mass.

BOSTON, July 27 (UPI)-- Third baseman Paul Schaal's error, with one out in the 10th inning, allowed Reggie Smith to score from third base today and give the Boston Red Sox a 6-5 victory over the California Angels. The game attracted 34,193, the largest Fenway Park crowd of the season.
ALBANY, Friday, July 28-- Negro youths rampaged through the capital city's ghetto section last night and early today smashing windows, stoning cars and setting fires.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27--Well-placed United States sources believe that major decisions on the war in Vietnam are unlikely to result from the current tour of President Johnson's two special representatives.
NEW CITY, N.Y., July 27-- Radio station WRKL, which was destroyed in a fire Saturday night only hours after it allowed a Negro militant to use its microphones, returned to the air today.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 28 (UPI)--Mrs. John F. Kennedy celebrated her 38th birthday today with a small party attended by relatives and friends.
WASHINGTON, July 28--Indications mounted today that President Johnson would send his tax increase message to Congress early next week.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)--The Chicago Dwelling Association will purchase the South Side apartment building that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. began remodeling 17 months ago as leader of the Chicago Freedom Movement.
BABYLON, L.I., July 28-- Bill Dickson of Orlando, Fla., had a second and a fourth today to capture the Y-Flyer Class national sailing championship.

WESTBURY, L.I, July 28 --The field for tomorrow night's Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway was reduced to seven starters today when the stewards ordered Starlight Way scratched. The mare is owned by Ira and Beverly Kristel of Valley Stream, L.I.
Rumors of lawlessness and impending violence--all of them unfounded--flew along the Eastern Seaboard from Albany to Atlanta yesterday on flapping tongues.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --The Treasury Department announced today the signing in Paris of a new income tax treaty between the United States and France.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP)--Harmon Killebrew hit his 30th homer and Dean Chance, a pitcher, contributed a rare hit tonight in a seven-run fourthinning rally that powered the Minnesota Twins to a 9-2 victory over Boston.

TRENTON, July 28--Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today an extensive new training program for the state and local police that will range from riot control and antisniper tactics to community relations and constitutional rights.

COCO Chanel did more than merely unveil her new col lection this week. She delivered herself of yet another blast at the miniskirted, ye-ye world she heartily dislikes, and Mrs. John F. Kennedy was among her targets.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 28-- The nation is short of papyrologists, and Princeton University is doing something about it.
LOS ANGELES, July 28-- The New York Mets have lost 603 games in their turbulent six-year career, but No. 603 may live longest in Met annals and in Wes Westrum's memory.

MANILA, Saturday, July 29 (AP)--Two special representatives of President Johnson landed unexpectedly at Clark Field in the Philippines early today after their jetliner lost the use of an engine on a flight from Bangkok, Thailand, to Canberra, Australia.
The Police Department announced yesterday that Deputy Commissioner Millard T. Meers, a special aide to the Commissioner on civil disobedience, had resigned for "personal reasons."

Governor Rockefeller yesterday joined Gov. John J. McKeithen of Louisiana in asking for a meeting of the National Governors Conference "to help stop the riots now sweeping the nation's racial ghettos and to prevent their recurrence."

FRANKFORT, Ky., July 28 (UPI)--The Kentucky Commission of Human Rights asked Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today to declare all apartment houses and trailer camps near Fort Knox and Fort Campbell that refuse to accom- modate Negroes "off limits" for rental purposes.
HONG KONG, July 28 (UPI) --American authorities have canceled a visit to Hong Kong by the aircraft carrier Constellation, a United States spokesman said today.

MONTREAL, July 28--The Summer National Cham- pionships of the American Contract Bridge League, which began here tonight at the Queen Elizabeth Hotel, will be attended by almost all the top-ranking players in the North American continent.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 28--Miss Carol T. Blakely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Paul Blakely, plans to be married tomorrow evening to Jonathan W. Kaplan, son of Dr. Milton A. Kaplan of New York and the late Mrs. Kaplan. Rabbi Harold L. Rubens will perform the ceremony at the Andrew Johnson Hotel.
DETROIT, July 28--They had slept on the blackened concrete for three and four days and the grease and grime was heavy in their clothing, but it made no difference.
MONTREAL, July 28 (Canadian Press)--A spokesman for five maritime unions said today that a nationwide shipping strike was a possibility.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 28--R.S. Garfield Todd, a Prime Minister of Rhodesia when it was still a British colony, warned today that the country's doom would be sealed if it chose apartheid, a separation of races on the South African pattern.
Frank Watson Luther, former director of the Chicago Opera, died yesterday at his home in Edgartown, Mass. He was 65 years old.
The new Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington will stand on four hollow legs and "float" 15 feet above a plaza.
ENUGU, Nigeria--Conceived in rebellion and plunged almost immediately into war, Africa's newest venture in nation-building appears to have withstood the first tests of infancy.

The National Broadcasting Company will televise tomorrow an hour's special on church services around the country where prayers of reconciliation will be offered in response to President Johnson's plea Thursday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Axelrod have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Eve Axelrod, to Peter Freeman Lemkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lemkin of New Haven.
BRUSSELS, July 27--When the African student walked into the Brussels bar late one night recently, the bartender stared hard and with unconcealed dislike, then slowly shook his head.
The American Stock Exchange ended a plus week with another advance yesterday in active trading.
The long-neglected grange country farmhouse of Alexander Hamilton, the nation's first Secretary of the Treasury, has been partly restored and is now open to the public.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)-- The Communications Satellite Corporation told the Federal Communications Commission today that it was prepared to finance, build and operate a pilot program in domestic communications service by satellite.

LONDON, July 28--It is a strange and unhappy fact that since Frederick Ashton became director of the Royal Ballet three years ago, he has produced only two works-- the very brief "Monotones," seen recently in New York, and "Sinfonietta," which has now had its London premiere at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. So niggardly an output gives his works a scarcity value at least. But, luckily, "Sinfonietta" has more to offer than that.

PARIS, July 28--Tourists used to detour through the village of Baignes to admire its Medieval covered markets. To provide them with parking space, the village fathers tore down the markets. Now there is plenty of space, but no tourism.

LONDON, July 28--Robert Willis, the only trade union leader on the Prices and Incomes Board, resigned today, charging that the hoard was "no longer an independent body" hut "merely a servant of certain ministers."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--San Francisco's two jointly owned major daily newspapers are seeking to damage suburban competitors through "an unlawful combination and conspiracy," a suburban publisher told a Senate subcommittee today.
Queen of the Stage, an unbeaten 2-year-old filly, and Straight Deal, a 5-year-old mare, are favored in the two $100,000 added races heading the national thoroughbred racing program today.
The four major lumber associations reported a drop of 4.7 per cent in production for the week ended July 22, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., July 28--Miss Mary Leslie Renchard, daughter of Mrs. Raymond L. Tyson and John V. Renchard, was married this afternoon to Henry Christopher Cashen 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Cashen. Both families are residents of Grosse Pointe.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP)-- Tony Horton's home run in the 12th inning tonight ended a tense pitching duel and gave the Cleveland Indians a 1-0 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles. Steve Hargan went the distance and held the losers to eight hits.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (UPI) --Special police riot squads were deployed to undisclosed locations today throughout the city, which is under an emergency proclamation restricting the movements of crowds.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Harris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilee Scott Harris, to Jeffrey Michael Twine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Twine. Both families are of Pound Ridge. A December wedding is planned.
HIRAM, Ohio, July 28 (AP)-- The Cleveland Browns recalled waivers on Jim Ninowski today. The quarterback hasn't reported to the club's training camp since it opened July 15.

CAMBRIDGE, Md" J22uly 28-- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew told a committee of city officials, white businessmen and moderate Negroes tonight that "this is a sick city" in which "segregation is completely obvious."
WASHINGTON, July 28-- The tiny cables that run from an electronic pacemaker into the human heart must withstand flexing with every beat, 100,000 times a day or more than 30 million times a year.
WHITE PLAINS, July 28-- Westchester County law enforcement agencies set up a pool of 3,496 men tonight to cope with widespread lawlessness and looting.
Revlon, Inc., has sold Royal Lynne, Ltd., a Hong Kong subsidiary which manufactures dresses, to Nathan Sheinman, president of the L.R. McMullin Company, a producer of dresses and sportswear.
The stock market continued to advance yesterday although profit taking and normal cau- tion before the weekend trimmed gains registered earlier in the session.

Frederick A. Dewey, an investment consultant and retired stockbroker and son of the late John Dewey, the educator and philosopher, died Thursday night at his home, 333 East 68th Street, after a short illness. He was 80 years old.
NEWARK, July 28--The state's Education Commissioner, Carl L. Marburger, visited four elementary schools in the predominantly Negro Central Ward today as part of a study of urban school problems.
The Army's Chief of Chaplains, Maj. Gen. Charles E. Brown Jr., received a 13-gun salute and conducted his last formal review of the troops on the parade ground of Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn yesterday.

A national covocation on the problems of cities will be planned Monday night in Washington at a meeting of 20 prominent Americans, including Henry Ford 2d, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., David Rockefeller, George Meany and Walter P. Reuther.
Placed side by side, two sets of casualty figures for the past week make revealing, sorrowful reading about the subjects of deepest concern to the United States Government and people, summer '67.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28-- The new Premier of Iraq announced tonight that his Government would seek increased royalties from "foreign oil companies" that extracted and sold Iraqi oil.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --The Government announced today that it had seized 48 cases of A food product called "Noodle-Roni Chick'n Almonds."
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) --President Johnson today reappointed William Walton, an artist who was a friend of President Kennedy, as a member of the Commission of Fine Arts.
GREAT NECK, L.I., July 28-Miss Dale Carol Kleinman and Fred Michael Berman plan to marry here at Temple Israel on Aug. 27.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 28 --The houses in Levittown have changed in appearance, but the people moving in still resemble the young couples who first came there in 1947 looking for more space fort their growing families.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- Americans may suffer 14,000 rat bites a year and may lose a billion dollars annually in damage to food and goods.

The Transamerica Corporation, which earlier this year acquired the United Artists Corporation in a $130-million deal, is further diversifying its activities with plans to enter the business of leasing and servicing data-processing equipment.

The Ford Motor Company's second-quarter net income dropped 32.5 per cent to $146.5million, or $1.34 a share, from the record $216.9-million, or $1.97 a share, earned in the year-earlier period, the report disclosed yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (UPI) --Julius Boros posted a secondround 72 today and led in the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic with a two-under-par 142. After 36 holes, he was first by a stroke.

President Johnson's response to the crisis in the cities is reasonable and constructive so far as it goes, but it does not go far enough. Mr. Johnson's television address night before last lacked the sense of urgency and the clear call for prompt, positive action on a broad front that the nation had a right to expect from its leader in what the President himself described as "a time of violence and tragedy."
CONCEPCION, Chile, July 28 (AP)--Chilean authorities have begun police and legal measures to stamp out guerrilla bands and Communist youth movements calling for the overthrow of the Government.
Gabriel Vole, a shy, hazeleyed man of 21, rose at 7 A.M, yesterday after only four hours of sleep to taste hamburger and a milk shake and to see Broadway come to life.
The city's plan for a showcase containership port on the eastern shore of Staten Island has hit a engineering snag that will require alteration of plans, it was disclosed yesterday.
PORTILLO, Chile--There are a couple of things, besides the excellent skiing, that North Americans who come to Portillo find gratifying.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28-- The Latin-American Solidarity Organization meeting next week in Havana under the aegis of Premier Fidel Castro raises again for South America one of the decade's most bedeviling questions--the depth of the influence of Cuba and her leaders on the rest of the hemi

WINNEPEG, Man., July 28 (AP)--Herb FitzGibbon, a former captain of the Princeton tennis team, upset Brazil's international star, Edison Mandarino, 6-2, 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the Pan-American Games semifinals today, but Arthur Ashe of Richmond was beaten by Thomas Koch, another Brazilian, in a match that lasted 3 hours 15 minutes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) --A Common Pleas Court judge enjoined a Negro leader, Cecil B. Moore, today from holding street corner rallies or demonstrations any place in the city.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- President Johnson will tell his new advisory commission on civil disorders what he expects of it when it holds its first meeting tomorrow at the White House.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --Young Negroes of the Neighborhood Youth Corps won high praise from Detroit and Newark police officials for their work during the height of rioting in those cities, a Department of Labor report says.

ROME, July 28--The "Madonna of Cossito," an early 13th-century painting described as a priceless example of the Roman school, has been recovered in a Swiss villa three years after being stolen from an Italian church.

Power, a trade magazine published for the electrical utility industry by McGraw-Hill, contains in its August issue an editorial applauding the Consolidated Edison Company's announced intention of studying the feasibility of an underground nuclear power plant in New York City, The editorial says in part:

OTTAWA, July 28 (AP)-- Delegates to the American Newspaper Guild convention criticized alternately the Central Intelligence Agency and each other last night before voting 2 to 1 to seek a link with another United States Government agency. The key vote was 263-134.
LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) --A British television sketch that poked fun at President de Gaulle drew a telephoned protest from the French Embassy today.
BRUSSELS, July 28--The Government of Premier Paul Vanden Boeynants decided today to trim Belgian military and technical assistance to the Congo.

CHICAGO, July 28--Gov. Otto Kerner pledged today that the 11-member Presidential commission to investigate urban rioting would conduct a thorough study, hear both sides, and offer recommendations by Jan. 1.

MIAMI BEACH, Saturday, July 28 (AP)--A recommendation that the Republican party bring its 1968 Presidential nominating convention to Miami Beach was announced early today by the party's site selection committee.
Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday the first of his bills providing for a sweeping reorganization of the executive branch of the municipal government.
British Petroleum has announced plans to build a $12.3million harbor site area capable of accommodating tankers of more than 200,000 deadweight tons at Europoort, the Netherlands.
"To the sons of famous stars: Why don't you try struggling for a change?"

HANOI, July 28 (Agence France-Presse)--Newspapers here today gave front-page coverage to a South Vietnamese National Liberation Front (Viet Cong) statement "vigorously condemning the barbarous regime of racial discrimination" and the "bloody repression" of Negroes in the United States.
A fireman, lowered on a rope, rescued two house painters clinging to a scaffold yesterday by pushing them to windows into the hands of waiting firemen and policemen.
A SELECTION from Cooper Union's unusual collec- tion of decorative arts is being exhibited this summer at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 28 (UPI)--A three-judge Federal court ordered the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to continue Federal aid to all Alabama schools and served notice that the courts, not the agency, would enforce desegregation orders.

PARIS, July 28--Pierre Cardin doesn't have to be a rebel anymore because he is too famous and too influential. It is almost a pity. His new fall-winter collection today shows how Cardin is evolving. The Cardin revolution is over.
Pearl Bailey said "Hello, David!" only once before she got the leading role in David Merrick's proposed production of "Hello, Dolly!" with a Negro cast.
HONG KONG, July 28--Terrorism has become the recourse of Communists here following their failure to score notable victories with demonstrations, riots and strikes.

It will be getaway day at the Big A today, and the Tidal Handicap will serve as the feature. The regular Aqueduct Saturday crowd of about 48,000 is expected to bid a temporary farewell to the thoroughbreds, who will transfer for the next four weeks to Saratoga Springs. They return here on Aug. 28 and will remain until well into December.

The Admiral Corporation yesterday joined the ranks of color-television set makers hard hit by softness in sales, Ross D. Siragusa, chairman, said preliminary figures showed his company would report a second-quarter operating loss of "approximately $3-million." A
LOS ANGELES, July 28-- Claude Osteen of the Los Angeles Dodgers shut out the New York Mets on seven hits tonight, 2-0, and dropped them into the National League cellar.
SAN DIEGO, July 28 (AP)-- The threat of permanent injury forced Paul Hornung to retire from professional football today.

MOSCOW, July 28--Senior diplomats in Moscow, including Arabs, as well as informed Russian observers think that the Soviet Union remains determined to prevent a resumption of fighting in the Middle East, despite its failure to advance a settlement by diplomatic means in the United Nations.

FLEETWOOD, N.Y., July 28--Mr, and Mrs. William Barrie Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Lynn Miller, to Spencer William Frank Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank of New York.
Prices of wheat for future delivery continued to march downward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn was down slightly and oats and soybeans were mixed.

The bond market closed the week yesterday on an encouraging note. A $150-million debenture offering by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation reached the market at 100 and was quickly snapped up by investors. By the end of the day the debentures were quoted at 100 bid, 100 asked.

LONDON, July 28--Robert shaw, the actor and novelist, made his debut as a dramatist last night with an adaptation of his novel "The Man in the Glass Booth." In this initial effort, Mr. Shaw has delivered a fascinating it enigmatic play that benefits from the exacting direction of a fellow playwright, Harold Pinter, and from a masterly performance by Donald Pleasance in its central role.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. William D. Kiley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Cannon Kiley, to Lieut. Donato A. Strammiello, U.S.A.F., son of Mrs. Donato Strammiello of Hartford and the late Mr. Strammiello.

New York State is the only state that has embedded in its Constitution a provision requiring that children who are being adopted must be placed, when practicable, with parents of the same religious persuasion as themselves. We believe that this provision should be deleted from any new or revised Constitution.

GLEN COVE, L.I. July 28-- Pete Bostwick Jr., using the croquet-putting style that is soon to be banned under the new rules of the United States Golf Association, will meet John Baldwin tomorrow in an all-Long Island final of the New York State amateur championship.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 28-- (AP)--The Turkish Army marshaled a fleet of helicopters today to fly supplies to victims of Turkey's most recent earthquake. The quake hit Wednesday night, and new tremors shuddered across the country late yesterday as the death toll mounted.

JERUSALEM, July 28--Israeli authorities are preparing to tighten their administration of the west bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip in response to growing opposition and civil disobedience in these areas.

HOUSTON, July 28 (AP)-- Rusty Staub, the National League's leading hitter, knocked in four runs with a double and single tonight, pacing the Houston Astros to a 9-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. Staub raised his batting average to 360.
The Police Department has directed precincts in areas with heavy Spanish-speaking populations to assign one Spanishspeaking policeman to every radio car on patrol.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP)-- Bora Kostic scored the deciding goal in the 88th minute of play as the St. Louis Stars defeated the New York Generals, 3-2, tonight. The National Professional Soccer League game was marred by a second-half fight.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28-- Fog and faint airs proved to be an unbeatable combination for the sailing craft involved in the New York Yacht Club cruise today.
When the habit on Wall Street changes from flannel gray to seersucker blue, the means of commuting for many changes, too--from subways and trains to car pools and airplanes.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)--Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson is considering plans to tape-record for history information about the President's birthplace near their Johnson City ranch. Mrs. Elizabeth Carpenter, the First Lady's press secretary, said today the tapes would be similar to those done by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt about Hyde Park, N.Y., where President Roosevelt lived for many years.

TOKYO, July 28--Japan's two leading newspapers, the multimillion circulation Asahi and Mainichi, commenting today on the recent racial violence in the United States for the first time, linked the outbreaks to American Negro dissatisfaction over heavy expenditures on the war in Vietnam while poverty continues at home.
Eighty businesses in one of the city's largest industrial buildings were saved yesterday from having their telephone service cut off in a dispute involving their landlords and the telephone company.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that a study it made of the Job Corpse indicated the antipoverty agency was failing to put people in the jobs it trained them for.
Lillian Moore, the country's leading dance historian, died of cancer yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 55 years old and lived at 406 West 46th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--The United States is quietly advising the Government of the Congo that it would be a great mistake to execute former Premier Moise Tshombe if he is extradited from Algeria.
PARIS, July 28--President de Gaulle's visit to Quebec was a success because it brought the problem of French Canadians to world attention, the Government argued today.

STOCKHOLM, July 28--The Volvo automobile concern of Sweden was criticized today for not introducing its exhaust fume cleaning system in Sweden. All cars exported to the United States beginning with the 1968 models, must be equipped with this device.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 28-- A 61-year-old woman lay bound and gagged for 10 and a half hours last night and early today after two burglars robbed her of $67,450 in cash and diamonds.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city would install floodlights at five playing fields in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx "as part of the continuing drive to give youngsters from poverty neighborhoods a full range of recreational opportunities."
PARIS, July 28--The leading spokesman for United States airlines suggested today that fares on supersonic planes should be set 25 per cent above those on subsonic jets.
PARIS, July 28 (AP)--Raoul Praxy, actor and playwright, died here today. He was 75 years old.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 28 (Agence France-Presse)-- North Vietnam denounced today with the "utmost vigor" what it called the "savage crimes" committed by American B-52 bombers in recent raids on the demilitarized zone and the area just north of it.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) --Vacationing medical volunteers with rapid-firing inoculation guns will leave for Costa Rica next week to immunize virtually the entire country and help check the spread of disease throughout Central America.
WHEN Scurry-Rainbow Oil, Ltd., was announcing im- portant mineral discoveries at Otter Lake last month, some of its executives were trading in the company's stock, it was disclosed yesterday.
ROME, July 28--Prof. Evaristo Breccia a noted archeologist, died here this morning after a fall from the window of his sixth floor apartment. He was 91 years old.
A 17-year-old youth was held In $1,500 ball yesterday on charges of raping two girls, 10 and 12.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28--South Vietnam accused Cambodia today of allowing her territory to be used by Vietcong and North Vietnamese forces "as a base for reprovisioning and regrouping."
JERUSALEM, July 28--Abie Nathan, Israel's self-appointed peace pilot, returned to Israel tonight after a second fruitless flight to the United Arab Republic in 17 months.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 28 (UPI)--Gov. Ronald Reagan signed today a bill outlawing the carrying of a loaded weapon in a city.

AMERSFOORT, the Netherlands, July 28 (AP)--Ray Rogers, a Cherokee Indian from Muskogee, Okla., won the individual championship and led the American men to the team title today in the world archery championships.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 29--The loss of seven American planes and a helicopter over North Vietnam was announced yesterday.

DARMSTADT, Germany, July 28 (Reuters)--Four former Nazi secret policemen received prison sentences here today ranging from three years to life for their part in the wartime murder of the Jewish population of Kolomyya, Poland.
Strong competition by independent steamship lines in the Far East trades has forced two steamship conferences to adopt the dual-rate system.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 28-- Governor Rockefeller appealed today to Republican women leaders to take the lead in lining up grass-roots support for his $2.5-billion state transportation bond issue.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28 --Jorge Velasquez, the nation's leading jockey, today broke the Monmouth Park riding record of 81 victories established by Sam Boulmetis in 1955.

Administration of the hallucinogenic drug LSD to pregnant rats resulted in a high percentage of stillborn, stunted young, a New York researcher reported yesterday.
DETROIT, July 28--The first of the military and state police forces patrolling riot-damaged Detroit were withdrawn today as incidents of sniping and fires continued to decrease.
A device that is designed to help a pilot follow a predetermined path of ascent or descent in airport areas has been developed and tested by Pan American World Airways, the airline said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28--The prospect of producing substantially more effective vaccines against many disease-causing viruses is being raised by new developments in advanced centrifuge design.
HANOVER, N.H., July 28 (AP)--Alvin F. Julian, Dartmouth's basketball coach for 17 years, died today at a nursing home in nearby White River Junction, Vt., He was 66 years old.

NEW ORLEANS, July 28 (AP) --The State Supreme Court stepped in hours before the Orleans Parish County Grand jury convened today and stayed a subpoena ordering a television newsman to appear for questioning.

ROSWELL, N.M., July 28 (AP)--A balloon taller than the Washington Monument soared 129,000 feet above the White Sands missile range today in a test connected with the proposed space shot to Mars in the nineteen-seventies.

Tenneco, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for both the second quarter and first half. Tenneco is a diversified company with major interests in oil, natural gas transportation, chemicals and packaging.
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 28 (UPI)--Anguilla appeared ready today to end its attempt to quit the British-sponsored federation of St. KittsNevis-Anguilla.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. David Schaps have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Schaps, to Joseph Rascoff. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Rascoff of Neponsit, Queens, New York, and the late Dr. Rascoff, who was a physician.
The United States Gypsum Company announced yesterday the election of Charles E. Dykes to the new post of financial vice president.
The New York Stock Exchange has imposed 100 per cent margin restrictions on three common stocks in the first such official action taken on Big Board securities since the spring of 1966.

MADRID, July 28--Spain's Vice President, Capt. Gen. Agustin Munoz Grandes, was relieved of his post today by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- The widespread racial rioting in American cities has exposed two military weaknesses and has cast doubt on some of the Pentagon's policies, some officers say.

Kornel C. Berger, president and founder of Berger Indus tries, Inc., a diversified metal working and steel tube manufacturing concern, died on Thursday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 80-55 Park Lane, Kew Gardens, Queens.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 28 --LeRoy H. Kurtz, who retired in 1959 as business manager of the public relations staff of the General Motors Corporation, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack in his home at 240 Rockingstone Avenue, His age was 72.

With the Government's reinstatement of the investment tax credit in June, the railroads placed orders for 11,449 new freight cars, a 61 per cent increase over the 7,090 cars ordered in June of last year, according to a joint announcement yesterday by the American Railway Car Institute and the Association of American Railroads.

A plan to call a conference within two weeks of the 2,000 Neighborhood Youth Corps workers who are scattered through some 100 East Harlem neighborhood organizations was approved yesterday at a meeting of youth workers.

PRAGUE, July 28 (Reuters) --The Government tonight protested sharply to Communist China against a demonstration outside the Czechoslovak Embassy in Peking today during which Red Guards accused Czechoslovakia of "revisionism," or modification of Marxist-Leninist doctrine.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were quietly firm yesterday on modest and selective demand.

ATLANTA, July 28 (UPI)-- Orlando Cepeda knocked in three runs with two homers and a single and Dal Maxvill drove in three more tonight to pace the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

DeWitt C. Baker will succeed Albert Leventhal as president and general manager of Golden Press, Inc., a subsidiary of Western Publishing Company. The appointment of Mr. Baker was announced yesterday in Racine, Wis., at Western's headquarters.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. Charles W.B. Wardell Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Talbot Wardell, to Larry Lee Chamberlin. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arlie Harris Chamberlin Jr. of Memphis. The wedding is planned for Oct. 7 at Christ Episcopal Church, in Oyster Bay.

Reports that the City Investing Company plans to merge soon with Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer, Inc., the motion-picture producer, were emphatically denied yesterday by George T. Schaffenberger, president and chief executive officer of City Investing.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark has, without fanfare, given lawyers at the Department of Justice permission to moonlight as volunteer attorneys for the poor, delegates to the Federal Bar Association were told here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (AP)--Juan Marichal ended a three-week victory famine and Willie McCovey and Tom Haller each drove in two runs tonight as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2.
A Harlem hardware dealer was shot and killed yesterday white chasing two robbers from his store at 2168 Eighth Avenue near West 117th Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 29--A raging fire, set off by an explosion, broke out on the flight deck of the giant United States aircraft carrier Forrestal off North Vietnam today, the Navy reported.

DURING the hot summer months, an electric blender can reduce the physical effort of cooking by taking over such kitchen chores as chopping, stirring, grinding and sieving. The appliance is used in those of the recipes on the following summer brunch or lunch menu.

The Jewish Family Service, a family counseling agency, and the Family Location Service, which deals with socio-legal aspects of family problems, have consolidated, it was announced yesterday. The joint agency will be called the Jewish Family Service.

VENICE, Italy, July 28 (Reuters)--Italian port authorities at Porto Marghera near here cordoned off two Chinese ships today because, they said, their crews were spreading Chinese) Communist propaganda.

Lionel Marks, vice president of Hedges Butler, Ltd., importers of wines and liquors, and a former president of William Jameson Co., Irish whiskey importers, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 65.

The Museum of Modern Art has received a gift of 27 foreign films that were distributed in the United States by Janus Films. The Janus donation is one of the largest ever made to the museum's archives.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 29 The Princeton University Chapel was the setting tonight for the marriage of Miss Linda Joyce Almgren, daughter of Mrs. Wright Almgren, to Milford Burton Kime. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Milford Kime of Glen Ridge.

HOUSTON, July 29 (AP) Jim Wynn of the Houston Astros, the National League's runs-batted-in leader, was sent to a hospital today after colliding with a teammate, Rusty Staub, in the sixth inning of the Astros' game against Pittsburgh.

PARIS The Jardin des Plantes, off the Quai St. Bernard on the Left Bank, is not merely the botanical garden of the French capital. It is a park for all seasons, where the visitor can stroll among some of the oldest trees on the Continent and admire the latest in dahllas, irises and roses.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 29 Jerry Crawford of Bow, N.H., scored his third straight sports car racing victory here today. It was an all-the-way in front performance in a 15-lap contest for Area 1 championship points and was run over Lime Rock's 1.5-mile course.

HARRISBURGH, Pa., July 30-- Jasper Deeter took the stage of the Harrisburgh Community Theater last night to reminisce about an old friend named Eugene O'Neil.

New York police handling of last week's Puerto Rican disorders got generally good marks yesterday at a lawyers' public hearing in East Harlem and in a separate interview with Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 30 --Robert O'Connor of the Niantic Yacht Club won the Lightning Class Eastern Connecticut Area championship of the Yacht Racing Association today as the annual two-day regatta ended off the Black Rock Yacht Club.

Mayor Lindsay's proposal to compromise away much of the stock transfer tax represents a peace offering to the New York Stock Exchange. In proffering it, the Mayor obviously expects the Exchange in turn to end its threat to depart from the city. He also intends by this goodwill gesture to demonstrate that his administration is anxious to improve its relations with the business community.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 30--Secretary General Thant warned tonight against viewing the fighting in Vietnam as an anti-Communist "holy war."

Mrs. Evelyn Olliphant de Seversky, wife of Alexander P. de Seversky, the aeronautical engineer and designer, herself well-known as a pilot, died Fri- day of a heart ailment in her country home at Asharoken Beach, Northport, L.I. She was 60 years old and lived here at 40 Central Park South.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The Defense Department has apparently been subsidizing the interest rates on its arms sale loans to underdeveloped countries by charging the recipients lower rates than it pays to the Export-Import Bank for money it borrows.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 30 (UPI)--Greek and Turkish Cypriotes fought last night and early today with rifles and submachine guns. A United Nations force stopped the clash.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (UPI)--Ted Abernathy came out of the bull pen to stamp out a Chicago threat in the eighth inning and preserve a 3-2 victory for the Cincinnati Reds today after the Cubs had won the opener, 8-4, with a 15-hit barrage.

PARIS, July 30--Roberto Capucci looks like a melancholy teen-ager--not a grown-up de- signer with a couture house here on Rue Cambon. The older, grander men in the French haute couture probably don't even know Capucci's name, and they certainly don't consider him competition.
Agnes de Mille will supervise the choreography and staging of "Come Summer," a musical with a 19th-century New England background. It will be her first new Broadway show since "Kwamina" in 1961.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 30-- Thursday and Friday nights, gangs of young Negroes ran through the streets of this city, smashing store windows in hit-and-run tactics and throwing fire bombs into several shops.
HARRISON, N.Y., July 30-- Alan Corey 3d and Russell Corey combined for nine goals today as the Long Island team routed Greenwich, 11-5, at Blind Brook Polo Club.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 30 (UPI)--Clifford Ann Creed made five birdies and her partner, Margie Masters, did some masterful putting today as they won the $25,000 Yankee open team golf tournament by two strokes.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 30-- Dean Ince of the host Bellport Bay Yacht Club completed a sweep of the four races in the Mini-cat division of the national multi-hull class sailing championships today and won three trophies. He took over-all and handicap honors as well as the award for skippering the top California cat.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (AP)--Vern Law recorded his first victory of the season today as the Pittsburgh Pirates edged the San Francisco Giants, 4-3 and snapped a three-game losing string.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (UPI) --Lou Johnson broke up a scoreless game in the eighth inning today, by hitting a home run off Chris Short to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. It was the fourth straight triumph for the Dodgers.

SALVATORE MATERA, a 16-year-old junior at Brooklyn Preparatory School, won the recent second annual United States Invitational Junior Chess Championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel, scoring 5 -1 to top an eight-man round robin.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP)--The Philadelphia Spartans tied Atlanta, 1-1, today on Jose Vidal's late goal in a National Professional Soccer League game. The visitor's score had come at 8:31 of the second period on a hard shot by Emmett Kapengwe of Zambia.

BETHANY, Conn., July 30-- Ch. Norhaven's Gladiator, a 2 year-old fawn and white boxer owned by Houston B. and Elizabeth L. Marshall of Pittsburgh, was named best in show today at the 47th annual Elm City Kennel Club dog show at the Bethway Kennels show grounds. There were 738 dogs in the show.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 30--Rescue workers with earth-moving equipment sifted through tons of debris today for additional victims of the three earthquakes that rocked Caracas last night.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 30-- Two sets down and his hopes apparently near extinction as he stood at 4-all and 0-40 on his service in the third, Cliff Drysdale won the acclaim of 2,500 fans at the Merion Cricket Club today as he fought off Clark Graebner in a highly entertaining three-hour final for the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship. TROY, N.Y., July 30--Dr. William J. Ryan, who retired in 1960 as a history and economics teacher at Boys High School in Brooklyn, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Poestenkill.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 30-- Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., a 37-year-old stock broker, won the United States clay-court tennis championship for men 35 years old and over today by scoring his second upset victory in two days.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- When the mutual fund industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission square off in public tomorrow for their fight over legislation reducing mutual fund charges to investors, almost all of those involved on both sides will be taking positions they know have no chance for adoption.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 30 --There is nothing very radical about John Houseman's new production of "Macbeth," which opened this afternoon at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater. There is nothing very interesting about it either.

ATLANTA, July 30 (UPI)-- Roger Maris's two-run single in the seventh inning helped the St. Louis Cardinals to score a 7-5 victory today over the Atlanta Braves.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30--The annual meeting at the Saratoga Race Track will start tomorrow and continue through 24 racing days. The sport will then return to Aqueduct to run out the remainder of the season. But right now the thoughts of the thoroughbred world generally are on the Spa.

EDMONTON, Alberta--Canadian oil production fans out from the boom- ing central Alberta city of Edmonton, and oilmen are talking about the prolific discoveries around Rainbow Lake and Zama Lake, several hundred miles northwest of here, and about the startup of commercial production at the Athabasca tar sands to the northeast.

HAVANA, July 30--The Cubans have their problems, but they are making progress. The standard of living in the Cuban countryside does not seem to have changed much in recent years, but the standard of education and the standard of health have obviously improved.

CENTRAL CITY, Colo., July 30--A series of high-pitched yelps broke out promptly at 8 o'clock last night in this authentically restored, tiny, 19th-century mining town, 8,500 feet up in the Rocky Mountains.

LONDON, July 30--In the 18 years since Anton Dolin and Alicia Markova founded London's Festival Ballet, it has had many good dancers, but very few good ballets. WESTERLY, R.I., July 30 (AP)--Waldo J. Kindig, former principal of Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, N.J., died of a heart attack here yesterday. EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30--One of eastern Long Island's 10 windmills will provide the setting for this year's Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue fashion show for the benefit of East Hampton's Guild Hall on Thursday at 4 P.M. Net income of the Bendix Corporation in the June quarter amounted to $9,686,307, or 80 cents a share, compared with $9,445,148, or 80 cents a share, in the same period last year, A.P. Fontaine, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

Graham, pastor of Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church, Sedgwick Avenue, near Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, and former master of ceremonies at St. Patrick's Cathedral, died Saturday in Neptune, N.J. MOORESTOWN, N.J., July 30--Thomas W. Massoth, a divisional vice president for ad- ministrative services of the Radio Corporation of America, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 227 East Oak Avenue. He was 62 years old.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., July 30--Miss Gail Eve Sanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maury D. Sanger of Brooklyn and Atlantic Beach was married this evening to Richard Eric Halperin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Halperin of South Salem, N.Y., and Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, July 30-- Miss Susan Gail Kobren, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Kobren, was married today in the White Plains Hotel to Dr. Murray Allan Morrison, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin G. Morrison of Northampton, Mass. Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz performed the ceremony.

George of Delmar, N.Y. The Rev. Michael J. Phillips performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30--A battalion of marines was ambushed yesterday as it was withdrawing from a sweep into the demilitarized zone. An official spokesman said 23 men had been killed and 191 wounded.
