Brig. Gen. Austin J. Montgomery, commander of the Eastern Area of the Military Traffic Management and Terminal Service, will retire today in a change-of-command ceremony at 3 P.M. on the Brooklyn Military Ocean Terminal's parade grounds at 58th Street and 1st Avenue.

LANGHORNE, Pa., July 30-- Two world speed records and a spectacular second-lap accident that put six cars out of action and sent Arnie Knepper of Belleview, Ill., to the hospital with severe burns highlighted the 150-mile race for Indianapolis cars today.

In a major economic "white paper," the American Bankers Association warned yesterday that, unless the United States eliminated the deficit in its balance of international payments, it might well be faced with the alternatives of either devaluing the dollar or placing an embargo on sales of gold to foreign governments.

Matti Haim, dancer and choreographer, who had conducted her School of Contemporary Dance here until recently, died Saturday in New York Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived at 1005 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

GROUTVILLE, South Africa July 30 (AP)--Cries of "Uhuru!" ("Freedom!") echoed through the cane-lined valley of the Umvoti River today as thousands of Africans paid a last tribute to Albert John Luthuli.
HONG KONG, Monday, July 31--Peking reported yesterday that the Chinese Communist Army was undergoing a severe purge.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $250million debenture sale tomorrow morning is likely to establish the trend of interest rates this week, if not this month.
DETROIT, July 30 (UPI)-- Gov. George Romney said tonight that the rioting in Detroit last week was triggered by national conditions that could plunge the United States into "civil guerrilla warfare."
Commuters who drive to and from Manhattan are being bogged down in more and longer traffic tie-ups by construction on highway projects.
Striking Welfare Department caseworkers voted last night to accept a mediator's proposals and to end their sixweek-old stoppage tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Mrs. Thomas Bradley Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Woodworth Bradley, to Ramsay Watson Vehslage of New York. He is the son of Mrs. John Van Pelt of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Frank Clinton Vehslage. An October Wedding is planned.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 (UPI) --Lou Graham of Nashville fought off a final-round challenge by Bob Verwey of South Africa today to win the $100,000 Minnesota golf classic, the first victory of his pro career, by one stroke.

ANCHORAGE, July 30 (AP)-- The bodies of two more climbers were, found late yesterday on Mount McKinley in addition to the one found earlier, but a "whiteout" today near the top of the 20,320-foot peak stalled the search for the four men still missing.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The executive branch was accused by a Congressional committee today of wasting billions of dollars by loose management of the Government's vast operations.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 30--Dennis W. Powers of Glen Cove, L.I., sailing Piper, Edward F. Kroepke's International Class sloop, won the 11th annual Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Cable and Anchor Reef overnight race today for one design sloops.

Most of the nation's psychiatrists and psychotherapists began a month of sunning, swimming and sightseeing last weekend at the start of their traditional August vacation. They left behind patients who feel deserted, rejected, anxious, angry --or, sometimes, relieved.
The election of H. Robert Kobrick to the new post of executive vice president of the Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation was announced over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, July 30--Six prominent American physicians and surgeons have left for South Vietnam to conduct a three-week to four-week survey of civilian medical needs.

MOSCOW, July 30, (UPI)--A demand by a Chilean Communist leader that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba stop meddling in the revolutionary affairs of other Latin-American nations was published today in the Soviet Union.

WHEATLEY HILLS, L.I., July 30--Mrs. Joseph Cotter rose at 4:30 this morning, hurried to Belmont Park, where she worked a string of race horses, then went to the Meadow Brook Hounds horse show, where she piloted Murmansk Run to the green working hunter championship.
The retail industry's view of its role in the riot-torn areas of the country is that it should look to the long-term positive aspect, rather than fret over damage and looting

BOSTON, July 30 (AP)--The executive board of the National League of Cities adopted a resolution today calling on all citizens and all levels of government to work together to end rioting and the cause of rioting in cities.

WINNIPEG, Mon., July 30 (UPI)--One runner, Lee Evans, and two swimmers, Claudia Kolb and Gregory Charlton, turned in world-record performances today to lead the United States in near-sweeps of track and swimming on a Pan-American Games day marked by a dispute over a "wrong-way" walker.

Two weeks after the Monkees set a new decibel record there, the Supremes and the Four Tops went to the Forest Hills Stadium, out-lasting the Saturday-night showers, and whipping up quite a storm of their own. They drew a full and enthusiastic house, and if the crowd was screaming less, it could have been because it was listening more.
This summer a considerable number of beach swimmers-- most of them children--will be drowned because they do not know the simple rules for escaping a rip current.

MARY QUANT, that doyenne of English mod designers, now has a shop named after her at Bloomingdale's where her dresses, coats, raincoats, hats, boots and shoes are being shown along with her new line of cosmetics.
HOUSTON, July 30--The New York Mets lost their fourth and fifth straight games today and sank deeper into the National League cellar when the Houston Astros swept a double-header, 6-5 and 9-1.

BALTIMORE, July 30 (AP)-- George Kirby scored a goal with 3 minutes 11 seconds remaining tonight and earned the New York Generals a 3-3 tie in a National Professional Soccer League match with the Baltimore Bays.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Two Senators who have strongly supported the Federal campaign for highway safety said today they had been unable to find out from the auto industry how much consumers would have to pay for safety improvements on 1968-model cars.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 --When Ronald Reagan won the governorship by a millionvote margin last November, Californians almost wrote off Senator Thomas H. Kuchel's chances of re-election to a third full term in 1968.
Chris W. Kentera, executive editor of the social sciences and humanities division of Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, Inc., will become director of the New York University Press on Sept. 1.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 30 --One person was killed and nearly 100 were injured, some seriously, in an earthquake early today that centered on the Adapazari area 100 miles east of Istanbul.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)--Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent brought their infant son, Patrick Lyndon, to the White House tonight.
CARACAS, July 30 (AP)-- Hardest hit in Caracas was the eastern residential section of Altamira, where five apartment buildings collapsed. One was 16 stories high.

An agreement to reduce the number of post office trucks and trailers parked in Manhattan's garment district during the day was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and New York Postmaster John R. Strachan.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Three high Administration officials have told Senators that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union will consider negotiations for mutual troop reductions in Europe while the Vietnam war continues.
Black Apartheid has emerged as a major force in American life for the first time this summer. It it grows stronger, it could even become a threat to the persistence of a united United States.

Amid bats, gnats and weak opponents, the New York Yankees enjoyed a successful Sunday at Yankee Stadium yesterday as they swept a double-header from Kansas City, 7-2 and 5-2, before a crowd of 50,013.

COPENHAGEN, July 30 (AP) --Douglas Revson, an American sports car driver, was one of two men killed today when his Brabham car spun off the Ring Djursland course in Jutland and crashed into a group of 10 officials during a trial run.

Thirty persons were injured early yesterday when a Public Service Consolidated Transport Company bus from Jersey City crashed into the back of another bus at the Queens entrance of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.

PADANARAM, Mass., July 30--The main development among the sailing craft engaged in the annual New York Yacht Club cruise today was a transfer of the Queen's Cup, the most distinguished prize of the event, from the originally announced yacht to the correct winner of yesterday's race off Newport.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) --The United States Chamber of Commerce urged the House today to limit any increase in Social Security benefits this year to an 8 per cent cost-ofliving rise.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP)-- Federal paratroopers withdrew today from Detroit's riot areas.

Responding to criticism from senator George McGovern, who argues that "it doesn't make any sense" to curtail food production while people go hungry at home and abroad, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman declared the other day that the recently reduced wheat acreage allotments are adequate to meet "careful estimates of effective demand." The Secretary's reply does not really answer the Senator's question. The pertinent phrase is "effective demand."
PITTSBURGH, July 30--The start of a steel recovery was indicated last week.
WASHINGTON, July 30--Representative Wilbur Mills, long a champion of reduced trade barriers, has introduced three pieces of protectionist legislation in the House.

TEL AVIV, July 30--Israel's economic planning authority has called for large-scale public works and measures to provide a flow of cash in the former Jordanian area west of the Jordan River to forestall a crisis.
CANADIANS are disappointed, and a few are bitter. Latin-Americans are furious. Even some Americans say if we can't do things right, we should forget the whole thing.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP)-- Dave May's first major league homer--a two-run shot in the first inning--paced the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over Cleveland today after the Indians had taken the first game of the double-header, 8-3, behind Sam McDowell, a lefthander.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) --California enjoyed a nine run seventh inning in which the first nine batters reached base today and defeated Wash ington, 10-2, in the second game of a double-header.

Steel production rose last week for the third week in succession over levels of the preceding period, but the gain was a relatively narrow 0.5 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Manufacturers made a reduction in the inventories in June for the first time in three years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The coordinating committee of the city-sponsored Puerto Rican community conference agreed last night to seek quick, visible action for the city's Puerto Ricans.

The seventh Earl of Harewood, a first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, and Miss Patricia Tuckwell, a former Australian fashion model and violinist, were married by a justice of the peace yesterday afternoon in an Elizabethan-style mansion in New Canaan, Conn.

Ten steamship companies asked the Federal Maritime Commission yesterday to approve the establishment of a new rate-making conference. The conference would compete with at least two other agreements that already have the commission's approval.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 31 (AP)--Sporadic sniper fire and rock and bottle throwing, sparked by the tossing of three gasoline bombs, were reported in the city's West Side last night and early today.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 31-- The secessionist government of Nigeria's former Eastern Region announced today that it was seizing the installations of the country's largest oil producer.
Four National Broadcasting Company correspondents will be assigned to the network's "Huntley-Brinkley Report" early in September.

Trading volume on the New York and American Stock Exchanges in July provided good news for all those members of the financial community whose income is based on stock market turnover.

The tragedy of the giant U.S.S. Forrestal, whose decks and men were seared and blasted by a series of explosions off Vietnam, was the second carrier fire in less than a year--the greatest calamity in carrier operations since World War II.

At 6:30 A.M. yesterday Ricardo Castro of 525 Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, parked his car across from 39 Whitehall Street, embraced his son tightly with both arms and watched him walk across the street to join the Army. Then he stared angrily as his son, Ricardo Jr., had to pass through an antiwar picket line to enter the induction center.

One of the most important members of the more than l,500 thoroughbreds here is the Tartan Stable's Dr. Fager, considered by most observers to be the leading 3-year-old of the season. Dr. Fager was on the track just walking today, and he seemed in good shape. Such was not the case on Saturday, however.

BRUSSELS, July 31--Some thought had been given to inviting President de Gaulle to Belgium early next year, but his defiant support of FrenchCanadian separatism has sharply reduced the chances that the invitation will be tendered.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31--The top-seeded players worked up a sweat in the first round today, but the cause was as much the high humidity and temperature as it was the competition as the 41st annual Eastern grass court championships opened at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
Mrs. Alan H. Kempner of Purchase, N.Y., and her three sons have pledged $500,000 to the Columbia University campaign for $200-million.

The appointment of Hugh B. Marius as a deputy commissioner in the City Department of Sanitation was announced yesterday by Samuel J. Kearing Jr. Mr. Marius, who is 46 years old, will be the highest ranking Negro in the department. The post pays $18,000 a year.

ALBANY, July 31--Two prominent delegates to the Constitutional Convention today strongly opposed a recommendation by Governor Rockefeller that the convention adopt a system of appointing rather than electing judges.
First-half gains in premium income and a slight decline in profits were reported yesterday in the consolidated results of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 31-- The New York Giants dropped eight players from their training-camp squad today, reducing the total to 58.
Bruno Sammartino and Spyros Arion were disqualified last night in an Australian tagteam match at Madison Square Garden for kicking the head of one of their opponents 20 times or more.

ABOARD U.S.S. WILL ROGERS, at Sea off Cape Kennedy, Fla., July 31--A ring of white water off Cape Kennedy and a long trail of fire and thunder across the Atlantic marked the end of a chapter today in one of the nation's most successful missile programs.
PARIS, July 31 [Reuters]-- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the statement issued by the French Government today on President de Gaulle's recent visit to Canada:

TORONTO, July 31 (UPI)-- The United Automobile Workers Union opened contract negotiations today with the first of the "big three" Canadian automobile manufacturers for new contracts covering more than 50,000 workers in Canada.
Charles A. Horrworth, former executive vice president of the American Hotel and Motel Association, died Saturday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 68.

NEENAH, Wis., July 31-- Ernst W. Mahler, a director and former executive vice president of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, manufacturer of paper and cellulose products, died here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

David Herselle, principal of the Meyer Levin Junior High School in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, died yesterday of a hearts ailment in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 62 years, old and lived at 475 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 31 (Reuters)--The International PEN (poets, essayists and novelists) Club today called for the release of writers imprisoned by Greece, Spain, Haiti, Bolivia, South Vietnam, Portugal, Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.

ATLANTA, July 31 (UPI)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. demanded today the suspension of a white police officer accused of having beaten one of Dr. King's top aides. He was turned down by Mayor Ivan Allen Jr.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 31--Gov. Ronald Reagan underwent a 45-minute operation at St. John's Hospital today for removal of bladder stones. He also had a small wartlike growth removed from his lower lip.
RIVIERA BEACH, Fla., July 31 (AP)--Policemen used tear gas to scatter 400 Negroes early today, but not before a lumber yard and a manufacturing plant lay in ruins.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.7 on Friday from 96.9 on Thursday.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 31 (Agence France-Presse)-- Foreign newsmen were shown damage to dikes on the River Cau today.

OTTAWA, July 31 (Canadian Press)--The last legal barrier to a strike by the Seafarers International Union of Canada that would halt all inland and coastal shipping was removed today.

HUNTER, N.Y., July 31-- Jim West went west re- cently to try his skill as an angler in Michigan's lakes and streams. He has returned to the northern Catskills convinced that there's no place like home.

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 31--General Joseph D. MONTREAL, July 31--A Canadian team headed the field into the final stage of the Master Mixed Team Championship here tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Charles David Ginsburg is the very model of a civilized man living the good life.

The annual Shaker Kitchen Festival will be held Aug. 6 to 12 in Hancock Shaker Village, Hancock, Mass. (on Route 20, five miles west of Pittsfield).

WASHINGTON, July 31--A $33-million cut ordered last week by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in technical assistance grants for agricultural development abroad could eventually cost the United States about $1.5-billion in direct food aid, according to a group of experts.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- Evidence accumulated in Congress today that the nation's riots have damaged the legislative future of the campaign against poverty.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (AP) --Two men charged with murdering two officers in the United States Border Patrol pleaded guilty to second-degree murder charges at their arraignment today in Federal court. day in Federal court.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP)--Two men and a woman were indicted and arrested today in connection with the record cash robbery of $1.5-million from a United States mail truck in Plymouth in 1962.

DETROIT, July 31--Three young Negroes, who were apparently unarmed, were deliberately killed by the police or other men in uniform during last week's rioting, Negroes who say they were at the scene charged today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Tuesday, Aug. 1--Heavily armed police sealed off a 35-block area last night and early today after bands of Negro youths roamed the streets of predominantly Negro South Providence, throwing rocks and bottles at the authorities. There was no estimate of damage. At least two persons were injured.

Michael John Madigan, who dropped out of school at the age of 13 to lug water for construction gangs and went on to establish one of New York's most profitable engineering concerns, has quietly stepped aside as head of Madigan-Hyland, Inc., which he founded with the late Richard V. Hyland in 1928.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- House and Senate conferees agreed today on a $4,866-billion civilian space budget, cutting only 4.6 per cent from the Administration's request.

WHITE PLAINS, July 31-- A lawyer and his 12-day-old daughter died last night in an automobile accident on the Cross Westchester Expressway.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 --Martin L. Gregory, vice president and operations group executive of the General Foods Corporation, died of a heart ailment yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 77 Winding Lane.

Sales of the Boeing Company in the three months ended June 30 soared to $748.9-million, from $637-million in the like quarter last year, but the company's profits dropped to $20,612,000, or $1.06 a share, from $25,169,000, or $1.45 a share.
Mount Vernon, N.Y., July 31--Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella's proposal to avert racial violence by subsidizing jobs for Negroes was turned down today by city officials.
THE new men's wear store that made its debut on Fifth Avenue at the northeast corner of 43d Street yesterday practically pleaded with women to come inside.

William Johnson Kibbe, treasurer emeritus and former president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, died Monday in Sanger's Home for Chronic Patients, 500 West 57th Street, He was 84 years old and formerly lived at 166 East 61st Street.

British Government bonds were in demand and posted moderate gains on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. Gains, ranging to 5/16, were mainly in the long-term and medium issues. Short-term issues were a bit easier.

NORWOOD, N.J., July 31 --Miss Anne Mahoney and Henry Earle Cole plan to marry Dec. 30.

STUART, Fla., July 31 (AP)-- A tour bus hit by a blast of wind went out of control and overturned on the Sunshine State Parkway today, injuring a11 20 passengers.
