Ten teen-agers told a group of teachers yesterday that going to some schools was "worse than no education at all," because of racial discrimination, narcotics and other classroom problems.

LONDON, July 31--The High Court ruled today that "sherry" means wine from the Jerez district of Spain. But the court refused to rule against the use of such labels as "British sherry" and "Cyprus sherry" on wines not coming from Spain.
ADEN, July 31 (Agence France-Presse)--Eleven Aden businessmen accused British troops today of a "rule of terror" in this colony.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 --Mr. and Mrs. James Nicholson Baird have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Sanford Baird, to Appleton Adams Mason 3d. He is the son of Mr. Mason Jr., headmaster of the Lake Forest Country Day School, and Mrs. Mason, of Lake Forest, Ill.
PARIS, July 31--The old charm of some of Coco Chanel's clothes jumped right back into fashion today-- thanks to Yves Saint Laurent.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 31 (Agence France-Presse)-- The foreign ministers of the Arab nations open a meeting here tomorrow at which they are expected to decide whether an Arab heads-of-state conference will be held.
Robert J. Mangum, who rose from ghetto poverty, was sworn in yesterday as the new chairman of the State Commission for Human Rights, with the prospect of enlarged powers.
The foreign exchange markets were quiet and dull yesterday with what bankers described as "routine commercial transactions" predominant.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I. July 31--Lexi Packer, an 18 year-old Fresh Meadow golfer won low gross honors today in the 10th annual Babe Za harias Memorial golf tournament for the benefit of the American Cancer Society, Nassau division.
LIMA, Peru, July 31 (Reuters) -The Peruvian Government announced today the signing of a $40-million loan with a group of banks in the United States.

MOUNT McKINLEY, Alaska, July 31 (UPI)--Fierce winds and overcast made search efforts impossible today on the upper reaches of 20,270-foot Mount McKinley, where four members of a seven-man climbing team are missing and feared dead.
A New York physician contended yesterday that autopsies were performed too infrequently, leading to misdiagnosis of many causes of death and a subsequent warping of mortality statistics.

Doctors at the California Rehabilitation Center report that intravenous injection of amphetamines has become a "well established and extensive form of drug abuse" comparable in addictive potential to heroin and cocaine.
HAVANA, July 31--The first conference of the Organization of Latin-American Solidarity opened tonight in the Havana Libre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 1--Policemen were fired upon early today, the police said, as two Negro gangs of about 50 persons each roamed a predominantly Negro district of Washington amid six or seven fires.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31--This capital of nostalgia in the realm of thoroughbred horse racing began its annual session today, and Angel Cordero Jr. proved the noblest Saratogan of them all.
JERSEY CITY, July 31-- Joseph Mailly, who was removed as acting postmaster of Jersey City last January, died today at his home, 53 Prospect Street. His age was 49.

BABYLON, L.I., July 31--A fleet of 230 assorted craft assembled off the Long Island Yacht Club today for the first day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual race week, and the skippers were rewarded with a fine so'wester.
CHICIGO (AP)--A 50-foot sculpture design presented to Chicago by Pablo Picasso will be erected on Chicogo's Civic Center plaza.
It didn't seem like 1967 at all yesterday in the bond market. It was more like the summer days of the early 1960's with trading light on all fronts.

The Major League Baseball Players Association made public yesterday a policy statement on its goals in negotiations with the club owners, and revealed several requests that go well beyond anything the players have asked before.

The stock market started out in a fast run yesterday but finished at a slow trot. Prices moved upward on a broad front until about 1 P.M., when a round of profit taking set in, trimming gains steadily until the close.

The end of the senseless six-week welfare strike is a victory for the city on two important counts. It assures a restoration of full services to two-thirds of a million of New York's most deprived citizens in a period of tension in every slum area. It also represents the first time in recent municipal history that the city has stood firm against unwarranted concessions as the means of ending an illegal disruption of city activities.
The author of "Inside the FBI," which gives an unflattering description of J. Edgar Hoover, was expelled yesterday from the Society of Former Special Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

An exhibit of architectural models, renderings and photographs of "The Schoolhouse in the City" opened yesterday in the second-floor lobby of the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue, at 46th Street.

TEL AVIV, July 31--The Cabinet decided today to lift the ban on the use of Israeli currency in occupied Arab areas. The Israeli pound is to be the sole legal tender in the Sinai Peninsula, the former Gaza Strip and the occupied area of Syria. On the west bank of Jordan, it and the Jordanian dinar are to be legal tender.

PARIS, July 31--President de Gaulle declared today that French Canadians believed that they did not enjoy "liberty, equality and fraternity," and he promised them the help of France in achieving their goals of freedom.
Sitting on the sand and registering impressions only from the surf, sand fleas and bikinis, a fellow could almost forget about the controversial subject of advertising.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Following up market movements late last week, the Treasury bill rate dipped sharply at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
As part of its "clean seas" program, the Humble Oil and Refining Company has installed special equipment at its Baton Rouge, La., refinery to treat ballast water polluted by oil.

ART MODELL said, "I've got the telegram right here. I'm saving it for the Hall of Fame." This was the telegram sent to Modell, the president of the Cleveland Browns last July 22 by Carl B. Stokes, a Cleveland attorney and politician, who said he was representing five of the Browns' players in collective bargaining with the club.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Johnson announced today that he had named David Ginsburg, a Washington lawyer who has held several Government jobs since the 1930's, as executive director of his new Special Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- The United States lost $45million of gold in June, the largest monthly loss this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. However, the loss for the year to date, at $66-million, remains far below the pace of most recent years. For the first six months of 1966, the drain was $277-million; there was a decline of $571-million for all of last year.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of Upstate New York, said today that two Nigerian officials have arrived in Moscow to obtain Soviet arms.

Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Nowak have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Marcia Nowak, to Cantor Albert Ruttner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Ruttner of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 24.

WHITE PLAINS, July 31-- A new Westchester park of 146 acres of woodlands, lakes, rocky terrain and scenic vistas in the populous southern half of the county was proposed today to the Board of Supervisors by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian.

A group of about 15 young Negroes converged on the Charles Street police station late last night after the police arrested a 16-year-old Negro on a charge of felonious assault. The youths left the station house after being told that the suspect would be taken to Night Court for arraignment.
Mrs. Dorothea Baldwin McCollester, the widow of Parker McCollester, a New York lawyer who died in 1954, died of a heart attack yesterday in her home at 157 East 75th Street. Her age was 76.

ASPEN, Colo., July 31-- When asked yesterday if there were any new trends at the Aspen Music School and the nine-week festival it stages each summer, the dean, Gordon Hardy, said: "It's their ages--they're younger and more talented."

BOSTON, July 31--Vice President Humphrey urged the nation's Mayors today to become "righteously indignant" over delays in Congressional action on the Administration's programs to combat urban poverty.
The Carborundum Company, a producer of abrasives, announced yesterday the election of Robert C. Straka Jr. as a group vice president.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 Joe Culmone is a well-liked jockey with a host of admirers in New Jersey. They like the way Joe hustles a horse home.
CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP)-- Rocky Colavito, traded from Cleveland to Chicago two days ago, blasted a two-run homer in the 10th inning tonight, giving the White Sox a 4-2 victory over the Indians.
For holders of long positions in corn futures, a report issued yesterday by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad signaled caution. Speculators sold enough to drop prices to new lifetime lows.

TUNIS, July 31--The Military Tribunal of Tunis sentenced 54 persons today to forced labor for terms of one to 20 years on charges of participating in antiJewish riots on June 5, the day the Israeli-Arab war began.

"For the girl who has everything . . . We have something to charge it on . . ." This is the message from the First National City Bank, which looks anything but staid or banker-like in its television advertising these days.
Joel Grey, who won a Tony for his performance as the master of ceremonies in "Cabaret," said yesterday that he had signed a contract to portray George M. Cohan in "George M!"
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Twenty-two American leaders in a variety of pursuits called upon the nation tonight to revise its priorities and to bring more resources to bear on domestic problems.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 31--More than 100 antlwar demonstrators waved placards and booed as President Johnson's special envoys arrived in Wellington today for talks on the war in Vietnam.
James J. Wolfson, former vice president of the general contracting division of the Tishman Realty Construction Company, Inc., has resigned to form his own construction consultant's organization.

The president of the United Federation of Teachers warned yesterday that prospects were bleak for avoiding a threatened mass resignation of teachers when the city schools reopen on Sept. 11. "We have reached the deadline," he said, "and no agreement is in sight."
ROCKFORD, Ill., July 31 (UPI)--All policemen and firemen were ordered on standby alert today following two nights of racial disorders in which 44 persons were arrested.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP)-- With only a handful of 1968 models being produced, auto production is expected to dwindle to its lowest level of the year this week.
HONG KONG, July 31-- Peking dropped hints today that Wuhan was still out of its control.

When the 12th World Jamboree of the Boy Scouts opens today in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, chances are the show will be stolen by a 78-year-old girl. Lady Baden-Powell, whose late husband founded the scouting movement, never misses a Scout jamboree.
LONDON, July 31--Margaret Kennedy, whose novel "The Constant Nymph," published in 1924, met with worldwide success, died today at Adderbury, Oxfordshire. She was in her early seventies.

By starting its own rat-control program, New York State has rebuked the United States Congress. More important, it has taken a small but significant step toward bettering the lives and living conditions of slum dwellers.

HOUSTON, July 31--Bo Belinsky and Larry Sherry, a pair of headline performers in their glory years in Los Angeles, combined to push the New York Mets deeper into the National League's cellar tonight by hurling the Houston Astros to their seventh straight victory, 3-2.

President de Gaulle has, in effect, declared political war against the integrity of Canada as it is presently constituted. That is the only interpretation that can be placed on the amazing communiqu issued yesterday after the longest French Cabinet meeting on record. The length of that session suggests strongly, of course, that there were more sober heads present, and that de Gaulle did not have his way without having to beat down determined opposition.
WORCESTER, Mass., July 31--Miss Phyllis Susan Romanoff and Walter Alexander Strauss plan to marry Sent. 10.

Defying a ban imposed by the world ruling body of soccer, Atletica Portuguesa of Brazil agreed yesterday to play the New York Generals of the Na-- tional Professional Soccer League in an exhibition game Friday night at Yankee Stadium.
The appointment of William T. Kuhn Jr. as executive vice president of the Long Island Real Estate Board has been announced by its president, Herbert H. Bellringer of Westhampton.

Fried, Krupp of Essen is marked in history as arms maker to three generations of German war makers. The reputation is untrue of the company today, and it obscures some of the company's more admirable accomplishments in the past, but it is a hard reputation to shake.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 31 (AP)--The United States swimming team, led by Mark Spitz and Catie Ball, two teen-aged marvels, continued the Yankees' golden cascade of PanAmerican Games medals today, a collection that is rapidly becoming an embarassment of riches.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31--The Congo reported to the Security Council today that new groups of mercenaries had been recruited in Belgium by backers of Moise Tshombe, the former Premier, "to stir up further trouble in the Congo."

WASHINGTON, July 31-- The cost of buying mutual funds is so high, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today, that most investors would have done better in recent years if they had simply bought one of they stocks that are the favorites of small investors.

A father who is trying to prevent his former wife from taking their two small daughters to live in Israel testified yesterday that he had tried to help her present husband start a new business here to prevent their migration.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31--A one-day strike of 40,000 rubber plantation workers scheduled for today was postponed when the Government agreed to reduce the export tax of crude rubber from 40 per cent to 20 per cent.

Policing the troubled neighborhoods in the cities demands not force alone but something more difficult --great patience, establishment of sound community relations long before riots occur, integrated police units, and special training and weapons. Police officers called upon to preserve the peace are not social workers--but neither are they troops engaged in fighting a foreign enemy.

The Communications Satellite Corporation reported yesterday first-half net income of $2,088,146, or 21 cents a share. Earnings in the first quarter were equal to 12 cents a share. Second-quarter net income was $858,584, or 9 cents a share. There are no comparative figures for the year-earlier period.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Some 50 Democrats who were delegates to either the 1960 or 1964 Democratic National Conventions called on President Johnson today not to seek reelection next year.
The issuance of distinctive license plates marked for "limited use" to motorists with bad driving records was advocated yesterday by a leading insurance company executive.

JUDY GARLAND returned to the Palace last night like some raffish, sequinsprinkled female Lazarus. That magnetic talent is alive once again in New York, and so is one of the most remarkable personalities of the contemporary entertainment scene. That the voice--as of last night's performance, anyway--is now a memory seems almost beside the point.
SHERMAN, Tex. July 31 (UPI)--An order of Roman Catholic nuns filed a $975,000 bankruptcy claim today against Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Medders of Muenster, Tex.

Prices were up and trading volume expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The list was ahead at the start and moved almost steadily higher as the day went on. Earnings reports were a major factor in the performance of several issues.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Senator J.W. Fulbright introduced today a resolution intended to prevent the executive branch from making national commitments to other nations without legislative approval.

SUBIC BAY, The Philippines, July 31 (AP)--The carrier Forrestal, ravaged by fire and explosions off Vietnam Saturday, docked tonight at this United States naval base bringing the bodies of some of the 129 men who died in the disaster. Small fires were still blazing up aboard ship. Seven men were unaccounted for and 64 were injured in the worst United States naval tragedy in a combat zone since World War II, the ship's officers reported.
Old ballets never die, they just fade away unless resuscitated by a dedicated hand.
While no one is certain how many rats there are in the city, the Health Department estimates that there are eight million--equal to the city's human population.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)-- Lou Brock drove in four runs, three with a homer, and Orlando Cepeda hit a homer and drove in three runs today as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Chicago Cubs, 9-2.
More Americans oppose the project to land a man on the moon than support it, according to the Louis Harris Survey.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it was raising the prices of its tires and inner tubes by 2.5 to 10 per cent as a result of wage settlements.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the nation's railroads must use firemen on any new train runs despite a Federal arbitration ruling under which 18,000 of 40,000 firemen's jobs have been eliminated.
For 12-year-old Sherry Hurd of the Bronx, it was the first time she had seen the Statue of Liberty. "I didn't know it was green," she said. "And it's bigger than in the pictures."
The Struthers Wells Corporation, an engineering and heavy equipment manufacturing concern, announced yesterday the election of Clark Root as executive vice president and chief operating officer.
Prentice-Hall, Inc., publishers of books and business services, is planning to go into the bond brokerage business.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)-- Lou Brock drove in four runs, three with a homer, and Orlando Cepeda hit a homer and drove in three runs today as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Chicago Cubs, 9-2.
More Americans oppose the project to land a man on the moon than support it, according to the Louis Harris Survey.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it was raising the prices of its tires and inner tubes by 2.5 to 10 per cent as a result of wage settlements.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the nation's railroads must use firemen on any new train runs despite a Federal arbitration ruling under which 18,000 of 40,000 firemen's jobs have been eliminated.
For 12-year-old Sherry Hurd of the Bronx, it was the first time she had seen the Statue of Liberty. "I didn't know it was green," she said. "And it's bigger than in the pictures."
The Struthers Wells Corporation, an engineering and heavy equipment manufacturing concern, announced yesterday the election of Clark Root as executive vice president and chief operating officer.
Prentice-Hall, Inc., publishers of books and business services, is planning to go into the bond brokerage business.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today he would attach the Administration's rat-control program, which was rejected recently by the House, to the House-passed antiriot bill "when and if" it gets to the Senate floor.
ALBANY, July 31--The Constitutional Convention rejected today a proposed easing of the 73-year-old requirement that the state's forest preserve be "forever kept as wild forest lands."
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) --Victims of the Newark riots were declared eligible today for disaster loans through the Small Business Administration.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Jim Maloney pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 2-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight, allowing only three hits, all singles.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 1--The conference of Arab foreign ministers began today on a militant note when the Palestine Liberation Organization called on all Arab nations to support "popular resistance in occupied Palestine."
Back a ways when she got her degree from the University of Oklahoma, Roselou Flanagan was treated by her folks to a trip to New York as a graduation present. Now look at her.
ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--The Greek Government announced today five ambassadorial appointments that are part of a major reshuffle of senior diplomats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Senate Securities subcommittee approved today, with amend- ments that met some of the major industry objections, legislation that would impose new requirements on those seeking to take over companies by of- fering to buy stock from the public.

C. Tiffany Richardson, a partner in Auerbach, Pollak Richardson, stockbrokers, from 1903 to 1964, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 840 Park Avenue and Southampton, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The United States Government, in a policy reversal, has authorized Mrs. Maria Trujillo de Leon Estevez to enter the country for medical treatment.

More than 1,000 persons trained with antipoverty funds for jobs as health aides have been unable to find employment despite the critical shortage of health personnel, Dr. James G. Haughton, first deputy health services administrator, said yesterday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 1 (UPI)--The last Lunar Orbiter spacecraft was launched tonight to examine five possible landing sites for astronauts and 36 puzzling moonscape features.
PARIS, Aug. 1--Andre Courreges's tall, big-boned models stand to lose a few pounds each time they show his new couture collection. For it's skip, skip, skip every second.

The 14th annual season of Free Chamber Music in Washlington Square Park may have opened and closed in a single evening yesterday. Funds could be raised only for the first of the scheduled four Tuesday programs.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company sold $250-million of debentures yesterday morning at an interest just slightly above 6 per cent--the highest for A.T. T. since 1919.

Paperboard production rose 1.1 per cent with 456,600 tons in the week ended July 29, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
NORTH AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 1--Separate paths of protest and politics are being pursued by Long Island civilright's leaders in an effort to redress Negro grievances and avoid community disorders.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1-- A bomb exploded at the Peace Corps office in Rio de Janeiro today, injuring two American volunteers and a Brazilian employe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- The House Ways and Means Committee approved new cutbacks in the Administration's Social Security bill today to reduce the prospective cost.

James W. Stevens and Robbert W. Todd have been named vice presidents of the First National City Bank, the bank announced yesterday. Both officers are assigned to the bank's specialized industries division.
The acquisition-minded Occidental Petroleum Corporation is holding merger talks with the Island Creek Coal Company--a deal that would involve an exchange of stock...
SURPRISINGLY, there was a lot of bearish comment yesterday after the Interstate Commerce Commission came through with railroad freight rate increases within a jot of what the railroads had asked.
The computer industry whirred and flashed all day yesterday and poured out a tape full of sales.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 1--Ivan Tors, like millions of American fathers, had a problem finding movies suitable for his 6-year old son. That was five years ago and the start of a motionpicture and television production company built on wild animals and their human friends that today stretches from California to Kenya and that he says will gross $26million this fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --More than 100,000 men have volunteered for duty in Vietnam the last three years and others are now seeking to serve in the war zone at the rate of 4,650 a month, the Army said today.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug 1--Gov. Ronald Reagan was reported by an aide today to be "feeling great" 24 hours after an operation for removal of bladder stones.

A sinister development in this summer's riots is the presence of snipers who for days at a time have held off police and National Guardsmen. The sniper, engaging in deadly and deliberate violence, is a much more menacing figure than the reckless teen-ager or the casual looter.
ROME, Aug. 1--Rome sources said today that translations of a new Dutch catechism, approved by the Dutch bishops but alleged to contain heresies, have been held up by the Vatican.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 1 --The Una Cup found a new winner today and so did yesterday's Third Division run from Padanaram during the New York Yacht Club cruise when unfinished business in the form of protest hearings was transacted.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Staughton Lynd, who was denied an appointment to Chicago State College as a result of an unauthorized visit to North Vietnam, says he will seek a court reversal of the school board's decision.

ADEN, Aug. 1 (Agence France-Presse)--The British High Commissioner, Sir Humphrey Trevelyan, returned today from the United Nations and London and immediately made a peace gesture to the extremist groups that have been fighting against the British Army.

Harry Koldin, founder 35 years ago of the Harry Koldin Dress Company of 501 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday at the Community Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 67 years old and lived at 241 Dover Street, Brooklyn.
One of the outstanding trends in American corporate life in recent years has been the rise of the professional economist to a position of top level responsibility.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1 (AP)--A gasoline bomb was thrown into a white-owned cafe in the Negro business district today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 1--A team of Canadian ex- perts led the field into the final session of the National Master Mixed Team Championship here tonight, but several New York stars were in close contention for the title.
Industrial issues moved ahead on a broad front yester- day on the London Stock Ex change.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo said yesterday he would ask Mayor Lindsay to appoint a budget coordinator to expedite city building projects in Puerto Rican areas and a coordinator of local services to speed action on Puerto Rican problems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --Senator Hugh Scott said today that news media "in many instances inadvertently contributed to the turmoil" in their reporting of recent riots.
Motion picture rights to "Man of La Mancha," the hit musical at the ANTA Washington Square Theater, have been acquired by United Artists.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 1--Form, weather form, that is, held true for Saratoga today. A fine sunny morning turned into a rainy afternoon and through most of the program the sport was held in successive downpours that created a sloppy and muddy track. The conditions interfered not at all, however, with the riding expertness of Angel Cordero.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Interstate Commerce Commission gave the railroads permission today to increase their freight rates by about $300million a year.

A new company formed by Robert Dowling, Serge Semenenko and David G. Baird has taken over the menagement of the Pierre Hotel and Apartment Cooperative, at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street, under a lease signed yesterday.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company--the nation's largest rubber company--reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30.

The Constitutional Convention has done well in approving a new, simplified article continuing the constitutional mandate that the state's Forest Preserve must be "forever kept as wild forest lands." In several respects the new article is an improvement on the present one.

Three butchers' union officials were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiracy and extortion, accused of having demanded $60,000 as the price for labor peace from the metropolitan area's major meatprocessing companies in 1964.
LONDON, Aug. 1--Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, obtained a temporary injunction today against the publication in Britain of an unauthorized edition of her memoirs.
Trading volume expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but prices wound up with only slight gains.
Negro rioters were praised, or at least pardoned, yesterday by speakers at a news conference sponsored by the National Conference for New Politics.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 (UPI)-- Stokely Carmichael was made an "honorary delegate" to the first conference of the Organization for Latin-American Solidarity here today and called for a "revolution" to liberate the American Negro.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 1--Thomas Lee Henry, who was chosen last night as chairman of a steering committee to help solve the problems of Poughkeepsie's Negro district, was indicted today on a charge of assaulting a city detective during disorders last weekend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The country's scheduled air lines are spending $2.1-billion on new transport equipment this year, according to a study made by the Air Transport Association, the industry trade organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, headed by John L. McClellan of Arkansas, was chosen today to conduct the chief Congressional inquiry into the cause and cure of urban rioting.

TRADITIONALLY, beauty contest winners are all smiling-through-tears excitement. The newest victor, a green-eyed brunette, stared in boredom at photographers, yawned widely and proceeded to sleep through a victory luncheon.

CAIRO, Wednesday, Aug. 1 (UPI)--Egypt "urgently" appealed yesterday for an end to the fighting in Yemen, where civil war has raged for five years, the authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram reported today. Egyptian troops have been involved in the war, and peace would enable them to come home.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 97 on Monday from 96.7 on Friday.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1-- Five weeks have passed since Romeo Hanover last raced and it may be 10 more before last season's 3-year-old pacing champion returns to competition.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1--Communist China celebrated the 40th anniversary of its army today, but many important army leaders were absent from a Peking reception held last night in honor of the event.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1--The generals who rule South Vietnam are at work on a plan that would perpetuate collective government by the junta despite the election of a President, Vice President and Congress.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Ang. 1--Talks between the Belgian and Congolese Governments this summer will probably determine whether the majority of the 40,000 to 50,000 Belgans in the Congo will remain.

GERONA, Spain, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--Tourists Joined thousands of civil guards, troops, firemen and forest wardens today to fight a vast forest fire raging out of control near the Costa Brava, a coastal resort area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told the President's new Special Advisory Commission of Civil Disorders today that he had no "intelligence" indicating a conspiracy behind the recent racial disorders.
The Red Cross here formally agreed yesterday in a memorandum signed with the city to assume greater responsibilities in helping to meet fire disasters.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1--In his seven years in office, Mayor Henry Walter Maier has become known as an organizer. He has revamped the executive office to make it more efficient. Before he goes before the Common Council with a new program, he has his facts carefully prepared.
Copper made new highs for the current upward move in futures trading yesterday. The reason continued to be the influence of the unsettled strike situation in this country.

Moscow has aimed a neat slap at Premier Fidel Castro, who is host to the Organization for Latin-American Solidarity (OLAS), now meeting in Havana. It printed in Pravda an attack on the Castroite policy of revolutionary violence by the Chilean Communist party leader, Luis Corvalan.

SANDWICH, Mass., Aug. 1 --The Rev. and Mrs. Arlan A. Baillie have announced the engagement of Mr. Baillie's daughter, Miss Carol Anne Baillie, to Jere Cole Austin 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jere C. Austin of Patchogue, L.I.

While commissions to "investigate" urban riots proliferate in Washington, a group of outstanding citizens has decided to take the lead in spurring the country to positive action to improve housing, schools and jobs, the obvious needs to combat despair in the slums.

General Mills, Inc., announced yesterday in Minneapolis that Charles B. Thornton and Walter B. Wriston will not stand for re-election as directors, and that the board will be reduced from 20 to 18 members.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1--Dr. and Mrs. Martin L. Singewald have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Singewald, to Carl F. Nathan. He is the son of Paul Nathan of New York and the late Mrs. Nathan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --A proposal to switch five major holidays to Mondays drew strong support today from the United States Chamber of Commerce, travel organizations and the Air Transportation Association.
Cuba's far-flung system of operational support for LatinAmerican subversive movements has been detailed by a Venezuelan who worked in the Cuban intelligence apparatus.

DETROIT, Aug. 1--The Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury Division today reported 12,799 new-car deliveries in the final third of July, up 26 per cent from 10,171 sold July 21-31 a year ago. For all of July, the division reported 30,502 sales, up 24 per cent from 24,210 in July, 1966.

LEXINGTON, Ky , Aug. 1-- Fayette County Fiscal Court today unanimously passed an open housing law prohibiting racial discrimination in commercial sales and rentals of real estate. The Fiscal Court is the county's three-member legislative body.
Merger talks between Schenley Industries, Inc., and P. Lorillard Co., which have been faltering for weeks, collapsed yesterday.
Arthur Tinker, a researcher for 10 years with Fesseden Blanchard Morrell, specialists in textile market research, died Monday on Cape Cod. He was 74 years old.

SANTA ROSA, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP)--Ellis O. Jones, a leading magazine editor in the early years of the century, who headed an isolationist antiwar organization during World War II, died today. He was 93 years old.

James E. Barrett, treasurer and vice president of the realty and auctioneering concern of Joseph P. Day, Inc., died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 62 years old and lived at 65 Prospect Street, Stamford, Conn.

HOUSTON, Aug. 1--Don Shaw, a 23-year-old left-hander completing his rookie year before reporting for six months of Army Reserve duty later this month, turned in five shutout innings of brilliant relief pitching tonight to hurl the Mets to a 5-1 victory over the Astros.
"That's not good, but it's on the way," George Szell said yesterday as he listened to himself performing in a Mozart violin and piano sonata.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1--About 350 enemy guerrillas have been killed in the first five days of a sweep by American and South Vietnamese troops in the Mekong River delta, Lieut. Gen. Frederick C. Weyand announced today.
Several sportings goods stores in New York City have decided to curb the sale of rifles and shotguns until the threat of racial violence has passed.

Lower prices for Chileanproduced copper and slack demand for fabricated products combined to cut the second- quarter earnings of the Anaconda Company below the year-earlier level, the company said yesterday.

With a five-run inning that, as a symbol of their ninthplace problems, deserved to be included in their family Hall of Fame, the New York Yankees defeated the California Angels, 6-1, last night at Yankee Stadium.

At 8:20 A.M. yesterday, a tall 'man with a healthy tan stepped briskly into the entrance of the New York Stock Exchange at 11 Wall Street. Robert W. Haack, who will take over as the Big Board's president on Sept. 11, a Monday, had arrived to begin his quiet but intensive period of orientation.
LONDON, Aug. 1--The Berkeley, the small but stately hotel on Piccadilly at Berkeley Street, is to be demolished and replaced by an insurance company building.
Thirty-five college students were given a sampling of Harlem life yesterday, to help them to decide if they want careers in social work.
A realignment of top management was announced yesterday in Miami by the Storer Broadcasting Company, which operates a chain of television and radio Stations.
ALBANY, Aug. 1--A Constitutional Convention committee voted tentatively today to repeal the 73-year-old prohibition against state financial aid to church-connected schools.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 1-- Meanwhile, at Monmouth Park, the New York bettors continued to pour in today as if there were no Aqueduct.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--Foreign Minister Tran Van Do today rejected Secretary General Thant's assertion that the war in Vietnam was a matter of national independence rather than Communist aggression.

The Brazil-United StatesCanada Freight Conference announced yesterday that rates on the shipment of coffee from the major ports of Brazil had been cut 25 cents a bag. It said the rates on cocoa had been cut 7 cents a bag.
The city's policemen have been authorized for the first time to drive taxis during their off-duty hours and to carry their service pistols while doing so.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nadler of Montreal have announced the engagement of Mrs. Nadler's daughter, Miss Margot Joan Metzger, to Robert Worrall Shoemaker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Shoemaker of Franklin, N.J.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company of Springfield, Mass., has announced that Thomas W. Lapwing has joined the company as a second vice president and senior officer in charge of the real estate department.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 1 (AP)--As his aide struck his flag from a yardarm at the United States Naval Academy field house today, Adm. David L. McDonald, Chief of Naval Operations, stepped into civilian life. He was succeeded by Adm. Thomas H. Moorer.
GENEVA, Aug. 1--Italy appealed to the nuclear powers today to sell part of their nuclear stockpiles to the nonnuclear powers with the understanding that they would be used for peaceful purposes.
More than 700 needy New York City youngsters will leave today for free summer vacations in Fresh Air Fund Friendly Town communities in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 1 (AP)--Claudia Kolb, a powerful 17-year-old swimmer from Santa Clara, Calif., won her third gold medal in the PanAmerican Games tonight in the 400-meter individual medley. She broke her second world record as the United States picked up 12 more firsts, and swept four track events.

THE Prince Street Players, who are doing free children's shows in the city's parks this summer (this weekend's offering in Prospect Park will he "Pinocchio") are at once amusing and depressing. On the debit side is their frankly campy approach to children's classics.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 1 --Rabbi Meyer M. Abramowitz of Temple B'rith Sholom and Mrs. Abramowitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Lois Abramowitz, to Jeffrey Lewis Ballon, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Sidney Ballon of West Hempstead, L.I.
LONDON, Aug. 1--A report on Britain's immigrant youth has urged the public to accept "the possibility of an increase in mixed marriages as an outcome of our declared policy on integration."
William J. Dibble was elected yesterday as president of the fabricated products division of the Allied Chemical Corporation.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (UPI) --Cookie Rojas got a double and two singles in four trips to the plate tonight to pace the Philadelphia Phillies to a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
One of the stock market's cliff-hanging situations ended yesterday when the Dow-Jones industrial average moved to a new high for the year.
ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (AP)--The Atlanta police department suspended a patrolman with 16 years' service today pending investigation of an incident involving an aide of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Wednesday, Aug. 2--Policemen and snipers traded gunfire in the second consecutive night of violence last night while more than 100 youths, crying "white power," tried to attack gangs of Negroes hurling rocks and bottles.

STRATFORD, Ont., Aug. 1 --Should Stratford, popu- lation 23,500, have a power failure some night, a simple remedy is at hand. The actors at the Stratford Festival are pouring enough energy into their new "Antony and Cleopatra" to light a town twice its size.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 1--Georges Bidault said today that he regarded Belgium as his "European cage" but that in the "not too distant future" the cage would come unlocked and he would return to France.

Delta Steamship Lines of New Orleans plans to abandon temporarily its passenger-ship services by the end of the year, according to an application submitted by the carrier to the Maritime Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Testimony released today by the Senate Preparedness Investigating subcommittee disclosed that the serious pilot shortages now confronting the Navy and Air Force would persist through at least the fiscal year 1971.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (UPI)--Juan Marichal joined his teammate, Mike McCormick, as the only other 14-game winner in the National League tonight and Willie Mays hit his first homer in five weeks in pacing the San Francisco Giants to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Miss Druscilla Taylor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Taylor of New York and Little Deer Isle, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Joseph Jennings, son of Mrs. Thomas J. Jennings of Rutherford, N.J., and the late Mr. Jennings.
Delinquency on real estate taxes owed by New York City landlords increased by onethird in the fiscal year just ended.
The exhibition soccer game that will be played Friday night at Yankee Stadium will have some goodies for everybody concerned:

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 1--The engagement of Miss Virginia Mae Walker to John Keeler Lawrence has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Walker. Mr. Lawrence is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lawrence of Hammondsport, N.Y.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP)--Five Detroit business executives, including Joseph A. Schoenith, a powerboat racer, were indicted today on charges of making illegal corporate political contributions last year to Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh of Detroit and others last year.

PARIS, Aug. 1 (Reuters)-- The French fashion house of Chanel will show a collection in Moscow next month at an international fashion festival organized by tho Soviet Chamber of Commerce, it was announced today.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1 (UP)--The skipper and navigator of Australia's Dame Pattie have come down with pneumonia.

WACO, Tex., Aug. 1--Miss Alice Anne Harrison and Hugh Douglas Wise 3d plan to be married here on Aug. 19. The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William C. Harrison have announced the engagement of their daughter and the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wise Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Gibson Island, Md.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--Rescue workers continued to search through the ruins of collapsed buildings here today as the official death count from the earthquake Saturday rose to 152.

DURBAN South Africa Aug. 1 (Reuters)--A white man critically injured in an auto accident lay on the road for an hour and a half last night because the ambulance that arrived on the scene was for nonwhites only and left without him.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Ken Boyer's double, his fourth hit of the game, ignited a sixrun Chicago ninth inning tonight as the American Leagueleading White Sox trounced Cleveland, 11-5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --Ralph Nader, the safety critic, told Senators today that industry-suggested changes in proposed natural gas pipeline safety legislation would create "a pervasive, self-serving structure of private government over standard-setting."

JOHN NICHOLS (1745-1826), a printer, publisher, antiquarian, collector of literary memorabilia, is a name better known to scholars and students of the 18th century than to the average reader. Nevertheless, in his own way, he is a figure worth consideration. For he is one of those, necessary to every age, who feed small but strong...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --The Office of Economic Opportunity announced the suspension today of Willie Wright, an antipoverty worker who leads the Community Black Patrol in Newark, N.J.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 1 (AP)--Tucker Frederickson of the New York Giants engaged in his first contact in a year today and reported no stiffness or pain in the left knee that kept him out of the entire 1966 season.
Governor Rockefeller directed the State Insurance Superintendent yesterday to press insurance companies to maintain damage coverage in ghetto areas despite the recent riots.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Run-scoring doubles by Ron Santo and Clarence Jones backed the six-hit pitching of Ferguson Jenkins and gave the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory today over the first-place St. Louis Cardinals.

There is a "Peanuts" cartoon in which little Linus is pictured throwing something that quickly lands on the ground. After repeated attempts, he gives up, eats the object and turns to Lucy to say, "No matter how hard you try, you can't throw a potato chip."

Indian Head, Inc., formerly a textile manufacturer and now a diversified company with divisions making metal products, auto parts and glass containers as well, has elected Robert W. Lear as president and chief operating officer.

HAVANA, Aug. 1--Stokely Carmichael is playing a miserable game down here. He is not only condemning his own country abroad, but he is misleading Fidel Castro and the other revolutionary Communists from Latin America about the condition and power of the Negroes in America.
Vornado, Inc., operator of the Two Guys chain of discount department stores, announced yesterday the election of Alvin C. Martin as a director.

New Jersey officials are trying to open land for housing in Newark's riot-torn Central Ward by asking leaders of the state's medical college if they can reduce the size of their proposed campus in the area.
Retail sales in New York's major department stores picked up sharply in July, reaching the year's best monthly gain since January.

COMPARED with "The Endless Summer," a tingling treatise of a movie about surfboarding, "Ski on the Wild Side" is strictly amateur night. What a joy it would have been to salute a second, cooling sports documentary during the hot months. But the color feature that arrived yesterday at the Guild and 34th Street East Theaters is strictly lukewarm stuff, rather amateurishly spilling from a grab-bag of random footage.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 1 --Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, who won the medal yesterday, and Mrs. Mary C. Bartol of Stanwich, the defending champion, led the way through the first round of the 42d annual Women's Westchester--and--Fair field Golf Asociation championship tournament at Siwanoy Country Club today.
PARIS, Aug. 1--President de Gaulle won support from the left today for his pledge to help "liberate" French-speaking Canada.

Those diehard prophets of rain, the weather forecasters, were predicting showers yesterday afternoon. Since the sky was cloudless in the early evening, more than 60,000 New Yorkers chose to ignore the predictions and turned out to hear the New York Philharmonic give its third concert of the summer in Central Park.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 1 --Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Wickwire 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Hedge Wickwire, to A. Faxon Henderson Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Faxon Henderson of Palm Beach Fla.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 1--There are at least two things worth stressing about the Netherlands Dance Theater, which is to offer its first Broadway season next April. The first is simply that it is the most adventurous of all European dance companies. The second is that it is the most American.
A new round of reductions in trans-Pacific air fares will be come effective Oct. 1, the International Air Transport Association announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 1--Anwar Khatib, former Governor of the Jordanian district of Jerusalem, protested today against his banishment to northern Israel for allegedly having incited subversion against the Israeli authorities.
C.B.S. News said last night that President Johnson was "in the final throes of deciding on a major peace gesture to the North Vietnamese."
OTTAWA, Aug. 1--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson tonight dismissed President de Gaulle's latest challenge on Quebec in a two-sentence statement reiterating Ottawa's...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Executives of major mutual funds told Congress today that proposed legislation to lower their charges to investors was "unnecessary" and "dangerous."
SEATTLE, Aug. 1 (UPI)-- Bob Gilliam drove the Hilton Hyperlube three laps around the Lake Washington Gold Cup course today to become the fifth qualifiers for Sunday's $37,250 hydroplane classic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Scientists planning to seed Atlan-- tic hurricanes will have a larger hunting ground this year and predict a 20 per cent better chance of finding a target.

"We don't have much option," John J. Scanlon, vice president and treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, commented in his office yesterday. A.T. T. had just borrowed nearly $250million and it paid the highest interest rate in almost half a century.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company said yesterday it lost $5,962,495 in the second quarter on operating revenues of $56,928,844. In the same quarter last year, the road earned $2,225,264 on revenue of $60,311,542.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J. Aug. 1 --A 10-year-old girl was accused today of having derailed a train here last Thursday. Four diesel engines were damaged, the corner of a factory was demolished and a crewman was slightly injured.
WASHINGTON Aug. 1 (AP) --Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today ordered the battleship New Jersey taken out ot mothballs to bolster United States naval fire power in the Vietnam war.
The process of cooling the heated atmosphere in the Middle East is being retarded by the unwelcome presence of some thousands of Iraqi troops in Jordan.

The city's antipoverty policymaking agency threatened yesterday to try to block $80,264,000 in Federal funds for the Board of Education here. On its side, the school system insisted it had been seeking community cooperation in developing programs for poverty areas.
ALBANY, Aug. 1--The Constitutional Convention voted unanimously today in favor of a proposition to maintain the state's forest preserve as an everlasting wilderness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Leaders of the government of the District of Columbia said today that they were "optimistic" about avoiding a recurrence of the arson, vandalism and rock throwing that erupted for three hours early this morning in the northwest Washington ghetto--
DETROIT, Aug. 1--Army paratroopers began leaving Detroit today and a nine-day curfew, imposed when rioting erupted July 23, was ended.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1-- For the first time since 1956 the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra will venture outside North America. A major sponsor for the tour will be the State Department's Cultural Exchange Program.
The strike of thousands of New York Telephone Company installers and repairmen was joined yesterday by overseas and long-distance operators.
The Dow-Jones industrial average, no doubt the most widely watched of all stock market indicators, leaped to a new high for it yesterday and unleashed a new wave of optimism on Wall Street.
The National Steel Corporation said yesterday it would raise prices of tinplate used in making cans by an average of 2.7 per cent on Sept. 5.

LONDON, Aug. 1--Estimates for the cost of developing the British--French Concorde air- liner have soared to 528- million ($1.47-billion), a House of Commons committee said in a report published today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 --This city's first flying debutante party returned at midnight last night to San Francisco International Airport, 12 hours after setting out on a surprise-filled adventure that led to Reno and the dinner show at a gambling casino.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Air Force is planning to introduce a new push-button bombing system in Vietnam for use at night and in bad weather.
An attempt by the city to quash subpoenas calling for the appearance in court of Mayor Lindsay and six other officials was rebuffed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol.

WASHINGTON Aug. 1. (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would require the Rexall Drug and Chemical Company of Los Angeles to sell within two years all its domestic interest in a plastic-bottle operation.
Two young sisters were burned to death last night when fire swept through an apartment at 526 East 11th Street. The girls had been left alone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) --Representative L. Mendel Rivers announced plans today for an investigation of whether the Johnson Administration had a plan for "military victory" in Vietnam and if so how long it would take to achieve.
Caseworkers involved in a six-week work stoppage at the city's welfare centers returned to their jobs yesterday as both sides in the dispute predicted an early settlement of unresolved issues.
The United States Court of Appeals held yesterday that the Secretary of Labor could not tell unions what policy they should follow in limiting candidacy for union office.

THE Ford Motor Company has signed Mario Andretti as its No. 1 driver for the rich Canadian-American Challenge Cup series of six races that start at Elkhart Lake, Wis., on Sept. 3. The Dearborn factory team will have two cars in the Series and will name another driver next.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--A Senate investigating committee was told today that a South Vietnamese importer who is a former member of the Saigon Cabinet had received illegal kickbacks of $896,258 from United States drug concerns, which deposited most of the money to his account in Swiss banks.

A new television season begins next month and industry spokesmen have labeled it "The Year of the Special." Just as other seasons were dominated by the Western, the private-eye, the crime show, the situation comedy and the superhero, this one is aimed at the selective viewer.

Thomas D. Austin, retired founder of the law firm of Austin DuPont, 161-19 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday at Jamaica Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 89-31 192d Street, Hollis, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 1 (AP) --The State Department announced today the lifting of its ban on travel by Americans to Algeria, Libya and the Sudan.

Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first six months. Operating revenues rose to $27,789,078 from $25,462,122 a year earlier. Net income of $4,382,968, equal to 93 cents a share, compared with $4,018,876, or 86 cents a share, in the 1966 period.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Aug. 2--Sporadic sniping and fire alarms plagued police and National Guard forces patrolling Negro areas of Milwaukee last night and early today.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 1--This city announced today that it would send a "mobile City Hall" into the racially tense South Side, beginning Friday, to hear complaints of residents.

NEWARK, Aug. 1 (AP)--The Prudential Insurance Company announced today that it will provide $18-million in long-term financing for the $24-million Gateway redevelopment program planned for a two-block area next to the Pennsylvania Railroad Station.

A tramp wins a knock-down fight with a cop (yay!). Two thieves relieve a woman of the purse concealed in her stocking (sob! sob!). And a maid accidentally (heh! heh!) wrings her sponge out the window on a trio of swells.
New Yorkers can now receive a two-minute news, weather and stock-market report by telephone.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 1 (Reuters)--Federal military headquarters said here tonight that Maj. Chukwuma Nzeogwu, leader of the proEastern military coup that overthrew Nigeria's last civilian government in January, 1966, had been killed in battle with the federal forces.
LONDON, Aug. 1.--Like a prudent football coach, Britain's nationalized steel company opened its first season today by singing the blues.
Nine gold bars valued at $23,376 were stolen by two armed men early yesterday from the cargo office of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission, in a split decision, ordered today the first formal testing of the tar and nicotine content of about 50 kinds of cigarettes on its new smoking machine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The State Department disclosed today that the United States made overtures in May toward diplomatic reconciliation with Cambodia but was rebuffed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Chief of State.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1--Every seeded player in the men's and women's divisions advanced today to the third round of the Eastern grasscourt tennis championships, but high-ranking Clark Graebner experienced some bad moments before winning at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
Markets Commissioner Gerard M. Weisberg made clear yesterday that in at least one instance he is determined to have less bounce to the ounce.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 1-- Thirteen skippers made it two straight today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual cruise week. The fleet moves to Bay Shore tomorrow for the third day of sailing.

BONN, Aug. 1--Prof. Richard Kuhn, an internationally known biochemist, whom the Nazis barred from accepting the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1938, died in Heidelberg today after a long illness. He was 66 years old.
A suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court here against Francis I. duPont Co., the brokerage firm, and the New York Stock Exchange by an investor who lost $1.25million in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that it was "absolutely" not true that the Administration had played politics in delaying the dispatch of Federal troops to quell the Detroit riot.

Chinatown's newest financial institution, the Chinese American Bank, opened its doors yesterday at 225 Park Row with S.K. Chow, the Ambassador of Taiwan to the United States and Frank Wille, State Superintendent of Banks, participating. Ambassador Chow cut the ribbon at the door of what had been the premises of the Chinatown branch of the Bank of China.
ATLANTA, Aug. 2 (UPI)-- Gov. Lester G. Maddox congratulated the Lowndes County School Board today for its action in removing Negro teachers from previously integrated white school faculties.

SHIZUOKA, Japan, Aug. 2 (UPI)--A police report today on the crash of a bet owned by the British Overseas Airways Corporation, which killed 124 persons, said the pilot was "probably responsible" for the disaster.
Jean Dalrymple and Franchot Tone will take possession tomorrow of Theater Four at 424 West 55th Street.
DETROIT. Aug. 2--The Ford Motor Company raised its 1968 truck prices sharply, a hint of what may be coming in car prices.
DETROIT, Aug. 2--Vice President Humphrey called tonight for a massive effort to help the impoverished areas of the United States, an effort that he likened to the Marshall Plan.

The Cerro Corporation reported yesterday a decline in sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30. It attributed the drop to a cut in selling prices for copper, lead, zinc and zinc concentrates and an increase in metal production costs ink Peru.
The election of Manuel Diaz as executive vice president of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, Inc., was announced yesterday by A. Theodore DeSmedt, president of the carrier.
The New York Yankees and California Angels struggled for nearly three hours at Yankee Stadium last night and for most of that time it looked as though nobody could possibly win.
New highs in the popular stock market indicators, heavy trading on the major securities exchanges and rapid capital gains in speculative issues often prove to be irresistible
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 --Sporadic acts of violence were reported tonight in South Providence after two successive nights of clashes between the police and angry bands of Negro youths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Senate investigators said today that a British organizer of French and Italian suppliers realized profits of 300 per cent on shipments of drugs to South Vietnam financed with Agency for International Development funds.
ALBANY, Aug. 2--The President of the Constitutional Convention, Anthony J. Travia, proposed today that New York State assume full responsibility for the administration of local welfare programs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) --Following is the roll-call by which the Senate voted $18.1million for the Teachers Corps:
JERUSALEM, Aug. 2--Israeli scholars are about to launch an extensive survey of the archeological sites in the occupied Arab territories.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, that house of treasures where visitors may roam among Egyptian tombs and masterpieces by Rembrandt, also keeps a fine collection of North American bubble gum wrappers.

ALLENDALE, N.J., Aug. 2-- Martin E. Husing, technical representative in the New York area for the General Aniline and Film Corporation died yesterday at the Neurological Institute in New York. He was 52 years old and lived at 100 Elmwood Avenue.
COWES, England, Aug. 2 (UPI)--Prince Charles beat his Navy veteran father, the Duke of Edinburgh, today in his first attempt at competitive sailing.

ROOSEVELT, L.I., Aug. 2-- The State Rent Commission cut rents today to as little as $1 a month for some tenants who live in overcrowded, dilapidated, unsanitary and dangerous homes in this suburban community.

Baron and Baroness Willy Roger de la Peine of Avignon, France, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Laurence de la Peine, to Dr. Gilles Reza Khan Monif, son of Mrs. Hassan Khan Monif of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Monif.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 2 (Reuters)--President Johnson's special envoy, Clark Clifford, described as an error today a report that he and Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor were consulting allied countries about new peace initiatives in Vietnam.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2-- Khalid al-Jundi, one of the Syrian regime's more radical leaders, was removed today as president of the powerful General Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union charged today that corrosion and disrepair of the natural gas system serving St. Louis were causing millions of cubic feet of raw natural gas to flow unrestricted under the city's streets.
THE search for identity flourishes in today's new novels. But, oddly, there seems to be an increasingly clear dilemma at the heart of it.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 2--Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella and the executive director of the city's antipoverty program accused each other today of reneging on a proposed jobrecruitment program here.
Mayor Lindsay, in shirtsleeves, drew friendly crowds of young people, mainly Negroes, and a number of hard-toanswer adult questions during a walking tour in three Bronx areas yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 2-- Strong southerly winds, blowing from 20 to 25 knots, caused the committee today to cancel the smaller yachts in the third day of action in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual race week.

GRONINGEN, The Netherlands, Aug. 2 (AP)--Ada Kok, an international competitor from the Netherlands, broke her own world record for the women's 200-meter butterfly swim today with a time of 2 minutes 22.5 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --The National Aeornautics and Space Administration selected the North American Aviation Rocketdyne Division, Canoga Park, Calif., today to design a new type of propellant injector for the engine that is to lift Apollo astronauts off the moon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)--The House Commerce Committee rejected today a Republican move to kill President Johnson's proposal for a Public Broadcasting Corporation to establish noncommercial radio and television networks.

Raymond H. Fiero, an investment broker and president of the Faith Home foundation, a Brooklyn charitable foundation for persons with incurable diseases, died yesterday at his home, 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. He was 90 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (UPI)--Willie Mays, still convalescing from the flu, drove in three runs today with his 15th homer of the season and a double while leading the San Francisco Giants to a 7-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates
Stock-exchange tapes ran late yesterday before the goggle-cyed gaze of traders and investors as prices moved to new 1967 highs on surging volume.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2--The American legal profession stepped up its campaign today to reform the probate system, which has come under fire from critics led by Norman F. Dacey, author ofu the best-selling book "How to Avoid Probate!"

WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Aug. 2 (AP)--Ray W. Kline, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh in New York, died of a heart attack while on a pack trip in the Madison Range, some 30 miles from here. He was 65 years old. The trip was sponsored by the University of Montana Foundation.

A mid-July Presidential "trial heat" poll gives President Johnson a margin of support over Gov. Ronald Reagan of California that is not much greater than an earlier survey gave the President over Gov. George Romney of Michigan and Richard M. Nixon, according to an article in yesterday's Washington Post by Dr. George Gallup, the poll taker.

Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, presented to Sandy Dennis yesterday the silver medal and certificate she won last month at the Moscow Film Festival for best actress.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 2--A proposal for a cease-fire in Yemen that the United Arab Republic plans to lay before the Arab foreign ministers' conference would entail a withdrawal of Egyptian troops from Yemen, authoritative sources said today.

HARTFORD, Aug. 2--A state's attorney here reported today that his investigation into the financial affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd showed that the Senator had not violated Connecticut's Corrupt Practices Act. Mr. Dodd, a Democrat, was censured by the Senate.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (UPI) --Nancy Moore, 24 years old, who set herself afire last July 4, died today in the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --President Johnson has appointed Graham J. Morgan of Chicago as vice chairman of the newly formed President's Committee on Urban Housing, the White House announced today.

Mayor Lindsay's proposals to reduce the controversial stock transfer tax were put together following a bitter fight last March between his administration and the New York Stock Exchange. The fight had threatened to damage the city economically and the Mayor politically.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 --Mrs. E.C.K. Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan, the champion in 1965, defeated Mrs. Mary C. Bartol of Stanwych, the defending champion, 5 and 4, in the quarter-final round of the 42d annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship tournament at Siwanoy Country Club today.

Mr. Hershey, who sailed on the Peace Ship when he was a 19-year-old reporter, puts down an impressionistic picture of that bizarre adventure. It began when Henry Ford, the self-confident maker of the Model T, had two visitors in Detroit. They were Mrs. Roszika Schwimmer of Hungary, originator of a plan for mediating World War I, and Louis P. Lochner, then agent of the Carnegie Peace Endowment arid later a noted journalist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) --A lawyer for a Texas Rio Grande Valley farm challenged Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York today to take a survey among workers to see if they wanted a collective bargaining election.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --A Houston physician, a Welsh physicist teaching in Florida and a Northwestern University astronomer are among a dozen or more men due to be astronauts.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 --The question was probably asked a thousand times at Monmouth Park today. The wife turned to the husband and said, "Well, dear, what do you think?"

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 2 (Ap)--The pro-Castro Army of National Liberation sharply attacked the Colombian Communist party today for its moderate policies and declared that armed revolution was "the only way left for the people to reach power."
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 2 (UPI)--Lunar orbiter 5, designed to take pictures of possible astronaut landing sites on the moon, sped toward its target today while scientists plotted its course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--J. Edward Day, a former Postmaster General of the United States and former Insurance Commissioner of Illinois, warned the Congress today that the insurance industry, as well as a major part of the mutual fund industry, is threatened by a Government proposal to outlaw one par ticular kind of mutual fund
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- The latest Government report on sonic boom tests tends to reinforce the widespread belief that supersonic airliners will not be allowed to fly at top speed over land.

BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Aug. 2--A simple routine enabling striped-bass anglers, drifting in boats, to thrive on the Cape Cod Canal's west end is making a sizable dent in this community's timehonored surfcasting activity.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 2 --Windigo, the 71 -foot yawl that continues to win her share of important events for Walter S. Gubelmann of Oyster Bay, L.I., gained the Clucas Cup today for being the fastest yacht on the New York Yacht Club cruise run.
A guideline for riot precautions was distributed to 15,000 department and specialty stores throughout the country yesterday by the National Retail Merchants Association.
NEWARK Aug. 2--A familyowned network of 20 companies, including companies operating in New York and New Jersey, were placed in the hands of a court-appointed trustee last night.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 2 (UPI)--The California Assembly passed today a bill removing single-family dwellings from the state's fair-housing law after rejecting attempts to repeal the controversial messure.
GUILFORD COLLEGE, N.C., Aug. 2--The fourth Internation, al Conference of Friends (Quakers) called on the "peoples of the world" today to "demand" an end to the Vietnam war.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 2 --City officials here are giving at least part credit for quieting racial disturbances involving small groups of people to a disabling gas that was not even used.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation will increase its prices on tinplate and blackplate, following the direction of the National Steel Corporation, it was learned yesterday.
A prefabricated swimming pool, the first of 10 that the Parks Department is installing in vacant lots in the city's slums, was dedicated in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn yesterday.

CAIRO, Aug. 2 (AP)--Egyptian officials were reported today to be going ahead with plans to donate the 2,000-yearold temple of Dendur to the United States despite Cairo's decision to break diplomatic relations during the Middle Eastern war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The United States Government is closely following an attempt by about 150 white mercenaries and several hundred Katangan allies to escape through Bukavu, in the eastern Congo, into neighboring Rwanda.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 2--Agricultural production in the territory on the west bank of the Jordan River is to be adjusted next season to the economic realities created by the Israeli conquest.

It represents neither constitutional reform nor public-spirited compromise. The Rockefeller Brothers Fund made $6,669,940 in contributions last year, the fund's annual report said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted unanimously today to leave unimpaired the authority of the Export-Import Bank to make loans for arms purchases by underdeveloped countries. However, the committee voted to limit the total amount of such loans.
Stock prices continued to advance in heavy trading yesterday, but late profit taking caused prices to close below their highest levels of the day.

MIJO, a powerful St. Bernard from Anchorage, Alaska, is America's dog hero of the year.
Prices showed little change yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

If the day comes, we hope to be ready."
The World Bank announced plans yesterday to sell $150million of bonds.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 2--Three Israeli soldiers were injured today in the second day of shooting across the Jordan River.

Francis J. Nulty, technical coordinator of Todd Shipyards Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 4020 Avenue D, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--All or nearly all of the private schools that have been organized in the South in an effort to maintain segregation will be entitled to tax exemption, at least for the present, under a ruling issued by the Internal Revenue Service tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- The executive director of the President's Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders said today that J. Edgar Hoover told the commission yesterday that "outside agitators" had played a role in this summer's Negro riots.
Two large New York banks announced yesterday the election of six new vice presidents.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP)-- General Motors Corporation announced today that it had reached agreement in principle with the Justice Department on a consent decree under which G.M. would sell a portion of its Euclid division.
Clair William Ditchy, former president of the American Institute of Architects, died Tuesday at William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 76 years old.
NHABE, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 3--Vietcong mortar crews struck this morning against a Shell Oil Company storage area in this village eight miles southeast of downtown Saigon.

BOSTON, Aug. 2--Mayor James H.J. Tate of Philadelphia asserted today that "there is no panic in any City Hall in America." But he warned that without help from other sectors of society in resolving problems in the ghetto, "no one can view the future of urban America with confidence."
CINCINNATT, Aug. 2 (UPI)-- Pete Rose hit two home runs and Lee May one, powering the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The powerful mind-affecting drug called STP has been identified by the Food and Drug Administration as an experimental compound developed by a major chemical company.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UPI)-- Crudely made Molotov cocktails touched off fires in two stores early today on the city's South Side. Firebombs failed to explode in at least five other stores.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 2--Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. reorganized the Florida Land Installment Sales Board today and ordered it to "clean up" any irregularities in the $200million-a-year land boom in Florida.
WYANDANCH, L.I., Thursday, Aug. 3--Minor fire damage was reported last night on the second day of scattered street incidents in this predominantly Negro suburb.

A secretary in a small Brooklyn insurance company was shot and killed at work yesterday afternoon by a suitor she had declined to date any longer, the police said. The man then shot himself fatally in the head.

MIAMI, Aug. 2 (AP)--A three-judge Federal court ordered today a realignment of Florida's Congressional districts based on popularity equality.
Investors kept the American Stock Exchange bubbling yesterday, expanding trading volume to the third largest on record.

THE recent Clare Benedict Team Tournament, held in the Swiss mountain resort of Leysin, was won by West Germany, which scored 13 game points out of a possible 20. An eight-month training program that will provide guaranteed jobs for 500 unemployed youths and better jobs for about 650 low-skill workers here was announced yesterday by Mitchell Sviridoff, administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration.

Central Park's summer bicycling hours will be extended to the winter to encourage sledding and sleighriding, Parks Commissioner August Heckscher said yesterday. WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--A plan for writing a Vietnam peace plank into the 1968 Presidential platform of the Democratic party has been circulated among 300 of the party's most influential liberals.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug 2 (AP)--The development of a series of steel alloys that can be stretched two to five times more than current highstrength steels was announced today at the University of California.

FOR more than 50 years, the International Olympic Committee has been trying to draft a rule saying who is and who is not an amateur. So far, the problem is unsolved. Justice Frederick Backer of State Supreme Court refused yesterday to enjoin the Port of New York Authority from furnishing television facilities on the top of the World Trade Center.
