WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- The director of the National Teachers Corps said today that yesterday's vote in the Senate, trimming $14.9-million from the corps' budget, would reduce by 1,000 the number of teachers to be trained for jobs in city slum schools in the next year.
Bill Talbert, former United States Davis Cup player and coach, will conduct a free tennis clinic for New Jersey youngsters from l0 A.M. to noon tomorrow at Branch Brook Park in Newark.
NASHVILLE, Aug. 3--The head of a "liberation school" for Negro children here today defended the federally financed establishment and called Captain Sorace "a white racist cracker cop."

It started early in the morning, with a phone ringing in Ralph Houk's house in Saddle River, N.J. The call was from Lee MacPhail, the general manager of the New York Yankees and Houk's boss. MacPhail was in Chicago, where it was even an hour earlier, attending the major league meetings.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP)-- Simultaneous meetings of members of the Seafarers International Union today gave approval in principle to a strike by the union against 32 inland and east coast shipping companies.
The formation of a new professional football league was announced yesterday by Joe Rosentover, the former commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Football League.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--Jordanian and Israeli forces exchanged fire over the Jordan River near the Damier Bridge this morning, a Jordanian military spokesman announced.

Supreme Court Justice George M. Carney issued a permanent injunction yesterday preventing the removal of two young girls to Israel by their mother, who was divorced from the girls' father and has remarried.

ROME, Aug. 3--The Vatican has decided that the new Dutch catechism does not contain heresies, but it is nevertheless holding up translation of the work into other languages because of certain "necessary" corrections and clarifications, the Roman Catholic newspaper L'Avvenire d'Italia of Bologna said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- President Johnson broke his public silence today on his handling of the dispatch of Federal troops to Detroit on July 24.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3-- The Government has made public parts of its projected Defense Against Communism law, which would blacklist Communists, prohibit anyone on the list from holding public office and set forth norms for Argentine judges in deciding What degree of Communism constituted a punishable offense.

Transferring full responsibility for the administration of local welfare programs to the state, now under consideration at the Constitutional Convention, makes sense for reasons that go beyond the great weight it would life off overstrained municipal budgets--$265million a year in this city alone.
Mottle Podell, inventor and engineer, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital, New York City. He was 87 years old and lived at 890 West End Avenue and in Northport, L.I.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)-- American League club owners voted unanimously tonight for Eastern and Western divisional breakdowns in baseball, but the National League owners asked for more time to study the proposal.
Federal and city detectives last night arrested two Queens men and confiscated $9,800 believed to have been stolen earlier in the day from a Long Island City savings and loan association.

Haiti is so beautiful; her people are so appealing-- and she has one of the worst governments this side of the inferno. Today's dispatch from Times correspondent Henry Giniger describes the latest dramatic twists in a situation that was so bad it could get little worse than it has been.
The scope of President Johnson's tax proposal was known by some Wall Street traders well before it was officially unveiled at noon yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay reacted yes-- terday with enthusiasm to a proposal made in Albany that New York State assume the city's $265-million share of the annual welfare bill here. The total iS now more than $913million, of which the Federal and state governments contribute the remainder.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 3--A golden halo studded with precious stones was stolen last night from a statue of the Virgin Mary in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, one of Christendom's holiest sites.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3--A group of citizens from Glassboro, N.J., site of the June discussions between President Johnson and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, packed tonight to leave for home, disappointed at the failure of plans to meet Mr. Kosygin.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 3 --In Hans Werner Henze's "Boulevard Solitude," the Santa Fe Opera has a rare item on its hands, a successful contemporary opera. Audience approval was loud and clear at the first American performpance last night in the imrovised opera house the company has constructed in the Santa Fe high school gymnasium (its own house burned to the ground last week).

MRS. LYNDON S. JOHN SON arrived in New York yesterday morning for what was described as "a day of fall shopping" wearing a brown cotton twill suit with matching brown and white striped silk blouse by Adele Simpson, black kid mediumheeled pumps, and a black handbag. She did not wear a hat.
With relatively little dissent, the American business community supported President Johnson yesterday in his call for a 10 per cent surtax on corporate and personal income.
BONN, Aug. 3--West Germany and Czechoslovakia signed a treaty today for the exchange of trade missions with limited consular functions. The missions will have diplomatic status.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 3--If enacted by Congress as proposed by President Johnson, the Administration's new tax bill would affect individuals as follows:

The stock market went on a roller-coaster ride yesterday. Prices fell sharply in midsession in reaction to President Johnson's proposals for increases in personal and corporate income taxes, then made a quick turnaround in a strong afternoon rally that substantially trimmed earlier losses.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 3 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David O'Koon of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Frances O'Koon, to Richard T. Ernenwein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood T. Ernenwein of New York and Carmel.

In nearly every respect, the House Foreign Affairs Committee has approved a foreign-aid authorization superior to the niggardly bill voted by its Senate counterpart last week. The hope now must be that Chairman Thomas E. Morgan can steer his measure through House debate reasonably intact and then hold the line against Senate wreckers in conference committee.

Mayor Lindsay is recruiting civic leaders to become members of a new organization-- the New York Coalition--designed to unite corporations, unions, churches and other private organizations in an attack on the problems of the city's slums.
HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)-- Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter, one of the nation's original seven astronauts, is leaving the space program to do deep-sea research for the Navy, it was announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The creation of 14 life peerages, including two for women, was announced today from 10 Downing Street. They are part of Prime Minister Wilson's plan for increasing representation of the Labor party in the House of Lords.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3-- Ingrid Bergman returned to the scene of many triumphs today after a 10-year absence to star snot in a movie but a play, Eugene O'Neill's "More Stately Mansions."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)--More American mothers are working outside the home than ever before, according to a Labor Department survey.
The damaged aortic valve of a 38-year-old man has been replaced with a valve of a calf at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- Democratic liberals who want to reduce the war in Vietnam are studying a plea to avoid using their strength for third party candidates, "Dump Johnson" movements and "Draft Kennedy-Fulbright" drives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The United States explained today that it had exercised its legal rights in blocking the projected sale by the British Government of six British-built Canberra fighter bombers to Peru. The sum involved was approximately $2.5-million.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3--The Spingold Master Knockout Team Championships, the most highly regarded event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, began here last night with an entry of 104 teams.
SILVER SPRING, Md., Aug. 3--Miss Marcia Louise Andersen and David Wilder Welles have made plans to be married on Sept. 23.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 3--Two United States Air Force planes continued flying Congolese soldiers and equipment to Bukavu today to help the Congolese Army in its attempt to prevent white mercenary rebels from breaking through to safety in neighboring Rwanda.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3 (UPI) --Heartened by a reduction in firebombings, sniping and looting, officials have begun to withdraw National Guardsmen from the city.
Rosser Reeves has set up a "think tank" he hopes will become for "corporate business what the Rand Corporation is for Washington."

BONN, Aug. 3--Paul Lobe, a leading figure of the Social Democratic party during the Weimar Republic and President of the Reichstag from 1920 until 1932, died here today at the age of 91. He had been hospitalized since July.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it will resume negotiations with prospective buyers, including the White Motor Corporation, for the sale of certain assets of G.M.'s Euclid Road Machinery Company Division.
Behind the accounts that make up the nation's budget lies the pursuit of America's responsibility and purpose at home and abroad.
PARIS, Aug. 3 (AP)--Defense Minister Pierre Messmer said today that France's first hydrogen bomb test next year would be in the 500-kiloton category.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3--Half a hundred young football players, fresh from college, will be asked to perform at least respectably here tomorrow night when they take on a group of baldish older men, who compose one of the finest teams in the world, the Green Bay Packers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 --President Johnson asked Congress today for a 10 per cent surcharge on personal and corporate income taxes, excepting only those individuals with the lowest incomes.
An extra charge for some copper products was posted yesterday by the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation, a fabricating subsidiary of the strike-beset Phelps Dodge Corporation.
The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday a record net income in the second quarter and first half this year that included a nonrecurring capital gain.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 3 (AP)-- A twin-engine plane with Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas and seven other persons aboard landed here safely today after circling for nearly an hour with a stuck landing gear.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI)--The Chicago Cubs signed Manager Leo Durocher to a new twoyear contract with an increase estimated at $10,000-a-year today for keeping the club in pennant contention. But the Atlanta Braves clouted seven home runs to rout the Cubs, 10-3, and send them six games behind the first-place St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- Officials of four major securities industry organizations told the Congress today that mutual fund sales charges could be successfully regulated by the National Association of Securities dealers.

HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- Thad Spencer, one of four heavyweights who will participate in an Astrodome boxing double-header Saturday says he was upset by the silent treatment given him by his opponent, Ernie Terrell.

PEKING, Aug. 3 (Agence France Presse)--Tao Chu, a former leader of the Cultural Revolution, was named in the press here today as the "criminal mastermind organizing and animating the fight against the Cultural Revolution" at Wuhan and in the whole of South China.

James Felt, the former chairman of the City Planning Commission, was appointed chairman yesterday of the Public Development Corporation, an agency charged with attracting new industry to the city and retaining the industry already here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--Le Thanh Nghe, a former South Vietnamese Minister named at a United States Senate hearing as having received $896,258 in improper commissions from American drug concerns, denied today that he had been involved in illegal transactions.

LONDON, Aug. 3--Most of London's theater critics gave warm praise to "America Hurrah," the Off Broadway production that opened last night before English Stage Society members at the Royal Court Theater.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 3 (AP)--Gov. Otto Kerner signed bills today designed to step up the war against crime in Illinois, including controls over possession of guns and an antilooting measure.

Mrs. Anne Fisher Holtzmann, an expert on election law and a leader of the League of Women Voters, died of cancer yesterday in the Harkness Pavillion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 44 years old and lived at 519 Alda Road, Mamaroneck.

Bond prices climbed late yesterday morning under the impact of President Johnson's request for a 10 per cent surcharge on Federal income taxes. Later, however, Govern- ment and corporate bonds lost some of their gains after it was reported that Congress would move slowly to enact the President's tax request.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) --Thurgood Marshall's nomination to become the first Negro Supreme Court Justice cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee today, with all five Southern members voting against him.
An Eastern Airlines shuttle flight to Washington--with Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson aboard-- was cleared of its 110 passengers and searched yesterday after a man had phoned the airline and said:

A tough-minded, disturbing but occasionally funny documentary about the plight of the American nurse in an age of increasing specialization was presented by the American Broadcasting Company last night in "Nurses: Crisis in Medicine." The program had originally been scheduled for June 9 but had been preempted by a news special on the Mideast crisis.
ESSEN, West Germany, Aug. 3--Alfried Krupp was buried in the family shrine today as the 100,000 workers in Krupp plants throughout West Germany put down their tools for a minute's tribute.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3-- About 250 Philadelphia businessmen pledged today to hire more than 1,500 of the city's unemployed persons in an effort to relieve racial tension.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) --A thorough investigation of "the conduct and effectiveness of the air war in North Vietnam" was announced today by the Senate Defense subcommittee.

AS the fires of Newark, Detroit and Milwaukee die down, and as others are kindling, recrimination brings angry explanation. So it was in Watts in August 1965. One Senator insisted that the violence had been organized by "groups under Havana and Peking influence"; another blamed "a small group of trained troublemakers."
PARIS, Aug. 3--South Korea apologized to France today for the way its agents "repatriated" eight Koreans in June, and promised that the five still absent would be permitted to return here.
WASHINGTON--In 1858, Prospect House, one of Georgetown's oldest and most historic homes, was sold for a little under $5,000.
It was an old story of rats, roaches, rot, slumlords and stench, but East Harlem tenants telling it to the Mayor's Mobile Action team yesterday could do so in Spanish.

ROOSEVELT, L.I., Aug. 3-- Landlords of homes here described by the State Rent Commissioner and Town of Hempstead officials as slum dwellings denied today that their buildings were overcrowded, dilapidated, unsanitary or dangerous.
The first American television crew to enter Communist China has emerged with 9,800 feet of sound color film. They had to use a ruse to get it.
The Manhattan Shirt Company announced here yesterday the appointment of William J. McKenna to the new post of executive vice president of its men's division.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--New York has the most severe air pollution problem of any major metropolitan area in the nation, the Public Health Service re- ported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)--For about 20 minutes today, President Johnson relived his days as a young Texas schoolteacher in a flurry of arm waving, finger pointing, clapping and chalk dust.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The United States will sign a previously announced agreement tomorrow to provide Israel with about $27.5-million in agricultural commodities.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (UPI)--A man under the influence of LSD and marijuana drilled a hole into his skull in the belief he would be able to conquer time, a psychiatrist reported today.
Despite nearly complete agreement between the New York Telephone Company and striking city installers and repairmen, some 15,700 workers are expected to remain off their jobs today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3--The South Vietnamese presidential campaign opened today with pledges from two civilian tickets that they would try to open immediate negotiations with North Vietnam if they were elected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Senator Carl Hayden pleaded today that Congress give his state of Arizona the water project that he has sought for 25 years. But the multimillion dollar project to transport Colorado River water across Arizona appeared to be dead for this year.

A group that might be called the silver watchers will have their day today when the General Services Administration takes bids for four million ounces of Government silver from a selected list of users.

WASHINGTON Aug. 3--A Nashville police captain testified today that the Federal Government was subsidizing a "liberation school" in his city that taught "unadulterated hatred" of whites and was run by an official of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman has urged President Johnson to postpone delivery to India of one-third of the 1.5 million tons of food grains authorized by Congressional resolution.
A probationary patrolman was killed yesterday when he fell from the room of a sixstory Bronx building in an attempt to enter his top-floor apartment.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 3--Israel and the United Arab Republic have agreed to a one-month cessation of navigation on the Suez Canal.
Fifty-two policewomen will be assigned experimentally to stationhouses, beginning at 4 o'clock today, to replace men assisting desk lieutenants.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 3--Harold W. Davis, a retired New York stockbroker and a former town supervisor of Pelham, died today at the age of 79 in New Rochelle Hospital.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 3--The Suffolk County Council of the Boy Scouts of America has arranged an excursion on Aug. 12 to Gardiners Island, where Robert D. L. Gardiner, who inherited the property from his family, will conduct visitors on a tour. He is on the council's executive board.
NEWARK, Aug. 3--Representatives of seven New Jersey cities and the state met here today to discuss the causes of racial conflict and how to prevent it.

Negro experts in penology and criminology will meet in Harlem next month for a fiveday conference. They will discuss juvenile delinquency, crime prevention and the possibility of establishing communications between residents of slum areas, the police and other city authorities.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

LAKE BLUFF, Ill., Aug. 3 (AP)--Patty Reese, the upset specialist from St. Petersburg, Fla., and Kristien Kemmer of San Diego, Calif., advanced to the final today of the National girls' 16-and-under tennis tournament.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3 --A rainstorm halted play today in the Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club, and the officials decided to revamp drastically, the match-play event in an effort to adhere to the schedule that calls for a final on Sunday.

PARIS, Aug. 3--People get so cross at Hubert de Givenchy. Among the crossest are some Americans now in Paris to report on the new fall-winter haute-couture collections. For Givenchy's clothes make this a mean job.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Senate Finance Committee voted today to instruct its staff to draft a bill providing for direct Government financing of Presidential and Senate election campaigns.
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., is planning to add steamship operations to its diversified activities in films, minerals, auto parts, hardware and sugar.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3-- As the lightning crackled overhead, and cars stood bumper to bumper waiting for an attendant to park them, the early arrivals at Monmouth Park today left their private benches and beach chairs and dashed inside.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- President Johnson announced plans today to dispatch 45,000 to 50,000 more American troops to Vietnam, beyond the number already committed. This will bring the total to 525,000 by June 30, he said.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 3 (AP)--Lieut. Col. Richard A. Rowden Jr. of Lackland Air Force Base, Tex., became the world skeet champion with a 20-gauge gun yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI)-- --Labron Harris Jr., the son of the Oklahoma State University golf coach, Bob Stanton of Australia and Bob Verwey of South Africa shot 5-under-par 66's today to share the first-round lead in the $102,000 Western open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked for reconsideration today of a recent Govermnent order cutting its long-distance rates by 3 per cent and imposing other changes in the prices the company charges and the profits it will be permitted to earn.
An economy-design general utility ship that could carry all types of cargo for the merchant marine was proposed yesterday by a leading naval architectural concern, J.J. Henry Co., Inc.

HONOLULU, Aug. 3--Justice Byron R. White questioned today whether the Supreme Court's critics were raising a relevant legal issue when they complained that recent decisions were making criminal convictions more difficult to obtain.

Mrs. Sylvia Weinick of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and Milton Weinick of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Lynn Weinick, to Roger Marc Levine. He is the son of the late George N. Levine, a lawyer, and Mrs. Abraham D. Levy of Roslyn Heights. Mr. Levine's stepfather, a former justice of the State Supreme Court, is Public Administrator of Bronx County.
DENVER, Aug. 3--The sale of stock bearing on control of The Denver Post was defended in a Federal court suit today by one of the architects of the deal.
A Negro surgeon who charged Columbia University with racial prejudice in its handling of personnel at Harlem Hospital has dropped his complaint with the city's Human Rights Commission.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3-- A United States grand jury met here today to consider testimony from a local teamster official, Edward Grady Partin of Baton Rouge, that he had been offered a "million dollar bribe" to change the testimony that he gave in the 1964 trial of James R. Hoffa, former president of the teamsters union, on charges of jury tampering.
Street lights and movie marquees, automobile headlights and store signs flickered on before noon yesterday as towering thunderclouds brought night-time darkness to the mid-day city.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 3 --President Chung Hee Park proposed today to send 3,000 South Korean reservists to South Vietnam this year to release American and South Korean support troops for combat duty.

The Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall put an intimate foot forward at its second concert last night, a chamber-music evening presided over by the Hungarian Quartet and agreeably enlivened by the guest appearance of the clarinetist David Glazer.
Elston Howard, the first Negro to play for the New York Yankees and one of the last links to their triumphant past, was traded yesterday to the Boston Red Sox.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3--The program of matches in the Eastern grass courts tennis championships was postponed today because of rain and the entire quarter-final round in the men's and women's singles was scheduled for tomorrow by Don Hobart, the tournament chairman.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 3-- An electrical storm caused the cancellation of today's scheduled racing of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's cruise week series.
The New York County Democratic organization began yesterday a drive to involve more young men and women in party affairs.
STRATFORD, Ont., Aug. 3 --The Stratford Festival box office is booming this year ($1-million in the till already). The festival's production of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" is one reason why.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP)-- Gov. George Romney said today that if the Detroit situation continues to "go smoothly," all remaining National Guard troops called into the city to quell rioting last week would leave by early next week.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 2--President Francois Duvalier's struggle to maintain his 10-year dictatorship has caused open conflict within his own family.

NEWARK, Aug. 3--A demand by the Office of Economic Opportunity for the immediate suspension of Willie Wright as a trustee of the United Community Corporation, Newark's antipoverty agency, was rejected tonight by the corporation's executive committee.

The 79-year-old Jackson Square Library at 251 West 13th Street in Greenwich Village is under contract of sale to a Long Island couple who plan to convert it into a residence. The library is off Jackson Square, near the intersection of Greenwich and Eighth Avenues.

The American Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that the administration of Gov. Richard J. Hughes was using "harassment and intimidation" to prevent the union's New Jersey affiliate and the Federally financed Newark Legal Services Project from collecting evidence of destruction of Negro-owned shops by the police during the recent Newark riots.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 --Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, who had won the qualifying medal, defeated Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow, 6 and 5, today at Siwanoy Country Club in a semi-final match of the 42d annual women's Westchester--and--Fairfield Golf Association championship tournament.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3--Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. McGuire have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Anne McGuire, to Robert Omer Herrmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Omer W. Herrmann of Bethesda, Md.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 3-- Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon of the Southern District of New York and Mrs. MacMahon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Ann MacMahon, to Jerome Paul Kenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Kenney of Newton Highlands, Mass.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3--American combat casualties dropped last week to their lowest level in six months, a United States command spokesman said today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 3--The State Senate voted an appropriation of $670,000 today for Tuskegee Institute. Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace had failed to include state support for the predominantly Negro private college in her recommended education budget.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3--The Saratoga Performing Arts Center, now in its second season, is the permanent summer home of two organizations. Last Sunday the New York City Ballet packed its tutus, leotards, ballet slippers, its glittering costumes and sets, and went on its way after giving 21 performances in July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- The Labor Department today awarded a $300,000 grant to an organization of Negro youths in Washington that will hire 900 teen-aged boys for a monthlong slum clean-up and rat control program. The youths will receive $56 a week through August.

The exhibition soccer game scheduled for tonight in Yankee Stadium between the New York Generals of the National Professioual Soccer League and Atletica Portuguesa of Brazil has been canceled.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- Congress scrutinized President Johnson's tax-increase program today with a mixture of resignation, pain and hostility.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3--John Nerud, trainer of the Tartan Stable's Dr. Fager, said today that the 3-year-old colt had suffered a recurrence of a virus condition that affected him over the weekend. Because of the illness, Nerud has had to cancel the training program of the horse and Dr. Fager will not run in the $75,000 added Travers on Aug. 19.
WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 3 (AP)--Harvard's eight defeated Canada's crew in a head-tohead duel of unbeaten heavyweights today in the preliminary rowing trials of the PanAmerican Games.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3--Early in July, an exhausted Marine infantryman-- a survivor of an ambush near the demilitarized zone in which nearly 100 of his companions were killed and more than 200 were wounded--shook his head and said, "Man, we need help."
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said yesterday:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy will make his debut on his own series of television programs in New York State in the week beginning Aug. 13.

President Johnson gave Congress dubious economic advice in yesterday's tax message. Neither his assessment of national priorities nor his prescription for economic health squares with the country's real needs in this anxious period.
Four leading directors have signed contracts to stage four short plays for a national tour by a company of deaf actors. The tour will be the first commercial venture of its kind.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 3--Gone Flyin', who has won six of seven championships this year, and The Actor--the only horse in the country who has beaten him--each won an open jumper class today at the Orange County Fair Horse Show.
Paul (Don Paolo) Gambino, elder brother of Carlo Gambino, who is head of the Mafia family bearing their name, was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn on charges of possessing stolen goods.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 3 --Intrepid, the new 12-Meter America's Cup defense candidate, and Bolero, a 73-foot yawl that has been a leading campaigner for cruising-yacht honors since she was launched 18 years ago, made off with the main silverware at today's New York Yacht Club cruise sailing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Forty Republican lawmakers urged President Johnson today to organize a White House "crisis center" to deal with racail riots.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- President Johnson tried to discourage the formation of a new coalition by leaders of the United States Conference of Mayors, it was disclosed today.

WYANDANCH, L.I., Aug. 3 --Nightly movies, a championship basketball game and a gripe session were hurriedly advertised today among young persons in this predominantly Negro hamlet in an effort to avoid more incidents of scattered violence.

The city's abandonment of the practice of assigning religions to foundlings is a progressive step that will greatly facilitate placing such children in the best homes available to them. The over-all welfare of the child, rather than the faith in which he will be reared, should be the dominant consideration.

AVIGNON, France, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--Stimulant drugs could have contributed to the death of Tom Simpson, a top British cyclist, during the Tour de France last month, an official medical report said today.
ALBANY, Friday, Aug. 4 (AP)-- State Police Superintendent Arthur Cornelius Jr. died early this morning in the Albany Medical Center, where he had undergone chest surgery on Tuesday.
Investors maintained a brisk trading pace on the American Stock Exchange again yesterday and prices, extending Wednesday's trend, edged a bit lower.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (UPI)-- The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and five of its members filed suits in Federal court here today to stop local courts from prosecuting them.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP) --Mayor Herbert Quinn was convicted by the Board of Aldermen tonight of misconduct in office and was removed from his post.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) --The Federal Communications Commission exempted news broadcasts and on-the-spot news coverage today from the "personal attack" provisions of its fairness doctrine.
The United States Weather Bureau, at 11.P.M. yesterday, made this forecast for Long Island Sound, Montauk Point to Block Island Sound, New York Harbor, the lower Hudson River and nearby waters:
DETROIT, Aug. 3--The General Motors Corporation took the offensive today in new contract bargaining with the United Automobile Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended July 29 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 3 (AP)--John Newcombe of Australia and Wilhelm Bungert of West Germany moved a step closer to a rematch of last month's Wimbledon final today, when both advanced to the quarter-finals of the International West German hard court tennis championship.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- Senator John J. Williams said today that the Treasury had uncovered widespread evasion of the income tax laws on concealed political campaign contributions.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3--William Haggin Perry's excellent California campaigner, Gamely, contributed a record-breaking performance today in winning a division of the Test Stakes. Opposing seven others in the seven-furlong race for 3-yearold fillies, Gamely covered the distance in 1:21 4-5, while beating her nearest rival, Wageko, by six lengths.
BATTING the proposed surtax around the analysts' circuit yesterday brought a mixed bag of reactions. The point of view depended on the industry and on accounting techniques within industries.
Borrowing by business from major New York City banks took the sharpest one-week drop in more than 3 years in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The Health Department said yesterday it had begun a search throughout radio-television stores here for defective color television tubes that could be a source of radiation danger.

AREA A--A few tuna in the 35-to-50 pound range have been taken by the Barnegat Light fleet about 20 miles east and southeast of the light. School tuna are in evidence but have not shown much interest in lures. Bottom fishermen have been faring well with sea bass and ling offshore at the wrecks.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum are planning a series of joint projects--exhibitions, loans of major works and pooling of personnel--in a program of cooperation unmatched in the history of each institution.

HAVANA, Aug. 3--The saddest thing about the Cuban revolution is that it is teaching hate and violence to the young. A remarkable new generation of Cubans, more literate and disciplined than any other, is being indoctrinated systematically with the idea that the United States is the embodiment of everything that is narrow, selfish, and evil in the world today.
The Lindsay administration has declined to assure the New York Stock Exchange that the city stock-transfer tax will not be raised in the future, informed sources said yesterday.

Extensive highway construction at nine strategic points in the metropolitan area is expected to cause severe traffic delays this weekend for the thousands of motorists who will be entering and leaving the city.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)-- Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, tells of the agonizing death of her father but dismisses any idea of a "doctors' plot" against the Soviet dictator in a Russian-language version of her memoirs just published here.

Dr. David H. Webster, an ophthalmologist and a former vice president of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, died, on Wednesday in Portland, Me. He was 81 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.
TRENTON, Aug. 3--The Newark College of Medicine and Dentistry has agreed in principle to use a major part of its proposed Newark campus for an urban welfare center in the Negro slums.

TULIP HILL, Md., Aug. 3 --Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Samuel Smith have announced the engagements of their twin daughters, the Misses Elizabeth Ellen and Winifred Lee Smith, to Capt. Gerald Phillips Tishler, U.S.A., of the Judge Advocate General Corps and to Ira Goldblatt, respectively.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--Mike Andrews drove in three runs with a homer and a single today and led Boston to a 5-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. The triumph moved the second-place Red Sox to within two games of the Chicago White Sox. Chicago was not scheduled to play today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The nation's labor federation said today it would support a tax increase but it expressed reservations about the details of President Johnson's proposal.
ALBANY, Aug. 3 (UPI)-- The Public Service Commission denied today a request by the New York Central Railroad to reduce passenger service between New York City and Buffalo.
HAVANA, Aug. 3 (Reuters)-- Delegates at the conference of the Organization for Latin- American solidarity last night assailed the Soviet Union for helping "dictatorships" in the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) --The National Transportation Safety Board has recommended additional fireproofing in the rudder and vertical fin area of BAC-111 jet airliners to help preevnt in-flight fires in the craft. The board's recommendation was made yesterday during its investigation of the crash June 23 of a Mohawk Airlines BAC-111 near Blossburg, Pa., in which all 34 persons aboard were killed.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 3--Miss Linda Nathan and Richard A. Kuzmack, graduates of Syracuse University, plan to be married this month. Dr. and Mrs. Norman Nathan have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Kuzmack of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Republican Coordinating Committee said today that as part of a Middle East peace settlement the United States should insist on an international guarantee of "innocent" passage through the Strait of Tiran and the Suez Canal.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 3 (AP)--Dick Carter of Boston won the New York Yacht Club event at the Cowes regatta today.

THERE is a word for the type of deal that sent Elston Howard from the New York Yankees to the Boston Red Sox yesterday for "two players to be delivered after the season," and for similar "deferred" trades that have given Ken Boyer and Rocky Colavito to the Chicago White Sox and Steve Barber to the Yankees.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 3-- There will be added incentives for the seasoned trotters in tomorrow night's featured $15,000 AA Junior Free-For-All trot at Roosevelt Raceway. At stake will be berths in the $50,000 American Trotting Championship, a stepping stone to the $100,000 Roosevelt International Trot.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.8 on Wednesday from 96.9 on Tuesday.
The seven major electric utility companies in the state are acting jointly to help develop a breeder reactor, in the quest for cheaper production of nuclear power, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 3--It seems impossible to go into a theater in the commonwealth of Massachusetts without hearing a curtain speech by Ted Shawn. He is the director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and one of the judges in the first Vestris Competition for new choreography, held last night in John Hancock Hall here, and he introduced the evening's work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI)-- The National Safety Council said today that slightly fewer persons were dying on the nation's highways. It reported that in the first six months of 1967 the highway death rate was 5 per 100-million vehicle-miles, as compared with 5.2 in the first six months of 1966.

CENTERPORT, L.I., Aug. 3-- Carolyn Yake, 17 years old, of the Larchmont Yacht Club took the girl's sailing championship of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today by winning the final two races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) United States development of a high-speed passenger train that would ride on a cushion of air would be drastically retarded if the Senate follows the House in reducing funds for the project, Federal officials said today.
PARIS, Aug. 3--Henryk Berlewi, a graphic designer, critic and painter who began experimenting With optical art in the nineteen-twenties, died of cancer here today. He was 72 years old.
ALBANY, Aug. 3--Tax col- lections in the first one-third of the state's fiscal year lagged behind Governor Rockefeller's budget estimates, State Controller Arthur Levitt indicated today.
Mrs. Jacquelyn Foster Haft, a concert singer, and Lee Scheinbart of New York were married here yesterday by Rabbi David Seligson of the Central Synagogue in the rabbi's study.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Chicago should be declared an emergency disaster area before race riots break out, an official of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference said today.
Armour Co., the meat packer, and Gulf Western Industries, Inc., a widely diversified manufacturing and operating company, announced yesterday the election of new presidents.

MINEOLA, L.I, Aug. 3--A sit-in by three candidates from the United For Peace party ended today after the protestors had sat for 26 hours in a Board of Elections office because they had been refused free voter registration lists.

ALBANY, Aug. 3--Ten major gas utilities have been asked by the Public Service Commission to attend a special meeting to discuss ways to reduce the time it takes for utilities to respond to emergency calls on gas leaks.
Late in July 1946, Mr. Lobe recounted his experiences under the Nazis in an interview, and revealed for the first time his part in the July 20, 1944, conspiracy against Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the New York Central, the Pennsylvania and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads to formulate an arrangement under which the bankrupt New Haven would automatically be leased by a merged Penn-Central to assure continued operation of the New Haven.

HONG KONG, Friday, Aug. 4--Chinese troop reenforcements were brought into the area near the border with Hong Kong last night to control demonstrators who several times crossed into Hong Kong territory and threw stones at British soldiers.

LONDON, Aug. 3--A special tribunal declared today that responsibility for the death of 116 children and 28 adults in the Welsh coal-mining town of Aberfan rested entirely with the National Coal Board and nine of its regional and local officials.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 3--Authoritative sources reported that Saudi Arabia reacted favorably to an Egyptian offer made formally today, to end the struggle for power between the two countries in Yemen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- Lieut, Gen. Lewis W. Walt, until recently commander of the Third Marine Amphibious Force in South Vietnam, insisted today that the Marines were successfully dealing with the North Vietnamese threat along the demilitarized zone.
A record 16,264 overseas passengers were cleared by the United States Customs Bureau last Monday at Kennedy International Airport, surpassing the previous high of 14,051 set only a day earlier.
Investors purchased $410.7million of Series E and Series H savings bonds last month, but they redeemed $368-million, the Treasury Department reported yesterday.
Prices drifted lows; yesterday in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) --President Johnson issued an executive order today providing permanent authority to activate any reservists who are not assigned to or participating satisfactorily in units.

HONOLULU, Aug. 4--Spokesmen for the national news media attempted today to persuade the rank and file membership of the American Bar Association that its leaders were moving toward a "disastrous" limitation of press freedom.
KALAMAZOO, Aug. 4 (UPI) --F.D. Robbins of Salt Lake City pulled the biggest upset so far in this year's national juniors and boys tennis tournament today when he downed ton-seeded Zan Guerry.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 4--The biggest project under way on Taiwan today is not another multimillion-dollar industrial installation for the island's rapidly expanding economy but a program to expand the free school system at a cost of $90million over three years.

SHORT HILLS. N.J., Aug. 4 --Edward Meyler Gilroy, a member of the State Civil Service Commission and secretary to Walter E. Edge, late Governor of New Jersey, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 31 Claremont Drive.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 4 --This damp and dreary night had to be marked down as a sorry one for the two pacers who figured to enjoy the $30,000 General Mad Anthony Pace at Brandywine Raceway the most tonight. Dancing David, with Bob Farrington in the sulky, pirouetted to a neck victory over Hope Time, who had a head over the third horse, Skipper Gene.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 4 (AP) --A defense money bill providing mere than $70-billion-- including more than $20-billion for Vietnam war costs--was recommended to the Senate today by its Appropriations Committee.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 4 (AP)--Negro who lost two businesses in fires that accompanied racial rioting in Cambridge July 24 committed suicide today, the Dorchester County Coroner reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4-- The United States is ending its military airlift in the Congo because of Congressional pressure.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 2--Haiti's economy is showing no forward movement, a fact that is contributing greatly to the aura of desperation and disarray that now surrounds the 10-year-old dictatorship of President Francois Duvalier.
A 94-year-old woman was found murdered in her bed yesterday morning in a walkup apartment in Brooklyn.
A Negro surgeon who charged Columbia University with racial prejudice in its handling of personnel at Harlem Hospital has dropped his complaint with the city's Human Rights Commission.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 4 --Easy Money, the national high-point champion, clinched the junior jumper championship and Camelot, who never saw a fence until two years ago, wrapped up the second-year green working hunter title today at the Orange County Fair horse show.

NAZARETH, Israel, Aug. 2-- Until the six-day war, this hill town in Galilee was Israel's largest Arab city, her unofficial Arab capital and, because of its prominence in Christian tradition, a bustline tourist center.
SHOPPING for star anise, fresh basil, feathers by the pound, pickling cucumbers, fresh tuna, pizza dough and kielbasy could be a chore, but not on First Avenue between Seventh and 12th Streets.
A number of motorists--confident that all was well and legal--had their cars parked yesterday on the north side of 52d Street between First Avenue and the East River at 7:30 A.M.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 4 --The Great Lakes bulk ship fleet has declined so that it is no longer able to meet an emergency such as the one in Korea, James A. Hirschfield, president of the Lake Carriers' Association, said today.
"The C.B.S. Evening News With Walter Cronkite" will get a new executive producer after Labor Day, the Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday.

What should the price of silver be? Yesterday traders had their first chance to learn what big commercial users were willing to pay for silver sold at auction by the Government. Bids for the 4 million ounces ranged from $1.29 an ounce, the price at which the Treasury had pegged silver for some years, to $1.81 an ounce.

Ettore De Stefano, editor and publisher from 1923 to 1965 of Gazzette Legale ltalo-American, a monthly bilingual paper that stressed immigration law for Italian-Americans, died yesterday at the home of a son, Dr. Victor De Stefano, at 81 Conklin Street, Farmingdale, L.I. He was 93 years old and lived at 1272 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP)-- Jim Lefebvre's two-base throwing error allowed Gene Alley to score from second with the winning run in the 10th inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates topped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2.
HONG KONG, Aug. 4 (Reuters)--Wounded Chinese soldiers are filling hospitals in the industrial city of Wuhan, in central China, the Canton radio reported today.
DUTCH HARBOR, Alaska, Aug. 4 (UPI)--A Soviet trawler seized by the Coast Guard for violating the United States 12-mile fishing limit was towed into port to day.
The Glen Alden Corporation and the Stanley Warner Corporation have agreed in principle on a merger, the two companies announced last night.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 4 (UPI)--Brig. Gen. William Jefferson Glasgow, the oldest graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, died here early today at the age of 101.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 4-- Miss Mary Anne Tietjen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Carl Tietjen, was married this afternoon to Donald Edward Byrne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Byrne of Forest Lake, Minn.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 4 (AP)--St. Louis blanked Washington, 7--0, and St. Paul shut out Pittsburgh, 7-0, today and advanced to tomorrow's finals in the Printers Union international baseball tournament.
Four major lumber associations reported a 12.8 per cent decline in production for the week ended July 29 compared with the corresponding 1966 week.
BOSTON, Aug. 4--Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, long a critic of White House policy in Vietnam, has resigned from the state Democratic Advisory Council.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 4 --Samuel P. Black, president of the Samuel Black Publishing Company in West Springfield, distributor of newspapers, magazines and books, died yesterday in the Wesson Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in total operating revenues and net income for the first half.

Heinrich Keilholz of Salzburg, Austria, and Mrs. Elfriede Amengual Loeser of Maracay, Venezuela, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Monika Keilholz, to Henry Theobald Bonser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Bonser of Weston, Conn.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 4--White mercenaries who attacked Congolese positions in the Utu area Tuesday have not been sighted since, inform sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4-- President Johnson's antipoverty program, reported to be in deep trouble in Congress, came under new attack today in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

TO come to the point quickly, Dino Buzzati's new novel, "Larger Than Life," is not quite of the order of his memorable anal beautifully fashioned "The Tartar Steppe," though it does possess the same atmosphere of something threatening, friehtenine and mysterious.
Harold E. Mitchell Sr., a retired stockbroker and former president and director of the Jack Waite Mining Company, died Thursday at Elmhurst Hospital. He was 77 years old.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 4 (UPI)--Kathy Whitworth, the leading money-winner on the 1967 tour, shot a one-under-par 71 today and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the 54-hole Midwest open at the Walnut Hill Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 4--Mrs. Edith Andrus Davenport, widow of Representative Frederick Morgan, Davenport, Republican of Utica, N.Y., die yesterday at a nursing home here. She was '93' years old.
American and Brazilian geologists have reported finding evidence that Africa and South America were locked together in a super continent that split apart 200 million years ago.
FARMINGDALE, L.I.--A permanent exhibition center for Israeli-made Industrial products has gone on display here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) --President Johnson announced today that he would nominate Stanley D. Metzger to be chairman of the Tariff Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--On Thanksgiving Day, 1961, Paul Robert Ignatius had just joined his wife and four children around the dinner table when the phone rang. It was the Pentagon calling.

In a transaction that is probably the largest tender offer ever made, Ling-TemcoVought, Inc., a major company in the aerospace industry, is offering to purchase the stock of Greatamerica Corporation, a bank and insurance holding company that owns 81 per cent of Braniff Airways.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 5 --Ground will be broken in early October for a $10.4-million coliseum, the first phase of Nassau County's $46-million John F. Kennedy Education, Cultural and Civic Center at Mitchel Field, the deactivated airbase.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4-- The pro-Moscow Syrian Communist party has used that Syria follow a "wise and farsighted foreign policy avoiding wild and unrealistic slogans."

HONG KONG, Aug. 4--With the situation in Hong Kong relatively quiet, despite three months of Communist agitation against the British authorities, attention has once again focused on the border, where the Chinese Communist Army is maintaining an uneasy peace.
Wall Street stood sharply divided yesterday over a possible curtailment of stock-exchange trading hours to resolve the logjam of paperwork in the back offices of brokerage houses.

The Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens announced yesterday it had received more than $8.3-million in grants to set up a Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood health center in Brooklyn. The clinic will be named for the late Dr. Charles R. Drew, who developed a method for separating plasma from red blood cells on a laree scale.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 4 (AP)--The United States' powerful track and field forces sent the nation's gold-medal harvest past the 100 mark today and shattered seven event records in the Pan-American Games.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 4-- Anguilla, a 35-square-mile island in the Caribbean, redeclared its independence today, closed its small airport and posted patrols along its beaches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--"Millions of Americans are still barred from full participation in the American dream," President Johnson said today as he' swore in Clifford Alexander Jr. as chairman' of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 4--Correspondents for The Associated Press and for Reuters, the British news agency, were ordered today to leave the Congo within 48 hours.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 4 (UPI)--A 17-year-old Knoxville cave explorer was rescued today after being trapped nearly 11 hours in a 70-foot pit a quarter-mile underground.
Auction sales at Parke-Bernet Galleries dropped about $5million last season from the 1965-66 period. The Madison Avenue auction house grossed $18,496,047 for the season that ended in June.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 (UPI)-- With peace restored to a riottorn Negro neighborhood on Milwaukee's Near North Side, Mayor Henry W. Maier moved today to cement relations in the community.
Seamen of the National Maritime Union last night called off a strike against three freighters of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines after a hearing before an arbitrator.
One of the city's rat patrols pulled up in its poison-laden blue and white panel truck yesterday in front of a Harlem tenement building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) --The parents of Victoria McCammon represented the United States at the Budapest International Fair last year while their daughter was one of President Johnson's personal secretaries.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 4-- The engagement of Miss Ellen Newton Riker to David D. Ackerman 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Newton Riker, Mr. Ackerman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ackerman Jr. of Myrtle Beach, S.C.
New York City's new tax on commuters yielded barely more than half of what the state had predicted for its first full year --only $12-million or $13-million instead of $23-million.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, Aug. 5 (AP)--Chinese Communist personnel opened fire from their fortified embassy on students attempting to sack the building today. One soldier and three youths were seriously wounded.

The Federal Public Health Service report ranking this city first in the nation in air pollution makes it plain that cleaning up New York's befouled atmosphere is not just a matter of civic pride; it is a question of survival.
The stock market got off the high-speed express yesterday and settled for a fast-moving local.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Morton G. Farber of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felice Karen Farber, to Richard Young Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Carpenter of Brooklyn Heights.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 14--Saudi officials were markedly cool today to the Egyptian proposal to revive the 1965 agreement for withdrawing Egyptian troops from Yemen

CHICAGO, Aug. 4--Mayor Richard J. Daley suspended today for 45 days the real estate broker's license of Victor Strmic on the ground he had discriminated against a prospective home buyer because she was a Negro.

COLUMBIA, Md., Aug. 4-- The Rouse Company, Baltimore developers of this new city halfway between Baltimore and Washington, had a success on their hands last night, but no one knew it for the first hour of the raincheck party--which got more thunder, lightning and torrents than hit the original rained-out party of July 14.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 3--Negro violence in the United States is prefigured by a little-known slave uprising that occurred in Virginia in 1831, William Styron, the author of a forthcoming historical novel about that rebellion, said today.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 4--A big corporate merger in the Netherlands in recent weeks, put together without the slightest rumbles of discontent from antitrust quarters, underscores the radically different approaches the United States and Western Europe are taking toward concentration of industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4-- Paul R. Ignatius, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, will be nominated by President Johnson to be Secretary of the Navy.
The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that it would put increases into effect on the various types of steel used by producers of cans for foods and beverages on Sept. 8.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 4 (UPI) --Police officers arrested four white youths tonight as suspects in an early morning shotgun blast fired at a crowd of Negroes that touched off a massed march on police headquarters.
Mayor Lindsay denied yesterday that President Johnson had rebuked him for helping to form an Urban Coalition of national business, labor, civil rights and religious leaders,
TEL AVIV, Aug. 4--Israel has decided to inaugurate state-owned television for the first time in her 19-year history in an effort to reach the Arab populations of the newly occupied areas.
ALBANY, Aug. 4--Governor Rockefeller indicated today that he might seek higher state taxes next year.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 4--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara was reported to have asked his colleagues in Saigon last month, "Who are all these long-haired kids on motorbikes?"
Eleven large chain store organizations announced yesterday that their sales rose sharply in July, five of them to record highs. Montgomery Ward Co. reported a decline in volume from the 1966 level.

West Germany's commendable effort to "normalize" relations with the Communist-ruled countries of Eastern Europe is again under way. On the day Foreign Minister Willy Brandt arrived in Rumania for an official visit, his personal adviser concluded a treaty with Czechoslovakia for an exchange of trade missions with limited consular functions.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that if the state took over the operation and financing of welfare programs from local governments it would have to raise taxes by $528million.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4--An unusual one-man inquiry into the operations of the nation's largest farm organization began here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, said tonight that placing political blame for the riots served no purpose but that it was imperative that the nation look to the future and act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)--President Johnson, who said he was used to being outnumbered by women, entertained 100 young women at the White House today and was made an honorary member of Girls' Nation.
Theodore C. Jackson, a banking executive with responsibility for nearly $500-million of depositors' money, was offering his views recently on Negro riots in his gleaming Fifth Avenue office.

Miss Dale Stott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Stott of St. Mary, Jersey, Channel Islands, Great Britain, and Thomas Jefferson Cunningharn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Cunningham of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., plan to be married today in the Parish Church of St. Brelade's (Anglican) in Jersey.

At 7 o'clock yesterday a small group of mostly elderly men arrived for morning prayers at their synagogue in Brooklyn and found that the 65-year-old building had been broken into and vandalized during the night.
ESSEN, Germany, Aug. 4 (AP)--Alfried Krupp von Bohilen and Halbach has willed his fortune, including the assets of the Krupp industrial empire, to a foundation to perpetuate the l56-year-old concern.

The tree on the roof of the Astor Hotel has a new owner --temporarily. Earlier this week, the Hercules Wrecking Corporation, which is razing the Times Square landmark to make way for an office building, said it would give the tree to anyone who wanted it.

Frances Coleman, president of the American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., from World War II until 1961, died Wednesday in Bar Harbor, Me., where she was a summer resident. She was 86 years old and lived at 104 East 68th Street.

HOUSTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)-- The nation's 11 newest astronauts were named today. They included the first two foreignborn American spacemen and the oldest and youngest astronauts ever to join the space program.
Average estimated damages of $12,000 as a result of rioting in Newark last month were reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in a survey of more than 300 affected businesses.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 4-- Thirty--four Negro children gathered in an Episcopal chapel today to play, sing and study, apparently unmindful that their attendance at the "liberation school" had become a controversial aspect of the nation's antipoverty program.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)--A group of draftees charged out of a Selective Service induction center today and attacked about 50 antiwar pickets who were chanting and carrying signs.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4-- President Juan Carlos Ongania is expected to sign within the next few days a law that is being called both a "defense against Communism" and a "witch-hunting license." By any name, it promises to be extremely controversial.
Two more men were arrested yesterday in the theft of $35,000 worth of Polish hams.

GENEVA, Aug. 4--President Johnson has been asked to use part of his $5-million special fund for the Middle East to help pay for the care and maintenance of several thousand Jews Who have fled from Arab countries since the Middle Eastern war.
CAIRO, Aug. 4--Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, editor of the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram, wrote today that it was essential that his country have diplomatic relations with the United States.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 2-- If there is any defect in the fourth annual Stanford Summer Festival of the Arts, it is the absence of major operatic and symphonic events. In other years the festival brought to the West Coast the New York City Opera, an opera company...

Some liberals long identified with the civil rights struggle believe that the widespread Negro riots may drive white Americans into choosing between massive repression or the mobilization of national resources and skills to bring the Negro people into the mainstream of American life.

A complaint in State Supreme Court against Greenwich Village coffeehouses should be dismissed, an attorney for the city argued here yesterday, because the complainants--although they were residents of the area--had no more right to sue than any other taxpayer.

More than 200 East Harlem residents marched and sang last night in a "peace-keeping" procession designed to encourage residents of the predominantly Puerto Rican neighborhood to join credit unions and avoid loan sharks.
Moscow, Aug. 4--"It's almost as had as the worst days of the cold war," a Western diplomat remarked today after a discussion of Soviet press treatment of the United States In recent weeks.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 4 (AP)--A West German court issued a temporary injunction today to prevent the weekly magazine Stern from publishing the memoirs of Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP)--Hitting drives of 250 yards, 17-year-old Candace Michaeloff of Minneapolis won the 41st annual women's Western junior golf tournament today by defeating the medalist, Marsha Houghton of Modesto, Calif., 3 and 2.

If the Constitutional Convention is to fulfill its responsibility to the people of this state it will vote next week to override its leaders and kill the time- dishonored practice of gerrymandering the boundaries for Congressional and legislative districts.

CAIRO--Weeks after the brief Arab-Israeli war, tattered posters with martial slogans and a smiling President Gamal Abdel Nasser still looked down on the people of Cairo, but the slogans no longer stirred the populace as they did during the fighting.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 4 (Reuters)--The 7,506ton British freighter Manchester Exporter limped into port here today 48 hours after fire had broken out aboard.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (UPI) --Johnny Briggs collected four hits and Cookie Rojas and Richie Allen added three apiece to back the seven-hit pitching of Dick Ellsworth tonight and lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--A 9-foot anchor, corroded and mud-encrusted but still operable, and dinnerware in a good state of preservation, have been recovered from the Civil War ironclad Tecumseh, which sank during the Battle of Mobile Bay 103 years ago tomorrow.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 4 --The Hartsdale School Board today told the State Superintendent of Education that it would not take part in an integration referendum he had ordered for tomorrow and that its schools would be locked to bar their use for the vote.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Aug. 4 (Reuters)--The Europa 1 rocket of the six-nation European Launching Development Organization crashed today in the central Australian desert after the French-built second stage failed to ignite, it was announced tonight.
THE new table settings at Tiffany's make it clear that the business of putting plates and forks on a table top can be raised to something of an art--with art.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 4 (UPI) --Texas filed a multimilliondollar antitrust suit today against five drug companies accused of fixing prices of antibiotics, Attorney General Crawford Martin announced.
WEST HAVEN, Conn., Aug 4 --Stanley McCandless, professor emeritus of lighting at the Yale School of Drama, died at Veterans Hospital here today. He was 70 years old.
The North German liner Bremen is expected to dock on schedule at 8 A.M. today in spite of taking time out early yesterday to see that a suddenly ill passenger got special medical attention.
The American Stock Exchange closed out a busy week, the second-most active in the market's history, by advancing on a broad front yesterday.
Numerous publishing houses and magazines and a major record company are preparing special works about the Soviet Union to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution on Nov. 7.
British Government bonds registered moderate gains on the London stock exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4-- President Johnson's tax proposal to Congress would increase personal and corporate taxes by about $10-billion in its first 12 months of operation, it was authoritatively learned today.
AN exhibition illustrating the "Genius of Louis C. Tiffany" is showing at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, L.I.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 4 --Gov. George Romney said tonight that the United States must show "much greater ingenuity and drive" in getting private capital and industry to aid in the economic development of poor nations.

The Amerada Petroleum Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of this year a net income of $25,295,346, equal to $1.98 a share. This compares with $28,906,849, or $2.26 a share, for the corresponding period a year earlier, before inclusion of extraordinary credits of $14.5-million, or $1.14 a share.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 --The New York Jets overran the Boston Patriots, 55-12, tonight in the first preseason game for both American Football League teams. Joe Namath, the Jets' man-about-town quarterback, apparently had much more excitement the night before.

United States customs collections rose to a record of $2,684,0l0,465 during the fiscal year 1967. New York's commercial printing industry, second only to clothing in dollar volume, is doing better than ever--despite talk of important printing contracts fleeing New York.

"Don't mail the matches" is the standard warning on matchbook coupons offering $1,000 life insurance policies for 25 cents. If anyone is foolish enough to mail matches, chances are he may also think that a quarter will buy a sound insurance policy.

MONTREAL, Aug. 6--Hollywood moviemakers seem to have a knack of putting the worst foot forward at international film festivals. Time after time, they have come up with some of their most embarrassing bobbles at Venice and Cannes. Now they've done it again in the full glare of the eighth International Film Festival of Montreal.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 6-- The untiring voice of Senator Wayne Morse is resounding at weekend picnics, at businessmen's luncheons and in private conferences from Portland to the California line.

Dr. Stanley Eiss, a specialist in abdominal surgery who was formerly for 35 years an attending physician and professor in surgery at Polyclinic Hospital, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Polyclinic. BONN, Aug. 6 (Reuters)-- The West German news agency reported today that security police had hroken up a Soviet spy ring in the Ruhr.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6--Steel shipments will rise by nearly one million tons in August, a mill executive said last week. He predicted shipments of 7.1 million tons for the month, compared with about 6.2 mil- lion tons in July. He emphasized that the sharp increase would do no more than restore business to the first-half levels after a July dip that was somewhat steeper than expected.

HAVANA, Aug. 6--The Cuban Government produced at a news conference today six men whom it described as counterrevolutionaries sent to Cuba by the Central Intelligence Agency to carry out sabotage and eventually to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro.

When President Johnson last Thursday at last requested an income tax surcharge, it was larger than Wall Street expected, but the bond market responded with a rally that dealers found disappointingly small.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) --The International Associa- tion of Fire Fighters posted a $1,000 reward today for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons causing death or injury to a fireman during a riot.

A comparative study of five different designs of power plants for future merchant marine ships has been completed by the Research Institute of the Illinois Institute of Technology for the Maritime Administration.

THE company that calls itself "Peerce," even though many of its wealthiest customers pronounce it "Purse," no longer belongs to a "Peerce" or even a "Purse." The S. S. Pierce Company was sold last month (for more than $10-million) by the Pierce family to Laird Industries, a corporate management subsidiary of Laird Co., investment bankers.

New York State's Health Commissioner said yesterday that Medicaid schedules might be revised to pay New York City doctors more than their upstate colleagues for treating needy patients.

The first sparring round in Britain's renewed fight to enter the Common Market has ended surprisingly with Harold Wilson, not Charles de Gaulle, ahead on points. Despite possible misgivings over how the United Nations handled the Middle East situation, 79 per cent of Americans today say it is "very important" for the United States to make the international organization a success, according to a survey by George Gallup in yesterday's, The Washington Post.
