WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) --Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, suggested today that the United States commit far greater resources toward easing racial unrest at home and let South Vietnam carry the burden of its war against the Vietcong.
HONOLULU, Aug. 6--The legal profession is planning to de-emphasize reliance on paid lawyers to assist the poor and will rely increasingly on the volunteer services of lawyers and law students.
ST. LOUiS, Aug. 6 (AP)-- Orlando Cepeda's three-run homer in the Fifth inning today carried the first-place St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 6--The Berkshire Music Festival behaved like a festival last night and came up with something special--the origfinal version of Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelto." As far as is known, It had not previously been performed in this country.
AUSTIN, Tex. Aug. 6 (AP)-- Dr. Fillmore H. Sanford, psychology professor at the University of Texas, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 53 years old.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 6--Miss Darlene Starr Carbone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Carbone, was married this afternoon to Julien David Yoseloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Yoseloff of Jamesburg, N.J. The Rev. George Hommel performed the ceremony in the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 6-- Miss Maryann Martha Allen, daughter of Mrs. John M. Allen and the late Mr. Allen, was married this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel to Ronald Frank Reilly, son of Mr, and Mrs. Frank E. Reilly of Glen Ridge. The Rev. Campion J. Doyle performed the ceremony.

GREAT DIAMOND ISLAND, Me., Aug. 5--The fog lifted long enough for the fishing party to go after the dogfish sharks. It was not the sharks themselves, so much as the embryos the females were bearing, that everyone was interesting in. For this was a scientific expedition, and a very special one at that.
MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 6 (Reuters)--Seven Russians and two Frenchmen were killed when a huge Soviet helicopter crashed near here today while fighting a forest fire.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4-- John Baldwin, a 22-year-old graduate student from Port Washington, L.I., won his third amateur golf title in three weeks today. Turning back 16year-old Bill Harmon in the final at the Plainfield Country Club, Baldwin added the Metropolitan amateur champion. ship to the Long Island and New York State titles that he had recently won.

A statewide walkout today of some 27,000 telephone installers and repairmen appeared probable last night when negotiators for the Communications Workers of America and the New York Telephone Company reported a deadlock and agreed that no purpose would be served by further meetings before the scheduled start of the walkout at 7 A.M.

GREAT DIAMOND ISLAND, Me., Aug. 5--The fog lifted long enough for the fishing party to go after the dogfish sharks. It was not the sharks themselves, so much as the embryos the females were bearing, that everyone was interesting in. For this was a scientific expedition, and a very special one at that.
MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 6 (Reuters)--Seven Russians and two Frenchmen were killed when a huge Soviet helicopter crashed near here today while fighting a forest fire.
For the first time since the private-eye business was founded by a Pinkerton in 1850, a non-Pinkerton has been named to the office of president of Pinkerton's, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) The President's commission on civil disorders will submit interim recommendations in its investigation of riots; Roy Wilkins said tonight.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that his court lacked the power to order a freighter on international waters back to port.
ADEN, Aug. 7 The Soviet Union was reported today to have asked to establish a military base in republicancontrolled territory in Yemen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The House voted today by voice vote to establish a 16member commission to study legislation for administrative action to deal with traffic in obscenity and pornography.

BONN, Aug. 7 Foreign Minister Willy Brandt got a lift home today in a Rumanian Government plane after his own chartered jet had broken down. To hear him tell it in Bonn, this was only part of the help West Germany is getting these days from the Communist regime in Bucharest.
Mrs, Lyndon B. Johnson was back in New York yesterday to add to her fall wardrobe.
JEFFERSON, Ga., Aug. 7 (AP) A bomb blast killed a state prosecutor today and the authorities sought clues linking the assassination to auto theft operations in northeast Georgia.
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., whose widely diversified interests range from movie making to auto parts, is now planning to go into the machine-tool equipment business.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 (AP) The Louisiana Supreme Court denied an application today by Walter Sheridan, a reporter for the National Broadcasting Company, seeking to avoid testifying before a grand jury inquiry on the assassination of President Kennedy.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 7 Charles J. Wilson, police chief here during the mayoral administration of Frank Hague and Frank Hague Eggers, died last night at his home, 188 Fairview Avenue. His age was 73.
Ross D. Sackett was elected yesterday as president of Holt, Rinehart Winston, Inc., a publisher recently acquired by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
A new medium for Investment in mortgages a mortgage collateralized note has been developed.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 7 The engagement of Miss Virginia M. Larkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Larkin, to Pvt. Daniel J. To bin, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Tobin of Larchmont, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 Even when they are busy fighting new wars, old soldiers seldom stop talking about old ones.

Further advances in prices of products using rubber were posted yesterday. The Firestone Rubber and Latex Products Company raised all of its product lines 5 to 10 per cent. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company added an average 5.1 per cent to its tire prices.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Aug. 7 (AP) The Southeastern Conference placed Mississippi State's basketball team on probation for the next two seasons today after having found the university guilty of violating recruiting rules.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7--Reversing the outcome of their match in the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis tournament at the Merion Club, Martin Riessen of Evanston, III., defeated Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, for the Eastern grass-court championships today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 7 (UPI) Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, a Democratic Congressman from the Lower Hudson Valley, announced today that he would not seek his party's nomination to run against United States Senator Jacob K. Javits.
GREENBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 7 Two gunmen, wearing masks of plastic bags painted with rosy red cheeks, escaped today with $50,000 to $70,000 from a branch of the Scarsdale National Bank and Trust Company.

LINCROFT, N.J., Aug. 7 The engagement of Miss Jane Frances Perrine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Perrine, to David Tullis Houston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Houston of Short Hills, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 7 "They're off," Jack E. Lee, the track announcer, proclaimed to 11,077 opening-day fans at Freehold Raceway today on a hazy, lazy summer afternoon.

With about 200 thoroughbred notables and Just plain enthusiasts crowding into the Cinema Room of the National Museum of Racing, the induction of seven new members into the Racing Hall of Fame took place this morning. George D. Widener, the president of the museum, conducted the ceremonies, with the assistance of Robert F. Kelley and Mrs. Elaine Mann, curatrix of the handsome quarters.

About eight hundred children swarmed into one block near Coney Island yesterday afternoon to celebrate the opening of the only play street in the area and to thank the 68-yearold retired social worker who created it.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 (UPI) Gene Brabender, backed by Sam Bowens's two-run homer, limited the Cleveland Indians to four hits and pitched his first complete game in the major leagues tonight as the Baltimore Orioles scored a 4-0 victory.
Lunar Orbiter 5 began yesterday transmitting a sequence of pictures of the moon that are of special interest to astronauts and scientists.

Sidney Kaye, proprietor of the Russian Tea Room, long a popular gathering place for musicians, actors and other celebrities, died in Memorial Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

MARLBORO, Vt., Aug. 7 Rudolf Serkin, the director of the Marlboro Music Festival and who for years has dipped into his own picket to help make up the festival's deficit, is well on the way toward creating a $1-million endowment fund.
THE girl with eyelashes only a fraction shorter than her skirt peered at some see-through molded chairs on tubular steel supports.
The Essex Wire Corporation announced yesterday it was discontinuing merger negotiations with the Chicago North Western Railway Company.
The author of the best seller "How to Avoid Probate" sought yesterday in Federal District Court to stop an injunction that could bar sale of the book in New York State.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 The Democratic majority at the State Constitutional Convention suddenly shifted its support today and backed a plan for a bipartisan commission to draw legislative and Congressional districts.
A community representative will be assigned to every class in the first three grades of two Harlem schools in September in an experimental program sponsored by the N.A.A.C.P.
BANGKOK, Thailand "We can't produce enough to keep up with demand," said Kenneth A. Page. "The factory is working 24 hours a day, six days a week. A terribly happy state of affairs."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Organized labor began a drive today to make life more difficult for companies that violate the law in an effort to thwart unionization.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 7 Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Glassman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rollyn Peggy Glassman, to James Lincoln Dritz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Dritz of New York. A September wedding is planned.

Revolving credit, which first appeared on the retail scene in the thirties but zoomed ahead in popularity after World War II, is an "openended" installment or charge account over which only the customer holds control so long as some sort of regular payment is made.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Department of Commerce revised downward today its estimate of homebuilding activity during June.

CRANFORD, N.J., Aug. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Ferguson Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Ferguson, to Oliver Cooper Winston Jr., son of Mr. Winston of Ithaca, N.Y., and Mrs. Morton E. Rome of Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Brig. Gen. Bernard W. Rogers was named by President Johnson today to be commandant of cadets at the United States Military Academy.
prices started off on the upside yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, but they backed down to a mixed pattern before the close.

The Travelers Insurance Companies, one of the nation's leading multiline insurers, reported yesterday a sharp drop in net income from operations for the first half. The Hartfordbased group also showed a substantial increase during the same period in its statuatory underwriting losses in casualty and property lines.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 7 Some lower tiers of the Wailing Wall are to be excavated next week.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (UPI) A Soviet newspaper today dismissed as "ultranationalist hysteria" an Arab call for the destruction of Israel and denied that any responsible Arab leader favored such a goal.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 7 (AP) Mrs. Henry Obre's Road At Sea, ridden by Ray Broussard, stunned an opening-day crowd of 18,692 when he streaked to a length and a half victory in the $17,450 Longport Stakes at the Atlantic City race course today.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 7 (UPI) Congolese army commanders said today that Government troops had surrounded a column of white mercenaries in hills overlooking the border with Rwanda. Heavy fighting was reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The United States Commission on Civil Rights, critical of the pace of Southern school desegregation, called today for faster, stricter observance of guidelines, more help from Congress to enforce the guidelines and one or two changes in the law to speed the process.

Max Tak, a correspondent here for the Dutch weekly newspaper Elseviers Weekblad and broadcaster of a weekly radio program, "New York Calling," beamed to the Netherlands, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, Freeport, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived at 145 Eact 74th Street.

In the lounge of the ANTA Theater on West 52d Street, at the opposite end from the empty bar and between large portraits of Ethel and John Barrymore, a chorus of youngsters sprawled on the floor and tripped over lyrics.
A 25-year-old man who had been arrested 14 times in the last seven years was arraigned on a homicide charge yesterday in the alleged kidnapping of another man from a busy midtown street.
QUOGUE, L.I., Aug. 7 Lud low Van Deventer, retired broker and former tennis star, died today in his residence here. He was 74 years old.

In the fashion world, 1967 is sure to go down as the year of the miniskirt. In the economy, it has been the year of the "mini-recession" perhaps the mildest and shortest economic adjustment in United States history.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP)--Ron Hunt delivered a two-out single in the ninth inning that drove in the tie-breaking run, then circled the bases on errors by Curt Flood and Phil Gagliano as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 6-4.

The trial of Robert H. (35X) Smith, a 35-year-old Black Muslim charged with attempted murder, was postponed in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday until Sept. 11 after his attorneys had complained that the police had created an "atmosphere of hysteria."

Gerhard Samuel led the New York Chamber Orchestra in the fifth concert of the month-long Philharmonic Hall Mozart festival last night and, in general, the fare offered was trim and neat but not very soulful.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 7--The young reporter wanted to tell readers of Frankfurter Rundschau what it was like to "take a trip" with LSD, but instead he was taken for a hilarious ride by Pardon, West Germany's leading satirical magazine.
The election of Wesley Lindow as executive vice president was announced yesterday by the Charter New York Corporation, which controls the Irving Trust Company.
The stock market's bulls pulled in their horns a bit yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) Jim Bunning pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to their seventh straight victory tonight, beating San Francisco, 8-0, with a four-hitter. The defeat ended the Giants' six-game winning streak.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 7--Saudi Arabia asked today for evacuation of Egyptian forces from Yemen as a condition for settling the civil war.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 7 Despite Mickey Mantle's 20th homer, the New York Yankees returned to normal, which for them is last place, as the California Angels rallied for seven runs with none out in the eighth inning tonight to gain an 8-4 victory.
City Council and Board of Estimate hearings on the city's antipoverty and welfare programs are being planned for next month by Democratic leaders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Two of the Senate's most influential critics of President Johnson's Vietnam policy, a Democrat and a Republican, called today for a new United States effort to take the Vietnam question before the United Nations.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 7 Nigeria's largest oil producer, the Shell-B.P. Petroleum Development Corporation, plans to make no royalty payments until next year or "until the situation becomes normal," Stanley Gray, its managing director, said today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 A committee of three senior civil servants held today that Prime Minister Wilson was "not unfair" in his widely criticized remarks about the former secretary of the joint Government-press committee on security matters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The famous "Jim Dandy report" had its beginning in August 1967 when Clark Clifford and Gen. Maxwell Taylor completed a two-week tour of Southeast Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 7 The South-West African People's Organization, described as a nationalist group, issued a protest here today against the trial of 37 of its members in a South African court.

Negroes who hold elective offices ranging from United States Senator to board of education member have been invited to a national conference next month at the University of Chicago to form a bipartisan Council of Negro Elected Officials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 William Lewis Taylor joined the civil rights movement when it was a particularly risky line of work for a white lawyer.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 A 27-acre island long popular with boating and picnicking enthusiasts has been sold to a Bridgeport company that plans to erect a nuclear power plant there, it was disclosed today.

MISS Edith Weiss de Csepel, the former Baroness Weiss, a daughter of the late Baron Manfred Weiss, founder of one of Hungary's leading arms and metal-products concerns, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 1000 Park Avenue.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 7 Southern California moved into the semi-final round of the United States Lawn Tennis Association girls' intersectional team championship today by defeating the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association squad, 6 matches to 1, on the grass courts of the Westchester Country Club. Each had drawn a first-round bye in the elimination tournament, which has entries from 11 of the 16 U.S.L.T.A. sections.

KINSASHA, Aug 7 The first elements of the European mercenaries seeking to break out of Congolese territory about 20 trucks and four armored cars were reported to have been sighted in Bukavu just before nightfall yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 97 on Friday from 96.9 on Thursday.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 7 Kathy Tanis, a 14-year-old student at Frankford Township High School, won the stock seat championship, took one other event and was runnerup in the medal class today at the opening session of the Sussex County Horse Show.
Benjamin Tabachinsky, a leading American critic of Soviet policies toward Jews, died Sunday night at the South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, L.I. He was 71 years old.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 7 The New York Giants, eager to strengthen their defensive unit, traded today for one new player from the Cleveland Browns and signed another from their farm club affiliate, the Westchester Bulls.
The recent riots appear to have had an effect in some commodity markets.

Dr. and Mrs. Conrad Rosenberg of New York and New Preston, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Jean Rosenberg, to Albert L. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weiss of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.
Mrs. Max Stern, wife of a psychiatrist, died Thursday in Copenhagen, three days after she was struck by a car. She was 58 years old and lived here at 960 Park Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 The Rumford Fair Housing Act still stood, although precariously, as the California Legislature adjourned early today.
James E. Fletcher and Alexander Hehmeyer were elected yesterday to new posts as executive vice presidents of Field Enterprises, Inc.
S. Mort Zimmerman, a Dallas financier, controls 40 per cent of the stock of the $60million New York bank.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7 Mrs. Ruth Cain Conner, director of the nursery school of Greenwich House on Barrow Street in New York in the early nineteen-forties, died Saturday in Rahway Hospital. Her age was 59. She was the wife of Clifford E. Conner, an engineer with the American Can Company.

Distribution of the first edition of The New York Times was delayed and curtailed last night when the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union required detailed inspection of all trucks before delivering the papers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who is still hoping somebody will return her $780,000 jewel collection that mysteriously disappeared last week from her Cady Hill House bedroom, tonight gave this 104-year-old shockproof resort something new to talk about. It was what she called a tea dance after the races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Although three-month bill rates remained essentially stable, there was a sizable rise in the six-month bill rate from last week's level at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Three senior Liberal Democrats on the House Banking Committee introduced legislation today aimed at building 500,000 housing units a year for families of low and moderate income.

An 18-year-old from Brooklyn named Forest Lee Ward watched the heavyweight championship elimination tournament bouts in Houston on television with a great deal more interest than the average boxing fan: in a few years he will probably be fighting some of the men he was watching.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 Vietcong guerrillas shot down five American helicopters today in an ambush on the outskirts of Saigon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Senate approved today a $768million project to transport Colorado River water across Arizona. The project would not include, however, two controversial dams.
GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 7 Tatsuo Shirane of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club won two of the six races today to take the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing championship.
Parker Brothers (they make games) sold 1.5 million Ouija boards in one year without advertising them. Now they've decided to advertise, so you can just guess what they expect will happen.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 7 Miss Janet Lynne Cucinell and Zachary Fenton Lansdowne were married here this evening in the Asbury Church, Methodist, by the Rev. George F. Weyand.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 7 (AP) Democratic candidates for Governor made last-minute appeals today after a spirited campaign based largely on emotions and personal attacks. Some 650,000 persons are expected to vote in the primary tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 7 The United Nations turned down today a request that a fact-finding mission be sent to Anguilla, a Caribbean island of 6,000 people that has declared itself independent of British Commonwealth rule.

For two years, Mrs. Gertrude Woglom, a 56-year-old Staten Island widow, had complained to city officials that damaged storm pipes near her home went unrepaired and that a street regrading had left her house in the bottom of a sink.
Tommie Smith and Paul Wilson, two record-holders, were scratched yesterday from the United States track and field team that will open a threemeet European tour in London Saturday.
The television networks plan to begin the new season with a number of special programs right after Labor Day.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 A quartet of seeded players easily advanced to the second round of the 78th invitation Meadow Club grass-court tennis tournament today, but eighth-seeded Peter Curtis of Britain was beaten.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 6--Motion pictures can now speak five languages at the same time.
More than 10,000 New York Telephone Company workers on long Island and upstate walked off their jobs yesterday in support of a strike by 15,000 company employes in the city.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 The inland waterways industry opposed today a proposal to relocate the demarcation line in the Gulf of Mexico separating the areas where international and inland navigation rules apply.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 Tne American Motors Corporation reported today another large loss in its third fiscal quarter ended June 30. The smallest of the four major American auto companies said it suffered a net loss of $17,925,988, or 94 cents a share, in the three months against a small profit, $22,441, a year before.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 7 (UPI)--Two Canadian horses, Governor Armbro and Fresh Yankee, were added today to the field for the ninth edition of the Roosevelt International, which will be contested at Roosevelt Raceway on Aug. 19.

Four years ago Robert Rosenthal, now a 34-year-old professor of social paychology at Harvard, reported after tests that rats performed far better when the experimenters were told, falsely, that the rats had been specially bred for intelligence.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7 Unless Westchester County acts quickly to achieve Negro equality, racial disturbances will become more numerous and more destructive and will not end with the summer, the Board of Supervisors was told today by its only Negro member.
Sears, Roebuck Co. has voluntarily suspended the sale of firearms and ammunition by its stores in the metropolitan area because of the tense racial atmosphere.

Theodore W. Kheel, the arbitrator between the National Maritime Union and most of the nation's subsidized lines, announced yesterday that the ships of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines "will be sailing without any interruptions."

Six Cubans and a Puerto Rican printer were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury as part of a $1million counterfeiting ring ostensibly "raising" money for arms to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro.
Charles L. Kluss, vice president of United States PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday night in his home at 25 Sutton Place South. His age was 55.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7 William N. Uezzell, who for 38 years was an engineer with the Consolidated Edison Company, died in the White Plains Hospital today. He was 60 years old and lived here at 15 North Broadway.

WAKEFIELD, R.I., Aug. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Bliss Read Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Bliss Read, to Robert Lewis Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. David V. Rosenthal of Boston. The couple plan to marry in September.

HARTFORD, Aug. 7 Four men, including the former president of the New Haven branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, were charged with two counts of arson today in the fire bombings of a restaurant and food market here Saturday.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 7 (UPI) A circuit court judge cited the Peninsula Shipbuilders Association for contempt of court today, fined it $15,000 and sentenced three of its top officers to short jail terms.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 (Agence France-Presse) Talks scheduled to begin Thursday between President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic were termed "highly important" today by the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent judgment today that would end a sixyear-old Federal antitrust suit against a Lexington, Ky., bank.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Informed sources said today that Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo, three times premier of Indonesia, had been arrested on charges of complicity in a plot to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 A predominantly Negro group from New York demonstrated in the House of Representatives gallery today against the defeat of a rat control bill on July 20.

When H. Rap Brown took over from Stokely Carmichael as chairman of the Student Nonviolent Co ordinating Committee last May, Carmichael told reporters: "People will be happy to have me back when you hear from him he's a bad man."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Attorney General Ramsey Clark sent letters to the 50 Governors today outlining the steps they must take to get Federal troops if they were unable to control riots.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) The British National Exports Council announced today that it had set up an organization to push sales of aircraft to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Urban Coalition, a newly formed group seeking answers to city problems, set a date, drew up an agenda and elected co-chairmen today for its firts national convention.
