Bearish economic reports over the weekend depressed the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
WARSAW, Aug. 6 Emotional espects of the Arab-Israeli conflict have attenuated relations between Poland's Communist leaders and the people.
An extra 658,000 troy ounces of silver unsold at the first auction of the metal last week by the General Services Administration will be added to the regular offering of 2 million ounces this Friday.
George D. Webster, board chairman of the First Western Financial Corporation, said yesterday he had "every expectation" that the company would hold its annual meeting on Aug. 18, as scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The president and general manager of The Santa Fe New Mexican said today that a bill to grant antitrust immunity for the merger or joint operation of financially shaky newspapers would stifle competition.

PARIS, Aug. 7 The results of a poll published today suggested that many Frenchmen differ with President de Gaulle on some major questions but that a majority wants no alignment with either the United States or the Soviet Union.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 7 Russell McInnes, a partner in the New York law firm of Wood, King, Dawson Logan died of a heart attack last night in his home at Scarsdale Manor Apartments North.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, under treatment for his third gastrointestinal upset in a year, remained on a liquid diet today at the Walter Reed General Hospital.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 7 (AP) A special Federal panel has been sent to the major copper-producing states in the West in an attempt to settle a strike in the industry, Gov. Calvin L. Rampton of Utah announced today.
The Department of Sanitation's new design consultant is painting the department's yellow trucks white in a move to eliminate New York's "visual noise."
HONOLULU, Aug. 7 Vice President Humphrey warned today of "catastrophe" if the United States withdrew from its' overseas commitments to concentrate on easing racial unrest at home.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 7 There were approximately five million fluke in residence in Great South Bay about 10 years ago, according to Dick Schaefer, a New York State Conservation Department fishery research biologist. And, they seemed to be thriving. The population level was constant from year-toyear.
Samuel Taylor, author of "Sabrina Fair" and "The Pleasure of His Company," has written a new comedy, "Avanti," which will be produced by the office of Richard Rodgers.

LONDON, Aug. 7--Lord Robens submitted his resignation today as chairman of the National Coal Board, which a Government-appointed tribunal last week said bore the major responsibility for the disaster last year in the Welsh coal mining town of Aberfan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that only gifts to charitable groups could be deducted for income tax purposes even if a ticket to a charity ball or other fundraising affair is labeled taxdeductible.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 7 Agence France-Presse) China has signed an agreement to give North Vietnam an undisclosed amount of free aid, the official Communist party newspaper Nhan Dan reported today.

SAIGON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Premier Ky said here today that the civilian presidential and vice-presidential candidates had "made a mistake" in not riding in the three open military trucks in which United States Marines at Dongha airfield offered to transport them to Quangtri.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 Nine of the 10 civilian candidates in South Vietnam's presidential race took a waitand-see attitude tonight toward further campaigning under Government auspices in the hinterland.

HAMBURG, Germany Aug. 7 (UPI) Judy Tegart and Lesley Turner of Australia won the women's doubles final of the West German tennis championships today with an 8-6, 6-1 victory over Francoise Durr of France and Gail Sheriff of Australia.

LEH, Kashmir, Aug. 1 The Indian Army in Ladakh is strenuously preparing to meet an enemy whose intentions are a mystery to which it has few clues. Like the British soldiers who trained them a generation ago, the Indian officers are quick to say they find the Chinese inscrutable.
WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 7 (AP) The curfew imposed on Wichita the last two nights to help keep down vandlism and acts of violence was lifted tonight.

The Maritime Subsidary Board and the Maritime Administration have granted the Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., permission to pursue its diversification plans by reorganizing the steamship company's corporate structure.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7--The Arab population of East Jerusalem staged a general strike today against Israeli control of the former Jordanian sector, halting all business activity, including shops and restaurants.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 7 (UPI) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the chief of state, today accused the Cambodian Communist party of waging a relentless compaign to undermine his authority and turn the nation into a satellite of Peking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Leonard F. Kowalewski, a Newark jailer and president of a policemen's fraternal order, brought new charges before the Senate Judiciary Committee today that antipoverty workers helped bring about the riots in his city last month.

The Agency for International Development is performing an overdue service in sending a team of six prominent American physicians to South Vietnam to determine what is needed to provide adequate medical treatment for civilian war casualties.
HAVANA, Aug. 7 (Reuters) The copilot of the Colombian airliner said today that he first had thought the five hijackers were friends on a holiday spree.
PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Aug. 7 Mobs armed with stones and knives rampaged through Port Louis for hours today before riot policemen using tear gas restored order.
Anthony C. Bliss, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association until last April, has married Sally Brayley, a soloist with the opera's ballet troupe for four and a half years.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 7 Miss Jean Fuller Mueller and George Leon Tillinghast 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tillinghast Jr. of Rumford, R.I., plan to marry in December.
While most people are fascinated by the soaring heights of the Empire State Building, officials of the world's tallest skyscraper have been preoccupied with its long-neglected, dingy depths.

A $10-million artists' center to provide low-income housing for 500 painters, sculptors, composers, choreographers and filmmakers will be created on the lower West Side. It will occupy a group of buildings that were formerly the headquarters of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
Parents and leaders from poverty areas here accused the Board of Education last night of willful neglect of schoolchildren and arrogant refusal to cooperate.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 7 Two additional Westchester families were found today to be living in a motel and a hotel, with their monthly rents of $1,200 and $600 paid for by the County Welfare Department.
An early sign of a predicted recovery in steel orders next month might have been provided yesterday by production figures released by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Yesterday's surprise switch on reapportionment by the Democratic majority at the Constitutional Contention is a real gain for representative government in his state, putting responsibility for drawing legislative district lines in the hands of a bipartisan commission will be vastly superior to the original plan for saving reapportionment to the Legislature assuring perpetual gerrymandering by the party in power.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will close trading today at 2 P.M., an hour and a half earlier than usual, in an effort to trim the huge backlog of paper work in brokerage offices.
Vessel construction subsidies totaling $100-million annually to bolster the United States fishing industry were urged yestetday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.
Jesse Werner, chairman and president of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, a manufacturer of aviation equipment.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 Like the man who said his big accomplishment in the French Revolution was surviving it, Gov. Ronald Reagan, convalescing at his suburban home...
Cats cannot eliminate rats in New York City, the Humane Society of the United States said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 7 Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, said today that there were "positive developments" in the Mid- dle East toward an eventual Israeli-Arab peace settlement.
ST.-PAUL-DE-VENCE, France, Aug. 7 Under a star-dusted Mediterranean Marc-Chagall sky, Marc Chagall acknowledged tonight a gala alfresco tribute to his 80th birthday.
DETROIT, Aug. 7 Two Detroit policemen were charged today with the murder of two young Negroes during Detroit's riots two weeks ago.

IF the Treasury Department has its way, the mutual savings banks may soon be in for a heavier tax burden. How they have avoided substantial taxes is a story of adroit investment policy harking back to 1962.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--The millions of Americans who have revolving charge accounts in department stores should be told what they pay in true annual interest rates, Administration officials told Congress today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7 The Joe Namath thing is a family matter. Like most families, the New York Jets have done what needed doing, and they're not going to discuss it with the neighbors. End of incident.
MANORVILLE, L.I., Aug. 7 (UPI) A 16-year-old boy, driving a borrowed 11-year-old car, died today and two others were injured in a head-on collision on Ryerson Avenue near South Street here.
MADISON AVENUE strollers, who might be considered immune to almost everything by now, are quirk- ing an eyebrow at the newest addition to the landscape.

Second-quarter earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., improved over the first quarter, but earnings for the half year were down sharply from a year ago, according to the report yesterday of Henry S. Wingate, its chairman.

HONG KONG, Aug. 7 After a year of unrelenting struggle and turmoil in Communist China, it is still difficult for Western observers to be sure what is really happening in that ancient and awesomely overpopulated nation. Much is obscure.
Robert M. Ganger, 64-yearold chairman of the D'Arcy Company, is stepping out of that job and that means promotions.
Time-Life Books will start a new serirs of condensed history books today called Time Capsule.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 Exclusive Native of the Harbor View Farm turned the pace-setting role into a decisive triumph in the $34,575 Sanford Stakes today. With Angel Cordero urging him into the lead at the start of the 5 -furlong sprint, Exclusive Native "ran away" from the others to score by four lengths over Ogden Phipps's Vitriolic, with the Calumet Farm's Forward Pass next.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 7 Crews representing Cedar Point Yacht Club of Westport, Conn., and Port Washington, L.I., Yacht Club led the way through the qualifying series of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship regatta off American Yacht Club today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7--The team of young experts headed by Andy Bernstein of New York and including Michael Becker and Steve Altman of New York and Monroe Ingberman and George Sorter of Chicago continued its giant-killing role in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 7 When a stretch-running bidder at Keeneland casually paid a quarter of a million dollars last month for a yearling colt by Raise A Native, bargain-hunting horsemen were shaken. Why would the man go that high, they wondered, considering the $200,000 Bold Ruler yearling he bought at the same store in 1966 hadn't yet got to the post?
Government and corporate bond prices declined yesterday, while tax-exempt state and municipal bonds held their ground.
Justin Sturm, sculptor, playwright and novelist, died Sunday in Westport, Conn. He was 68 years old.

The ten craft unions in West Coast shipyards have acted to substitute statesmanship for selfishness in the wake of the costly whipsaw strike that shut the yards for eight months and finally compelled President Johnson to get a back-to-work order under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) A $300,000 project to give work to some 900 Negro youngsters and clean up the slums where they live was started here today.
HAVANA, Aug. 7 (AP) A Colombian airliner that was forced to land here after, it had been hijacked by five partisans of Fidel Castro flew today to the Colombian island of San Andres.
Mayor Lindsay took a walk last evening through what he called "one of the roughest areas I've seen" a half-mile section of Williamsburg in Brooklyn.
BERLIN, Aug. 7 East Germany has placed orders for $25million worth of rolling stock and electric equipment in West Berlin, it was announced today.

YONKERS, Aug. 7--The engagement of Miss Alice Marie Cannon to Hugh Bingham has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Robert B. McKittrick of Yonkers and Warren B. Cannon of New York. Mr. Bingham is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Bingham of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marilyn J. Schwartz, daughter of Benjamin Schwartz of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Schwartz, to Archibald F. Robertson Jr. of 17 East 11th Street. He is the son of Mrs. Robertson of Bedford, Va., and the late Mr. Robertson. The wedding will take place in September.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7--Leopoldo Torre Nilsson, prize-winning Argentine film director, is involved in a struggle to convince the Mayor of Buenos Aires that Harold Pinter's play "The Homecoming" is not pornographic.

OUT of familiar and much-used material, a murderous piece of brutality at sea during the last war and the subsequent court-martial of those responsible for it, Gwyn Griffin has fashioned a novel that...

A new American music ensemble, barely six weeks old and led by an English conductor, made its New York concert debut late yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Lincoln Center library. It was the Berkshire Boy Choir, and it performed as if it had been in the business for years.
ALBANY, Aug. 7 A committee of the Constitutional Convention voted tonight to require the Legislature to provide a system of free higher education for all state residents.
How can a large garment concern enjoy the economies of large-scale production and still meet the needs of retailers who emphasize fashion?

The inability of many citizens of Wayne Township, in New Jersey, to recognize antiSemitism caused the landslide defeat of two jewish candidates for the school board last February, according to a study by two University of California sociologists.
Harry J. Goodelman, poet, painter and Yiddish writer, died yesterday at Calvary Hospital, the Bronx. He was 75 years old and lived at 24 East 11th Street.
J. Lakin Baldridge, a biggame fisherman, died of a stroke on Sunday at Claridge's Hotel in London. He was 74 years old and lived at 117 East 72d Street and at Burnt House, Warwick West, Bermuda.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 7 Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan protested to United Nations officials today that the United Arab Republic was violating the agreement made last week halting navigation in the Suez Canal for one month.
The Amazing Mets, who had not won a game this side of the Mississippi since July 23, won one last night by staging two of their gaudiest rallies of the year.
Two common stock offerings reached the market yesterday and were quickly snapped up by investors.

The engagement of Miss Ann Levine to Cpl. Theodore Stewart Parker, U.S.M.C., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Milton I. Levine of New York and Lincolndale, N.Y. Corporal Parker is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Parker of Larchmont, N.Y.

As West German Ambassador in Moscow from 1958 to 1962, Dr. Kroll apparently dedicated himself to the task of laying the foundations for an eventual rapprochement between the Federal Republic and the Soviet Union.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 8--White mercenaries occupied strategic points in the city of Bukavu today, but a unit of the Congolese Army was reported to be holding positions blocking access to the two bridges leading into the neighboring country of Rwanda.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 8-- Hollis V. Warner, a 72-year-old farmer who once ran one of the largest duck farms in the world here, was shot to death with a convicted prostitute today in a farm shed.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8--Many of the world's best track-andfield athletes will compete tomorrow and Thursday nights in the first dual meet between the Americas and Europe.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8--Anguilla's drive for independence received consideration today in a United Nations subcommittee on colonialism.

A new international medical relief organization will build a 40-bed children's hospital in South Vietnam, under a project to be sponsored by the United States Agency for International Development, South Vietnam and private sources. The hospital, which will provide plastic and rehabilitive surgery, will welcome any child patient in South Vietnam needing such surgery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Despite the recent riots in the cities and the Republicans' strong numerical position, Republican leaders in the House are talking about compromise on the endangered antipoverty bill for the first time since the program began in 1964.
A merger agreement was reached yesterday by the Allied Products Corporation and the General Bronze Corporation involving an exchange of stock valued at more than $25-million.
Wheat, corn and soybean prices drifted downward yesterday, reflecting bearish sentiment. Good weather and predictions of bumper crops have led to much selling recently.

Sudan's Premier says the thirteen Arab Foreign Ministers agreed at their meeting in Khartoum to "work together as one hand," but the omission of specifics from their communique indicates enduring deep divisions on important questions.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 8 (AP)--Voters of Jacksonville and Duval County discarded their old systems of government today and approved a new consolidated government, making Jacksonville the largest city in Florida, ahead of Miami and Tampa.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Baldwin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Elizabeth Baldwin, to Pvt. Henry G. McWhinney 3d., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. McWhinney of Morristown.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP)--The 47th annual Saratoga Sales broke all records for an opening session tonight when 64 yearlings sold for a total of $990,000, an average of $15,469.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 8-- A question that has rarely been asked and never fully answered hangs over Congressional consideration of the controversial reforms of mutual fund practices proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8--If you go across the country and talk at random to anybody you meet about the riots and the war, you get a very confused and even contradictory impression of the Presidential political outlook for 1968.

Mr. and Mrs. Fowler Hamilton of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Kath erine Hamilton, to Valerian Lubomir Puskar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Imrich Puskar of Bratislava, Czechoslovakia.
There is an increase in antiampersand attitudes among agency men.

A 41-year-old woman told the police yesterday that she had been offered $20,000 in a plot to assassinate Mayor Lindsay, but an assistant District Attorney said later there was "no evidence of any conspiracy."
An unusual first-night audience gathered cast night at the Carver Amphitheater on 102d Street between Park and Madison Avenues for the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's initial outdoor performance.

A building and permanent loan of $4.69-million at 6 per cent for 30 years has been placed with the Bowery Savings Bank in a refinancing of the 19-story building at 110 Church Street, at the southwest corner of Park Place.

TRENTON, Aug. 8--The State Division of Clean Air and Water proposed to clean the foul air over the Northern New Jersey metropolitan region today provided that industry, government and taxpaying homeowners were prepared to foot the bill.

MIDLAND, Tex., Aug. 8 (AP) --A temporary restraining order blocking the proposed acquisition of the Kern County Land Company by Tenneco, Inc., was issued here late yesterday by District Judge Perry Pickett.
The Lindsay administration has decided the public need not be suspicious of cabaret entertainers, go-go girls and bartenders.
A spin-off by Spartans Industries, Inc., of its 97-store discount department store chain, the Spartan-Atlantic stores, appeared likely yesterday.
PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Aug. 8--The people of Mauritius voted for independence yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 8--Four stores in East Jerusalem were padlocked by the Israeli au- thorities today and five arrest warrants were issued in retaliation for the general strike by the Arab population yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 8 (Reuters)-- France is buying more and selling relatively less in trade with foreign countries, according to French Finance Ministry figures released today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 8 --Ned Hinds of the Norwalk Shore and Country Club, Andy Singer of the Beach Point Yacht Club of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Bruce Mosbacher of Noro-- ton Y.C., were division winners in the Pequot Club's an-- nual Blue Jay midget invitation regatta after the last of three races in the two-day series was sailed on Long Island Sound today.

The Department of Sanitation yesterday fulfilled part of Mayor Lindsay's promise to the residents of Boerum Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn: It removed broken mattresses, cans and other debris that partly blocked the Mayor's stroll along the sidewalk Monday evening.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8--The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club crew from Port Washington, L.I., captained by Peter Dirkes, sailed into a 2-point lead today when the first three races of the final round-robin of the Long Island Sound junior championship regatta were held off the American Yacht Club.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 8 --Republican Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., and the Democratic cabinet dropped their cloaks of politeness today for a public exchange of charges and recriminations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --Senator A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma and chairman of the Senate Aviation Subcommittee, took issue today with the Justice Department's opposition to the merger of two manufacturers of jet planes--the Rockwell-Standard Corporation of Pittsburgh and North American Aviation, Inc., of Los Angeles.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 8--Victor Louis, the Russian journalist who has been carrying copies of Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs around to Western publishers for two weeks, said today that he got them through connections with the Stalin family.

HAVANA, Aug. 8--Informed sources reported tonight that an 11th-hour crisis had rocked the conference of the LatinAmerican Solidarity Organization after Cuba proposed a condemnation of Soviet economic policy in the hemisphere. Traditional Communists threatened to walk out, the sources said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --An Air Force mess attendant, dismissed for refusing to work on Saturday, the Seventh-day Adventist sabbath, has been ordered restored to her job, the Senate Constitutional Right Subcommittee reported today.
The state lottery issued its first batch of checks to winners yesterday, along with advice that winners check soon to find how much they will owe in taxes.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Aug. 8--Mr. and Mrs. B. Walter Sterenfeld have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Greer Sterenfeld, to Gerald Goldman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. Goldman of Newton Centre, Mass.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, chief of state and military candidate for President, said tonight that he was ready to make any compromise to bring about a resumption of the suspended presidential campaign.

SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP)--A Coast Guard airplane, returning from a successful search mission over the Pacific Ocean, crashed near Mount Mars in Monterey County yesterday, killing two airmen.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 8--The folds of her black habit rippling gently in the breeze, Sister Bonaventure Ghidoni, a 5-foot, 1-inch bundle of educational energy, skillfully guided a trim blue and white motorboat into Long Island Sound yesterday morning.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 8--Uruguay has fallen upon some of her worst times. Most of her citizens are bitter and confused about the trouble. Few believe any longer in the adage that Uruguay is the Switzerland of Latin America.
Enzo Magnozzi sighed deeply yesterday when he thought about how many ways his big, fat pie would be sliced.
The nation's death rate dropped far below normal-- sometimes below the minimal expectations--in each of the first 20 weeks of 1967.

FLORENCE, Italy, Aug. 4-- The great Crucifix of Cimabue, painted before 1288, lies on its back on a rack inside the vast 18th-century glasshouse called the Limonaia in the Boboli Gardens. Only the left side of Christ's face and parts of His arms and torso are intact-- the rest of the paint has vanished.

Vice President Humphrey made it painfully clear this week that the Johnson Administration is determined to fight poverty, urban decay and other root causes of civic unrest with all the slogans in its arsenal --provided it doesn't have to back them up with money.
The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday in Atlanta the formation of CocaCola Europe as a division of its foreign sales arm, the Coca-Cola Export Corporation.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 8 --The Association of Southeast Asian Nations was founded today in Bangkok's Foreign Ministry with the signing of a sevenpoint declaration.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 8 (AP)--A. W. Willis Jr., the first Negro elected to the Tennessee Legislature since Reconstruction, entered the crowded race for mayor of this Mississippi River city today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 (UPI)--A superior court judge upheld today the validity of the National Basketball Association's controversial option clause.

The P. Lorillard Company, a leading cigarette concern, announced yesterday it would continue to "seek opportunities to growth through acquisitions" as well as through further expansion of its tobacco operations.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8 --William Bowrey of Australia was close to disaster today in the Southampton invitation grass-court tennis tournament at the Meadow Club. An unranked player from Peoria, Ill., William Tym took the first set from Bowrey and led, 4-2 and 30-0 on the Aussie's service in the second before Bowrey applied himself and brought the full weight of his powerful strokes to bear and pulled out the victory 5-7 7-5, 6-3.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 8 (Reuters)--Discussions to avert a nationwide port workers strike in support of demands for increasing the port labor force are expected to begin tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- Total construction activity rose slightly in June to reach the highest level in 13 months, the Commerce Department reported today.
MONTROSE, Ala., Aug. 8 (UPI)--Percy H. Whiting, retired author, newspaperman and educational administrator, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old.

The launching of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in Bangkok yesterday fits into a healthy trend in the South Pacific. States that used to ignore or be in conflict with each other are now getting together in economic, cultural and scientific fields.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 8--A famine was declared today in 18 of the 43 districts in Madhya Pradesh by the new united-front government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Republicans in the House, backed by Southern Democrats, succeeded today in drastically revising President Johnson's principal anticrime bill to give most controls to the states and to provide strong antiriot measures.
Chet Huntley, commentator for the National Broadcasting Company, became the central figure yesterday in a New Jersey frontier feud involving a city celebrity and farming folk.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 8--One of the top planners of the Hong Kong riots was reported today to have defected to Taiwan.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8--The Royal Canadian Mounted Police, at a border crossing 40 miles south of Montreal today, seized aid parcels destined for North Vietnam from eight American pacifists who had been refused export permits by the United States Government.
A display booth in the exhibition hall at the Americana Hotel yesterday was dominated by a poster with a bust of Socrates and the following words:
The Bristol-Myers Company announced here yesterday the election as a director of Henry H. Henley, president of Cluett, Peabody Co., an apparel manufacturer.

GENEVA, Aug. 8--The nonproductive negotiations on a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons reached a turning point today with the announcement that William C. Foster, United States representative in the disarmament conference, would return to Washington tomorrow.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday in the first of a series of abbreviated trading sessions designed to clear the pile-up of paperwork that has developed from heavy trading in recent weeks.

Another first for the city's summer street recreational program will take place at noon Saturday when the world lightweight champion, Carlos Ortiz, will train on Fast 112th Street, between Second and Third Avenues.
C. James Lombardi Jr., an East Side druggist, was freed in $10,000 bail yesterday pending his retrial on charges of attempted rape, assault and attempted assault.
CAPITAL gains taxes going up? That's the thesis of vinegary John Wright in his latest installment of Wright Advisory Reports published weekly in Bridgeport, Conn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. Aug. 8--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Mackey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Alice Mackey, to Anthony M. Carey 3d, son of Mrs. Carey Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. Carey.
After more than half a century as a girl's school, Julia Richman High School, 317 East 67th Street, will admit 450 boys this fall.
MOSCOW, Aug. 8--Two Russian adventurers missing more than two weeks on a desolate peninsula in the Arctic were found by helicopters today, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

TAKAMATSU, Japan, Aug. 8 --After 15 hours of rescue operations, workers managed to bring out alive today the trapped skipper of a small Japanese tanker that had collided with a Chinese Nationalist freighter in Japan's heavily traveled Inland Sea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- Paul H. Douglas, once the Senate's most tenacious champion of "truth in lending," urged the House today to fight for a tough credit disclosure law.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 8--A sliding scale for golf purses depending on the quality of the field was recommended today by the International Golf Sponsors Association. The sponsors proposed a minimum purse of $75,000 for tour events that would be increased to $110,000 if nine of the top 10 moneywinners of the preceding year participated.

A PATCHWORK documentary on the Erie Canal was offered last night by WCBS-TV; it was hardly worth the required minimum budget of film. A handful of generalizations about the erstwhile economic importance of the waterway was pieced out with random scenes of the canal's glorious days and its abandonment in many parts of the state today.
LEEDS, England, Aug. 8 (AP)--The British Army today introduced a new tank, the Chieftain, which it described as "the battle tank of the seventies."

At the heart of the latest report by the Civil Rights Commission on the slow pace of Southern school desegregation is the warning by its staff director, William L. Taylor, that "we are going to raise another generation" unprepared for equal opportunities in a competitive society.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (UPI)--Jess Willard, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, lost today a $1.35-million damage suit over the televising of films of the 26-round fight in which he captured the title from Jack Johnson in Havana in 1915.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- The Senate approved without a dissenting vote today a bill to preserve and protect "some of America's unspoiled and free flowing streams, or their segments, that symbolize this vanishing heritage of our original landscape."

"Don't fight the fireman-- he's your friend." City firemen said yesterday that they would spend $15,000 disseminating this slogan and urging rioters not to shoot or throw bottles and bricks at firemen responding to an alarm.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 8 --The head of Nashville's antipoverty agency admitted today that his testimony last Friday at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on a liberation school here was "not exactly correct."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (UPI)-- A mother stricken with leukemia was shot to death today in her hospital bed. Her son, quoted by his father as saying, "She's out of her misery now--I shot her," was charged with her murder.
Two advertising men at Conde Nast Publications, Inc., Gordon N. Morford and Ralph F. Timm, have been named magazine publishers --Mr. Morford of Mademoiselle and Mr. Timm of Glamour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House minority leader, said today that he saw "no justification for sending one more American" soldier to South Vietnam until President Johnson removed restrictions on the bombing campaign against North Vietnam.
DETROIT, Aug. 8--A $300,000 laboratory, 1,000 feet deep in the ground, has been built under Detroit by the missiles and space division of the LTV Aerospace Corporation.
HAVANA, Aug. 8 (AP)--The Cuban radio announced today the postponement of the closing of the conference amid reports of differences among the delegates.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 8-- Oscar R L was added today to the field for the ninth annual Roosevelt International Trot, which will be held here Aug. 19. The 9-year-old stallion, joining Roquepine, the renowned 6-year-old mare, will give France double representation in the 1 -mile classic for a gross purse of $100,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 (AP)--The California Bankcard Asscociation spoke out today in rebuttal to criticism made a House Banking subcommittee of the association's instant credit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --The Justice Department's decision to take over Veterans Administration mortgage foreclosures has cost the Government $800,000 since 1965, a House Government Operations Committee report states.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 --Terre Bonne, a Gothic chateau here, will be open to the public from 5 to 8 P.M. on Sunday for a reception and buffet dinner benefiting the National Council of Women of the United States. Mr. and Mrs. David H. Cogan, the chateau owners, are the hosts.
Ohrbach's and E.J. Korvette will open new stores in the New York metropolitan area on the same day, Aug. 17, both companies said in separate announcements yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 8--Mr. and Mrs. James F. Watson of Garden City and Morrisville, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annmarie Bernadette Watson, to Lieut. Raymond Joseph Alexander, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco J. Alexander of East Hartford, Conn.
The Internal Revenue Service has begun distributing new guidelines to help taxpayers determine whether the tickets they buy for fund-raising charitable events are deductible.
MOUNT BULLER, Australia, Aug. 8 (UPI)--Rick Chaffee, a 21-year-old student at the University of Vermont, won the Australian giant slalom Alpine ski title today from an international field.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines plans to submit a plan for the construction of a threeship nuclear-powered fleet, John M. Will, chairman of the company's board, disclosed yesterday.
CAIRO, Aug. 8 (AP)--The newspaper Al Akhbar said today that a threeman committee had been formed to work out a peace formula acceptable to all parties in the four-year-old Yemeni civil war.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 8 (AP)--L.B. Maytag, industrialist and former president of the Maytag Company, of Newton, Iowa, maker of washing machines, died at his home here today. He would have been 79 years old on Aug. 24.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, appears headed for recovery from his latest health difficulty, a gastrointestinal upset.
ATLANTA, Aug. 8 (UPI)-- Gov. Lester G. Maddox said tonight that he had agreed to an audience to two escaped convicts on the condition they release a woman hostage.

"NOT everybody goes back to school in September," said Sheila Levy, fashion director for Gimbels in New York, explaining why the store had created a coordinated group of dresses, coats, suits and accessories suitable to the small-boned woman who didn't want to look like a teen-ager.
Color the Grand Concourse Nile green, buttercup yellow and brick red.

A Federal judge ruled late Monday that the entire board of directors of the General Contract Finance Corporation, St. Louis, is liable for more than $600,000 in damages because of insurance commissions wrongfully paid to two of its members. A copy of the decision was made available here yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 8--Negotiators for automobile manufacturers say they are getting ready to reject the bulk of the new contract demands of the United Automobile Workers.
Frederick Zimmermann, double bass player with the New York Philharmonic from 1930 to 1966, died in Ohlstadt, Germany, last Thursday. He lived at 321 West 55th Street and he was 61 years old.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Aug. 8 (AP)--Part of a huge oil refinery near here blew up early today, killing three men and starting a dangerous fire. Three men were missing.

Second-quarter net profit of the Commercial Credit Company improved to $7,503,926, or 67 cents a share, from $6,695,465, or 61 cents a share, earned in the corresponding three months last year, the unaudited report of the company disclosed yesterday. Net sales increased to $79,427,623 from $76,232,997.

ALBANY, Aug. 8--With only a few cries of "no" from the Republican side, the Constitutional Convention shouted approval today for the creation of a bipartisan commission to take reapportionment out of the hands of the Legislature.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 8--The secessionist government of Ni- geria's Eastern Region was accused today of preparing to cede oil and other mineral rights in its territory to the Rothschild Bank in France in return for $16.8-million in foreign currency.
BAY BEACH, Ont., Aug. 8 (AP)--The defending champion, Bud Melges of Lake Geneva, Wis., sailed to the opening-day lead in the national open Flying Dutchman Class championship today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 8-- One of the longest singles in Mickey Mantle's career, a towering drive against the leftcenterfield fence near the 396foot mark, aided the New York Yankees to a 1-0 victory tonight over the California Angels.
PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 8 (AP)--Pen Duick III, a 55foot French schooner skippered by Eric Tabarly, took over the lead in the 605-mile Fastnet Rock Yacht race tonight.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 8--A quick and quiet revolution has transformed Roman Catholic seminary education in the Netherlands from an inefficient system of small rural institutions to one of the most progressive in the entire church.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 8-- Dean A. Andrews Jr., a New Orleans lawyer who has said, "I'll be the only person ever convicted in the assassination of President Kennedy and I don't know beans about it," will go on trial for perjury here tomorrow.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 8--Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., and Karen Krantzcke of Australia led the field into the second round of the annual women's invitation grass-court tennis tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.
The new developments being tested in Illinois and Massachusetts may one day make the printed word far more accessible to blind persons.

About 475 children from 10 Head Start programs crowded into a school auditorium in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday afternoon to sing, jump, yell and clap along with Tom Glazer, a folk singer, and his guitar.
The Polaroid Corporation announced yesterday the election to its board of Henry Necarsulmer, a general partner of the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 8--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's governing Congress party lost a vote in Parliament today for the first time since India gained independence 20 years ago.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 8 (AP)--Audley Farm Stable's Bag of Ice won the six-furlong Hamilton Purse at Atlantic City today by three lengths under Chuck Baltazar.

Directors of the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company voted yesterday in Chicago to reduce the extra dividend to 25 cents a common share from the 50 cents paid a year ago. The extra, plus the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents, is payable Sept. 6 to holders of record Aug. 21.
GENEVA, Aug. 8--The European chemical industry contends it has made considerable sacrifices to assure the success of the Kennedy round of trade negotiations that were completed here last June.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --The publisher of The El Paso (Tex.) Times urged today the enactment of an antitrust exemption for the merger or joint operation of financially failing newspapers.
THE waistline, rather than the hemline, is where the fashion action apparently is going to be this season. It was the focal point in the collections of Norman Norell and James Galanos.
Interest rates in different sectors of the bond market moved in different directions yesterday. United States Government and tax-exempt bond rates declined, while corporate bond rates advanced.

Light but persistent selling set the London Stock Exchange back yesterday along a fairly broad front. Before the close, the price declines had reached such popular blue chips as Unilever, Dunlop, Courtaulds, Rolls Royce and English Electric.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) --A compromise bill authorizing $4.9-billion for the United States civilian space program won final Congressional approval today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8--All a fellow had to do at the race track today was "roll" 11 and 3 and there he was, in possession of a small bankroll. This combination produced a daily double payoff of $2,256 for $2, a record for this region, long associated with big returns on quick hazards.
Striking telephone workers and the New York Telephone Company reached a settlement yesterday, ending a nine-day walkout involving more than 25,000 members of the Communications Workers of America.
Stereotypers at The Daily News walked off the job for three hours last night, holding up production of late editions of the newspaper. They returned at 1:15 A.M. today.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it was increasing by 3 to 7.5 per cent the prices of most industrial rubber products and rubber automotive parts, excluding tires.
Richard E. Linburn, a retired stockbroker, died Monday in his home at 1160 Park Avenue of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

The Constitutional Convention's overwhelming adoption yesterday of a plan for a bipartisan commission to draw Congressional and legislative district lines was as close to a political miracle as can be hoped for these days. It represented a striking demonstration of the power of aroused public opinion to balk a reactionary move by the entrenched leaders of both major parties acting in concert.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8-- Trading volume declined on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange today after trading hours were curtailed to permit member firms to catch up on an avalanche of paper work caused by a high volume of business.

"I BELIEVE in the decencies," says Mr. Parks the mousey protagonist of the second of these two adroitly chilling tales--"however much you wish someone would be pushed onto an electric line." Parks is slowly losing his mind.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Opposition is mounting in the House against three draft treaties aimed at terminating the United States' 64-year-old sovereignty over the Panama Canal and placing the Canal under joint United States-Panamanian administration.

Walter Neale, who retired in 1955 as vice president, treasurer and director of the Duplan Corporation, a textile manufacturer, died Monday in San Rafaet, Calif. He was 68 years old and formerly lived here and in Rye,. N.Y.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 8-- Chile is opposed to any plans for an inter-American force to combat guerrillas, according to an article in the daily newspaper El Diario Ilustrado today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8 (AP)--A North Vietnamese defector introduced by the South Vietnamese Government as a lieutenant colonel said today that the allies would win the war, perhaps in two or three years.
ALBANY, Aug. 8--A committee of the Constitutional Convention voted today to retain the present system of electing most judges in the state, rather than appointing them.

What was to have been a three-week idyl at a camp in Hunter, N.Y., for 65 children from the Newark riot area ended abruptly on the 12th day yesterday when the 8-to-13year-olds were bused back to Newark.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- House Republicans decided today not to take a party stand against President Johnson's plan to reorganize the District of Columbia city government.
The election of William S. Field as a vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America was announced yesterday in Newark.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI)--The Government estimated today that this year's cotton harvest would be the smallest since 1921--and on the smallest acreage in almost a century.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8--The United States military command in Vietnam has started to move into its new, spacious headquarters, generally called Pentagon East.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 8 (UPI)--Two Molotov cocktails were thrown at a dry-cleaning establishment on the west side of South Bend tonight as sporadic vandalism continued in this city where serious disorders occurred two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- There is far too much drug advertising and too little training for doctors on the proper choice and use of drugs, two witnesses told a Senate hearing today.
Eighteen New York Congressmen yesterday criticized Governor Rockefeller's plan to lease a major part of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan for state offices.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP)--Two white Detroit policemen, charged with first degree murder in connection with the slaying of two Negro youths in a motel in the racial turmoil here last month, were freed on $5,000 bond each today.
LONDON, Aug. 8 (Reuters) --Britain's space effort was criticized today as a record of wasted opportunities marked by lack of purpose, policy and proper organization.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that the Democratic plan for hearings on the city's antipoverty and welfare programs was not designed as an attack on Mayor Lindsay's administration.
LONDON, Aug. 8--Aleksei Flegon, the London book publisher, dismissed Mr. Louis' remarks about him as "the Soviet line put out by a Soviet journalist."

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 8 --Riding with a 102-degree fever, Teri Ardleigh won two of the three equitation championships at the Sussex County Horse Show today, but missed equaling her feat of last year when she swept the entire division.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Boog Powell's error allowed the tie-breaking run to score and Chuck Hinton's sacrifice fly produced another as the Cleveland Indians rallied for two runs in the ninth inning and a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

A proposal before the Constitutional Convention to authorize the Legislature to provide free higher education for all state residents drew cautious responses yesterday from several government officials and educators. Most said they wanted to see specific forms of the proposal before commenting.

Miss Jane Bergerman and Martin J. Usdan plan to marry on Sept. 9. Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Bergerman of 863 Park Avenue and Rowayton, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. David Usdan of New York and the late Mr. Usdan.

Three flights of stairs above the Bowery, Ralph Grant, parttime painter, part-time dancer, part-time commercial artist ("I have to make a living"), looked around his loft, with its bare brick walls and a ceiling pockmarked with rust.

HONOLULU, Aug. 8--Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that America's involvement in Vietnam was contributing to racial unrest at home, while the domestic disorders, in turn were encouraging Hanoi and the Vietcong to fight on.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Wednesday, Aug. 9--This city's Common Council, meeting in extraordinary session in the basement auditorium of a Roman Catholic church here, defeated by a 9-to-1 vote early this morning a proposed antiloitering ordinance. Negroes had charged it was aimed at keeping them off the streets.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug., 8 --Lincoln Kirstein is best known as the man who founded the New York City Ballet and helped George Balanchine bring it to its present eminence. But he is also a distinguished writer. He has published art criticism, books on ballet, and two or three volumes of verse. Now he has committed a play.

TAXCO, Mexico, Aug. 8 (AP) --William Spratling, who put the name of this ancient colonial village on the map as a leading silvercraft center, died today in an automobile accident. He was 67 years old.

THE seventh meeting in the 12-race Trans-American championship series is scheduled for Saturday and Sunday at Upper Marlboro, Md., and for the first time, the under2-liter and over-2-liter cars will run in separate divisions. The smaller sedans, so far dominated by Porsche and Alfa Romeo, will run on Saturday afternoon and the big sedans, such Mercury Cougar, Shelby Mustang, Dodge Dart, Chevrolet Camaro and Plymouth Barracuda, will go Sunday afternoon.
THE man appointed yesterday to head the $52-mil- lion-a-year fortunes of the old American publishing house of Harper Row is a member of that distinctive fraternity of intellectuals without degrees.
The two largest West German steamship lines, North German Lloyd and HamburgAmerican, have ordered four containerships for the North Atlantic trade.

There were two extreme moments in last night's Mozart Festival concert at Philharmonic Hall, the blithe tomfoolery of a mock-Turkish passage in the Cassation for Flute, Clarinet, Horn and Bassoon and the extraordinary harmonic originality" in a slow-movement passage of the great Quintet for Piano, Oboe, Clarinet, Horn and Bassoon in E flat (K.452).

William Kolmer, vice president and a founder of KolmerMarcus, Inc., a men's clothing store at Broadway, and 37th Street, died Monday in Miami, where he was on vacation. He was 72 years old and lived at 875 Fifth Avenue.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Aug. 8--The Isle of Man's elected representatives, in a Ruritanian scuffle with the British Government regarding pirate radio, decided today to appeal their grievances to the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Following are excerpts from a report of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency and individual views of Senators William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, on the Export-Import Bank:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 8-- Backed by Gov. Robert E. McNair, the South Carolina branch of the N.A.A.C.P. is coordinating an effort to create a state- wide volunteer biracial panel to study the racial situation in the state.

JACKSON, Miss., Wednesday, Aug. 9--State Treasurer William Winter and Representative John Bell Williams won places in a runoff battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday in Mississippi's primary election.
"Harry, you lucky dog!" the customer said enviously to his broker yesterday. "I hear the exchanges are closing at 2 P.M. That means you can take off early and play some golf."

Frank C. Norris, a novelist and former managing editor of Time magazine, died after a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at his summer home at Siasconset, Mass., on the island of Nantucket. He was 60 years old.

QUICK, cooling summertime desserts that require no cooking are appealing to the homemaker who must supply youngsters with interesting and nutritious snacks. The following ice cream recipes are bound to please.
The Metropolitan Opera House yesterday acquired a new artistic dimension. Lighting, once limited to the role of illumination, has joined scenery and costume as a partner in the production of opera.

MAXIMILLION Productions' "Absolutely Time," which will be given today at the 92d Street Y.M., has an effective closing scene in which the audience brings a smile to the lips of a gloomy princess. Up to that point, the show time and again passes up the rich comic possibilities of its setting (a kingdom where nobody laughs) for routine funny faces and frantic chases that might happen in any kingdom anywhere.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8 (UPI)--United States Fourth Division infantrymen reported killing 65 guerrillas today in a 10-hour jungle battle near Quangngai, 325 miles northeast of Saigon. A spokesman said one American had been killed and four wounded.

CARMEL VALLEY, Calif., Aug. 8--Theater is where you find it, and this weekend I found two relatively unheralded ones that have been created and sustained by young people with a commitment to an idea. The White Oaks Theater is situated here and it has the temerity to attempt musicals in repertory.

ALBANY, Aug. 8--Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he had called a meeting of the policy committee of the Republican Governors Conference to discuss immediate means of relaxing tension in the nation's racial ghettos.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press)--Ronnie Barnes of Brazil overcame Frank Tutvin of Toronto, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2, and Herb FitzGibbon of Garden City, L.I., scored a 6-1, 6-3, 6-2 victory over Marc Blondeau of Quebec in the second round of the Canadian tennis championships today.
Equipment valued at more than $3-million was carted yesterday into Room 206 of Uris Hall, Columbia University's computer center, as the university began an expansion of its facilities.
SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (UPI)--A committee supporting Senator Robert F. Kennedy as the Democratic party's Presidential nominee in 1968 has been formed in the state of Washington, it was announced today.
ALBANY, Aug. 8--A proposal that could increase New York City's power to levy nonproperty taxes has been reported to the floor of the Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- The bill to extend the life and lending authority of the Export-Import Bank was called up in the Senate today and immediately ran into a cross fire of amendments that, if sustained, could restrict the Administration's freedom of action in foreign policy in two important areas.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP)-- Carlos Marquez was seriously injured today when his mount was involved in a three-horse spill in the second race at Arlington Park.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --The Pentagon issued a call today for the drafting of 17,000 men in October, the lowest in six months.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 8--The home of Councilman Leo A. Jackson, a Negro Democrat, was the target of an attempted firebombing early this morning.
SAIGON, Aug. 8--Another American plane was shot down in North Vietnam yesterday. Bad weather limited air attacks to the southern panhandle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- More Americans held jobs in July than in any other month in history as the economy absorbed a summer flood of 3.6 million young persons without any increase in unemployment.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (AP)-- United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark has accused Local 38 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers of racial discrimination in the union's apprenticeship program.
Murray Schisgal, whose double bill of "The Typist" and "The Tiger" were first produced Off Broadway and who then became a Broadway playwright with "Luv," will return to Off Broadway.

In December 1908, shortly before leaving office, President Theodore Roosevelt submitted a report to Congress in which he observed: "The present administration of affairs of the District of Columbia by three commissioners...has the inevitable defects of divided responsibility, confusion of authority, and administration by a board instead of by a single responsible executive."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 (AP)--A rat extermination program such as Congress recently refused to fund would not work, says Dr. Leo Kartman, the nation's chief Federal investigator of rats and wild rodents.

Israeli authorities padlocked four stores in East Jerusalem yesterday and issued warrants for the arrest of five alleged instigators of a general strike that halted all business activity in the Old City and former Jordanian sector on Monday. "We're trying to make the punishment fit the crime," one Israeli official said of the padlockings. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Mrs. Orlena Zabriskie Scoville of Taconic, Conn., who was decorated by the Portuguese Government for rebuilding a ruined old palace, Quinta da Bacalhoa, in Azeitao, Portugal, died there yesterday. Her age was 80.
Issues closed mixed in heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in an abbreviated session.

HONG KONG, Aug. 8--A Red Guard newspaper has painted a vivid picture of the recent riots in the Chinese city of Wuhan, describing how "conservatives" killed supporters of Mao Tsetung with spears, pitchforks and axes.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8--Three of the four quarter-final matches in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here yesterday were hard-fought battles.
Leslie Uggams, star of "Hallelujah, Baby," has been signed by the American Broadcasting Company to star in a special program in the fall. No date has been set.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 8 (UPI)--Roy Emerson of Australia and Francoise Durr of France overcame a broiling sun today as they captured the singles titles in the West Gernan championships.
The first man to fly at "more than twice the speed of sound, A. Scott Crossfield, was named yesterday as system director of research and development for flight by Eastern Airlines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- The loser in the bitterly contested election last May for the presidency of the National Federation of Republican Women has taken the first steps toward organizing her conservative followers into a rival group.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --President Johnson brought a collection of House Democrats to the White House today and with chalk and blackboard went over the Government's tax and financial problems.

Paul H. Fassnacht, a mechanical engineer and president of Precision Shapes, Inc., of Suffern, N.Y., died Saturday in Bad Oeynhausen, Germany, while he was on a visit. He was 74 years old and lived in Placida, Fla.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 8-- The bitterness that long characterized relations on Taiwan between the ethnic Chinese natives of the island and the Chinese from the mainland has receded into the background.
The American Museum of Natural History soberly reported yesterday that it had on display four live pink grasshoppers.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Aug. 9 Mrs. Phyllis Pugatch was sitting quietly in her kitchen at 7 o'clock tonight. Her husband, Martin, a salesman, was pulling into the driveway outside.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 9 Tucker Frederickson, the New York Giants' star fullback of two years ago and the most notable of the club's walking wounded last season, passed another test here today on the road to renewed mobility.

A crowd of 200 Negroes, some of them wearing the uniforms of black nationalist organizations, milled in the corridors of Queens County Courthouse yesterday as State Supreme Court Justice John R. Starkey put off until Oct. 24 a hearing on motions to dismiss indictments against 17 Negroes charged with conspiracy to commit anarchy.
The destroyer squadron flagship Wilkinson will visit New York Aug. 19 and 20 and will be open to the public those days from 1 to 4 P.M. at the foot of West 48th Street (pier 88).

VIENNA, Aug. 9 (Reuters) Between 100 and 300 people were believed to have drowned in a pleasure-boat disaster on Lake Tel, near Bucharest, according to unofficial reports reaching here today. [Rumanian sources confirmed that at least 50 had died in the incident Sunday, United Press International reported.]

PARIS, Aug. 9 The pictorial weekly Paris Match has acquired exclusive French rights to the memoirs of Mrs. Alliluyeva. Apparently to protect the rights it had previously bought from her American agents, Paris Match decided to publish the 1963 Moscow version, "My Life With Father: 20 Letters to a Friend."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Sanford L. Platt, vice, president and representative here since 1959 of the Hawaiian Sugar Planters Association, died today in Colorado Springs, apparently of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.
"The Fantastic World of Sophia Loren" will be presented on the American Broadcasting Company on Oct. 25 at 10 P.M.
Blessed with a tight, experienced team that could show the Actor's Studio a thing or two, the Baltimore Bays found themselves a 1-0 victor over the New York Generals at Yankee Stadium last night.
The Kern County Land Company asserted last night that a stockholders' suit to block its proposed merger with Tenneco, Inc., "is without merit" and "entirely contrary to the facts."
KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 9 White mercenaries and dissident Katangese soldiers marched up to the Rwanda border this morning and released some 150 European civilians who had been in their control.
SHANGUGU, Rwanda, Aug. 9--White mercenary forces swept through Bukavu today, scattering Congolese troops before them and taking up commanding positions on the Rwanda border.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 The greatest money earner in thoroughbred history, Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's Kelso, will come back to the race track tomorrow, as an actor. The 10-year-old gelidng which amassed $1,977,898 through a career that ended last year, will demonstrate his skill at dressage and jumping under the handling of Alison Cram, a former national junior dressage champion. He wlll porform on the jumping track between the fourth and fifth races.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday as investors continued to be cautious.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) J. Edgar Hoover described the "new left" today, as a "new kind of conspiracy in our country."
Corn futures set another round of new lifetime lows for all contracts yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) Earl Wilson pitched a five-hitter and Al Kaline drove in two runs with a sacrifice fly and a home run tonight as the Detroit Tigers defeated the American League-leading Chicago White Sox, 4-2.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 New York City would be able to borrow $440-million extra to finance housing and other capital projects, under proposals approved today by a committee of the Constitutional Convention.

Miss Louise Crosby Mathews, daughter of Sidney Mathews of 1192 Park Avenue and Mrs. Dorothea S. Mathews of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Squire Newland Bozorth, son of Mrs. Squire Smith Bozorth of Lake Oswego, Ore., and the late Dr. Bozorth.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Dyer Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Dyer, to Timothy J. Politis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Politis of Mechanicville, N.Y.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 9 Troops of the airmobile First Cavalry Division were dropped by helicopter on a fortified North Vietnamese tunnel stronghold in the central coastal mountains today, touching off a battle in which ten United States soldiers were reported to have been killed.

MOUNT CARMEL, Conn., Aug. 9 The chairman of the panel formed by President Johnson last year to assess the world food problem said today that the pride of American agriculture, hybrid corn, had proved to be somewhat of a dud to food production in underdeveloped lands. What has succeeded instead, he added, is American skill in producing net and better strains.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9 Frank Froehling 3d of New York was eliminated from the fouthampton invitation tennis ournament today and William Bowrey of Australia and Ray Moore of South Africa each lost the opening set of his match at the Meadow Club.
Rain fills reservoirs but drains open-air concerts of audiences.

"When the volume soars, the back office roars" With this phrase, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, set into perspective yesterday the huge problem of paper work bedeviling the brokerage industry.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (AP) --Soviet scientists have launched two unmanned spacecraft to test a new parachute system designed to avoid the malfunction blamed for the death of an astronaut last April, informed sources said Wednesday.

The battle of City Hall duplicating machines continues yesterday as unidentified "spokes- men" for City Council President Frank D. O'Connor and Mayor Lindsay debated whether there should be an investigation of antipoverty and welfare programs here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --Following is the roll-call vote by which the House voted, 244 to 160, to sustain President Johnson's plan to reorganize the District of Columbia government. The motion was to disapprove it. A yes vote meant a vote against the plan; a no vote, for it.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 A Washington report that the Pentagon is thinking of removing United States military bases here and in Okinawa and placing them in Guam and the Marianas Islands, outside the range of Chinese Communist nuclear missiles, has sharpened interest in the issue of these bases.

A new committee, Americans for Permanent Peace in the Middle East, which contends that Soviet expansionist policies in the region constitute an increasing threat to the permanent interests of the United States, announced its formation today with an advertisement in The New York Times.
SHEEPSHEAD BAY'S party and charter boat fleet on the southern end of Brooklyn remains the last stronghold in a neighborhood that once was the brightest sports area in metropolitan New York.
Three masked gunmen one wearing a wig and false nose robbed three guards of the United States Trucking Corporation yesterday and escaped with a $14,389 payroll.

Contributions acknowledged by the Fresh Air Fund today totaled $328,559,12. The fund has set a goal of $625,000 this year to support free summer vacations in private rural and suburban homes for nearly 13,000 needy New York City children and for 2,500 boys and girls at its natural-wilderness camping facilities in Dutchess County, N.Y.

A hospital employes' union offered $7,800 yesterday to send 62 Negro children from the Newark riot area to Camp Abelard at Hunter, N.Y., after learning that the vacations of 65 other children at the camp had been cancelled for lack of financial support by the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Heaven help the working girl, particularly if she tries to buy burglary and theft insurance. She is not only the prime target of burglars but also the growing despair of the insurance industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Many persons have been infuriated this summer by the demagogic virtuosity of H. Rap Brown, but very few know "Brown's" true identity. His real name is John Green and he is an undercover outside agitator on the payroll of the Senate Appropriations Committee.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP) A rising market in thoroughbred horses was evident in the second edition of the 47th annual Saratoga yearling sales in the Fasig-Tipton Company ring tonight.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 9 The engagement of Miss Sharon Way to Warren Leslie Tittle has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Way. Mr. Tittle is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Tittle.
Plans for construction of new plants were announced by several companies yesterday.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation achieved the highest sales, revenues and earnings in its 47year history for the second quarter and first half this year, Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, reported yesterday to some 108,000 shareholders.

CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 9 (UPI) Throngs of Negroes marched up and down the main street of Chattanooga tonight protesting a speech by former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. The police blocked off a 24-square block area.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 Sixty Jewish business leaders from 13 countries met today to talk about how Israel could in the next decade expand her economy enough to end her dependence on gifts from Jews throghout the world.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 The sagging state lottery had an even more dismal sales performance in July, its second month, than in June.

Federal approval of plans for a $9.5-million combination home-and-hospital for the aged in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, was announced jointly yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Abe Stark, Borough President of Brooklyn.

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 9 Helen Clay Frick, the only surviving child of Henry Clay Frick, the late Pittsburgh "coke king,' withdrew today her libel suit against a historian she had charged with defaming the memory of her father. But the argument over the historian's assessment of Mr. Frick as "stern, brusque and autocratic" and an enemy of labor unions continued when Miss Frick issued a statement expressing "delight" at the author's "retraction of false statements."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9 Intrepid's steering rudder was replaced with a smaller one and then the 12-Meter yacht's bottom received new coats of copper-colored paint at 3 o'clock this morning. About 12 hours later the yacht joined Constellation in sailing exercises.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) American business is estimated to have direct investments abroad with a total book value of about $25-billion.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 Dean A. Andrews Jr., a onetime lawyer for Lee Harvey Oswald, made a legal attack tonight on the right of District Attorney Jim Garrison to try Mr. Andrews for periury.

The stock market moved back onto an upward track yesterday although closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange were not as strong as they had been earlier in the session.
HAVANA, Aug. 9 (Reuters) The Organization of LatinAmerican Solidarity approved a resolution today condemning Soviet economic and technical policy in the Western Hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the continuous rise in medical prices "reflects an antiquated system for delivery of health care."
STARK, N.H., Aug. 9 (UPI) The 20-year-old son of Paul Goodman, author and social critic, was killed yesterday in a mountain climbing accident near his family's summer home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 The Administration has offered a home ownership plan for low-income families.
Howard J. Samuels, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor last year, is expected to be named Under Secretary of Commerce by President Johnson later this month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 The Senate defeated today by a vote of 48 to 40 a move to impose a ban on the financing of arms sales to underdeveloped countries by the Export-Import Bank.
MONTREAL, Aug. 9 Harry Benjamin, newspaper and magazine distributor, died yesterday at his home. He was 72 years old.
Ten thousand subscribers at $2.50 a ticket to four shows are sought by Joseph Papp for the new 299-seat Florence Sutro Anspacher Theater in the former Astor Library, 425 Lafayette Street.

OXFORD, Miss., Aug. 9 The engagement of Miss Jean Christine Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper Howard Williamson, to the Rev. Douglas Paul Walrath, son of Mrs. Leon Paul Walrath of Troy, N.Y., and the late Mr. Walrath, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
