DENISON, Iowa, Aug. 9 (AP) Maj. Gen. Junior F. Miller, Adjutant General of the Iowa National Guard, and a National Guard pilot parachuted to safety from a military airplane after an engine flameout today.
LONDON, Aug. 9 Joe Orton, 34-year-old British playwright, was found dead today in his apartment in Islington, north London.

The New York Mets enjoyed two of those baseball rarities yesterday: an afternoon game and a four-run first inning. And they made maximum use of both to defeat the Atlanta Braves for the second straight time, 5-1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Retail sales in June rose 2 per cent above the May level, revised Census Bureau figures showed today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 9 Tory Fretz of Los Angeles, the second-seeded player, defeated Ann Moore of New Orleans, 6-2, 6-2, and entered the quarter-finals of the women's invitation grass-court tennis tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

ATHENS, Aug. 9 The Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America opened its first meeting on Greek soil today with the aim of improving cultural and religious ties between Orthodox communicants in Greece and the Americas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Senator Charles H. Percy is seriously considering seeking the role of favorite-son candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination from Illinois next year.

LONDON, Aug. 9 The influence of the American dance is to be found all across northern Europe, in Germany, Denmark, Sweden, even in the Soviet Union. But it is in the Netherlands and Britain that it makes its deepest impression. Some American choreographers have found more recognition in Britain than in their native land.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 10 An experiment of potential significance to the arts is being conducted in the Pacific Northwest. It involves intercommunity and interstate cooperation and is likely to become international in scope. If it succeeds it could become a model for other regional consortiums ...
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 9--Reliable Arab sources reported today that the Sudan had arranged to obtain armaments from the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Less than three months after Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, publicly denounced the idea of a coalition with Southern Democrats, such a coalition has voted against the Administration Democrats on a number of important issues.

The Security First National Bank of Los Angeles and the Pacific National Bank of San Francisco announced yesterday that they had started negotiations "looking toward a possible merger." Tho two banks stressed that no agreement had been reached and that, if a merger were proposed, it would havo to be approved by stockholdors as well as Federal regulatory authorities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The Navy has issued what it describes as the final list of 134 dead in the fire that swept the carrier Forrestal off North Vietnam July 29.

Audiences, being what they are, will naturally cough, whisper, shuffle and rustle their programs throughout any performance. Last night in a Dance Theater Workshop concert at 215 West 20th Street, Gus Solomons Jr. did not request silence but only that the audience do what comes naturally, as accompaniment to his dance "Kinesia #5." And it did.
"I LIVE in a very sophisticated neighborhood, but when I asked for a cab, the doorman said, 'Where are you going?' I said, 'Circle Line,' and he said, 'You're kidding!'"

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 9 Unofficial but usually reliable sources reported today that troops from Nigeria's secessionist former Eastern Region had attacked in the Midwest, apparently linking their move to a reported mutiny among federal troops in that state.

Frederick C. Hessler, retired payroll manager of The New York Times Company, died Sunday of a heart attack at Andes, in the Catskills, while visiting his daughter, Mrs. Harold Gundelach. He was 67 years old.
Stately neoclassical and mellow Tudor are out and shimmering curtain-wall modernity is on the way in at the bustling intersection of Queens Boulevard and Continental Avenue in Forest Hills.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 9-- The Laotian Government has ended a two-week opium war in the Thai-Laotian-Burmese border area by bombing Chinese Nationalist and Burmese Shan forces that were fighting in Laotian territory, high Laotian military sources said today.

NEWARK, Aug. 9 (AP) The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit today against Gov. Richard J. Hughes and other State Officials on behalf of 66 Negro families of Plainfield whose homes were searched for stolen weapons during racial rioting last month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) Manny Sanguillen, a rookie catcher, hit a bases-loaded double, driving in three runs as the Pittsburgh Pirates rallied for four runs in the ninth inning and a 10-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the second game of a double-header today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9 The Rocky Point Club crew from Old Greenwich, Conn., captained by Tim Etchells, won the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship by one point today when Etchells sailed his Lightning Class sloop, Good Grief, to victory in the final race of the series off American Yacht Club.
One of two patrolmen diverted the attention yesterday of a young woman who threatened to jump 12 stories from a roof and she was seized and brought to safety.

SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 9 The United States chess champion, 24-year-old Bobby Fischer of New York, got off to a bad start at the end of the second round of the 18-man Tournament of Solidarity here last night.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 9 The town of Westport served notice last night that it intends to fight vigorously against any plan for a nuclear power plant on a deserted island one mile from its shore.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 9 (AP) A Chinese Communist defector from Hong Kong, Wu Shutung, said today that anti-British violence in the colony was instigated by Hong Kong Communists without outside direction and had failed to receive full support from Peking.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Cantor have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Ann Cantor, to Barry Goldstein. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goldstein of Lawrence, L.I.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 The Detroit police are investigating another case in which a white policeman is alleged to have needlessly killed a young Negro during the riot two weeks ago.

"TITUS ANDRONICUS" is the black sheep of the Shakespeare canon. It is a lurid shocker, so crudely pitched at the lowest element in the Elizabethan audience what might be called the bear-baiting crowd that some scholars refuse to believe that Shakespeare actually wrote it, and most wish that he hadn't.
DENVER, Aug. 9 (AP) The severest earthquake ever recorded in Denver shook a wide area around the city today.

Decked out in a red Breton sailing jacket, sweatshirt, chinos and tennis sneakers, Parks Commissioner August Heckscher deftly guided Whistler sailboat 872 across the waters of Flushing Meadow Lake yesterday to start the first series of free sailboating lessons to be held within the city parks.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Aug. 9 Harold R. Baker of 800 Willis Place, a reporter for The Daily Journal in Elizabeth since 1960, died there today at St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a brief illness. His ase was 39.
ALBANY, Aug. 9 A proposal to create a Department of Criminal Justice to coordinate the state's drive against crime fell short of passage tonight in the Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--A Republican House of Representatives campaign group, headed by Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, is planning to use a Marine training demonstration at Quantico, Va., this Friday for publicity purposes.
Citizens for Educational Freedom was accused yesterday of using "arm-twisting and political pressure" in Albany to obtain repeal of the strict ban on state financial aid to church-connected schools.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 9 (UPI) Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. stepped forward tonight at a rally being addressed by H. Rap Brown, militant Negro leader, and welcomed him to Florida, but added that he did not want to hear "any talk about guns."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--A number of Senators who have consistently advocated greater reliance on air and sea power in the Vietnam war today joined the demand for a sharp intensification of the air war against North Vietnam.
The American Electric Power Company announced yesterday a new tender offer for shares of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Secretary of Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today approval of water quality standards set by seven states and reported that "we are making real headway" in overcoming water pollution.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 9 (AP) Ken McMullen's homerun in the 20th inning tonight led the Washington Senators to a 9-7 victory over the Minnesota Twins in the longest major league game played at Metropolitan Stadium.

HONOLULU, Aug. 9 A liberally oriented unit of the American Bar Association warned today against "the excessive use of force" by the police in riot situations and delared that Negroes as a race should not be blamed for the lawlessness of a relatively few individuals.

A Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs does not rank high in the State Department bureaucracy, but J. Wayne Fredericks transformed that post into a key instrument of two-way education. He did much to educate leaders of the new Africa about America, but his greater contribution may have been the education of Americans about Africa's problems and prospects.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Charley Gogolak kicked three field goals and the Washington defense set up three touchdowns tonight as the Redskins upset the Chicago Bears, 37-14, in the National Football League exhibition opener for both teams.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Representative Thaddus J. Dulski of Buffalo, the chairman of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, confirmed today that he had accepted for his personal use about $11,000 from the proceeds of a testimonial dinner in Buffalo in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment to block Export-Import Bank financing of arms sales to underdeveloped countries:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Utah's Attorney General, Phil L. Hansen, accused Salt Lake City's two major newspapers today of controlling an exclusive communications empire. He said that state antitrust action had been under consideration for some time.

PEKING, Aug. 9 (Agence France-Presse)--Crowds of Chinese began demonstrating outside the Mongolian Embassy here today, apparently because of an incident earlier in the day in which a Mongolian Embassy car was destroyed by a crowd.
"It's a very interesting picture," a Brooklyn housewife told her son-in-law. "You should see it." She paused, then added with a giggle: "But don't take your wife. It's too dirty."

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it was increasing prices 3 to 5 per cent for calendered plastic film and sheeting. Early in the week the company raised prices for tires and tubes and, later, other industrial rubber products.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 The Swiss Government called on voters today to reject a proposed constitutional amendment that would reduce the number of foreigners in the country to about 400,000.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 9 The state's Hudson River Valley Commission approved plans today for nine construction projects along the river end opposed a project in Yonkers that it said would disfigure 1,000 feet of waterfront.
Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus were named yesterday to represent the United States for the fourth consecutive year in the World Cup and international trophy golf matches.

Whatever else the Organization for Latin-American Solidarity (OLAS) achieved in the conference that has just ended in Havana, it was not solidarity. The already fractured Communist movement has been given another gaping wound.
Cynicism prevailed in the decision of the House of Representatives to upset the Administration on the crime-control bill.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 9 (AP) A labor crisis was apparently averted today by a Government agreement to grant salary increases to 200,000 state workers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 9 (UPI) Retired Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark has been evacuated by air to the United States with a severe case of infectious hepatitis, the United States Embassy said today.
The attorney for the late Hyman Mintz, Republican Assemblyman from Sullivan County, sought vainly in Supreme Court yesterday to obtain dismissal of an indictment against his client.

While Carlos Ortiz is getting into shape to defend his lightweight title against Ismael Laguna next Wednesday evening at Shea Stadium, he is also rehearsing a bit of public persuasion in the hope of averting extraneous violence outside the ring.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) A group of professors asked the Board of Governors of State Colleges and Universities today to reconsider its rejection of Staughton Lynd's bid for a teaching post.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 9 Miss Nancy Wood Kelly and William Wallace McFarland of Cambridge, Mass., will be married on Sept. 2. Mr. and Mrs. Walter McCune Kelly have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitcomb Jones McFarland of San Mateo, Calif.
ELIZABETH, N.J. Restoring an old and historic house, said Mrs. John Kean, is like ferreting out the clues in a mystery story.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Gennaro (Jerry) Angiulo, identified in United States Senate testimony in 1963 as the head of organized crime in Boston pleaded not guilty today in Superior Court to two charges arising from a gangland slaying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 The House of Representatives accepted today the Johnson Administration's plan to reorganize the District of Columbia government to make it more representative of the city's disfranchised citizens, two-thirds of them Negroes.

ALBANY, Aug. 9 Governor Rockefeller today announced the appointment of a 24-member citizens committee to review the state's laws against discrimination and determine whether stronger legislation is needed.
MONTREAL, Aug. 9 (Canadian Press) Lester Sack of Clarksdale, Miss., upset India's Jaiki Mukerjea, 7-5, 3-6, 6-2, 1-6, 6-2, in the Canadian tennis championships today.
The nation's electric power production rose 9.9 per cent in the week ended Aug. 5, from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

PUTNAM VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 9 The Board of Education here last night rescinded a resolution adopted in May that barred the classroom use of phonograph records that satirized Brotherhood Week and Roman Catholic ritual. Also rescinded was a provision calling for the immediate dismissal of any teacher violating the rule.
MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 9 (Reuters) Anton Walbrook, stage and screen actor, died at Starnberg near here today after a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 While Congressional critics focus on complaints that poverty workers have fomented disorders, the Office of Economic Opportunity has accumulated a far greater number of unsolicited accolades for the "cooling" operations of poverty workers in riotous and threatening situations.
Unfailingly considerate for his partner, Patricia McBride, Edward Villella has a knack for short-changing himself.
Four persons were arrested early yesterday afternoon as members of an alleged abortion ring operating from an apartment on Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The Commerce Department set up emergency export procedures today to ease the pinch on producers of copper concentrates who are hampered by industry strikes in which they are not involved.

The German mark moved above its parity of 25 cents with the dollar and closed at 25.01 1/8, in foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The trend was observed on the London exchange, where the spurt began Tuesday afternoon and continued throughout yesterday.
A secondary offering of 230,000 shares of Tektronix, Inc., common stock was made yesterday at 46 7/8 a share and Lehman Brothers, the managing underwriter, reported the shares oversubscribed.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 9 Mississippi's Democratic primary election yesterday put at least 11 Negroes into local office, returns showed today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 Vince Matthews and Bob Beamon, two alumni of New York playgrounds, upset more celebrated teammates tonight on the opening program of the first-ever track and field meet between the Americas and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- Few military men on earth have as much destructive power within their grasp as has Adm. Ulysses Simpson Grant Sharp Jr., commander of all United States forces in the Pacific area.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9--A former Jordanian district judge and a prominent Arab businessman were arrested today as instigators of the general strike that crippled the former Jordanian part of Jerusalem Monday.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) Auto production in the United States this year was 11 per cent below last year's level and the lowest since the 1963 model year, Ward's Automotive Reports disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Oil production in the Middle East and North Africa is now greater than it was before the Suez Canal was closed down on June 5, according to figures released here today.

The Joint Chiefs of Staff have selected Frank A. Nemec, president of Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., as winner of the 18th annual National Transportation Award of the National Defense Transportation Association.

James Jarcho has been appointed to the newly created post of administrative assistant to Robert Olnick, president of Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., builders. Oliver S. Johnson has been named chief estimator and Daniel Pearce was made project manager.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) Wade N. Harris, chairman of the Midland-Ross Corporation, died last night in San Francisco of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
PEEL, Isle of Man, Aug. 9 "Britain has lost a quarter of the world's surface, so what's another 225 square miles?"
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 An action expected to diminish American interest in the British Open championship will establish a new tournament with a $200,000 purse on the 1968 United States pro golf circuit.

Three jewelers from Philadelphia were robbed of $22,200 in diamonds and other precious stones last night, as they had dinner in an Italian restaurant on Grand Street. The gems were stolen from their parked car, the police said.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday assailed the opposition of 18 New York Representatives to the state's plan to locate its offices in the World Trade Center.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug 9 (UPI) An aid program serving half a million refugees in South Vietnam's northern provinces was described today as "a highly visible failure."

NOW that a San Francisco court has ruled that Rick Barry is under obligation to the San Francisco Warriors of the National Basketball Association for one more year, even though he signed a contract with the Oakland Oaks of the new American Basketball Association, it is possible to look at the coming season with some sort of order.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 9-Political ill will has reduced the field for the North American rowing championships starting here tomorrow.

PEEKSHILL, N.Y., Aug. 9 John Schmitt, the No. 1 center of. the New York Jets, resumed workouts at the training camp at Peekskill Military Academy today following a 24hour virus attack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 A Congressional effort to make department stores tell customers the yearly rate of interest they pay on revolving charge accounts is doomed to failure, a House subcommittee was told today.

Claudio Arrau, the Chileanborn pianist, has embarked on a campaign to provide financial help for talented young Latin American musicians to enable them to study in the United States and Europe.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) Wes Parker's throwing error enabled Mike Shannon to score the winning run as the St. Louis Cardinals scored in the 11th inning and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, tonight.

DIANNE T. MOORE and her Mor-Shor Kennel are rel- atively new names in the dog-show world, but MorShor has suddenly rocketed into the group and best-inshow orbit and should be heard, loud and clear, from now on.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 9 The engagement of Miss Judith Ann Loveman to Dennis Edward Noonan has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David B. Loveman 2d. Mr. Noonan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Noonan of Watertown, Mass.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9--Assemblyman Jesse Unruh, a Democrat, took a large measure of credit today for the favorable image registered to date by the Republican administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 The Spingold Knockout Team contest, which concluded the American Contract Bridge League's summer national championships here, resulted in a well-deserved victory for Edgar Kaplan, Alvin Roth and William Root of New York, and Norman Kay of "Philadelphia.

The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday plans to lay off about 575 employes. The company's common shares subsequently fell 12 , to 251 , on the New York Stock Exchange. Later in the day, Xerox directors voted in Los Angeles to raise the quarterly dividend by 10 cents a share.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., turned in record sales in the three months and six months ended June 30, but earnings fell from a year earlier, according to the midyear report issued yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10--A United Nations council established to lead South-West Africa to independence from South Africa was installed today under the presidency of Jose Piffera, the permanent representative of Chile.
Plans for the construction of a $20-million, 23-story state office building in Harlem are going according to schedule, state officials said yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10(AP)-- Willie McCovey blasted a three run homer tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat the first place St. Louis Cardinals, 5-2.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10--Navy carrier pilots shot down two supersonic MIG21 fighters with air-to-air missiles in North Vietnam today, a United States military spokesman announced.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a series of five free concerts will be staged in poorer areas of the city. The series, "Sounds of Summer, '67," is being sponsored by Lever Brothers at a cost of $15,000.

"A Farewell Salute to the Queen Mary," a lavish, bon voyage party to be held Sept. 21, the eve of her final trans-Atlantic crossing, is already sold out. Seven hundred persons will attend the event, a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) --The Senate Housing Subcommittee approved today a provision in the proposed housing bill of 1967 calling for a $40million rat control program.

BAY CITY, Mich., Aug. 10 (AP)--Two drawings, by Pablo Picasso and the sculptor Henry Moore, were stolen from an exhibition at Delta College near, here, the State Police said today.

The Rev. Francis D. Burns, administrative head for the last three years of the Jesuit retreat at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., died Wednesday at the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital after having suffered a stroke. He was 63 years old.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 10-- A group of university scientists announced today that they hoped to open an oceanographic center here by next summer to serve universities and research firms in the metropolitan area.

HAVANA, Aug. 10 (UPI)-- Delegates to the Latin-American Solidarity Conference ended an 11-day meeting totonight with the adoption of a long manifesto that said "the duty of Latin-American peoples is to make revolution."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- Dr. James L. Goddard, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, told a Senate hearing today he was not satisfied with industry's research performance in supporting its new drug applications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The staff of the National Center for Air Pollution Control was ordered today to stop road tests of the antismog devices that must be on all 1968 model automobiles and to turn over the work to other Government personnel.
LONDON, Aug. 10--The Commonwealth Relations Office has confirmed that the Government is permitting some arms shipments to the Nigerian Government.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 10 (UPI)--The South Carolina Highway Patrol disclosed today it had hired its first Negro patrolman, a 23-year-old former security guard with the Marine Corps.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10-- The bodies of two young sisters who disappeared yesterday from the residential suburb of Altadena were found this morning 25 miles away in a weed-grown vacant lot in the Negro district of watts. The victims were white.
The Federal Reserve pressed its policy of monetary ease during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics released yesterday indicated.

HONG KONG, Friday, Aug. 11 (UPI)--Workers from Com munist China crossed into Hong Kong last night, disarmed policemen at a border post and forced a British official and an army officer at knife point to sign a paper agreeing to Chinese demands.

CAIRO, Aug. 10--President Tito of Yugoslavia, arriving in Cairo today in the hope of finding a peace formula for the Middle East, was greeted with cries of "We shall fight, we shall fight to victory!" There also were placards welcoming him as a "man of peace."
BOGALUSA, La., Aug. 10 (UPI)--About 100 chanting Negroes filed down a 16-mile stretch of highway today on the first leg of a 10-day, 94mile protest march to the state capital in Baton Rouge.
VENICE, Italy, Aug. 10--The Roman Catholic Patriarch of Venice issued a "cry of alarm" today over "provocatory and shameless" miniskirts but conceded that there was not much to be done about them.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 10--Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that Israel could not maintain her security if she gave up all of the territory she conquered in June.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10--Jose Piffera, Chile's representative at the United Nations, looks like a Bohemian, works like a beaver and dreams of a more just world for the smaller nations.
LONDON, Aug. 10--The Imperial Tobacco Company, manufacturer of players cigarettes, announced today plans to acquire the H.P. Sauce Company in a major diversification move.

LONDON, Aug. 10--Scotland Yard is preparing a report for the Attorney General, Sir Elwyn Jones, on whether to prosecute Duncan Sandys, a former Conservative Cabinet Minister, for incitement to racial hatred.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10--Mikhail Chulaki, the general manager and artistic director of the Bolshoi Opera, is a benignlooking man who, with his glasses, bald head and a certain plumpness, reminds one of Mr. Pickwick. By rights, he should have been looking harrassed. Instead, he was calm and detached as he ticked off points one by one.

GAY HEAD, Mass., Aug. 10 --Residents of this village on Martha's Vineyard are contending with the frustrations of trying to control erosion of the multicolored cliffs that bring thousands of visitors here each summer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--A special Presidential board began moving into a critical stage today in its efforts to mediate a settlement in the railroad labor dispute.

Otto J. Scheer, president of William Scheer, Inc., jewelry manufacturers at Rockefeller Center, and formerly an ardent sports fisherman, died Wednesday in his home, 130 East 56th Street, of a heart attack after a lingering illness. His age was 82.
Dr. Frank Stanton, President of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has replied to Senator Robert Hugh Scott's criticism of newspaper, radio and television coverage of the recent riots.
HONG KONG, Aug. 10 (Reuters)--Bloody clashes between 10,000 Red Guards and workers were reported today to have broken out in Canton, south China's major city.

A number of price changes-- some up, some down, but averaging out to an increase of $141--were announced yesterday by the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation for its 1968-model trucks.
The Federal Government has sidetracked $8.7-million in aid that had been earmarked for the Aldene railroad commuter plan in New Jersey.
The combination of Mozart, the pianist Peter Serkin and the Guarneri String Quartet drew a near-capacity audience to Philharmonic Hall last night in the continuation of the Mozart Festival.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 10--H. Rap Brown, the controversial Negro leader, headed for Atlanta early today after a face-to-face encounter with Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. that apparently left him annoyed and somewhat shaken.
PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 10 (UPI)--Australia's victory in the Admiral's Cup was assured today as a dead calm held up many of the racing yachts in the 630-mile Fastnet event off England's south coast.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- Retail sales rose 1 per cent in July, after adjustment for seasonal changes, to a total of $26.7-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
Political bickering at City Hall over the proposal for a city study of welfare and antipoverty programs died down yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Following is a table showing the percentage of National Guard personnel in the various states who are Negroes. The first three columns of figures are for the Army National Guard, the second three columns for the Air National Guard, both as of Dec. 31, 1966.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 10--Three United States soldiers were killed and 15 were wounded today when their truck was ambushed by North Koreans just south of the demilitarized zone, a United Nations Command spokesman announced.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 10-- Henri Levesque, a man with a long memory, decided today that Roquepine's fortunes in the $100,000 Roosevelt International Trot on Aug. 19 would rest with him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended trading in the common stock and other securities of the Roto American Corporation of Paramus, N.J., effective immediately. The suspension will run through Aug. 19.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 10-- A $30-million line of credit has been negotiated with the Chase Manhattan Bank for Puerto Rico's Highways Authority, the Government Development Bank For Puerto Rico said today.

Eight Republican Governors, complaining that Federal programs for racially tense urban areas of the country were in- adequate, met here yesterday to present their own "action program" against "the tragic epidemic of riots."

The city's Council Against Poverty voted unanimously last night to "use all our power and resources" to prevent the Board of Education from receiving Federal funds for special enrichment programs for poor children.

The Republican Governors have offered the nation a constructive and enlightened response to the recent rioting. Although they recognize that prompt and firm law enforcement is essential in putting down disorders, they also see clearly that police measures are not enough.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP)--Ken Boyer's home run off a relief pitcher, Mike Marshall, in the eighth inning powered the Chicago White Sox to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight. BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 10 (UPI)--Bob Allison hit two home runs and drove in three runs today to back Jim Perry's five-hit pitching and lead the Minnesota Twins to a 5-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
The members of the Department of Sanitation band will play on--but on their own time and without charge.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP)--The highest price ever paid for a yearling filly at public auction was tendered tonight when John E. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., gave $190,000 for a bay daughter of Bold Ruler from Blue Norther.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--President Johnson has been holding public and private sessions for the last few weeks with members of Congress and a cross-section of business and labor leaders concerning tax and fiscal policies, the White House said today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10-- An Indiana statewide rally of the Ku Klux Klan planned for Saturday was forbidden yesterday by Johnson County Superior Court Judge Jack Rog ers.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- A large committee of militant Negroes, angered because city officials had failed to "get the message" from Detroit's riots, promised today to take control of all rebuilding efforts.

SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10 --Bobby Fischer of New York, the United States chess champion, adjourned his third-round game in a superior position to his opponent, Yugoslav Grand Master Mato Damjanovic, in the 18-man Tournament of Solidarity here last night.

ATHENS, Aug. 10--Athenagoras I. Ecumenical Patriarch of Eastern Orthodoxy, is plan ning to visit Pope Paul VI in Rome in late October and Orthodox patriarchs in Moscow and three Eastern European countries next month.

WASHINGTON, AUG. 10-- The White House began today "an intensive national search for the best man" to head the new, more representative city government that comes into legal being here at midnight tonight.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (AP)-- Chuck Hinton slashed a twoout double into right field in the 13th inning tonight to drive in a run and give the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

AREA A--Bluefish is fair off shore along the New Jer sey coast with some sizable fish being taken 15 miles east by north of the Manasquan Inlet. Porgies are run ning off the Shrewsbury Rocks, while fluke have been appearing in the Seaside area. The fluke have been partial to smelts and spearing. Tuna fishing has picked up farther off the Manasquan area.

Plans for construction of the tallest buildings in Los Angeles --a pair of office towers in the downtown financial district-- have been made by the "Atlantic Richfield Company and the Bank of America, who would be joint developers.

OTTO PREMINGER sat down on a 10-footlong, blue sofa in front of a marble-topped coffee table. On the wall above him hung a Ben Nicholson painting. The film director leaned forward and gave the tabletop a nudge. It rolled back, exposing an illuminated panel of 26 buttons, switches and dials. He pressed a key and a low, whirring sound answered his touch.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 10--The Harvard University undefeated eight-oared crew and the Potomac Boat Club pair without coxswain qualified today in the opening heats of the North American rowing championships. The finals will be held Sunday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

SALT LAKE CITY (AP)-- Japan took two-more world Judo titles tonight as Eiji Maruki won the middleweight division and Hiroshi Minatoya defeated a fellow countryman to take the light-middleweight crown at the University of Utah.
MONTREAL, Aug. 10-- Bridge players left for their homes today or went sightseeing after the close of the American Contract Bridge League's summer national championships.
The liner United States will interrupt her regular trans-Atlantic schedule next year to make the longest single voyage of her 15 years at sea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The first public suggestion by an influential Egyptian political figure that Cairo needs diplomatic relations with the United States has caused interest here, but officials do not expect it to lead to an early resumption of ties.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10--The United States Davis Cup team's defeat by Ecuador may have been a calamity to those mortified by our successive failures to get to the challenge round, but it was not a calamity to Dwight F. (Pete) Davis Jr.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) --The House voted today to take a census every five years instead of every 10 years as in the past

The appointment of Arthur W. Stout Jr., executive vice president and works manager of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation since 1963, as executive general manager of the Houston Division of Todd Shipyards Corporation was announced yesterday.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 10-- About 1,000 shore residents and their guests are expected to attend the annual Carnation Ball of St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church on Saturday evening at the Governor's Summer Mansion here. In past years the event has realized an average of more than $25,000 for the church's charities.
LONDON, Aug. 10--The pound slid below 2.78 today, its lowest level since the November, 1964, sterling crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Senate ethics committee will check into the fees and cases that Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, has been sharing with a lawyer for James R. Hoffa, imprisoned president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Representatives of trucking companies and 16 locals of the Teamster Union in the New York and New Jersey metropolitan area began negotiations yesterday for a uniform collective bargaining agreement.

In the face of record production, wheat, corn and soybean prices have been drifting downward and yesterday all three set life-of-contract lows in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the award of three contracts, totaling more than $4.6-million, for improved passenger accommodations at Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- William C. Foster, the chief United States disarmament negotiator, announced today that the Soviet Union had advised him it might be ready to join the United States in presenting to the Geneva conference a ...
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP)--Gov. Ronald Reagan announced today that he has appointed his wife, Nancy, to the California Arts Commission.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11--United States fighterbombers cut the rail and high way bridge across the Red River at Hanoi today--an important link to China, the port of Haiphong and the Hanoi airport.
Insured losses resulting from the Detroit riots will reach about $85-million, insurance sources said yesterday. They made no attempt to evaluate the entire property losses.

The engagement of Miss Lois Ann Russell to Peter Evan Charles has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Russell of 301 East 48th Street. Mr. Charles is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lloyd Charles of 242 East 48th Street. The wedding is planned for Sept. 3d.

Net income of the British American Oil Co., Ltd. for the initial six months this year increased to $20,007,000, or 91 cents a share, from $19,239,000, or 88 cents a share, a year ago, it was reported yesterday.
LENORE, W.Va., Aug. 11 (UPI)--A teen-age boy fell 14 feet into an abandoned sandstone well today and was trapped when its sides began to cave in.

WANTAGH, L.I., Aug. 11-- About 325 lifeguards at Jones Beach, Robert Moses State Park on Fire Island, and Sunken Meadow State Park went on strike this morning, and beach policemen spent the day telling swimmers to stick to wading.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 11 --Mr. and Mrs. Benedict T. Harter of Madison and Sea Girt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Harter, to Lieut. Joseph James Kelly, of the Army. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kelly of Roswell, N.M., and Washington. A fall wedding is planned.

A strong tide has developed at the Constitutional Convention for guaranteeing free higher education to all qualified New Yorkers. The objective is appealing in a period when lifelong education is increasingly important in career development, but careful wording is needed to keep the guarantee from turning into a limitless subsidy to private as well as public colleges.
NEWARK, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- The taxi cab driver whose arrest touched off the city's racial riots last month filed a $700,000 damage suit today against the police.
Keith Funston is not alone in his concern about the growing pile of paper that is clogging the canyons of Wall Street. Francis X. Moran and Richard L. Harris also worry about it.
TRENTON, Aug. 11--Central New Jersey has been rejected again as a possible site for the New York metropolitan area's fourth major jetport, this time by the Federal Department of Transportation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 11-- The unveiling of Fran Tarkenton wearing a blue New York Giant uniform and throwing passes to New York Giant receivers behind New York Giant blockers takes place here tomorrow in Cornell's picturesque Schoellkopf Crescent.

YONKERS, Aug. 11--Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Dvorovy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane A. Dvorovy, to James E. Fogarty of New York. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Fogarty of Auburn.

Kenneth B. Sprague, financial vice president of the American and Foreign Power Company, died Thursday of a heart attack in Honolulu, where he was attending a convention of the American Bar Association. He was 59 years old and lived at 104 Golf Edge, Westfield, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 --The police chief of the nation's capital, John Layton, testified today at antiriot bill hearings that "at the moment I have no indication of any violent planned outbreak in the city."

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- A Superior Court judge upheld today state laws prohibiting Sunday liquor sales in Georgia but said that Gov. Lester G. Maddox must have been "drunk on power" to order raids last weekend on defiant nightclubs.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that Vietcong guerrillas had shot down an American B-52 bomber in South Vietnam on July 21.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)--National Guard commanders said today they wanted more Negro recruits and denied that the present low percentage was the result of racial discrimination.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 11--The Congo is facing formidable difficulties, most of which must be dealt with in the next few months. Many foreign diplomats here are convinced that the existence of Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu's regime is at stake.

DANVILLE, Pa., Aug 11 (AP) --Dr. Harold Leighton Foss, former chief of staff of the Geisinger Medical Center here and a prominent figure in American surgery, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at the institution he guided from a small, semi-rural hospital into a leading medical center. He was 84 years old.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that mediation efforts "will go forward" in a new attempt to avert a threatened mass re signation by city teachers on Sept. 1.
The H.C. Bohack Company name, which has hung above food stores in the metropolitan area for the last 64 years, may fade gradually from the New York scene.

A three-day natural fireworks display in the sky-- a meteor shower in which more "shooting stars" than usual are visible--began early this morning. The best hours for viewing the show with the naked eye are between 1 and 3 A.M., toward the northeast, Dr. Franklin Branley, an astronomer at the Hayden Planetarium, said yesterday.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11--A fashion show and happening at the Benson gallery here Aug. 19 from 5 P.M. to midnight will benefit the Hampton Day School.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11--The Congo has appealed to Security Council members for aid in the face of alleged plans for subversion. It did not ask for a Council meeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. (UPI)--President Johnson announced today the appointment of a new 12-member consumer advisory council to be headed by Bronson C. LaFollette, Attorney General of Wisconsin.
Grove Press, which began publishing Off Broadway programs in January when the owners of Showcard refused to print the "MacBird!" playbill because of its theme, is buying Showcard.
Two actions of possible effect on the North Cascade Mountains in the state of Washington are going forward this summer. They concern the rugged face of part of the United States.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 11--The United States qualified crews for all of Sunday's seven finals of the North American rowing championships today as its four with coxswain, four without coxswain, pair with coxswain, and singles finished in first or second place in the repechages.

Sixteen families were made homeless yesterday when a three-alarm fire damaged three buildings on Walworth Street near DeKalb Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The American Red Cross provided food and shelter for 37 persons in 10 of the families, while the remainder stayed with relatives and friends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) --The National Transportation Safety Board said today that manufacturing defects had been found in the propeller of the propjet airliner that crashed near Marseilles, Ohio, last March 5, killing all 38 occupants.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 11--Rex Baxter continued his sub-par pace today as he retained the lead in the American Golf Classic by two strokes. Despite two double bogeys in a round of 68, the 31-year-old Texan set a thirty-six hole record for the tourney with an aggregate of 134 over the Firestone Country Club Course. The previous mark was 135.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11--British reinforcements were moved to key points on Hong Kong's border with Communist China today after a Government official and a British Army officer were held captive for six hours by workers from the Chinese side.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has commended broadcasters for using "fairness and restraint" in the coverage of recent racial disturbances here.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 11-- Tough talk came from chairman Jim C. Langdon of the Texas Railroad Commission today as oil purchasers again raised their demand for Texas Oil to meet the shortages created by the Middle East crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- House and Senate foreign policy committees issued widely differing reports today on the scope and direction of the foreign aid program. A collision between the two branches seemed assured.
TOKYO, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Large-scale armed clashes between followers and opponents of Chairman Mao were reported going on today in at least nine major cities of Communist China.
American Standard, Inc., a manufacturer of heating equipment, has announced the election of John Mosler as a director.

Phoebe Hyde, an associate editor of House Beautiful magazine, collapsed and died Wednesday at her office at 572 Madison Avenue. She had been suffering from cancer. She was 49 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.

LONDON, Saturday Aug. 12 --Scotland Yard has foiled an attempt to introduce forged paintings into Britain as part of one of the most extensive art swindles, according to a report by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 --Thomas C. Mayers, Mayor of Stamford, and Mrs. Mayers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Marie Mayers, to James Albert McDonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonald of Roslindale, Mass.
The London Stock Exchange closed out a lackluster week with a slightly firmer undertone yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 11--Despite, the closing of the Suez Canal and the Arab states' embargo on deliveries to Britain and the United States, Western Europe is getting very nearly all the oil it needs.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 11 (AP)--Uruguay announced today a 12 per cent devaluation of the peso, the third devaluation in six months.
Governor Rockefeller will spend today and Sunday at the summer home of Gov. George Romney of Michigan on Mackinac Island, Mr. Rockefeller's office said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The American Bar Association, whose governing body criticized the Administration's patent reform bill this week, plans to deliver its own version to Congress, in a few days, it announced here today.
LONDON, Aug. 11--Michael de Freitas, the 33-year-old leader of the British Black Muslim movement, was arrested today at his London home on charges of stirring up racial hatred.
PARIS, Aug. 11 (Reuters)-- French opposition leaders and labor unions replied today to President de Gaulle's policy speech last night in which he criticized his opponents as "apostles of decline."

NASHVILLE, Aug. 11 (AP)-- A six-month inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation shows that "the Government would not be justified in prosecuting" a metropolitan policeman who shot and killed a Vanderbilt University student from North Carolina, United States Attorney Gilbert Merritt said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11--The South Vietnamese chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, outlined sweeping plans today to decentralize the civil administration and reorganize the army to bolster the lagging pacification program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)-- The board of governors of the Illinois state colleges and universities rejected today a request for a special meeting to review a decision denying Staughton Lynd a faculty post at Chicago State College.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- The General Services Administration sold 2,191,000 ounces of silver today at prices ranging from $1.74 to $1.801 an ounce. This price range--at the second of regular weekly auctions-- was off slightly from successful bids at the first sale a week ago, when prices ranged from $1.775 to $1.81.

The City Investing Company is holding negotiations with the General Development Corporation on making a tender offer for 1,785,000 to 2,467,000 shares of General Development common stock, George T. Scharffenberger, the president of City Investing, said yesterday.

Atlantic Coast Football League affiliates of the New York Giants and the New York Jets will clash tonight in an exhibition football game at Mount Vernon Memorial Field. The kickoff will be at 8:15 P.M.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11-- An assistant to New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison told a five-man trial jury today that Dean A. Andrews Jr. committed perjury when he testified before a grand jury last March.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Aug. 11-- Xander J. Buter, general sales manager in the New York area for Wyeth Laboratories, Inc., of Philadelphia, was pronounced dead at Grasslands Hospital here today after suffering a heart seizure. He was 49 years old and lived at 20 Ox Ridge Road in Elmsford.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--A special Presidential board began to shape plans for a compulsory settlement in the railroad dispute today after the carriers and six shopcraft ...
KENT, Conn., Aug. 11-- Harold W. Jennys, a retired New York investment broker, died at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
ANGUILLA, Aug. 11 (UPI) --The head of this tiny Caribbean island's governing council warned today that any attempt to land a police force here would be considered a "direct challenge to war."

Representative William F. Ryan called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to "explain why the recruitment policies of the New York National Guard have failed to enlist more Negroes and to eliminate segregation."
At least 100 electronic concerns are exploring the commercial use of a miniaturized television aerial developed by the United States Air Force after four years of research.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., Aug. 11 (UPI)--Army Capt. Howard B. Levy, who was sentenced to three years at hard labor for advocating disloyalty among Vietnam-bound troops, lost the first automatic appeal of his case today.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 (AP)--United States marines could use additional men and helicopters to meet mounting pressure from North Vietnamese troops along the demilitarized zone, Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., Commandant of the Marine Corps, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- United States officials indicated today that the Administration would probably take another look at the possibility of a pause in the bombing of North Vietnam after the South Vietnamese elections, but they suggested that a pause was unlikely.

SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 --The 24-year-old United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of New York, scored twice in the last two rounds in the Tournament of Solidarity here. In the fourth round last night, the American won from the Hungarian international master, Intmas Dely, and before that he scored his adjourned thirdround game against Yugoslav grand master, Mato Damjanovic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- Total manufacturing and trade inventories declined in June the first monthly decline in six years, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)--Most bankrupts are small wage earners with several dependents, loaded down with the results of credit purchases and often subject to garnishment of their wages, a panel of bankruptcy referees told Congressmen today.

HONOLULU, Aug. 11 (AP)-- The 24-man crew of the Japanese fishing vessel Shoichi Maru abandoned ship in lifeboats 200 miles northwest of Wake Island after a fire swept through her engine room last night.

Police Commissioner Howard Leary turned down yesterday a request from the New York State Athletic Commission to furnish protection for fans at next Wednesday night's boxing card at Shea Stadium, headlined by a lightweight title ...
A bicycle path along the Hudson River would "make a lot of kids happy," Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton believes.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11--More than 70 union leaders, complete with rah-rah buttons and brochures, ended a three-day meeting in this affluent, picture-book community today in general agreement that unions are having a problem holding the allegiance of the young.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) --The makers of Geritol must tone down their advertising but may continue to sell their product as a patent medicine, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- The Federal Maritime Commission received two protests today against the granting of interim approval to an agreement that has been requested by the Interamerican Freight Conference, a new group with 10 members.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 11 (Reuters)--Ten rare Asian lions have died--believed to have been poisoned--in the Gir forests of western India, their only remaining natural habitat, it was reported here today.
ANAHEIM, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Jim McGlothlin pitched a threehitter tonight and Jimmie Hall scored on a fourth-inning wild pitch to give the California Angels a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
East Harlem residents celebrated victory yesterday in a 17-month fight for the destruction of a run-down tenement bordering a schoolyard.
CORINTH, Miss., Aug. 11 (UPI)--A high-speed head-on collision tonight killed nine persons, including five members of a family going to a lake near here on a vacation weekend.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 11 (UPI)--Tony Oliva singled in Zoilo Versalles with two out in the seventh inning tonight as the Minnesota Twins topped the league-leading Chicago White Sox, 3-2, behind the sixhit pitching of Dean Chance.
Help stamp out phrases like the "contextual dynamics of the Bronx," the New York State Council on the Arts urged yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 11--The Ford Motor Company today reported 56,289 new-car sales in the initial third of August, up 9 per cent from 51,603 sales a year before.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Aug. 11--William Stuart BaringGould, an author and authority on Sherlock Holmes, died of a stroke last night at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 54 years old and lived on East Woods Road.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) --Jim Lefebvre sparked three Dodger sorges, reaching base four times on three hits and an error, as Los Angeles shut out Cincinnati tonight, 5-0, and snapped the Reds' three-game winning streak.

CAIRO, Aug. 11--Mohammed Hassanein Heyal, the editor of the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram, said today that only a miracle could prevent a resumption of fighting between the Arabs and Israel. He said Egypt's first task was to rebuild her armed forces and prepare for a return to the battlefield.
WASHINGTON, Aug.11--The Food and Drug Administration has put a major computer system in operation to give all its experts better access to the agency's huge pool of technical data.
NEWARK, Aug. 11--Jimmy Preston is going back to camp. He says the first thing he will do when he gets there is to say hello to his friends and then he will probably try to get on the basketball team.
BONN, Aug. 11--Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger will travel to Washington Sunday determined to meet President Johnson as an equal and ready to defend West Germany's interests.

Ladislav Mnacko, a leading Czech writer and journalist, has denounced "anti-Semitism" in his country and has gone to Israel in defiance of a travel ban to protest Czechoslovakia's support of the Arabs in the Middle East crisis.

Carl Resnikoff, an assistant vice president of the Ruberoid Company, a division of the General Aniline Film Corporation, which he joined in 1959, died yesterday in the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Institute. He was 60 years old and lived at 249 East 48th Street.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11--It was all over today ex cept the shouting, and the shouting was loud. Officials, coaches and athletes agreed that the first dual track meet between the Americas and Europe, which ended here last night, was the right meet in the wrong place at the wrong time.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 11-- The Brazilian Government denied loading facilities to freighters of six European shipping lines today in the first round of what threatens to be an important diplomatic and commercial confrontation.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 96.5 on Thursday from 96.4 on Wednesday.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 11 (Reuters)--The foreign ministers of the Regional Cooperation for Development Organization announced today steps to increase trade between the three member states--Iran, Pakistan and Turkey.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- The St. Louis Cardinals were handed a staggering blow today when Charlie Johnson, rated among the top quarterbacks in pro football, was ordered to report for military service.

A plan for Flushing Meadows Park by a prize-winning international design team is being delayed because the City Controller's office is refusing payment for the first stage of the work, pending required investigation of the architects' contracts and status.

The Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall is paying more attention to the composer's vocal music than did last summer's. That this can be refreshing was realized by last night's program, made up of excerpts from a dozen Mozart operas.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 11--Ruth Currier and Company offered two violently contrasting works tonight at Connecticut College's Palmer Auditorium: the joyful Brandenburg Concerto No. 4 and the premiere of Miss Currier's grim fable "Fantasies and Facades."

MONTREAL, Aug 10--The Bolshoi Opera opened last night with a performance of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov." It was one of the more eagerly anticipated events of Expo 67, for this famous opera company has never been seen in the Western hemisphere. In fact it has left its home base in Moscow only once before-- in 1964, when it went to La Scala with "Boris" and Rimsky-Korsakov's "Sadko."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11--Australians were in sole possession of the field in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today and for the first time within memory four players from Down Under will meet in the semi-finals, which will be held at the Meadow Club tomorrow.
ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (AP)-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that a nationwide campaign for a referendum on the war in Vietnam was now under way in a dozen areas.

HOUSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- Police Chief Herman Short said tonight that a Houston poverty project funded totally by the Office of Economic Opportunity had ordered seven telescopic sights for high-powered rifles and that the order had been approved in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- An engineer with 30 years of experience in steel is offering American industry and the developing countries an economical and relatively small rolling mill.

THE two basic plans in dummy-play, as any ele mentary textbook reveals, are the dummy-ruff and the establishment of a long suit. Both these possibilities existed on the diagramed deal, reported by Jim Garcia, a topranking American Bridge Association expert, but both plans were wrong. Instead, the declarer had to resort to a play that at first sight seems pointless.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 (AP)-- The European Economic Community foresaw today a pro gressive quickening of the Common Market's economic growth this year with internal demand providing the main impulse. The movement is likely to remain very slow in the beginning, however, the market's second quarterly survey of 1967 noted.
The city has devised a plan to put private real estate agencies to work helping to find new sites for businesses uprooted for renewal and public improvements.
A $55,000 study to improve the quality of environmental design and the use of open space in the city's housing and renewal program was announced yesterday at City Hall.

FLEMINGTON, N.J.--Turntable Junction, a 15-store shopping complex here, has been open for only a year, but already it looks old. It was planned that way--to blend in with the historic borough of Flemington, the county seat of Hunterdon and a stagecoach stop in the mid18th century.
Three lumber organizations reported an 8.3 per cent rise in production for the week ended Aug. 5, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- The Senate imposed a ban today on a planned $50-million loan by the Export-Import Bank for the purchase of American machine tools for an auto plant to be built in the Soviet Union by the Fiat Company of Italy.

The nationwide foreclosure rate on all types of mortgage loans held by federally insured savings and loan associations fell substantially during the second quarter of 1967, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported.

THE lives of great creative figures do not always make for exalting reading. Only too often the life and the work run parallel, the work a creative mystery, the life scarcely reflecting the greatness and sublimity of the artistic product.
NASHVILLE, Aug. 11-- Nashville's "liberation school," a part of the Federal antipoverty program, was suspended today pending a vote by the Metropolitan Action Commission on whether to discontinue it.
Dr. Marshall W. Nirenberg, the scientist who was pri marily responsible for cracking the genetic code, predicted yesterday that science might be able to manipulate human hereditary within 25 years.
Several long-term Government coupon securities drifted to record lows in yesterday's bond market session and another issue finished at its low for 1967.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11--Jared Brinsmade, a tall, angular 20-year-old who could pass for a cowpuncher, rode his two horses into the lead for both the first and second year green working hunter divisions today at the Essex County Horse Show.

The low prices for wheat, corn and soybeans on Thursday apparently induced some buying yesterday, both by longs taking new positions and by shorts covering their positions. As a result prices were nudged ahead and only one new life-of-contract was set.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he had "grave doubts" about a recommendation by the International Association of Chiefs of Police that the post of chief inspector be eliminated.

CELVELAND, Aug. 11--Extrabase hits and extra effort, once their trademark, provided the New York Yankees with a rare sweep of a double-header tonight as Al Downing and MelStottlemyre ambushed the Cleveland Indians.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11--The Tadzhik tightrope walkers in native costume finished their act to the accompaniment of a mournful Central Asian reed pipe and tomtoms.
BONN, Aug. 11--The magazine Stern is defying a court injunction by publishing in its Aug. 20 issue the second part of a series about Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs and the Stalin family.

MIAMI, Aug. 11--Premier Fidel Castro charged last night that a number of Communist leaders in Latin America and Cuba had joined forces to try to depose him and moderate the policies of the Cuban revolution.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 11-- William R. Haughton, the harness horseman whose middle initial stands for Robert, but which could, be changed to E. --for energetic--will have the opportunity tomorrow afternoon and night to accomplish an unusual harness racing feat.

SCARBOROUGH ON HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 11--Mrs. E.C.K. Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan, Conn., and Hugh Skelley Jr. of Salem C.C. scored 34, 39--73 in alternate-stroke play at Sleepy Hollow C.C. today and won the annual mixed foursomes championship of the Women's TriCounty Golf Association by one stroke.
A Jewish rabbi and historian cautioned his fellow rabbis this week against "unnecessary alarm" over what seemed to be a sharp rise in marriages between Jews and non-Jews.

BEFORE the Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in shares of North American Research and Development Corporation, Gould's Position published a report that drew more than passing interest.

Seth Marshall Agnew, president of the Children's Book Council and manager of the books-for-young-readers division of Doubleday Co., died after a heart attack yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived at 145 East 63d Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Mark Spitz of Santa Clara, Calif., and Greg Charlton of Southern California, bettered listed world records today, and Don Schollander, the 1964 Olympic star, was badly beaten in the opening session of the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 11 (UPI)--Ruby Kolod, a leading gambler here who was part of group that financed the construction of the Desert Inn Hotel, died of a heart attack at his home today. He was 57 years old.
Peter Adolph of Bronxville, N.Y., and Davis Henley of Houston, Tex., won titles yesterday in the metropolitan boys' tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) --The Pittsburgh Phantoms scored two goals for the Atlanta Chiefs, but scored three for themselves to gain a 3-2 National Soccer League victory before 1,461 tonight.
Black Nationalists angrily interrupted Mayor Lindsay last night as he spoke at an opening ceremony for Harlem's first sidewalk cafe.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 11--A three-hour black power rally here tonight ended with a small group of Negro youths tossing stones and bottles, and adults agreeing to boycott some white-owned stores.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Aug. 11--The nearly completed Macy's store, where civil rights activists demonstrated last February for more construction jobs for Negroes, is reported to be having trouble recruiting a staff.

TOKYO, Aug. 11--The delicate relations between Japan and South Korea, long marred by lingering elements of historical animosity, were brought a long step closer today with the conclusion of the first ministerial conference on economic matters between the two countries.

Mrs. Juliana Campioni Lombardi, associate director of the North Shore Conservatory of Music in Great Neck, L.I., and a former actress, died yesterday of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital. Her age was 34 and her home was at 90 Schenck Avenue in Great Neck. She was the wife of Carlo Lombardi, a concert pianist and professor of music at Adelphi University.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press)--Holders of shares and secured notes of the Alliance Credit Corporation, at two separate special meetings, have rejected the company's proposed reorganization plan that would have enabled Alliance to meet its debt requirements and protect noteholders against further deterioration of the company's assets.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has asked the Government to cancel two of its three subsidized cargo ship services in and out of the Great Lakes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11--Jordan called today for "more serious steps" by the United Nations against "Israeli acts of lawlessness" in Jerusalem, the Gaza Strip and occupied areas of western Jordan.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J. Aug. 11 (UP)--Teen agers at the Jersey shore have at their disposal, through the mails, a little known drug that produces wilder but shorter trips than LSD, a public health officer said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)--Two ambassadors and three other Presidential nominees were approved today by the Senate.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 11--Kerry Melville of Australia and Tory Fretz of Los Angeles reached the final of the annual invitation women's grass court tennis tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.
PARIS--Let your Vuitton bake in the sun every day for six months. The whitish leather straps will turn dark brown.
Wes Westrum deployed Army reservists like a general last night as the New York Mets prevailed over the clock, the National Guard drill schedule and the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

CENTERPORT, L.I., Aug. 11 --Gary Knapp of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and Laurie Jackson of the Cedar Point Yacht Club won the major prizes today in the fourth annual Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound novice Blue Jay Class invitation regatta.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- Leaders of the National Student Association have reached an agreement with the Central Intelligence Agency to sever their last remaining tie with the agency.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 11-- President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malawi, told yesterday of what he called an attempt by the Peking regime to "induce him to recognize Communist China and join the progressive force."

SAIGON, Aug. 11--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, the chief of state and the military's presidential candidate, said today that he would try to arrange a one-week pause in the bombing of North Vietnam if he won the election on Sept. 3.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, not ordinarily likened to the United States Cavalry, has come dash ing to the rescue of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad just in time's nick. The commission has ordered the line's automatic leasing by the Pennsylvania and New York Central just as soon as they merge.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)--Bill White's third straight hit, a sixth-inning single, scored Johnny Briggs with the decisive run today as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 11 (UPI)--The correction of an apparent error in the tabulation of votes put Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. back in the race for Lieutenant Governor today.

The first day of school is less than a month away, but it is still far from sure that the teachers will be there. More than 30,000 of them have signed resig nation forms and turned them over to the United Federation of Teachers as a club to be held over the city in the stalled negotiations for a new union agreement.
GLASS collectors, dealers and museum curators tried to unravel the mysteries of 19th-century American glass at a two-day forum conducted by the Sandwich Historical Society in Cape Cod.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)--A sharp fight was shaping up today over a Government proposal that would open up a multimillion-dollar market in convenience accessories for telephones.
DETROIT, Aug. 11--The Chrysler Corporation said today reported that it was recalling 7,427 van vehicles, most of them trucks, for inspection and correction of a possible safety defect.
The trading pace backed down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and so did prices.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Q. Hillman of Greenwich and London of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Woodfin Hillman, to Geoffrey Leland Clarkson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Clarkson of Riverside. An autumn wedding is planned.

The United Parents Association and the United Federation of Teachers announced yesterday that they would campaign against any new state constitution that did not retain the present strict ban on state financial aid to church-connected schools.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 11-- Both federal and rebel troops in the five-week-old Nigerian civil conflict have been ordered to fight a broadened war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--A dozen Senators from both parties charged today that the South Vietnamese presidential election campaign was being turned into a "fraud," "farce" and "charade" by the ruling military junta.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (UPI)-- Orlando Cepeda, returning to the line-up after being suspended for two days, hit a tworun homer in the sixth inning off Gaylord Perry tonight to give the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
