Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that it will be at least early 1969 --three years past the target date--before the city's new electronic traffic-control system can get into operation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) --The Defense Department made public today the names of 29 servicemen killed in action in Vietnam. Among them were Specialist 5 Larry B. Gordian and Pfc. Edward D. Randazzo, both Army men from Brooklyn.

WILTON, Conn., Aug. 14Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Brooks have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Kay Brooks, to John Sibley Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Perkins of Bangor, Me.
MONTREAL, Aug. 14--"Don't Look Back," a full-length documentary film about Bob Dylan the folk singer, drew a packed house for its premiere at the Montreal International Film Festival tonight.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 14-- Visitors to the Wailing Wall have been generally solemn and subdued since Israel seized the Old City of Jerusalem.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) A saboteur cut his way through barbed wire and set off an explosion in a secret North Atlantic Treaty Organization radar base near London yesterday.

Sigmund Gottlober, publisher of the program of the Lewisohn Stadium Concerts for 40 years, and advertising representative for the souvenir programs of many touring orchestra and opera and theater troupes, died yesterday in his home, 162 West 54th Street. He was 77 years old.
LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., Aug. 14--Mrs. Charles M. Gelberg has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Gelberg, to Lewis A. Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Kaplan of West Brighton, S.I.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 14 --Secretary of Agriculture Or ville L. Freeman made a strong plea here today for collective bargaining machinery for farm ers to give them "muscle in the marketplace."

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 14 (AP)--Martin Mulligan, an Australian residing in Italy, captured the men's singles title today in the Bavarian tennis championships by defeating Wilhelm Bungert of West Germany, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4.
Neophyte Nureyevs and fledgling Fonteyns kicked and stretched yesterday in a graceful competition for $10,000 worth of scholarships to the National Academy of Ballet.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 14-- H. Rap Brown, the head of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was indicted by a Dorchester County grand jury today on charges of arson, inciting to riot and disturbing the peace.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 14--Officers of the National Student Association called today for "unilateral withdrawal" of the group from the "cold war of international student politics."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 15--Tran Van Huong, the leading civilian presidential candidate, threatened today to withdraw from the race unless the Government stopped applying what he called "intimidating" pressures.

PEKING, Aug. 14 (Agence France Presse)--Tens of thousands of Chinese demonstrated outside the Soviet Embassy today, shouting "down with Soviet revisionism!" A guard of 200 Chinese troops stood between demonstrators and the compound.

Miss Amelia H. Grant, director of the bureau of nursing of the City Health Department from its organization in 1928 until her retirement in 1943, died last Tuesday in the Lamp Nursing Home in Amsterdam, N.Y. She was 79 years old and lived at Little Silver, N.J.

LONDON, Aug. 14--The subcommittee of a United Nations agency, in a step toward modifying the traditional freedom of captains to navigate as they like, has recommended the establishment of voluntary sea lanes.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Aug. 14 --Mrs. J. Jay Hodupp has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Claire Cranston Hodupp, to William Clarkson Irving of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Irving of Darien and Kent, Conn.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 14--The engagement of Miss Francine Elizabeth Harris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jonathan L. Harris, to Paul Zweig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zweig of Brooklyn, New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, Aug. 15 (UPI)--Communist China lodged a new protest with Britain today and issued another list of demands with regard to Hong Kong.
HOPES of doubling one's money may be responsi ble for more speculation than any other benchmark of greed. But there can be no doubt that many a trader is so motivated.
Eastman Chemical Products, Inc., a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company, announced yesterday price rises of cent to 2 cents a pound wide range of chemicals.

The Rev. Daniel Berrigan, the controversial Jesuit poet, essayist and theologian who has been a relentless critic of American policy in Vietnam, has been named associate director of Cornell University's oldest and largest voluntary student organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14-- Vicky Rogers of Rye, N.Y., reached the third round of the 50th annual United States girls lawn tennis championship today by winning two matches at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 15--American pilots struck yesterday for the second day in a row within 10 miles of the North Vietnamese border with China, a military spokesman announced.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (UPI)--Roger Fisher, a Harvard law professor, stated Anguilla's case for independence at a meeting of the United Nations subconimittee on colonialism today.
Prices moved down and the trading pace slowed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- The House-Senate conference committee on Congressional redistricting has been deadlocked for weeks and it is now considered likely that the pending redistricting bill is dead for this year.
The Negro residents of a predominantly middle-class neighborhdod in Queens rallied last night to protest what they called a ballooning crime rate and to demand more policemen.
CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 14 --A proposal to extend an official welcome to Negroes has aroused some strong resentment in this affluent suburban town.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- Administration sources said today that President Johnson was expected to warn Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger that cuts in the West German armed forces without agreement by the Allies would lead to louder calls for a reduction of the American military commitment in Europe.

Sandy Koufax, the star lefthanded pitcher who hurled a no-hitter against the Mets and had a 17-2 career wonlost mark against them before retiring because of an arthritic left elbow, will behonored by the Mets on Monday night, Sept. 18.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 14A referendum on whether Suffolk County should build and operate a nighttime race track for thoroughbred horses will be submitted to county residents this fall.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Nick Eddy and Mel Farr, Detroit's all-America speedsters making their pro debuts, slipped and picked their way through the Buffalo defense tonight, giving the Lions a 19-- 17 victory over the Bills in an interleague exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)--President Johnson announced today that he intended to help discharged veterans find jobs through an individually tailored program of perssonal contacts by representatives of the Public Employment Service.

Sentiment, rage, remembrance and laughter (some of it bitter) were offered in a satisfying mixture last night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park in a program entitled "Poetry and Folk Music of American Negroes." It was part of the special Monday night series being offered by the New York Shakespeare Festival.
A trunkload of costumes belonging to the Martha Graham dance troupe, was stolen yesterday morning from an automobile parked at 96th Street and Broadway.

The opening program of the "C.B.S. Playhouse" will be uninterrupted by commercials. The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that the 90-minute program on Oct. 17 would open with a commercial lasting five or six minutes. The network will present Loring Mandel's drama, "Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night."
ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 14 --Miss Patricia Ann Arvidson and Nicholas Gouverneur Phelps plan to marry here Sept. 9 in the First Congregational Church.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 14 (UPI)--Nearly 800 Mississippi Negroes, protesting that they were going hungry, staged a poor people's march" on the state capitol today. State troopers stopped them at the doors to the statehouse.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 14-- A trustee of the Farmingdale public Library who is awaiting trial on a petit larceny charge involving his confiscation of a literary magazine from the library was charged today with third-degree assault by a woman librarian. The trustee, Carl E. Gorton, had asserted that the magazine, The Paris Review, contained a pornographic article.

The Flamingo Hotel, one of the oldest hotels on "The Strip" Laa Vegas, is being sold by Morris Lansburgh and Sam Sohen for $12.5-million to Kirk Kerkorian, who already owns one of the newest hotels, Caeier's Palace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- For the first time in its 35year history, the Washington National Symphony will tour Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 --Corporate profits rose slight ly in the second quarter from the first quareter but remained will below the second quarter of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Argentina's military Government is off to a bad start in reconstructing the political life of the country. No valid case can be made for giving priority at this time to a "Defense Against Communism" law which would provide an official blacklist and plenty of opportunities for witch-hunts.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 14 (Reuters)--The governing Congress party accused the Indian princes today of trying to revive feudalism.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 14 (Reuters)--Arab officials will meet here tomorrow to consider an Iraqi plan for a tighter oil boycott against nations accused of helping Israel during the Middle East war in June. Britain and the United States are the main targets.

ARETTE, France, Aug. 14 (Reuters)--Old people and children streamed out of this village near the Spanish border today after a series of earth tremors struck the surrounding French Pyrenees last night and this morning.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14--Owen Davidson of Australia won the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 14 (UPI) --Mayor Floyd McCree, a Negro, announced his resignation tonight after a heated debate with city commissioners over an open housing ordinance he had sought. Mr. McCree, who had been Mayor since last November, told commissioners they would have his written resignation in time for next Monday's meeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- Joan Baez, the folk singer and pacifist, gave a free--and controversial--concert tonight for 30,000 people who jammed an outdoor theater area beside the Washington Monument.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 14--The police fired tear-gas shells to disperse about 5,000 Hindu demonstrators in Srinagar to day.

Dr. Frederick Lawson Hovde, the president of Purdue University and a former star quarterback at the University of Minnesota, was named yesterday as the Gold Medal winner for 1967 by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14-- The Philadelphia Bulletin's editions tomorrow will carry 225 free "jobs wanted" advertisements from unemployed persons in an effort to cut unemployment.
Investors took a wait-andsee position on the London stock exchange yesterday in anticipation of Britain's trade figures, due today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- Scientists have discovered a potent way of making a living body protect itself against many disease-causing viruses.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press)--Boats from the United States finished one, two today in the opening-day race bf the international Lightning Class world champoinship regatta. Argentina led the South American competitors when it placed two crews among the first 12 finishers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- President Johnson announced today that he had set up a 16member high-level committee to make the most comprehensive review of recent years into the nation's communications policy, foreign and domestic.

Chronicling the 26 Mozart programs now being presented in Philharmonic Hall is a bit like describing Elysium. It is hard to get away from the superlatives that just about every piece of Mozart inspires. If the performances sometimes fall short of ideal, the average quality is very high.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 14 (AP) --Jane Darwell, who during her 61 years as an actress played opposite the six most celebrated children of their generation-- Shirley Temple and the Dionne quintuplets--died yesterday at the Motion Picture Country Home. She was 87 years old and had suffered a stroke last Memorial Day and a heart attack last week.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Ted Savage's fielding error on Roger Maris's single allowed two St. Louis runs to score with one out in the ninth inning, enabling the Cardinals to beat the Chicago Cubs, 6-5, tonight.

Two fallen baseball empires collided at Yankee Stadium last night in the struggle for eighth place in the American League, and the New York Yankees won the opening round by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4.

The panel of three law professors named by Mayor Lindsay to help avert a teachers' strike provides assurance to all New Yorkers--parents pupils, teachers, administrators and just plain taxpayers--that the complex problems involved in the deadlocked contract negotiations will receive responsible and imaginative analysis.

Any temptation to exult over Washington's announcement that more Americans held jobs last month than ever before evaporates when one gets to the black print. It shows Negro unemployment still running at twice the white rate. Worst of all, idleness among Negro teen-agers--a group whose frustrations make them a conspicuous element in every urban riot --is astronomic. One out of four remains jobless.
The directors of the Nor wich Pharmacal Company voted yesterday to split the company's common stock 2for-1, subject to shareholder approval at a meeting to be held Sept. 28.
The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday ordered a modification in its decision requiring the Norfolk Western Railway Company to acquire control of three smaller Eastern railroads.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 96.6 on Fri day from 96.5 on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)--A witness supporting an interest disclosure bill said today that because credit charges were sometimes so unfairly high installment records in credit stores were a prime target for destruction by rioters this summer.

The General Services Administration said yesterday it planned to offer 2,331,000 troy ounces of silver to commercial users at its weekly competitive bidding, scheduled for Friday. The total includes 331,000 troy ounces carried over from previous offerings.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 14--Most of the gems stolen from a statue of the Virgin Mary in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem on Aug. 2 were recovered today in a carpentry shop here. Three persons were arrested.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--The Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP)--A total of 87 horses of racing age, many in recent competition, were sold today by the Fasig-Tipton Company, horse auctioneers, for a combined $298,800, an average of $3,434 for each sale.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., Aug. 14 (AP)--Bjorn Ferm of Sweden clung to the lead today in the United States modern pentathlon championships but a strong swimming performance by Don Walheim moved him into second place.
DETROIT, Aug. 14--A Michigan state trooper testified today that he believed the police were "out of control" during a raid on a Detroit motel in which three Negroes were killed.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP)--Peggy Conley, a 20-yearold Spokane, Wash., golfer, took a one-stroke lead today in the first qualifying round for the 67th United States Golf Association women's amatuer golf championship at the Annandale Golf Club. She carded a 39, 3574, two strokes over par.

A MOST unusual opportunity to insure the success of a contract arose on the diagrammed deal during the Summer National Championships in Montreal. The winning maneuver for South was not a play of any kind: he was offered a choice by the laws of the game and selected the wrong option.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 14--Israel has carefully limited the role of the personal representative Secretary General Thant will send to Israel to report to him on the situation in Jerusalem, informed sources said today.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 14-- Three skippers from the host Monmouth Boat Club--Jon Schwartz in the Blue Jay Class, Pris Gale in the Wood Pussies and Dave Allen in the Lightnings--led their classes after today's opening races of the ninth national junior sweepstakes regatta on the Navesink River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a temporary suspension of overthe-counter trading in the common stock of the Coditron Corporation of New York City through Aug. 23.

The heavy social, medical, judicial and criminal burden that protitution places on the community is underscored in this week's survey by Times reporter J. Anthony Lukas. The women trapped in vice pass through an eternally revolving door of courts and jails--a cycle of such pointlessness that the revised New York State Criminal Code, when it takes effect Sept. 1, will reduce the maximum penalty for prostitution from 1 year to fifteen days.
Steel production gained sharply last week for the fifth week in succession, suggesting that the predicted order recovery by September was developing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The number of persons living in poverty has fallen below 30 million, the Census Bureau reported today. It said 41 per cent of the nonwhite population was poor and 12 per cent of the white ponulation was poor. The new figure is 29.7 million.
THREDBO, Australia, Aug. 14 (UPI)--Bernard Orcel of France beat Jim Heuga of Tahoe, Calif., today in the first leg of the Thredbo Cup slalom race.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP)--Jim Fregosi's two-base error on a routine grounder in the eighth inning opened the way for Minnesota to score two runs tonight and the Twins beat the California Angels, 2-l.

A sailor who was rescued after clinging for three days to wreckage in the Atlantic off Cape Hatteras, N.C., reported last night that four companions on a yacht were missing after the craft sank Friday.
A Brooklyn father of eight was stabbed to death early yesterday morning in a street-corner argument.
LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 15 --A short but colorful era came to a formal end for Britain at midnight when legislation took effect outlawing radio pirates and their nonstop pop.
One workman was killed and another critically injured yesterday afternoon when they fell four stories from a scaffold onto crowded 57th Street, just off Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Navy is intensifying a search for an unmanned ship, loaded with 2,000 tons of explosives, that was supposed to have been blown up in a test but instead as lost in a fog off Alaska last Thursday.
The Treasury spelled out yesterday for the first time the demands it expects to make on the money and capital markets for the fiscal year ending next June 30.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 14 (UPI) --A Lincoln, N.H., youth was killed and two girls, including the daughter of the director of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, were injured last night when vandals threw waterfilled containers through the windshield of their car.
Giftware buyers from department, and specialty stores, in New York this week for their semiannual buying trip, are looking hopefully toward the Christmas season.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 14--Congolese mobs sacked the Belgian Embassy and beat whites in the capital of Kinshasa today until President Joseph D. Mobutu personally intervened, the Belgian Foreign Ministry reported.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 14 (AP)--The city of Fairbanks and the community of Nenana, 50 miles southwest of here, were both declared disaster areas by Gov. Walter J. Hickel today as drenching rains brought rivers in central Alaska over flood stage.

The appointment of Dr. Harry J. Watters as vice president and general manager of the TRG division of the Control Data Corporation, was announced yesterday by William C. Norris, chairman and president of the company.

The Allied Products Corporation, which is actively seeking to diversify its operations through merger or acquisition, disclosed plans yesterday to acquire the closely held Loadcraft, Inc., through-an exchange of stock worth more than $25million.
A husky, cheerful man, stripped to the waist, stood on the Bryant Park lawn yesterday morning helping to set up a poster display by leading American artists.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14 (AP)--Jordan delivered to Israel today the first applications for more than 20,000 refugees to return to their homes in Israeli-occupied territory.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 14--Miss Marjorie Diane Jacobson and Mark E. Gershwind plan to marry next July 3.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) --Alvin A. Spivak of United Press International became director of information today for President Johnson's Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders.

ALBANY, Aug. 14--Committees of the Constitutional Convention, working against a midnight deadline, today recommended a conservation bill of rights to protect the state's natural resources but discarded proposed constitutional protection for public power programs.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Production of new cars picked up tempo last week as 1968 models started to come off assembly lined in increasing numbers. The pace is expected to quicken this week.

Six male patients, escaped from a treatment center for drug addicts in Yonkers and several women patients set small fires in a similar center in Manhattan in separate incidents last night.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday referred back to a district court a dispute over the control of S.H. Kress Co., the varietystore chain acquired four years ago by Genesco, Inc.
The slump in wheat prices continued yesterday, after a day's respite on Friday, and all contracts fell sufficiently to made new lifetime lows.

There was nothing really startling about Roquepine, Graianella and Real Speed getting the one, two and three post positions for Saturday night's $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway at a drawing yesterday, during breakfast at Reuben's restaurant. But most of the people on hand were surprised that the horses for the first three posts were "known" in advance by a selfdescribed "mentalist" named Kreskin.
To tourists walking past the flashing lights of West 42d Street they're just facades on all-night movie houses. But to Joseph Fitzula, each is a house of beautiful memories.
Alan S. Boyd, Secretary of Transportation, took a major step yesterday in the field of maritime operations, an area in which his agency's powers are a matter of dispute.

SARATOGA, Calif., Aug. 14 --Miss Karen Koenig, daughter of Capt. Joseph William Koenig, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Koenig, was married this afternoon to Lieut. Craig Stephen Sim, U.S.M.C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Craig Sim of Garden City,

The National Bank of Northern New York in upstate Watertown an announced yesterday that it had been holding "conversations" recently with the Bank of New York and the County Trust Company of White Plains about possible inclusion in the statewide bank holding company the two banks are now organizing.
Thomas Colman Christian sat in a hotel lounge here yesterday, describing how the descendants of the H.M.S. Bounty mutineers were making out on Pitcairn Island.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 14 --Prof. and Mrs. Walter A. Rosenblith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Rosenblith, to Sheldon L. Baskin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Baskin of Highland Park, Ill. A Sept. 9 wedding is planned.

Volume on New York's foreign exchange market yesterday was "less than moderate," with sterling wavering from a low of $2.7844 to a high for the day of $2.7850 and closing at $2.7849. In final spot quotations last week, the pound was at $2.7847.
"I NEVER go to the store in shorts or slacks un- less it's raining or cold and never with rollers in my hair," vouched Mrs. Russell B. Funkhouser Jr. of Stamford, Conn. "It's a matter of self-pride."
TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 14 (AP)--"Without you, golf would not be what it is today," Ben Hogan wrote to Walter Hagen. "I give you my deep thanks."
In March, 1936, Lucky Luciano--described as New York's "vice czar"--went or trial for running the biggest prostitution racket the city had ever seen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14-- Lewis Gouverneur Morris, a former trustee of the Museum of the City of New York, died today at his home, Malbone, after a long illness. He was 85 years old and maintained a residence at 1510 Park Avenue, New York.

Anticipating record payouts for riot damages around the nation, the property-insurance industry has approached the Federal Government for "cooperation to assure the continued availability of insurance in riot-prone areas."
Harry Rudolph, the president of the Eastern Basketball League, said yesterday that any player who jumped to another league would be barred for life from the Eastern circuit.
A special committee of the Episcopal Church termed the concept of heresy "anachronistic" yesterday and called for a "drastic revision of canon law" to make heresy trials almost impossible.

REPORTER: Excuse me for interrupting your midsummer siesta, Dr. Critic, but the public would like to know what, in your`opinion, will be the outstanding books coming out this fall. Can you tell us how the season shapes up, from where you sit now?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--A tax increase is essential to slow a threatened runaway expansion of the economy, three top Administration officials told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--Political leaders here are in general agreement that President Johnson's re-election prospects have been seriously damaged by the summer's urban race riots, but some of them are puzzled by the President's response. From the evidence so far, Mr. Johnson is avoiding any imme-...

WEST GLACIER, Mont., Aug. 14 (AP)--"Michele, get out of your bag, run, climb a tree." "Oh, my God, I'm dead." That was the way Paul R. Dunn, remembered the grizzly bear attack that killed 19-yearold Michele Koons of San Diego, Calif., in Glacier National Park yesterday.
HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 14 (UPI)--The Philadelphia Eagles announced today that they had obtained a defensive back, Jim Kearney, from the Detroit Lions.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14-- The man who started the Mets' downward spiral in the first game they ever played more than five years ago, and who hadn't lost to them since, finally got his come-uppance tonight.

Dr. Herbert Needleman, chairman of a national committee that has sought to bring injured Vietnamese children to the United States for medical treatment, said yesterday that he and a colleague returned from Saigon last Wednesday after having been thwarted in their efforts by South Vietnamese governmental red tape.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14--Roger Tuckerman, a special partner in the Wall Street brokerage firm of Wood, Walker Co., died today in Southampton Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 123 Main Street in Farmington, Conn.
PAINESVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 14--Miss Carol Jane Baker and Thomas Steele Darnall Jr., son of Mrs. Darnall of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mr. Darnall, plan to marry here Sep. 30.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 14 (AP)--The United States Government dismissed a charge of fishing inside the 12-mile territorial limit against a Russian trawler captain, Daniel Baronik, in United States District Court today.

GENEVA, Aug. 14--The police in Lucerne today seized a collection of more than 100 paintings attributed to Van Gogh, Cezanne and other French impressionists that had been condemned as fakes by the Swiss art dealers association and other authorities.

BUFFALO, Aug. 14--The engagement of Miss Martha Lake Marcy to Dr. Rowland Richards Jr. has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. George H. Marcy. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. John Edwin Burri of Laguna Beach, Calif., and the late Dr. Richards. A Dec. 23 wedding is planned.
ALBANY, Aug. 14--Stricter controls on wiretapping and abolition of the constitutional restrictions on gambling were voted out of committee tonight to the floor of the Constitutional Convention.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 14.--Prime Minister Forbes Burnham called on delegates from 11 Caribbean countries today to take prompt action to integrate the region's economy.
For the first half of the year, the Ladies' Home Journal stands No. 1 among mass circulation women's magazines.

A major battle for control of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company began taking shape yesterday when Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., proposed to acquire all of the big machinery manufacturer's outstanding stock.

SKOPJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14--Bobby Fischer of New York, the 24-year-old United States chess champion, extended his winning streak to four when he defeated Yugoslav candidate master Vasil Panov in the sixth round of the Tournament of Solidarity here last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14-- With the balance of power in the State Senate at stake, San Francisco voters go to the polls in a special election tomorrow.

GENEVA, Aug. 14--The United States and the Soviet Union, having agreed to disagree on the inspection provisions of a proposed treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, were reported to have made progress today in their efforts to achieve an acceptable wording of the other articles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) --A weekly newspaper publisher from Montana, a Chicago economist and a New York professor today urged Senate rejection of the Failing Newspaper Bill.
The Household Finance Corporation reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for the three and six months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) --A British freighter bound from Communist China to Cuba has been permitted to enter Honolulu Harbor for emergency repairs, a Government spokesman said today.
The stock market went through another broad retreat yesterday.

The Williamsburgh Savings Bank in Brooklyn and the Central Savings Bank in Manhattan have abruptly called off their proposed merger. The combination would have created an institution with almost $2-billion in assets.

COLD buffets and barbecues are summertime fa vorites, but the addition of a hot casserole will increase the appetite appeal. Here are recipes for casseroles that can be prepared early in the day and baked, if desired, just before serving. In that case, cooking time should be increased slightly to allow for warming the dish taken directly from the refrigerator.
ATLANTA, Aug. 14 (UPI)-- Gov. George Romney tonight urged the Southern Christian Leadership Conference to oppose black nationalism.

To avert riots like the recent ones in Detroit, Newark and other cities, big majorities of Negroes and whites agreed in a poll on the need for new Federal programs to undertake large-scale works projects for the unemployed, to tear down ghettos, to exterminate rats and to set up summer camps. The survey by Louis Harris was published in yesterday's Washington Post.

Of the more than 500,000 people who saw at least one of the films at the Moscow Film Festival last month, 325,000 saw features entered by American film, companies, according to Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) --The National Academy of Sciences said today that it was joining British scientists in protesting a proposal to establish a British military airfield on Aldabra Island in the Indian Ocean --an island rated by the academy as a "biological treasure house" of bird and plant life.

Frank E. McKeown, executive assistant to the president of the Real Estate Borad of New York, died Sunday at the Lutheran Medical Center. Mr. McKeown, who lived at 19180th Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, was 64 years old.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14-- For the third time of the summer there was a drawing today for pairings matching the four 12-Meter yachts that aspire to become the defender of the America's Cup and the last was the one that counted most. The outcome was that Intrepid will square off against Constellation and American Eagle will oppose Columbia for the beginning of the final selection trials tomorrow.
The mail-fraud conspiracy trial of Louis E. Wolfson and Eilur B. Gerbert, Florida financiers, was scheduled yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri for Sept. 6.
Columbia University's medical school, the first in the United States to award the degree of doctor of medicine, marked its 200th anniversary yesterday.

ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., Aug. 14--Mr. and Mrs. Philip Matlick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Anne Matlick, to Michael Rosin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rosen of Woodbridg, Conn.

"La-goon-ah! Camp-ay-on!" "La-goon-ah! Camp-ay-on!" Ismael Laguna, the man of the moment in every Panamanian heart, marched yesterday afternoon at the center of an affectionate cluster of his countrymen who rhythmically proclaimed Laguna the champion.

Conjugal visits for married inmates of the Mississippi State Penitentiary have probably kept marriages intact and have probably bolstered morale, and reduced recidivism and homosexuality, according to an article in the June issue of the Criminal Law Bulletin.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14--The militant Buddhist faction of South Vietnam accused the Government today of trying to suppress and destroy Buddhism.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 14--"I couldn't believe her last race, and that's why I put her in this stakes," said Johnny Nerud after the running of the $26,100 Adirondack today. Nerud's comment was prompted by the surprise performance turned in by Joseph Roebling's Wildwook, a filly trained by Nerud.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 14 . -- The marriage of Miss Patricia Hope Jenkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall Jenkins, to Patrick Michael Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Martin of Teheran, Iran, took place here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 --Federal health, officials testified today that some color television sets in addition to a number made by the General Electric Company "could generate excessive radiation" in some circumstances.

MONTREAL, Aug. 14--The most interesting opera in the Bolshoi's traveling repertory was presented last night at the Salle Wilfrid Pelletier. That was RimskyKorsakov's. "The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh." Its interest lies in its rarity to Western ears. This was its first performance outside the Soviet Union; and even there it was unknown until recent years.
The appointment of Frank T. Horan as manager of shipyard modernization at the Quincy (Mass.) Division of General Dynamics was announced yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 14 --Two teen-aged girls were seen in a 1959 or 1960 darkcolored Chevrolet sedan shortly before they were strangled, and the car was "at the scene of the crime at about 2:30 A.M. Friday," the district attorney said today.
IN the role of Mame Dennis Burnside, Celeste Holm is (a) better than Angela Lansbury, (b) not so good, (c) about the same, (d) none of the above.

Senator Mansfield is not the only international expert who believes United Nations machinery might be used to bring an end to the Vietnam war. Sir Alec Douglas-Home, Britain's former Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary, has come up with a suggestion which Secretary General Thant might consider once South Vietnam's elections are over.

CLEVELAND, Aug.14 (UPI)-- Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., twisted her back in the first set, but gamely fought her way to a 3-6, 8-6, 6-2 victory over Virginia Wade of Britain today in the clinching Wightman Cup match for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--The International Union of Electrical Workers today ordered locals in its big New York-New Jersey district to vote on removal of two top officers. The union's trustees called for the votes after a majority of locals representing nearly 60 per cent of the district's members signed petitions requesting the step.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 14--Foreign Minister Abba Eban tonight rejected third-party mediation in the dispute between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- United States officials expressed concern today over the implications of the attack on the Belgian Embassy in Kinshasa this morning by a Congolese mob.

When a front wheel of Earl Lerner's Volkswagen bus collapsed on the Van Wyck Expressway yesterday, he walked to a nearby telephone, asked for help from the roadway's authorized towing service and went back toward his van. But it wasn't there.
The Philippa Schuyler Memorial Foundation announced yesterday a "Winning the Peace" program that is to help Vietnamese people on an individual basis.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 14 --Prof. John K. Fairbank, Harvard's foremost China specialist, declared today that the war in Vietnam has caught American universities totally unprepared.
PARIS, Aug. 14--Manuel Prado Ugarteche, twice President of Peru, died of a heart attack in a hospital tonight. He was 78 years old.
A conservation group yesterday challenged the Consolidated Edison Company's figures on the cost of building an alternative to its proposed hydroelectric project on Storm King Mountain.

The city could nearly fill Shea Stadium with people whose applications for Medicaid have not yet been processed. A.F. Moncure, deputy commissioner of the Department of Social Services, said yesterday that the department was six weeks and at least 45,000 forms behind in processing applications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14-- The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff warned Congress today that deep cuts in foreign military, aid and restrictions on arms credit sales were an invitation to increased subversion and open aggression by the Soviet Union and Communist China.

HOLDEN, La., Aug. 15 (AP) --Some 15 white men attacked 20 Negro civil rights marchers in this little town today, touching off a brief melee in which a deputy sheriff and several Negroes were knocked down.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 15-Mrs. Petterson Morgan has made known the marriage of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Macready, to Carlos Guerrero, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carlos D. Guerrero of Mexico City and Acapulco. The civil ceremony took place in Mexico City on Saturday.
Delinquencies and foreclosures of home mortgages dropped sharply in the three months ended June 30, the quarterly survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America has shown.
The New York City school system has developed over the years a virtuosity in neutralizing all criticism of its flaws.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 15--The wheelchair could not get through the door, and Maurice Stokes had to be lifted out so the chair could be folded and then moved. Three men, including Jack Twyman, picked up Stokes, and it was a job because Stokes weighs 250 pounds.

A merger agreement in principle was reached yesterday by directors of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and the Northern Ohio Telephone Company for an exchange of stock valued at close to $145million.
DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 15-- The city's vice mayor today, defeated a Negro woman lawyer in Virginia's first primary runoff election for nomination to a state legislative seat.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Aug. 15--Stuart W. Cleaveland, president and treasurer of the W. W. Mertz Company, a department store here, died Saturday of a heart attack in Charlotte Hungerford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 70 Ridgebrook Road.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 15 (UPI)--Gov. George Romney said today that he thought American involvement in Vietname was a "tragic" mistake. The massive military buildup there may threaten the future of "the whole of Southeast Asia." he said.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15--Just before the feature race today Harold Polk, the owner of Jim J., rebuffed a prospective buyer by placing a price of more than $137,500 on his colt, a steady going performer trained by Eddie Yowell.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug 16--Saigon and its sister city of Cholon were still without electricity at 11 A.M. today, 14 hours after the start of a power failure.
"You're an important man," Joe Perrone, a South Brooklyn teen-ager, said to Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello, "but how do we know that talking to you will do any good?"
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Personal income rose strongly in July for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.
A physician who billed Medicaid for an average of 65 house calls daily has been examining every member of the families of patients he visits whether they were sick or not.

Alton F. Cook, motion-picture critic for The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, died yesterday at his home, 72-15 37th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens. Mr. Cook, who was 62 years old, had been in poor health in recent years and had undergone four cancer operations.
WANTAGH, L.I., Aug. 15 --The Long Island State Park Commission increased its "safety patrols" today at three beaches where 325 lifeguards have been on strike since Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) --The Senate poverty subcommittee approved a $2.2-billion extension of the antipoverty program today and added to it a $3-billion emergency program to deal with jobs in the slums and riot damage.
Representative Theodore R. Kupferman, Republican of New York, will introduce a bill today that would aid such groups as the New York Fresh Air Fund to send underprivileged children to summer camps.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15--A spokesman for the ruling generals denied today as "unfounded" and "unsubstantiated" the charges that they had condoned election fraud and the harassment of their opponents' campaigns.
JASPER, Ala., Aug. 15 (AP)-- Capital charges have been filed against five men in the terrorizing of three families by hooded, robed nightriders.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 15--Belgium charged the Congolese authorities today with direct responsibility for the sacking of the Belgian Embassy in Kinshasa yesterday and instructed Ambassador Paul Bihin to demand "concrete steps" toward an improvement of the situation.

NEWARK, Aug. 15--Two Bergen County ministers and a housewife yesterday attacked a state law that makes it a crime to advocate--in a public place of at a metting attended by more than five persons--that citizens should not serve in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The House Post Office Committee voted today to raise the cost of mailing a first-class letter from five cents to six. It also voted to raise the cost of mailing a postcard from four cents to five.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee recessed hearings indefinitely today after hearing a proposed bill for failing newspapers praised as a life preserver for local editorial competition and damned as anew bulwark for monopoly.
Bishop A. Raymond Grant of the Portland (Ore.) District of the Methodist Church, which takes in Oregon, Idaho and Alaska, died yesterday of cancer in Portland. He was 69 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 15--A National Guard man testified today that he saw a Detroit po lice officer take a Negro into a hotel room during Detroit's lot last month and then heard shot and possibly the thud of falling body.

A Senate majority has struck a timely blow at the shadowy procedure under which the Defense Department has guaranteed loans from Export-Import Bank funds for arms sales to underdeveloped countries. Other voting tests loom on this issue, but it is an encouraging start that 46 Senators backed the Foreign Relations Committee's effort to curb the Pentagon arms salesmen.
STAMFORD, Conn.--"It is very big for a house and very small for a castle," said a little boy who was visiting the David H. Cogans' house here a while ago.
SAN FRANCISCO., Aug. 15 (AP)--The San Francisco Mining Exchange, born in the gold rush days, announced today that it would go out of business at the close of the day's transactions.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 15 --Thousands of people were trapped on roofs and upper floors of larger buildings in this flood-stricken city tonight, and several fires raged out of control.
The problem of illegally parked cars in Manhattan has become so acute that Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary is considering recruiting civilians to assist the men in uniform.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15-- Ray Ruffels of Australia, the runner-up at Southampton yesterday, was beaten in the first round of the Hall of Fame tennis tournament at the Newport Casino today. Mark Cox of Britain also was eliminated.

Sixteen of the 172 vessels mobilized from the nation's reserve fleet for service in the Vietnam sealift are being shunted from active status to semiretirement, the Department of Defense has annnunced.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15--Secretary General Thant announced today that he had appointed Dr. Ernesto A. Thalmann of Switzerland as his personal representative to study conditions in Jerusalem under Israeli rule. Dr. Thalmann is to report on his mission within two weeks. He is scheduled to arrive in Jerusalem Monday.

ALPINE, N. J., Aug. 15Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Bailey have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Anne Bailey, to Lieut. Richard Burton Adams, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Renard P. Adams of Buffalo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15--At 12:22 this afternoon, after nearly an hour and a half of musicmaking, flag-raising, anthemsinging, praying, speech-making, poetry-reciting, and telegram-reading in Civic Center Plaza, a white ribbon was pulled and, as planned, 12,000 square feet of blue percale fell from the 50 feet and 163 tons of steel called the Chicago Picasso.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Democratic and Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee warned the Johnson Administration today that it had not successfully made its case for a 10 per cent tax surcharge on individuals and corporations.
The story goes that a British correspondent was interviewing youngsters in a Negro slum in Chicago.

The Office of Economic Opportunity announced here last night that it had approved the use of five summer camps that had been proposed to it by the United Community Corporation of Newark.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 15--The marriage of Miss Judy Cecile Jacobs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Leonard Jacobs, to Richard James Monaco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Monaco of Yonkers, took place this evening at the Jacobs home. Rabbi Michael Robinson performed the cremeony.

ALBANY, Aug. 15--The Constitutional Convention, plunging into its most emotional issue, rejected tonight an effort to carry over into a new state constitution the 73-year-old prohibition against state financial aid to church-connected schools.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPI)-- Rick Monday's three-run homer lifted the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight in the second game of a double-header after Rocky Colavito's threerun homer paced Chicago to a 4-2 triumph.

Two Negro sisters--a welfare supervisor and a registered nurse--are still "camping out" among packing boxes and crates after trying for nearly three years' to buy a house in an all-white neighborhood in Brooklyn.

BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP)-- The chairman of a joint state legislative committee on penal institutions called the Erie County Jail a "breeding ground for the penitentiaries of tomorrow" during a tour of the institution today.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug.15 --Eugene V. Gedney of 33 Pinecliff Road, Chappaqua, a former president of the New York State Cemetery Association and a leader in Westchester County civic and educational organizations, died of a circulatory failure last night in Northern Westchester Hospital here. He was 62 years old.
ALBANY, Aug. 15--The state reported today that only 4.1 million lottery tickets were sold in July, a drop of more than 2.3 million from the June sales.
Loy Durant Thompson, a former senior vice president and director of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, died yesterday in his home in Naples, Fla. His age was 58.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Three young Israelis, charged with stealing a gold halo from a statue of the Virgin Mary in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in the Old City of Jerusalem on Aug. 2, were remanded in custody for 15 days by a Magistrate's Court here today.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 15-- Eight conservation organizations demanded today that the Consolidated Edison Company build an underground 21-mile high-voltage transmission line from Millwood to Yonkers.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Aug. 16--The Mets, of all people, lost a double-header to the Phillies that started at 6:05 last night and ended at 5 minutes to 1 this morning.

GRIMSBY, England--Almost all foreign fishing vessels scheduled to land at Grimsby one day were diverted to their home ports by radio because of a ban on foreign-caught cod imposed by local trawler owners.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to revive the activities of the Subversive Activities Control Board rather than abolish the agency.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 15--This ancient land marked today its 20th anniversary as an independent modern state in a mood of gloom and self-doubt relieved by only the faintest rays of hope and pride.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Rayonier, Inc., reached agreement yesterday on terms for a merger. Word that I.T.T. was considering entering the chemical field through an association with Rayonier was made known last Sunday.
LONDON, Aug. 15--Dozens of stage stars were among more than 1,000 people who attended a memorial service today for Vivien Leigh, the actress, who died on July 8 at the age of 53.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 15-- Nigerian officials moved today to curb outbreaks of violence against members of the Ibo tribe in Lagos and in Ibadan, capital of the Western Region, 80 miles by road north of this fedaral capital.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15--If there was nothing more to see than what Columbia and Intrepid showed today at the start of the final trials to pick an America's Cup defender, the two yachts could be paired off tomorrow for a show-down match series to meet Australia.
ROME, Aug. 15--Pope Paul VI spoke in melancholy terms today of man's efforts to establish peace.

When President Johnson proposed his civil rights bill last year, Title V was intended primarily to protect civil rights workers in the South against violence. The House approved that title with relatively little controversy, but it foundered along with the rest of the bill in the subsequent Senate filibuster against the "open housing" section. Now the old Title V is before the House as a separate measure.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15-- With expected arrival tomorrow of Oscar R.L from Paris and Fresh Yankee of Canada from Brandywine Raceway of Wilmington, Del., the entire field of nine for Saturday night's $100,000 International Trot will be on the grounds at Roosevelt Raceway, the site of the ninth annual event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Joan Baez, the pacifist folk singer, said today she had no argument with the Daughters of the American Revolution, despite the organization's refusal to let her use its Constitution Hall for a concert.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP)--The New York Giants of the National Football League, already weakened by injuries in the defensive line, had another casualty today when their defensive end and captain, Jim Katcavage, fractured an index finger.

For the third time in three days fire broke out yesterday in the state's Manhattan Rehabilitation Center for women narcotics users. Six staff members were taken to Polyclinic Hospital for treatment for possible smoke inhalation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., the Marine Corps Commandant, said today that the Marines could use more combat troops in Vietnam but that the White House had decided not to mobilize the reserve Fourth Marine Division and Air Wing.

ATLANTA, Aug. 15--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that he planned to "dislocate" Northern cities with massive but nonviolent demonstrations of civil disobedience before Congress adjourns its current session.

WEST GLACIER, Mont., Aug. 15--National Park Service rangers shot and killed two grizzly bears last night that may have been responsible for the attacks on Sunday that killed two girls and injured a young men seriously.
LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 15 (UPI)--Brian London, the former British heavyweight boxing champion, outpointed James Woody of New York tonight in a 10-round bout at Liverpool Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) --A constitutional amendment designed to strip Stokely Carmichael, militant Negro civil rights leader, of his citizenship was proposed today by Representative Joe Pool, Democrat of Texas.
LONDON, Aug. 15--Britain, trying to reverse what the Government argues is an undeserved lack of confidence in the pound, issued a cheery sounding assessment today.

YONKERS, Aug. 15--The William Jacobs family, which has been living on relief in a $600-a-month motel at taxpayers' expense, was offered a nine-room house, with a big yard today. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15-- Bobby Riggs, Bill Talbert, Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont and Mrs. Louise Brough Clapp have been voted into the national Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame here.

The former superintendent of real estate for the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philip F. Kennedy Jr., has been named a vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., in an expansion of the company's executive and consultine staff.

A 429-foot tanker torpedoed off the New Jersey Coast on March 10, 1942, was ruled out by Coast Guard yesterday as a source of oil pollution for Jersey coast beaches.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (UPI)-- Julian Javier's two-run triple sparked a five-run sixth inning tonight that enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to beat the Chicago Cubs, 6-4. The triumph stretched the Cards' National League lead to 10 games.

LONDON, Aug. 15--Earl Stanhope, controversial First Lord of the Admiralty at the start of World War II, died today at his home, Chevening Manor in Kent. He was 86 years old.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 (UPI)--Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., led an advance by the seeded players in the 40th Essex women's invitation tennis tournament today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15--A group of New Left activists announced a campaign today to get a slate of candidates on the California ballot next year, including a still undetermined choice for president.

Interest rates moved in different directions yesterday. Tax-exempt bond rates rose and corporate bond rates hoveyed at their highs of the summer, but several short-term, rates moved downward.

Paperboard production rose 2.4 per cent with 454,700 tons in the week ended Aug. 12, compared with the level in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Institute of the American Paperboard Institute reported yesterday.

The election of Drummond C. Bell, National Distillers and Chemical Corporation vicepresident, as president and chief executive officer of the Beacon Manufacturing Company, was announced yesterday. Beacon manufactures textile products and is partly owned by National.

Three out of five wheat contracts, all five corn contracts, and three out of six soybean contracts sold at life-of-contract lows during trading yesterday, continuing the long and sharp price declines of the three basic crops.

The New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles revived their old house-wrecking talents at Yankee Stadium last night in 4 hours of tumult that the Orioles finally won in the 13th inning, 11-10.
Prices advanced along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 --Three golfing chums won the top honors today in the Metropolitan sectional qualifying for the United States Amateur championship.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday that it would attempt to intervene as a "friend of the court" in a lawsuit brought by a group of Minnesota data-processing companies seeking to prevent a St. Paul bank from selling computer services to the public.

Mitchell Sviridoff, whom Mayor Lindsay considered one of the principal men in his administration, has resigned as head of the city's Human Resources Administration, effective at the end of the year.

CRANFORD, N.J., Aug. 15 --Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Ferguson Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan E. Ferguson, to O. Cooper Winston Jr., son of Oliver C. Winston of Ithaca, N.Y., and Mrs. Morton E. Rome of Baltimore.

A man who said he was trying to raise money to overthrow Premier Fidel Cstro of Cuba pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court here to counterfeiting charges.

THERE is a soccer stadium in Brazil with a moat between the stands and the playing field. The moat serves as an automatic deterrent to emotionally overwrought customers with homicidal tendencies. It prevents them from swarming onto the field to dismember officials or players. Latins have been known to take their sports with what amounts to a blind and hysterical ardor.

On the fourth floor they are building a bullring. On the fifth floor they are patching massive branches that belong to a life-sized tree (its roots are on the ground floor). And three levels below the ground they are simply building another floor.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 15--The Minister of Labor, Yigal Allon, has proposed that Israel establish paramilitary settlements on the Syrian Heights, in the Jordan Valley and in the southern part of the Gaza Strip, in areas occupied by the Israelis in the war with the Arabs in June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 --President Johnson and Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger agreed today that there would be full consultation among the allies before any decisions were made on reducing or redeploying American or West German military forces in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The House began debate today on a long pending bill that would extend legal protection from intimidation and violence to persons exercising their civil rights.
NEWARK, Aug. 15--The riots here last month cost $10,251,200 in business damages, almost one-fifth of this in looted liquor, the city's Office of Economic Development reported today.

All three defendants in a Securities and Exchange Commission suit involving Interamerican Industries, Ltd., consented yesterday in Federal District Court here to the commission's request for a preliminary injunction against them.

TRENTON, Aug. 15--The establishment of the New Jersey Urban Education Corps to bring the "Peace Corps spirit" into Newark and other decaying school systems of the state's cities was announced here today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 (UPI)--United States B-52's bombed North Vietnamese forces today in three high-altitude raids along the southern border of North Vietnam.
The stock market rallied for three hours yesterday and then lost most of its gains in the last hour of trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The Soviet Union has added titanium, a light, tough metal used in the production of airplanes, to the list of rare and strategic materials exported to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, lodged his first public complaint today about child welfare restrictions in the pending Social Security bill.

New York's pier rebuilding program has virtually haited and the construction industry is threatened with curtailment because a sudden strict inter pretation of the air pollution control law has prevented the burning of waste timber, ac cording to city officials.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP)--Jim Perry pitched a sixhitter tonight as Minnesota, the American League leader, extended its winning streak to six games with a 4-0 victory over the California Angels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Government agencies now agree that the number of persons living in a poverty income bracket is 29.7 million, as announced by the Census Bureau yesterday for 1966.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 15--Kenneth B. Halstead, general solicitor of the United States Steel Corporation from 1923 until his retirement at the end of 1945, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived on Old Stone Hill Road, Pound Ridge.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP)--A world record price for a thoroughbred sold at auction was set tonight at the Saratoga sales ring when A.B. (Bull) Hancock Jr. of Lexington, Ky., paid $365,000 for Quill, a brood mare.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company rewarded 82 years of service yesterday by naming John F. Cooper and Robert F. Cronan vice presidents of the bank.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)--The Navy has dropped a number of depth charges from low-flying aircraft in an unsuccessful effort to detonate a cargo of 2,000 tons of explosives that sank in Alaskan waters last Thursday.
The New York Shakespeare Festival has eliminated the mobile tour of "Volpone" in Spanish and streamlined the fall production of "Hamlet" for the schools.
NEWARK, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Shareholders of the General Instrument Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., approved today a merger of the two companies.
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., made a common stock offering yesterday in the third of three subsidiaries it formed from Wilson Co. Investors bid the shares up more than $8 from the offering price.
Avis, Inc., the car rental concern, under pressure from the Chicago police department, has reluctantly abandoned an advertising campaign in that city.
TOKYO, Aug. 15--At a service today commemorating the end of World War II 22 years ago, an elderly Japanese in a kimono snapped pictures of Emperor Hirohito through a telephoto lens.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Reggie Smith, George Scott and Carl Yastrzemski hit home runs and Dave Morehead pitched a six-hitter as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4-0 tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- A member of the Senate Banking Committee sought to prove today that it is possible to pick a portfolio of stocks that would do better than most mutual funds simply by throwing darts at the New York Stock Exchange list.
DETROIT, Aug. 15--A split within the United Automobile Workers appeared to widen today as the union demoted one of the leaders of its skilled workers.
Cinerama, Inc., the company that owns the big-screen filming process, embarked yesterday on an expansion program designed to cure the ills that have plagued the concern during most of its life.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 15--William P. Bundy, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, said today that the prospects for a "peaceful and secure Southeast Asia now appear brighter", than at any time in recent years.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will throb to jazz music for the first time on Oct. 7 Mayor Lindsay has picked that date to be Jazz Day in the Cultural Showcase Fortnight Oct. 1 to 15. A concert will be held in the Museum's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium to end the day.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 16 --Brig. Gen. Francis K. Newcomer, U.S.A., retired, a former Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, died here today at the age of 77.

The Rev. John Courtney Murray, the Jesuit theologian generally credited with having been the major author of the decree favoring religious liberty passed by the Ecumenical Council, Vatican II, in 1965, died yesterday afternoon apparently of a heart attack.
VICTORIA, B. C., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press)--The defending champion, Nick Weslock of Burlington, Ont., was eliminated in the first round of the Canadian amateur golf tournament today.

Buzzing and stinging throughout 15 furious rounds, Carlos Ortiz, a busy-bee of a boxer, retained his world lightweight championship last night with a unanimous decision over a grasshopper, Ismael Laguna of Panama, at peaceful Shea Stadium.

LONDON, Aug. 16--Ronan O'Rahilly, the 27-year-old owner of the last of the pirate radio stations, Radio Caroline, has continued broadcasting pop music and commercials despite a new law against such stations.
ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 16 (UPI)--The Marine Corps today withdrew its promised participation in a "Support Your Servicemen" parade scheduled here Saturday.

BONN, Aug. 16--The federal Government indicated growing concern today over an incident in which the East German police were permitted to detain and eventually extradite a West German woman from Hungary, where she had gone as a tourist.

ATHENS Aug. 16 (UPI)-- Former Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza was sentenced to five years in prison today on a charge that he held a social gathering in his suburban villa without a police permit.

NEWARK, Aug. 16 (AP)-- Almost one of every four babies born to Newark residents last year was illegitimate, according to figures released yesterday by Newark's Health Department.
PARIS, Aug. 16--The jawbone of a prehistoric ancestor of man estimated to have lived a million and a half years ago was discovered July 7 in Ethiopia, it was announced here today.

James A. Farley Jr., son of the former Postmaster General and Democratic National Chairman, was married Tuesday in Las Vegas, Nev., to Joan Loew. The ceremony was performed at the Sands Hotel by Justice of the Peace Joseph S. Pavilikowski.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) --Two members of the House ethics committee today questioned the possible effect of proposals that House members publicly disclose their sources of income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16--A plan to save the New Haven Railroad from having to end service at the end of the year was evolved at a conference here today and sent to the White House.

The senior noteholders of the bankrupt Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., Toronto, may realize a bit more recovery money, according to a report by the Montreal Trust Company, receiver and manager.

"ESCALATE in '68'" was the slogan of the recent American Fishing Tackle Manufacturers Association's annual trade show in Chicago. Judging from the tempting assortment of lures, rods, reels, boating and camping equipment displayed, however, the sub-theme could well have been "make them pine for '69. "
ALBANY, Aug. 16--Following is the vote of the Constitutional Convention tonight in repealing the state's ban against financial aid to church-supported schools.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) --The House Post Office Committee voted Today to close a loophole in postal rates affecting business mailing.
Legal actions by three baseball players to enjoin Pocket Books, Inc., from publishing their biographies were dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

Under a newly minted Lion and Unicorn symbol, a group of British manufacturers of quality merchandise will introduce their wares to American consumers this fall in a joint effort to expand their country's exports to the United States.

Four Roman Catholic bishops two of them heads of dioceses, held news conferences yesterday in South Orange, N.J., Atlanta, St. Paul and Oklahoma City to announce their endorsement of the national "Negotiation Now!" campaign and its program for attempting to end the war in Vietnam.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 16 (UPI) --Raymond W. Beringer, 38 years old, who was defeated by Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, in the 1962 primary election, was accidentally shot to death early today.

Richard J. Mulhern, president of the Boston Maine Corporation, will meet with Burt Kleiner, the head of Kleiner, Bell Co., Beverly Hills, Calif., investment banking concern, during the first week of September in New York to discuss the recent change in control of the Boston Maine.

The New York Yankees have come up with a good idea for this season's festival, which will precede Saturday's game with the pennant-conscious Minnesota Twins at the Stadium.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 16 (UPI)--Ralph Boston, the world record-holder in the long jump, led the United States track and field team to a 56-49 margin over West Germany today at the midway point of their two-day international dual meet.

In a preliminary to the Carlos Ortiz-Ismael Laguna bout at Shea Stadium last night, Frankie Narvaez, the Puerto Rican lightweight whose defeats led to two bottle-throwing demonstrations in the last two years at Madison Square Garden, scored a knockout victory.
Negotiations between the Consolidated Foods Corporation and the Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation for a possible acquisition have advanced to the point where the principals have been talking.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass.--If Samuel Chamberlain had not attended a gastronomic fair in Dijon, France, a quarter of a century ago, he might be remembered primarily as a master of etching in America.

HONG KONG, Aug. 16-- The Chinese Communist press today reopened the case of Peng Teh-huai, who challenged Mao Tse-tung's leadership in 1959. It charged that Mr. Peng's "backstage boss" was the chief of state, Liu Shaochi.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Aug. 16--South Vietnam's civilian presidential candidates finally took their campaign to the provinces today, 10 days behind schedule.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 16-- Mrs. Mabel Keith Durfee, wife of Walter H. Durfee, retired provost and professor of mathematics at Hobart and William Smith Colleges here, died today in Geneva General Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived at 56 Park Place.

HONOLULU, Aug. 16 (AP)-- Adm. Roy L. Johnson, commander of the Pacific Fleet, denied yesterday a charge by a former Navy lieutenant that pilots were required to fly needless missions to beat the number of sorties by other carriers in Vietnam.

A sampling of reports filed as the result of a new law this year has shown that many purportedly charitable foundations are tax dodges, according to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. He said that the foundations were also sources of funds for the personal use of their directors.

TUBAS, Jordan, Aug. 19-- The trucks wind down the hill, each enveloped in a cloud of dust, until they reach the sloping river bank. Most pause for a moment, drop into a lower gear and plunge into the swift green water.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- President Johnson promised the head of the Jewish War Veterans today that the United States intended to stand firm behind its program for a Middle East settlement.

A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Shapiro of Lexington, Mass., on Aug. 8 in the Boston Lying-In Hospital. Mrs. Shapiro is the former Miss Marian Helen Kaplun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Kaplur of the Bronx.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 19. --Miss Margaret Walker Cross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Patterson Cross, was married here this evening to Channing Stowell 3d, son of Mrs. Channing Stowell Jr. of Baton Rouge and the late Lieut.-Col. Stowell Jr., U.S.A.F.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 19 --St. Paul's Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Damon, daughter, of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kent Damon, to Kevin Shore, son of John J. Shore of Worcester, Mass., and Mrs. Mary Shore of Gloucester, Mass.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19-- Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., won the United States girls lawn tennis championship for the third straight year today by defeating Vicky Rogers of Rye, N.Y., 6-1, 6-3, in the 50th annual tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 19--Teachers, lawyers, physicians, clergymen and housewives joined a group of 30 persons today who marched through the heart of the Negro south side to meet with residents and hear their grievances.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 19--Secretary General Thant said today that, in the absence of a political settlement in the Middle East, the future of more than 300,000 displaced Arabs was beset by "uncertainties and imponderables."

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 19--Seminars, speeches and informal sessions at the National Student Association congress make it clear that students across the country are demanding broad changes in what they learn and how they learn it.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19-- The 50-page blue-covered pamphlet, reading "Not printed at Government expense," was subtitled: "The Accomplishments of the First Eight Months of the Administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan."

MONTREAL. AT the first performance of the Bolshoi Opera at Expo 67, everybody was nervous. The Rus sians were understandably nervous. It was their first trip to the Western Hemisphere, and they wanted everything to be right.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19-- Miss Karen Gail Love and Stewart Cooler, who attend the University of Bridgeport, have become engaged. Mr. and Mrs. Alan Love have announced their daughter's betrothal to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Cooler of Bronxville, N.Y.A February wedding is planned.

EASTON, Pa., Aug. 19--Miss Anne Hugh Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hugh Kennedy, was married this afternoon to John Gordon Turnbull, son of Mrs. J. Gordon Turnbull of Los Angeles and Santa Ynez, Calif., and the late Mr. Turnbull.

MORE homeowners are seeking more lawn labor-saving products this year than ever before. Equipment manufacturers and local garden center operators agree on this, and they also agree that power tools are still the home lawnsman's favorite way to solve the problem of better turf with less work.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 --Dr. Thomas Kantor of the host Cedar Point Yacht Club retained the Atlantic Class national championship today by placing fourth with Windsong in the final race of the 38th annual regatta, sailed on Long Island Sound.

The Staten Island Cricket Club and the Commonwealth C.C. of Washington, played to a draw at Walker Park in Staten Island yesterday. Staten Island had 70 runs and British Commonwealth, 24 for 3 wickets.
